('DOS CHAPTER I PART I', {'On an exceptionally hot evening early in July a young man came out of\nthe garret in which he lodged in S': 22, 'Place and walked slowly, as though\nin hesitation, towards K': 10, 'bridge': 1, 'He had successfully avoided meeting his landlady on the staircase': 10, 'His\ngarret was under the roof of a high, five-storied house and was more\nlike a cupboard than a room': 20, 'The landlady who provided him with garret,\ndinners, and attendance, lived on the floor below, and every time\nhe went out he was obliged to pass her kitchen, the door of which\ninvariably stood open': 35, 'And each time he passed, the young man had a\nsick, frightened feeling, which made him scowl and feel ashamed': 20, 'He was\nhopelessly in debt to his landlady, and was afraid of meeting her': 14, 'This was not because he was cowardly and abject, quite the contrary; but\nfor some time past he had been in an overstrained irritable condition,\nverging on hypochondria': 28, 'He had become so completely absorbed in\nhimself, and isolated from his fellows that he dreaded meeting, not\nonly his landlady, but anyone at all': 25, 'He was crushed by poverty, but the\nanxieties of his position had of late ceased to weigh upon him': 19, 'He had\ngiven up attending to matters of practical importance; he had lost all\ndesire to do so': 18, 'Nothing that any landlady could do had a real terror\nfor him': 12, 'But to be stopped on the stairs, to be forced to listen to her\ntrivial, irrelevant gossip, to pestering demands for payment, threats\nand complaints, and to rack his brains for excuses, to prevaricate, to\nlie--no, rather than that, he would creep down the stairs like a cat and\nslip out unseen': 52, 'This evening, however, on coming out into the street, he became acutely\naware of his fears': 16, '"I want to attempt a thing _like that_ and am frightened by these\ntrifles," he thought, with an odd smile': 20, '"Hm': 1, "yes, all is in a man's\nhands and he lets it all slip from cowardice, that's an axiom": 18, 'It would\nbe interesting to know what it is men are most afraid of': 14, 'Taking a new\nstep, uttering a new word is what they fear most': 13, 'But I am talking\ntoo much': 6, "It's because I chatter that I do nothing": 8, 'Or perhaps it is\nthat I chatter because I do nothing': 11, "I've learned to chatter this\nlast month, lying for days together in my den thinking": 15, 'of Jack the\nGiant-killer': 4, 'Why am I going there now': 6, 'Am I capable of _that_': 5, 'Is\n_that_ serious': 3, 'It is not serious at all': 6, "It's simply a fantasy to amuse\nmyself; a plaything": 9, 'Yes, maybe it is a plaything': 6, '"\n\nThe heat in the street was terrible: and the airlessness, the bustle\nand the plaster, scaffolding, bricks, and dust all about him, and that\nspecial Petersburg stench, so familiar to all who are unable to get out\nof town in summer--all worked painfully upon the young man\'s already\noverwrought nerves': 51, 'The insufferable stench from the pot-houses, which\nare particularly numerous in that part of the town, and the drunken men\nwhom he met continually, although it was a working day, completed\nthe revolting misery of the picture': 37, "An expression of the profoundest\ndisgust gleamed for a moment in the young man's refined face": 16, 'He was,\nby the way, exceptionally handsome, above the average in height, slim,\nwell-built, with beautiful dark eyes and dark brown hair': 22, 'Soon he sank\ninto deep thought, or more accurately speaking into a complete blankness\nof mind; he walked along not observing what was about him and not caring\nto observe it': 31, 'From time to time, he would mutter something, from the\nhabit of talking to himself, to which he had just confessed': 21, 'At these\nmoments he would become conscious that his ideas were sometimes in a\ntangle and that he was very weak; for two days he had scarcely tasted\nfood': 29, 'He was so badly dressed that even a man accustomed to shabbiness would\nhave been ashamed to be seen in the street in such rags': 25, 'In that quarter\nof the town, however, scarcely any shortcoming in dress would have\ncreated surprise': 16, 'Owing to the proximity of the Hay Market, the number\nof establishments of bad character, the preponderance of the trading\nand working class population crowded in these streets and alleys in the\nheart of Petersburg, types so various were to be seen in the streets\nthat no figure, however queer, would have caused surprise': 54, "But there was\nsuch accumulated bitterness and contempt in the young man's heart, that,\nin spite of all the fastidiousness of youth, he minded his rags least\nof all in the street": 32, 'It was a different matter when he met with\nacquaintances or with former fellow students, whom, indeed, he disliked\nmeeting at any time': 23, 'And yet when a drunken man who, for some unknown\nreason, was being taken somewhere in a huge waggon dragged by a heavy\ndray horse, suddenly shouted at him as he drove past: "Hey there, German\nhatter" bawling at the top of his voice and pointing at him--the young\nman stopped suddenly and clutched tremulously at his hat': 58, "It was a tall\nround hat from Zimmerman's, but completely worn out, rusty with age, all\ntorn and bespattered, brimless and bent on one side in a most unseemly\nfashion": 30, 'Not shame, however, but quite another feeling akin to terror\nhad overtaken him': 13, '"I knew it," he muttered in confusion, "I thought so': 10, "That's the worst\nof all": 5, 'Why, a stupid thing like this, the most trivial detail might\nspoil the whole plan': 15, 'Yes, my hat is too noticeable': 6, 'It looks absurd\nand that makes it noticeable': 8, 'With my rags I ought to wear a cap, any\nsort of old pancake, but not this grotesque thing': 19, 'Nobody wears such\na hat, it would be noticed a mile off, it would be remembered': 16, 'What\nmatters is that people would remember it, and that would give them\na clue': 15, 'For this business one should be as little conspicuous as\npossible': 11, 'Trifles, trifles are what matter': 5, "Why, it's just such\ntrifles that always ruin everything": 9, '"\n\nHe had not far to go; he knew indeed how many steps it was from the gate\nof his lodging house: exactly seven hundred and thirty': 27, 'He had counted\nthem once when he had been lost in dreams': 12, 'At the time he had put no\nfaith in those dreams and was only tantalising himself by their hideous\nbut daring recklessness': 22, 'Now, a month later, he had begun to look upon\nthem differently, and, in spite of the monologues in which he jeered at\nhis own impotence and indecision, he had involuntarily come to regard\nthis "hideous" dream as an exploit to be attempted, although he\nstill did not realise this himself': 51, 'He was positively going now for a\n"rehearsal" of his project, and at every step his excitement grew more\nand more violent': 22, 'With a sinking heart and a nervous tremor, he went up to a huge house\nwhich on one side looked on to the canal, and on the other into the\nstreet': 31, 'This house was let out in tiny tenements and was inhabited by\nworking people of all kinds--tailors, locksmiths, cooks, Germans of\nsorts, girls picking up a living as best they could, petty clerks, etc': 34, 'There was a continual coming and going through the two gates and in the\ntwo courtyards of the house': 19, 'Three or four door-keepers were employed on\nthe building': 9, 'The young man was very glad to meet none of them, and\nat once slipped unnoticed through the door on the right, and up the\nstaircase': 26, 'It was a back staircase, dark and narrow, but he was familiar\nwith it already, and knew his way, and he liked all these surroundings:\nin such darkness even the most inquisitive eyes were not to be dreaded': 38, '"If I am so scared now, what would it be if it somehow came to pass that\nI were really going to do it': 24, '" he could not help asking himself as he\nreached the fourth storey': 13, 'There his progress was barred by some porters\nwho were engaged in moving furniture out of a flat': 18, 'He knew that the\nflat had been occupied by a German clerk in the civil service, and his\nfamily': 19, 'This German was moving out then, and so the fourth floor on this\nstaircase would be untenanted except by the old woman': 22, '"That\'s a good\nthing anyway," he thought to himself, as he rang the bell of the old\nwoman\'s flat': 19, 'The bell gave a faint tinkle as though it were made of\ntin and not of copper': 17, 'The little flats in such houses always have bells\nthat ring like that': 13, 'He had forgotten the note of that bell, and now\nits peculiar tinkle seemed to remind him of something and to bring it\nclearly before him': 26, 'He started, his nerves were terribly overstrained\nby now': 9, 'In a little while, the door was opened a tiny crack: the old\nwoman eyed her visitor with evident distrust through the crack, and\nnothing could be seen but her little eyes, glittering in the darkness': 36, 'But, seeing a number of people on the landing, she grew bolder, and\nopened the door wide': 17, 'The young man stepped into the dark entry, which\nwas partitioned off from the tiny kitchen': 16, 'The old woman stood facing\nhim in silence and looking inquiringly at him': 13, 'She was a diminutive,\nwithered up old woman of sixty, with sharp malignant eyes and a sharp\nlittle nose': 19, 'Her colourless, somewhat grizzled hair was thickly smeared\nwith oil, and she wore no kerchief over it': 17, "Round her thin long neck,\nwhich looked like a hen's leg, was knotted some sort of flannel rag,\nand, in spite of the heat, there hung flapping on her shoulders, a mangy\nfur cape, yellow with age": 37, 'The old woman coughed and groaned at every\ninstant': 9, 'The young man must have looked at her with a rather peculiar\nexpression, for a gleam of mistrust came into her eyes again': 23, '"Raskolnikov, a student, I came here a month ago," the young man made\nhaste to mutter, with a half bow, remembering that he ought to be more\npolite': 28, '"I remember, my good sir, I remember quite well your coming here," the\nold woman said distinctly, still keeping her inquiring eyes on his face': 25, '"And here': 2, 'I am again on the same errand," Raskolnikov continued, a\nlittle disconcerted and surprised at the old woman\'s mistrust': 19, '"Perhaps\nshe is always like that though, only I did not notice it the other\ntime," he thought with an uneasy feeling': 22, 'The old woman paused, as though hesitating; then stepped on one side,\nand pointing to the door of the room, she said, letting her visitor pass\nin front of her:\n\n"Step in, my good sir': 35, '"\n\nThe little room into which the young man walked, with yellow paper on\nthe walls, geraniums and muslin curtains in the windows, was brightly\nlighted up at that moment by the setting sun': 34, '"So the sun will shine like this _then_ too': 9, '" flashed as it were by\nchance through Raskolnikov\'s mind, and with a rapid glance he scanned\neverything in the room, trying as far as possible to notice and\nremember its arrangement': 32, 'But there was nothing special in the room': 8, 'The\nfurniture, all very old and of yellow wood, consisted of a sofa with\na huge bent wooden back, an oval table in front of the sofa, a\ndressing-table with a looking-glass fixed on it between the windows,\nchairs along the walls and two or three half-penny prints in yellow\nframes, representing German damsels with birds in their hands--that was\nall': 61, 'In the corner a light was burning before a small ikon': 11, 'Everything\nwas very clean; the floor and the furniture were brightly polished;\neverything shone': 14, '"Lizaveta\'s work," thought the young man': 6, 'There was not a speck of dust\nto be seen in the whole flat': 14, '"It\'s in the houses of spiteful old widows that one finds such\ncleanliness," Raskolnikov thought again, and he stole a curious glance\nat the cotton curtain over the door leading into another tiny room, in\nwhich stood the old woman\'s bed and chest of drawers and into which he\nhad never looked before': 53, 'These two rooms made up the whole flat': 8, '"What do you want': 4, '" the old woman said severely, coming into the room\nand, as before, standing in front of him so as to look him straight in\nthe face': 27, '"I\'ve brought something to pawn here," and he drew out of his pocket\nan old-fashioned flat silver watch, on the back of which was engraved a\nglobe; the chain was of steel': 32, '"But the time is up for your last pledge': 9, 'The month was up the day\nbefore yesterday': 8, '"\n\n"I will bring you the interest for another month; wait a little': 13, '"\n\n"But that\'s for me to do as I please, my good sir, to wait or to sell\nyour pledge at once': 22, '"\n\n"How much will you give me for the watch, Alyona Ivanovna': 12, '"\n\n"You come with such trifles, my good sir, it\'s scarcely worth anything': 13, "I gave you two roubles last time for your ring and one could buy it\nquite new at a jeweler's for a rouble and a half": 26, '"\n\n"Give me four roubles for it, I shall redeem it, it was my father\'s': 15, 'I\nshall be getting some money soon': 7, '"\n\n"A rouble and a half, and interest in advance, if you like': 13, '"\n\n"A rouble and a half': 6, '" cried the young man': 5, '"Please yourself"--and the old woman handed him back the watch': 10, 'The\nyoung man took it, and was so angry that he was on the point of going\naway; but checked himself at once, remembering that there was nowhere\nelse he could go, and that he had had another object also in coming': 42, '"Hand it over," he said roughly': 6, 'The old woman fumbled in her pocket for her keys, and disappeared behind\nthe curtain into the other room': 19, 'The young man, left standing alone in\nthe middle of the room, listened inquisitively, thinking': 15, 'He could hear\nher unlocking the chest of drawers': 9, '"It must be the top drawer," he reflected': 8, '"So she carries the keys in\na pocket on the right': 11, 'All in one bunch on a steel ring': 8, "And there's\none key there, three times as big as all the others, with deep notches;\nthat can't be the key of the chest of drawers": 26, 'then there must be some\nother chest or strong-box': 9, "that's worth knowing": 3, 'Strong-boxes always\nhave keys like that': 6, 'but how degrading it all is': 6, '"\n\nThe old woman came back': 6, '"Here, sir: as we say ten copecks the rouble a month, so I must take\nfifteen copecks from a rouble and a half for the month in advance': 28, 'But\nfor the two roubles I lent you before, you owe me now twenty copecks\non the same reckoning in advance': 21, 'That makes thirty-five copecks\naltogether': 5, 'So I must give you a rouble and fifteen copecks for the\nwatch': 13, 'Here it is': 3, '"\n\n"What': 2, 'only a rouble and fifteen copecks now': 7, '"\n\n"Just so': 3, '"\n\nThe young man did not dispute it and took the money': 12, 'He looked at the\nold woman, and was in no hurry to get away, as though there was still\nsomething he wanted to say or to do, but he did not himself quite know\nwhat': 35, '"I may be bringing you something else in a day or two, Alyona\nIvanovna--a valuable thing--silver--a cigarette-box, as soon as I get it\nback from a friend': 27, '" he broke off in confusion': 6, '"Well, we will talk about it then, sir': 8, '"\n\n"Good-bye--are you always at home alone, your sister is not here with\nyou': 14, '" He asked her as casually as possible as he went out into the\npassage': 15, '"What business is she of yours, my good sir': 9, '"\n\n"Oh, nothing particular, I simply asked': 7, 'You are too quick': 4, 'Good-day,\nAlyona Ivanovna': 3, '"\n\nRaskolnikov went out in complete confusion': 7, 'This confusion became more\nand more intense': 7, 'As he went down the stairs, he even stopped short, two\nor three times, as though suddenly struck by some thought': 21, 'When he was\nin the street he cried out, "Oh, God, how loathsome it all is': 16, 'and\ncan I, can I possibly': 6, "No, it's nonsense, it's rubbish": 5, '" he added\nresolutely': 4, '"And how could such an atrocious thing come into my head': 11, 'What filthy things my heart is capable of': 8, 'Yes, filthy above all,\ndisgusting, loathsome, loathsome': 7, "--and for a whole month I've been": 7, '"\n But no words, no exclamations, could express his agitation': 10, 'The feeling\nof intense repulsion, which had begun to oppress and torture his heart\nwhile he was on his way to the old woman, had by now reached such a\npitch and had taken such a definite form that he did not know what to\ndo with himself to escape from his wretchedness': 53, 'He walked along the\npavement like a drunken man, regardless of the passers-by, and jostling\nagainst them, and only came to his senses when he was in the next\nstreet': 30, 'Looking round, he noticed that he was standing close to a tavern\nwhich was entered by steps leading from the pavement to the basement': 24, 'At that instant two drunken men came out at the door, and abusing and\nsupporting one another, they mounted the steps': 21, 'Without stopping to\nthink, Raskolnikov went down the steps at once': 11, 'Till that moment he had\nnever been into a tavern, but now he felt giddy and was tormented by a\nburning thirst': 22, 'He longed for a drink of cold beer, and attributed his\nsudden weakness to the want of food': 18, 'He sat down at a sticky little\ntable in a dark and dirty corner; ordered some beer, and eagerly drank\noff the first glassful': 24, 'At once he felt easier; and his thoughts became\nclear': 10, '"All that\'s nonsense," he said hopefully, "and there is nothing in it\nall to worry about': 16, "It's simply physical derangement": 4, 'Just a glass of\nbeer, a piece of dry bread--and in one moment the brain is stronger,\nthe mind is clearer and the will is firm': 26, 'Phew, how utterly petty it all\nis': 7, '"\n\nBut in spite of this scornful reflection, he was by now looking cheerful\nas though he were suddenly set free from a terrible burden: and he gazed\nround in a friendly way at the people in the room': 39, 'But even at that\nmoment he had a dim foreboding that this happier frame of mind was also\nnot normal': 20, 'There were few people at the time in the tavern': 10, 'Besides the two drunken\nmen he had met on the steps, a group consisting of about five men and\na girl with a concertina had gone out at the same time': 31, 'Their departure\nleft the room quiet and rather empty': 9, 'The persons still in the tavern\nwere a man who appeared to be an artisan, drunk, but not extremely so,\nsitting before a pot of beer, and his companion, a huge, stout man with\na grey beard, in a short full-skirted coat': 42, 'He was very drunk: and had\ndropped asleep on the bench; every now and then, he began as though in\nhis sleep, cracking his fingers, with his arms wide apart and the upper\npart of his body bounding about on the bench, while he hummed some\nmeaningless refrain, trying to recall some such lines as these:\n\n   "His wife a year he fondly loved\n    His wife a--a year he--fondly loved': 69, '"\n\nOr suddenly waking up again:\n\n   "Walking along the crowded row\n    He met the one he used to know': 19, '"\n\nBut no one shared his enjoyment: his silent companion looked with\npositive hostility and mistrust at all these manifestations': 20, 'There was\nanother man in the room who looked somewhat like a retired government\nclerk': 15, 'He was sitting apart, now and then sipping from his pot and\nlooking round at the company': 17, 'He, too, appeared to be in some agitation': 8, '': 0})
('DOS CHAPTER II PART I', {'Raskolnikov was not used to crowds, and, as we said before, he avoided\nsociety of every sort, more especially of late': 21, 'But now all at once he\nfelt a desire to be with other people': 14, 'Something new seemed to be taking\nplace within him, and with it he felt a sort of thirst for company': 20, 'He\nwas so weary after a whole month of concentrated wretchedness and gloomy\nexcitement that he longed to rest, if only for a moment, in some other\nworld, whatever it might be; and, in spite of the filthiness of the\nsurroundings, he was glad now to stay in the tavern': 50, 'The master of the establishment was in another room, but he frequently\ncame down some steps into the main room, his jaunty, tarred boots with\nred turn-over tops coming into view each time before the rest of his\nperson': 39, 'He wore a full coat and a horribly greasy black satin waistcoat,\nwith no cravat, and his whole face seemed smeared with oil like an\niron lock': 27, 'At the counter stood a boy of about fourteen, and there was\nanother boy somewhat younger who handed whatever was wanted': 21, 'On the\ncounter lay some sliced cucumber, some pieces of dried black bread, and\nsome fish, chopped up small, all smelling very bad': 23, 'It was insufferably\nclose, and so heavy with the fumes of spirits that five minutes in such\nan atmosphere might well make a man drunk': 25, 'There are chance meetings with strangers that interest us from the\nfirst moment, before a word is spoken': 18, 'Such was the impression made on\nRaskolnikov by the person sitting a little distance from him, who looked\nlike a retired clerk': 22, 'The young man often recalled this impression\nafterwards, and even ascribed it to presentiment': 14, 'He looked repeatedly\nat the clerk, partly no doubt because the latter was staring\npersistently at him, obviously anxious to enter into conversation': 23, 'At\nthe other persons in the room, including the tavern-keeper, the clerk\nlooked as though he were used to their company, and weary of it, showing\na shade of condescending contempt for them as persons of station and\nculture inferior to his own, with whom it would be useless for him to\nconverse': 53, 'He was a man over fifty, bald and grizzled, of medium height,\nand stoutly built': 15, 'His face, bloated from continual drinking, was of\na yellow, even greenish, tinge, with swollen eyelids out of which keen\nreddish eyes gleamed like little chinks': 26, 'But there was something very\nstrange in him; there was a light in his eyes as though of intense\nfeeling--perhaps there were even thought and intelligence, but at the\nsame time there was a gleam of something like madness': 39, 'He was wearing an\nold and hopelessly ragged black dress coat, with all its buttons missing\nexcept one, and that one he had buttoned, evidently clinging to this\nlast trace of respectability': 32, 'A crumpled shirt front, covered with spots\nand stains, protruded from his canvas waistcoat': 14, 'Like a clerk, he wore\nno beard, nor moustache, but had been so long unshaven that his chin\nlooked like a stiff greyish brush': 24, 'And there was something respectable\nand like an official about his manner too': 13, 'But he was restless; he\nruffled up his hair and from time to time let his head drop into his\nhands dejectedly resting his ragged elbows on the stained and sticky\ntable': 32, 'At last he looked straight at Raskolnikov, and said loudly and\nresolutely:\n\n"May I venture, honoured sir, to engage you in polite conversation': 23, 'Forasmuch as, though your exterior would not command respect, my\nexperience admonishes me that you are a man of education and not\naccustomed to drinking': 25, 'I have always respected education when in\nconjunction with genuine sentiments, and I am besides a titular\ncounsellor in rank': 20, 'Marmeladov--such is my name; titular counsellor': 6, 'I\nmake bold to inquire--have you been in the service': 10, '"\n\n"No, I am studying," answered the young man, somewhat surprised at\nthe grandiloquent style of the speaker and also at being so directly\naddressed': 25, 'In spite of the momentary desire he had just been feeling for\ncompany of any sort, on being actually spoken to he felt immediately his\nhabitual irritable and uneasy aversion for any stranger who approached\nor attempted to approach him': 40, '"A student then, or formerly a student," cried the clerk': 10, '"Just what\nI thought': 4, 'I\'m a man of experience, immense experience, sir," and he\ntapped his forehead with his fingers in self-approval': 18, '"You\'ve been a\nstudent or have attended some learned institution': 10, 'But allow me': 3, '"\n He got up, staggered, took up his jug and glass, and sat down beside\nthe young man, facing him a little sideways': 23, 'He was drunk, but spoke\nfluently and boldly, only occasionally losing the thread of his\nsentences and drawling his words': 20, 'He pounced upon Raskolnikov as\ngreedily as though he too had not spoken to a soul for a month': 19, '"Honoured sir," he began almost with solemnity, "poverty is not a vice,\nthat\'s a true saying': 16, "Yet I know too that drunkenness is not a virtue,\nand that that's even truer": 15, 'But beggary, honoured sir, beggary is a\nvice': 8, 'In poverty you may still retain your innate nobility of soul, but\nin beggary--never--no one': 15, 'For beggary a man is not chased out of human\nsociety with a stick, he is swept out with a broom, so as to make it as\nhumiliating as possible; and quite right, too, forasmuch as in beggary\nI am ready to be the first to humiliate myself': 48, 'Hence the pot-house': 3, 'Honoured sir, a month ago Mr': 6, 'Lebeziatnikov gave my wife a beating, and\nmy wife is a very different matter from me': 16, 'Do you understand': 3, 'Allow me\nto ask you another question out of simple curiosity: have you ever spent\na night on a hay barge, on the Neva': 24, '"\n\n"No, I have not happened to," answered Raskolnikov': 9, '"What do you mean': 4, '"\n\n"Well, I\'ve just come from one and it\'s the fifth night I\'ve slept\nso': 15, '" He filled his glass, emptied it and paused': 9, 'Bits of hay were in\nfact clinging to his clothes and sticking to his hair': 15, 'It seemed quite\nprobable that he had not undressed or washed for the last five days': 16, 'His hands, particularly, were filthy': 5, 'They were fat and red, with black\nnails': 8, 'His conversation seemed to excite a general though languid interest': 10, 'The\nboys at the counter fell to sniggering': 8, 'The innkeeper came down from the\nupper room, apparently on purpose to listen to the "funny fellow"\n and sat down at a little distance, yawning lazily, but with dignity': 29, 'Evidently Marmeladov was a familiar figure here, and he had most\nlikely acquired his weakness for high-flown speeches from the habit of\nfrequently entering into conversation with strangers of all sorts in\nthe tavern': 34, 'This habit develops into a necessity in some drunkards, and\nespecially in those who are looked after sharply and kept in order\nat home': 24, 'Hence in the company of other drinkers they try to justify\nthemselves and even if possible obtain consideration': 18, '"Funny fellow': 2, '" pronounced the innkeeper': 4, '"And why don\'t you work, why\naren\'t you at your duty, if you are in the service': 17, '"\n\n"Why am I not at my duty, honoured sir," Marmeladov went on, addressing\nhimself exclusively to Raskolnikov, as though it had been he who put\nthat question to him': 30, '"Why am I not at my duty': 7, 'Does not my heart ache\nto think what a useless worm I am': 13, 'A month ago when Mr': 5, "Lebeziatnikov\nbeat my wife with his own hands, and I lay drunk, didn't I suffer": 15, 'Excuse me, young man, has it ever happened to you': 10, 'hm': 1, 'well, to\npetition hopelessly for a loan': 7, '"\n\n"Yes, it has': 4, 'But what do you mean by hopelessly': 7, '"\n\n"Hopelessly in the fullest sense, when you know beforehand that you\nwill get nothing by it': 17, 'You know, for instance, beforehand with positive\ncertainty that this man, this most reputable and exemplary citizen, will\non no consideration give you money; and indeed I ask you why should he': 32, "For he knows of course that I shan't pay it back": 11, 'From compassion': 2, 'But\nMr': 2, "Lebeziatnikov who keeps up with modern ideas explained the other day\nthat compassion is forbidden nowadays by science itself, and that that's\nwhat is done now in England, where there is political economy": 33, 'Why, I\nask you, should he give it to me': 10, "And yet though I know beforehand that\nhe won't, I set off to him and": 15, '"\n\n"Why do you go': 5, '" put in Raskolnikov': 4, '"Well, when one has no one, nowhere else one can go': 11, 'For every man must\nhave somewhere to go': 8, 'Since there are times when one absolutely must\ngo somewhere': 10, 'When my own daughter first went out with a yellow ticket,\nthen I had to go': 16, '(for my daughter has a yellow passport)," he added\nin parenthesis, looking with a certain uneasiness at the young man': 20, '"No matter, sir, no matter': 5, '" he went on hurriedly and with apparent\ncomposure when both the boys at the counter guffawed and even the\ninnkeeper smiled--"No matter, I am not confounded by the wagging of\ntheir heads; for everyone knows everything about it already, and all\nthat is secret is made open': 48, 'And I accept it all, not with contempt, but\nwith humility': 11, 'So be it': 3, '‘Behold the man': 3, "' Excuse me, young\nman, can you": 7, 'No, to put it more strongly and more distinctly; not\n_can_ you but _dare_ you, looking upon me, assert that I am not a pig': 25, '"\n\nThe young man did not answer a word': 9, '"Well," the orator began again stolidly and with even increased dignity,\nafter waiting for the laughter in the room to subside': 21, '"Well, so be\nit, I am a pig, but she is a lady': 13, "I have the semblance of a beast, but\nKaterina Ivanovna, my spouse, is a person of education and an officer's\ndaughter": 21, 'Granted, granted, I am a scoundrel, but she is a woman of a\nnoble heart, full of sentiments, refined by education': 21, 'And yet': 2, 'oh,\nif only she felt for me': 7, 'Honoured sir, honoured sir, you know every man\nought to have at least one place where people feel for him': 20, 'But Katerina\nIvanovna, though she is magnanimous, she is unjust': 10, 'And yet, although\nI realise that when she pulls my hair she only does it out of pity--for\nI repeat without being ashamed, she pulls my hair, young man," he\ndeclared with redoubled dignity, hearing the sniggering again--"but, my\nGod, if she would but once': 45, 'But no, no': 3, "It's all in vain and it's no\nuse talking": 9, 'No use talking': 3, 'For more than once, my wish did come true\nand more than once she has felt for me but': 19, 'such is my fate and I am a\nbeast by nature': 11, '"\n\n"Rather': 2, '" assented the innkeeper yawning': 5, 'Marmeladov struck his fist\nresolutely on the table': 8, '"Such is my fate': 4, 'Do you know, sir, do you know, I have sold her very\nstockings for drink': 15, 'Not her shoes--that would be more or less in the\norder of things, but her stockings, her stockings I have sold for drink': 23, 'Her mohair shawl I sold for drink, a present to her long ago, her own\nproperty, not mine; and we live in a cold room and she caught cold this\nwinter and has begun coughing and spitting blood too': 39, "We have three\nlittle children and Katerina Ivanovna is at work from morning till\nnight; she is scrubbing and cleaning and washing the children, for she's\nbeen used to cleanliness from a child": 33, 'But her chest is weak and she has\na tendency to consumption and I feel it': 16, "Do you suppose I don't feel it": 7, 'And the more I drink the more I feel it': 10, "That's why I drink too": 5, 'I try\nto find sympathy and feeling in drink': 9, 'I drink so that I may suffer\ntwice as much': 10, '" And as though in despair he laid his head down on the\ntable': 14, '"Young man," he went on, raising his head again, "in your face I seem to\nread some trouble of mind': 20, 'When you came in I read it, and that was why\nI addressed you at once': 16, 'For in unfolding to you the story of my life, I\ndo not wish to make myself a laughing-stock before these idle listeners,\nwho indeed know all about it already, but I am looking for a man\nof feeling and education': 41, 'Know then that my wife was educated in a\nhigh-class school for the daughters of noblemen, and on leaving she\ndanced the shawl dance before the governor and other personages for\nwhich she was presented with a gold medal and a certificate of merit': 44, 'The medal': 2, 'well, the medal of course was sold--long ago, hm': 9, 'but the\ncertificate of merit is in her trunk still and not long ago she showed\nit to our landlady': 20, 'And although she is most continually on bad terms\nwith the landlady, yet she wanted to tell someone or other of her past\nhonours and of the happy days that are gone': 32, "I don't condemn her for\nit, I don't blame her, for the one thing left her is recollection of\nthe past, and all the rest is dust and ashes": 29, 'Yes, yes, she is a lady\nof spirit, proud and determined': 11, "She scrubs the floors herself and has\nnothing but black bread to eat, but won't allow herself to be treated\nwith disrespect": 22, "That's why she would not overlook Mr": 7, "Lebeziatnikov's\nrudeness to her, and so when he gave her a beating for it, she took to\nher bed more from the hurt to her feelings than from the blows": 30, 'She was\na widow when I married her, with three children, one smaller than the\nother': 16, "She married her first husband, an infantry officer, for love, and\nran away with him from her father's house": 19, 'She was exceedingly fond of\nher husband; but he gave way to cards, got into trouble and with that he\ndied': 21, 'He used to beat her at the end: and although she paid him back, of\nwhich I have authentic documentary evidence, to this day she speaks of\nhim with tears and she throws him up to me; and I am glad, I am glad\nthat, though only in imagination, she should think of herself as having\nonce been happy': 59, "And she was left at his death with three children in\na wild and remote district where I happened to be at the time; and she\nwas left in such hopeless poverty that, although I have seen many ups\nand downs of all sort, I don't feel equal to describing it even": 52, 'Her\nrelations had all thrown her off': 7, 'And she was proud, too, excessively\nproud': 7, 'And then, honoured sir, and then, I, being at the time a\nwidower, with a daughter of fourteen left me by my first wife, offered\nher my hand, for I could not bear the sight of such suffering': 38, 'You can\njudge the extremity of her calamities, that she, a woman of education\nand culture and distinguished family, should have consented to be my\nwife': 26, 'But she did': 3, 'Weeping and sobbing and wringing her hands, she\nmarried me': 10, 'For she had nowhere to turn': 6, 'Do you understand, sir, do you\nunderstand what it means when you have absolutely nowhere to turn': 17, "No,\nthat you don't understand yet": 6, 'And for a whole year, I performed\nmy duties conscientiously and faithfully, and did not touch this" (he\ntapped the jug with his finger), "for I have feelings': 28, 'But even so, I\ncould not please her; and then I lost my place too, and that through no\nfault of mine but through changes in the office; and then I did touch\nit': 34, 'It will be a year and a half ago soon since we found ourselves at\nlast after many wanderings and numerous calamities in this magnificent\ncapital, adorned with innumerable monuments': 30, 'Here I obtained a\nsituation': 5, 'I obtained it and I lost it again': 8, 'This\ntime it was through my own fault I lost it: for my weakness had come\nout': 17, "We have now part of a room at Amalia Fyodorovna Lippevechsel's;\nand what we live upon and what we pay our rent with, I could not say": 27, 'There are a lot of people living there besides ourselves': 10, 'Dirt and\ndisorder, a perfect Bedlam': 6, 'yes': 1, "And meanwhile my daughter by\nmy first wife has grown up; and what my daughter has had to put up with\nfrom her step-mother whilst she was growing up, I won't speak of": 33, 'For,\nthough Katerina Ivanovna is full of generous feelings, she is a spirited\nlady, irritable and short-tempered': 17, 'Yes': 1, "But it's no use going over\nthat": 7, 'Sonia, as you may well fancy, has had no education': 10, 'I did make an\neffort four years ago to give her a course of geography and universal\nhistory, but as I was not very well up in those subjects myself and we\nhad no suitable books, and what books we had': 41, 'hm, anyway we have not\neven those now, so all our instruction came to an end': 16, 'We stopped at\nCyrus of Persia': 6, 'Since she has attained years of maturity, she has read\nother books of romantic tendency and of late she had read with great\ninterest a book she got through Mr': 30, "Lebeziatnikov, Lewes' Physiology--do\nyou know it": 6, "--and even recounted extracts from it to us: and that's the\nwhole of her education": 15, 'And now may I venture to address you, honoured\nsir, on my own account with a private question': 18, 'Do you suppose that\na respectable poor girl can earn much by honest work': 14, 'Not fifteen\nfarthings a day can she earn, if she is respectable and has no special\ntalent and that without putting her work down for an instant': 27, "And what's\nmore, Ivan Ivanitch Klopstock the civil counsellor--have you heard of\nhim": 13, '--has not to this day paid her for the half-dozen linen shirts she\nmade him and drove her roughly away, stamping and reviling her, on the\npretext that the shirt collars were not made like the pattern and were\nput in askew': 42, 'And there are the little ones hungry': 7, "And Katerina\nIvanovna walking up and down and wringing her hands, her cheeks flushed\nred, as they always are in that disease: ‘Here you live with us,' says\nshe, ‘you eat and drink and are kept warm and you do nothing to help": 43, "'\nAnd much she gets to eat and drink when there is not a crust for the\nlittle ones for three days": 22, 'I was lying at the time': 6, 'well, what of\nit': 4, 'I was lying drunk and I heard my Sonia speaking (she is a gentle\ncreature with a soft little voice': 20, 'fair hair and such a pale, thin\nlittle face)': 9, 'She said: ‘Katerina Ivanovna, am I really to do a thing\nlike that': 13, "' And Darya Frantsovna, a woman of evil character and very\nwell known to the police, had two or three times tried to get at her\nthrough the landlady": 29, '‘And why not': 3, "' said Katerina Ivanovna with a jeer,\n‘you are something mighty precious to be so careful of": 17, "' But don't blame\nher, don't blame her, honoured sir, don't blame her": 13, 'She was not herself\nwhen she spoke, but driven to distraction by her illness and the crying\nof the hungry children; and it was said more to wound her than anything\nelse': 32, "For that's Katerina Ivanovna's character, and when children\ncry, even from hunger, she falls to beating them at once": 19, "At six o'clock\nI saw Sonia get up, put on her kerchief and her cape, and go out of the\nroom and about nine o'clock she came back": 28, 'She walked straight up to\nKaterina Ivanovna and she laid thirty roubles on the table before her\nin silence': 19, 'She did not utter a word, she did not even look at her, she\nsimply picked up our big green _drap de dames_ shawl (we have a shawl,\nmade of _drap de dames_), put it over her head and face and lay down\non the bed with her face to the wall; only her little shoulders and her\nbody kept shuddering': 61, 'And I went on lying there, just as before': 9, "And then I saw, young man, I saw Katerina Ivanovna, in the same silence\ngo up to Sonia's little bed; she was on her knees all the evening\nkissing Sonia's feet, and would not get up, and then they both fell\nasleep in each other's arms": 46, 'together, together': 2, 'and I': 2, 'lay\ndrunk': 2, '"\n\nMarmeladov stopped short, as though his voice had failed him': 11, 'Then he\nhurriedly filled his glass, drank, and cleared his throat': 11, '"Since then, sir," he went on after a brief pause--"Since then, owing\nto an unfortunate occurrence and through information given by\nevil-intentioned persons--in all which Darya Frantsovna took a\nleading part on the pretext that she had been treated with want of\nrespect--since then my daughter Sofya Semyonovna has been forced to take\na yellow ticket, and owing to that she is unable to go on living with\nus': 69, 'For our landlady, Amalia Fyodorovna would not hear of it (though\nshe had backed up Darya Frantsovna before) and Mr': 20, 'Lebeziatnikov too': 2, "All the educated\nman like me live in the same rooms with a girl like that": 41, "' And Katerina\nIvanovna would not let it pass, she stood up for her": 14, "and so that's\nhow it happened": 6, 'And Sonia with a cleft palate and all of his numerous family have cleft\npalates too": 32, 'And his wife, too, has a cleft palate': 8, 'They all live in one\nroom, but Sonia has her own, partitioned off': 13, 'Hm': 1, 'very poor\npeople and all with cleft palates': 8, 'Then I got up in the morning,\nand put on my rags, lifted up my hands to heaven and set off to his\nexcellency Ivan Afanasyvitch': 26, 'His excellency Ivan Afanasyvitch, do you\nknow him': 8, 'No': 1, "Well, then, it's a man of God you don't know": 10, 'He is wax': 3, 'wax before the face of the Lord; even as wax melteth': 11, 'His eyes were\ndim when he heard my story': 9, '‘Marmeladov, once already you have\ndeceived my expectations': 8, "I'll take you once more on my own\nresponsibility'--that's what he said, ‘remember,' he said, ideas": 34, "I returned home, and when I\nannounced that I'd been taken back into the service and should receive a\nsalary, heavens, what a to-do there was": 26, '"\n\nMarmeladov stopped again in violent excitement': 7, 'At that moment a whole\nparty of revellers already drunk came in from the street, and the sounds\nof a hired concertina and the cracked piping voice of a child of seven\nsinging "The Hamlet" were heard in the entry': 40, 'The room was filled with\nnoise': 6, 'The tavern-keeper and the boys were busy with the new-comers': 10, 'Marmeladov paying no attention to 19, 'Boots, cotton shirt-fronts--most magnificent,\na uniform, they got up all in splendid style, for eleven roubles and\na half': 19, 'The first morning I came back from the office I found herself up as though she were going\non a visit; and not that she'd anything to do it with, she smartened\nherself up with nothing at all, she'd done her hair nicely, put on a\nclean collar of some sort, cuffs, and there she was, quite a different\nperson, she was younger and better looking": 61, "Sonia, my little darling,\nhad only helped with money ‘for the time,' she said, ‘it won't do for had quarrelled to the last degree with\nour landlady Amalia Fyodorovna only a week before, she could not\nresist then asking her in to coffee': 41, 'For two hours they were sitting,\nwhispering together': 8, "‘Semyon Zaharovitch is in the service again,\nnow, and receiving a salary,' says she, ‘and he went himself to his\nexcellency and his excellency himself came out to him, made all he, ‘I rely now on your word as a gentleman": 55, "' And\nall that, let me tell you, she has simply made up for herself, and not\nsimply out of wantonness, for the sake of bragging; no, she believes full--twenty-three roubles\nforty copecks altogether--she called me her poppet: ‘poppet,' said she,\n‘my little poppet": 26, "' And when we were by ourselves, you understand": 9, 'You would not think chin began\nto twitch': 14, 'He controlled himself however': 4, 'The tavern, the degraded\nappearance of the man, the five nights in the hay barge, and the pot of\nspirits, and yet this poignant love for his wife and children bewildered\nhis listener': 33, 'Raskolnikov listened intently but with a sick sensation': 8, 'He felt vexed that he had come here': 8, '"Honoured sir, honoured sir," cried Marmeladov recovering himself--"Oh,\nsir, perhaps all this seems a laughing matter to you, as it does to\nothers, and perhaps I am only worrying you with the stupidity of all the\ntrivial details of my home life, but it is not a laughing matter to me': 51, 'For I can feel it all': 6, 'And the whole of that heavenly day of my life\nand the whole of that evening I passed in fleeting dreams of how I would\narrange it all, and how I would dress all the children, and how I should\ngive her rest, and how I should rescue my own daughter from dishonour\nand restore her to the bosom of her family': 62, 'And a great deal more': 5, 'Quite excusable, sir': 3, 'Well, then, sir" (Marmeladov suddenly gave a sort\nof start, raised his head and gazed intently at his listener) "well, on\nthe very next day after all those dreams, that is to say, exactly five\ndays ago, in the evening, by a cunning trick, like a thief in the night,\nI stole from Katerina Ivanovna the key of her box, took out what was\nleft of my earnings, how much it was I have forgotten, and now look\nat me, all of you': 83, "It's the fifth day since I left home, and they are\nlooking for me there and it's the end of my employment, and my uniform\nis lying in a tavern on the Egyptian bridge": 34, 'I exchanged it for the\ngarments I have on': 9, "and it's the end of everything": 6, '"\n\nMarmeladov struck his forehead with his fist, clenched his teeth, closed\nhis eyes and leaned heavily with his elbow on the table': 23, 'But a minute\nlater his face suddenly changed and with a certain assumed slyness begin pulling my hair': 20, 'What does my hair\nmatter': 5, 'Bother my hair': 3, "That's what I say": 4, "Indeed it will be better if\nshe does begin pulling it, that's not what I am afraid of": 18,
