afraid\nof': 7, 'Know, sir, that such blows are not a pain to me, but even an\nenjoyment': 15, "In fact I can't get on without it": 8, "It's better so": 3, 'Let\nher strike me, it relieves her heart': 8, "it's better so": 3, 'There is the\nhouse': 4, 'The house of Kozel, the cabinet-maker': 6, 'a German, well-to-do': 3, 'Lead the way': 3, '"\n\nThey went in from the yard and up to the fourth storey': 13, 'The staircase\ngot darker and darker as they went up': 10, "It was nearly eleven o'clock\nand although in summer in Petersburg there is no real night, yet it was\nquite dark at the top of the stairs": 27, 'A grimy little door at the very top of the stairs stood ajar': 13, 'A very\npoor-looking room about ten paces long was lighted up by a candle-end;\nthe whole of it was visible from the entrance': 23, "It was all in disorder,\nlittered up with rags of all sorts, especially children's garments": 15, 'Across the furthest corner was stretched a ragged sheet': 9, 'Behind it\nprobably was the bed': 6, 'There was nothing in the room except two chairs\nand a sofa covered with American leather, full of holes, before which\nstood an old deal kitchen-table, unpainted and uncovered': 29, 'At the edge\nof the table stood a smoldering tallow-candle in an iron candlestick': 14, 'It\nappeared that the family had a room to themselves, not part of a room,\nbut their room was practically a passage': 22, "The door leading to the other\nrooms, or rather cupboards, into which Amalia Lippevechsel's flat was\ndivided stood half open, and there was shouting, uproar and laughter\nwithin": 28, 'People seemed to be playing cards and drinking tea there': 10, 'Words\nof the most unceremonious kind flew out from time to time': 12, 'Raskolnikov recognised Katerina Ivanovna at once': 6, 'She was a rather tall,\nslim and graceful woman, terribly emaciated, with magnificent dark brown\nhair and with a hectic flush in her cheeks': 24, 'She was pacing up and down\nin her little room, pressing her hands against her chest; her lips\nwere parched and her breathing came in nervous broken gasps': 28, 'Her eyes\nglittered as in fever and looked about with a harsh immovable stare': 14, 'And\nthat consumptive and excited face with the last flickering light of the\ncandle-end playing upon it made a sickening impression': 21, 'She seemed to\nRaskolnikov about thirty years old and was certainly a strange wife for\nMarmeladov': 16, 'She had not heard them and did not notice them coming in': 12, 'She seemed to be lost in thought, hearing and seeing nothing': 11, 'The room\nwas close, but she had not opened the window; a stench rose from the\nstaircase, but the door on to the stairs was not closed': 27, 'From the inner\nrooms clouds of tobacco smoke floated in, she kept coughing, but did not\nclose the door': 19, 'The youngest child, a girl of six, was asleep, sitting\ncurled up on the floor with her head on the sofa': 21, 'A boy a year older\nstood crying and shaking in the corner, probably he had just had a\nbeating': 19, 'Beside him stood a girl of nine years old, tall and thin,\nwearing a thin and ragged chemise with an ancient cashmere pelisse flung\nover her bare shoulders, long outgrown and barely reaching her knees': 35, "Her arm, as thin as a stick, was round her brother's neck": 12, 'She was\ntrying to comfort him, whispering something to him, and doing all she\ncould to keep him from whimpering again': 21, 'At the same time her large\ndark eyes, which looked larger still from the thinness of her frightened\nface, were watching her mother with alarm': 25, 'Marmeladov did not enter the\ndoor, but dropped on his knees in the very doorway, pushing Raskolnikov\nin front of him': 21, 'The woman seeing a stranger stopped indifferently\nfacing him, coming to herself for a moment and apparently wondering what\nhe had come for': 23, 'But evidently she decided that he was going into\nthe next room, as he had to pass through hers to get there': 22, 'Taking no\nfurther notice of him, she walked towards the outer door to close it\nand uttered a sudden scream on seeing her husband on his knees in the\ndoorway': 30, '"Ah': 1, '" she cried out in a frenzy, "he has come back': 11, 'The criminal': 2, 'the\nmonster': 2, 'And where is the money': 5, "What's in your pocket, show me": 6, 'And\nyour clothes are all different': 6, 'Where are your clothes': 4, 'Where is the\nmoney': 4, 'Speak': 1, '"\n\nAnd she fell to searching him': 7, 'Marmeladov submissively and obediently\nheld up both arms to facilitate the search': 12, 'Not a farthing was there': 5, '"Where is the money': 4, '" she cried--"Mercy on us, can he have drunk it all': 11, 'There were twelve silver roubles left in the chest': 9, '" and in a fury\nshe seized him by the hair and dragged him into the room': 17, 'Marmeladov\nseconded her efforts by meekly crawling along on his knees': 11, '"And this is a consolation to me': 7, 'This does not hurt me, but is a\npositive con-so-la-tion, ho-nou-red sir," he called out, shaken to and\nfro by his hair and even once striking the ground with his forehead': 31, 'The child asleep on the floor woke up, and began to cry': 12, 'The boy in the\ncorner losing all control began trembling and screaming and rushed\nto his sister in violent terror, almost in a fit': 24, 'The eldest girl was\nshaking like a leaf': 8, '"He\'s drunk it': 3, 'he\'s drunk it all," the poor woman screamed in\ndespair--"and his clothes are gone': 14, 'And they are hungry, hungry': 5, '"--and\nwringing her hands she pointed to the children': 9, '"Oh, accursed life': 3, 'And you, are you not ashamed': 6, '"--she pounced all at once upon\nRaskolnikov--"from the tavern': 9, 'Have you been drinking with him': 6, 'You have\nbeen drinking with him, too': 7, 'Go away': 2, '"\n\nThe young man was hastening away without uttering a word': 11, 'The inner door\nwas thrown wide open and inquisitive faces were peering in at it': 15, 'Coarse\nlaughing faces with pipes and cigarettes and heads wearing caps thrust\nthemselves in at the doorway': 17, 'Further in could be seen figures in\ndressing gowns flung open, in costumes of unseemly scantiness, some of\nthem with cards in their hands': 24, 'They were particularly diverted, when\nMarmeladov, dragged about by his hair, shouted that it was a consolation\nto him': 19, 'They even began to come into the room; at last a sinister shrill\noutcry was heard: this came from Amalia Lippevechsel herself pushing her\nway amongst them and trying to restore order after her own fashion and\nfor the hundredth time to frighten the poor woman by ordering her\nwith coarse abuse to clear out of the room next day': 60, 'As he went out,\nRaskolnikov had time to put his hand into his pocket, to snatch up the\ncoppers he had received in exchange for his rouble in the tavern and to\nlay them unnoticed on the window': 38, 'Afterwards on the stairs, he changed\nhis mind and would have gone back': 13, '"What a stupid thing I\'ve done," he thought to himself, "they have Sonia\nand I want it myself': 18, '" But reflecting that it would be impossible to\ntake it back now and that in any case he would not have taken it, he\ndismissed it with a wave of his hand and went back to his lodging': 39, '"Sonia wants pomatum too," he said as he walked along the street, and he\nlaughed malignantly--"such smartness costs money': 19, 'And maybe Sonia\nherself will be bankrupt to-day, for there is always a risk, hunting\nbig game': 17, 'digging for gold': 3, 'then they would all be without a crust\nto-morrow except for my money': 13, 'Hurrah for Sonia': 3, "What a mine they've dug\nthere": 6, "And they're making the most of it": 7, 'Yes, they are making the most\nof it': 8, "They've wept over it and grown used to it": 9, 'Man grows used to\neverything, the scoundrel': 7, '"\n\nHe sank into thought': 5, '"And what if I am wrong," he cried suddenly after a moment\'s thought': 13, '"What if man is not really a scoundrel, man in general, I mean, the\nwhole race of mankind--then all the rest is prejudice, simply artificial\nterrors and there are no barriers and it\'s all as it should be': 38, '"': 1})
('DOS CHAPTER III PART I', {'He waked up late next day after a broken sleep': 10, 'But his sleep had not\nrefreshed him; he waked up bilious, irritable, ill-tempered, and looked\nwith hatred at his room': 20, 'It was a tiny cupboard of a room about six\npaces in length': 13, 'It had a poverty-stricken appearance with its dusty\nyellow paper peeling off the walls, and it was so low-pitched that a man\nof more than average height was ill at ease in it and felt every moment\nthat he would knock his head against the ceiling': 46, 'The furniture was in\nkeeping with the room: there were three old chairs, rather rickety; a\npainted table in the corner on which lay a few manuscripts and books;\nthe dust that lay thick upon them showed that they had been long\nuntouched': 43, 'A big clumsy sofa occupied almost the whole of one wall and\nhalf the floor space of the room; it was once covered with chintz, but\nwas now in rags and served Raskolnikov as a bed': 36, "Often he went to sleep\non it, as he was, without undressing, without sheets, wrapped in his old\nstudent's overcoat, with his head on one little pillow, under which he\nheaped up all the linen he had, clean and dirty, by way of a bolster": 45, 'A\nlittle table stood in front of the sofa': 9, 'It would have been difficult to sink to a lower ebb of disorder, but to\nRaskolnikov in his present state of mind this was positively agreeable': 26, 'He had got completely away from everyone, like a tortoise in its shell,\nand even the sight of a servant girl who had to wait upon him and looked\nsometimes into his room made him writhe with nervous irritation': 39, 'He was\nin the condition that overtakes some monomaniacs entirely concentrated\nupon one thing': 14, 'His landlady had for the last fortnight given up sending\nhim in meals, and he had not yet thought of expostulating with her,\nthough he went without his dinner': 29, "Nastasya, the cook and only servant,\nwas rather pleased at the lodger's mood and had entirely given up\nsweeping and doing his room, only once a week or so she would stray into\nhis room with a broom": 38, 'She waked him up that day': 6, '"Get up, why are you asleep': 6, '" she called to him': 5, '"It\'s past nine, I have\nbrought you some tea; will you have a cup': 14, "I should think you're fairly\nstarving": 6, '"\n\nRaskolnikov opened his eyes, started and recognised Nastasya': 9, '"From the landlady, eh': 4, '" he asked, slowly and with a sickly face sitting\nup on the sofa': 14, '"From the landlady, indeed': 4, '"\n\nShe set before him her own cracked teapot full of weak and stale tea and\nlaid two yellow lumps of sugar by the side of it': 27, '"Here, Nastasya, take it please," he said, fumbling in his pocket (for\nhe had slept in his clothes) and taking out a handful of coppers--"run\nand buy me a loaf': 30, "And get me a little sausage, the cheapest, at the\npork-butcher's": 11, '"\n\n"The loaf I\'ll fetch you this very minute, but wouldn\'t you rather have\nsome cabbage soup instead of sausage': 20, "It's capital soup, yesterday's": 4, 'I\nsaved it for you yesterday, but you came in late': 11, "It's fine soup": 3, '"\n\nWhen the soup had been brought, and he had begun upon it, Nastasya\nsat down beside him on the sofa and began chatting': 24, 'She was a country\npeasant-woman and a very talkative one': 10, '"Praskovya Pavlovna means to complain to the police about you," she\nsaid': 12, 'He scowled': 2, '"To the police': 3, 'What does she want': 4, '"\n\n"You don\'t pay her money and you won\'t turn out of the room': 14, "That's what\nshe wants, to be sure": 7, '"\n\n"The devil, that\'s the last straw," he muttered, grinding his teeth,\n"no, that would not suit me': 18, 'just now': 2, 'She is a fool," he added aloud': 7, '"I\'ll go and talk to her to-day': 7, '"\n\n"Fool she is and no mistake, just as I am': 11, 'But why, if you are so\nclever, do you lie here like a sack and have nothing to show for it': 21, 'One\ntime you used to go out, you say, to teach children': 12, 'But why is it you\ndo nothing now': 8, '"\n\n"I am doing': 4, '" Raskolnikov began sullenly and reluctantly': 6, '"What are you doing': 4, '"\n\n"Work': 2, '"\n\n"What sort of work': 5, '"\n\n"I am thinking," he answered seriously after a pause': 10, 'Nastasya was overcome with a fit of laughter': 8, 'She was given to laughter\nand when anything amused her, she laughed inaudibly, quivering and\nshaking all over till she felt ill': 22, '"And have you made much money by your thinking': 9, '" she managed to\narticulate at last': 7, '"One can\'t go out to give lessons without boots': 9, "And I'm sick of it": 5, '"\n\n"Don\'t quarrel with your bread and butter': 8, '"\n\n"They pay so little for lessons': 7, "What's the use of a few coppers": 7, '" he\nanswered, reluctantly, as though replying to his own thought': 11, '"And you want to get a fortune all at once': 10, '"\n\nHe looked at her strangely': 6, '"Yes, I want a fortune," he answered firmly, after a brief pause': 12, '"Don\'t be in such a hurry, you quite frighten me': 10, 'Shall I get you the\nloaf or not': 8, '"\n\n"As you please': 4, '"\n\n"Ah, I forgot': 4, 'A letter came for you yesterday when you were out': 10, '"\n\n"A letter': 3, 'for me': 2, 'from whom': 2, '"\n\n"I can\'t say': 4, 'I gave three copecks of my own to the postman for it': 12, 'Will\nyou pay me back': 5, '"\n\n"Then bring it to me, for God\'s sake, bring it," cried Raskolnikov\ngreatly excited--"good God': 16, '"\n\nA minute later the letter was brought him': 9, 'That was it: from his mother,\nfrom the province of R----': 11, 'He turned pale when he took it': 7, 'It was a\nlong while since he had received a letter, but another feeling also\nsuddenly stabbed his heart': 19, '"Nastasya, leave me alone, for goodness\' sake; here are your three\ncopecks, but for goodness\' sake, make haste and go': 20, '"\n\nThe letter was quivering in his hand; he did not want to open it in her\npresence; he wanted to be left _alone_ with this letter': 27, 'When Nastasya\nhad gone out, he lifted it quickly to his lips and kissed it; then he\ngazed intently at the address, the small, sloping handwriting, so dear\nand familiar, of the mother who had once taught him to read and write': 42, 'He delayed; he seemed almost afraid of something': 8, 'At last he opened it;\nit was a thick heavy letter, weighing over two ounces, two large sheets\nof note paper were covered with very small handwriting': 27, '"My dear Rodya," wrote his mother--"it\'s two months since I last had a\ntalk with you by letter which has distressed me and even kept me\nawake at night, thinking': 30, 'But I am sure you will not blame me for my\ninevitable silence': 13, 'You know how I love you; you are all we have to look\nto, Dounia and I, you are our all, our one hope, our one stay': 27, 'What a\ngrief it was to me when I heard that you had given up the university\nsome months ago, for want of means to keep yourself and that you had\nlost your lessons and your other work': 38, 'How could I help you out of my\nhundred and twenty roubles a year pension': 15, 'The fifteen roubles I sent\nyou four months ago I borrowed, as you know, on security of my pension,\nfrom Vassily Ivanovitch Vahrushin a merchant of this town': 28, "He is a\nkind-hearted man and was a friend of your father's too": 13, "But having given\nhim the right to receive the pension, I had to wait till the debt was\npaid off and that is only just done, so that I've been unable to send\nyou anything all this time": 38, 'But now, thank God, I believe I shall\nbe able to send you something more and in fact we may congratulate\nourselves on our good fortune now, of which I hasten to inform you': 34, 'In\nthe first place, would you have guessed, dear Rodya, that your sister\nhas been living with me for the last six weeks and we shall not be\nseparated in the future': 32, 'Thank God, her sufferings are over, but I will\ntell you everything in order, so that you may know just how everything\nhas happened and all that we have hitherto concealed from you': 33, "When you\nwrote to me two months ago that you had heard that Dounia had a great\ndeal to put up with in the Svidrigaïlovs' house, when you wrote that\nand asked me to tell you all about it--what could I write in answer to\nyou": 46, 'If I had written the whole truth to you, I dare say you would have\nthrown up everything and have come to us, even if you had to walk all\nthe way, for I know your character and your feelings, and you would not\nlet your sister be insulted': 49, 'I was in despair myself, but what could I\ndo': 10, 'And, besides, I did not know the whole truth myself then': 11, 'What\nmade it all so difficult was that Dounia received a hundred roubles\nin advance when she took the place as governess in their family, on\ncondition of part of her salary being deducted every month, and so it\nwas impossible to throw up the situation without repaying the debt': 50, 'This sum (now I can explain it all to you, my precious Rodya) she took\nchiefly in order to send you sixty roubles, which you needed so terribly\nthen and which you received from us last year': 37, "We deceived you then,\nwriting that this money came from Dounia's savings, but that was not\nso, and now I tell you all about it, because, thank God, things have\nsuddenly changed for the better, and that you may know how Dounia loves\nyou and what a heart she has": 50, 'At first indeed Mr': 4, 'Svidrigaïlov treated\nher very rudely and used to make disrespectful and jeering remarks at\ntable': 15, "But I don't want to go into all those painful details, so as\nnot to worry you for nothing when it is now all over": 25, 'In short, in spite\nof the kind and generous behaviour of Marfa Petrovna, Mr': 14, "Svidrigaïlov's\nwife, and all the rest of the household, Dounia had a very hard time,\nespecially when Mr": 18, 'Svidrigaïlov, relapsing into his old regimental\nhabits, was under the influence of Bacchus': 13, 'And how do you think it\nwas all explained later on': 11, 'Would you believe that the crazy fellow had\nconceived a passion for Dounia from the beginning, but had concealed\nit under a show of rudeness and contempt': 27, 'Possibly he was ashamed and\nhorrified himself at his own flighty hopes, considering his years and\nhis being the father of a family; and that made him angry with Dounia': 30, 'And possibly, too, he hoped by his rude and sneering behaviour to hide\nthe truth from others': 17, 'But at last he lost all control and had the face\nto make Dounia an open and shameful proposal, promising her all sorts of\ninducements and offering, besides, to throw up everything and take her\nto another estate of his, or even abroad': 43, 'You can imagine all she went\nthrough': 7, 'To leave her situation at once was impossible not only on\naccount of the money debt, but also to spare the feelings of Marfa\nPetrovna, whose suspicions would have been aroused: and then Dounia\nwould have been the cause of a rupture in the family': 45, 'And it would\nhave meant a terrible scandal for Dounia too; that would have been\ninevitable': 16, 'There were various other reasons owing to which Dounia could\nnot hope to escape from that awful house for another six weeks': 22, 'You know\nDounia, of course; you know how clever she is and what a strong will she\nhas': 18, 'Dounia can endure a great deal and even in the most difficult cases\nshe has the fortitude to maintain her firmness': 21, 'She did not even write\nto me about everything for fear of upsetting me, although we were\nconstantly in communication': 20, 'It all ended very unexpectedly': 5, 'Marfa\nPetrovna accidentally overheard her husband imploring Dounia in the\ngarden, and, putting quite a wrong interpretation on the position, threw\nthe blame upon her, believing her to be the cause of it all': 34, "An awful\nscene took place between them on the spot in the garden; Marfa Petrovna\nwent so far as to strike Dounia, refused to hear anything and was\nshouting at her for a whole hour and then gave orders that Dounia should\nbe packed off at once to me in a plain peasant's cart, into which they\nflung all her things, her linen and her clothes, all pell-mell, without\nfolding it up and packing it": 75, 'And a heavy shower of rain came on, too,\nand Dounia, insulted and put to shame, had to drive with a peasant in an\nopen cart all the seventeen versts into town': 32, 'Only think now what answer\ncould I have sent to the letter I received from you two months ago and\nwhat could I have written': 25, 'I was in despair; I dared not write to\nyou the truth because you would have been very unhappy, mortified\nand indignant, and yet what could you do': 28, 'You could only perhaps ruin\nyourself, and, besides, Dounia would not allow it; and fill up my letter\nwith trifles when my heart was so full of sorrow, I could not': 31, 'For a\nwhole month the town was full of gossip about this scandal, and it came\nto such a pass that Dounia and I dared not even go to church on account\nof the contemptuous looks, whispers, and even remarks made aloud about\nus': 44, 'All our acquaintances avoided us, nobody even bowed to us in the\nstreet, and I learnt that some shopmen and clerks were intending to\ninsult us in a shameful way, smearing the gates of our house with pitch,\nso that the landlord began to tell us we must leave': 49, 'All this was set\ngoing by Marfa Petrovna who managed to slander Dounia and throw dirt at\nher in every family': 21, 'She knows everyone in the neighbourhood, and that\nmonth she was continually coming into the town, and as she is\nrather talkative and fond of gossiping about her family affairs and\nparticularly of complaining to all and each of her husband--which is not\nat all right--so in a short time she had spread her story not only in\nthe town, but over the whole surrounding district': 66, 'It made me ill, but\nDounia bore it better than I did, and if only you could have seen how\nshe endured it all and tried to comfort me and cheer me up': 33, 'She is\nan angel': 4, "But by God's mercy, our sufferings were cut short: Mr": 10, "Svidrigaïlov returned to his senses and repented and, probably\nfeeling sorry for Dounia, he laid before Marfa Petrovna a complete and\nunmistakable proof of Dounia's innocence, in the form of a letter Dounia\nhad been forced to write and give to him, before Marfa Petrovna\ncame upon them in the garden": 51, 'This letter, which remained in Mr': 6, "Svidrigaïlov's hands after her departure, she had written to refuse\npersonal explanations and secret interviews, for which he was entreating\nher": 21, 'In that letter she reproached him with great heat and indignation\nfor the baseness of his behaviour in regard to Marfa Petrovna, reminding\nhim that he was the father and head of a family and telling him how\ninfamous it was of him to torment and make unhappy a defenceless girl,\nunhappy enough already': 54, 'Indeed, dear Rodya, the letter was so nobly and\ntouchingly written that I sobbed when I read it and to this day I cannot\nread it without tears': 28, "Moreover, the evidence of the servants, too,\ncleared Dounia's reputation; they had seen and known a great deal more\nthan Mr": 21, 'Svidrigaïlov had himself supposed--as indeed is always the case\nwith servants': 11, "Marfa Petrovna was completely taken aback, and ‘again\ncrushed' as she said herself to us, but she was completely convinced of\nDounia's innocence": 23, 'The very next day, being Sunday, she went straight\nto the Cathedral, knelt down and prayed with tears to Our Lady to give\nher strength to bear this new trial and to do her duty': 35, 'Then she\ncame straight from the Cathedral to us, told us the whole story, wept\nbitterly and, fully penitent, she embraced Dounia and besought her to\nforgive her': 28, "The same morning without any delay, she went round to all\nthe houses in the town and everywhere, shedding tears, she asserted in\nthe most flattering terms Dounia's innocence and the nobility of\nher feelings and her behavior": 38, "What was more, she showed and read to\neveryone the letter in Dounia's own handwriting to Mr": 17, 'Svidrigaïlov and\neven allowed them to take copies of it--which I must say I think was\nsuperfluous': 17, 'In this way she was busy for several days in driving about\nthe whole town, because some people had taken offence through precedence\nhaving been given to others': 28, "And therefore they had to take turns, so\nthat in every house she was expected before she arrived, and everyone\nknew that on such and such a day Marfa Petrovna would be reading the\nletter in such and such a place and people assembled for every reading\nof it, even many who had heard it several times already both in their\nown houses and in other people's": 67, "In my opinion a great deal, a very\ngreat deal of all this was unnecessary; but that's Marfa Petrovna's\ncharacter": 20, "Anyway she succeeded in completely re-establishing Dounia's\nreputation and the whole ignominy of this affair rested as an indelible\ndisgrace upon her husband, as the only person to blame, so that I really\nbegan to feel sorry for him; it was really treating the crazy fellow too\nharshly": 48, 'Dounia was at once asked to give lessons in several families,\nbut she refused': 14, 'All of a sudden everyone began to treat her with marked\nrespect and all this did much to bring about the event by which, one may\nsay, our whole fortunes are now transformed': 33, 'You must know, dear Rodya,\nthat Dounia has a suitor and that she has already consented to marry\nhim': 19, 'I hasten to tell you all about the matter, and though it has been\narranged without asking your consent, I think you will not be aggrieved\nwith me or with your sister on that account, for you will see that we\ncould not wait and put off our decision till we heard from you': 54, 'And you\ncould not have judged all the facts without being on the spot': 14, 'This\nwas how it happened': 5, 'He is already of the rank of a counsellor, Pyotr\nPetrovitch Luzhin, and is distantly related to Marfa Petrovna, who\nhas been very active in bringing the match about': 29, 'It began with his\nexpressing through her his desire to make our acquaintance': 13, 'He was\nproperly received, drank coffee with us and the very next day he sent\nus a letter in which he very courteously made an offer and begged for a\nspeedy and decided answer': 34, 'He is a very busy man and is in a great hurry\nto get to Petersburg, so that every moment is precious to him': 24, 'At first,\nof course, we were greatly surprised, as it had all happened so quickly\nand unexpectedly': 17, 'We thought and talked it over the whole day': 9, 'He is a\nwell-to-do man, to be depended upon, he has two posts in the government\nand has already made his fortune': 22, 'It is true that he is forty-five years\nold, but he is of a fairly prepossessing appearance and might still be\nthought attractive by women, and he is altogether a very respectable and\npresentable man, only he seems a little morose and somewhat conceited': 44, 'But possibly that may only be the impression he makes at first sight': 13, 'And beware, dear Rodya, when he comes to Petersburg, as he shortly will\ndo, beware of judging him too hastily and severely, as your way is, if\nthere is anything you do not like in him at first sight': 39, 'I give you this\nwarning, although I feel sure that he will make a favourable impression\nupon you': 18, 'Moreover, in order to understand any man one must be\ndeliberate and careful to avoid forming prejudices and mistaken ideas,\nwhich are very difficult to correct and get over afterwards': 30, 'And Pyotr\nPetrovitch, judging by many indications, is a thoroughly estimable man': 12, "At his first visit, indeed, he told us that he was a practical man, but\nstill he shares, as he expressed it, many of the convictions ‘of our\nmost rising generation' and he is an opponent of all prejudices": 39, 'He\nsaid a good deal more, for he seems a little conceited and likes to be\nlistened to, but this is scarcely a vice': 24, 'I, of course, understood very\nlittle of it, but Dounia explained to me that, though he is not a man\nof great education, he is clever and seems to be good-natured': 31, "You know\nyour sister's character, Rodya": 6, 'She is a resolute, sensible, patient and\ngenerous girl, but she has a passionate heart, as I know very well': 20, 'Of course, there is no great love either on his side, or on hers, but\nDounia is a clever girl and has the heart of an angel, and will make\nit her duty to make her husband happy who on his side will make her\nhappiness his care': 48, 'Of that we have no good reason to doubt, though it\nmust be admitted the matter has been arranged in great haste': 22, 'Besides he\nis a man of great prudence and he will see, to be sure, of himself, that\nhis own happiness will be the more secure, the happier Dounia is with\nhim': 32, 'And as for some defects of character, for some habits and even\ncertain differences of opinion--which indeed are inevitable even in\nthe happiest marriages--Dounia has said that, as regards all that, she\nrelies on herself, that there is nothing to be uneasy about, and\nthat she is ready to put up with a great deal, if only their future\nrelationship can be an honourable and straightforward one': 67, 'He struck me,\nfor instance, at first, as rather abrupt, but that may well come\nfrom his being an outspoken man, and that is no doubt how it is': 29, "For\ninstance, at his second visit, after he had received Dounia's consent,\nin the course of conversation, he declared that before making\nDounia's acquaintance, he had made up his mind to marry a girl of\ngood reputation, without dowry and, above all, one who had experienced\npoverty, because, as he explained, a man ought not to be indebted to his\nwife, but that it is better for a wife to look upon her husband as her\nbenefactor": 77, 'I must add that he expressed it more nicely and politely\nthan I have done, for I have forgotten his actual phrases and only\nremember the meaning': 27, 'And, besides, it was obviously not said of design,\nbut slipped out in the heat of conversation, so that he tried afterwards\nto correct himself and smooth it over, but all the same it did strike\nme as somewhat rude, and I said so afterwards to Dounia': 47, "But Dounia was\nvexed, and answered that ‘words are not deeds,' and that, of course, is\nperfectly true": 18, 'Dounia did not sleep all night before she made up\nher mind, and, thinking that I was asleep, she got out of bed and was\nwalking up and down the room all night; at last she knelt down before\nthe ikon and prayed long and fervently and in the morning she told me\nthat she had decided': 57, '"I have mentioned already that Pyotr Petrovitch is just setting off for\nPetersburg, where he has a great deal of business, and he wants to open\na legal bureau': 29, 'He has been occupied for many years in conducting civil\nand commercial litigation, and only the other day he won an important\ncase': 23, 'He has to be in Petersburg because he has an important case before\nthe Senate': 15, 'So, Rodya dear, he may be of the greatest use to you, in\nevery way indeed, and Dounia and I have agreed that from this very day\nyou could definitely enter upon your career and might consider that\nyour future is marked out and assured for you': 47, 'Oh, if only this comes to\npass': 7, 'This would be such a benefit that we could only look upon it as a\nprovidential blessing': 17, 'Dounia is dreaming of nothing else': 6, 'We have even\nventured already to drop a few words on the subject to Pyotr Petrovitch': 16, 'He was cautious in his answer, and said that, of course, as he could not\nget on without a secretary, it would be better to be paying a salary to\na relation than to a stranger, if only the former were fitted for the\nduties (as though there could be doubt of your being fitted': 55, ') but then\nhe expressed doubts whether your studies at the university would leave\nyou time for work at his office': 21, 'The matter dropped for the time, but\nDounia is thinking of nothing else now': 14, "She has been in a sort of fever\nfor the last few days, and has already made a regular plan for\nyour becoming in the end an associate and even a partner in Pyotr\nPetrovitch's business, which might well be, seeing that you are a\nstudent of law": 48, 'I am in complete agreement with her, Rodya, and share\nall her plans and hopes, and think there is every probability of\nrealising them': 24, "And in spite of Pyotr Petrovitch's evasiveness, very\nnatural at present (since he does not know you), Dounia is firmly\npersuaded that she will gain everything by her good influence over her\nfuture husband; this she is reckoning upon": 39, 'Of course we are careful\nnot to talk of any of these more remote plans to Pyotr Petrovitch,\nespecially of your becoming his partner': 24, 'He is a practical man and might\ntake this very coldly, it might all seem to him simply a day-dream': 20, 'Nor\nhas either Dounia or I breathed a word to him of the great hopes we have\nof his helping us to pay for your university studies; we have not spoken\nof it in the first place, because it will come to pass of itself,\nlater on, and he will no doubt without wasting words offer to do it of\nhimself, (as though he could refuse Dounia that) the more readily since\nyou may by your own efforts become his right hand in the office, and\nreceive this assistance not as a charity, but as a salary earned by your\nown work': 102, 'Dounia wants to arrange it all like this and I quite agree\nwith her': 14, 'And we have not spoken of our plans for another reason, that\nis, because I particularly wanted you to feel on an equal footing when\nyou first meet him': 29, 'When Dounia spoke to him with enthusiasm about\nyou, he answered that one could never judge of a man without seeing\nhim close, for oneself, and that he looked forward to forming his own\nopinion when he makes your acquaintance': 40, 'Do you know, my precious\nRodya, I think that perhaps for some reasons (nothing to do with Pyotr\nPetrovitch though, simply for my own personal, perhaps old-womanish,\nfancies) I should do better to go on living by myself, apart, than with\nthem, after the wedding': 45, 'I am convinced that he will be generous and\ndelicate enough to invite me and to urge me to remain with my daughter\nfor the future, and if he has said nothing about it hitherto, it is\nsimply because it has been taken for granted; but I shall refuse': 49, "I have\nnoticed more than once in my life that husbands don't quite get on with\ntheir mothers-in-law, and I don't want to be the least bit in anyone's\nway, and for my own sake, too, would rather be quite independent, so\nlong as I have a crust of bread of my own, and such children as you and\nDounia": 60, 'If possible, I would settle somewhere near you, for the most\njoyful piece of news, dear Rodya, I have kept for the end of my letter:\nknow then, my dear boy, that we may, perhaps, be all together in a\nvery short time and may embrace one another again after a separation of\nalmost three years': 56, "It is settled _for certain_ that Dounia and I are to\nset off for Petersburg, exactly when I don't know, but very, very soon,\npossibly in a week": 28, 'It all depends on Pyotr Petrovitch who will let us\nknow when he has had time to look round him in Petersburg': 22, 'To suit his\nown arrangements he is anxious to have the ceremony as soon as possible,\neven before the fast of Our Lady, if it could be managed, or if that is\ntoo soon to be ready, immediately after': 39, 'Oh, with what happiness I shall\npress you to my heart': 11, 'Dounia is all excitement at the joyful thought\nof seeing you, she said one day in joke that she would be ready to marry\nPyotr Petrovitch for that alone': 29, 'She is an angel': 4, 'She is not writing\nanything to you now, and has only told me to write that she has so much,\nso much to tell you that she is not going to take up her pen now, for\na few lines would tell you nothing, and it would only mean upsetting\nherself; she bids me send you her love and innumerable kisses': 61, 'But\nalthough we shall be meeting so soon, perhaps I shall send you as much\nmoney as I can in a day or two': 24, 'Now that everyone has heard that Dounia\nis to marry Pyotr Petrovitch, my credit has suddenly improved and I know\nthat Afanasy Ivanovitch will trust me now even to seventy-five roubles\non the security of my pension, so that perhaps I shall be able to send\nyou twenty-five or even thirty roubles': 52, "I would send you more, but I am\nuneasy about our travelling expenses; for though Pyotr Petrovitch has\nbeen so kind as to undertake part of the expenses of the journey, that\nis to say, he has taken upon himself the conveyance of our bags and big\ntrunk (which will be conveyed through some acquaintances of his), we\nmust reckon upon some expense on our arrival in Petersburg, where we\ncan't be left without a halfpenny, at least for the first few days": 83, 'But\nwe have calculated it all, Dounia and I, to the last penny, and we see\nthat the journey will not cost very much': 24, 'It is only ninety versts from\nus to the railway and to-day; If it is so, I pray for you': 30, 'Remember,\ndear boy, how in your childhood, when your father was living, you used\nto lisp your prayers at my knee, and how happy we all were in on his threadbare dirty pillow and pondered, pondered a long\ntime': 16, 'His heart was beating violently, and his brain was in a turmoil': 12, 'At last he felt cramped and stifled in the little yellow room that was\nlike a cupboard or a box': 20, 'His eyes and his mind craved for space': 8, 'He\ntook up his hat and went out, this time without dread of meeting\nanyone; he had forgotten his dread': 20, 'He turned in the direction of the\nVassilyevsky Ostrov, walking along Vassilyevsky Prospect, as though\nhastening on some business, but he walked, as his habit was, without\nnoticing his way, muttering and even speaking aloud to himself, to the\nastonishment of the passers-by': 43, 'Many of them took him to be drunk': 8, '': 0})
('DOS CHAPTER IV PART I', {"His mother's letter had been a torture to him, but as regards the chief\nfact in it, he had felt not one moment's hesitation, even whilst he was\nreading the letter": 31, 'The essential question was settled, and irrevocably\nsettled, in his mind: "Never such a marriage while I am alive and\nMr': 21, 'Luzhin be damned': 3, '" "The thing is perfectly clear," he muttered\nto himself, with a malignant smile anticipating the triumph of his\ndecision': 20, '"No, mother, no, Dounia, you won\'t deceive me': 8, 'and then they\napologise for not asking my advice and for taking the decision without\nme': 16, 'I dare say': 3, "They imagine it is arranged now and can't be broken\noff; but we will see whether it can or not": 20, 'A magnificent excuse:\n‘Pyotr Petrovitch is such a busy man that even his wedding has to be in\npost-haste, almost by express': 22, "' No, Dounia, I see it all and I know what\nyou want to say to me; and I know too what you were thinking about, when\nyou walked up and down all night, and what your prayers were like before\nthe Holy Mother of Kazan who stands in mother's bedroom": 51, 'Bitter is\nthe ascent to Golgotha': 6, 'Hm': 1, 'so it is finally settled; you have\ndetermined to marry a sensible business man, Avdotya Romanovna, one\nwho has a fortune (has _already_ made his fortune, that is so much\nmore solid and impressive), a man who holds two government posts and who\nshares the ideas of our most rising generation, as mother writes, and\nwho _seems_ to be kind, as Dounia herself observes': 64, 'That _seems_ beats\neverything': 4, "And that very Dounia for that very ‘_seems_' is marrying\nhim": 11, 'Splendid': 1, 'splendid': 1, '"': 1, "But I should like to know why mother has written to me about ‘our\nmost rising generation'": 17, 'Simply as a descriptive touch, or with the idea\nof prepossessing me in favour of Mr': 16, 'Luzhin': 1, 'Oh, the cunning of them': 5, 'I should like to know one thing more: how far they were open with one\nanother that day and night and all this time since': 25, 'Was it all put into\n_words_, or did both understand that they had the same thing at heart\nand in their minds, so that there was no need to speak of it aloud, and\nbetter not to speak of it': 40, "Most likely it was partly like that, from\nmother's letter it's evident: he struck her as rude _a little_, and\nmother in her simplicity took her observations to Dounia": 29, 'And she was\nsure to be vexed and ‘answered her angrily': 11, "' I should think so": 5, 'Who\nwould not be angered when it was quite clear without any naïve questions\nand when it was understood that it was useless to discuss it': 26, "And why\ndoes she write to me, ‘love Dounia, Rodya, and she loves you more than\nherself'": 17, 'Has she a secret conscience-prick at sacrificing her daughter\nto her son': 12, '‘You are our one comfort, you are everything to us': 10, "' Oh,\nmother": 3, '"\n\nHis bitterness grew more and more intense, and if he had happened to\nmeet Mr': 16, 'Luzhin at the moment, he might have murdered him': 9, '"Hm': 1, 'yes, that\'s true," he continued, pursuing the whirling ideas that\nchased each other in his brain, "it is true that ‘it needs time and care\nto get to know a man,\' but there is no mistake about Mr': 38, "The\nchief thing is he is ‘a man of business and _seems_ kind,' that was\nsomething, wasn't it, to send the bags and big box for them": 27, 'A kind man,\nno doubt after that': 7, "But his _bride_ and her mother are to drive in a\npeasant's cart covered with sacking (I know, I have been driven in\nit)": 24, 'No matter': 2, "It is only ninety versts and then they can ‘travel very\ncomfortably, third class,' for a thousand versts": 18, 'Quite right, too': 3, "One\nmust cut one's coat according to one's cloth, but what about you, Mr": 14, 'She is your bride': 4, 'And you must be aware that her mother has\nto raise money on her pension for the journey': better of them, too': 10, 'The luggage will cost less\nthan their fares and very likely go for nothing': 14, "How is it that they\ndon't both see all that, or is it that they don't want to see": 19, 'And\nthey are pleased, pleased': 5, 'And to think that this is only the first\nblossoming, and that the real fruits are to come': 18, 'But what really\nmatters is not the stinginess, is not the "That's how it always is with these\nSchilleresque noble hearts; till the last moment every goose is a swan\nwith them, till the last moment, they hope for the best and will see\nnothing wrong, and although they have an inkling of the other side of\nthe picture, yet they won't face the truth till they are forced to; the\nvery thought of it makes them shiver; they thrust the truth away with\nboth hands, until the man they deck out in false colours puts a fool's\ncap on them with his own hands": 94, 'I should like to know whether Mr': 7, 'Luzhin\nhas any orders of merit; I bet he has the Anna her\ncomfort, to save her life she would not sell herself, but for someone\nelse she is doing it": 25, 'For one she loves, for one she adores, she will\nsell herself': 12, "That's what it all amounts to; for her brother, for her\nmother, she will sell herself": 16, 'She will sell everything': 4, "In such cases,\n‘we overcome our moral feeling if necessary,' freedom, peace, conscience\neven, all, heart and mind, clamouring insistently for an answer': 45, "Now his\nmother's letter had burst on him like a thunderclap": 11, 'It was clear\nthat he must not now suffer passively, worrying himself over unsolved\nquestions, but that he must do something, do it at once, and do it\nquickly': 29, 'Anyway he must decide on something, or else': 8, '"Or throw up life altogether': 5, '" he cried suddenly, in a frenzy--"accept\none\'s lot humbly as it is, once for all and stifle everything in\noneself, giving up all claim to activity, life and love': 30, '"\n\n"Do you understand, sir, do you understand what it means when you have\nabsolutely nowhere to turn': 18, '" Marmeladov\'s question came suddenly into\nhis mind, "for every man must have somewhere to turn': 16, '"\n\nHe gave a sudden start; another thought, that he had had yesterday,\nslipped back into his mind': 18, "But he did not start at the thought\nrecurring to him, for he knew, he had _felt beforehand_, that it must\ncome back, he was expecting it; besides it was not only yesterday's\nthought": 34, 'The difference was that a month ago, yesterday even, the\nthought was a mere dream: but now': 17, 'now it appeared not a dream at all,\nit had taken a new menacing and quite unfamiliar shape, and he suddenly\nbecame aware of this himself': 26, 'He felt a hammering in his head, and\nthere was a darkness before his eyes': 15, 'He looked round hurriedly, he was searching for something': 9, 'He wanted\nto sit down and was looking for a seat; he was walking along the K----\nBoulevard': 18, 'There was a seat about a hundred paces in front of him': 12, 'He\nwalked towards it as fast he could; but on the way he met with a little\nadventure which absorbed all his attention': 23, 'Looking for the seat, he had\nnoticed a woman walking some twenty paces in front of him, but at first\nhe took no more notice of her than of other objects that crossed his\npath': 35, 'It had happened to him many times going home not to notice the\nroad by which he was going, and he was accustomed to walk like that': 27, 'But\nthere was at first sight something so strange about the woman in front\nof him, that gradually his attention was riveted upon her, at first\nreluctantly and, as it were, resentfully, and then more and more\nintently': 38, 'He felt a sudden desire to find out what it was that was so\nstrange about the woman': 18, 'In the first place, she appeared to be a girl\nquite young, and she was walking in the great heat bareheaded and with\nno parasol or gloves, waving her arms about in an absurd way': 35, 'She had\non a dress of some light silky material, but put on strangely awry, not\nproperly hooked up, and torn open at the top of the skirt, close to the\nwaist: a great piece was rent and hanging loose': 40, 'A little kerchief was\nflung about her bare throat, but lay slanting on one side': 15, 'The girl was\nwalking unsteadily, too, stumbling and staggering from side to side': 13, "She\ndrew Raskolnikov's whole attention at last": 7, 'He overtook the girl at the\nseat, but, on reaching it, she dropped down on it, in the corner;\nshe let her head sink on the back of the seat and closed her eyes,\napparently in extreme exhaustion': 38, 'Looking at her closely, he saw at once\nthat she was completely drunk': 13, 'It was a strange and shocking sight': 7, 'He\ncould hardly believe that he was not mistaken': 9, 'He saw before him the\nface of a quite young, fair-haired girl--sixteen, perhaps not more than\nfifteen, years old, pretty little face, but flushed and heavy looking\nand, as it were, swollen': 32, 'The girl seemed hardly to know what she was\ndoing; she crossed one leg over the other, lifting it indecorously, and\nshowed every sign of being unconscious that she was in the street': 33, 'Raskolnikov did not sit down, but he felt unwilling to leave her,\nand stood facing her in perplexity': 18, "This boulevard was never much\nfrequented; and now, at two o'clock, in the stifling heat, it was quite\ndeserted": 19, 'And yet on the further side of the boulevard, about fifteen\npaces away, a gentleman was standing on the edge of the pavement': 23, 'He,\ntoo, would apparently have liked to approach the girl with some object\nof his own': 16, 'He, too, had probably seen her in the distance and had\nfollowed her, but found Raskolnikov in his way': 19, 'He looked angrily at\nhim, though he tried to escape his notice, and stood impatiently biding\nhis time, till the unwelcome man in rags should have moved away': 28, 'His\nintentions were unmistakable': 4, 'The gentleman was a plump, thickly-set\nman, about thirty, fashionably dressed, with a high colour, red lips and\nmoustaches': 19, 'Raskolnikov felt furious; he had a sudden longing to insult\nthis fat dandy in some way': 16, 'He left the girl for a moment and walked\ntowards the gentleman': 12, '"Hey': 1, 'You Svidrigaïlov': 2, 'What do you want here': 5, '" he shouted, clenching\nhis fists and laughing, spluttering with rage': 11, '"What do you mean': 4, '" the gentleman asked sternly, scowling in haughty\nastonishment': 9, '"Get away, that\'s what I mean': 6, '"\n\n"How dare you, you low fellow': 7, '"\n\nHe raised his cane': 5, 'Raskolnikov rushed at him with his fists, without\nreflecting that the stout gentleman was a match for two men like\nhimself': 21, 'But at that instant someone seized him from behind, and a\npolice constable stood between them': 16, '"That\'s enough, gentlemen, no fighting, please, in a public place': 10, 'What\ndo you want': comrades at the\nuniversity': 10, 'It was remarkable that Raskolnikov had hardly any friends at\nthe university; he kept aloof from everyone, went to see no one, and did\nnot welcome anyone who came to see him, and indeed everyone soon gave\nhim up': 39, "He took no part in the students' gatherings, amusements or\nconversations": 11, 'He worked with great intensity without sparing himself,\nand he was respected for this, but no one liked him': 19, 'He was very poor,\nand there was a sort of haughty pride and reserve about him, as though\nhe were keeping something to himself': 24, 'He seemed to some of his comrades\nto look down upon them all as children, as though he were superior in\ndevelopment, knowledge and convictions, as though their beliefs and\ninterests were beneath him': 34, 'With Razumihin he had got on, or, at least, he was more unreserved and\ncommunicative with him': 17, 'Indeed it was impossible to be on any other\nterms with Razumihin': 12, 'He was an exceptionally good-humoured and candid\nyouth, good-natured to the point of simplicity, though both depth and\ndignity lay concealed under that simplicity': 24, 'The better of his comrades\nunderstood this, and all were fond of him': 13, 'He was extremely intelligent,\nthough he was certainly rather a simpleton at times': 13, 'He was of striking\nappearance--tall, thin, blackhaired and always badly shaved': 11, 'He was\nsometimes uproarious and was reputed to be of great physical strength': 13, 'One night, when out in a festive company, he had with one blow laid\na gigantic policeman on his back': 20, 'There was no limit to his drinking\npowers, but he could abstain from drink altogether; he sometimes went\ntoo far in his pranks; but he could do without pranks altogether': 30, 'Another thing striking about Razumihin, no failure distressed him, and\nit seemed as though no unfavourable circumstances could crush him': 20, 'He\ncould lodge anywhere, and bear the extremes of cold and hunger': 12, 'He was\nvery poor, and kept himself entirely on what he could earn by work of\none sort or another': 20, 'He knew of no end of resources by which to earn\nmoney': 12, 'He spent one whole winter without lighting his stove, and used to\ndeclare that he liked it better, because one slept more soundly in\nthe cold': 26, 'For the present he, too, had been obliged to give up the\nuniversity, but it was only for a time, and he was working with all his\nmight to save enough to return to his studies again': 37, 'Raskolnikov had\nnot been to see him for the last four months, and Razumihin did not even\nknow his address': 20, 'About two months before, they had met in the street,\nbut Raskolnikov had turned away and even crossed to the other side that\nhe might not be observed': 28, 'And though Razumihin noticed him, he passed\nhim by, as he did not want to annoy him': 17, '': 0})
('DOS CHAPTER V PART I', {'"Of course, I\'ve been meaning lately to go to Razumihin\'s to ask for\nwork, to ask him to get me lessons or something': 23, '" Raskolnikov thought,\n"but what help can he be to me now': 12, 'Suppose he gets me lessons, suppose\nhe shares his last farthing with me, if he has any farthings, so that\nI could get some boots and make myself tidy enough to give lessons': 33, 'hm': 1, 'Well and what then': 4, 'What shall I do with the few coppers I\nearn': 10, "That's not what I want now": 6, "It's really absurd for me to go to\nRazumihin": 9, '"\n\nThe question why he was now going to Razumihin agitated him even more\nthan he was himself aware; he kept uneasily seeking for some sinister\nsignificance in this apparently ordinary action': 32, '"Could I have expected to set it all straight and to find a way out by\nmeans of Razumihin alone': 20, '" he asked himself in perplexity': 6, 'He pondered and rubbed his forehead, and, strange to say, after long\nmusing, suddenly, as if it were spontaneously and by chance, a fantastic\nthought came into his head': 29, '"Hm': 1, 'to Razumihin\'s," he said all at once, calmly, as though he had\nreached a final determination': 16, '"I shall go to Razumihin\'s of course,\nbut': 8, 'not now': 2, 'I shall go to him': 5, 'on the next day after It, when It\nwill be over and everything will begin afresh': 16, '"\n\nAnd suddenly he realised what he was thinking': 9, '"After It," he shouted, jumping up from the seat, "but is It really\ngoing to happen': 16, 'Is it possible it really will happen': 7, '" He left the\nseat, and went off almost at a run; he meant to turn back, homewards,\nbut the thought of going home suddenly filled him with intense loathing;\nin that hole, in that awful little cupboard of his, all _this_ had for a\nmonth past been growing up in him; and he walked on at random': 58, 'His nervous shudder had passed into a fever that made him feel\nshivering; in spite of the heat he felt cold': 21, 'With a kind of effort he\nbegan almost unconsciously, from some inner craving, to stare at all\nthe objects before him, as though looking for something to distract his\nattention; but he did not succeed, and kept dropping every moment into\nbrooding': 42, 'When with a start he lifted his head again and looked round,\nhe forgot at once what he had just been thinking about and even where he\nwas going': 29, 'In this way he walked right across Vassilyevsky Ostrov, came\nout on to the Lesser Neva, crossed the bridge and turned towards the\nislands': 24, 'The greenness and freshness were at first restful to his weary\neyes after the dust of the town and the huge houses that hemmed him in\nand weighed upon him': 30, 'Here there were no taverns, no stifling closeness,\nno stench': 10, 'But soon these new pleasant sensations passed into morbid\nirritability': 10, 'Sometimes he stood still before a brightly painted summer\nvilla standing among green foliage, he gazed through the fence, he saw\nin the distance smartly dressed women on the verandahs and balconies,\nand children running in the gardens': 38, 'The flowers especially caught his\nattention; he gazed at them longer than at anything': 14, 'He was met, too, by\nluxurious carriages and by men and women on horseback; he watched them\nwith curious eyes and forgot about them before they had vanished from\nhis sight': 31, 'Once he stood still and counted his money; he found he had\nthirty copecks': 14, '"Twenty to the policeman, three to Nastasya for the\nletter, so I must have given forty-seven or fifty to the Marmeladovs\nyesterday," he thought, reckoning it up for some unknown reason, but he\nsoon forgot with what object he had taken the money out of his pocket': 47, 'He recalled it on passing an eating-house or tavern, and felt that he\nwas hungry': 15, 'Going into the tavern he drank a glass of vodka and ate a\npie of some sort': 17, 'He finished eating it as he walked away': 8, 'It was a long\nwhile since he had taken vodka and it had an effect upon him at once,\nthough he only drank a wineglassful': 25, 'His legs felt suddenly heavy and\na great drowsiness came upon him': 12, 'He turned homewards, but reaching\nPetrovsky Ostrov he stopped completely exhausted, turned off the road\ninto the bushes, sank down upon the grass and instantly fell asleep': 27, 'In a morbid condition of the brain, dreams often have a singular\nactuality, vividness, and extraordinary semblance of reality': 19, 'At times\nmonstrous images are created, but the setting and the whole picture are\nso truth-like and filled with details so delicate, so unexpectedly, but\nso artistically consistent, that the dreamer, were he an artist like\nPushkin or Turgenev even, could never have invented them in the waking\nstate': 49, 'Such sick dreams always remain long in the memory and make a\npowerful impression on the overwrought and deranged nervous system': 21, 'Raskolnikov had a fearful dream': 5, 'He dreamt he was back in his childhood\nin the little town of his birth': 15, 'He was a child about seven years old,\nwalking into the country with his father on the evening of a holiday': 21, 'It\nwas a grey and heavy day, the country was exactly as he remembered it;\nindeed he recalled it far more vividly in his dream than he had done in\nmemory': 31, 'The little town stood on a level flat as bare as the hand, not\neven a willow near it; only in the far distance, a copse lay, a dark\nblur on the very edge of the horizon': 37, 'A few paces beyond the last market\ngarden stood a tavern, a big tavern, which had always aroused in him a\nfeeling of aversion, even of fear, when he walked by it with his father': 35, 'There was always a crowd there, always shouting, laughter and abuse,\nhideous hoarse singing and often fighting': 17, 'Drunken and horrible-looking\nfigures were hanging about the tavern': 9, 'He used to cling close to his\nfather, trembling all over when he met them': 15, 'Near the tavern the road\nbecame a dusty track, the dust of which was always black': 16, 'It was a\nwinding road, and about a hundred paces further on, it turned to the\nright to the graveyard': 20, 'In the middle of the graveyard stood a stone\nchurch with a green cupola where he used to go to mass two or three\ntimes a year with his father and mother, when a service was held in\nmemory of his grandmother, who had long been dead, and whom he had never\nseen': 53, 'On these occasions they used to take on a white dish tied up in a\ntable napkin a special sort of rice pudding with raisins stuck in it in\nthe shape of a cross': 34, 'He loved that church, the old-fashioned, unadorned\nikons and the old priest with the shaking head': 16, "Near his grandmother's\ngrave, which was marked by a stone, was the little grave of his younger\nbrother who had died at six months old": 25, 'He did not remember him at all,\nbut he had been told about his little brother, and whenever he visited\nthe graveyard he used religiously and reverently to cross himself and\nto bow down and kiss the little grave': 39, "And now he dreamt that he was\nwalking with his father past the tavern on the way to the graveyard; he\nwas holding his father's hand and looking with dread at the tavern": 33, 'A\npeculiar circumstance attracted his attention: there seemed to be\nsome kind of festivity going on, there were crowds of gaily dressed\ntownspeople, peasant women, their husbands, and riff-raff of all sorts,\nall singing and all more or less drunk': 40, 'Near the entrance of the tavern\nstood a cart, but a strange cart': 13, 'It was one of those big carts usually\ndrawn by heavy cart-horses and laden with casks of wine or other heavy\ngoods': 22, 'He always liked looking at those great cart-horses, with their\nlong manes, thick legs, and slow even pace, drawing along a perfect\nmountain with no appearance of effort, as though it were easier going\nwith a load than without it': 40, "But now, strange to say, in the shafts of\nsuch a cart he saw a thin little sorrel beast, one of those peasants'\nnags which he had often seen straining their utmost under a heavy load\nof wood or hay, especially when the wheels were stuck in the mud or in\na rut": 53, 'And the peasants would beat them so cruelly, sometimes even\nabout the nose and eyes, and he felt so sorry, so sorry for them that\nhe almost cried, and his mother always used to take him away from the\nwindow': 40, 'All of a sudden there was a great uproar of shouting, singing\nand the balalaïka, and from
