that he could not kill her at one blow': 14, '"She\'s a tough one," was shouted in the crowd': 9, '"She\'ll fall in a minute, mates, there will soon be an end of her," said\nan admiring spectator in the crowd': 21, '"Fetch an axe to her': 5, 'Finish her off," shouted a third': 6, '"I\'ll show you': 3, 'Stand off," Mikolka screamed frantically; he threw down\nthe shaft, stooped down in the cart and picked up an iron crowbar': 21, '"Look\nout," he shouted, and with all his might he dealt a stunning blow at the\npoor mare': 18, 'The blow fell; the mare staggered, sank back, tried to pull,\nbut the bar fell again with a swinging blow on her back and she fell on\nthe ground like a log': 32, '"Finish her off," shouted Mikolka and he leapt beside himself, out of\nthe cart': 14, 'Several young men, also flushed with drink, seized anything\nthey could come across--whips, sticks, poles, and ran to the dying\nmare': 21, 'Mikolka stood on one side and began dealing random blows with the\ncrowbar': 13, 'The mare stretched out her head, drew a long breath and died': 12, '"You butchered her," someone shouted in the crowd': 8, '"Why wouldn\'t she gallop then': 5, '"\n\n"My property': 3, '" shouted Mikolka, with bloodshot eyes, brandishing the bar\nin his hands': 12, 'He stood as though regretting that he had nothing more to\nbeat': 12, '"No mistake about it, you are not a Christian," many voices were\nshouting in the crowd': 16, 'But the poor boy, beside himself, made his way, screaming, through the\ncrowd to the sorrel nag, put his arms round her bleeding dead head and\nkissed it, kissed the eyes and kissed the lips': 35, 'Then he jumped up and\nflew in a frenzy with his little fists out at Mikolka': 16, 'At that instant\nhis father, who had been running after him, snatched him up and carried\nhim out of the crowd': 21, '"Come along, come': 3, 'Let us go home," he said to him': 8, '"Father': 1, 'Why did they': 3, 'kill': 1, 'the poor horse': 3, '" he sobbed, but his\nvoice broke and the words came in shrieks from his panting chest': 17, '"They are drunk': 3, 'They are brutal': 3, "it's not our business": 4, '" said his\nfather': 4, 'He put his arms round his father but he felt choked, choked': 12, 'He\ntried to draw a breath, to cry out--and woke up': 11, 'He waked up, gasping for breath, his hair soaked with perspiration, and\nstood up in terror': 16, '"Thank God, that was only a dream," he said, sitting down under a tree\nand drawing deep breaths': 18, '"But what is it': 4, 'Is it some fever coming on': 6, 'Such a hideous dream': 4, '"\n\nHe felt utterly broken: darkness and confusion were in his soul': 12, 'He\nrested his elbows on his knees and leaned his head on his hands': 14, '"Good God': 2, '" he cried, "can it be, can it be, that I shall really take an\naxe, that I shall strike her on the head, split her skull open': 28, 'that I\nshall tread in the sticky warm blood, break the lock, steal and tremble;\nhide, all spattered in the blood': 21, 'with the axe': 3, 'Good God, can it\nbe': 5, '"\n\nHe was shaking like a leaf as he said this': 11, '"But why am I going on like this': 8, '" he continued, sitting up again, as it\nwere in profound amazement': 12, '"I knew that I could never bring myself\nto it, so what have I been torturing myself for till now': 20, 'Yesterday,\nyesterday, when I went to make that': 8, '_experiment_, yesterday I\nrealised completely that I could never bear to do it': 13, 'Why am I going\nover it again, then': 8, 'Why am I hesitating': 4, 'As I came down the stairs\nyesterday, I said myself that it was base, loathsome, vile, vile': 17, 'the\nvery thought of it made me feel sick and filled me with horror': 14, '"No, I couldn\'t do it, I couldn\'t do it': 9, 'Granted, granted that there is\nno flaw in all that reasoning, that all that I have concluded this last\nmonth is clear as day, true as arithmetic': 27, 'My God': 2, "Anyway I couldn't\nbring myself to it": 7, "I couldn't do it, I couldn't do it": 8, 'Why, why then am\nI still': 6, '"\n\nHe rose to his feet, looked round in wonder as though surprised at\nfinding himself in this place, and went towards the bridge': 24, 'He was pale,\nhis eyes glowed, he was exhausted in every limb, but he seemed suddenly\nto breathe more easily': 20, 'He felt he had cast off that fearful burden that\nhad so long been weighing upon him, and all at once there was a sense\nof relief and peace in his soul': 32, '"Lord," he prayed, "show me my path--I\nrenounce that accursed': 10, 'dream of mine': 3, '"\n\nCrossing the bridge, he gazed quietly and calmly at the Neva, at the\nglowing red sun setting in the glowing sky': 22, 'In spite of his weakness he\nwas not conscious of fatigue': 11, 'It was as though an abscess that had been\nforming for a month past in his heart had suddenly broken': 20, 'Freedom,\nfreedom': 2, 'He was free from that spell, that sorcery, that obsession': 10, 'Later on, when he recalled that time and all that happened to him during\nthose days, minute by minute, point by point, he was superstitiously\nimpressed by one circumstance, which, though in itself not very\nexceptional, always seemed to him afterwards the predestined\nturning-point of his fate': 47, 'He could never understand and explain to\nhimself why, when he was tired and worn out, when it would have been\nmore convenient for him to go home by the shortest and most direct way,\nhe had returned by the Hay Market where he had no need to go': 49, 'It was\nobviously and quite unnecessarily out of his way, though not much so': 14, 'It\nis true that it happened to him dozens of times to return home without\nnoticing what streets he passed through': 21, 'But why, he was always asking\nhimself, why had such an important, such a decisive and at the same time\nsuch an absolutely chance meeting happened in the Hay Market (where he\nhad moreover no reason to go) at the very hour, the very minute of his\nlife when he was just in the very mood and in the very circumstances\nin which that meeting was able to exert the gravest and most decisive\ninfluence on his whole destiny': 79, 'As though it had been lying in wait for\nhim on purpose': 12, "It was about nine o'clock when he crossed the Hay Market": 11, 'At the tables\nand the barrows, at the booths and the shops, all the market people were\nclosing their establishments or clearing away and packing up their\nwares and, like their customers, were going home': 35, 'Rag pickers and\ncostermongers of all kinds were crowding round the taverns in the dirty\nand stinking courtyards of the Hay Market': 22, 'Raskolnikov particularly\nliked this place and the neighbouring alleys, when he wandered aimlessly\nin the streets': 16, 'Here his rags did not attract contemptuous attention,\nand one could walk about in any attire without scandalising people': 19, 'At\nthe corner of an alley a huckster and his wife had two tables set out\nwith tapes, thread, cotton handkerchiefs, etc': 22, 'They, too, had got up to\ngo home, but were lingering in conversation with a friend, who had just\ncome up to them': 23, 'This friend was Lizaveta Ivanovna, or, as everyone\ncalled her, Lizaveta, the younger sister of the old pawnbroker, Alyona\nIvanovna, whom Raskolnikov had visited the previous day to pawn his\nwatch and make his _experiment_': 35, 'He already knew all about Lizaveta\nand she knew him a little too': 13, 'She was a single woman of about\nthirty-five, tall, clumsy, timid, submissive and almost idiotic': 15, 'She was\na complete slave and went in fear and trembling of her sister, who\nmade her work day and night, and even beat her': 25, 'She was standing with\na bundle before the huckster and his wife, listening earnestly and\ndoubtfully': 16, 'They were talking of something with special warmth': 8, 'The\nmoment Raskolnikov caught sight of her, he was overcome by a strange\nsensation as it were of intense astonishment, though there was nothing\nastonishing about this meeting': 28, '"You could make up your mind for yourself, Lizaveta Ivanovna," the\nhuckster was saying aloud': 15, '"Come round to-morrow about seven': 5, 'They will\nbe here too': 5, '"\n\n"To-morrow': 2, '" said Lizaveta slowly and thoughtfully, as though unable to\nmake up her mind': 14, '"Upon my word, what a fright you are in of Alyona Ivanovna," gabbled\nthe huckster\'s wife, a lively little woman': 20, '"I look at you, you are like\nsome little babe': 10, 'And she is not your own sister either--nothing but a\nstep-sister and what a hand she keeps over you': 19, '"\n\n"But this time don\'t say a word to Alyona Ivanovna," her husband\ninterrupted; "that\'s my advice, but come round to us without asking': 24, 'It will be worth your while': 6, 'Later on your sister herself may have a\nnotion': 9, '"\n\n"Am I to come': 5, '"\n\n"About seven o\'clock to-morrow': 5, 'And they will be here': 5, 'You will be able\nto decide for yourself': 8, '"\n\n"And we\'ll have a cup of tea," added his wife': 11, '"All right, I\'ll come," said Lizaveta, still pondering, and she began\nslowly moving away': 14, 'Raskolnikov had just passed and heard no more': 8, 'He passed softly,\nunnoticed, trying not to miss a word': 10, 'His first amazement was followed\nby a thrill of horror, like a shiver running down his spine': 17, "He had\nlearnt, he had suddenly quite unexpectedly learnt, that the next day at\nseven o'clock Lizaveta, the old woman's sister and only companion, would\nbe away from home and that therefore at seven o'clock precisely the old\nwoman _would be left alone_": 43, 'He was only a few steps from his lodging': 9, 'He went in like a man\ncondemned to death': 9, 'He thought of nothing and was incapable of thinking;\nbut he felt suddenly in his whole being that he had no more freedom\nof thought, no will, and that everything was suddenly and irrevocably\ndecided': 35, 'Certainly, if he had to wait whole years for a suitable opportunity, he\ncould not reckon on a more certain step towards the success of the plan\nthan that which had just presented itself': 34, 'In any case, it would have\nbeen difficult to find out beforehand and with certainty, with\ngreater exactness and less risk, and without dangerous inquiries and\ninvestigations, that next day at a certain time an old woman, on whose\nlife an attempt was contemplated, would be at home and entirely alone': 51})
('DOS CHAPTER VI PART I', {'Later on Raskolnikov happened to find out why the huckster and his\nwife had invited Lizaveta': 16, 'It was a very ordinary matter and there was\nnothing exceptional about it': 13, "A family who had come to the town and been\nreduced to poverty were selling their household goods and clothes, all\nwomen's things": 23, 'As the things would have fetched little in the market,\nthey were looking for a dealer': 16, "This was Lizaveta's business": 4, 'She\nundertook such jobs and was frequently employed, as she was very honest\nand always fixed a fair price and stuck to it': 23, 'She spoke as a rule\nlittle and, as we have said already, she was very submissive and timid': 18, 'But Raskolnikov had become superstitious of late': 7, 'The traces of\nsuperstition remained in him long after, and were almost ineradicable': 13, 'And in all this he was always afterwards disposed to see something\nstrange and mysterious, as it were, the presence of some peculiar\ninfluences and coincidences': 26, 'In the previous winter a student he knew\ncalled Pokorev, who had left for Harkov, had chanced in conversation to\ngive him the address of Alyona Ivanovna, the old pawnbroker, in case he\nmight want to pawn anything': 38, 'For a long while he did not go to her, for\nhe had lessons and managed to get along somehow': 20, "Six weeks ago he had\nremembered the address; he had two articles that could be pawned: his\nfather's old silver watch and a little gold ring with three red stones,\na present from his sister at parting": 37, 'He decided to take the ring': 6, 'When\nhe found the old woman he had felt an insurmountable repulsion for her\nat the first glance, though he knew nothing special about her': 25, 'He got\ntwo roubles from her and went into a miserable little tavern on his way\nhome': 17, 'He asked for tea, sat down and sank into deep thought': 11, 'A strange\nidea was pecking at his brain like a chicken in the egg, and very, very\nmuch absorbed him': 20, 'Almost beside him at the next table there was sitting a student, whom he\ndid not know and had never seen, and with him a young officer': 27, 'They had\nplayed a game of billiards and began drinking tea': 11, 'All at once he heard\nthe student mention to the officer the pawnbroker Alyona Ivanovna and\ngive him her address': 20, 'This of itself seemed strange to Raskolnikov; he\nhad just come from her and here at once he heard her name': 21, 'Of course\nit was a chance, but he could not shake off a very extraordinary\nimpression, and here someone seemed to be speaking expressly for him;\nthe student began telling his friend various details about Alyona\nIvanovna': 37, '"She is first-rate," he said': 5, '"You can always get money from her': 7, 'She is\nas rich as a Jew, she can give you five thousand roubles at a time and\nshe is not above taking a pledge for a rouble': 28, 'Lots of our fellows have\nhad dealings with her': 9, 'But she is an awful old harpy': 7, '"\n\nAnd he began describing how spiteful and uncertain she was, how if you\nwere only a day late with your interest the pledge was lost; how she\ngave a quarter of the value of an article and took five and even seven\npercent a month on it and so on': 51, 'The student chattered on, saying\nthat she had a sister Lizaveta, whom the wretched little creature was\ncontinually beating, and kept in complete bondage like a small child,\nthough Lizaveta was at least six feet high': 36, '"There\'s a phenomenon for you," cried the student and he laughed': 11, 'They began talking about Lizaveta': 5, 'The student spoke about her with a\npeculiar relish and was continually laughing and the officer listened\nwith great interest and asked him to send Lizaveta to do some mending\nfor him': 32, 'Raskolnikov did not miss a word and learned everything about\nher': 11, 'Lizaveta was younger than the old woman and was her half-sister,\nbeing the child of a different mother': 18, 'She was thirty-five': 3, 'She worked\nday and night for her sister, and besides doing the cooking and the\nwashing, she did sewing and worked as a charwoman and gave her sister\nall she earned': 31, "She did not dare to accept an order or job of any kind\nwithout her sister's permission": 17, 'The old woman had already made her\nwill, and Lizaveta knew of it, and by this will she would not get a\nfarthing; nothing but the movables, chairs and so on; all the money was\nleft to a monastery in the province of N----, that prayers might be\nsaid for her in perpetuity': 53, 'Lizaveta was of lower rank than her sister,\nunmarried and awfully uncouth in appearance, remarkably tall with long\nfeet that looked as if they were bent outwards': 27, 'She always wore battered\ngoatskin shoes, and was clean in her person': 12, 'What the student expressed\nmost surprise and amusement about was the fact that Lizaveta was\ncontinually with child': 18, '"But you say she is hideous': 6, '" observed the officer': 4, '"Yes, she is so dark-skinned and looks like a soldier dressed up, but\nyou know she is not at all hideous': 21, 'She has such a good-natured face\nand eyes': 8, 'Strikingly so': 2, 'And the proof of it is that lots of people are\nattracted by her': 14, 'She is such a soft, gentle creature, ready to put up\nwith anything, always willing, willing to do anything': 19, 'And her smile is\nreally very sweet': 7, '"\n\n"You seem to find her attractive yourself," laughed the officer': 11, '"From her queerness': 3, "No, I'll tell you what": 5, 'I could kill that damned\nold woman and make off with her money, I assure you, without the\nfaintest conscience-prick," the student added with warmth': 25, 'The officer\nlaughed again while Raskolnikov shuddered': 7, 'How strange it was': 4, '"Listen, I want to ask you a serious question," the student said hotly': 13, '"I was joking of course, but look here; on one side we have a stupid,\nsenseless, worthless, spiteful, ailing, horrid old woman, not simply\nuseless but doing actual mischief, who has not an idea what she is\nliving for herself, and who will die in a day or two in any case': 52, 'You\nunderstand': 2, 'You understand': 2, '"\n\n"Yes, yes, I understand," answered the officer, watching his excited\ncompanion attentively': 13, '"Well, listen then': 3, 'On the other side, fresh young lives thrown away for\nwant of help and by thousands, on every side': 19, "A hundred thousand good\ndeeds could be done and helped, on that old woman's money which will be\nburied in a monastery": 22, 'Hundreds, thousands perhaps, might be set on the\nright path; dozens of families saved from destitution, from ruin, from\nvice, from the Lock hospitals--and all with her money': 28, 'Kill her, take\nher money and with the help of it devote oneself to the service of\nhumanity and the good of all': 23, 'What do you think, would not one tiny\ncrime be wiped out by thousands of good deeds': 17, 'For one life thousands\nwould be saved from corruption and decay': 11, "One death, and a hundred lives\nin exchange--it's simple arithmetic": 10, 'Besides, what value has the life of\nthat sickly, stupid, ill-natured old woman in the balance of existence': 18, 'No more than the life of a louse, of a black-beetle, less in fact\nbecause the old woman is doing harm': 21, "She is wearing out the lives of\nothers; the other day she bit Lizaveta's finger out of spite; it almost\nhad to be amputated": 24, '"\n\n"Of course she does not deserve to live," remarked the officer, "but\nthere it is, it\'s nature': 18, '"\n\n"Oh, well, brother, but we have to correct and direct nature, and, but\nfor that, we should drown in an ocean of prejudice': 24, 'But for that,\nthere would never have been a single great man': 12, "They talk of\nduty, conscience--I don't want to say anything against duty and\nconscience;--but the point is, what do we mean by them": 23, 'Stay, I have\nanother question to ask you': 8, 'Listen': 1, '"\n\n"No, you stay, I\'ll ask you a question': 9, '"\n\n"Well': 2, '"\n\n"You are talking and speechifying away, but tell me, would you kill the\nold woman _yourself_': 17, '"\n\n"Of course not': 4, 'I was only arguing the justice of it': 8, "It's nothing to\ndo with me": 6, '"\n\n"But I think, if you would not do it yourself, there\'s no justice about\nit': 16, 'Let us have another game': 5, '"\n\nRaskolnikov was violently agitated': 5, 'Of course, it was all ordinary\nyouthful talk and thought, such as he had often heard before in\ndifferent forms and on different themes': 24, 'But why had he happened to hear\nsuch a discussion and such ideas at the very moment when his own brain\nwas just conceiving': 24, '_the very same ideas_': 4, 'And why, just at the\nmoment when he had brought away the embryo of his idea from the old\nwoman had he dropped at once upon a conversation about her': 30, 'This\ncoincidence always seemed strange to him': 7, 'This trivial talk in a tavern\nhad an immense influence on him in his later action; as though there had\nreally been in it something preordained, some guiding hint': 29, '*****\n\nOn returning from the Hay Market he flung himself on the sofa and sat\nfor a whole hour without stirring': 21, 'Meanwhile it got dark; he had no\ncandle and, indeed, it did not occur to him to light up': 19, 'He could never\nrecollect whether he had been thinking about anything at that time': 14, 'At\nlast he was conscious of his former fever and shivering, and he realised\nwith relief that he could lie down on the sofa': 24, 'Soon heavy, leaden sleep\ncame over him, as it were crushing him': 12, 'He slept an extraordinarily long time and without dreaming': 9, "Nastasya,\ncoming into his room at ten o'clock the next morning, had difficulty\nin rousing him": 16, 'She brought him in tea and bread': 7, 'The tea was again the\nsecond brew and again in her own tea-pot': 13, '"My goodness, how he sleeps': 5, '" she cried indignantly': 4, '"And he is always\nasleep': 5, '"\n\nHe got up with an effort': 7, 'His head ached, he stood up, took a turn in\nhis garret and sank back on the sofa again': 19, '"Going to sleep again," cried Nastasya': 6, '"Are you ill, eh': 4, '"\n\nHe made no reply': 5, '"Do you want some tea': 5, '"\n\n"Afterwards," he said with an effort, closing his eyes again and turning\nto the wall': 16, 'Nastasya stood over him': 4, '"Perhaps he really is ill," she said, turned and went out': 11, "She came in\nagain at two o'clock with soup": 9, 'He was lying as before': 5, 'The tea stood\nuntouched': 4, 'Nastasya felt positively offended and began wrathfully\nrousing him': 9, '"Why are you lying like a log': 7, '" she shouted, looking at him with\nrepulsion': 8, 'He got up, and sat down again, but said nothing and stared at the floor': 15, '"Are you ill or not': 5, '" asked Nastasya and again received no answer': 8, '"You\'d better go out and get a breath of air," she said after a pause': 15, '"Will you eat it or not': 6, '"\n\n"Afterwards," he said weakly': 5, '"You can go': 3, '"\n\nAnd he motioned her out': 6, 'She remained a little longer, looked at him with compassion and went\nout': 13, 'A few minutes afterwards, he raised his eyes and looked for a long while\nat the tea and the soup': 20, 'Then he took the bread, took up a spoon and\nbegan to eat': 13, 'He ate a little, three or four spoonfuls, without appetite, as it were\nmechanically': 14, 'His head ached less': 4, 'After his meal he stretched himself\non the sofa again, but now he could not sleep; he lay without stirring,\nwith his face in the pillow': 26, 'He was haunted by day-dreams and such\nstrange day-dreams; in one, that kept recurring, he fancied that he was\nin Africa, in Egypt, in some sort of oasis': 28, 'The caravan was resting,\nthe camels were peacefully lying down; the palms stood all around in a\ncomplete circle; all the party were at dinner': 25, 'But he was drinking water\nfrom a spring which flowed gurgling close by': 13, 'And it was so cool, it was\nwonderful, wonderful, blue, cold water running among the parti-coloured\nstones and over the clean sand which glistened here and there like\ngold': 29, 'Suddenly he heard a clock strike': 6, 'He started, roused himself,\nraised his head, looked out of the window, and seeing how late it was,\nsuddenly jumped up wide awake as though someone had pulled him off the\nsofa': 32, 'He crept on tiptoe to the door, stealthily opened it and began\nlistening on the staircase': 16, 'His heart beat terribly': 4, 'But all was quiet\non the stairs as if everyone was asleep': 12, 'It seemed to him strange and\nmonstrous that he could have slept in such forgetfulness from the\nprevious day and had done nothing, had prepared nothing yet': 27, 'And\nmeanwhile perhaps it had struck six': 7, 'And his drowsiness and stupefaction\nwere followed by an extraordinary, feverish, as it were distracted\nhaste': 16, 'But the preparations to be made were few': 8, 'He concentrated all his\nenergies on thinking of everything and forgetting nothing; and his heart\nkept beating and thumping so that he could hardly breathe': 25, 'First he had\nto make a noose and sew it into his overcoat--a work of a moment': 17, 'He\nrummaged under his pillow and picked out amongst the linen stuffed away\nunder it, a worn out, old unwashed shirt': 21, 'From its rags he tore a long\nstrip, a couple of inches wide and about sixteen inches long': 18, 'He folded\nthis strip in two, took off his wide, strong summer overcoat of some\nstout cotton material (his only outer garment) and began sewing the two\nends of the rag on the inside, under the left armhole': 38, 'His hands shook\nas he sewed, but he did it successfully so that nothing showed outside\nwhen he put the coat on again': 23, 'The needle and thread he had got ready\nlong before and they lay on his table in a piece of paper': 21, 'As for the\nnoose, it was a very ingenious device of his own; the noose was intended\nfor the axe': 20, 'It was impossible for him to carry the axe through the\nstreet in his hands': 15, 'And if hidden under his coat he would still have\nhad to support it with his hand, which would have been noticeable': 22, 'Now\nhe had only to put the head of the axe in the noose, and it would hang\nquietly under his arm on the inside': 25, 'Putting his hand in his coat\npocket, he could hold the end of the handle all the way, so that it did\nnot swing; and as the coat was very full, a regular sack in fact, it\ncould not be seen from outside that he was holding something with the\nhand that was in the pocket': 56, 'This noose, too, he had designed a\nfortnight before': 9, 'When he had finished with this, he thrust his hand into a little opening\nbetween his sofa and the floor, fumbled in the left corner and drew out\nthe _pledge_, which he had got ready long before and hidden there': 40, 'This\npledge was, however, only a smoothly planed piece of wood the size and\nthickness of a silver cigarette case': 20, 'He picked up this piece of wood\nin one of his wanderings in a courtyard where there was some sort of\na workshop': 23, 'Afterwards he had added to the wood a thin smooth piece\nof iron, which he had also picked up at the same time in the street': 26, 'Putting the iron which was a little the smaller on the piece of wood,\nhe fastened them very firmly, crossing and re-crossing the thread round\nthem; then wrapped them carefully and daintily in clean white paper and\ntied up the parcel so that it would be very difficult to untie it': 51, 'This\nwas in order to divert the attention of the old woman for a time, while\nshe was trying to undo the knot, and so to gain a moment': 29, 'The iron strip\nwas added to give weight, so that the woman might not guess the first\nminute that the "thing" was made of wood': 25, 'All this had been stored by\nhim beforehand under the sofa': 11, 'He had only just got the pledge out when\nhe heard someone suddenly about in the yard': 17, '"It struck six long ago': 5, '"\n\n"Long ago': 3, 'My God': 2, '"\n\nHe rushed to the door, listened, caught up his hat and began to descend\nhis thirteen steps cautiously, noiselessly, like a cat': 23, 'He had still the\nmost important thing to do--to steal the axe from the kitchen': 15, 'That the\ndeed must be done with an axe he had decided long ago': 14, 'He had also a\npocket pruning-knife, but he could not rely on the knife and still less\non his own strength, and so resolved finally on the axe': 28, 'We may note in\npassing, one peculiarity in regard to all the final resolutions taken by\nhim in the matter; they had one strange characteristic: the more final\nthey were, the more hideous and the more absurd they at once became in\nhis eyes': 44, 'In spite of all his agonising inward struggle, he never for\na single instant all that time could believe in the carrying out of his\nplans': 26, 'And, indeed, if it had ever happened that everything to the least point\ncould have been considered and finally settled, and no uncertainty of\nany kind had remained, he would, it seems, have renounced it all\nas something absurd, monstrous and impossible': 42, 'But a whole mass of\nunsettled points and uncertainties remained': 10, 'As for getting the axe,\nthat trifling business cost him no anxiety, for nothing could be easier': 17, 'Nastasya was continually out of the house, especially in the evenings;\nshe would run in to the neighbours or to a shop, and always left the\ndoor ajar': 28, 'It was the one thing the landlady was always scolding her\nabout': 12, 'And so, when the time came, he would only have to go quietly into\nthe kitchen and to take the axe, and an hour later (when everything\nwas over) go in and put it back again': 36, 'But these were doubtful points': 5, 'Supposing he returned an hour later to put it back, and Nastasya had\ncome back and was on the spot': 20, 'He would of course have to go by and wait\ntill she went out again': 15, 'But supposing she were in the meantime to miss\nthe axe, look for it, make an outcry--that would mean suspicion or at\nleast grounds for suspicion': 26, 'But those were all trifles which he had not even begun to consider, and\nindeed he had no time': 19, 'He was thinking of the chief point, and put off\ntrifling details, until _he could believe in it all_': 19, 'But that seemed\nutterly unattainable': 5, 'So it seemed to himself at least': 7, 'He could not\nimagine, for instance, that he would sometime leave off thinking, get\nup and simply go there': 19, 'Even his late experiment (i': 5, 'e': 1, 'his visit with\nthe object of a final survey of the place) was simply an attempt at\nan experiment, far from being the real thing, as though one should say\n"come, let us go and try it--why dream about it': 40, '"--and at once he\nhad broken down and had run away cursing, in a frenzy with himself': 17, 'Meanwhile it would seem, as regards the moral question, that his\nanalysis was complete; his casuistry had become keen as a razor, and he\ncould not find rational objections in himself': 31, 'But in the last resort\nhe simply ceased to believe in himself, and doggedly, slavishly sought\narguments in all directions, fumbling for them, as though someone were\nforcing and drawing him to it': 33, 'At first--long before indeed--he had been much occupied with one\nquestion; why almost all crimes are so badly concealed and so easily\ndetected, and why almost all criminals leave such obvious traces': 32, 'He\nhad come gradually to many different and curious conclusions, and in his\nopinion the chief reason lay not so much in the material impossibility\nof concealing the crime, as in the criminal himself': 34, 'Almost every\ncriminal is subject to a failure of will and reasoning power by a\nchildish and phenomenal heedlessness, at the very instant when prudence\nand caution are most essential': 30, 'It was his conviction that this eclipse\nof reason and failure of will power attacked a man like a disease,\ndeveloped gradually and reached its highest point just before the\nperpetration of the crime, continued with equal violence at the moment\nof the crime and for longer or shorter time after, according to the\nindividual case, and then passed off like any other disease': 64, 'The\nquestion whether the disease gives rise to the crime, or whether the\ncrime from its own peculiar nature is always accompanied by something of\nthe nature of disease, he did not yet feel able to decide': 37, 'When he reached these conclusions, he decided that in his own case there\ncould not be such a morbid reaction, that his reason and will would\nremain unimpaired at the time of carrying out his design, for the\nsimple reason that his design was "not a crime': 47, '" We will omit all the\nprocess by means of which he arrived at this last conclusion; we have\nrun too far ahead already': 24, 'We may add only that the practical, purely\nmaterial difficulties of the affair occupied a secondary position in his\nmind': 20, '"One has but to keep all one\'s will-power and reason to deal\nwith them, and they will all be overcome at the time when once one has\nfamiliarised oneself with the minutest details of the business': 36, '" But\nthis preparation had never been begun': 8, 'His final decisions were what he\ncame to trust least, and when the hour struck, it all came to pass quite\ndifferently, as it were accidentally and unexpectedly': 28, 'One trifling circumstance upset his calculations, before he had even\nleft the staircase': 13, "When he reached the landlady's kitchen, the door\nof which was open as usual, he glanced cautiously in to see whether, in\nNastasya's absence, the landlady herself was there, or if not, whether\nthe door to her own room was closed, so that she might not peep out when\nhe went in for the axe": 55, 'But what was his amazement when he suddenly\nsaw that Nastasya was not only at home in the kitchen, but was occupied\nthere, taking linen out of a basket and hanging it on a line': 35, 'Seeing\nhim, she left off hanging the clothes, turned to him and stared at him\nall the time he was passing': 21, 'He turned away his eyes, and walked past as\nthough he noticed nothing': 13, 'But it was the end of everything; he had not\nthe axe': 12, 'He was overwhelmed': 3, '"What made me think," he reflected, as he went under the gateway, "what\nmade me think that she would be sure not to be at home at that moment': 29, 'Why, why, why did I assume this so certainly': 9, '"\n\nHe was crushed and even humiliated': 7, 'He could have laughed at himself in\nhis anger': 9, 'A dull animal rage boiled within him': 7, 'He stood hesitating in the gateway': 6, "To go into the street, to go a walk\nfor appearance' sake was revolting; to go back to his room, even more\nrevolting": 23, '"And what a chance I have lost for ever': 9, '" he muttered,\nstanding aimlessly in the gateway, just opposite the porter\'s little\ndark room, which was also open': 19, 'Suddenly he started': 3, "From the porter's\nroom, two paces away from him, something shining under the bench to the\nright caught his eye": 20, 'He looked about him--nobody': 4, 'He approached the\nroom on tiptoe, went down two steps into it and in a awakening\nsuspicion': 12, 'He scarcely looked at the passers-by, tried to escape looking\nat their faces at all, and to be as little noticeable as possible': 23, 'Suddenly he thought of his hat': 6, their refreshing effect on the atmosphere in all\nthe squares': 29, 'By degrees he passed to the conviction that if the summer\ngarden were extended to the field of Mars, and perhaps joined to the\ngarden of the Mihailovsky Palace, it would be a splendid thing and a\ngreat benefit to the town': 42, 'Then he was interested by the question why\nin all great towns men are not simply driven by for him, everything went well again at the gates': 11, 'At that very\nmoment, as though expressly for his benefit, a huge waggon of hay had\njust driven in at the gate, completely screening him as he ('DOS CHAPTER VII PART I', {'The door was as before opened a tiny crack, and again two sharp and\nsuspicious eyes stared at him out of the darkness': 23, 'Then Raskolnikov lost\nhis head and nearly made a great mistake': 11, 'Fearing the old woman would be frightened by their being alone, and not\nhoping that the sight of him would disarm her suspicions, he took\nhold of the door and drew it towards him to prevent the old woman from\nattempting to shut it again': 45, 'Seeing this she did not pull the door back,\nbut she did not let go the handle so that he almost dragged her out with\nit on to the stairs': 30, 'Seeing that she was standing in the doorway not\nallowing him to pass, he advanced straight upon her': 18, 'She stepped back\nin alarm, tried to say something, but seemed unable to speak and stared\nwith open eyes at him': 21, '"Good evening, Alyona Ivanovna," he began, trying to speak easily, but\nhis voice would not obey him, it broke and shook': 21, '"I have come': 3, 'I have\nbrought something': 4, "but we'd better come in": 5, 'to the light': 3, '"\n\nAnd leaving her, he passed straight into the room uninvited': 11, 'The old\nwoman ran after him; her tongue was unloosed': 10, '"Good heavens': 2, 'What it is': 3, 'Who is it': 3, 'What do you want': 4, '"\n\n"Why, Alyona Ivanovna, you know me': 7, 'Raskolnikov': 1, 'here, I brought you\nthe pledge I promised the other day': 11, '" And he held out the pledge': 7, 'The old woman glanced for a moment at the pledge, but at once stared in\nthe eyes of her uninvited visitor': 21, 'She looked intently, maliciously and\nmistrustfully': 6, 'A minute passed; he even fancied something like a sneer\nin her eyes, as though she had already guessed everything': 20, 'He felt that\nhe was losing his head, that he was almost frightened, so frightened\nthat if she were to look like that and not say a word for another half\nminute, he thought he would have run away from her': 41, '"Why do you look at me as though you did not know me': 13, '" he said suddenly,\nalso with malice': 7, '"Take it if you like, if not I\'ll go elsewhere, I am\nin a hurry': 15, '"\n\nHe had not even thought of saying this, but it was suddenly said of\nitself': 16, "The old woman recovered herself, and her visitor's resolute tone\nevidently restored her confidence": 14, '"But why, my good sir, all of a minute': 9, 'What is it': 3, '" she asked,\nlooking at the pledge': 7, '"The silver cigarette case; I spoke of it last time, you know': 12, '"\n\nShe held out her hand': 6, '"But how pale you are, to be sure': 8, 'and your hands are trembling too': 6, 'Have you been bathing, or what': 6, '"\n\n"Fever," he answered abruptly': 5, '"You can\'t help getting pale': 5, 'if you\'ve\nnothing to eat," he added, with difficulty articulating the words': 12, 'His strength was failing him again': 6, 'But his answer sounded like the\ntruth; the old woman took the pledge': 13, '"What is it': 3, '" she asked once more, scanning Raskolnikov intently, and\nweighing the pledge in her hand': 15, '"A thing': 2, 'cigarette case': 2, 'Silver': 1, 'Look at it': 3, '"\n\n"It does not seem somehow like silver': 8, 'How he has wrapped it up': 6, '"\n\nTrying to untie the string and turning to the window, to the light (all\nher windows were shut, in spite of the stifling heat), she left\nhim altogether for some seconds and stood with her back to him': 39, 'He\nunbuttoned his coat and freed the axe from the noose, but did not yet\ntake it out altogether, simply holding it in his right hand under the\ncoat': 29, 'His hands were fearfully weak, he felt them every moment growing\nmore numb and more wooden': 16, 'He was afraid he would let the axe slip and\nfall': 11, 'A sudden giddiness came over him': 6, '"But what has he tied it up like this for': 10, '" the old woman cried with\nvexation and moved towards him': 11, 'He had not a minute more to lose': 8, 'He pulled the axe quite out, swung\nit with both arms, scarcely conscious of himself, and almost without\neffort, almost mechanically, brought the blunt side down on her head': 29, 'He\nseemed not to use his own strength in this': 10, 'But as soon as he had once\nbrought the axe down, his strength returned to him': 16, 'The old woman was as always bareheaded': 7, "Her thin, light hair, streaked\nwith grey, thickly smeared with grease, was plaited in a rat's tail and\nfastened by a broken horn comb which stood out on the nape of her neck": 33, 'As she was so short, the blow fell on the very top of her skull': 15, 'She\ncried out, but very faintly, and suddenly sank all of a heap on the\nfloor, raising her hands to her head': 22, 'In one hand she still held "the\npledge': 8, '" Then he dealt her another and another blow with the blunt side\nand on the same spot': 18, 'The blood gushed as from an overturned glass, the\nbody fell back': 12, 'He stepped back, let it fall, and at once bent over her\nface; she was dead': 16, 'Her eyes seemed to be starting out of their sockets,\nthe brow and the whole face were drawn and contorted convulsively': 21, 'He laid the axe on the ground near the dead body and felt at once in her\npocket (trying to his\nhands were still trembling': 19, 'He remembered afterwards that he had been\nparticularly collected and careful, trying all the time not to get\nsmeared with blood': 21, 'He pulled out the keys other wall stood a big bed, very clean and covered with\na silk patchwork wadded quilt': 18, 'Against a third wall was a chest of\ndrawers': 9, 'Strange to say, so soon as he began to fit the keys it was too late to go back': 14, 'He positively smiled at himself, when suddenly another terrifying idea\noccurred to his mind': 14, 'He suddenly fancied that the old woman might be\nstill alive and might recover her senses': 16, 'Leaving the keys in the chest,\nhe ran back to the body, snatched up the axe and lifted it once more\nover the old woman, but did not bring it down': 31, 'There was no doubt that\nshe was dead': 8, 'Bending down and examining her again more closely, he saw\nclearly that the skull was broken and even battered in on one side': 23, 'He\nwas about to feel it with his finger, but drew back his hand and indeed\nit was evident without that': 21, 'Meanwhile there was a perfect pool of\nblood': 8, 'All at once he noticed a string on her neck; he tugged at it, but\nthe string was strong and did not snap and besides, it was soaked\nwith blood': 30, 'He tried to pull it out from the front of the dress, but\nsomething held it and prevented its coming': 20, "In his impatience he raised\nthe axe again to cut the string from above on the body, but did not\ndare, and with difficulty, smearing his hand and the axe in the blood,\nafter two minutes' hurried effort, he cut the string and took it off\nwithout touching the body with the axe; he was not mistaken--it was a\npurse": 60, 'On the string were two crosses, one of Cyprus wood and one of\ncopper, and an image in silver filigree, and with them a small greasy\nchamois leather purse with a steel rim and ring': 35, "The purse was stuffed\nvery full; Raskolnikov thrust it in his pocket without looking at them\nagain': 14, 'But he was unsuccessful': 4, 'They would not fit in the locks': 7, 'It\nwas not so much that his hands were shaking, but that he kept making\nmistakes; though he saw for instance that a key was not the right one\nand would not fit, still he tried to put it in': 40, 'Suddenly he remembered\nand realised that the big key with the deep notches, which was hanging\nthere with the small keys could not possibly belong to the chest of\ndrawers (on his last visit this had struck him), but to some strong box,\nand that everything perhaps was hidden in that box': 52, 'He left the senses': 9, '" he thought with terror': 5, 'But no sooner did he touch the clothes than a gold watch slipped from\nunder the fur coat': 18, 'He made haste to turn them all over': 8, 'There turned\nout others simply\nwrapped in newspaper, carefully and exactly folded, and tied round with\ntape': 18, 'Without any delay, he began filling up the pockets of his trousers\nand overcoat without examining or undoing the parcels and cases; but he\nhad not time to take many': 30, 'He suddenly heard steps in the room where the old woman lay': 12, 'He stopped\nshort and was still as death': 8, 'But all was quiet, so it must have been\nhis fancy': 11, 'All at once he heard distinctly a faint cry, as though\nsomeone had uttered a low broken moan': 18, 'Then again dead silence for\na minute or two': 9, 'He crushed and scared that she did not\neven raise a hand to guard her face, though that was the most necessary\nand natural action at the moment, for the axe was raised over her face': 47, 'She only put him, especially after this\nsecond, quite unexpected murder': 15, 'He longed to run away from the place\nas fast as possible': 12, 'And if at that moment he had been capable of seeing\nand reasoning give himself up, and\nnot from fear, but from simple horror and loathing of what he had\ndone': 102, 'The feeling of loathing especially surged up within him and grew\nstronger every minute': 14, 'He would not now have gone to the box or even\ninto the room for anything in the world': 19, 'But a sort of blankness, even dreaminess, had begun by degrees to take\npossession of him; at moments he began washing his hands\nin the bucket': 32, 'When they were clean, he took out the axe, washed the\nblade and spent a long time, about three minutes, washing the wood where\nthere were spots of blood rubbing them with soap': 33, 'Then he wiped it all\nwith some linen that was hanging to dry on a line in the kitchen and\nthen he was a long while attentively examining the axe at the window': 33, such\na noise': 9, '" flashed through his mind': 5, 'Once more he closed the door and\nwaited': 8, 'At last all was still, not a soul stirring': 9, 'He was just taking a\nstep towards the stairs when and cannot even move one's arms": 44, 'At last when the unknown was mounting to the fourth floor, he suddenly\nstarted, and succeeded in slipping neatly and quickly back into the\nflat and closing the ('DOS CHAPTER I PART II', {'So he lay a very long while': 7, 'Now and then he seemed to wake up, and at\nsuch moments he noticed that it was far into the night, but it did not\noccur to him to get up': 31, 'At last he noticed that it was beginning to get\nlight': 11, 'He was lying on his back, still dazed from his recent oblivion': 12, "Fearful, despairing cries rose shrilly from the street, sounds which he\nheard every night, indeed, under his window after two o'clock": 21, 'They woke\nhim up now': 5, '"Ah': 1, 'the drunken men are coming out of the taverns," he thought, "it\'s\npast two o\'clock," and at once he leaped up, as though someone had\npulled him from the sofa': 30, '"What': 1, "Past two o'clock": 3, '"\n\nHe sat down on the sofa--and instantly recollected everything': 10, 'All at\nonce, in one flash, he recollected everything': 9, 'For the first moment he thought he was going mad': 10, 'A dreadful chill came\nover him; but the chill was from the fever that had begun long before in\nhis sleep': 21, 'Now he was suddenly taken with violent shivering, so that his\nteeth chattered and all his limbs were shaking': 19, 'He opened the door and\nbegan listening--everything in the house was asleep': 12, 'With amazement he\ngazed at himself and everything in the room around him, wondering how he\ncould have come in the night before without fastening the door, and have\nflung himself on the sofa without undressing, without even taking his\nhat off': 42, 'It had fallen off and was lying on the floor near his pillow': 13, '"If anyone had come in, what would he have thought': 10, "That I'm drunk\nbut": 4, '"\n\nHe rushed to the window': 6, 'There was light enough, and he began hurriedly\nlooking himself all over from head to foot, all his threads and rags, and mistrusting himself, went through\nhis search three times': 19, 'But there seemed to be nothing, no trace, except in one place, where\nsome thick drops of congealed blood were wide open': 9, 'Peasants stood waiting within': 4, 'There,\ntoo, the heat was stifling and there was a sickening smell of fresh\npaint and stale oil from the newly decorated rooms': 23, 'After waiting second room some\nclerks sat writing, dressed hardly better than he was, and rather a\nqueer-looking set': 19, 'He went up to one of them': 7, '"What is it': 3, '"\n\nHe showed the notice he had received': 8, '"You are a student': 4, '" the man asked, glancing at the notice': 8, '"Yes, formerly a student': 4, '"\n\nThe clerk looked at him, but without the slightest interest': 11, 'He was a\nparticularly unkempt person with the look of a fixed idea in his eye': 16, '"There would be no getting anything out of him, because he has no\ninterest in anything," thought Raskolnikov': 18, '"Go in there to the head clerk," said the clerk, pointing towards the\nfurthest room': 15, 'He went into that room--the fourth in order; it was a small room and\npacked full of people, rather better dressed than in the outer rooms': 26, 'Among them were two ladies': 5, 'One, poorly dressed in mourning, sat at the\ntable opposite the chief clerk, writing something at his dictation': 18, 'The other, a very stout, buxom woman with a purplish-red, blotchy face,\nexcessively smartly dressed with a brooch on her bosom as big as a\nsaucer, was standing on one side, apparently waiting for something': 35, 'Raskolnikov thrust his notice upon the head clerk': 8, 'The latter glanced\nat it, said: "Wait a minute," and went on attending to the lady in\nmourning': 18, 'He breathed more freely': 4, '"It can\'t be that': 4, '"\n\nBy degrees he began to regain confidence, he kept urging himself to have\ncourage and be calm': 18, '"Some foolishness, some trifling carelessness, and I may betray myself': 10, 'Hm': 1, 'it\'s a pity there\'s no air here," he added, "it\'s stifling': 11, "It\nmakes one's head dizzier than ever": 7, "and one's mind too": 4, '"\n\nHe was conscious of a terrible inner turmoil': 9, 'He was afraid of losing\nhis self-control; he tried to catch at something and fix his mind on it,\nsomething quite irrelevant, but he could not succeed in this at all': 31, 'Yet\nthe head clerk greatly interested him, he kept hoping to see through him\nand guess something from his face': 20, 'He was a very young man, about two and twenty, with a dark mobile\nface that looked older than his years': 21, 'He was fashionably dressed and\nfoppish, with his hair parted in the middle, well combed and pomaded,\nand wore a number of rings on his well-scrubbed fingers and a gold chain\non his waistcoat': 34, 'He said a couple of words in French to a foreigner who\nwas in the room, and said them fairly correctly': 21, '"Luise Ivanovna, you can sit down," he said casually to the\ngaily-dressed, purple-faced lady, who was still standing as though not\nventuring to sit down, though there was a chair beside her': 32, '"Ich danke," said the latter, and softly, with a rustle of silk she sank\ninto the chair': 17, 'Her light blue dress trimmed with white lace floated\nabout the table like an air-balloon and filled almost half the room': 21, 'She\nsmelt of scent': 4, 'But she was obviously embarrassed at filling half\nthe room and smelling so strongly of scent; and though her smile was\nimpudent as well as cringing, it betrayed evident uneasiness': 30, 'The lady in mourning had done at last, and got up': 11, 'All at once, with\nsome noise, an officer walked in very jauntily, with a peculiar swing of\nhis shoulders at each step': 22, 'He tossed his cockaded cap on the table and\nsat down in an easy-chair': 14, 'The small lady positively skipped from her\nseat on seeing him, and fell to curtsying in a sort of ecstasy; but the\nofficer took not the smallest notice of her, and she did not venture to\nsit down again in his presence': 42, 'He was the assistant superintendent': 5, 'He\nhad a reddish moustache that stood out horizontally on each ('DOS CHAPTER II PART II', {'"And what if there has been a search already': 9, 'What if I find them in my\nroom': 8, '"\n\nBut here was his room': 6, 'Nothing and no one in it': 6, 'No one had peeped in': 5, 'Even Nastasya had not touched it': 6, 'But heavens': 2, 'how could he have left\nall those things in the hole': 11, 'He rushed to the corner, slipped his hand under the paper, pulled the\nthings out and lined his pockets with them': 21, 'There were eight articles in\nall: two little boxes with ear-rings or something of the sort, he hardly\nlooked to see; then four small leather cases': 26, 'There was a chain, too,\nmerely wrapped in newspaper and something else in newspaper, that looked\nlike a decoration': 19, 'He put them all in the different pockets of his\novercoat, and the remaining pocket of his trousers, trying to conceal\nthem as much as possible': 26, 'He took the purse, too': 5, 'Then he went out of\nhis room, leaving the door open': 11, 'He walked quickly and resolutely, and\nthough he felt shattered, he had his senses about him': 16, 'He was afraid of\npursuit, he was afraid that in another half-hour, another quarter of an\nhour perhaps, instructions would be issued for his pursuit, and so at\nall costs, he must hide all traces before then': 37, 'He must clear everything\nup while he still had some strength, some reasoning power left him': 16, 'Where was he to go': 5, 'That had long been settled: "Fling them into the canal, and all traces\nhidden in the water, the thing would be at an end': 24, '" So he had decided in\nthe night of his delirium when several times he had had the impulse to\nget up and go away, to make haste, and get rid of it all': 34, 'But to get\nrid of it, turned out to be a very difficult task': 14, "He wandered along\nthe bank of the Ekaterininsky Canal for half an hour or more and looked\nseveral times at the steps running down to the water, but he could not\nthink of carrying out his plan; either rafts stood at the steps' edge,\nand women were washing clothes on them, or boats were moored there, and\npeople were swarming everywhere": 61, 'Moreover he could be seen and noticed\nfrom the banks on all sides; it would look suspicious for a man to go\ndown on purpose, stop, and throw something into the water': 32, 'And what if\nthe boxes were to float instead of sinking': 11, 'And of course they would': 5, 'Even as it was, everyone he met seemed to stare and look round, as if\nthey had nothing to do but to watch him': 24, '"Why is it, or can it be my\nfancy': 9, '" he thought': 3, 'At last the thought struck him that it might be better to go to the\nNeva': 16, 'There were not so many people there, he would be less observed,\nand it would be more convenient in every way, above all it was further\noff': 27, 'He wondered how he could have been wandering for a good half-hour,\nworried and anxious in this dangerous past without thinking of it\nbefore': 24, 'And that half-hour he had lost over an irrational plan, simply\nbecause he had thought of it in delirium': 19, 'He had become extremely absent\nand forgetful and he was aware of it': 13, 'He certainly must make haste': 5, 'He walked towards the Neva along V---- Prospect, but on the way\nanother idea struck him': 16, '"Why to the Neva': 4, 'Would it not be better to go\nsomewhere far off, to the Islands again, and there hide the things\nin some solitary place, in a wood or under a bush, and mark the spot\nperhaps': 35, '" And though he felt incapable of clear judgment, the idea\nseemed to him a sound one': 17, 'But he was not destined to go there': 8, 'For\ncoming out of V---- Prospect towards the square, he saw on the left a\npassage leading between two blank walls to a courtyard': 24, 'On the right\nhand, the blank unwhitewashed wall of a four-storied house stretched far\ninto the court; on the left, a wooden hoarding ran parallel with it for\ntwenty paces into the court, and then turned sharply to the left': 40, 'Here\nwas a deserted fenced-off place where rubbish of different sorts was\nlying': 13, 'At the end of the court, the corner of a low, smutty, stone shed,\napparently part of some workshop, peeped from behind the hoarding': 24, "It\nwas probably a carriage builder's or carpenter's shed; the whole place\nfrom the entrance was black with coal dust": 20, 'Here would be the place to\nthrow it, he thought': 10, 'Not seeing anyone in the yard, he slipped in, and\nat once saw near the gate a sink, such as is often put in yards where\nthere are many workmen or cab-drivers; and on the hoarding above had\nbeen scribbled in chalk the time-honoured witticism, "Standing here\nstrictly forbidden': 49, '" This was all the better, for there would be nothing\nsuspicious about his going in': 16, '"Here I could throw it all in a heap and\nget away': 12, '"\n\nLooking round once more, with his hand already in his pocket, he noticed\nagainst the outer wall, between the entrance and the sink, a big unhewn\nstone, weighing perhaps sixty pounds': 32, 'The other side of the wall was a\nstreet': 9, 'He could hear passers-by, always numerous in that part, but he\ncould not be seen from the entrance, unless someone came in from the\nstreet, which might well happen indeed, so there was need of haste': 36, 'He bent down over the stone, seized the top of it firmly in both hands,\nand using all his strength turned it over': 23, 'Under the stone was a small\nhollow in the ground, and he immediately emptied his pocket into it': 18, 'The purse lay at the top, and yet the hollow was not filled up': 14, 'Then he\nseized the stone again and with one twist turned it back, so that it was\nin the same position again, though it stood a very little higher': 29, 'But\nhe scraped the earth about it and pressed it at the edges with his foot': 16, 'Nothing could be noticed': 4, 'Then he went out, and turned into the square': 9, 'Again an intense,\nalmost unbearable joy overwhelmed him for an instant, as it had in\nthe police-office': 17, '"I have buried my tracks': 5, 'And who, who can think of\nlooking under that stone': 10, 'It has been lying there most likely ever since\nthe house was built, and will lie as many years more': 20, 'And if it were\nfound, who would think of me': 10, 'It is all over': 4, 'No clue': 2, '" And he laughed': 4, 'Yes, he remembered that he began laughing a thin, nervous noiseless\nlaugh, and went on laughing all the time he was crossing the square': 24, 'But\nwhen he reached the K---- Boulevard where two days before he had come\nupon that girl, his laughter suddenly ceased': 21, 'Other ideas crept into his\nmind': 6, 'He felt all at once that it would be loathsome to pass that seat\non which after the girl was gone, he had sat and pondered, and that it\nwould be hateful, too, to meet that whiskered policeman to whom he had\ngiven the twenty copecks: "Damn him': 48, '"\n\nHe walked, looking about him angrily and distractedly': 9, 'All his ideas now\nseemed to be circling round some single point, and he felt that there\nreally was such a point, and that now, now, he was left facing that\npoint--and for the first time, indeed, during the last two months': 42, '"Damn it all': 3, '" he thought suddenly, in a fit of ungovernable fury': 10, '"If it has begun, then it has begun': 8, 'Hang the new life': 4, 'Good Lord, how\nstupid it is': 6, 'And what lies I told to-day': 6, 'How despicably I fawned\nupon that wretched Ilya Petrovitch': 9, 'But that is all folly': 5, 'What do I\ncare for them all, and my fawning upon them': 12, 'It is not that at all': 6, 'It\nis not that at all': 6, '"\n\nSuddenly he stopped; a new utterly unexpected and exceedingly simple\nquestion perplexed and bitterly confounded him': 17, '"If it all has really been done deliberately and not idiotically, if\nI really had a certain and definite object, how is it I did not even\nglance into the purse and don\'t know what I had there, for which I have\nundergone these agonies, and have deliberately undertaken this base,\nfilthy degrading business': 54, 'And here I wanted at once to throw into the\nwater the purse together with all the things which I had not seen\neither': 24, "how's that": 2, '"\n\nYes, that was so, that was all so': 9, 'Yet he had known it all before, and\nit was not a new question for him, even when it was decided in the night\nwithout hesitation and consideration, as though so it must be, as though\nit could not possibly be otherwise': 42, 'Yes, he had known it all, and\nunderstood it all; it surely had all been settled even yesterday at the\nmoment when he was bending over the box and pulling the jewel-cases out\nof it': 35, 'Yes, so it was': 4, '"It is because I am very ill," he decided grimly at last, "I have been\nworrying and fretting myself, and I don\'t know what I am doing': 27, 'Yesterday and the day before yesterday and all this time I have been\nworrying myself': 15, 'I shall get well and I shall not worry': 9, "But what\nif I don't get well at all": 9, 'Good God, how sick I am of it all': 9, '"\n\nHe walked on without resting': 6, 'He had a terrible longing for some\ndistraction, but he did not know what to do, what to attempt': 19, 'A new\noverwhelming sensation was gaining more and more mastery over him\nevery moment; this was an immeasurable, almost 15, 'If anyone had addressed him, he felt that he\nmight have spat at him or bitten him': 17, 'He stopped suddenly, on coming out on the bank of the Little Neva, near\nthe bridge to Vassilyevsky the palace': 22, 'The sky was without\na cloud and the water was almost bright blue, which is so rare in the\nNeva': 20, 'The cupola of the cathedral, which is seen at its best from the\nbridge about was attending the university, he had\nhundreds of times--generally on his way home--stood still on this spot,\ngazed at this truly magnificent spectacle and almost always marvelled at\na vague and mysterious emotion it roused in him': 39, 'It left him strangely\ncold; this gorgeous picture was for him blank and lifeless': 14, 'He wondered\nevery time at his sombre and enigmatic impression and, ('DOS CHAPTER III PART II', {'He was not completely unconscious, however, all the time he was ill; he\nwas in a feverish state, sometimes delirious, sometimes half conscious': 23, 'He remembered a great deal afterwards': 6, 'Sometimes it seemed as though\nthere were a number of people round him; they wanted to take him away\nsomewhere, there was a great deal of squabbling and discussing about\nhim': 31, 'Then he would be alone in the room; they had all gone away afraid\nof him, and only now and then opened the door a crack to look at him;\nthey threatened him, plotted something together, laughed, and mocked\nat him': 41, 'He remembered Nastasya often at his bedside; he distinguished\nanother person, too, whom he seemed to know very well, though he could\nnot remember who he was, and this fretted him, even made him cry': 35, 'Sometimes he fancied he had been lying there a month; at other times\nit all seemed part of the same day': 21, 'But of _that_--of _that_ he had\nno recollection, and yet every minute he felt that he had forgotten\nsomething he ought to remember': 23, 'He worried and tormented himself trying\nto remember, moaned, flew into a rage, or sank into awful, intolerable\nterror': 19, 'Then he struggled to get up, would have run away, but someone\nalways prevented him by force, and he sank back into impotence and\nforgetfulness': 25, 'At last he returned to complete consciousness': 7, "It happened at ten o'clock in the morning": 8, 'On fine days the sun shone\ninto the room at that hour, throwing a streak of light on the right\nwall and the corner near the door': 27, 'Nastasya was standing beside him\nwith another person, a complete stranger, who was looking at him\nvery inquisitively': 18, 'He was a young man with a beard, wearing a full,\nshort-waisted coat, and looked like a messenger': 18, 'The landlady was\npeeping in at the half-opened door': 9, 'Raskolnikov sat up': 3, '"Who is this, Nastasya': 4, '" he asked, pointing to the young man': 8, '"I say, he\'s himself again': 5, '" she said': 3, '"He is himself," echoed the man': 6, 'Concluding that he had returned to his senses, the landlady closed the\ndoor and disappeared': 15, 'She was always shy and dreaded conversations or\ndiscussions': 9, 'She was a woman of forty, not at all bad-looking, fat\nand buxom, with black eyes and eyebrows, good-natured from fatness and\nlaziness, and absurdly bashful': 26, '"Who': 1, 'are you': 2, '" he went on, addressing the man': 7, 'But at that moment\nthe door was flung open, and, stooping a little, as he was so tall,\nRazumihin came in': 21, '"What a cabin it is': 5, '" he cried': 3, '"I am always knocking my head': 6, 'You call\nthis a lodging': 5, 'So you are conscious, brother': 5, "I've just heard the news\nfrom Pashenka": 7, '"\n\n"He has just come to," said Nastasya': 8, '"Just come to," echoed the man again, with a smile': 10, '"And who are you': 4, '" Razumihin asked, suddenly addressing him': 6, '"My name is\nVrazumihin, at your service; not Razumihin, as I am always called, but\nVrazumihin, a student and gentleman; and he is my friend': 25, 'And who are\nyou': 4, '"\n\n"I am the messenger from our office, from the merchant Shelopaev, and\nI\'ve come on business': 17, '"\n\n"Please sit down': 4, '" Razumihin seated himself on the other side of the\ntable': 11, '"It\'s a good thing you\'ve come to, brother," he went on to\nRaskolnikov': 13, '"For the last four days you have scarcely eaten or drunk\nanything': 12, 'We had to give you tea in spoonfuls': 8, 'I brought Zossimov to see\nyou twice': 7, 'You remember Zossimov': 3, 'He examined you carefully and said at\nonce it was nothing serious--something seemed to have gone to your head': 19, "Some nervous nonsense, the result of bad feeding, he says you have not\nhad enough beer and radish, but it's nothing much, it will pass and you\nwill be all right": 31, 'Zossimov is a first-rate fellow': 5, 'He is making quite a\nname': 6, 'Come, I won\'t keep you," he said, addressing the man again': 11, '"Will\nyou explain what you want': 6, 'You must know, Rodya, this is the second time\nthey have sent from the office; Semyonovitch; he is in our office, too': 10, '"\n\n"He was more intelligent than you, don\'t you think so': 11, '"\n\n"Yes, indeed, sir, he is of more weight than I am': 12, '"\n\n"Quite so; go on': Raskolnikov': 33, '"If you are in\nan intelligible condition, I\'ve thirty-five roubles to remit to you, as\nSemyon Semyonovitch has received from Afanasy Ivanovitch at your mamma\'s\nrequest '"\n\n"Very well': 3, '"\n\nRaskolnikov looked at all this with profound astonishment and a dull,\nunreasoning terror': 14, 'He made up his mind to keep quiet and see what\nwould happen': 13, '"I as though this process was the principal and most effective\nmeans towards his friend's recovery": 43, 'Raskolnikov said nothing and made\nno resistance, though he felt quite strong enough to sit up on the sofa\nwithout support and could not merely have held a cup or a spoon, but\neven perhaps could have walked about': 39, 'But from some queer, almost\nanimal, cunning he conceived the idea of hiding his strength and lying\nlow for a time, pretending if necessary not to be yet in full possession\nof his faculties, and meanwhile listening to find out what was going on': 44, 'Yet he could not overcome his sense of repugnance': 9, 'After sipping a dozen\nspoonfuls of tea, he suddenly released his head, pushed the spoon away\ncapriciously, and sank back on the pillow': 23, 'There were that when's it's worn out, they will\ngive you another next year": 17, 'Yes, on my word': 4, 'Well, now let us pass to\nthe United States of America, as they called them at school': 17, 'I assure\nyou world is always to keep to the\nseasons; if you don't insist on having asparagus in January, you keep\nyour money in your purse; and it's the same with this purchase": 45, "It's\nsummer now, so I've been buying summer things--warmer materials will be\nwanted for autumn, so you will have to throw these away in any case": 26, 'especially as they will be done for by then from their own lack from this monster': 11, 'We all did our best': 5, 'And as to your linen, your landlady has seen to that': 11, 'Here, to begin\nwith are three shirts, hempen but with a fashionable front': 13, 'Well\nnow then, eighty copecks the cap, two roubles twenty-five copecks the\nsuit--together three roubles five copecks--a rouble and a half for the\nboots--for, you see, they are very good--and that makes four roubles\nfifty-five copecks; five roubles for the underclothes--they were\nbought in the lot--which makes exactly nine roubles fifty-five copecks': 52, 'Forty-five copecks change in ('DOS CHAPTER IV PART II', {'Zossimov was a tall, fat man with a puffy, colourless, clean-shaven face\nand straight flaxen hair': 16, 'He wore spectacles, and a big gold ring on\nhis fat finger': 12, 'He was twenty-seven': 3, 'He had on a light grey fashionable\nloose coat, light summer trousers, and everything about him loose,\nfashionable and spick and span; his linen was irreproachable, his\nwatch-chain was massive': 30, 'In manner he was slow and, as it were,\nnonchalant, and at the same time studiously free and easy; he made\nefforts to conceal his self-importance, but it was apparent at every\ninstant': 33, 'All his acquaintances found him tedious, but said he was clever\nat his work': 14, '"I\'ve been to you twice to-day, brother': 7, 'You see, he\'s come to himself,"\n him accounts for it, and therefore it does not tell seriously\nagainst him--one must take into consideration the facts which prove him\ninnocent, especially as they are facts that _cannot be denied_": 63, 'And\ndo you suppose, from the character of our legal system, that they will\naccept, or that they are in a position to accept, this fact--resting\nsimply on a psychological impossibility--as in, when Koch and Pestryakov knocked\nat the door': 14, 'Koch, like an ass, did not stay at the door; so the\nmurderer popped out and ran down, too; for he had no other way of\nescape': 27, 'He hid from Koch, Pestryakov and the porter in the flat when\nNikolay and Dmitri had just run out of it': 21, 'He stopped there while the\nporter and others were going upstairs, waited till they were out ('DOS CHAPTER V PART II', {'This was a gentleman no longer young, of a stiff and portly appearance,\nand a cautious and sour countenance': 19, 'He began by stopping short in the\ndoorway, staring about him with offensive and undisguised astonishment,\nas though asking himself what sort of place he had come to': 28, 'Mistrustfully and with an affectation of being alarmed and almost\naffronted, he scanned Raskolnikov\'s low and narrow "cabin': 18, '" With the\nsame amazement he stared at Raskolnikov, who lay undressed, dishevelled,\nunwashed, on his miserable dirty sofa, looking fixedly at him': 23, 'Then with\nthe same deliberation he scrutinised the uncouth, unkempt figure and\nunshaven face of Razumihin, who looked him boldly and inquiringly in the\nface without rising from his seat': 30, 'A constrained silence lasted for a\ncouple of minutes, and then, as might be expected, some scene-shifting\ntook place': 19, 'Reflecting, probably from certain fairly unmistakable signs,\nthat he would get nothing in this "cabin" by attempting to overawe them,\nthe gentleman softened somewhat, and civilly, though with some severity,\nemphasising every syllable of his question, ('DOS CHAPTER VI PART II', {'But as soon as she went out, he got up, latched the door, undid the\nparcel which Razumihin had brought in that evening and had tied up again\nand began dressing': 31, 'Strange to say, he seemed immediately to have become\nperfectly calm; not a trace of his recent delirium nor of the panic\nfear that had haunted him of late': 29, 'It was the first moment of a strange\nsudden calm': 10, 'His movements were precise and definite; a firm purpose was\nevident in them': 13, '"To-day, to-day," he muttered to himself': 6, 'He understood\nthat he was still weak, but his intense spiritual concentration gave him\nstrength and self-confidence': 17, 'He hoped, moreover, that he would not\nfall down in the street': 12, "When he had dressed in entirely new clothes, he\nlooked at the money lying on the table, and after a moment's thought\nput it in his pocket": 27, 'It was twenty-five roubles': 4, 'He took also all the\ncopper change from the ten roubles spent by Razumihin on the clothes': 17, 'Then he softly unlatched the door, went out, slipped downstairs and\nglanced in at the open kitchen door': 18, "Nastasya was standing with her back\nto him, blowing up the landlady's samovar": 13, 'She heard nothing': 3, 'Who would\nhave dreamed of his going out, indeed': 9, 'A minute later he was in the\nstreet': 8, "It was nearly eight o'clock, the sun was setting": 9, 'It was as stifling as\nbefore, but he eagerly drank in the stinking, dusty town air': 16, 'His head\nfelt rather dizzy; a sort of savage energy gleamed suddenly in his\nfeverish eyes and his wasted, pale and yellow face': 23, 'He did not know and\ndid not think where he was going, he had one thought only: "that all\n_this_ must be ended to-day, once for all, immediately; that he would\nnot return home without it, because he _would not go on living like\nthat_': 45, '" How, with what to make an end': 8, 'He had not an idea about it,\nhe did not even want to think of it': 16, 'He drove away thought; thought\ntortured him': 7, 'All he knew, all he felt was that everything must be\nchanged "one way or another," he repeated with desperate and immovable\nself-confidence and determination': 25, 'From old habit he took his usual walk in the direction of the Hay\nMarket': 15, 'A dark-haired young man with a barrel organ was standing in\nthe road in front of a little general shop and was grinding out a very\nsentimental song': 28, 'He was accompanying a girl of fifteen, who stood\non the pavement in front of him': 16, 'She was dressed up in a crinoline, a\nmantle and a straw hat with a flame-coloured feather in it, all very\nold and shabby': 24, 'In a strong and rather agreeable voice, cracked and\ncoarsened by street singing, she sang in hope of getting a copper from\nthe shop': 24, "Raskolnikov joined two or three listeners, took out a five\ncopeck piece and put it in the girl's hand": 19, 'She broke off abruptly on a\nsentimental high note, shouted sharply to the organ grinder "Come on,"\n and both moved on to the next shop': 25, '"Do you like street music': 5, '" said Raskolnikov, addressing a middle-aged\nman standing idly by him': 11, 'The man looked at him, startled and wondering': 8, '"I love to hear singing to a street organ," said Raskolnikov, and his\nmanner seemed strangely out of keeping with the subject--"I like it\non cold, dark, damp autumn evenings--they must be damp--when all the\npassers-by have pale green, sickly faces, or better still when wet\nsnow is falling straight down, when there\'s no wind--you know what I\nmean': 59, '--and the street lamps shine through it': 7, '"\n\n"I don\'t know': 4, 'Excuse me': 2, '" muttered the stranger, frightened by the\nquestion and Raskolnikov\'s strange manner, and he crossed over to now': 30, "Recognising the place, he stopped, looked round\nand addressed a young fellow in a red shirt who stood gaping before a\ncorn chandler's shop": 24, '"Isn\'t there a man who keeps a booth an unaccountable inclination to enter into\nconversation with people': 11, 'But the peasants took no notice of him; they\nwere all shouting in groups together': 15, 'He stood and thought a little am afraid,' I would say, ‘a\nrelation of mine lost twenty-five roubles the other day through a\nfalse note,' and then I'd tell them the whole story": 28, "And after I began\ncounting the third, ‘No, sensation\nstimulated and revived his energies at once, but his strength failed as\nquickly when the stimulus was removed': 23, 'Zametov, left alone, sat for a long time in the same place, plunged ('DOS CHAPTER VII PART II', {'An elegant carriage stood in the middle of the road with a pair of\nspirited grey horses; there was no one in it, and the coachman had got\noff his box and stood by; the horses were being held by the bridle': 42, 'A mass of people had gathered round, the police standing in front': 12, 'One\nof them held a lighted lantern which he was turning on something lying\nclose to the wheels': 18, 'Everyone was talking, shouting, exclaiming; the\ncoachman seemed at a loss and kept repeating:\n\n"What a misfortune': 17, 'Good Lord, what a misfortune': 5, '"\n\nRaskolnikov pushed his way in as far as he could, and succeeded at last\nin seeing the object of the commotion and interest': 24, 'On the ground a\nman who had been run over lay apparently unconscious, and covered with\nblood; he was very badly dressed, but not like a workman': 27, 'Blood was\nflowing from his head and face; his face was crushed, mutilated and\ndisfigured': 15, 'He was evidently badly injured': 5, '"Merciful heaven': 2, '" wailed the coachman, "what more could I do': 9, "If I'd\nbeen driving fast or had not shouted to him, but I was going quietly,\nnot in a hurry": 20, 'Everyone could see I was going along just like everybody\nelse': 11, "A drunken man can't walk straight, we all know": 9, 'I saw him\ncrossing the street, staggering and almost falling': 10, 'I shouted again\nand a second and a third time, then I held the horses in, but he fell\nstraight under their feet': 23, 'Either he did it on purpose or he was very\ntipsy': 11, 'The horses are young and ready to take fright': 9, 'they started,\nhe screamed': 4, 'that made them worse': 4, "That's how it happened": 4, '"\n\n"That\'s just how it was," a voice in the crowd confirmed': 12, '"He shouted, that\'s true, he shouted three times," another voice\ndeclared': 11, '"Three times it was, we all heard it," shouted a third': 11, 'But the coachman was not very much distressed and frightened': 10, 'It was\nevident that the carriage belonged to a rich and important person who\nwas awaiting it somewhere; the police, of course, were in no little\nanxiety to avoid upsetting his arrangements': 32, 'All they had to do was to\ntake the injured man to the police station and the hospital': 18, 'No one knew\nhis name': 5, 'Meanwhile Raskolnikov had squeezed in and stooped closer over him': 10, "The\nlantern suddenly lighted up the unfortunate man's face": 9, 'He recognised\nhim': 3, '"I know him': 3, 'I know him': 3, '" he shouted, pushing to the front': 7, '"It\'s a\ngovernment clerk retired from the service, Marmeladov': 9, "He lives close\nby in Kozel's house": 7, 'Make haste for a doctor': 5, 'I will pay, see': 4, '" He\npulled money out of his pocket and showed it to the free\nmoment, walking to and fro in her little room from window to stove and\nback again, with her arms folded across her chest, talking to herself\nand coughing': 40, 'Of late she had begun to talk more than ever to her eldest\ngirl, Polenka, a child of ten, who, though there was much she did not\nunderstand, understood very well that her mother needed her, and so\nalways watched her with her big clever eyes and strove her utmost\nto appear to understand': 54, 'This time Polenka was undressing her little\nbrother, who had been unwell all day and was going to bed': 19, 'The boy was\nwaiting for her to take off his shirt, which had to be washed at night': 18, 'He was sitting straight and motionless on a chair, with a silent,\nserious face, with his legs stretched out straight before open to relieve\nthem a little from the clouds of tobacco smoke which floated in from the\nother rooms and brought on long terrible fits of coughing in the poor,\nconsumptive woman': 39, 'Katerina
