then': 11, "he danced the mazurka with me and wanted to\nmake me an offer next day; but I thanked him in flattering expressions\nand told him that my heart had long been another's": 32, 'That other was your\nfather, Polya; papa was fearfully angry': 10, 'Is the water ready': 4, 'Give me\nthe shirt, and the stockings': 7, 'Lida," said she to the youngest one, "you\nmust manage without your chemise to-night': 14, 'and lay your stockings out\nwith it': 7, "I'll wash them together": 4, "How is it that drunken vagabond\ndoesn't come in": 9, 'He has worn his shirt till it looks like a dish-clout,\nhe has torn it to rags': 17, "I'd do it all together, so as not to have to\nwork two nights running": 15, 'Oh, dear': 2, '(Cough, cough, cough, cough': 4, ') Again': 2, "What's this": 2, '" she cried, noticing a crowd in the passage and the men,\nwho were pushing into her room, carrying a burden': 21, '"What is it': 3, 'What are\nthey bringing': 4, 'Mercy on us': 3, '"\n\n"Where are we to put him': 7, '" asked the policeman, looking round when\nMarmeladov, unconscious and covered with blood, had been carried in': 17, '"On the sofa': 3, 'Put him straight on the sofa, with his head this way,"\n Raskolnikov showed him': 14, '"Run over in the road': 5, 'Drunk': 1, '" someone shouted in the passage': 6, 'Katerina Ivanovna stood, turning white and gasping for breath': 9, 'The\nchildren were terrified': 4, 'Little Lida screamed, rushed to Polenka and\nclutched at her, trembling all over': 13, 'Having laid Marmeladov down, Raskolnikov flew to Katerina Ivanovna': 9, '"For God\'s sake be calm, don\'t be frightened': 8, '" he said, speaking\nquickly, "he was crossing the road and was run over by a carriage, don\'t\nbe frightened, he will come to, I told them bring him here': 30, "I've been\nhere already, you remember": 6, "He will come to; I'll pay": 6, '"\n\n"He\'s done it this time': 6, '" Katerina Ivanovna cried despairingly and she\nrushed to her husband': 11, 'Raskolnikov noticed at once that she was not one of those women who\nswoon easily': 15, "She instantly placed under the luckless man's head a\npillow, which no one had thought of and began undressing and examining\nhim": 22, 'She kept her head, forgetting herself, biting her trembling lips\nand stifling the screams which were ready to break from her': 21, 'Raskolnikov meanwhile induced someone to run for a doctor': 9, 'There was a\ndoctor, it appeared, next door but one': 10, '"I\'ve sent for a doctor," he kept assuring Katerina Ivanovna, "don\'t be\nuneasy, I\'ll pay': 15, "Haven't you water": 3, 'and give me a napkin or a towel,\nanything, as quick as you can': 14, 'He is injured, but not killed, believe\nme': 8, 'We shall see what the doctor says': 7, '"\n\nKaterina Ivanovna ran to the window; there, on a broken chair in the\ncorner, a large earthenware basin full of water had been stood, in\nreadiness for washing her children\'s and husband\'s linen that night': 36, 'This washing was done by Katerina Ivanovna at night at least twice a\nweek, if not oftener': 17, 'For the family had come to such a pass that they\nwere practically without change of linen, and Katerina Ivanovna could\nnot endure uncleanliness and, rather than see dirt in the house, she\npreferred to wear herself out at night, working beyond her strength when\nthe rest were asleep, so as to get the wet linen hung on a line and dry\nby the morning': 65, "She took up the basin of water at Raskolnikov's request,\nbut almost fell down with her burden": 17, "But the latter had already\nsucceeded in finding a towel, wetted it and began washing the blood off\nMarmeladov's face": 20, 'Katerina Ivanovna stood by, breathing painfully and pressing her hands\nto her breast': 13, 'She was in need of attention herself': 7, 'Raskolnikov began\nto realise that he might have made a mistake in having the injured man\nbrought here': 18, 'The policeman, too, stood in hesitation': 6, '"Polenka," cried Katerina Ivanovna, "run to Sonia, make haste': 9, "If you\ndon't find her at home, leave word that her father has been run over\nand that she is to come here at once": 25, 'when she comes in': 4, 'Run, Polenka': 2, 'there, put on the shawl': 5, '"\n\n"Run your fastest': 4, '" cried the little boy on the chair suddenly, after\nwhich he relapsed into the same dumb rigidity, with round eyes, his\nheels thrust forward and his toes spread out': 30, "Meanwhile the room had become so full of people that you couldn't have\ndropped a pin": 16, 'The policemen left, all except one, who remained for a\ntime, trying to drive out the people who came in from the stairs': 23, "Almost\nall Madame Lippevechsel's lodgers had streamed in from the inner rooms\nof the flat; at first they were squeezed together in the doorway, but\nafterwards they overflowed into the room": 31, 'Katerina Ivanovna flew into a\nfury': 6, '"You might let him die in peace, at least," she shouted at the crowd,\n"is it a spectacle for you to gape at': 23, 'With cigarettes': 2, '(Cough, cough,\ncough': 3, ') You might as well keep your hats on': 9, 'And there is one in his\nhat': 7, 'Get away': 2, 'You should respect the dead, at least': 7, '"\n\nHer cough choked her--but her reproaches were not without result': 11, 'They\nevidently stood in some awe of Katerina Ivanovna': 9, 'The lodgers, one after\nanother, squeezed back into the doorway with that strange inner feeling\nof satisfaction which may be observed in the presence of a sudden\naccident, even in those nearest and dearest to the victim, from which\nno living man is exempt, even in spite of the sincerest sympathy and\ncompassion': 53, "Voices outside were heard, however, speaking of the hospital and saying\nthat they'd no business to make a disturbance here": 20, '"No business to die': 4, '" cried Katerina Ivanovna, and she was rushing to\nthe door to vent her wrath upon them, but in the doorway came face to\nface with Madame Lippevechsel who had only just heard of the accident\nand ran in to restore order': 42, 'She was a particularly quarrelsome and\nirresponsible German': 8, '"Ah, my God': 3, '" she cried, clasping her hands, "your husband drunken\nhorses have trampled': 12, 'To the hospital with him': 5, 'I am the landlady': 4, '"\n\n"Amalia Ludwigovna, I beg you to recollect what you are saying,"\n Katerina Ivanovna began haughtily (she always took a haughty tone with\nthe landlady that she might "remember her place" and even now could not\ndeny herself this satisfaction)': 40, '"Amalia Ludwigovna': 2, '"\n\n"I have you once before told that you to call me Amalia Ludwigovna may\nnot dare; I am Amalia Ivanovna': 21, '"\n\n"You are not Amalia Ivanovna, but Amalia Ludwigovna, and as I am not\none of your despicable flatterers like Mr': 21, "Lebeziatnikov, who's laughing\nbehind the door at this moment (a laugh and a cry of ‘they are at it\nagain' was in fact audible at the door) so I shall always call you\nAmalia Ludwigovna, though I fail to understand why you dislike that\nname": 45, 'You can see for yourself what has happened to Semyon Zaharovitch;\nhe is dying': 14, 'I beg you to close that door at once and to admit no one': 14, 'Let him at least die in peace': 7, 'Or I warn you the Governor-General,\nhimself, shall be informed of your conduct to-morrow': 14, 'The prince knew\nme as a girl; he remembers Semyon Zaharovitch well and has often been\na benefactor to him': 20, 'Everyone knows that Semyon Zaharovitch had many\nfriends and protectors, whom he abandoned himself from an honourable\npride, knowing his unhappy weakness, but now (she pointed to\nRaskolnikov) a generous young man has come to our assistance, who has\nwealth and connections and whom Semyon Zaharovitch has known from a\nchild': 51, 'You may rest assured, Amalia Ludwigovna': 6, '"\n\nAll this was uttered with extreme rapidity, getting quicker and quicker,\nbut a cough suddenly cut short Katerina Ivanovna\'s eloquence': 21, 'At that\ninstant the dying man recovered consciousness and uttered a groan; she\nran to him': 16, 'The injured man opened his eyes and without recognition or\nunderstanding gazed at Raskolnikov who was bending over him': 19, 'He drew\ndeep, slow, painful breaths; blood oozed at the corners of his mouth\nand drops of perspiration came out on his forehead': 23, 'Not recognising\nRaskolnikov, he began looking round uneasily': 8, 'Katerina Ivanovna looked\nat him with a sad but stern face, and tears trickled from her eyes': 17, '"My God': 2, 'His whole chest is crushed': 5, 'How he is bleeding," she said\nin despair': 8, '"We must take off his clothes': 6, 'Turn a little, Semyon\nZaharovitch, if you can," she cried to him': 12, 'Marmeladov recognised her': 3, '"A priest," he articulated huskily': 5, 'Katerina Ivanovna walked to the window, laid her head against the window\nframe and exclaimed in despair:\n\n"Oh, cursed life': 20, '"\n\n"A priest," the dying man said again after a moment\'s silence': 12, '"They\'ve gone for him," Katerina Ivanovna shouted to him, he obeyed her\nshout and was silent': 16, 'With sad and timid eyes he looked for her; she\nreturned and stood by his pillow': 16, 'He seemed a little easier but not for\nlong': 9, 'Soon his eyes rested on little Lida, his favourite, who was shaking in\nthe corner, as though she were in a fit, and staring at him with her\nwondering childish eyes': 31, '"A-ah," he signed towards her uneasily': 6, 'He wanted to say something': 5, '"What now': 2, '" fractured, several ribs on the right side were broken': 14, "On the left side, just over the heart, was a large, sinister-looking\nyellowish-black bruise--a cruel kick from the horse's hoof": 20, 'The '"\n\n"Better bleed him then': 5, '"\n\n"If you like': 4, 'But I warn you it will be perfectly useless': 9, '"\n\nAt that moment other steps were heard; the crowd in the passage parted,\nand the priest, a little, grey old man, appeared in the doorway bearing\nthe sacrament': 29, 'A policeman had gone for him at the time of the accident': 12, 'The doctor changed places with him, exchanging glances with him': 10, 'Raskolnikov begged the doctor to remain a little while': 9, 'He shrugged his\nshoulders and remained': 6, 'All stepped back': 3, 'The confession was soon over': 5, 'The dying man probably\nunderstood little; he could only utter indistinct broken sounds': 13, 'Katerina Ivanovna took little Lida, lifted the boy from the chair, knelt\ndown in the corner by the stove and made the children kneel in front of\nher': 28, 'The little girl was still trembling; but the boy, kneeling on his\nlittle bare knees, lifted his hand rhythmically, crossing himself with\nprecision and bowed down, touching the floor with his forehead, which\nseemed to afford him especial satisfaction': 39, "Katerina Ivanovna bit her\nlips and held back her tears; she prayed, too, now and then door from the inner rooms was\nopened inquisitively again': 11, 'In the passage the crowd of spectators from\nall the flats on the staircase grew denser and denser, but they did not\nventure beyond the threshold': 26, 'A single candle-end lighted up the scene': 7, 'At that moment Polenka forced her way through the crowd at the door': 13, 'She\ncame in panting from running so fast, took off her kerchief, looked for\nher mother, went up to her and said, "She\'s coming, I met her in the\nstreet': 30, '" Her mother made her kneel beside her': 8, 'Timidly and noiselessly a young girl made her way through the crowd,\nand strange was her appearance in that room, in the midst of want, rags,\ndeath and despair': 29, 'She, too, was in rags, her attire was all of\nthe cheapest, but decked out in gutter finery of a special stamp,\nunmistakably betraying its shameful purpose': 27, 'Sonia stopped short in the\ndoorway and looked about her bewildered, unconscious of everything': 14, 'She forgot her fourth-hand, gaudy silk dress, so unseemly here with\nits ridiculous long train, and her immense crinoline that filled up the\nwhole doorway, and her light-coloured shoes, and the parasol she brought\nwith her, though it was no use at night, and the absurd round straw hat\nwith its flaring flame-coloured feather': 54, 'Under this rakishly-tilted hat\nwas a pale, frightened little face with lips parted and eyes staring in\nterror': 18, 'Sonia was a small thin girl of eighteen with fair hair, rather\npretty, with wonderful blue eyes': 17, 'She looked intently at the bed and the\npriest; she too was out of breath with running': 17, 'At last whispers, some\nwords in the crowd probably, reached her': 11, 'She looked down and took a\nstep forward into the room, still keeping close to the door': 17, 'The service was over': 4, 'Katerina Ivanovna went up to her husband again': 8, 'The priest stepped back and turned to say a few words of admonition and\nconsolation to Katerina Ivanovna on leaving': 20, '"What am I to do with these': 7, '" she interrupted sharply and irritably,\npointing to the little ones': 11, '"God is merciful; look to the Most High for succour," the priest began': misery': 7, 'He drank everything away, the drunkard': 6, 'He robbed us to get drink, he\nwasted their lives and mine for drink': 14, "And thank God he's dying": 5, 'One\nless to keep': 4, '"\n\n"You from his head, setting his pillow straight,\nand had only turned now and then for a moment to address the priest': 40, 'Now\nshe flew at him almost in a frenzy': 9, '"Ah, father': 2, "That's words and only words": 5, 'Forgive': 1, "If he'd not been run\nover, he'd have come home to-day drunk and his only shirt dirty and\nin rags and he'd have fallen asleep like a log, and I should have been\nsousing and rinsing till daybreak, washing his rags and the children's\nand then drying them by the window and as soon as it was daylight I\nshould have been darning them": 64, "That's how I say': 7, '" And the sick man\nwas silent, but at the same instant his wandering eyes strayed to the\ndoorway and he saw Sonia': 23, 'Till then he had not noticed her: she was standing in the shadow in moving': 14, 'He died in her arms': 5, '"He\'s got what he wanted," Katerina Ivanovna cried, seeing her husband\'s\ndead body': 13, '"Well, what\'s to be done now': 6, 'How am I to bury him': 6, 'What can\nI give them to-morrow to eat': 8, '"\n\nRaskolnikov went up to Katerina Ivanovna': 7, '"Katerina Ivanovna," he began, "last week your husband told me all his\nlife and circumstances': 15, 'Believe me, he spoke of you with passionate\nreverence': 9, 'From that evening, when I learnt how devoted he was to you\nall and how he loved and respected you especially, Katerina Ivanovna,\nin answered Raskolnikov': 4, '"The doctor and the priest have been,\nall as it should have been': 13, "Don't worry the poor woman too much, she is\nin consumption as it is": 14, 'Try and cheer her up, if possible': 7, 'you are a\nkind-hearted man, I know': 7, '" he added with a smile, looking straight in\nhis face': 11, '"But you are spattered with blood," observed Nikodim Fomitch, noticing\nin the down slowly and deliberately, feverish but not conscious\nof it, entirely absorbed in a new overwhelming sensation of life and\nstrength that surged up suddenly within him': 29, 'This sensation might be\ncompared to that of a man condemned to death who has suddenly been\npardoned': 18, 'Halfway down the staircase he was overtaken by the priest on\nhis way home; Raskolnikov let him pass, exchanging a silent greeting\nwith him': 24, 'He was just descending the last steps when he heard rapid\nfootsteps behind him': 14, 'Someone overtook him; it was Polenka': 6, 'She was\nrunning after him, calling "Wait': 7, 'wait': 1, '"\n\nHe turned round': 4, 'She was at the bottom of the staircase and stopped\nshort a step above him': 15, 'A dim light came in from the yard': 8, "Raskolnikov\ncould distinguish the child's thin but pretty little face, looking at\nhim with a bright childish smile": 18, 'She had run after him with a message\nwhich she was evidently glad to give': 15, '"Tell me, what is your name': 6, 'and where do you live': 5, '" she said\nhurriedly in a breathless voice': 8, 'He laid both hands on her shoulders and looked at her with a sort of\nrapture': 16, 'It was such a joy to him to look at her, he could not have said\nwhy': 17, '"Who sent you': 3, '"\n\n"Sister Sonia sent me," answered the girl, smiling still more brightly': 12, '"I knew it was sister Sonia sent you': 8, '"\n\n"Mamma sent me, too': 5, 'when sister Sonia was sending me, mamma came up,\ntoo, and said ‘Run fast, Polenka': 15, '\'"\n\n"Do you love sister Sonia': 6, '"\n\n"I love her more than anyone," Polenka answered with a peculiar\nearnestness, and her smile became graver': 18, '"And will you love me': 5, '"\n\nBy way of answer he saw the little girl\'s face approaching him, her full\nlips naïvely held out to kiss him': 22, 'Suddenly her arms as thin as sticks\nheld him tightly, her head rested on his shoulder and the little girl\nwept softly, pressing her face against him': 27, '"I am sorry for father," she said a moment later, raising her\ntear-stained face and brushing away the tears with her hands': 22, '"It\'s\nnothing but misfortunes now," she added suddenly with that peculiarly\nsedate air which children try hard to assume when they want to speak\nlike grown-up people': 27, '"Did your father love you': 5, '"\n\n"He loved Lida most," she went on very seriously without a smile,\nexactly like grown-up people, "he loved her because she is little and\nbecause she is ill, too': 30, 'And he always used to bring her presents': 8, 'But\nhe taught us to read and me grammar and scripture, too," she added with\ndignity': 16, '"And mother never used to say anything, but we knew that she\nliked it and father knew it, too': 19, "And mother wants to teach me French,\nfor it's time my education began": 13, '"\n\n"And do you know your prayers': 7, '"\n\n"Of course, we do': 5, 'We knew them long ago': 5, 'I say my prayers to myself\nas I am a big girl now, but Kolya and Lida say them aloud with mother': 22, "First they repeat the ‘Ave Maria' and then another prayer: ‘Lord,\nforgive and bless sister Sonia,' and then another, ‘Lord, forgive and\nbless our second father": 26, "' For our elder father is dead and this is\nanother one, but we do pray for the other as well": 21, '"\n\n"Polenka, my name is Rodion': 6, 'Pray sometimes for me, too': 5, "‘And Thy\nservant Rodion,' nothing more": 6, '"\n\n"I\'ll pray for you all the rest of my life," the little girl declared\nhotly, and suddenly smiling again she rushed at him and hugged him\nwarmly once more': 30, 'Raskolnikov told her his name and address and promised to be sure to\ncome next day': 16, 'The child went away quite enchanted with him': 8, 'It was past\nten when he came out into the street': 11, 'In five minutes he was standing on\nthe bridge at the spot where the woman had jumped in': 18, '"Enough," he pronounced resolutely and triumphantly': 6, '"I\'ve done with\nfancies, imaginary terrors and phantoms': 8, 'Life is real': 3, "haven't I lived\njust now": 5, 'My life has not yet died with that old woman': 10, 'The Kingdom of\nHeaven to her--and now enough, madam, leave me in peace': 13, 'Now for the\nreign of reason and light': 8, 'and of will, and of strength': 6, 'and now\nwe will see': 5, 'We will try our strength': 5, '" he added defiantly, as though\nchallenging some power of darkness': 11, '"And I was ready to consent to live\nin a square of space': 13, '"I am very weak at this moment, but': 8, 'I believe my illness is all over': 7, 'I knew it would be over when I went out': 10, "By the way, Potchinkov's house\nis only a few steps away": 11, 'I certainly must go to Razumihin even if\nit were not close by': 13, 'let him win his bet': 5, 'Let us give him some\nsatisfaction, too--no matter': 8, 'Strength, strength is what one wants, you\ncan get nothing without it, and strength must be won by strength--that\'s\nwhat they don\'t know," he added proudly and self-confidently and\nhe walked with flagging footsteps from the bridge': 37, 'Pride and\nself-confidence grew continually stronger in him; he was becoming\na different man every moment': 16, 'What was it had happened to work this\nrevolution in him': 11, 'He did not know himself; like a man catching at a\nstraw, he suddenly felt that he, too, ‘could live, that there was still\nlife for him, that his life had not died with the old woman': 37, "' Perhaps he\nwas in too great a hurry with his conclusions, but he did not think of\nthat": 19, '"But I did ask her to remember ‘Thy servant Rodion\' in her prayers," the\nidea struck him': 17, '"Well, that was': 3, 'in case of emergency," he added and\nlaughed himself at his boyish sally': 13, 'He was in the best of spirits': 7, "He easily found Razumihin; the new lodger was already known at\nPotchinkov's and the porter at once showed him the way": 21, 'Half-way\nupstairs he could hear the noise and animated conversation of a big\ngathering of people': 16, 'The door was wide open on the stairs; he could\nhear exclamations and discussion': 14, "Razumihin's room was fairly large; the\ncompany consisted of fifteen people": 11, "Raskolnikov stopped in the entry,\nwhere two of the landlady's servants were busy behind a screen with two\nsamovars, bottles, plates and dishes of pie and savouries, brought up\nfrom the landlady's kitchen": 33, 'Raskolnikov sent in for Razumihin': 5, 'He ran\nout delighted': 4, 'At the first glance it was apparent that he had had a\ngreat deal to drink and, though no amount of liquor made Razumihin quite\ndrunk, this time he was perceptibly affected by it': 34, '"Listen," Raskolnikov hastened to say, "I\'ve only just come to tell you\nyou\'ve won your bet and that no one really knows what may not happen to\nhim': 28, "I can't come in; I am so weak that I shall fall down directly": 14, 'And\nso good evening and good-bye': 6, 'Come and see me to-morrow': 5, '"\n\n"Do you know what': 5, "I'll see you home": 4, "If you say you're weak yourself,\nyou must": 8, '"\n\n"And your visitors': 4, 'Who is the curly-headed one who has just peeped\nout': 10, '"\n\n"He': 2, 'Goodness only knows': 3, "Some friend of uncle's, I expect, or perhaps\nhe has come without being invited": 14, "I'll leave uncle with them, he\nis an invaluable person, pity I can't introduce you to him now": 18, 'But\nconfound them all now': 5, "They won't notice me, and I need a little fresh\nair, for you've come just in the nick of time--another two minutes and I\nshould have ('DOS CHAPTER I PART III', {'Raskolnikov got up, and sat down on the sofa': 9, 'He waved his hand weakly\nto Razumihin to cut short the flow of warm and incoherent consolations\nhe was addressing to his mother and sister, took them both by the hand\nand for a minute or two gazed from one to the other without speaking': 45, 'His mother was alarmed by his expression': 7, 'It revealed an emotion\nagonisingly poignant, and at the same time something immovable, almost\ninsane': 15, 'Pulcheria Alexandrovna began to cry': 5, "Avdotya Romanovna was pale; her hand trembled in her trash, and I do, too, yet we shall talk our way to the\ntruth at last, for we are on the right path, while Pyotr Petrovitch': 57, 'is not on the right path': 6, "Though I've been calling them all sorts of\nnames just now, I do respect them all": 16, "though I don't respect Zametov,\nI like him, for he is a puppy, and that bullock Zossimov, because he\nis an honest man and knows his work": 27, '" said the mother, looking timidly at her daughter,\ntrying to read her thoughts and, already half consoled by Dounia\'s\nstanding up for her brother, which meant that she had already forgiven\nhim': 33, '"I am sure he will think better of it to-morrow," she added,\nprobing her further': 15, '"And I am sure that he will say the same to-morrow': 11, 'about that,"\n Avdotya Romanovna said finally': embraced her without speaking': 7, "Then she sat down to wait\nanxiously for Razumihin's return, timidly watching her daughter who\nwalked up and down the room with her arms folded, lost in thought": 28, "This walking up and down when she was thinking was a habit of Avdotya\nRomanovna's and the mother was always afraid to break in on her\ndaughter's mood at such moments": 31, 'Razumihin, of course, was ridiculous in his sudden drunken infatuation\nfor Avdotya Romanovna': 13, 'Yet apart from his eccentric condition, many\npeople would have thought it justified if they had seen Avdotya\nRomanovna, especially at that moment when she was walking to and\nfro with folded arms, pensive and melancholy': 36, 'Avdotya Romanovna was\nremarkably good-looking; she was tall, strikingly well-proportioned,\nstrong and self-reliant--the latter quality was apparent in every\ngesture, though it did not in the least detract from the grace and\nsoftness of her movements': 36, 'In face she resembled her brother, but she\nmight be described as really beautiful': 14, "Her hair was dark brown, a\nlittle lighter than her brother's; there was a proud light in her almost\nblack eyes and yet at times a look of extraordinary kindness": 30, 'She was\npale, but it was a healthy pallor; her face was radiant with freshness\nand vigour': 17, 'Her mouth was rather small; the full red lower lip projected\na little as did her chin; it was the only irregularity in her beautiful\nface, but it gave it a peculiarly individual and almost haughty\nexpression': 37, 'Her face was always more serious and thoughtful than gay;\nbut how well smiles, how well youthful, lighthearted, irresponsible,\nlaughter suited her face': 23, 'It was natural enough that a warm, open,\nsimple-hearted, honest giant like Razumihin, who had never seen anyone\nlike her and was not quite sober at the time, should lose his head\nimmediately': 33, 'Besides, as chance would have it, he saw Dounia for the\nfirst time transfigured by her love for her brother and her joy at\nmeeting him': 26, "Afterwards he saw her lower lip quiver with indignation\nat her brother's insolent, cruel and ungrateful words--and his fate was\nsealed": 21, "He had spoken the truth, moreover, when he blurted out in his drunken\ntalk on the stairs that Praskovya Pavlovna, Raskolnikov's eccentric\nlandlady, would be jealous of Pulcheria Alexandrovna as well as of\nAvdotya Romanovna on his account": 38, 'Although Pulcheria Alexandrovna was\nforty-three, her face still retained traces of her former beauty; she\nlooked much younger than her age, indeed, which is almost always the\ncase with women who retain serenity of spirit, sensitiveness and pure\nsincere warmth of heart to old age': 45, 'We may add in parenthesis that to\npreserve all this is the only means of retaining beauty to old age': 20, "Her\nhair had begun to grow grey and thin, there had long been little crow's\nfoot wrinkles round her eyes, her cheeks were hollow and sunken from\nanxiety and grief, and yet it was a handsome face": 37, 'She was Dounia\nover again, twenty years older, but without the projecting underlip': 13, 'Pulcheria Alexandrovna was emotional, but not sentimental, timid and\nyielding, but only to a certain point': 16, 'She could give way and accept a\ngreat deal even of what was contrary to her convictions, but there was a\ncertain barrier fixed by honesty, principle and the deepest convictions\nwhich nothing would induce her to cross': 38, "Exactly twenty minutes after Razumihin's departure, there came two\nsubdued but hurried knocks at the door: he had come back": 20, '"I won\'t come in, I haven\'t time," he hastened to say when the door was\nopened': 16, '"He sleeps like a top, soundly, quietly, and God grant he may\nsleep ten hours': 15, "Nastasya's with him; I told her not to leave till I\ncame": 12, "Now I am fetching Zossimov, he will report to you and then you'd\nbetter turn in; I can see you are too tired to do anything": 26, '"\n\nAnd he ran off down the corridor': 8, '"What a very competent and': 5, 'devoted young man': 3, '" cried Pulcheria\nAlexandrovna exceedingly delighted': 6, '"He seems a drinking party to\ngo to Raskolnikov's, but he came reluctantly and with the greatest\nsuspicion to see the ladies, mistrusting Razumihin in his exhilarated\ncondition": 33, 'But his vanity was at once reassured and flattered; he saw\nthat they were really expecting him as an oracle': 20, 'He stayed just ten\nminutes and succeeded in completely convincing and comforting Pulcheria\nAlexandrovna': 14, 'He spoke with marked sympathy, but with the reserve and\nextreme seriousness of a young doctor at an important consultation': 20, 'He did not utter a word on any other subject and did not display the\nslightest desire to enter into more personal relations with the two\nladies': 27, 'Remarking at his first entrance the dazzling beauty of Avdotya\nRomanovna, he endeavoured not to notice her at all during his visit and\naddressed himself solely to Pulcheria Alexandrovna': 29, 'All this gave him\nextraordinary inward satisfaction': 7, 'He declared that he thought the\ninvalid at this moment going on very satisfactorily': 14, 'According to his\nobservations the patient\'s illness was due partly to his unfortunate\nmaterial surroundings during the last few months, but it had partly also\na moral origin, "was, so to speak, the product of several material and\nmoral influences, anxieties, apprehensions, troubles, certain ideas': 45, 'and so on': 3, '" Noticing stealthily that Avdotya Romanovna was following his\nwords with close attention, Zossimov allowed himself to enlarge on this\ntheme': 21, 'On Pulcheria Alexandrovna\'s anxiously and timidly inquiring as\nto "some suspicion of insanity," he replied with a composed and candid\nsmile that his words had been exaggerated; that certainly the patient\nhad some fixed idea, something approaching a monomania--he, Zossimov,\nwas now particularly studying this interesting branch of medicine--but\nthat it must be recollected that until to-day the patient had been in\ndelirium and': 64, 'and that no doubt the presence of his family would have\na favourable effect on his recovery and distract his mind, "if only all\nfresh shocks can be avoided," he added significantly': 32, 'Then he got ('DOS CHAPTER II PART III', {"Razumihin waked up next morning at eight o'clock, troubled and serious": 11, 'He found himself confronted with many new and unlooked-for perplexities': 10, 'He had never expected that he would ever wake up feeling like that': 13, 'He\nremembered every detail of the previous day and he knew that a perfectly\nnovel experience had befallen him, that he had received an impression\nunlike anything he had known before': 31, 'At the same time he recognised\nclearly that the dream which had fired his imagination was hopelessly\nunattainable--so unattainable that he felt positively ashamed of it, and\nhe hastened to pass to the other more practical cares and difficulties\nbequeathed him by that "thrice accursed yesterday': 46, '"\n\nThe most awful recollection of the previous day was the way he had shown\nhimself "base and mean," not only because he had been drunk, but\nbecause he had taken advantage of the young girl\'s position to abuse\nher _fiancé_ in his stupid jealousy, knowing nothing of their mutual\nrelations and obligations and next to nothing of the man himself': 61, 'And\nwhat right had he to criticise him in that hasty and unguarded manner': 14, 'Who had asked for his opinion': 6, 'Was it thinkable that such a creature as\nAvdotya Romanovna would be marrying an unworthy man for money': 18, 'So there\nmust be something in him': 7, 'The lodgings': 2, 'But after all how could he know\nthe character of the lodgings': 12, 'He was furnishing a flat': 5, 'Foo': 1, 'how\ndespicable it all was': 5, 'And what justification was it that he was drunk': 9, 'Such a stupid excuse was even more degrading': 8, 'In wine is truth, and the\ntruth had all come out, "that is, all the uncleanness of his coarse\nand envious heart"': 22, 'And would such a dream ever be permissible to\nhim, Razumihin': 11, 'What was he beside such a girl--he, the drunken noisy\nbraggart of last night': 14, 'Was it possible to imagine so absurd and cynical\na juxtaposition': 11, 'Razumihin blushed desperately at the very idea and\nsuddenly the recollection forced itself vividly upon him of how he had\nsaid last night on the stairs that the landlady would be jealous of\nAvdotya Romanovna': 35, 'that was simply intolerable': 4, 'He brought his fist\ndown heavily on the kitchen stove, hurt his hand and sent one of the\nbricks flying': 20, '"Of course," he muttered to himself a minute later with a feeling of\nself-abasement, "of course, all these infamies can never be wiped out or\nsmoothed over': 27, "and so it's useless even to think of it, and I must\ngo to them in silence and do my duty": 21, 'in silence, too': 3, 'and not ask\nforgiveness, and say nothing': 7, 'for all is lost now': 5, '"\n\nAnd yet as he dressed he examined his attire more carefully than usual': 14, "He hadn't another suit--if he had had, perhaps he wouldn't have put it\non": 14, '"I would have made a point of not putting it on': 11, '" But in any case he\ncould not remain a cynic and a dirty sloven; he had no right to offend\nthe feelings of others, especially when they were in need of his\nassistance and asking him to see them': 40, 'He brushed his clothes carefully': 5, 'His linen was always decent; in that respect he was especially clean': 12, 'He washed that morning scrupulously--he got some soap from Nastasya--he\nwashed his hair, his neck and especially his hands': 19, 'When it came to the\nquestion whether to shave his stubbly chin or not (Praskovya Pavlovna\nhad capital razors that had been left by her late husband), the question\nwas angrily answered in the negative': 35, '"Let it stay as it is': 6, 'What if\nthey think that I shaved on purpose to': 10, 'They certainly would think\nso': 5, 'Not on any account': 4, '"\n\n"And': 2, 'the worst of it was he was so coarse, so dirty, he had the\nmanners of a pothouse; and': 19, 'and even admitting that he knew he had\nsome of the essentials of a gentleman': 15, 'what was there in that to be\nproud of': 9, 'Everyone ought to be a gentleman and more than that': 10, 'and all\nthe same (he remembered) he, too, had done little things': 12, 'not exactly\ndishonest, and yet': 5, 'And what thoughts he sometimes had; hm': 7, 'and to\nset all that beside Avdotya Romanovna': 8, 'Confound it': 2, 'So be it': 3, "Well, he'd\nmake a point then of being dirty, greasy, pothouse in his manners and he\nwouldn't care": 18, "He'd be worse": 3, '"\n\nHe was engaged in such monologues when Zossimov, who had spent the night\nin Praskovya Pavlovna\'s parlour, came in': 20, 'He was going home and was in a hurry to look at the invalid first': 15, 'Razumihin informed him that Raskolnikov was sleeping like a dormouse': 10, "Zossimov gave orders that they shouldn't wake him and promised to see\nhim again about eleven": 16, '"If he is still at home," he added': 8, '"Damn it all': 3, "If one can't control\none's patients, how is one to cure them": 12, 'Do you know whether _he_ will\ngo to them, or whether _they_ are coming here': 15, '"\n\n"They are coming, I think," said Razumihin, understanding the object\nof the question, "and they will discuss their family affairs, no doubt': "They\nhad risen at seven o'clock or earlier": 8, 'He entered looking as black as\nnight, bowed awkwardly and was at once furious with himself for it': 18, 'He\nhad reckoned without his host: Pulcheria Alexandrovna fairly rushed at\nhim, seized him by both hands and was almost kissing them': 22, 'He glanced\ntimidly at Avdotya Romanovna, but her proud countenance wore at that\nmoment an expression of such gratitude and friendliness, such\ncomplete and unlooked-for respect (in place of the sneering looks and\nill-disguised contempt he had expected), that it threw him into greater\nconfusion than if he had been met with abuse': 53, 'Fortunately there was a\nsubject for conversation, and he made haste to snatch at it': 15, 'Hearing that everything was going well and that Rodya had not yet waked,\nPulcheria Alexandrovna declared that she was glad to hear it, because\n"she had something which it was very, very necessary to talk over\nbeforehand': 37, '" Then followed an inquiry about breakfast and an invitation\nto have it with them; they had waited to have it with him': 23, 'Avdotya\nRomanovna rang the bell: it was answered by a ragged dirty waiter, and\nthey asked him to bring tea which was served at last, but in such\na dirty and disorderly way that the ladies were ashamed': 38, "Razumihin\nvigorously attacked the lodgings, but, remembering Luzhin, stopped\nin embarrassment and was greatly relieved by Pulcheria Alexandrovna's\nquestions, which showered in a continual stream upon him": 27, "He talked for three quarters of an hour, being constantly interrupted\nby their questions, and succeeded in describing to them all the\nmost important facts he knew of the last year of Raskolnikov's life,\nconcluding with a circumstantial account of his illness": 42, 'He omitted,\nhowever, many things, which were better omitted, including the scene at\nthe police station with all its consequences': 20, 'They listened eagerly\nto his story, and, when he thought he had finished and satisfied his\nlisteners, he found that they considered he had hardly begun': 26, '"Tell me, tell me': 4, 'What do you think': 4, "Excuse me, I still don't know\nyour name": 8, '" Pulcheria Alexandrovna put in hastily': 6, '"Dmitri Prokofitch': 2, '"\n\n"I should like very, very much to know, Dmitri Prokofitch': 11, 'how he\nlooks': 3, 'on things in general now, is\nhe now': 6, 'In a word, I should like': 6, '"\n\n"Ah, mother, how can he answer all that at once': 11, '" observed Dounia': 3, '"Good heavens, I had not expected to find him in the least like this,\nDmitri Prokofitch': 16, '"\n\n"Naturally," answered Razumihin': 4, '"I have no mother, but my uncle comes\nevery year and almost every time he can scarcely recognise me, even in\nappearance, though he is a clever man; and your three years\' separation\nmeans a great deal': 37, 'What am I to tell you': 6, 'I have known Rodion for\na year and a half; he is morose, gloomy, proud and haughty, and of\nlate--and perhaps for a long time before--he has been suspicious and\nfanciful': 31, 'He has a noble nature and a kind heart': 9, 'He does not like\nshowing his feelings and would rather do a cruel thing than open his\nheart freely': 19, "Sometimes, though, he is not at all morbid, but simply\ncold and inhumanly callous; it's as though he were alternating between\ntwo characters": 23, 'Sometimes he is fearfully reserved': 5, 'He says he is\nso busy that everything is a hindrance, and yet he lies in bed doing\nnothing': 19, "He doesn't jeer at things, not because he hasn't the wit, but\nas though he hadn't time to waste on such trifles": 22, 'He never listens\nto what is said to him': 9, 'He is never interested in what interests other\npeople at any given moment': 13, 'He thinks very highly of himself and perhaps\nhe is right': 11, 'Well, what more': 3, 'I think your arrival will have a most\nbeneficial influence upon him': 12, '"\n\n"God grant it may," cried Pulcheria Alexandrovna, distressed by\nRazumihin\'s account of her Rodya': 15, 'And Razumihin ventured to look more boldly at Avdotya Romanovna at last': 12, 'He glanced at her often while he was talking, but only for a moment and\nlooked away again at once': 20, 'Avdotya Romanovna sat at the table, listening\nattentively, then got up again and began walking to and fro with her\narms folded and her lips compressed, occasionally putting in a question,\nwithout stopping her walk': 35, 'She had the same habit of not listening to\nwhat was said': 12, 'She was wearing a dress of thin dark stuff and she had a\nwhite transparent scarf round her neck': 19, 'Razumihin soon detected signs of\nextreme poverty in their belongings': 10, 'Had Avdotya Romanovna been dressed\nlike a queen, he felt that he would not be afraid of her, but perhaps\njust because she was poorly dressed and that he noticed all the misery\nof her surroundings, his heart was filled with dread and he began to be\nafraid of every word he uttered, every gesture he made, which was very\ntrying for a man who already felt diffident': 68, '"You\'ve told us a great deal that is interesting about my brother\'s\ncharacter': 13, 'and have told it impartially': 5, 'I am glad': 3, 'I thought that you\nwere too uncritically devoted to him," observed Avdotya Romanovna with\na smile': 16, '"I think you are right that he needs a woman\'s care," she added\nthoughtfully': 14, '"I didn\'t say so; but I daresay you are right, only': 11, '"\n\n"What': 2, '"\n\n"He loves no one and perhaps he never will," Razumihin declared\ndecisively': 13, '"You mean he is not capable of love': 8, '"\n\n"Do you know, Avdotya Romanovna, you are awfully like your brother, in\neverything, indeed': 15, '" he blurted out suddenly to his own surprise, but\nremembering at once what he had just before said of her brother,\nhe turned as red as a crab and was overcome with confusion': 34, "Avdotya\nRomanovna couldn't help laughing when she looked at him": 10, '"You may both be mistaken about Rodya," Pulcheria Alexandrovna remarked,\nslightly piqued': 12, '"I am not talking of our present difficulty, Dounia': 9, "What Pyotr what\nhe would do when he was only fifteen': 14, 'And I am sure that he might\ndo something now that nobody else would think of doing': 17, "Well, for\ninstance, do you know how a year and a half ago would have made him pause': 22, 'No, he would calmly have\ndisregarded all obstacles': 8, "And yet it isn't that he doesn't love us": 9, '"\n\n"He has never spoken a word of that affair to me," '"\n\n"And what did you hear': 6, '" both the ladies asked at once': 7, '"Well, nothing very special': 4, "I only learned that the marriage, which\nonly failed to take place through the girl's death, was not at all to\nPraskovya Pavlovna's liking": 24, 'They say, too, the girl was not at all\npretty, in fact I am told positively ugly': 17, 'and such an invalid': 4, 'and\nqueer': 2, 'But she seems to have had some good qualities': 9, "She must have\nhad some good qualities or it's quite inexplicable": 11, "She had no money\neither and he wouldn't have considered her money": 12, "But it's same object\nin view': 54, 'I likewise shall be deprived of the honour of an interview with\nyou to-morrow morning by business in the Senate that does not admit of\ndelay, and also that I may not intrude on your family circle while you\nare meeting your son, and Avdotya Romanovna her brother': 48, "I shall have\nthe honour of visiting you and paying you my respects at your lodgings\nnot later recovered two hours later and so, being able\nto leave the house, may visit you also': 32, 'I was confirmed in that belief\nby the testimony of my own eyes in the lodging of a drunken man who\nwas run to\nraise that sum': 61, 'Herewith expressing my special respect to your estimable\ndaughter, Avdotya Romanovna, I beg you to accept the respectful homage\nof\n\n"Your humble servant,\n\n"P': 24, how to wear poor clothes': 41, 'Razumihin looked reverently\nat Dounia and felt proud of escorting her': 11, '"The queen who mended her\nstockings in prison," he thought, "must have looked then every ('DOS CHAPTER III PART III', {'"He is well, quite well': 5, '" Zossimov cried cheerfully as they entered': 7, 'He had come in ten minutes earlier and was sitting in the same place\nas before, on the sofa': 19, 'Raskolnikov was sitting in the opposite corner,\nfully dressed and carefully washed and combed, as he had not been for\nsome time past': 23, 'The room was immediately crowded, yet Nastasya managed\nto follow the visitors in and stayed to listen': 17, 'Raskolnikov really was almost well, as compared with his condition the\nday before, but he was still pale, listless, and sombre': 21, 'He looked like\na wounded man or one who has undergone some terrible physical suffering': 15, 'His brows were knitted, his lips compressed, his eyes feverish': 10, 'He spoke\nlittle and reluctantly, as though performing a duty, and there was a\nrestlessness in his movements': 18, 'He only wanted a sling on his arm or a bandage on his finger to complete\nthe impression of a man with a painful abscess or a broken arm': 29, 'The\npale, sombre face lighted up for a moment when his mother and sister\nentered, but this only gave it a look of more intense suffering, in\nplace of its listless dejection': 32, 'The light soon died away, but the look\nof suffering remained, and Zossimov, watching and studying his patient\nwith all the zest of a young doctor beginning to practise, noticed\nin him no joy at the arrival of his mother and sister, but a sort of\nbitter, hidden determination to bear another hour or two of inevitable\ntorture': 58, 'He saw later that almost every word of the following\nconversation seemed to touch on some sore place and irritate it': 21, 'But\nat the same time he marvelled at the power of controlling himself\nand hiding his feelings in a patient who the previous day had, like a\nmonomaniac, fallen into a frenzy at the slightest word': 36, '"Yes, I see myself now that I am almost well," said Raskolnikov,\ngiving his mother and sister a kiss of welcome which made Pulcheria\nAlexandrovna radiant at once': 28, '"And I don\'t say this _as I did\nyesterday_," he said, addressing Razumihin, with a friendly pressure of\nhis hand': 20, '"Yes, indeed, I am quite surprised at him to-day," began Zossimov, much\ndelighted at the ladies\' entrance, for he had not succeeded in keeping\nup a conversation with his patient for ten minutes': 33, '"In another three or\nfour days, if he goes on like this, he will be just as before, that is,\nas he was a month ago, or two': 28, 'or perhaps even three': 4, 'This has been\ncoming on for a long while': 9, 'eh': 1, 'Confess, now, that it has been\nperhaps your own fault': 10, '" he added, with a tentative smile, as though\nstill afraid of irritating him': 14, '"It is very possible," answered Raskolnikov coldly': 7, '"I should say, too," continued Zossimov with zest, "that your complete\nrecovery depends solely on yourself': 16, 'Now that one can talk to you,\nI should like to impress upon you that it is essential to avoid the\nelementary, so to speak, fundamental causes tending to produce your\nmorbid condition: in that case you will be cured, if not, it will go\nfrom bad to worse': 49, "These fundamental causes I don't know, but they must\nbe known to you": 13, 'You are an intelligent man, and must have observed\nyourself, of course': 12, 'I fancy the first stage of your derangement\ncoincides with your leaving the university': 14, 'You must not be left without\noccupation, and so, work and a definite aim set before you might, I\nfancy, be very beneficial': 23, '"\n\n"Yes, yes; you are perfectly right': 7, 'I will make haste and return to\nthe university: and then everything will go smoothly': 15, '"\n\nZossimov, who had begun his sage advice partly to make an effect before\nthe ladies, was certainly somewhat mystified, when, glancing at his\npatient, he observed unmistakable mockery on his face': 32, 'This lasted\nan instant, however': 5, 'Pulcheria Alexandrovna began at once thanking\nZossimov, especially for his visit to their lodging the previous night': 17, '"What': 1, 'he saw you last night': 5, '" Raskolnikov asked, as though startled': 6, '"Then you have not slept either after your journey': 9, '"\n\n"Ach, Rodya, that was only till two o\'clock': 9, 'Dounia and I never go to\nbed before two at home': 11, '"\n\n"I don\'t know how to thank him either," Raskolnikov went on,\nsuddenly frowning and looking down': 17, '"Setting aside the question of\npayment--forgive me for referring to it (he turned to Zossimov)--I\nreally don\'t know what I have done to deserve such special attention\nfrom you': 29, "I simply don't understand it": 5, 'and': 1, "it weighs upon\nme, indeed, because I don't understand it": 10, 'I tell you so candidly': 5, '"\n\n"Don\'t be irritated': 4, '" Zossimov forced himself to laugh': 6, '"Assume that you\nare my first patient--well--we fellows just beginning to practise love\nour first patients as if they were our children, and some almost fall in\nlove with them': 30, 'And, of course, I am not rich in patients': 9, '"\n\n"I say nothing about him," added Raskolnikov, pointing to Razumihin,\n"though he has had nothing from me either but insult and trouble': 23, '"\n\n"What nonsense he is talking': 6, 'Why, you are in a sentimental mood to-day,\nare you': 10, '" shouted Razumihin': 3, 'If he had had more penetration he would have seen that there was no\ntrace of sentimentality in him, but something indeed quite the opposite': 25, 'But Avdotya Romanovna noticed it': 5, 'She was intently and uneasily watching\nher brother': 8, '"As for you, mother, I don\'t dare to speak," he went on, as though\nrepeating a lesson learned by heart': 20, '"It is only to-day that I carefulness': 7, '"I\nremember everything even to the slightest detail, and yet--why I did\nthat and went there and said that, I can\'t clearly explain now': 24, '"\n\n"A familiar phenomenon," interposed Zossimov, "actions are sometimes\nperformed in a masterly and most cunning way, while the direction of the\nactions is deranged and dependent on various morbid impressions--it\'s\nlike a it\'s not," answered Dounia firmly': 7, '"Bah': 1, 'you, too, have ideals," he muttered, looking at her almost with\nhatred, and smiling sarcastically': 15, '"I ought to have considered that': 6, "Well, that's praiseworthy, and it's better for you": 8, "and if you reach a\nline you won't overstep, you will be unhappy": 13, 'and if you overstep it,\nmaybe you will be still unhappier': 11, 'But all that\'s nonsense," he added\nirritably, vexed at being carried away': 12, '"I only meant to say that I beg\nyour forgiveness, mother," he concluded, shortly and abruptly': 16, '"That\'s enough, Rodya, I am sure that everything you do is very good,"\n said his mother, delighted': 17, '"Don\'t be too sure," he answered, twisting his mouth into a smile': 12, 'A silence followed': 3, 'There was a certain constraint in all this\nconversation, and in the silence, and in the reconciliation, and in the\nforgiveness, and all were feeling it': 26, '"It is as though they were afraid of me," ('DOS CHAPTER IV PART III', {'At that moment the door was softly opened, and a young girl walked into\nthe room, looking timidly about her': 20, 'Everyone turned towards her with\nsurprise and curiosity': 8, 'At first sight, Raskolnikov did not recognise\nher': 8, 'It was Sofya Semyonovna Marmeladov': 5, 'He had seen her yesterday for\nthe first time, but at such a moment, in such surroundings and in such\na dress, that his memory retained a very different image of her': 32, 'Now she\nwas a modestly and poorly-dressed young girl, very young, indeed,\nalmost like a child, with a modest and refined manner, with a candid but\nsomewhat frightened-looking face': 29, 'She was wearing a very plain indoor\ndress, and had on a shabby old-fashioned hat, but she still carried a\nparasol': 21, 'Unexpectedly finding the room full of people, she was not so\nmuch embarrassed as completely overwhelmed with shyness, like a\nlittle child': 22, 'She was even about to retreat': 6, '"Oh': 1, "it's you": 2, '" said\nRaskolnikov, extremely astonished, and he, too, was confused': 10, 'He at once\nrecollected that his mother and sister knew through Luzhin\'s letter\nof "some young woman of notorious behaviour': 20, '" He had only just been\nprotesting against Luzhin\'s calumny and declaring that he had seen the\ngirl last night for the first time, and suddenly she had walked in': 30, 'He\nremembered, too, that he had not protested against the expression "of\nnotorious behaviour': 14, '" All this passed vaguely and fleetingly through\nhis brain, but looking at her more intently, he saw that the humiliated\ncreature was so humiliated that he felt suddenly sorry for her': 32, 'When she\nmade a movement to retreat in terror, it sent a pang to his heart': 16, '"I did not expect you," he said, hurriedly, with a look that made her\nstop': 15, '"Please sit down': 3, 'You come, no doubt, from Katerina Ivanovna': 7, 'Allow me--not there': 3, 'Sit here': 2, '"\n\nAt Sonia\'s entrance, Razumihin, who had been sitting on one of\nRaskolnikov\'s three chairs, close to the door, got up to allow her to\nenter': 26, "Raskolnikov had at first shown her the place on the sofa where\nZossimov had been sitting, but feeling that the sofa which served him\nas a bed, was too _familiar_ a place, he hurriedly motioned her to\nRazumihin's chair": 39, '"You sit here," he said to Razumihin, putting him on the sofa': 12, 'Sonia sat down, almost shaking with terror, and looked timidly at the\ntwo ladies': 14, 'It was evidently almost inconceivable to herself that she\ncould sit down beside them': 14, 'At the thought of it, she was so frightened\nthat she hurriedly got up again, and in utter confusion addressed\nRaskolnikov': 21, '"I': 1, 'I': 1, 'have come for one minute': 5, 'Forgive me for disturbing you," she\nbegan falteringly': 8, '"I come from Katerina Ivanovna, and she had no one to\nsend': 12, 'Katerina Ivanovna told me to beg you': 7, 'to be at the service': 5, 'in\nthe morning': 3, 'at Mitrofanievsky': 2, 'and then': 2, 'to us': 2, 'to her': 2, 'to do her the honour': 5, 'she told me to beg you': 6, '" Sonia stammered and\nceased speaking': 6, '"I will try, certainly, most certainly," answered Raskolnikov': 8, 'He,\ntoo, stood up, and he, too, faltered and could not finish his sentence': 14, '"Please sit down," he said, suddenly': 6, '"I want to talk to you': 6, 'You are\nperhaps in a hurry, but please, be so kind, spare me two minutes," and\nhe drew up a chair for her': 23, 'Sonia sat down again, and again timidly she took a hurried, frightened\nlook at the two ladies, and dropped her eyes': 21, "Raskolnikov's pale face\nflushed, a shudder passed over him, his eyes glowed": 12, '"Mother," he said, firmly and insistently, "this is Sofya Semyonovna\nMarmeladov, the daughter of that unfortunate Mr': 17, 'Marmeladov, who was run\nover yesterday before my eyes, and of whom I was just telling you': 17, '"\n\nPulcheria Alexandrovna glanced at Sonia, and slightly screwed up\nher eyes': 12, "In spite of her embarrassment before Rodya's urgent and\nchallenging look, she could not deny herself that satisfaction": 18, "Dounia\ngazed gravely and intently into the poor girl's face, and scrutinised\nher with perplexity": 15, 'Sonia, hearing herself introduced, tried to raise\nher eyes again, but was more embarrassed than ever': 16, '"I wanted to ask you," said Raskolnikov, hastily, "how things were\narranged yesterday': 13, 'You were not worried by the police, for instance': 9, '"\n\n"No, that was all right': 6, 'it was too evident, the cause of death': 8, 'they did not worry us': 5, 'only the lodgers are angry': 5, '"\n\n"Why': 2, '"\n\n"At the body\'s remaining so long': 7, 'You see it is hot now': 6, 'So that,\nto-day, they will carry it to the cemetery, into the chapel, until\nto-morrow': 15, "At first Katerina Ivanovna was unwilling, but now she sees\nherself that it's necessary": 14, '"\n\n"To-day, '"\n\n"Yes': 2, 'just a little': 3, 'She told me to thank you very much for helping\nus yesterday': 12, 'But for you, we should have had nothing for the funeral': 11, '"\n\nAll at once her lips and chin began trembling, but, with an effort, she\ncontrolled herself, looking down again': 20, 'During the conversation, Raskolnikov watched her carefully': 7, 'She had a\nthin, very thin, pale little face, rather irregular and angular, with a\nsharp little nose and chin': 20, 'She could not have been called pretty, but\nher blue eyes were so clear, and when they lighted up, there was such\na kindliness and simplicity in her expression that one could not help\nbeing attracted': 36, 'Her face, and her whole figure indeed, had another\npeculiar characteristic': 11, 'In spite of her eighteen years, she looked\nalmost a little girl--almost a child': 14, 'And in some of her gestures, this\nchildishness seemed almost absurd': 11, '"But has Katerina Ivanovna been able to manage with such small means': 12, 'Does she even mean to have a funeral lunch': 9, '" Raskolnikov asked,\npersistently keeping up the conversation': 8, '"The coffin will be plain, of course': 7, "and everything will be plain, so\nit won't cost much": 10, 'Katerina Ivanovna and I have reckoned it all out, so\nthat there will be enough left': 16, 'and Katerina Ivanovna was very anxious\nit should be so': 10, "You ('DOS CHAPTER V PART III', {'Raskolnikov was already entering the room': 6, 'He came in looking as though\nhe had the utmost difficulty not to burst out laughing again': 17, 'Behind him\nRazumihin strode in gawky and awkward, shamefaced and red as a peony,\nwith an utterly crestfallen and ferocious expression': 21, "His face and\nwhole figure really were ridiculous at that moment and amply justified\nRaskolnikov's laughter": 16, 'Raskolnikov, not waiting for an introduction,\nbowed to Porfiry Petrovitch, who stood in the middle of the room\nlooking inquiringly at them': 22, 'He held out his hand and shook hands, still\napparently making desperate efforts to subdue his mirth and utter a few\nwords to introduce himself': 25, 'But he had no sooner succeeded in assuming\na serious air and muttering something when he suddenly glanced again as\nthough accidentally at Razumihin, and could no longer control himself:\nhis stifled laughter broke out the more irresistibly the more he tried\nto restrain it': 45, 'The extraordinary ferocity with which Razumihin received\nthis "spontaneous" mirth gave the whole scene the appearance of most\ngenuine fun and naturalness': 22, 'Razumihin strengthened this impression as\nthough on purpose': 8, '"Fool': 1, 'You fiend," he roared, waving his arm which at once struck a\nlittle round table with an empty tea-glass on it': 21, 'Everything was sent\nflying and crashing': 6, '"But why break chairs, gentlemen': 5, 'You know it\'s a loss to the Crown,"\n Porfiry Petrovitch quoted gaily': 12, "Raskolnikov was still laughing, with his hand in Porfiry Petrovitch's,\nbut anxious not to overdo it, awaited the right moment to put a natural\nend to it": 27, 'Razumihin, completely put to confusion by upsetting the table\nand smashing the glass, gazed gloomily at the fragments, cursed and\nturned sharply to the window where he stood looking out with his back\nto the company with a fiercely scowling countenance, seeing nothing': 43, 'Porfiry Petrovitch laughed and was ready to go on laughing, but\nobviously looked for explanations': 15, "Zametov had been sitting in the\ncorner, but he rose at the visitors' entrance and was standing in\nexpectation with a smile on his lips, though he looked with surprise and\neven it seemed incredulity at the whole scene and at Raskolnikov with a\ncertain embarrassment": 46, "Zametov's unexpected presence struck Raskolnikov\nunpleasantly": 6, '"I\'ve got to think of that," he thought': 8, '"Excuse me, please," he began,\naffecting extreme embarrassment': 8, '"Raskolnikov': 1, '"\n\n"Not at all, very pleasant to see you': 9, "and how pleasantly you've come\nin": 6, "Why, won't he even say good-morning": 6, '" Porfiry Petrovitch nodded\nat Razumihin': 6, '"Upon my honour I don\'t know why he is in such a rage with me': 15, 'I only\ntold him as we came along that he was like Romeo': 13, 'and proved it': 3, 'And\nthat was all, I think': 6, '"\n\n"Pig': 2, '" ejaculated Razumihin, without turning round': 6, '"There must have been very grave grounds for it, if he is so furious at\nthe word," Porfiry laughed': 19, '"Oh, you sharp lawyer': 4, 'Damn you all': 3, '" snapped Razumihin, and suddenly\nbursting out laughing himself, he went up to Porfiry with a more\ncheerful face as though nothing had happened': 24, '"That\'ll do': 2, 'We are\nall fools': 4, 'To come to business': 4, 'This is my friend Rodion Romanovitch\nRaskolnikov; in the first place he has heard of you and wants to make\nyour acquaintance, and secondly, he has a little matter of business with\nyou': 33, 'Bah': 1, 'Zametov, what brought you here': 5, 'Have you met before': 4, 'Have you\nknown each other long': 6, '"\n\n"What does this mean': 5, '" thought Raskolnikov uneasily': 4, 'Zametov seemed taken aback, but not very much so': 9, '"Why, it was at your rooms we met yesterday," he said easily': 12, '"Then I have been spared the trouble': 7, 'All last week he was begging me\nto introduce him to you': 12, 'Porfiry and you have sniffed each other out\nwithout me': 10, 'Where is your tobacco': 4, '"\n\nPorfiry Petrovitch was wearing a dressing-gown, very clean linen, and\ntrodden-down slippers': 13, 'He was a man of about five and thirty, short,\nstout even to corpulence, and clean shaven': 17, 'He wore his hair cut short\nand had a large round head, particularly prominent at the back': 17, 'His\nsoft, round, rather snub-nosed face was of a sickly yellowish colour,\nbut had a vigorous and rather ironical expression': 20, 'It would have been\ngood-natured except for a look in the eyes, which shone with a watery,\nmawkish light under almost white, blinking eyelashes': 24, 'The expression\nof those eyes was strangely out of keeping with his somewhat womanish\nfigure, and gave it something far more serious than could be guessed at\nfirst sight': 29, 'As soon as Porfiry Petrovitch heard that his visitor had a little matter\nof business with him, he begged him to sit down on the sofa and sat down\nhimself on the other end, waiting for him to explain his business, with\nthat careful and over-serious attention which is at once oppressive and\nembarrassing, especially to a stranger, and especially if what you are\ndiscussing is in your opinion of far too little importance for such\nexceptional solemnity': 78, 'But in brief and coherent phrases Raskolnikov\nexplained his business clearly and exactly, and was so well satisfied\nwith himself that he even succeeded in taking a good look at Porfiry': 31, 'Porfiry Petrovitch did not once take his eyes off him': 10, 'Razumihin,\nsitting opposite at the same table, listened warmly and impatiently,\nlooking from one to the other every moment with rather excessive\ninterest': 23, '"Fool," Raskolnikov swore to himself': 5, '"You have to give information to the police," Porfiry replied, with a\nmost businesslike air, "that having learnt of this incident, that is of\nthe murder, you beg to inform the lawyer in charge of the case that such\nand such things belong to you, and that you desire to redeem them': 52, 'or': 1, 'but they will write to you': 6, '"\n\n"That\'s just the point, that at the present moment," Raskolnikov tried\nhis utmost to feign embarrassment, "I am not quite in funds': 23, 'and\neven this trifling sum is beyond me': 8, 'I only wanted, you see, for\nthe present to declare that the things are mine, and that when I have\nmoney': 21, '"\n\n"That\'s no matter," answered Porfiry Petrovitch, receiving his\nexplanation of his pecuniary position coldly, "but you can, if you\nprefer, write straight to me, to say, that having been informed of the\nmatter, and claiming such and such as your property, you beg': 44, '"\n\n"On an ordinary sheet of paper': 7, '" Raskolnikov interrupted eagerly, again\ninterested in the financial side of the question': 13, '"Oh, the most ordinary," and suddenly Porfiry Petrovitch looked with\nobvious irony at him, screwing up his eyes and, as it were, winking at\nhim': 25, "But perhaps it was Raskolnikov's fancy, for it all lasted but a\nmoment": 13, 'There was certainly something of the sort, Raskolnikov could\nhave sworn he winked at him, goodness knows why': 18, '"He knows," flashed through his mind like lightning': 8, '"Forgive my troubling you about such trifles," he went on, a little\ndisconcerted, "the things are only worth five roubles, but I prize them\nparticularly for the sake of those from whom they came to me, and I must\nconfess that I was alarmed when I heard': 47, '"\n\n"That\'s why you were so much struck when I mentioned to Zossimov that\nPorfiry was inquiring for everyone who had pledges': 22, '" Razumihin put in\nwith obvious intention': 7, 'This was really unbearable': 4, 'Raskolnikov could not help glancing at him\nwith a flash of vindictive anger in his black eyes, but immediately\nrecollected himself': 21, '"You seem to be jeering at me, brother': 8, '" he said to him, with a\nwell-feigned irritability': 9, '"I dare say I do seem to you absurdly anxious\nabout such trash; but you mustn\'t think me selfish or grasping for that,\nand these two things may be anything but trash in my eyes': 35, "I told you\njust now that the silver watch, though it's not worth a cent, is the\nonly thing left us of my father's": 24, 'You may laugh at me, but my mother is\nhere," he turned suddenly to Porfiry, "and if she knew," he turned again\nhurriedly to Razumihin, carefully making his voice tremble, "that the\nwatch was lost, she would be in despair': 40, 'You know what women are': 5, '"\n\n"Not a bit of it': 6, "I didn't mean that at all": 6, 'Quite the contrary': 3, '"\n shouted Razumihin distressed': 4, '"Was it right': 3, 'Was it natural': 3, '"\n\n"When did she come': 5, '"\n\n"Last night': 3, '"\n\nPorfiry paused as though reflecting': 6, '"Your things would not in any case be lost," he went on calmly and\ncoldly': 15, '"I have been expecting you here for some time': 9, '"\n\nAnd as though that was a matter of no importance, he carefully offered\nthe ash-tray to Razumihin, who was ruthlessly scattering cigarette ash\nover the straight in the face, but he failed, and suddenly\nadded:\n\n"I say that because I suppose there were a great many pledges': 33, 'that it\nmust be difficult to remember them all': 9, 'But you remember 'Who got the best of it': 6, '"\n\n"Oh, no one, of course': 6, 'They got on to everlasting questions, floated\noff into space': 10, '"\n\n"Only fancy, Rodya, what we got on to yesterday': 10, 'Whether there is such a\nthing as crime': 8, 'I told you that we talked our heads off': 9, '"\n\n"What is there strange': 5, 'It\'s an everyday social question," Raskolnikov\nanswered casually': 8, '"The question wasn\'t put quite like that," observed Porfiry': 9, '"Not quite, that\'s true," Razumihin agreed at once, getting warm and\nhurried as usual': 14, '"Listen, Rodion, and tell us your opinion, I want to\nhear it': 12, 'I was fighting tooth and nail with them and wanted you to\nhelp me': 14, 'I told them you were coming': 6, 'It began with the socialist\ndoctrine': 6, 'You know their doctrine; crime is a protest against the\nabnormality of the social organisation and nothing more, and nothing\nmore; no other causes admitted': 25, '"\n\n"You are wrong there," cried Porfiry Petrovitch; he was noticeably\nanimated and kept laughing as he looked at Razumihin, which made him\nmore excited than ever': 27, '"Nothing is admitted," Razumihin interrupted with heat': 7, '"I am not wrong': 4, "I'll show you their pamphlets": 5, "Everything with them\nis ‘the influence of environment,' and nothing else": 11, 'Their favourite\nphrase': 3, 'From which it follows that, if society is normally organised,\nall crime will cease at once, since there will be nothing to protest\nagainst and all men will become righteous in one instant': 33, "Human nature\nis not taken into account, it is excluded, it's not supposed to exist": 15, "They don't recognise that humanity, developing by a historical living\nprocess, will become at last a normal society, but they believe that a\nsocial system that has come out of some mathematical brain is going\nto organise all humanity at once and make it just and sinless in an\ninstant, quicker than any living process": 55, "That's why they instinctively\ndislike history, ‘nothing but ugliness and stupidity in it,' and they\nexplain it all as stupidity": 20, "That's why they so dislike the _living_\nprocess of life; they don't want a _living soul_": 16, "The living soul\ndemands life, the soul won't obey the rules of mechanics, the soul is an\nobject of suspicion, the soul is retrograde": 24, "But what they want though\nit smells of death and can be made of India-rubber, at least is not\nalive, has no will, is servile and won't revolt": 28, 'And it comes in the end\nto their reducing everything to the building of walls and the planning\nof rooms and passages in a phalanstery': 25, "The phalanstery is ready,\nindeed, but your human nature is not ready for the phalanstery--it\nwants life, it hasn't completed its vital process, it's too soon for the\ngraveyard": 29, "You can't skip over nature by logic": 7, 'Logic presupposes three\npossibilities, but there are millions': 8, 'Cut away a million, and reduce\nit all to the question of comfort': 13, "That's the easiest solution of the\nproblem": 7, "It's seductively clear and you musn't think about it": 9, "That's\nthe great thing, you mustn't think": 7, 'The whole secret of life in two\npages of print': 10, '"\n\n"Now he is off, beating the drum': 8, 'Catch hold of him, do': 5, '" laughed\nPorfiry': 3, '"Can you imagine," he turned to Raskolnikov, "six people\nholding forth like that last night, in one room, with punch as a\npreliminary': 23, 'No, brother, you are wrong, environment accounts for a\ngreat deal in crime; I can assure you of that': 19, '"\n\n"Oh, I know it does, but just tell me: a man of forty violates a child\nof ten; was it environment drove him to it': 26, '"\n\n"Well, strictly speaking, it did," Porfiry observed with noteworthy\ngravity; "a crime of that nature may be very well ascribed to the\ninfluence of environment': 26, '"\n\nRazumihin was almost in a frenzy': 7, '"Oh, if you like," he roared': 6, '"I\'ll\nprove to you that your white eyelashes may very well be ascribed to the\nChurch of Ivan the Great\'s being two hundred and fifty feet high, and I\nwill prove it clearly, exactly, progressively, and even with a Liberal\ntendency': 41, 'I undertake to': 3, 'Will you bet on it': 5, '"\n\n"Done': 2, "Let's hear, please, how he will prove it": 8, '"\n\n"He is always humbugging, yesterday,\nsimply to make fools of them': 11, 'And the things he said yesterday': 6, 'And they\nwere delighted': 4, 'He can keep it up for a fortnight together': 9, 'Last year he\npersuaded us that he was going into a monastery: he stuck to it for two\nmonths': 19, 'Not long ago he took it into his head to declare he was going\nto get married, that he had everything ready for the wedding': 25, 'He ordered\nnew clothes indeed': 5, 'We all began to congratulate him': 6, 'There was no\nbride, nothing, all pure fantasy': 8, '"\n\n"Ah, you are wrong': 5, 'I got the clothes before': 5, 'It was bit, I shall take you in,\ntoo': 9, 'Ha-ha-ha': 1, "No, I'll tell you the truth": 6, 'All these questions about\ncrime, environment, children, recall to my mind an article of yours\nwhich interested me at the time': 21, "‘On Crime'": 2, 'or something of the\nsort, I forget the title, I read it with pleasure two months ago in the\n_Periodical Review_': 21, '"\n\n"My article': 3, 'In the _Periodical Review_': 4, '" Raskolnikov asked in\nastonishment': 5, '"I certainly did write an article upon a book six months\nago when I left the university, but I sent it to the _Weekly Review_': 25, '"\n\n"But it came out in the _Periodical_': 8, '"\n\n"And the _Weekly Review_ ceased to exist, so that\'s why it wasn\'t\nprinted at the time': 17, '"\n\n"That\'s true; but when it ceased to exist, the _Weekly Review_ was\namalgamated with the _Periodical_, and so your article appeared two\nmonths ago in the latter': 28, "Didn't you know": 3, '"\n\nRaskolnikov had not known': 5, '"Why,
