'What was the date': 4, "It doesn't matter though, I will find it": 8, 'Think of\nnot telling us': 5, '"\n\n"How did you find out that the article was mine': 11, "It's only signed with\nan initial": 6, '"\n\n"I only learnt it by chance, the other day': 10, 'Through the editor; I know\nhim': 6, 'I was very much interested': 5, '"\n\n"I analysed, if I remember, the psychology of a criminal before and\nafter the crime': 16, '"\n\n"Yes, and you maintained that the perpetration of a crime is always\naccompanied by illness': 16, 'Very, very original, but': 4, 'it was not that part\nof your article that interested me so much, but an idea at the end of\nthe article which I regret to say you merely suggested without working\nit out clearly': 35, 'There is, if you recollect, a suggestion that there are\ncertain persons who can': 14, 'that is, not precisely are able to, but have\na perfect right to commit breaches of morality and crimes, and that the\nlaw is not for them': 27, '"\n\nRaskolnikov smiled at the exaggerated and intentional distortion of his\nidea': 12, 'What do you mean': 4, 'A right to crime': 4, 'But not because of the\ninfluence of environment': 8, '" Razumihin inquired with some alarm even': 7, '"No, not exactly because of it," answered Porfiry': 8, '"In his article all\nmen are divided into ‘ordinary\' and ‘extraordinary': 11, "' Ordinary men have\nto live in submission, have no right to transgress the law, because,\ndon't you see, they are ordinary": 22, 'But extraordinary men have a right to\ncommit any crime and to transgress the law in any way, just because they\nare extraordinary': 23, 'That was your idea, if I am not mistaken': 9, '"\n\n"What do you mean': 5, "That can't be right": 4, '" Razumihin muttered in\nbewilderment': 5, 'Raskolnikov smiled again': 3, 'He saw the point at once, and knew where they\nwanted to drive him': 14, 'He decided to take up the challenge': 7, '"That wasn\'t quite my contention," he began simply and modestly': 10, '"Yet\nI admit that you have stated it almost correctly; perhaps, if you like,\nperfectly so': 16, '" (It almost gave him pleasure to admit this': 9, ') "The only\ndifference is that I don\'t contend that extraordinary people are always\nbound to commit breaches of morals, as you call it': 24, 'In fact, I doubt\nwhether such an argument could be published': 11, "I simply hinted that an\n‘extraordinary' man has the right": 10, 'that is not an official right, but\nan inner right to decide in his own conscience to overstep': 18, 'certain\nobstacles, and only in case it is essential for the practical fulfilment\nof his idea (sometimes, perhaps, of benefit to the whole of humanity)': 25, "You say that my article isn't definite; I am ready to make it as clear\nas I can": 18, 'Perhaps I am right in thinking you want me to; very well': 12, 'I\nmaintain that if the discoveries of Kepler and Newton could not have\nbeen made known except by sacrificing the lives of one, a dozen, a\nhundred, or more men, Newton would have had the right, would indeed have\nbeen in duty-bound': 42, 'to _eliminate_ the dozen or the hundred men for\nthe sake of making his discoveries known to the whole of humanity': 21, 'But\nit does not follow from that that Newton had a right to murder people\nright and left and to steal every day in the market': 26, 'Then, I remember, I\nmaintain in my article that all': 10, 'well, legislators and leaders of men,\nsuch as Lycurgus, Solon, Mahomet, Napoleon, and so on, were all without\nexception criminals, from the very fact that, making a new law, they\ntransgressed the ancient one, handed down from their ancestors and held\nsacred by the people, and they did not stop short at bloodshed either,\nif that bloodshed--often of innocent persons fighting bravely in defence\nof ancient law--were of use to their cause': 72, "It's remarkable, in fact,\nthat the majority, indeed, of these benefactors and leaders of humanity\nwere guilty of terrible carnage": 20, 'In short, I maintain that all great men\nor even men a little out of the common, that is to say capable of giving\nsome new word, must from their very nature be criminals--more or less,\nof course': 38, "Otherwise it's hard for them to get out of the common rut;\nand to remain in the common rut is what they can't submit to, from their\nvery nature again, and to my mind they ought not, indeed, to submit to\nit": 42, 'You see that there is nothing particularly new in all that': 11, 'The\nsame thing has been printed and read a thousand times before': 12, "As for my\ndivision of people into ordinary and extraordinary, I acknowledge that\nit's somewhat arbitrary, but I don't insist upon exact numbers": 23, 'I only\nbelieve in my leading idea that men are _in general_ divided by a law\nof nature into two categories, inferior (ordinary), that is, so to say,\nmaterial that serves only to reproduce its kind, and men who have\nthe gift or the talent to utter _a new word_': 50, 'There are, of course,\ninnumerable sub-divisions, but the distinguishing features of both\ncategories are fairly well marked': 17, 'The first category, generally\nspeaking, are men conservative in temperament and law-abiding; they live\nunder control and love to be controlled': 21, "To my thinking it is their duty\nto be controlled, because that's their vocation, and there is nothing\nhumiliating in it for them": 23, 'The second category all transgress the\nlaw; they are destroyers or disposed to destruction according to their\ncapacities': 18, 'The crimes of these men are of course relative and varied;\nfor the most part they seek in very varied ways the destruction of the\npresent for the sake of the better': 32, 'But if such a one is forced for the\nsake of his idea to step over a corpse or wade through blood, he can, I\nmaintain, find within himself, in his conscience, a sanction for wading\nthrough blood--that depends on the idea and its dimensions, note that': 47, "It's only in that sense I speak of their right to crime in my article\n(you remember it began with the legal question)": 23, "There's no need for\nsuch anxiety, however; the masses will scarcely ever admit this right,\nthey punish them or hang them (more or less), and in doing so fulfil\nquite justly their conservative vocation": 34, 'But the same masses set these\ncriminals on a pedestal in the next generation and worship them (more or\nless)': 20, 'The first category is always the man of the present, the second\nthe man of the future': 17, 'The first preserve the world and people it, the\nsecond move the world and lead it to its goal': 19, 'Each class has an equal\nright to exist': 8, 'In fact, all have equal rights with me--and _vive la\nguerre éternelle_--till the New Jerusalem, of course': 17, '"\n\n"Then you believe in the New Jerusalem, do you': 10, '"\n\n"I do," Raskolnikov answered firmly; as he said these words and during\nthe whole preceding tirade he kept his eyes on one spot on the carpet': 27, '"And': 1, 'and do you believe in God': 6, 'Excuse my curiosity': 3, '"\n\n"I do," repeated Raskolnikov, raising his eyes to Porfiry': 10, "do you believe in Lazarus' rising from the dead": 9, '"\n\n"I': 2, 'I do': 2, 'Why do you ask all this': 6, '"\n\n"You believe it literally': 5, '"\n\n"Literally': 2, '"\n\n"You don\'t say so': 5, 'I asked from curiosity': 4, 'Excuse me': 2, 'But let us\ngo back to the question; they are not always executed': 13, 'Some, on the\ncontrary': 4, '"\n\n"Triumph in their lifetime': 5, 'Oh, yes, some attain their ends in this\nlife, and then': 11, '"\n\n"They begin executing other people': 6, '"\n\n"If it\'s necessary; indeed, for the most part they do': 11, 'Your remark is\nvery witty': 5, '"\n\n"Thank you': 3, 'But tell me this: how do you distinguish those extraordinary\npeople from the ordinary ones': 15, 'Are there signs at their birth': 6, 'I feel\nthere ought to be more exactitude, more external definition': 11, "Excuse the\nnatural anxiety of a practical law-abiding citizen, but couldn't they\nadopt a special uniform, for instance, couldn't they wear something, be\nbranded in some way": 27, "For you know if confusion arises and a member of\none category imagines that he belongs to the other, begins to ‘eliminate\nobstacles' as you so happily expressed it, then": 30, '"\n\n"Oh, that very often happens': 6, 'That remark is wittier than the other': 7, '"\n\n"No reason to; but take note that the mistake can only arise in\nthe first category, that is among the ordinary people (as I perhaps\nunfortunately called them)': 29, "In spite of their predisposition to\nobedience very many of them, through a playfulness of nature, sometimes\nvouchsafed even to the cow, like to imagine themselves advanced people,\n‘destroyers,' and to push themselves into the ‘new movement,' and\nthis quite sincerely": 41, 'Meanwhile the really _new_ people are very often\nunobserved by them, or even despised as reactionaries of grovelling\ntendencies': 19, "But I don't think there is any considerable danger here,\nand you really need not be uneasy for they never go very far": 23, "Of course,\nthey might have a thrashing sometimes for letting their fancy run away\nwith them and to teach them their place, but no more; in fact, even\nthis isn't necessary as they castigate themselves, for they are very\nconscientious: some perform this service for one another and others\nchastise themselves with their own hands": 55, "They will impose various\npublic acts of penitence upon themselves with a beautiful and edifying\neffect; in fact you've nothing to be uneasy about": 24, "It's a law of\nnature": 5, '"\n\n"Well, you have certainly set my mind more at rest on that score; but\nthere\'s another thing worries me': 20, 'Tell me, please, are there many people\nwho have the right to kill others, these extraordinary people': 17, "I am\nready to bow down to them, of course, but you must admit it's alarming\nif there are a great many of them, eh": 25, '"\n\n"Oh, you needn\'t worry about that either," Raskolnikov went on in the\nsame tone': 15, '"People with new ideas, people with the faintest capacity for\nsaying something _new_, are extremely few in number, extraordinarily\nso in fact': 22, 'One thing only is clear, that the appearance of all these\ngrades and sub-divisions of men must follow with unfailing regularity\nsome law of nature': 25, 'That law, of course, is unknown at present, but I am\nconvinced that it exists, and one day may become known': 21, 'The vast mass of\nmankind is mere material, and only exists in order by some great effort,\nby some mysterious process, by means of some crossing of races and\nstocks, to bring into the world at last perhaps one man out of a\nthousand with a spark of independence': 49, 'One in ten thousand perhaps--I\nspeak roughly, approximately--is born with some independence, and with\nstill greater independence one in a hundred thousand': 22, 'The man of genius\nis one of millions, and the great geniuses, the crown of humanity,\nappear on earth perhaps one in many thousand millions': 25, 'In fact I have\nnot peeped into the retort in which all this takes place': 15, 'But there\ncertainly is and must be a definite law, it cannot be a matter of\nchance': 17, '"\n\n"Why, are you both joking': 6, '" Razumihin cried at last': 5, '"There you sit,\nmaking fun of one another': 8, 'Are you serious, Rodya': 4, '"\n\nRaskolnikov raised his pale and almost mournful face and made no reply': the bell rang': 11, 'I was sitting to-day, feeling very heavy after a\nmiserable dinner from a cookshop; I was sitting smoking, all of a sudden\nMarfa Petrovna again': 25, 'She came in very smart in a '"\n\n"No, I won\'t believe it': 6, '" Raskolnikov cried, with positive anger': 6, '"What do people generally say': 5, '" muttered Svidrigaïlov, as though\nspeaking to himself, looking aside and that\nonly proves that they are unable to appear except to the sick, not that\nthey don't exist": 28, '"\n\n"Nothing of the sort," Raskolnikov insisted irritably': 8, '"No': 1, "You don't think so": 4, '" Svidrigaïlov went on, looking at him\ndeliberately': 8, '"But what do you say to this argument (help me with\nit): ghosts are, as it were, shreds and fragments of other worlds, the\nbeginning of them': 27, 'A man in health has, of course, no reason to see\nthem, because he is above all a man of this earth and is bound for the\nsake of completeness and order to live only in this life': 38, "But as soon\nas one is ill, as soon as the normal earthly order of the organism is\nbroken, one begins to realise the possibility of another world; and the\nmore seriously ill one is, the closer becomes one's contact with that\nother world, so that as soon as the man dies he steps straight into that\nworld": 58, 'I thought of that long ago': 6, 'If you believe in a future life, you\ncould ('DOS CHAPTER II PART IV', {"It was nearly eight o'clock": 5, "The two young men hurried to Bakaleyev's,\nto arrive before Luzhin": 11, '"Why, who was that': 4, '" asked Razumihin, as soon as they were in the\nstreet': 11, '"It was Svidrigaïlov, that landowner in whose house my sister was\ninsulted when she was their governess': 17, 'Through his persecuting her with\nhis attentions, she was don't\nknow why I'm afraid of that man": 9, "He came here at once after his wife's\nfuneral": 9, 'He is very strange, and is determined on doing something': 10, 'We\nmust guard Dounia from him': 6, "that's what I wanted to tell you, do you\nhear": 10, '"\n\n"Guard her': 3, 'What can he do to harm Avdotya Romanovna': 8, 'Thank you, Rodya,\nfor speaking to me like that': 9, 'We will, we will guard thought just now that perhaps I really am mad,\nand have only seen a phantom': 16, '"\n\n"Why, who can tell': 5, 'Perhaps I am really mad, and perhaps everything that\nhappened all these days may be only imagination': 17, '"\n\n"Ach, Rodya, you have been upset again': 8, 'But what did he say, what did\nhe come for': 10, '"\n\nRaskolnikov did not answer': 5, 'Razumihin thought a minute': 4, '"Now let me tell you my story," he began, "I came to you, you were\nasleep': 16, "Then we had dinner and then I went to Porfiry's, Zametov was\nstill with him": 15, 'I tried to begin, but it was no use': emphatic lesson and make them feel the gravity of the position': 37, 'But he could not bring himself to do this': 9, 'Besides, he could not endure\nuncertainty, and he wanted an explanation: if his characteristics of that personage, I am\nin agreement with you': 43, 'I do not know whether he is well off now, and\nprecisely what Marfa Petrovna left him; this will be known to me within\na very short period; but no doubt here in Petersburg, if he has any\npecuniary resources, he will relapse at once into his old ways': 49, 'He is\nthe most depraved, and abjectly vicious specimen of that class of men': 14, 'I have considerable reason to believe that Marfa Petrovna, who was so\nunfortunate as to fall in love with him and to pay his debts eight years\nago, was of service to him also in another way': 37, 'Solely by her exertions\nand sacrifices, a criminal charge, involving an element of fantastic\nand homicidal brutality for which he might well have been sentenced to\nSiberia, was you have good evidence of\nthis': 15, '" Dounia asked sternly and emphatically': 6, '"I only repeat what I was told in secret by Marfa Petrovna': 12, 'I must\nobserve that from the legal point of view the case was far from clear': 16, 'There was, and I believe still is, living here a woman called Resslich,\na foreigner, who lent small sums of money at interest, and did other\ncommissions, and with this woman Svidrigaïlov had for a long while close\nand mysterious relations': 41, 'She had a relation, a niece I believe, living\nwith her, a deaf and dumb girl of fifteen, or perhaps not more than\nfourteen': 24, 'Resslich hated this girl, and grudged her every crust; she\nused to beat her mercilessly': 15, 'One day the girl was found hanging in\nthe garret': 10, 'At the inquest the verdict was suicide': 7, 'After the usual\nproceedings the matter ended, but, later on, information was given that\nthe child had been': 18, 'cruelly outraged by Svidrigaïlov': 4, "It is true, this\nwas not clearly established, the information was given by another German\nwoman of loose character whose word could not be trusted; no statement\nwas actually made to the police, thanks to Marfa Petrovna's money and\nexertions; it did not get beyond gossip": 46, 'And yet the story is a very\nsignificant one': 9, 'You heard, no doubt, Avdotya Romanovna, when you were\nwith them the story of the servant Philip who died of ill treatment he\nreceived six years ago, before the abolition of serfdom': 32, '"\n\n"I heard, on the contrary, that this Philip hanged himself': 11, '"\n\n"Quite so, but what drove him, or rather perhaps disposed him,\nto suicide was the systematic persecution and severity of Mr': 22, 'Svidrigaïlov': 1, '"\n\n"I don\'t know that," answered Dounia, dryly': 8, '"I only heard a queer story\nthat Philip was a sort of hypochondriac, a sort of domestic philosopher,\nthe servants used to say, ‘he read himself silly,\' and that he hanged\nhimself partly on account of Mr': 37, "Svidrigaïlov's mockery of him and not\nhis blows": 8, "When I was there he behaved well to the servants, and they\nwere actually fond of him, though they certainly did blame him for\nPhilip's death": 26, '"\n\n"I perceive, Avdotya Romanovna, that you seem disposed to undertake his\ndefence all of a sudden," Luzhin observed, twisting his lips into\nan ambiguous smile, "there\'s no doubt that he is an astute man, and\ninsinuating where ladies are concerned, of which Marfa Petrovna, who has\ndied so strangely, is a terrible instance': 54, 'My only desire has been to be\nof service to you and your mother with my advice, in view of the renewed\nefforts which may certainly be anticipated from him': 30, "For my part it's\nmy firm conviction, that he will end in a debtor's prison again": 16, "Marfa Petrovna had not the slightest intention of settling anything\nsubstantial on him, having regard for his children's interests, and,\nif she left him anything, it would only be the merest sufficiency,\nsomething insignificant and ephemeral, which would not last a year for a\nman of his habits": 48, '"\n\n"Pyotr Petrovitch, I beg you," said Dounia, "say no more at ease, and quite hopes that we shall become friends': 15, 'He is\nparticularly anxious, by the way, Dounia, for an interview with you, at\nwhich he asked me to assist': 20, 'He has a proposition to ('DOS CHAPTER III PART IV', {'The fact was that up to the last moment he had never expected such an\nending; he had been overbearing to the last degree, never dreaming that\ntwo destitute and defenceless women could escape from his control': 37, 'This\nconviction was strengthened by his vanity and conceit, a conceit to\nthe point of fatuity': 16, 'Pyotr Petrovitch, who had made his way up from\ninsignificance, was morbidly given to self-admiration, had the highest\nopinion of his intelligence and capacities, and sometimes even gloated\nin solitude over his image in the glass': 36, 'But what he loved and valued\nabove all was the money he had amassed by his labour, and by all sorts\nof devices: that money made him the equal of all who had been his\nsuperiors': 36, 'When he had bitterly reminded Dounia that he had decided to take her in\nspite of evil report, Pyotr Petrovitch had spoken with perfect sincerity\nand had, indeed, felt genuinely indignant at such "black ingratitude': 35, '"\n And yet, when he made Dounia his offer, he was fully aware of the\ngroundlessness of all the gossip': 20, "The story had been everywhere\ncontradicted by Marfa Petrovna, and was by then disbelieved by all the\ntownspeople, who were warm in Dounia'a defence": 24, 'And he would not have\ndenied that he knew all that at the time': 14, 'Yet he still thought highly\nof his own resolution in lifting Dounia to his level and regarded it as\nsomething heroic': 21, 'In speaking of it to Dounia, he had let out the secret\nfeeling he cherished and admired, and he could not understand that\nothers should fail to admire it too': 30, 'He had called on Raskolnikov with\nthe feelings of a benefactor who is about to reap the fruits of his good\ndeeds and to hear agreeable flattery': 27, 'And as he went downstairs now, he\nconsidered himself most undeservedly injured and unrecognised': 14, 'Dounia was simply essential to him; to do without her was unthinkable': 12, 'For many years he had had voluptuous dreams of marriage, but he had\ngone on waiting and amassing money': 19, 'He brooded with relish, in profound\nsecret, over the image of a girl--virtuous, poor (she must be poor),\nvery young, very pretty, of good birth and education, very timid, one\nwho had suffered much, and was completely humbled before him, one who\nwould all her life look on him as her saviour, worship him, admire him\nand only him': 59, 'How many scenes, how many amorous episodes he had imagined\non this seductive and playful theme, when his work was over': 21, 'And,\nbehold, the dream of so many years was all but realised; the beauty and\neducation of Avdotya Romanovna had impressed him; her helpless position\nhad been a great allurement; in her he had found even more than he\ndreamed of': 41, 'Here was a girl of pride, character, virtue, of education\nand breeding superior to his own (he felt that), and this creature would\nbe slavishly grateful all her life for his heroic condescension, and\nwould humble herself in the dust before him, and he would have absolute,\nunbounded power over her': 51, 'Not long before, he had, too, after long\nreflection and hesitation, made an important change in his career and\nwas now entering on a wider circle of business': 28, 'With this change his\ncherished dreams of rising into a higher class of society seemed likely\nto be realised': 19, 'He was, in fact, determined to try his fortune\nin Petersburg': 11, 'He knew that women could do a very great deal': 10, 'The\nfascination of a charming, virtuous, highly educated woman might make\nhis way easier, might do wonders in attracting people to him, throwing\nan aureole round him, and now everything was in ruins': 33, 'This sudden\nhorrible rupture affected him like a clap of thunder; it was like a\nhideous joke, an absurdity': 19, 'He had only been a tiny bit masterful,\nhad not even time to speak out, had simply made a joke, been carried\naway--and it had ended so seriously': 28, 'And, of course, too, he did love\nDounia in his own way; he already possessed her in his dreams--and all\nat once': 22, 'No': 1, 'The next day, the very next day, it must all be set right,\nsmoothed over, settled': 16, 'Above all he must crush that conceited milksop\nwho was the cause of it all': 15, 'With a sick feeling he could not help\nrecalling Razumihin too, but, he soon reassured himself on that score;\nas though a fellow like that could be put on a level with him': 33, 'The man\nhe really dreaded in earnest was Svidrigaïlov': 9, 'He had, in short, a\ngreat deal to attend to': 10, '*****\n\n"No, I, I am more to blame than anyone': 10, '" said Dounia, kissing and\nembracing her mother': 8, '"I was tempted by his money, but on my honour,\nbrother, I had no idea he was such a base man': 21, 'If I had seen through him\nbefore, nothing would have tempted me': 12, "Don't blame me, brother": 4, '"\n\n"God has delivered us': 5, 'God has delivered us': 4, '" Pulcheria Alexandrovna\nmuttered, but half consciously, as though scarcely able to realise what\nhad happened': 16, 'They were all relieved, and in five minutes they were laughing': 11, 'Only now\nand then Dounia turned white and frowned, remembering what had passed': 13, 'Pulcheria Alexandrovna was surprised to find that she, too, was glad:\nshe had only that morning thought rupture with Luzhin a terrible\nmisfortune': 23, 'Razumihin was delighted': 3, 'He did not yet dare to express his\njoy fully, but he was in a fever of excitement as though a ton-weight\nhad fallen off his heart': 27, 'Now he had the right to devote his life to\nthem, to serve them': 14, 'Anything might happen now': 4, 'But he felt afraid to\nthink of further possibilities and dared not let his imagination\nrange': 16, he says he is going to be\nmarried and has already fixed on the girl': 16, 'No doubt he has a motive,\nand probably a bad one': 11, "But it's odd that he should be so clumsy about\nit if he had any '"I won\'t lose sight of him': 6, 'Rodya has given me leave': 5, 'He said to me\nhimself just now': 7, '‘Take care of my sister': 5, "' Will you give me leave, too,\nAvdotya Romanovna": 9, '"\n\nDounia smiled and held out her hand, but the look of anxiety did not\nleave her face': 18, 'Pulcheria Alexandrovna gazed at her timidly, but the\nthree thousand roubles had obviously a soothing effect on her': 18, 'A quarter of an hour later, they were all engaged in a lively\nconversation': 14, 'Even Raskolnikov listened attentively for some time,\nthough he did not talk': 12, 'Razumihin was the speaker': 4, '"And why, why should you go away': 7, '" he flowed on ecstatically': 5, '"And what\nare you to do in a little town': 10, 'The great thing is, you are all here\ntogether and you need one another--you do need one another, believe me': 20, 'For a time, anyway': 4, "Take me into partnership, and I assure you we'll\nplan a capital enterprise": 13, 'Listen': 1, "I'll explain it all in detail to\nyou, the whole project": 11, 'It all flashed into my head this morning,\nbefore anything had happened': 12, 'I tell you what; I have an uncle, I must\nintroduce him to you (a most accommodating and respectable old man)': 21, 'This uncle has got a capital of a thousand roubles, and he lives on his\npension and has no need of that money': 23, 'For the last two years he has\nbeen bothering me to borrow it from him and pay him six per cent': 21, 'interest': 1, 'I know what that means; he simply wants to help me': 11, 'Last year\nI had no need of it, but this year I resolved to borrow it as soon as\nhe arrived': 21, "Then you lend me another thousand of your three and we have\nenough for a start, so we'll go into partnership, and what are we going\nto do": 28, '"\n\nThen Razumihin began to unfold his project, and he explained at length\nthat almost all our publishers and booksellers know nothing at all\nof what they are selling, and for that reason they are usually bad\npublishers, and that any decent publications pay as a rule and give\na profit, sometimes a considerable one': 55, 'Razumihin had, indeed, been\ndreaming of setting up as a publisher': 11, 'For the last two years he had\nbeen working in publishers\' offices, and knew three European languages\nwell, though he had told Raskolnikov six days before that he was\n"schwach" in German with an object of persuading him to take half his\ntranslation and half the payment for it': 49, 'He had told a lie then, and\nRaskolnikov knew he was lying': 12, '"Why, why should we let our chance slip when we have one of the chief\nmeans of success--money of our own': 21, '" cried Razumihin warmly': 4, '"Of course\nthere will be a lot of work, but we will work, you, Avdotya Romanovna,\nI, Rodion': 18, 'You get a splendid profit on some books nowadays': 9, 'And\nthe great point of the business is that we shall know just what wants\ntranslating, and we shall be translating, publishing, learning all at\nonce': 26, 'I can be of use because I have experience': 9, "For nearly two years\nI've been scuttling about among the publishers, and now I know every\ndetail of their business": 20, 'You need not into the\ntiny entry': 13, 'On a broken chair stood a candle in a battered copper candlestick': 12, '"It\'s you': 2, 'Good heavens': 2, '" cried Sonia weakly, and she stood rooted to\nthe spot': 11, wall with three windows looking\nout on to the canal ran aslant so that one corner formed a very acute\nangle, and it was difficult to see in it without very strong light': 34, 'The other corner was '"\n\n"But what would become of them': 7, '" Sonia asked faintly, gazing at him with\neyes of anguish, but not seeming surprised at his suggestion': 18, 'Raskolnikov looked strangely at her': 5, 'He read it all in her face; so she\nmust have had that thought already, perhaps many times, and earnestly\nshe had thought out in her despair how to end it and so earnestly, that\nnow she scarcely wondered at his suggestion': 42, 'She had not even noticed\nthe cruelty of his words': 10, '(The significance of his reproaches and his\npeculiar attitude to her shame she had, of course, not noticed either,\nand that, too, was clear to him': 26, ') But he saw how monstrously the thought\nof her disgraceful, shameful position was torturing her and had long\ntortured her': 21, '"What, what," he thought, "could hitherto have hindered\nher from putting an end to it': 15, '" Only then he realised what those poor\nlittle orphan children and that pitiful half-crazy Katerina Ivanovna,\nknocking her head against the wall in her consumption, meant for Sonia': 29, 'But, nevertheless, it was clear to him again that with her character and\nthe amount of education she had after all received, she could not in any\ncase remain so': 30, 'He was still confronted by the question, how could she\nhave remained so long in that position without going out of her mind,\nsince she could not bring herself to jump into the water': 34, "Of course he\nknew that Sonia's position was an exceptional case, though unhappily not\nunique and not infrequent, indeed; but that very exceptionalness, her\ntinge of education, her previous life might, one would have thought,\nhave killed her at the first step on that revolting path": 46, 'What held her\nup--surely not depravity': 6, 'All that infamy had obviously only touched\nher mechanically, not one drop of real depravity had penetrated to her\nheart; he saw that': 23, 'He saw through her as she stood before him': 9, '"There are three ways before her," he thought, "the canal, the madhouse,\nor': 13, 'at last to sink into depravity which obscures the mind and turns\nthe heart to stone': 16, '"\n\nThe last idea was the most revolting, but he was a sceptic, he was\nyoung, abstract, and therefore cruel, and so he could not help believing\nthat the last end was the most likely': 35, '"But can that be true': 5, '" he cried to himself': 5, '"Can ('DOS CHAPTER V PART IV', {"When next morning at eleven o'clock punctually Raskolnikov went into the\ndepartment of the investigation of criminal causes and sent his name in\nto Porfiry Petrovitch, he was surprised at being kept waiting so long:\nit was at least ten minutes before he was summoned": 45, 'He had expected\nthat they would pounce upon him': 9, 'But he stood in the waiting-room, and\npeople, who apparently had nothing to do with him, were continually\npassing to and fro before him': 24, 'In the next room which looked like an\noffice, several clerks were sitting writing and obviously they had\nno notion who or what Raskolnikov might be': 26, 'He looked uneasily and\nsuspiciously about him to see whether there was not some guard, some\nmysterious watch being kept on him to prevent his escape': 26, 'But there was\nnothing of the sort: he saw only the faces of clerks absorbed in petty\ndetails, then other people, no one seemed to have any concern with him': 30, 'He might go where he liked for them': 8, 'The conviction grew stronger in him\nthat if that enigmatic man of yesterday, that phantom sprung out of the\nearth, had seen everything, they would not have let him stand and wait\nlike that': 34, 'And would they have waited till he elected to appear at\neleven': 12, 'Either the man had not yet given information, or': 9, 'or simply\nhe knew nothing, had seen nothing (and how could he have seen anything': 15, ')\nand so all that had happened to him the day before was again a phantom\nexaggerated by his sick and overstrained imagination': 23, 'This conjecture\nhad begun to grow strong the day before, in the midst of all his\nalarm and despair': 19, 'Thinking it all over now and preparing for a fresh\nconflict, he was suddenly aware that he was trembling--and he felt a\nrush of indignation at the thought that he was trembling with fear at\nfacing that hateful Porfiry Petrovitch': 40, 'What he dreaded above all was\nmeeting that man again; he hated him with an intense, unmitigated hatred\nand was afraid his hatred might betray him': 26, 'His indignation was such\nthat he ceased trembling at once; he made ready to go in with a cold and\narrogant bearing and vowed to himself to keep as silent as possible,\nto watch and listen and for once at least to control his overstrained\nnerves': 46, 'At that moment he was summoned to Porfiry Petrovitch': 9, 'He found Porfiry Petrovitch alone in his study': 8, 'His study was a room\nneither large nor small, furnished with a large writing-table, that\nstood before a sofa, upholstered in checked material, a bureau, a\nbookcase in the corner and several chairs--all government furniture,\nof polished yellow wood': 39, 'In the further wall there was a closed door,\nbeyond it there were no doubt other rooms': 17, "On Raskolnikov's entrance\nPorfiry Petrovitch had at once closed the door by which he had come in\nand they remained alone": 21, 'He met his visitor with an apparently genial\nand good-tempered air, and it was only after a few minutes that\nRaskolnikov saw signs of a certain awkwardness in him, as though he had\nbeen thrown out of his reckoning or caught in something very secret': 45, '"Ah, my dear fellow': 4, 'Here you are': 3, 'in our domain"': 3, 'began Porfiry,\nholding out both hands to him': 8, '"Come, sit down, old man': 5, "or perhaps\nyou don't like to be called ‘my dear fellow' and ‘old man": 14, "'--_tout\ncourt_": 2, "Please don't think it too familiar": 6, 'Here, on the sofa': 4, '"\n\nRaskolnikov sat down, keeping his eyes fixed on him': 10, '"In our domain,"\n the apologies for familiarity, the French phrase _tout court_, were all\ncharacteristic signs': 16, '"He held out both hands to me, but he did not give me one--he drew it\nback in time," struck him suspiciously': 22, 'Both were watching each other,\nbut when their eyes met, quick as lightning they looked away': 16, '"I brought you this paper': 5, 'about the watch': 3, 'Here it is': 3, 'Is it all\nright or shall I copy it again': 10, '"\n\n"What': 2, 'A paper': 2, 'Yes, yes, don\'t be uneasy, it\'s all right," Porfiry\nPetrovitch said as though in haste, and after he had said it he took the\npaper and looked at it': 29, '"Yes, it\'s all right': 4, 'Nothing more is needed,"\n he declared with the same rapidity and he laid the paper on the table': 18, 'A minute later when he was talking of something else he took it from the\ntable and put it on his bureau': 22, '"I believe you said yesterday you would like to question me': 11, 'formally': 1, 'about my acquaintance with the murdered woman': 7, '" Raskolnikov\nwas beginning again': 5, '"Why did I put in ‘I believe\'" passed through\nhis mind in a flash': 14, '"Why am I so uneasy at having put in that ‘_I\nbelieve_\'': 12, '" came in a second flash': 6, 'And he suddenly felt that his\nuneasiness at the mere contact with Porfiry, at the first words, at the\nfirst looks, had grown in an instant to monstrous proportions, and that\nthis was fearfully dangerous': 35, 'His nerves were quivering, his emotion was\nincreasing': 8, '"It\'s bad, it\'s bad': 4, 'I shall say too much again': 6, '"\n\n"Yes, yes, yes': 4, 'There\'s no hurry, there\'s no hurry," muttered Porfiry\nPetrovitch, moving to and fro about the table without any apparent aim,\nas it were making dashes towards the window, the bureau and the table,\nat one moment avoiding Raskolnikov\'s suspicious glance, then again\nstanding still and looking him straight in the face': 51, 'His fat round little figure looked very strange, like a ball rolling\nfrom one side to the other and rebounding back': 21, '"We\'ve plenty of time': 4, 'Do you smoke': 3, 'have you your own': 4, 'Here, a\ncigarette': 3, '" he went on, offering his visitor a cigarette': 9, '"You know I am\nreceiving you here, but my own quarters are through there, you know, my\ngovernment quarters': 19, 'But I am living outside for the time, I had to\nhave some repairs done here': 16, "It's almost finished now": 4, 'Government\nquarters, you know, are a capital thing': 8, 'Eh, what do you think': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, a capital thing," answered Raskolnikov, looking at him almost\nironically': 12, '"A capital thing, a capital thing," repeated Porfiry Petrovitch, as\nthough he had just thought of something quite different': 19, '"Yes, a capital\nthing," he almost shouted at last, suddenly staring at Raskolnikov and\nstopping short two steps from him': 20, 'This stupid repetition was too incongruous in its ineptitude with the\nserious, brooding and enigmatic glance he turned upon his visitor': 21, "But this stirred Raskolnikov's spleen more than ever and he could not\nresist an ironical and rather incautious challenge": 19, '"Tell me, please," he asked suddenly, looking almost insolently at him\nand taking a kind of pleasure in his own insolence': 21, '"I believe it\'s a\nsort of legal rule, a sort of legal tradition--for all investigating\nlawyers--to begin their attack from afar, with a trivial, or at least\nan irrelevant subject, so as to encourage, or rather, to divert the man\nthey are cross-examining, to disarm his caution and then all at once to\ngive him an unexpected knock-down blow with some fatal question': 63, "Isn't\nthat so": 3, "It's a sacred tradition, mentioned, I fancy, in all the manuals\nof the art": 14, '"\n\n"Yes, yes': 3, 'Why, do you imagine that was why I spoke about government\nquarters': 12, 'eh': 1, '"\n\nAnd as he said this Porfiry Petrovitch screwed up his eyes and winked;\na good-humoured, crafty look passed over his face': 22, 'The wrinkles on his\nforehead were smoothed out, his eyes contracted, his features broadened\nand he suddenly went off into a nervous prolonged laugh, shaking all\nover and looking Raskolnikov straight in the face': 34, "The latter forced\nhimself to laugh, too, but when Porfiry, seeing that he was laughing,\nbroke into such a guffaw that he turned almost crimson, Raskolnikov's\nrepulsion overcame all precaution; he left off laughing, scowled and\nstared with hatred at Porfiry, keeping his eyes fixed on him while his\nintentionally prolonged laughter lasted": 53, "There was lack of precaution on\nboth sides, however, for Porfiry Petrovitch seemed to be laughing in\nhis visitor's face and to be very little disturbed at the annoyance with\nwhich the visitor received it": 35, "The latter fact was very significant\nin Raskolnikov's eyes: he saw that Porfiry Petrovitch had not been\nembarrassed just before either, but that he, Raskolnikov, had perhaps\nfallen into a trap; that there must be something, some motive here\nunknown to him; that, perhaps, everything was in readiness and in\nanother moment would break upon him": 56, 'He went straight to the point at once, rose from his seat and took his\ncap': 16, '"Porfiry Petrovitch," he began resolutely, though with considerable\nirritation, "yesterday you expressed a desire that I should come to you\nfor some inquiries" (he laid special stress on the word "inquiries")': 31, '"I\nhave come and if you have anything to ask me, ask it, and if not, allow\nme to withdraw': 20, 'I have no time to spare': 6, 'I have to be at the funeral\nof that man who was run over, of whom you': 17, 'know also," he added,\nfeeling angry at once at having made this addition and more irritated at\nhis anger': 19, '"I am sick of it all, do you hear': 9, 'and have long been': 4, "It's\npartly what made me ill": 6, 'In short," he shouted, feeling that the phrase\nabout his illness was still more out of place, "in short, kindly examine\nme or let me go, at once': 28, 'And if you must examine me, do so in the\nproper form': 12, 'I will not allow you to do so otherwise, and so meanwhile,\ngood-bye, as we have evidently nothing to keep us now': 22, '"\n\n"Good heavens': 3, 'What do you mean': 4, 'What shall I question you about': 6, '"\n cackled Porfiry Petrovitch with a change of tone, instantly leaving off\nlaughing': 13, '"Please don\'t disturb yourself," he began fidgeting from place\nto place and fussily making Raskolnikov sit down': 17, '"There\'s no hurry,\nthere\'s no hurry, it\'s all nonsense': 9, "Oh, no, I'm very glad you've come\nto see me at last": 12, 'I look upon you simply as a visitor': 8, 'And as for\nmy confounded laughter, please excuse it, Rodion Romanovitch': 11, 'Rodion\nRomanovitch': 2, 'That is your name': 4, "It's my nerves, you tickled me\nso with your witty observation; I assure you, sometimes I shake with\nlaughter like an india-rubber ball for half an hour at a time": 30, "I'm\noften afraid of an attack of paralysis": 8, 'Do sit down': 3, 'Please do, or I\nshall think you are angry': 9, '"\n\nRaskolnikov did not speak; he listened, watching him, still frowning\nangrily': 12, 'He did sit down, but still held his cap': 9, '"I must tell you one thing about myself, my dear Rodion Romanovitch,"\n Porfiry Petrovitch continued, moving about the room and again avoiding\nhis visitor\'s eyes': 25, '"You see, I\'m a bachelor, a man of no consequence\nand not used to society; besides, I have nothing before me, I\'m set, I\'m\nrunning to seed and': 28, 'and have you noticed, Rodion Romanovitch, that in\nour Petersburg circles, if two clever men meet who are not intimate, but\nrespect each other, like you and me, it takes them half an hour before\nthey can find a subject for conversation--they are dumb, they sit\nopposite each other and feel awkward': 52, 'Everyone has subjects of\nconversation, ladies for instance': 8, "people in high society always have\ntheir subjects of conversation, _c'est de rigueur_, but people of the\nmiddle sort like us, thinking people that is, are always tongue-tied\nand awkward": 30, 'What is the reason of it': 6, "Whether it is the lack of public\ninterest, or whether it is we are so honest we don't want to deceive one\nanother, I don't know": 26, 'What do you think': 4, 'Do put down your cap, it\nlooks as if you were just going, it makes me uncomfortable': 17, 'I am so\ndelighted': 4, '"\n\nRaskolnikov put down his cap and continued listening in silence with\na serious frowning face to the vague and empty chatter of Porfiry\nPetrovitch': 25, '"Does he really want to distract my attention with his silly\nbabble': 12, '"\n\n"I can\'t offer you coffee here; but why not spend five minutes with a\nfriend': 16, '" Porfiry pattered on, "and you know all these official\nduties': 11, "please don't mind my running up and down, excuse it, my dear\nfellow, I am very much afraid of offending you, but exercise is\nabsolutely indispensable for me": 28, "I'm always sitting and so glad to be\nmoving about for five minutes": 13, 'I suffer from my sedentary life': 6, 'I\nalways intend to join a gymnasium; they say that officials of all ranks,\neven Privy Councillors, may be seen skipping gaily there; there you have\nit, modern science': 29, 'yes, yes': 2, 'But as for my duties here, inquiries\nand all such formalities': 11, 'you mentioned inquiries yourself just now': 6, 'I assure you these interrogations are sometimes more embarrassing for\nthe interrogator than for the interrogated': 16, 'You made the observation\nyourself just now very aptly and wittily': 11, '" (Raskolnikov had made no\nobservation of the kind': 9, ') "One gets into a muddle': 6, 'A regular muddle': 3, 'One\nkeeps harping on the same note, like a drum': 10, 'There is to be a reform and\nwe shall be called by a different name, at least, he-he-he': 18, 'And as for\nour legal tradition, as you so wittily called it, I thoroughly agree\nwith you': 17, 'Every prisoner on trial, even the rudest peasant, knows that\nthey begin by disarming him with irrelevant questions (as you so happily\nput it) and then deal him a knock-down blow, he-he-he': 32, '--your felicitous\ncomparison, he-he': 4, "So you really imagined that I meant by ‘government\nquarters'": 10, 'he-he': 1, 'You are an ironical person': 5, 'Come': 1, "I won't go on": 4, 'Ah,\nby the way, yes': 5, 'One word leads to another': 5, 'You spoke of formality just\nnow, apropos of the inquiry, you know': 12, "But what's the use of formality": 6, "In many cases it's nonsense": 5, 'Sometimes one has a friendly chat and gets\na good deal more out of it': 15, 'One can always fall back on formality, allow\nme to assure you': 12, 'And after all, what does it amount to': 8, 'An examining\nlawyer cannot be bounded by formality at every step': 11, 'The work of\ninvestigation is, so to speak, a free art in its own way, he-he-he': 16, '"\n\nPorfiry Petrovitch took breath a moment': 7, 'He had simply babbled on\nuttering empty phrases, letting slip a few enigmatic words and again\nreverting to incoherence': 19, 'He was almost running about the room, moving\nhis fat little legs quicker and quicker, looking at the ground, with his\nright hand behind his back, while with his left making gesticulations\nthat were extraordinarily incongruous with his words': 39, 'Raskolnikov\nsuddenly noticed that as he ran about the room he seemed twice to stop\nfor a moment near the door, as though he were listening': 26, '"Is he expecting anything': 4, '"\n\n"You are certainly quite right about it," Porfiry began gaily, looking\nwith extraordinary simplicity at Raskolnikov (which startled him and\ninstantly put him on his guard); "certainly quite right in laughing so\nwittily at our legal forms, he-he': 39, 'Some of these elaborate psychological\nmethods are exceedingly ridiculous and perhaps useless, if one adheres\ntoo closely to the forms': 20, 'Yes': 1, 'I am talking of forms again': 6, 'Well, if\nI recognise, or more strictly speaking, if I suspect someone or other to\nbe a criminal in any case entrusted to me': 24, "you're reading for the law,\nof course, Rodion Romanovitch": 9, '"\n\n"Yes, I was': 4, '"\n\n"Well, then it is a precedent for you for the future--though don\'t\nsuppose I should venture to instruct you after the articles you publish\nabout crime': 27, 'No, I simply make bold to state it by way of fact, if I\ntook this man or that for a criminal, why, I ask, should I worry him\nprematurely, even though I had evidence against him': 37, "In one case I may\nbe bound, for instance, to arrest a man at once, but another may be in\nquite a different position, you know, so why shouldn't I let him walk\nabout the town a bit": 38, 'he-he-he': 1, "But I see you don't quite understand, so\nI'll give you a clearer example": 14, 'If I put him in prison too soon, I\nmay very likely give him, so to speak, moral support, he-he': 20, "You're\nlaughing": 2, '"\n\nRaskolnikov had no idea of laughing': 7, "He was sitting with compressed\nlips, his feverish eyes fixed on Porfiry Petrovitch's": 13, '"Yet that is the case, with some types especially, for men are so\ndifferent': 14, "You say ‘evidence'": 3, 'Well, there may be evidence': 5, 'But\nevidence, you know, can generally be taken two ways': 10, 'I am an examining\nlawyer and a weak man, I confess it': 12, 'I should like to make a proof, so\nto say, mathematically clear': 12, 'I should like to make a chain of evidence\nsuch as twice two are four, it ought to be a direct, irrefutable proof': 23, 'And if I shut him up too soon--even though I might be convinced _he_\nwas the man, I should very likely be depriving myself of the means of\ngetting further evidence against him': 33, 'And how': 2, 'By giving him, so to\nspeak, a definite position, I shall put him out of suspense and set his\nmind at rest, so that he will retreat into his shell': 30, 'They say that at\nSevastopol, soon after Alma, the clever people were in a terrible fright\nthat the enemy would attack openly and take Sevastopol at once': 27, 'But when\nthey saw that the enemy preferred a regular siege, they were delighted,\nI am told and reassured, for the thing would drag on for two months at\nleast': 30, "You're laughing, you don't believe me again": 7, "Of course, you're\nright, too": 5, "You're right, you're right": 4, 'These are special cases, I\nadmit': 6, "But you must observe this, my dear Rodion Romanovitch, the\ngeneral case, the case for which all legal forms and rules are intended,\nfor which they are calculated and laid down in books, does not exist at\nall, for the reason that every case, every crime, for instance, so soon\nas it actually occurs, at once becomes a thoroughly special case and\nsometimes a case unlike any that's gone before": 70, 'Very comic cases of that\nsort sometimes occur': 8, "If I leave one man quite alone, if I don't touch\nhim and don't worry him, but let him know or at least suspect every\nmoment that I know all about it and am watching him day and night, and\nif he is in continual suspicion and terror, he'll be bound to lose his\nhead": 55, "He'll come of himself, or maybe do something which will make it as\nplain as twice two are four--it's delightful": 20, "It may be so with a simple\npeasant, but with one of our sort, an intelligent man cultivated on a\ncertain side, it's a dead certainty": 26, "For, my dear fellow, it's a very\nimportant matter to know on what side a man is cultivated": 18, 'And then\nthere are nerves, there are nerves, you have overlooked them': 12, 'Why, they\nare all sick, nervous and him walk\nabout for a bit': 9, "I know well enough that I've caught him and that he\nwon't escape me": 14, 'Where could he escape to, he-he': 6, 'Abroad, perhaps': 2, 'A\nPole will escape abroad, but not here, especially as I am watching\nand have taken measures': 17, 'Will he escape into the depths of the country\nperhaps': 10, 'But you know, peasants live there, real rude Russian peasants': 10, gazing with\nthe same intensity into Porfiry\'s face': 19, '"It\'s a lesson," he thought, turning cold': 7, '"This is beyond the cat\nplaying with a mouse, like yesterday': 11, "He can't be showing from the beginning': 9, 'He felt that his parched lips were flecked\nwith foam, his heart was throbbing': 14, 'But he was still determined not to\nspeak till the right moment': 12, 'He realised that this was the best\npolicy in his position, because instead of saying too much he would be\nirritating his enemy by his silence and provoking him into speaking too\nfreely': 33, 'Anyhow, this was what he hoped for': 7, '"No, I see you don\'t believe me, you think I am playing a harmless joke\non you," Porfiry began again, getting more and more lively, chuckling\nat every instant and again pacing round the room': 35, '"And to be sure you\'re\nright: God has given me a figure that can awaken none but comic ideas in\nother people; a buffoon; but let me tell you, and I repeat it, excuse\nan old man, my dear Rodion Romanovitch, you are a man still young, so to\nsay, in your first youth and so you put intellect above everything, like\nall young people': 65, "Playful wit and abstract arguments fascinate you and\nthat's for all the world like the old Austrian _Hof-kriegsrath_, as\nfar as I can judge of military matters, that is: on paper they'd beaten\nNapoleon and taken him prisoner, and there in their study they worked it\nall out in the cleverest fashion, but look you, General Mack surrendered\nwith all his army, he-he-he": 63, 'I see, I see, Rodion Romanovitch, you are\nlaughing at a civilian like me, taking examples out of military history': 20, "But I can't help it, it's my weakness": 8, 'I am fond of military science': 6, "And I'm ever so fond of reading all military histories": 10, "I've certainly\nmissed my proper career": 6, 'I ought to have been in the army, upon my\nword I ought': 13, "I shouldn't have been a Napoleon, but I might have been a\nmajor, he-he": 14, "Well, I'll tell you the whole truth, my dear fellow, about\nthis _special case_, I mean: actual fact and a man's temperament, my\ndear sir, are weighty matters and it's astonishing how they sometimes\ndeceive the sharpest calculation": 38, 'I--listen to an old man--am speaking\nseriously, Rodion Romanovitch" (as he said this Porfiry Petrovitch, who\nwas scarcely five-and-thirty, actually tell you these things for nothing and don't even expect a\nreward for it, he-he": 21, 'Well, to proceed, wit in my opinion is a splendid\nthing, it is, so to say, an adornment of nature and a consolation of\nlife, and what tricks it can play': 31, "So that it sometimes is hard for a\npoor examining lawyer to know where he is, especially when he's liable\nto be carried away by his own fancy, too, for you know he is a man after\nall": 38, "But the poor fellow is saved by the criminal's temperament, worse\nluck for him": 14, "But young people carried away by their own wit don't think\nof that ‘when they overstep all obstacles,' as you wittily and cleverly\nexpressed it yesterday": 26, 'He will lie--that is, the man who is a _special\ncase_, the incognito, and he will lie well, in the cleverest fashion;\nyou might think he would triumph and enjoy the fruits of his wit, but at\nthe most interesting, the most flagrant moment he will faint': 47, 'Of course\nthere may be illness and a stuffy room as well, but anyway': 14, "Anyway he's\ngiven us the idea": 6, "He lied incomparably, but he didn't reckon on his\ntemperament": 10, "That's what betrays him": 4, 'Another to\nmurder and how he kept it up': 11, 'It was a regular hallucination; he brought\nforward facts, he imposed upon everyone and why': 15, 'He had been partly, but\nonly partly, unintentionally the himself that he was the murderer': 51, 'But at last the High Court\nof Appeal went into it and the poor fellow was acquitted and put under\nproper care': 22, 'Thanks to the Court of Appeal': 6, be": 6, '" He rejected that idea, feeling\nto what a degree of fury it might drive him, feeling that that fury\nmight drive him mad': 24, '"I was not delirious': 4, 'I knew what I was doing," he cried, straining\nevery faculty to penetrate Porfiry\'s game, "I was quite myself, do you\nhear': 22, '"\n\n"Yes, I hear and understand': 6, 'You said yesterday you were not delirious,\nyou were shall say beforehand," he said, conscious\nhimself that he was not weighing his words as he ought': 50, '"You want to\nfrighten me': 5, 'or you are simply laughing at me': 7, '"\n\nHe still stared at truth as nearly as possible': 20, 'to\nconceal as little as possible': 6, "I don't believe you": 4, '"\n\n"What a wily person you are': 7, '" Porfiry tittered, "there\'s no catching\nyou; you\'ve a perfect monomania': 11, "So you don't believe me": 5, "But still you\ndo believe me, you believe a quarter; I'll soon make you believe the\nwhole, because I have a sincere liking for you and genuinely sister are here\nnow; you must think of them': 13, 'You must soothe and comfort them and you do\nnothing but frighten them': 13, '"\n\n"What has that to do with you': 8, 'How do you know it': 5, 'What concern is it of\nyours': 6, 'You are keeping watch on me and want to let me know it': 13, 'Why, I learnt it all from you yourself': 8, "You don't\nnotice that in your excitement you tell me and others everything": 13, 'From\nRazumihin, too, I learnt a number of interesting details yesterday': 11, 'No,\nyou interrupted me, but I must tell you that, for all your wit, your\nsuspiciousness makes you lose the common-sense view of things': 24, 'To return\nto bell-ringing, for instance': 6, 'I, an examining lawyer, have betrayed a\nprecious thing like that, a real fact (for it is a fact worth having),\nand you see nothing in it': 27, 'Why, if I had the slightest suspicion of you,\nshould I have acted like that': 15, "No, I should first have disarmed your\nsuspicions and not let you see I knew of that fact, should have diverted\nyour attention and suddenly have dealt you a knock-down blow (your\nexpression) saying: ‘And what were you doing, sir, pray, at ten or\nnearly eleven at the murdered woman's flat and why did you ring the bell\nand why did you ask about blood": 65, 'And why did you invite the porters\nto go with you to the police station, to the lieutenant': 18, "' That's ('DOS CHAPTER I PART V', {'The morning that followed the fateful interview with Dounia and\nher mother brought sobering influences to bear on Pyotr Petrovitch': 20, 'Intensely unpleasant as it was, he was forced little by little to accept\nas a fact beyond recall what had seemed to him only the day before\nfantastic and incredible': 30, 'The black snake of wounded vanity had been\ngnawing at his heart all night': 14, 'When he got out of bed, Pyotr Petrovitch\nimmediately looked in the looking-glass': 13, 'He was afraid that he had\njaundice': 7, 'However his health seemed unimpaired so far, and looking at\nhis noble, clear-skinned countenance which had grown fattish of\nlate, Pyotr Petrovitch for an instant was positively comforted in the\nconviction that he would find another bride and, perhaps, even a better\none': 43, 'But coming back to the sense of his present position, he turned\naside and spat vigorously, which excited a sarcastic smile in Andrey\nSemyonovitch Lebeziatnikov, the young friend with whom he was staying': 33, "That smile Pyotr Petrovitch noticed, and at once set it down against his\nyoung friend's account": 16, 'He had set down a good many points against him\nof late': 12, "His anger was redoubled when he reflected that he ought not to\nhave told Andrey Semyonovitch about the result of yesterday's interview": 22, 'That was the second mistake he had made in temper, through impulsiveness\nand irritability': 14, 'Moreover, all that morning one unpleasantness\nfollowed another': 8, 'He even found a hitch awaiting him in his legal case\nin the senate': 14, 'He was particularly irritated by the owner of the flat\nwhich had been taken in view of his approaching marriage and was being\nredecorated at his own expense; the owner, a rich German tradesman,\nwould not entertain the idea of breaking the contract which had just\nbeen signed and insisted on the full forfeit money, though Pyotr\nPetrovitch would be giving him back the flat practically redecorated': 67, 'In\nthe same way the upholsterers refused to return a single rouble of the\ninstalment paid for the furniture purchased but not yet removed to the\nflat': 27, '"Am I to get married simply for the sake of the furniture': 12, '" Pyotr\nPetrovitch ground his teeth and at the same time once more he had a\ngleam of desperate hope': 20, '"Can all that be really so irrevocably over': 8, 'Is it no use to make another effort': 8, '" The thought of Dounia sent a\nvoluptuous pang through his heart': 12, 'He endured anguish at that moment,\nand if it had been possible to slay Raskolnikov instantly by wishing it,\nPyotr Petrovitch would promptly have uttered the wish': 27, '"It was my mistake, too, not to have given them money," he thought, as\nhe returned dejectedly to Lebeziatnikov\'s room, "and why on earth was I\nsuch a Jew': 29, 'It was false economy': 4, 'I meant to keep them without a penny\nso that they should turn to me as their providence, and look at them': 22, 'foo': 1, "If I'd spent some fifteen hundred roubles on them for the trousseau\nand presents, on knick-knacks, dressing-cases, jewellery, materials, and\nall that sort of trash from Knopp's and the English shop, my position\nwould have been better and": 38, 'stronger': 1, 'They could not have refused me\nso easily': 8, 'They are the sort of people that would feel bound to had been invited, but absorbed in his own cares\nhe had paid no attention': 27, 'Inquiring of Madame Lippevechsel who was busy\nlaying the table while Katerina Ivanovna was away at the cemetery, he\nheard that the entertainment was to be a great affair, that all the\nlodgers had been invited, among them some who had not known the dead\nman, that even Andrey Semyonovitch Lebeziatnikov was invited in spite of\nhis previous quarrel with Katerina Ivanovna, that he, Pyotr Petrovitch,\nwas not only invited, but was eagerly expected as he was the most\nimportant of the lodgers': 83, 'Amalia dressed up to the nines, all in new black silk, and she\nwas proud of it': 50, "All this suggested an idea to Pyotr Petrovitch and he\nwent into his room, or rather Lebeziatnikov's, somewhat strange, though perhaps natural': 13, 'Pyotr Petrovitch had despised and hated him from the day he came to stay\nwith him and at the same time he seemed somewhat afraid of him': 27, 'He\nhad not come to stay with him on his arrival in Petersburg simply from\nparsimony, though that had been perhaps his chief object': 24, 'He had heard\nof Andrey Semyonovitch, who had once been his ward, as a leading young\nprogressive who was taking an important part in certain interesting\ncircles, the doings of which were a legend in the provinces': 37, 'It had\nimpressed Pyotr Petrovitch': 5, 'These powerful omniscient circles who\ndespised everyone and showed everyone up had long inspired in him a\npeculiar but quite vague alarm': 22, 'He had not, of course, been able to form\neven an approximate notion of what they meant': 17, 'He, like everyone, had\nheard that there were, especially in Petersburg, progressives of some\nsort, nihilists and so on, and, like many people, he exaggerated and\ndistorted the significance of those words to an absurd degree': 36, 'What for\nmany years past he had feared more than anything was _being shown\nup_ and this was the chief ground for his continual uneasiness at the\nthought of transferring his business to Petersburg': 34, 'He was afraid of\nthis as little children are sometimes panic-stricken': 11, 'Some years before,\nwhen he was just entering on his own career, he had come upon two cases\nin which rather important personages in the province, patrons of his,\nhad been cruelly shown up': 34, 'One instance had ended in great scandal\nfor the person attacked and the other had very nearly ended in serious\ntrouble': 21, 'For this reason Pyotr Petrovitch intended to go into the\nsubject as soon as he reached Petersburg and, if necessary, to\nanticipate contingencies by seeking the favour of "our younger\ngeneration': 31, '" He relied on Andrey Semyonovitch for this and before\nhis visit to Raskolnikov he had succeeded in picking up some current\nphrases': 23, 'He soon discovered that Andrey Semyonovitch was a commonplace\nsimpleton, but that by no means reassured Pyotr Petrovitch': 18, 'Even if he\nhad been certain that all the progressives were fools like him, it\nwould not have allayed his uneasiness': 21, 'All the doctrines, the ideas, the\nsystems, with which Andrey Semyonovitch pestered him had no interest for\nhim': 18, 'He had his own object--he simply wanted to find out at once what\nwas happening _here_': 16, 'Had these people any power or not': 7, 'Had he anything\nto fear from them': 7, 'Would they expose any enterprise of his': 7, 'And what\nprecisely was now the object of their attacks': 10, 'Could he somehow make up\nto them and get round them if they really were powerful': 16, 'Was this sometimes extremely conceited in\nspeech, which had an absurd effect, incongruous with his little figure': 22, 'He was one of the lodgers most respected by Amalia Ivanovna, for he did\nnot get drunk and paid regularly for his lodgings': 23, 'Andrey Semyonovitch\nreally was rather stupid; he attached himself to the cause of progress\nand "our younger generation" from enthusiasm': 20, 'He was one of the numerous\nand varied legion of dullards, of half-animate abortions, conceited,\nhalf-educated coxcombs, who attach themselves to the idea most in\nfashion only to vulgarise it and who caricature every cause they serve,\nhowever sincerely': 39, 'Though Lebeziatnikov was so good-natured, he, too, was beginning to\ndislike Pyotr Petrovitch': 13, 'This happened on both sides begun\ninstinctively to guess that Lebeziatnikov was not merely a commonplace\nsimpleton, but, perhaps, a liar, too, and that he had no connections of\nany consequence even in his own circle, but had simply picked things up\nthird-hand; and that very likely he did not even know much about his own\nwork of propaganda, for he was in too great a muddle': 67, 'A fine person he\nwould be to show anyone third\ntime': 12, '"Seeing her position with her unfortunate little ones, I should be glad,\nas I have said before, so far as lies in my power, to be of service,\nthat is, so far as is in my power, 13, 'Sonia took it, flushed crimson, jumped up, muttered something\nand began taking leave': 13, 'Pyotr Petrovitch accompanied her ceremoniously\nto the door': 8, 'She got out of the room at last, agitated and distressed,\nand returned to Katerina Ivanovna, overwhelmed with confusion': 19, 'All this time Lebeziatnikov had stood at the window or walked about the\nroom, anxious not to interrupt the conversation; when Sonia had gone he\nwalked up to Pyotr Petrovitch and solemnly held out his hand': 36, '"I heard and _saw_ everything," he said, laying stress on the last verb': 13, '"That is honourable, I mean to say, it\'s humane': 9, 'You wanted to avoid\ngratitude, I saw': 7, 'And although I cannot, I confess, in principle\nsympathise with private charity, for it not only fails to eradicate the\nevil but even promotes it, yet I must admit that I saw your action with\npleasure--yes, yes, I like it': 40, '"\n\n"That\'s all nonsense," muttered Pyotr Petrovitch, somewhat disconcerted,\nlooking carefully at Lebeziatnikov': 13, '"No, it\'s not nonsense': 4, 'A man who has suffered distress and annoyance as\nyou did yesterday and who yet can sympathise with the misery of others,\nsuch a man': 25, 'even though he is making a social mistake--is still\ndeserving of respect': 12, 'I did not expect it indeed of you, Pyotr\nPetrovitch, especially as according to your ideas': 16, 'oh, what a drawback\nyour ideas are to you': 9, 'How distressed you are for instance by your\nill-luck yesterday," cried the simple-hearted Lebeziatnikov, who felt\na return of affection for Pyotr Petrovitch': 23, '"And, what do you want with\nmarriage, with _legal_ marriage, my dear, noble Pyotr Petrovitch': 15, 'Why do\nyou cling to this _legality_ of marriage': 9, "Well, you may beat me if you\nlike, but I am glad, positively glad it hasn't come off, that you are\nfree, that you are not quite lost for humanity": 30, "you see, I've spoken\nmy mind": 6, '"\n\n"Because I don\'t want in your free marriage to be made a fool of and\nto bring up another man\'s children, that\'s why I want legal marriage,"\n Luzhin replied in order to make some answer': 36, 'He seemed preoccupied by something': 5, '"Children': 1, 'You referred to children," Lebeziatnikov started off like\na warhorse at the trumpet call': 14, '"Children are a social question and a\nquestion of first importance, I agree; but the question of children has\nanother solution': 21, 'Some refuse to have children altogether, because they\nsuggest the institution of the family': 14, "We'll speak of children later,\nbut now as to the question of honour, I confess that's my weak point": 19, 'That horrid, military, Pushkin expression is unthinkable in the\ndictionary of the future': 13, 'What does it mean it's not humiliating": 6, 'and if I ever, to suppose an\nabsurdity, were to be legally married, I should be positively glad of\nit': 20, "I should say to my wife: ‘My dear, hitherto I have loved you, now\nI respect you, for you've shown you can protest": 23, "' You laugh": 3, "That's\nbecause you are incapable of getting away from prejudices": 10, 'Confound\nit all': 3, "I understand now where the unpleasantness is of being deceived\nin a legal marriage, but it's simply a despicable consequence of a\ndespicable position in which both are humiliated": 29, "When the deception is\nopen, as in a free marriage, then it does not exist, it's unthinkable": 17, 'Your wife will only prove how she respects you by considering you\nincapable of opposing her happiness and avenging yourself on her for\nher new husband': 26, 'Damn it all': 3, 'I sometimes dream if I were to be married,\npfoo': 10, "I mean if I were to marry, legally or not, it's just the same,\nI should present my wife with a
