('DOS CHAPTER II PART V', {"It would be difficult to explain exactly what could have originated the\nidea of that senseless dinner in Katerina Ivanovna's disordered brain": 22, "Nearly ten of the twenty roubles, given by Raskolnikov for Marmeladov's\nfuneral, were wasted upon it": 16, 'Possibly Katerina Ivanovna felt obliged to\nhonour the memory of the deceased "suitably," that all the lodgers,\nand still more Amalia Ivanovna, might know "that he was in no way their\ninferior, and perhaps very much their superior," and that no one had the\nright "to turn up his nose at him': 52, '" Perhaps the chief element was that\npeculiar "poor man\'s pride," which compels many poor people to spend\ntheir last savings on some traditional social ceremony, simply in order\nto do "like other people," and not to "be looked down upon': 41, '" It is very\nprobable, too, that Katerina Ivanovna longed on this occasion, at\nthe moment when she seemed to be abandoned by everyone, to show those\n"wretched contemptible lodgers" that she knew "how to do things, how\nto entertain" and that she had been brought up "in a genteel, she might\nalmost say aristocratic colonel\'s family" and had not been meant for\nsweeping floors and washing the children\'s rags at night': 72, 'Even the\npoorest and most broken-spirited people are sometimes liable to these\nparoxysms of pride and vanity which take the form of an irresistible\nnervous craving': 26, 'And Katerina Ivanovna was not broken-spirited; she\nmight have been killed by circumstance, but her spirit could not have\nbeen broken, that is, she could not have been intimidated, her will\ncould not be crushed': 35, 'Moreover Sonia had said with good reason that her\nmind was unhinged': 12, 'She could not be said to be insane, but for a year\npast she had been so harassed that her mind might well be overstrained': 25, 'The later stages of consumption are apt, doctors tell us, to affect the\nintellect': 14, 'There was no great variety of wines, nor was there Madeira; but wine\nthere was': 15, 'There was vodka, rum and Lisbon wine, all of the poorest\nquality but in sufficient quantity': 16, "Besides the traditional rice and\nhoney, there were three or four dishes, one of which consisted of\npancakes, all prepared in Amalia Ivanovna's kitchen": 24, 'Two samovars were\nboiling, that tea and punch might be offered after dinner': 13, "Katerina\nIvanovna had herself seen to purchasing the provisions, with the help\nof one of the lodgers, an unfortunate little Pole who had somehow been\nstranded at Madame Lippevechsel's": 29, "He promptly put himself at Katerina\nIvanovna's disposal and had been all that morning and all the day before\nrunning about as fast as his legs could carry him, and very anxious\nthat everyone should be aware of it": 39, 'For every trifle he ran to Katerina\nIvanovna, even hunting her out at the bazaar, at every instant called\nher "_Pani_': 21, '" She was heartily sick of him before the end, though\nshe had declared at first that she could not have got on without this\n"serviceable and magnanimous man': 29, '" It was one of Katerina Ivanovna\'s\ncharacteristics to paint everyone she met in the most glowing colours': 18, 'Her praises were so exaggerated as sometimes to be embarrassing; she\nwould invent various circumstances to the credit of her new acquaintance\nand quite genuinely believe in their reality': 29, 'Then all of a sudden she\nwould be disillusioned and would rudely and contemptuously repulse the\nperson she had only a few hours before been literally adoring': 27, 'She\nwas naturally of a gay, lively and peace-loving disposition, but from\ncontinual failures and misfortunes she had come to desire so _keenly_\nthat all should live in peace and joy and should not _dare_ to break the\npeace, that the slightest jar, the smallest disaster reduced her almost\nto frenzy, and she would pass in an instant from the brightest hopes and\nfancies to cursing her fate and raving, and knocking her head against\nthe wall': 77, "Amalia Ivanovna, too, suddenly acquired extraordinary importance in\nKaterina Ivanovna's eyes and was treated by her with extraordinary\nrespect, probably only because Amalia Ivanovna had thrown herself heart\nand soul into the preparations": 33, 'She had undertaken to lay the table,\nto provide the linen, crockery, etc': 13, ', and to cook the dishes in her\nkitchen, and Katerina Ivanovna had left it all in her hands and gone\nherself to the cemetery': 25, 'Everything had been well done': 5, 'Even the\ntable-cloth was nearly clean; the crockery, knives, forks and glasses\nwere, of course, of all shapes and patterns, lent by different lodgers,\nbut the table was properly laid at the time fixed, and Amalia Ivanovna,\nfeeling she had done her work well, had put on a black silk dress and\na cap with new mourning ribbons and met the returning party with some\npride': 66, 'This pride, though justifiable, displeased Katerina Ivanovna for\nsome reason: "as though the table could not have been laid except by\nAmalia Ivanovna': 23, '" She disliked the cap with new ribbons, too': 9, '"Could she\nbe stuck up, the stupid German, because she was mistress of the house,\nand had consented as a favour to help her poor lodgers': 26, 'As a favour': 3, 'Fancy that': 2, "Katerina Ivanovna's father who had been a colonel and almost\na governor had sometimes had the table set for forty persons, and then\nanyone like Amalia Ivanovna, or rather Ludwigovna, would not have been\nallowed into the kitchen": 38, '"\n\nKaterina Ivanovna, however, put off expressing her feelings for the\ntime and contented herself with treating her coldly, though she decided\ninwardly that she would certainly have to put Amalia Ivanovna down\nand set her in her proper place, for goodness only knew what she was\nfancying herself': 49, 'Katerina Ivanovna was irritated too by the fact that\nhardly any of the lodgers invited had come to the funeral, except\nthe Pole who had just managed to run into the cemetery, while to the\nmemorial dinner the poorest and most insignificant of them had turned\nup, the wretched creatures, many of them not quite sober': 56, 'The older\nand more respectable of them all, as if by common consent, stayed away': 15, "Pyotr Petrovitch Luzhin, for instance, who might be said to be the most\nrespectable of all the lodgers, did not appear, though Katerina Ivanovna\nhad the evening before told all the world, that is Amalia Ivanovna,\nPolenka, Sonia and the Pole, that he was the most generous,\nnoble-hearted man with a large property and vast connections, who had\nbeen a friend of her first husband's, and a guest in her father's\nhouse, and that he had promised to use all his influence to secure her\na considerable pension": 88, "It must be noted that when Katerina Ivanovna\nexalted anyone's connections and fortune, it was without any ulterior\nmotive, quite disinterestedly, for the mere pleasure of adding to\nthe consequence of the person praised": 34, 'Probably "taking his cue" from\nLuzhin, "that contemptible wretch Lebeziatnikov had not turned up\neither': 15, 'What did he fancy himself': 5, 'He was only asked out of kindness\nand because he was sharing the same room with Pyotr Petrovitch and was a\nfriend of his, so that it would have been awkward not to invite him': 35, '"\n\nAmong those who failed to appear were "the genteel lady and her\nold-maidish daughter," who had only been lodgers in the house for the\nlast fortnight, but had several times complained of the noise and uproar\nin Katerina Ivanovna\'s room, especially when Marmeladov had come\nback drunk': 48, 'Katerina Ivanovna heard this from Amalia Ivanovna who,\nquarrelling with Katerina Ivanovna, and threatening to turn the whole\nfamily out of doors, had shouted at her that they "were not worth the\nfoot" of the honourable lodgers whom they were disturbing': 41, 'Katerina\nIvanovna determined now to invite this lady and her daughter, "whose\nfoot she was not worth," and who had turned away haughtily when she\ncasually met them, so that they might know that "she was more noble in\nher thoughts and feelings and did not harbour malice," and might see\nthat she was not accustomed to her way of living': 61, "She had proposed to\nmake this clear to them at dinner with allusions to her late father's\ngovernorship, and also at the same time to hint that it was exceedingly\nstupid of them to turn away on meeting her": 39, 'The fat colonel-major (he\nwas really a discharged officer of low rank) was also absent, but it\nappeared that he had been "not himself" for the last two days': 29, "The party\nconsisted of the Pole, a wretched looking clerk with a spotty face and\na greasy coat, who had not a word to say for himself, and smelt\nabominably, a deaf and almost blind old man who had once been in the\npost office and who had been from immemorial ages maintained by someone\nat Amalia Ivanovna's": 58, 'A retired clerk of the commissariat department came, too; he was\ndrunk, had a loud and most unseemly laugh and only fancy--was without\na waistcoat': 25, 'One of the visitors sat straight down to the table without\neven greeting Katerina Ivanovna': 15, 'Finally one person having no suit\nappeared in his dressing-gown, but this was too much, and the efforts of\nAmalia Ivanovna and the Pole succeeded in removing him': 28, "The Pole brought\nwith him, however, two other Poles who did not live at Amalia Ivanovna's\nand whom no one had seen here before": 24, 'All this irritated Katerina\nIvanovna intensely': 6, '"For whom had they made all these preparations\nthen': 9, '" To make room for the visitors the children had not even been laid\nfor at the table; but the two little ones were sitting on a bench in the\nfurthest corner with their dinner laid on a box, while Polenka as a big\ngirl had to look after them, feed them, and keep their noses wiped like\nwell-bred children\'s': 60, 'Katerina Ivanovna, in fact, could hardly help meeting her guests with\nincreased dignity, and even haughtiness': 16, 'She stared at some of them with\nspecial severity, and loftily invited them to take their seats': 17, 'Rushing\nto the conclusion that Amalia Ivanovna must be responsible for those who\nwere absent, she began treating her with extreme nonchalance, which the\nlatter promptly observed and resented': 29, 'Such a beginning was no good omen\nfor the end': 10, 'All were seated at last': 5, 'Raskolnikov came in almost at the moment of their return from the\ncemetery': 13, 'Katerina Ivanovna was greatly delighted to see him, in the\nfirst place, because he was the one "educated visitor, and, as everyone\nknew, was in two years to take a professorship in the university," and\nsecondly because he immediately and respectfully apologised for having\nbeen unable to be at the funeral': 51, 'She positively pounced upon him, and\nmade him sit on her left hand (Amalia Ivanovna was on her right)': 19, 'In\nspite of her continual anxiety that the dishes should be passed round\ncorrectly and that everyone should taste them, in spite of the agonising\ncough which interrupted her every minute and seemed to have grown worse\nduring the last few days, she hastened to pour out in a half whisper to\nRaskolnikov all her suppressed feelings and her just indignation at\nthe failure of the dinner, interspersing her remarks with lively and\nuncontrollable laughter at the expense of her visitors and especially of\nher landlady': 86, '"It\'s all that cuckoo\'s fault': 5, 'You know whom I mean': 5, 'Her, her': 2, '" Katerina\nIvanovna nodded towards the landlady': 7, '"Look at her, she\'s making round\neyes, she feels that we are talking about her and can\'t understand': 18, 'Pfoo, the owl': 3, 'Ha-ha': 1, '(Cough-cough-cough': 1, ') And what does she put on that\ncap for': 10, '"\n\nHere her laugh turned again to an insufferable fit of coughing that\nlasted five minutes': 16, 'Drops of perspiration stood out on her forehead\nand her handkerchief was stained with blood': 15, 'She showed Raskolnikov\nthe blood in silence, and as soon as she could get her breath began\nwhispering to him again with extreme animation and a hectic flush on her\ncheeks': 31, '"Do you know, I gave her the most delicate instructions, so to speak,\nfor inviting that lady and her daughter, you understand of whom I am\nspeaking': 27, 'It needed the utmost delicacy, the greatest nicety, but she\nhas managed things so that that fool, that conceited baggage, that\nprovincial nonentity, simply because she is the widow of a major, and\nhas come to try and get a pension and to fray out her 29, 'The message from Pyotr Petrovitch was very successful': 8, 'Listening to\nSonia with dignity, Katerina Ivanovna inquired with equal dignity how\nPyotr Petrovitch was, then at once whispered almost aloud to\nRaskolnikov that it certainly would have been strange for a man of\nPyotr Petrovitch\'s position and standing to find himself in such\n"extraordinary company," in spite of his scanned her visitors, and\nsuddenly inquired aloud across the table of the deaf man: "Wouldn\'t he\nhave some more meat, and had he been given some wine': 36, '" The old man made\nno answer and for a long while could not understand what he was asked,\nthough his neighbours amused themselves by poking and shaking him': 29, 'He\nsimply gazed about him with his mouth open, which only increased the\ngeneral mirth': 15, '"What an imbecile': 3, 'Look, look': 2, 'Why was he brought': 4, 'But as to Pyotr\nPetrovitch, I always had confidence in him," Katerina Ivanovna\ncontinued, "and, of course, he is not like': 21, '" with an extremely stern\nface she addressed Amalia Ivanovna so sharply and loudly that the latter\nwas quite disconcerted, "not like your dressed up draggletails whom\nmy father would not have taken as cooks into his kitchen, and my late\nhusband would have done them honour if he had invited them in the\ngoodness of his heart': 58, '"\n\n"Yes, he was fond of drink, he was fond of it, he did drink': 15, '" cried the\ncommissariat clerk, gulping down his twelfth glass of vodka': 12, '"My late husband certainly had that weakness, and everyone knows\nit," Katerina Ivanovna attacked him at once, "but he was a kind and\nhonourable man, who loved and respected his family': 31, 'The worst of it was\nhis good nature made him trust all sorts of disreputable people, and he\ndrank with fellows who were not worth the sole of his shoe': 30, 'Would you\nbelieve it, Rodion Romanovitch, they found a gingerbread cock in his\npocket; he was dead drunk, but he did not forget the children': 25, '"\n\n"A cock': 3, 'Did you say a cock': 5, '" shouted the commissariat clerk': 5, 'Katerina Ivanovna did not vouchsafe a reply': 7, 'She sighed, lost in\nthought': 5, '"No doubt you think, like everyone, that I was too severe with him," she\nwent on, addressing Raskolnikov': 18, '"But that\'s not so': 4, 'He respected me, he\nrespected me very much': 8, 'He was a kind-hearted man': 5, 'And how sorry I was\nfor him sometimes': 8, "He would sit in a corner and look at me, I used to\nfeel so sorry for him, I used to want to be kind to him and then would\nthink to myself: ‘Be kind to him and he will drink again,' it was only\nby severity that you could keep him within bounds": 54, '"\n\n"Yes, he used to get his hair pulled pretty often," roared the\ncommissariat clerk again, swallowing another glass of vodka': 21, '"Some fools would be the better for a good drubbing, as well as having\ntheir hair pulled': 17, 'I am not talking of my late 12, 'Many of the\nvisitors were sniggering, evidently delighted': 8, 'They began poking the\ncommissariat clerk and whispering something to him': 11, 'They were evidently\ntrying to egg him on': 8, '"Allow me to ask what are you alluding to," began the clerk, "that is\nto say, whose': 17, 'about whom': 2, 'did you say just now': 5, "But I don't care": 4, "That's nonsense": 2, 'Widow': 1, 'I forgive you': 3, 'Pass': 1, '"\n\nAnd he took another drink of vodka': 8, 'Raskolnikov sat in silence, listening with disgust': 7, 'He only ate from\npoliteness, just tasting the food that Katerina Ivanovna was continually\nputting on his plate, to avoid hurting her feelings': 23, 'He watched Sonia\nintently': 4, "But Sonia became more and more anxious and distressed; she,\ntoo, foresaw that the dinner would not end peaceably, and saw with\nterror Katerina Ivanovna's growing irritation": 27, "She knew that she, Sonia,\nwas the chief reason for the ‘genteel' ladies' contemptuous treatment of\nKaterina Ivanovna's invitation": 19, 'She had heard from Amalia Ivanovna that\nthe mother was positively offended at the invitation and had asked the\nquestion: "How could she let her daughter sit down beside _that young\nperson_': 32, '" Sonia had a feeling that Katerina Ivanovna had already heard\nthis and an insult to Sonia meant more to Katerina Ivanovna than an\ninsult to herself, her children, or her father, Sonia knew that\nKaterina Ivanovna would not be satisfied now, "till she had shown those\ndraggletails that they were both': 52, '" To make matters worse someone\npassed Sonia, from the other end of the table, a plate with two hearts\npierced with an arrow, cut out of black bread': 29, 'Katerina Ivanovna flushed\ncrimson and at once said aloud across the table that the man who sent it\nwas "a drunken ass': 22, '"\n\nAmalia Ivanovna was foreseeing something amiss, and at the same time\ndeeply wounded by Katerina Ivanovna\'s haughtiness, and to restore the\ngood-humour of the company and raise herself in their esteem she began,\napropos of nothing, telling a story about an acquaintance of hers "Karl\nfrom the chemist\'s," who was driving one night in a cab, and that "the\ncabman wanted him to kill, and Karl very much begged him not to kill,\nand wept and clasped hands, and frightened and from fear pierced his\nheart': 87, '" Though Katerina Ivanovna smiled, she observed at once that\nAmalia Ivanovna ought not to tell anecdotes in Russian; the latter was\nstill more offended, and she retorted that her "_Vater aus Berlin_ was a\nvery important man, and always went with his hands in pockets': 46, '" Katerina\nIvanovna could not restrain herself and laughed so much that Amalia\nIvanovna lost patience and could scarcely control herself': 21, '"Listen to the owl': 4, '" Katerina Ivanovna whispered at once, her\ngood-humour almost restored, "she meant to say he kept his hands in\nhis pockets, but she said he put his hands in people\'s pockets': 31, '(Cough-cough': 1, ') And have you noticed, Rodion Romanovitch, that all these\nPetersburg foreigners, the Germans especially, are all stupider than\nwe': 20, "Can you fancy anyone of us telling how ‘Karl from the chemist's'\n‘pierced his heart from fear' and that the idiot, instead of punishing\nthe cabman, ‘clasped his hands and wept, and much begged": 34, "' Ah, the fool": 4, "And you know she fancies it's very touching and does not suspect how\nstupid she is": 16, 'To my thinking that drunken commissariat clerk is a great\ndeal cleverer, anyway one can see that he has addled his brains with\ndrink, but you know, these foreigners are always so well behaved\nand serious': 36, 'Look how she sits glaring': 5, 'She is angry, ha-ha': 4, ')"\n\nRegaining her good-humour, Katerina Ivanovna began at once telling\nRaskolnikov that when she had obtained her pension, she intended to open\na school for the daughters of gentlemen in her native town T----': 34, 'This was the first time she had spoken to him of the project, and she\nlaunched out into the most alluring details': 22, 'It suddenly appeared that\nKaterina Ivanovna had in her hands the very certificate of honour of\nwhich Marmeladov had spoken to Raskolnikov in the tavern, when he told\nhim that Katerina Ivanovna, his wife, had danced the shawl dance\nbefore the governor and other great personages on leaving school': 49, 'This\ncertificate of honour was obviously intended now to prove Katerina\nIvanovna\'s right to open a boarding-school; but she had armed herself\nwith it chiefly with the object of overwhelming "those two stuck-up\ndraggletails" if they came to the dinner, and proving incontestably\nthat Katerina Ivanovna was of the most noble, "she might even say\naristocratic family, a colonel\'s daughter and was far superior to\ncertain adventuresses who have been so much to the fore of late': 77, '" The\ncertificate of honour immediately passed into the hands of the drunken\nguests, and Katerina Ivanovna did not try to retain it, for it actually\ncontained the statement _en toutes lettres_, that her father was of the\nrank of a major, and also a companion of an order, so that she really\nwas almost the daughter of a colonel': 60, 'Warming up, Katerina Ivanovna proceeded to enlarge on the peaceful and\nhappy life they would lead in T----, on the gymnasium teachers whom\nshe would engage to give lessons in her boarding-school, one a most\nrespectable old Frenchman, one Mangot, who had taught Katerina Ivanovna\nherself in old days and was still living in T----, and would no doubt\nteach in her school on moderate terms': 66, 'Next she spoke of Sonia who would\ngo with her to T---- and help her in all her plans': 19, 'At this someone at\nthe further end of the table gave a sudden guffaw': 14, 'Though Katerina Ivanovna tried to appear to be disdainfully unaware of\nit, she raised her voice and began at once speaking with conviction of\nSonia\'s undoubted ability to assist her, of "her gentleness, patience,\ndevotion, generosity and good education," tapping Sonia on the cheek and\nkissing her warmly twice': 49, 'Sonia flushed crimson, and Katerina Ivanovna\nsuddenly burst into tears, immediately observing that she was "nervous\nand silly, that she was too much upset, that it was time to finish, and\nas the dinner was over, it was time to hand round the tea': 44, '"\n\nAt that moment, Amalia Ivanovna, deeply aggrieved at taking no part in\nthe conversation, and not being listened to, made one last effort,\nand with secret misgivings ventured on an exceedingly deep and weighty\nobservation, that "in the future boarding-school she would have to pay\nparticular attention to _die Wäsche_, and that there certainly must be a\ngood _dame_ to look after the linen, and secondly that the young ladies\nmust not novels at night read': 77, '"\n\nKaterina Ivanovna, who certainly was upset and very tired, as well as\nheartily sick of the dinner, at once cut short Amalia Ivanovna, saying\n"she knew nothing about it and was talking nonsense, that it was the\nbusiness of the laundry maid, and not of the directress of a high-class\nboarding-school to look after _die Wäsche_, and as for novel-reading,\nthat was simply rudeness, and she begged her to be silent': 72, '" Amalia\nIvanovna fired up and getting angry observed that she only "meant her\ngood," and that "she had meant her very good," and that "it was long\nsince she had paid her _gold_ for the lodgings': 37, '"\n\nKaterina Ivanovna at once "set her down," saying that it was a lie to\nsay she wished her good, because only yesterday when her dead husband\nwas lying on the table, she had worried her about the lodgings': 39, 'To this\nAmalia Ivanovna very appropriately observed that she had invited those\nladies, but "those ladies had not come, because those ladies _are_\nladies and cannot come to a lady who is not a lady': 35, '" Katerina Ivanovna\nat once pointed out to her, that as she was a slut she could not judge\nwhat made one really a lady': 25, 'Amalia Ivanovna at once declared that her\n"_Vater aus Berlin_ was a very, very important man, and both hands in\npockets went, and always used to say: ‘Poof': 28, 'poof': 1, '\'" and she leapt\nup from the table to represent her father, sticking her hands in her\npockets, puffing her cheeks, and uttering vague sounds resembling "poof': 27, '" amid loud laughter from all the lodgers, who purposely encouraged\nAmalia Ivanovna, hoping for a fight': 17, 'But this was too much for Katerina Ivanovna, and she at once declared,\nso that all could hear, that Amalia Ivanovna probably never had a\nfather, but was simply a drunken Petersburg Finn, and had certainly once\nbeen a cook and probably something worse': 44, 'Amalia Ivanovna turned as red\nas a lobster and squealed that perhaps Katerina Ivanovna never had a\nfather, "but she had a _Vater aus Berlin_ and that he wore a long coat\nand always said poof-poof-poof': 36, '"\n\nKaterina Ivanovna observed contemptuously that all knew what her family\nwas and that on that very certificate of honour it was stated in print\nthat her father was a colonel, while Amalia Ivanovna\'s father--if she\nreally had one--was probably some Finnish milkman, but that probably she\nnever had a father at all, since it was still uncertain whether her name\nwas Amalia Ivanovna or Amalia Ludwigovna': 67, 'At this Amalia Ivanovna, lashed to fury, struck the table with her fist,\nand shrieked that she was Amalia Ivanovna, and not Ludwigovna, "that\nher _Vater_ was named Johann and that he was a burgomeister, and that\nKaterina Ivanovna\'s _Vater_ was quite never a burgomeister': 45, '" Katerina\nIvanovna rose from her chair, and with a stern and apparently calm voice\n(though she was pale and her chest was heaving) observed that "if she\ndared for one moment to set her contemptible wretch of a father on a\nlevel with her papa, she, Katerina Ivanovna, would tear her cap off her\nhead and trample it under foot': 61, '" Amalia Ivanovna ran about the room,\nshouting at the top of her voice, that she was mistress of the house and\nthat Katerina Ivanovna should leave the lodgings that minute; then she\nrushed for some reason to collect the silver spoons from the table': 45, had it in your hand)": 72, 'You folded it and kept it in your hand\nall the time': 12, "I didn't think of it again until, when you were getting\nup, you changed it from your right hand to your left ('DOS CHAPTER IV PART V', {'Raskolnikov had been a vigorous and active champion of Sonia against\nLuzhin, although he had such a load of horror and anguish in his own\nheart': 26, 'But having gone through so much in the morning, he found a sort\nof relief in a change of sensations, apart from the strong personal\nfeeling which impelled him to defend Sonia': 32, 'He was agitated too,\nespecially at some moments, by the thought of his approaching interview\nwith Sonia: he _had_ to tell her who had killed Lizaveta': 26, 'He knew the\nterrible suffering it would be to him and, as it were, brushed away the\nthought of it': 20, 'So when he cried as he left Katerina Ivanovna\'s, "Well,\nSofya Semyonovna, we shall see what you\'ll say now': 19, '" he was still\nsuperficially excited, still vigorous and defiant from his triumph over\nLuzhin': 15, "But, strange to say, by the time he reached Sonia's lodging, he\nfelt a sudden impotence and fear": 18, 'He stood still in hesitation at the\ndoor, asking himself the strange question: "Must he tell her who killed\nLizaveta': 20, '" It was a strange question because he felt at the very time\nnot only that he could not help telling her, but also that he could\nnot put off the telling': 32, 'He did not yet know why it must be so, he\nonly _felt_ it, and the agonising sense of his impotence before\nthe inevitable almost crushed him': 27, 'To cut short his hesitation and\nsuffering, he quickly opened the door and looked at Sonia from the\ndoorway': 19, 'She was sitting with her elbows on the table and her face in\nher hands, but seeing Raskolnikov she got up at once and came to meet\nhim as though she were expecting him': 34, '"What would have become of me but for you': 9, '" she said quickly, meeting\nhim in the middle of the room': 12, 'Evidently she was in haste to say this to him': 10, 'It was what she had been\nwaiting for': 8, 'Raskolnikov went to the table and sat down on the chair from which she\nhad only just risen': 18, 'She stood facing him, two steps away, just as she\nhad done the day before': 15, '"Well, Sonia': 2, '" he said, and felt that his voice was trembling, "it was\nall due to ‘your social position and the habits associated with it': 24, "' Did\nyou understand that just now": 7, '"\n\nHer face showed her distress': 6, '"Only don\'t talk to me as you did yesterday," she interrupted him': back to the\nwall, putting out her hand, with childish terror in her face, looking\nas little children do when they begin to be frightened of something,\nlooking intently and uneasily at what frightens them, shrinking back and\nholding out their little hands on the point of crying": 66, 'Almost the same\nthing happened now to Sonia': 8, 'With the same helplessness and the same\nterror, she she\ntried to look into him and catch some last hope': 16, 'But there was no hope;\nthere was no doubt remaining; it was all true': 14, 'Later on, indeed, when\nshe recalled that moment, she thought pressed forward': 9, '"She\'s dying," someone shouted': 4, '"She\'s gone out of her mind," said another': 8, '"Lord have mercy upon us," said a woman, crossing herself': 10, '"Have they\ncaught the herself against a stone, as Sonia thought, but that the blood\nthat stained the pavement red was from her chest': 34, '"I\'ve seen that before," muttered the official to Raskolnikov and\nLebeziatnikov; "that\'s consumption; the blood flows and chokes the\npatient': 20, 'I saw the same thing with a relative of my own not long ago': 14, 'nearly a pint of blood, all in a minute': 9, "What's to be done though": 5, 'She is dying': 3, '"\n\n"This way, this way, to my room': 8, '" Sonia implored': 3, '"I live here': 3, 'See,\nthat house, the second from here': 7, 'Come to me, make haste," she turned\nfrom one to the other': 12, '"Send for the doctor': 4, '"\n\nThanks to the official\'s efforts, this plan was adopted, the policeman\neven helping to carry Katerina Ivanovna': 18, "She was carried to Sonia's\nroom, almost unconscious, and laid on the bed": 13, 'The blood was still\nflowing, but she seemed to be coming to herself': 13, 'Raskolnikov,\nLebeziatnikov, and the official accompanied Sonia into the room and were\nfollowed by the policeman, who first drove back the crowd which followed\nto the very door': 28, 'Polenka came in holding Kolya and Lida, who\nwere trembling and weeping': 12, "Several persons came in too from the\nKapernaumovs' room; the landlord, a lame one-eyed man of strange\nappearance with whiskers and hair that stood up like a brush, looked at him\nwith surprise, not understanding where he had come from and not having\nnoticed him in the crowd': 21, 'A doctor and priest wore spoken of': 7, 'The\nofficial whispered to Raskolnikov that he thought it was too late now\nfor the doctor, but he ordered him to be sent for': 24, 'Kapernaumov ran\nhimself': 3, 'Meanwhile Katerina Ivanovna had regained her breath': 7, 'The bleeding ceased\nfor a time': 6, 'She looked with sick but intent and penetrating eyes at\nSonia, who stood pale and trembling, wiping the sweat from her brow with\na handkerchief': 25, 'At last she asked to poor thing': 3, 'I am done for': 4, 'I am broken': 3, '"\n she cried with vindictive despair, and her head fell heavily back on the\npillow': 15, 'She sank into unconsciousness again, but this time it did not last long': 13, 'Her pale, yellow, wasted face dropped back, her mouth fell open, her leg\nmoved convulsively, she gave a deep, deep sigh and died': 23, "Sonia fell upon her, flung her arms about her, and remained motionless\nwith her head pressed to the dead woman's wasted bosom": 22, "Polenka threw\nherself at her mother's feet, kissing them and weeping violently": 12, "Though\nKolya and Lida did not understand what had happened, they had a feeling\nthat it was something terrible; they put their hands on each other's\nlittle shoulders, stared straight at one another and both at ('DOS CHAPTER I PART VI', {'A strange period began for Raskolnikov: it was as though a fog had\nfallen upon him and wrapped him in a dreary solitude from which there\nwas no escape': 29, 'Recalling that period long after, he believed that his\nmind had been clouded at times, and that it had continued so, with\nintervals, till the final catastrophe': 27, 'He was convinced that he had been\nmistaken about many things at that time, for instance as to the date\nof certain events': 23, 'Anyway, when he tried later on to piece his\nrecollections together, he learnt a great deal about himself from what\nother people told him': 24, 'He had mixed up incidents and had explained\nevents as due to circumstances which existed only in his imagination': 19, 'At\ntimes he was a prey to agonies of morbid uneasiness, amounting sometimes\nto panic': 15, 'But he remembered, too, moments, hours, perhaps whole days,\nof complete apathy, which came upon him as a reaction from his previous\nterror and might be compared with the abnormal insensibility, sometimes\nseen in the dying': 36, 'He seemed to be trying in that latter stage to escape\nfrom a full and clear understanding of his position': 20, 'Certain essential\nfacts which required immediate consideration were particularly irksome\nto him': 12, 'How glad he would have been to be free from some cares, the\nneglect of which would have threatened him with complete, inevitable\nruin': 24, 'He was particularly worried about Svidrigaïlov, he might be said to be\npermanently thinking of Svidrigaïlov': 16, "From the time of Svidrigaïlov's\ntoo menacing and unmistakable words in Sonia's room at the moment of\nKaterina Ivanovna's death, the normal working of his mind seemed to\nbreak down": 30, 'But although this new fact caused him extreme uneasiness,\nRaskolnikov was in no hurry for an explanation of it': 19, 'At times, finding\nhimself in a solitary and remote part of the town, in some wretched\neating-house, sitting alone lost in thought, hardly knowing how he had\ncome there, he suddenly thought of Svidrigaïlov': 34, 'He recognised\nsuddenly, clearly, and with dismay that he ought at once to come to an\nunderstanding with that man and to make what terms he could': 27, 'Walking\noutside the city gates one day, he positively fancied that they had\nfixed a meeting there, that he was waiting for Svidrigaïlov': 23, 'Another\ntime he woke up before daybreak lying on the ground under some bushes\nand could not at first understand how he had come there': 25, "But during the two or three days after Katerina Ivanovna's death, he\nhad two or three times met Svidrigaïlov at Sonia's lodging, where he\nhad gone aimlessly for a moment": 30, 'They exchanged a few words and made no\nreference to the vital subject, as though they were tacitly agreed not\nto speak of it for a time': 27, "Katerina Ivanovna's body was still lying in the coffin, Svidrigaïlov was\nbusy making arrangements for the funeral": 17, 'Sonia too was very busy': 5, "At\ntheir last meeting Svidrigaïlov informed Raskolnikov that he had made\nan arrangement, and a very satisfactory one, for Katerina Ivanovna's\nchildren; that he had, through certain connections, succeeded in getting\nhold of certain personages by whose help the three orphans could be at\nonce placed in very suitable institutions; that the money he had settled\non them had been of great assistance, as it is much easier to place\norphans with some property than destitute ones": 77, 'He said something\ntoo about Sonia and promised to come himself in a day or two to see\nRaskolnikov, mentioning that "he would like to consult with him, that\nthere were things they must talk over': 36, '"\n\nThis conversation took place in the passage on the stairs': 11, 'Svidrigaïlov\nlooked intently at Raskolnikov and suddenly, after a brief pause,\ndropping his voice, asked: "But how is it, Rodion Romanovitch; you\ndon\'t seem yourself': 25, "You look and you listen, but you don't seem to\nunderstand": 11, 'Cheer up': 2, "We'll talk things over; I am only sorry, I've\nso much to do of my own business and other people's": 20, 'Ah, Rodion\nRomanovitch," he added suddenly, "what all men need is fresh air, fresh\nair': 15, 'more than anything': 3, '"\n\nHe moved to one side to make way for the priest and server, who\nwere coming up the stairs': 20, 'They had come for the requiem service': 7, "By\nSvidrigaïlov's orders it was sung twice a day punctually": 10, 'Svidrigaïlov\nwent his way': 4, "Raskolnikov stood still a moment, thought, and followed\nthe priest into Sonia's room": 13, 'He stood at the door': 5, 'They began quietly,\nslowly and mournfully singing the service': 9, 'From his childhood the\nthought of death and the presence of death had something oppressive\nand mysteriously awful; and it was long since he had heard the requiem\nservice': 29, 'And there was something else here as well, too awful and\ndisturbing': 12, 'He looked at the children: they were all kneeling by the\ncoffin; Polenka was weeping': 15, 'Behind them Sonia prayed, softly and, as it\nwere, timidly weeping': 11, '"These last two days she hasn\'t said a word to me, she hasn\'t glanced at\nme," Raskolnikov thought suddenly': 19, 'The sunlight was bright in the room;\nthe incense rose in clouds; the priest read, "Give rest, oh Lord': 19, '"\n Raskolnikov stayed all through the service': 7, 'As he blessed them and\ntook his leave, the priest looked round strangely': 13, 'After the service,\nRaskolnikov went up to Sonia': 8, 'She took both his hands and let her\nhead sink on his shoulder': 13, 'This slight friendly gesture bewildered\nRaskolnikov': 6, 'It seemed strange to him that there was no trace of\nrepugnance, no trace of disgust, no tremor in her hand': 21, 'It was the\nfurthest limit of self-abnegation, at least so he interpreted it': 13, 'Sonia said nothing': 3, 'Raskolnikov pressed her hand and went out': 7, 'He felt\nvery miserable': 4, 'If it had been possible to escape to some solitude, he\nwould have thought himself lucky, even if he had to spend his whole life\nthere': 26, 'But although he had almost always been by himself of late, he had\nnever been able to feel alone': 19, 'Sometimes he walked out of the town on to\nthe high road, once he had even reached a little wood, but the lonelier\nthe place was, the more he seemed to be aware of an uneasy presence near\nhim': 39, 'It did not frighten him, but greatly annoyed him, so that he\nmade haste to return to the town, to mingle with the crowd, to enter\nrestaurants and taverns, to walk in busy thoroughfares': 34, 'There he felt\neasier and even more solitary': 8, 'One day at dusk he sat for an hour\nlistening to songs in a tavern and he remembered that he positively\nenjoyed it': 23, 'But at last he had suddenly felt the same uneasiness again,\nas though his conscience smote him': 17, '"Here I sit listening to singing,\nis that what I ought to be doing': 14, '" he thought': 3, 'Yet he felt at once\nthat that was not the only cause of his uneasiness; there was something\nrequiring immediate decision, but it was something he could not clearly\nunderstand or put into words': 34, 'It was a hopeless tangle': 5, '"No, better the\nstruggle again': 5, 'Better Porfiry again': 3, 'or Svidrigaïlov': 2, 'Better some\nchallenge again': 4, 'some attack': 2, 'Yes, yes': 2, 'He went out of\nthe tavern and rushed away almost at a run': 13, 'The thought of Dounia and\nhis mother suddenly reduced him almost to a panic': 14, 'That night he woke\nup before morning among some bushes in Krestovsky Island, trembling\nall over with fever; he walked home, and it was early morning when he\narrived': 29, "After some hours' sleep the fever left him, but he woke up\nlate, two o'clock in the afternoon": 18, "He remembered that Katerina Ivanovna's funeral had been fixed for that\nday, and was glad that he was not present at it": 22, 'Nastasya brought him\nsome food; he ate and drank with appetite, almost with greediness': 14, 'His\nhead was fresher and he was calmer than he had been for the last three\ndays': 17, 'He even felt a passing all the way": 14, 'We kept begging her to be calm': 7, "We came in, you weren't here; she sat down, and stayed ten minutes,\nwhile we stood waiting in silence": 19, "She got up and said: ‘If ('DOS CHAPTER III PART VI', {"He hurried to Svidrigaïlov's": 4, 'What he had to hope from that man he\ndid not know': 12, 'But that man had some hidden power over him': 9, 'Having once\nrecognised this, he could not rest, and now the time had come': 14, "On the way, one question particularly worried him: had Svidrigaïlov been\nto Porfiry's": 13, 'As far as he could judge, he would swear to it, that he had not': 15, "He\npondered again and again, went over Porfiry's visit; no, he hadn't been,\nof course he hadn't": 17, 'But if he had not been yet, would he go': 10, "Meanwhile, for the present he\nfancied he couldn't": 8, 'Why': 1, 'He could not have explained, but if he could,\nhe would not have wasted much thought over it at the moment': 21, 'It all\nworried him and at the same time he could not attend to it': 15, 'Strange to\nsay, none would have believed it perhaps, but he only felt a faint vague\nanxiety about his immediate future': 21, 'Another, much more important anxiety\ntormented him--it concerned himself, but in a different, more vital way': 16, 'Moreover, he was conscious of immense moral fatigue, though his mind was\nworking better that morning than it had done of late': 22, 'And was it worth while, after all that had happened, to contend with\nthese new trivial difficulties': 17, "Was it worth while, for instance, to\nmanoeuvre that Svidrigaïlov should not go to Porfiry's": 15, 'Was it worth\nwhile to investigate, to ascertain the facts, to waste time over anyone\nlike Svidrigaïlov': 17, 'Oh, how sick he was of it all': 8, 'And yet he was hastening to Svidrigaïlov; could he be expecting\nsomething _new_ from him, information, or means of escape': 20, 'Men will\ncatch at straws': 5, 'Was it destiny or some instinct bringing them together': 9, 'Perhaps it was only fatigue, despair; perhaps it was not Svidrigaïlov\nbut some other whom he needed, and Svidrigaïlov had simply presented\nhimself by chance': 25, 'Sonia': 1, 'But what should he go to Sonia for now': 9, 'To beg\nher tears again': 5, 'He was afraid of Sonia, too': 6, 'Sonia stood before him as\nan irrevocable sentence': 8, 'He must go his own way or hers': 8, 'At that moment\nespecially he did not feel equal to seeing her': 12, 'No, would it not be\nbetter to try Svidrigaïlov': 9, 'And he could not help inwardly owning that\nhe had long felt that he must see him for some reason': 20, 'But what could they have in common': 7, 'Their very evil-doing could not\nbe of the same kind': 10, 'The man, moreover, was very unpleasant, evidently\ndepraved, undoubtedly cunning and deceitful, possibly malignant': 14, 'Such\nstories were told about him': 6, "It is true he was befriending Katerina\nIvanovna's children, but who could tell with what motive and what it\nmeant": 20, 'The man always had some design, some project': 8, "There was another thought which had been continually hovering of late\nabout Raskolnikov's mind, and causing him great uneasiness": 19, 'It was so\npainful that he made distinct efforts to get rid of it': 14, 'He sometimes\nthought that Svidrigaïlov was dogging his footsteps': 9, 'Svidrigaïlov had\nfound out his secret and had had designs on Dounia': 12, 'What if he had them\nstill': 6, "Wasn't it practically certain that he had": 7, 'And what if, having\nlearnt his secret and so having gained power over him, he were to use it\nas a weapon against Dounia': 24, 'This idea sometimes even tormented his dreams, but it had never\npresented itself so vividly to him as on his way to Svidrigaïlov': 23, 'The very thought moved him to gloomy rage': 8, 'To begin with, this would\ntransform everything, even his own position; he would have at once to\nconfess his secret to Dounia': 22, 'Would he have to give himself up perhaps\nto prevent Dounia from taking some rash step': 16, 'The letter': 2, 'This morning\nDounia had received a letter': 7, 'From whom could she get letters in\nPetersburg': 8, 'Luzhin, perhaps': 2, "It's true Razumihin was there to protect\nher, but Razumihin knew nothing of the position": 15, 'Perhaps it was his duty\nto tell Razumihin': 8, 'He thought of it with repugnance': 6, 'In any case he must see Svidrigaïlov as soon as possible, he decided\nfinally': 14, 'Thank God, the details of the interview were of little\nconsequence, if only he could get at the root of the matter; but\nif Svidrigaïlov were capable': 27, 'if he were intriguing against\nDounia--then': 6, 'Raskolnikov was so exhausted by what he had passed through that month\nthat he could only decide such questions in one way; "then I shall kill\nhim," he thought in cold despair': 32, 'A sudden anguish oppressed his heart, he stood still in the middle of\nthe street and began looking about to see where he was and which way he\nwas going': 30, 'He found himself in X': 5, 'Prospect, thirty or forty paces from\nthe Hay Market, through which he had come': 14, 'The whole second storey of\nthe house on the left was used as a tavern': 15, 'All the windows were wide\nopen; judging from the figures moving at the windows, the rooms were\nfull to overflowing': 20, 'There were sounds of singing, of were somehow\ntoo blue and their expression somehow too heavy and fixed': 14, 'There was\nsomething awfully unpleasant in that handsome face, which looked so\nwonderfully young for his age': 17, 'Svidrigaïlov was smartly dressed in light\nsummer clothes and was particularly dainty in his linen': 15, 'He wore a huge\nring with a precious stone in it': 11, '"Have I got to bother myself about word': 6, 'You know that I can keep it': 7, 'And in the\nsecond place if you want to tell me anything--for I keep fancying all\nthis time that you have something to tell me--make haste and tell ('DOS CHAPTER IV PART VI', {'"You know perhaps--yes, I told you myself," began Svidrigaïlov, "that\nI was in the debtors\' prison here, for an immense sum, and had not\nany expectation of being able to pay it': 32, "There's no need to go into\nparticulars how Marfa Petrovna bought me out; do you know to what a\npoint of insanity a woman can sometimes love": 27, 'She was an honest woman,\nand very sensible, although completely uneducated': 11, 'Would you believe\nthat this honest and jealous woman, after many scenes of hysterics and\nreproaches, condescended to enter into a kind of contract with me which\nshe kept throughout our married life': 33, 'She was considerably older than\nI, and besides, she always kept a clove or something in her mouth': 18, "There\nwas so much swinishness in my soul and honesty too, of a sort, as to\ntell her straight out that I couldn't be absolutely faithful to her": 28, 'This confession drove her to frenzy, but yet she seems in a way to have\nliked my brutal frankness': 19, "She thought it showed I was unwilling to\ndeceive her if I warned her like this beforehand and for a jealous\nwoman, you know, that's the first consideration": 28, 'After many tears an\nunwritten contract was drawn up between us: first, that I would never\nleave Marfa Petrovna and would always be her husband; secondly, that I\nwould never absent myself without her permission; thirdly, that I would\nnever set up a permanent mistress; fourthly, in return for this, Marfa\nPetrovna gave me a free hand with the maidservants, but only with her\nsecret knowledge; fifthly, God forbid my falling in love with a woman of\nour class; sixthly, in case I--which God forbid--should be visited by\na great serious passion I was bound to reveal it to Marfa Petrovna': 101, 'On\nthis last score, however, Marfa Petrovna was fairly at ease': 11, 'She was a\nsensible woman and so she could not help looking upon me as a dissolute\nprofligate incapable of real love': 22, "But a sensible woman and a jealous\nwoman are two very different things, and that's where the trouble\ncame in": 20, 'But to judge some people impartially we must renounce certain\npreconceived opinions and our habitual attitude to the ordinary people\nabout us': 22, "I have reason to have faith in your judgment rather than\nin anyone's": 13, 'Perhaps you have already heard a great deal that was\nridiculous and absurd about Marfa Petrovna': 16, 'She certainly had some very\nridiculous ways, but I tell you frankly that I feel really sorry for the\ninnumerable woes of which I was the cause': 27, "Well, and that's enough, I\nthink, by way of a decorous _oraison funèbre_ for the most tender wife\nof a most tender husband": 23, 'When we quarrelled, I usually held my tongue\nand did not irritate her and that gentlemanly conduct rarely failed to\nattain its object, it influenced her, it pleased her, indeed': 30, 'These were\ntimes when she was positively proud of me': 10, "But your sister she couldn't\nput up with, anyway": 9, 'And however she came to risk taking such a\nbeautiful creature into her house as a governess': 17, 'My explanation is that\nMarfa Petrovna was an ardent and impressionable woman and simply fell\nin love herself--literally fell in love--with your sister': 23, 'Well, little\nwonder--look at Avdotya Romanovna': 6, 'I saw the danger at the first continually\ncomplaining of me; how could she fail to confide in such a delightful\nnew friend': 30, 'I expect they talked of nothing else but me and no doubt\nAvdotya Romanovna heard all those dark and nothing easier than flattery': 15, "If there's the hundredth part\nof a false note in speaking the truth, it leads to a discord, and that\nleads to trouble": 23, 'But if all, to the last note, is false in flattery, it\nis just as agreeable, and is heard not without satisfaction': 22, 'It may be\na coarse satisfaction, but still a satisfaction': 10, 'And however coarse the\nflattery, at least half will be sure to seem true': 14, "That's so for all\nstages of development and classes of society": 11, 'A vestal virgin might be\nseduced by flattery': 8, 'I can never remember without laughter how I once\nseduced a lady who was devoted to her husband, her children, and her\nprinciples': 23, 'What fun it was and how little trouble': 8, 'And the lady really\nhad principles--of her own, anyway': 9, 'All my tactics lay in simply being\nutterly annihilated and prostrate before her purity': 14, 'I flattered her\nshamelessly, and as soon as I succeeded in getting a pressure of\nthe hand, even a glance from her, I would reproach myself for having\nsnatched it by force, and would declare that she had resisted, so that\nI could never have gained anything but for my being so unprincipled': 53, 'I maintained that she was so innocent that she could not foresee my\ntreachery, and yielded to me unconsciously, unawares, and so on': 23, 'In\nfact, I triumphed, while my lady feet, a charmer": 16, 'Well, we made friends': 4, 'I told them I was\nin a hurry owing to domestic circumstances, and the next day, that is\nthe day before yesterday, we were betrothed': 25, 'When I has something fantastic in it, the face\nof mournful religious ecstasy": 17, "Haven't you noticed it": 4, "Well, she's\nsomething in that line": 6, "The day after we'd been betrothed, I bought her\npresents to the value of fifteen hundred roubles--a set of diamonds and\nanother of pearls and a silver dressing-case as large as this, with all\nsorts of things in it, so that even my Madonna's the principal aim is right, a\nsolitary wrongdoing and hundreds of good deeds': 34, "It's galling too, of\ncourse, for a young man of gifts and overweening pride to know that if\nhe had, for instance, a paltry three thousand, his whole career, his\nwhole future would be differently shaped and yet not to have that three\nthousand": 44, "Add to that, nervous irritability from hunger, from lodging\nin a hole, from rags, from a vivid sense of the charm of his social\nposition and his sister's and mother's position too": 32, 'Above all, vanity,\npride and vanity, though goodness knows he may have good qualities\ntoo': 15, "I am not blaming him, please don't think it; besides, it's not\nmy business": 14, 'A special little theory came in too--a theory of a\nsort--dividing mankind, you see, into material and superior persons,\nthat is persons to whom the law does not apply owing to their\nsuperiority, who make laws for the rest of mankind, the material, that\nis': 45, "It's all right as a theory, _une théorie comme une autre_": 11, 'Napoleon\nattracted him tremendously, that is, what affected him was that a\ngreat many men of genius have not hesitated at wrongdoing, but ('DOS CHAPTER VI PART VI', {"He spent that evening till ten o'clock going from one low haunt to\nanother": 14, 'Katia too turned up and sang another gutter song, how a certain\n\n"villain and tyrant,"\n\n"began kissing Katia': 18, '"\n\nSvidrigaïlov treated Katia and the organ-grinder and some singers and\nthe waiters and two little clerks': 17, 'He was particularly drawn to these\nclerks by the fact that they both had crooked noses, one bent to the\nleft and the other to the right': 27, 'They took him finally to a pleasure\ngarden, where he paid for their entrance': 14, 'There was one lanky\nthree-year-old pine-tree and three bushes in the garden, besides a\n"Vauxhall," which was in reality a drinking-bar where tea too was\nserved, and there were a few green tables and chairs standing round it': 38, 'A chorus of wretched singers and a drunken but exceedingly depressed\nGerman clown from Munich with a red nose entertained the public': 22, 'The\nclerks quarrelled with some other clerks and a fight seemed imminent': 12, 'Svidrigaïlov was chosen to decide the dispute': 7, 'He listened to them for\na quarter of an hour, but they shouted so loud that there was no\npossibility of understanding them': 23, 'The only fact that seemed certain was\nthat one of them had stolen something and had even succeeded in\nselling it on the spot to a Jew, but would not share the spoil with his\ncompanion': 36, 'Finally it appeared that the stolen object was a teaspoon\nbelonging to the Vauxhall': 14, 'It was missed and the affair began to seem\ntroublesome': 10, 'Svidrigaïlov paid for the spoon, got up, and walked out of\nthe garden': 13, "It was about six o'clock": 5, 'He had not drunk a drop of wine\nall this time and had ordered tea more for the sake of appearances than\nanything': 23, 'It was a dark and stifling evening': 7, "Threatening storm-clouds came over\nthe sky about ten o'clock": 9, 'There was a clap of thunder, and the rain\ncame down like a waterfall': 14, 'The water fell not in drops, but beat on the\nearth in streams': 13, 'There were flashes of lightning every minute and each\nflash lasted while one could count five': 16, 'Drenched to the skin, he went home, locked himself in, opened the\nbureau, took out all his money and tore up two or three papers': 25, 'Then,\nputting the money in his pocket, he was about to change his clothes,\nbut, looking out of the window and listening to the thunder and the\nrain, he gave up the idea, took up his hat and went out of the room\nwithout locking the door': 47, 'He went straight to Sonia': 5, 'She was at home': 4, 'She was not alone: the four Kapernaumov children were with her': 11, 'She\nwas giving them tea': 5, 'She received Svidrigaïlov in respectful silence,\nlooking still\npersisted': 4, 'Drenched to the skin, he walked into the little flat where\nthe parents of his betrothed lived, in Third Street in Vassilyevsky\nIsland': 23, 'He knocked some time before he was admitted, and his visit\nat first caused great perturbation; but Svidrigaïlov could be\nvery fascinating when he liked, so that the first, and indeed very\nintelligent surmise of the sensible parents that Svidrigaïlov had\nprobably had so much to drink that he did not know what he was doing\nvanished immediately': 58, 'The decrepit father was wheeled in to see\nSvidrigaïlov by the tender and sensible mother, who as usual began the\nconversation with various irrelevant questions': 25, 'She never asked a direct\nquestion, but began by smiling and rubbing her hands and then, if she\nwere obliged to ascertain something--for instance, when Svidrigaïlov\nwould like to have the wedding--she would begin by interested and\nalmost eager questions about Paris and the court life there, and only\nby degrees brought the conversation round to Third Street': 58, 'On other\noccasions this had of course been very impressive, but this time Arkady\nIvanovitch seemed particularly impatient, and insisted on seeing his\nbetrothed at once, though he had been informed, to begin with, that she\nhad already gone to bed': 41, 'The girl of course appeared': 5, 'Svidrigaïlov informed her at once that he was obliged by very important\naffairs to leave Petersburg for a time, and therefore brought her\nfifteen thousand roubles and begged her accept them as a present from\nhim, as he had long been intending to make her this trifling present\nbefore their wedding': 51, 'The logical connection of the present with his\nimmediate departure and the absolute necessity of visiting them for that\npurpose in pouring rain at midnight was not made clear': 29, 'But it all went\noff very well; even the inevitable ejaculations of wonder and regret,\nthe inevitable questions were extraordinarily few and restrained': 23, 'On the\nother hand, the gratitude expressed was most glowing and was reinforced\nby tears from the most sensible of mothers': 21, 'Svidrigaïlov got up,\nlaughed, kissed his betrothed, patted her cheek, declared he would soon\ncome back, and noticing in her eyes, together with childish curiosity, a\nsort of earnest dumb inquiry, reflected and kissed her again, though\nhe felt sincere anger inwardly at the thought that his present would be\nimmediately locked up in the keeping of the most sensible of mothers': 62, 'He\nwent away, leaving them all in a state of extraordinary excitement, but\nthe tender mamma, speaking quietly in a half whisper, settled some of\nthe most important of their doubts, concluding that Svidrigaïlov was\na great man, a man of great affairs and connections and of great\nwealth--there was no knowing what he had in his mind': 58, 'He would start\noff on a journey and give away money just as the fancy took him, so that\nthere was nothing surprising about it': 25, "Of course it was strange that he\nwas wet through, but Englishmen, for instance, are even more eccentric,\nand all these people of high society didn't think of what was said of\nthem and didn't stand on ceremony": 38, 'Possibly, indeed, he came like that\non purpose to show that he was not afraid of anyone': 17, 'Above all, not a\nword should be said about it, for God knows what might come of it, and\nthe money must be locked up, and it was most fortunate that Fedosya, the\ncook, had not left the kitchen': 39, 'And above all not a word must be said\nto that old cat, Madame Resslich, and so on and so on': 21, "They sat up\nwhispering till two o'clock, but the girl went to bed much earlier,\namazed and rather sorrowful": 19, 'Svidrigaïlov meanwhile, exactly at midnight, crossed the bridge on the\nway back to the mainland': 15, 'The rain had ceased and there was a roaring\nwind': 10, 'He began shivering, and for one moment he gazed at the black\nwaters of the Little Neva with a look of special interest, even inquiry': 25, 'But he soon felt it very cold, standing by the water; he turned and\nwent towards Y': 17, 'Prospect': 1, 'He walked along that endless street for a long\ntime, almost half an hour, more than once stumbling in the dark on the\nwooden pavement, but continually looking for something on the right side\nof the street': 37, 'He had noticed passing through this street lately that\nthere was a hotel somewhere towards the end, built of wood, but fairly\nlarge, and its name he remembered was something like Adrianople': 32, 'He was\nnot mistaken: the hotel was so conspicuous in that God-forsaken place\nthat he could not fail to see it even in the dark': 25, 'It was a long,\nblackened wooden building, and in spite of the late hour there were\nlights in the windows and signs of life within': 25, 'He went in and asked\na ragged fellow who met him in the corridor for a room': 17, 'The latter,\nscanning Svidrigaïlov, pulled himself together and led him at once to a\nclose and tiny room in the distance, at the end of the corridor, under\nthe stairs': 30, 'There was no other, all were occupied': 7, 'The ragged fellow\nlooked inquiringly': 5, '"Is there tea': 3, '" asked Svidrigaïlov': 3, '"Yes, sir': 2, '"\n\n"What else is there': 5, '"\n\n"Veal, vodka, savouries': 4, '"\n\n"Bring me tea and veal': 6, '"\n\n"And you want nothing else': 6, '" he asked with apparent surprise': 6, '"Nothing, nothing': 2, '"\n\nThe ragged man went away, completely disillusioned': 8, '"It must be a nice place," thought Svidrigaïlov': 8, '"How was it I didn\'t\nknow it': 7, 'I expect I look as if I came from a café chantant and have\nhad some adventure on the way': 20, 'It would be interesting to know who stayed\nhere': 9, '"\n\nHe lighted the candle and looked at the room more carefully': 12, 'It was a\nroom so low-pitched that Svidrigaïlov could only just stand up in it;\nit had one window; the bed, which was very dirty, and the plain-stained\nchair and table almost filled it up': 35, 'The walls looked as though they\nwere made of planks, covered with shabby paper, so torn and dusty\nthat the pattern was indistinguishable, though the general\ncolour--yellow--could still be made out': 31, 'One of the walls was cut short\nby the sloping ceiling, though the room was not an attic but just under\nthe stairs': 23, 'Svidrigaïlov set down the candle, sat down on the bed and sank into\nthought': 14, 'But a strange persistent murmur which sometimes rose to a shout\nin the next room attracted his attention': 18, 'The murmur had not ceased from\nthe moment he entered the room': 12, 'He listened: someone was upbraiding and\nalmost tearfully scolding, but he heard only one voice': 15, 'Svidrigaïlov got up, shaded the light with his hand and at once he saw\nlight through a crack in the wall; he went up and peeped through': 27, 'The\nroom, which was somewhat larger than his, had two occupants': 11, 'One of\nthem, a very curly-headed man with a red inflamed face, was standing\nin the pose of an orator, without his coat, with his legs wide apart to\npreserve his balance, and smiting himself on the breast': 38, 'He reproached\nthe other with being a beggar, with having no standing whatever': 13, 'He\ndeclared that he had taken the other out of the gutter and he could turn\nhim out when he liked, and that only the finger of Providence sees it\nall': 31, "The object of his reproaches was sitting in a chair, and had the\nair of a man who wants dreadfully to sneeze, but can't": 24, 'He sometimes\nturned sheepish and befogged eyes on the speaker, but obviously had not\nthe slightest idea what he was talking about and scarcely heard it': 26, 'A\ncandle was burning down on the table; there were wine-glasses, a nearly\nempty bottle of vodka, bread and cucumber, and glasses with the dregs\nof stale tea': 28, 'After gazing attentively at this, Svidrigaïlov turned away\nindifferently and sat down on the bed': 15, "The ragged attendant, returning with the tea, could not resist asking\nhim again whether he didn't want anything more, and again receiving a\nnegative reply, finally withdrew": 27, 'Svidrigaïlov made haste to drink a\nglass of tea to warm himself, but could not eat anything': 17, 'He began\nto feel feverish': 5, 'He took off his coat and, wrapping himself in the\nblanket, lay down on the bed': 16, 'He was annoyed': 3, '"It would have been better\nto be well for the occasion," he thought with a smile': 16, 'The room was\nclose, the candle burnt dimly, the wind was roaring outside, he heard\na mouse scratching in the corner and the room smelt of mice and of\nleather': 30, 'He lay in a sort of reverie: one thought followed another': 11, 'He\nfelt a longing to fix his imagination on something': 10, '"It must be a garden\nunder the window," he thought': 10, '"There\'s a sound of trees': 5, 'How I dislike\nthe sound of trees on a stormy night, in the dark': 14, 'They give one a\nhorrid feeling': 6, '" He remembered how he had disliked it when he passed\nPetrovsky Park just now': 15, 'This reminded him of the bridge over the Little\nNeva and he felt cold again as he had when standing there': 21, '"I never have\nliked water," he thought, "even in a landscape," and he suddenly smiled\nagain at a strange idea: "Surely now all these questions of taste and\ncomfort ought not to matter, but I\'ve become more particular, like an\nanimal that picks out a special place': 47, 'for such an occasion': 4, 'I ought\nto have gone into the Petrovsky Park': 9, 'I suppose it seemed dark, cold,\nha-ha': 7, 'As though I were seeking pleasant sensations': 7, "By the way, why\nhaven't I put out the candle": 10, '" very\ntime and place for you': 23, "But now you won't come": 5, '"\n\nHe suddenly recalled how, an hour before carrying out his design on\nDounia, he had recommended Raskolnikov to trust her to successful rogue in time when he's got over\nhis nonsense": 14, "But now he's _too_ eager for life": 7, 'These young men\nare contemptible on that point': 8, 'But, hang the fellow': 4, "Let him please\nhimself, it's nothing to do with me": 10, '"\n\nHe could not get to sleep': 7, "By degrees Dounia's image rose before him,\nand a shudder ran over him": 13, '"No, I must give up all that now," he\nthought, rousing himself': 12, '"I must think of something else': 6, "It's queer\nand funny": 4, "I never had a great hatred for anyone, I never particularly\ndesired to avenge myself even, and unpleasant ran over\nhis leg again': 25, 'He pulled off the blanket and lighted the candle': 9, 'Shaking\nwith feverish chill he bent down to examine the bed: there was nothing': 14, 'He shook the and\nsuddenly darted under the pillow': 32, 'He threw down the pillow, but in one\ninstant felt something leap on his chest and dart over his body and down\nhis back under his shirt': 27, 'He trembled window, however; without getting up he drew the\nblanket over him and wrapped himself in it': 24, 'He was not thinking of\nanything and did not want to think': 12, 'But one image rose after another,\nincoherent scraps of thought without beginning or end passed through his\nmind': 18, 'He sank into drowsiness': 4, 'Perhaps the cold, or the dampness, or\nthe dark, or the wind that howled under the window and tossed the trees\nroused a sort of persistent craving for the fantastic': 30, 'He kept dwelling\non images of flowers, he fancied a charming flower garden, a bright,\nwarm, almost hot day, a holiday--Trinity day': 22, 'A fine, sumptuous country\ncottage in the English taste overgrown with fragrant flowers, with\nflower beds going round the house; the porch, wreathed in large, high drawing-room and again everywhere--at the windows,\nthe doors on to the balcony, and on the balcony itself--were flowers': 38, 'The floors were strewn with freshly-cut fragrant hay, the windows\nwere open, a fresh, cool, light air came into the room': 21, 'The birds were\nchirruping under the window, and in the middle of the room, on a table\ncovered with a white satin shroud, stood a coffin': 26, 'The coffin was\ncovered with white silk and edged with a thick white frill; wreaths of\nflowers surrounded it on all sides': 22, 'Among the flowers lay a girl in a\nwhite muslin dress, with her arms crossed and pressed on her bosom, as\nthough carved out of marble': 26, 'But her loose fair hair was wet; there was\na wreath of roses on her head': 16, 'The stern and already rigid was no holy image, no burning candle\nbeside the coffin; no sound of prayers: the girl had drowned herself': 24, 'She was only fourteen, but her heart was broken': 9, 'And she had destroyed\nherself, crushed by an insult that had appalled and amazed that childish\nsoul, had smirched that angel purity with unmerited disgrace and torn\nfrom her a last scream of despair, unheeded and brutally '"\n\nHe moved away from the window, shut it, lighted the candle, put on his\nwaistcoat, his overcoat and his hat and went out, carrying the candle,\ninto the passage to look for the ragged attendant who would be asleep\nsomewhere in the midst of candle-ends and all sorts of rubbish, to pay\nhim for the room and leave the hotel': 61, '"It\'s the best minute; I couldn\'t\nchoose a better': 9, '"\n\nHe walked for some time through a long narrow corridor without finding\nanyone and was just going to call out, when suddenly in a dark corner\nbetween an old cupboard and the door he caught sight of a strange object\nwhich seemed to be alive': 46, 'He bent down with the candle and saw a little\ngirl, not more than five years old, shivering and crying, with her\nclothes as wet as a been\ncrying a long time, but are beginning to be comforted': 22, "The child's face\nwas pale and tired, she was numb with cold": 12, '"How can she have come here': 6, 'She must have hidden here and not slept all night': 10, '" He began questioning\nher': 5, 'The child suddenly becoming animated, chattered away in her baby\nlanguage, something about "mammy" and that "mammy would beat her," and\nabout some cup that she had "bwoken': 28, '" The child chattered on without\nstopping': 7, "He could only guess from what she said that she was a\nneglected child, whose mother, probably a drunken cook, in the service\nof the hotel, whipped and frightened her; that the child had broken\na cup of her mother's and was so frightened that she had run away the\nevening before, had hidden for a long while somewhere outside in the\nrain, at last had made her way in here, hidden behind the cupboard and\nspent the night there, crying and trembling from the damp, the darkness\nand the fear that she would be badly beaten for it": 99, 'He took her in his\narms, went back to his room, sat her on the bed, and began undressing\nher': 20, 'The torn shoes which she had on her stockingless feet were as\nwet as if they had been standing in a puddle all night': 24, 'When he had\nundressed her, he put her on the bed, covered her up and wrapped her in\nthe blanket from her head downwards': 24, ('DOS CHAPTER VII PART VI', {"The same day, about seven o'clock in the evening, Raskolnikov was on\nhis way to his mother's and sister's lodging--the lodging in Bakaleyev's\nhouse which Razumihin had found for them": 30, 'The stairs went up from\nthe street': 7, 'Raskolnikov walked with lagging steps, as though still\nhesitating whether to go or not': 14, 'But nothing would have turned him back:\nhis decision was taken': 11, '"Besides, it doesn\'t matter, they still know nothing," he thought, "and\nthey are used to thinking of me as eccentric': 20, '"\n\nHe was appallingly dressed: his clothes torn and dirty, soaked with a\nnight\'s rain': 15, 'His face was almost distorted from fatigue, exposure, the\ninward conflict that had lasted for twenty-four hours': 17, 'He had spent all\nthe previous night alone, God knows where': 11, 'But anyway he had reached a\ndecision': 7, 'He knocked at the door which was opened by his mother': 11, 'Dounia was not\nat home': 5, 'Even the servant happened to be out': 7, 'At first Pulcheria\nAlexandrovna was speechless with joy and surprise; then she took him by\nthe hand and drew him into the room': 23, '"Here you are': 3, '" she began, faltering with joy': 6, '"Don\'t be angry with\nme, Rodya, for welcoming you so foolishly with tears: I am laughing not\ncrying': 18, 'Did you think I was crying': 6, "No, I am delighted, but I've got\ninto such a stupid habit of shedding tears": 15, "I've been like that ever\nsince your father's death": 9, 'I cry for anything': 4, 'Sit down, dear boy, you\nmust be tired; I see you are': 12, 'Ah, how muddy you are': 5, '"\n\n"I was in the rain yesterday, mother': 8, '" Raskolnikov began': 3, '"No, no," Pulcheria Alexandrovna hurriedly interrupted, "you thought I\nwas going to cross-question you in the womanish way I used to; don\'t be\nanxious, I understand, I understand it all: now I\'ve learned the ways\nhere and truly I see for myself that they are better': 46, "I've made up my\nmind once for all: how could I understand your plans and expect you to\ngive an account of them": 23, "God knows what concerns and plans you may have,\nor what ideas you are hatching; so it's not for me to keep nudging your\nelbow, asking you what you are thinking about": 32, 'But, my goodness': 3, 'why\nam I running to and fro as though I were crazy': 12, 'I am reading your\narticle in the magazine for the third time, Rodya': 13, 'Dmitri Prokofitch\nbrought it to me': 6, "Directly I saw it I cried out to myself: ‘There,\nfoolish one,' I thought, ‘that's what he is busy about; that's the\nsolution of the mystery": 26, 'Learned people are always like that': 6, 'He may\nhave some new ideas in his head just now; he is thinking them over and I\nworry him and upset him': 23, "' I read it, my dear, and of course there was a\ngreat deal I did not understand; but that's only natural--how should I": 24, '"\n\n"Show me, mother': 4, '"\n\nRaskolnikov took the magazine and glanced at his article': 10, 'Incongruous\nas it was with his mood and his circumstances, he felt that strange and\nbitter sweet sensation that every author experiences the first time he\nsees himself in print; besides, he was only twenty-three': 35, 'It lasted only\na moment': 5, 'After reading a few lines he frowned and his heart throbbed\nwith anguish': 13, 'He recalled all the inward conflict of the preceding\nmonths': 10, 'He flung the article on the table with disgust and anger': 11, '"But, however foolish I may be, Rodya, I can see for myself that you\nwill very soon be one of the leading--if not the leading man--in the\nworld of Russian thought': 31, 'And they dared to think you were mad': 8, "You\ndon't know, but they really thought that": 8, 'Ah, the despicable creatures,\nhow could they understand genius': 9, 'And Dounia, Dounia was all but\nbelieving it--what do you say to that': 13, "Your father sent twice to\nmagazines--the first time poems (I've got the manuscript and will show\nyou) and the second time a whole novel (I begged him to let me copy it\nout) and how we prayed that they should be taken--they weren't": 43, 'I was\nbreaking my heart, Rodya, six or seven days ago over your food and your\nclothes and the way you are living': 23, 'But now I see again how foolish\nI was, for you can attain any position you like by your intellect and\ntalent': 22, "No doubt you don't care about that for the present and you are\noccupied with much more important matters": 19, '"\n\n"Dounia\'s not at home, mother': 6, '"\n\n"No, Rodya': 3, "I often don't see her; she leaves me alone": 9, "Dmitri\nProkofitch comes to see me, it's so good of him, and he always talks\nabout you": 17, 'He loves you and respects you, my dear': 8, "I don't say that\nDounia is very wanting in consideration": 10, 'I am not complaining': 4, 'She has\nher ways and I have mine; she seems to have got some secrets of late and\nI never have any secrets from you two': 26, 'Of course, I am sure that Dounia\nhas far too much sense, and besides she loves you and me': 19, "but I don't\nknow what it will all lead to": 10, "You've made me so happy by coming now,\nRodya, but she has missed you by going out; when she comes in I'll tell\nher: ‘Your brother came in while you were out": 32, 'Where have you been all\nthis time': 7, "' You mustn't spoil me, Rodya, you know; come when you can,\nbut if you can't, it doesn't matter, I can wait": 22, 'I shall know, anyway,\nthat you are fond of me, that will be enough for me': 16, "I shall read what\nyou write, I shall hear about you from everyone, and sometimes you'll\ncome yourself to see me": 21, 'What could be better': 4, "Here you've come now to\ncomfort your mother, I see that": 11, '"\n\nHere Pulcheria Alexandrovna began to cry': 7, '"Here I am again': 4, "Don't mind my foolishness": 4, 'My goodness, why am I\nsitting here': 7, '" she cried, jumping up': 5, '"There is coffee and I don\'t
