('DOS EPILOGUE', {'I\n\nSiberia': 2, 'On the banks of a broad solitary river stands a town, one of\nthe administrative centres of Russia; in the town there is a fortress,\nin the fortress there is a prison': 32, 'In the prison the second-class\nconvict Rodion Raskolnikov has been confined for nine months': 14, 'Almost a\nyear and a half has passed since his crime': 11, 'There had been little difficulty about his trial': 8, 'The criminal adhered\nexactly, firmly, and clearly to his statement': 10, 'He did not confuse nor\nmisrepresent the facts, nor soften them in his own interest, nor omit\nthe smallest detail': 20, "He explained every incident of the murder, the\nsecret of _the pledge_ (the piece of wood with a strip of metal) which\nwas found in the murdered woman's hand": 29, "He described minutely how he\nhad taken her keys, what they were like, as well as the chest and its\ncontents; he explained the mystery of Lizaveta's murder; described how\nKoch and, after him, the student knocked, and repeated all they had said\nto one another; how he afterwards had run downstairs and heard Nikolay\nand Dmitri shouting; how he had hidden in the empty flat and afterwards\ngone home": 70, 'He ended by indicating the stone in the yard off the\nVoznesensky Prospect under which the purse and the trinkets were found': 22, 'The whole thing, in fact, was perfectly clear': 8, 'The lawyers and the\njudges were very much struck, among other things, by the fact that he\nhad hidden the trinkets and the purse under a stone, without making\nuse of them, and that, what was more, he did not now remember what the\ntrinkets were like, or even how many there were': 53, 'The fact that he had\nnever opened the purse and did not even know how much was in it seemed\nincredible': 21, 'There turned out to be in the purse three hundred and\nseventeen roubles and sixty copecks': 16, 'From being so long under the stone,\nsome of the most valuable notes lying uppermost had suffered from the\ndamp': 20, 'They were a long while trying to discover why the accused man\nshould tell a lie about this, when about everything else he had made\na truthful and straightforward confession': 30, "Finally some of the lawyers\nmore versed in psychology admitted that it was possible he had really\nnot looked into the purse, and so didn't know what was in it when he\nhid it under the stone": 37, 'But they immediately drew the deduction that\nthe crime could only have been committed through temporary mental\nderangement, through homicidal mania, without object or the pursuit of\ngain': 28, 'This fell in with the most recent fashionable theory of temporary\ninsanity, so often applied in our days in criminal cases': 21, "Moreover\nRaskolnikov's hypochondriacal condition was proved by many witnesses, by\nDr": 11, 'Zossimov, his former fellow students, his landlady and her servant': 10, 'All this pointed strongly to the conclusion that Raskolnikov was not\nquite like an ordinary murderer and robber, but that there was another\nelement in the case': 27, 'To the intense annoyance of those who maintained this opinion, the\ncriminal scarcely attempted to defend himself': 17, 'To the decisive question\nas to what motive impelled him to the murder and the robbery, he\nanswered very clearly with the coarsest frankness that the cause was\nhis miserable position, his poverty and helplessness, and his desire to\nprovide for his first steps in life by the help of the three thousand\nroubles he had reckoned on finding': 59, 'He had been led to the murder\nthrough his shallow and cowardly nature, exasperated moreover by\nprivation and failure': 19, 'To the question what led him to confess, he\nanswered that it was his heartfelt repentance': 16, 'All this was almost\ncoarse': 5, 'The sentence however was more merciful than could have been expected,\nperhaps partly because the criminal had not tried to justify himself,\nbut had rather shown a desire to exaggerate his guilt': 32, 'All the strange\nand peculiar circumstances of the crime were taken into consideration': 13, 'There could be no doubt of the abnormal and poverty-stricken condition\nof the criminal at the time': 17, 'The fact that he had made no use of what he\nhad stolen was put down partly to the effect of remorse, partly to his\nabnormal mental condition at the time of the crime': 34, 'Incidentally the\nmurder of Lizaveta served indeed to confirm the last hypothesis: a man\ncommits two murders and forgets that the door is open': 24, 'Finally, the\nconfession, at the very moment when the case was hopelessly muddled by\nthe false evidence given by Nikolay through melancholy and fanaticism,\nand when, moreover, there were no proofs against the real criminal, no\nsuspicions even (Porfiry Petrovitch fully kept his word)--all this did\nmuch to soften the sentence': 51, "Other circumstances, too, in the prisoner's\nfavour came out quite unexpectedly": 11, 'Razumihin somehow discovered and\nproved that while Raskolnikov was at the university he had helped a poor\nconsumptive fellow student and had spent his last penny on supporting\nhim for six months, and when this student died, leaving a decrepit\nold father whom he had maintained almost from his thirteenth year,\nRaskolnikov had got the old man into a hospital and paid for his funeral\nwhen he died': 68, "Raskolnikov's landlady bore witness, too, that when they\nhad lived in another house at Five Corners, Raskolnikov had rescued two\nlittle children from a house on fire and was burnt in doing so": 33, 'This was\ninvestigated and fairly well confirmed by many witnesses': 10, 'These facts\nmade an impression in his favour': 8, 'And in the end the criminal was, in consideration of extenuating\ncircumstances, condemned to penal servitude in the second class for a\nterm of eight years only': 27, "At the very beginning of the trial Raskolnikov's mother fell ill": 11, 'Dounia\nand Razumihin found it possible to get her out of Petersburg during the\ntrial': 15, 'Razumihin chose a town on the railway not far from Petersburg, so\nas to be able to follow every step of the trial and at the same time\nto see Avdotya Romanovna as often as possible': 36, "Pulcheria Alexandrovna's\nillness was a strange nervous one and was accompanied by a partial\nderangement of her intellect": 18, 'When Dounia returned from her last interview with her brother, she\nhad found her mother already ill, in feverish delirium': 20, "That evening\nRazumihin and she agreed what answers they must make to her mother's\nquestions about Raskolnikov and made up a complete story for her\nmother's benefit of his having to go away to a distant part of Russia\non a business commission, which would bring him in the end money and\nreputation": 53, 'But they were struck by the fact that Pulcheria Alexandrovna never\nasked them anything on the subject, neither then nor thereafter': 21, "On the\ncontrary, she had her own version of her son's sudden departure; she\ntold them with tears how he had come to say good-bye to her, hinting\nthat she alone knew many mysterious and important facts, and that Rodya\nhad many very powerful enemies, so that it was necessary for him to be\nin hiding": 56, 'As for his future career, she had no doubt that it would be\nbrilliant when certain sinister influences could be removed': 21, 'She assured\nRazumihin that her son would be one day a great statesman, that his\narticle and brilliant literary talent proved it': 22, 'This article she was\ncontinually reading, she even read it aloud, almost took it to bed\nwith her, but scarcely asked where Rodya was, though the subject was\nobviously avoided by the others, which might have been enough to awaken\nher suspicions': 42, "They began to be frightened at last at Pulcheria Alexandrovna's strange\nsilence on certain subjects": 15, 'She did not, for instance, complain of\ngetting no letters from him, though in previous years she had only lived\non the hope of letters from her beloved Rodya': 29, "This was the cause of\ngreat uneasiness to Dounia; the idea occurred to her that her mother\nsuspected that there was something terrible in her son's fate and was\nafraid to ask, for fear of hearing something still more awful": 40, 'In any\ncase, Dounia saw clearly that her mother was not in full possession of\nher faculties': 17, 'It happened once or twice, however, that Pulcheria Alexandrovna gave\nsuch a turn to the conversation that it was impossible to answer her\nwithout mentioning where Rodya was, and on receiving unsatisfactory and\nsuspicious answers she became at once gloomy and silent, and this mood\nlasted for a long time': 50, 'Dounia saw at last that it was hard to deceive\nher and came to the conclusion that it was better to be absolutely\nsilent on certain points; but it became more and more evident that\nthe poor mother suspected something terrible': 41, "Dounia remembered her\nbrother's telling her that her mother had overheard her talking in her\nsleep on the night after her interview with Svidrigaïlov and before the\nfatal day of the confession: had not she made out something from that": 40, 'Sometimes days and even weeks of gloomy silence and tears would be\nsucceeded by a period of hysterical animation, and the invalid would\nbegin to talk almost incessantly of her son, of her hopes of his\nfuture': 37, 'Her fancies were sometimes very strange': 6, 'They humoured her,\npretended to agree with her (she saw perhaps that they were pretending),\nbut she still went on talking': 21, "Five months after Raskolnikov's confession, he was sentenced": 8, 'Razumihin\nand Sonia saw him in prison as often as it was possible': 13, 'At last\nthe moment of separation came': 7, 'Dounia swore to her brother that the\nseparation should not be for ever, Razumihin did the same': 17, 'Razumihin, in\nhis youthful ardour, had firmly resolved to lay the foundations at least\nof a secure livelihood during the next three or four years, and saving\nup a certain sum, to emigrate to Siberia, a country rich in every\nnatural resource and in need of workers, active men and capital': 51, 'There\nthey would settle in the town where Rodya was and all together would\nbegin a new life': 18, 'They all wept at parting': 5, 'Raskolnikov had been very dreamy for a few days before': 10, 'He asked a great\ndeal about his mother and was constantly anxious about her': 14, 'He worried\nso much about her that it alarmed Dounia': 10, "When he heard about his\nmother's illness he became very gloomy": 11, 'With Sonia he was particularly\nreserved all the time': 9, 'With the help of the money left to her by\nSvidrigaïlov, Sonia had long ago made her preparations to follow the\nparty of convicts in which he was despatched to Siberia': 31, 'Not a word\npassed between Raskolnikov and her on the subject, but both knew it\nwould be so': 18, "At the final leave-taking he smiled strangely at his\nsister's and Razumihin's fervent anticipations of their happy future\ntogether when he should come out of prison": 26, "He predicted that their\nmother's illness would soon have a fatal ending": 12, 'Sonia and he at last\nset off': 7, 'Two months later Dounia was married to Razumihin': 8, 'It was a quiet and\nsorrowful wedding; Porfiry Petrovitch and Zossimov were invited however': 14, 'During all this period Razumihin wore an air of resolute determination': 11, 'Dounia put implicit faith in his carrying out his plans and indeed she\ncould not but believe in him': 19, 'He displayed a rare strength of will': 7, 'Among other things he began attending university lectures again in order\nto take his degree': 15, 'They were continually making plans for the future;\nboth counted on settling in Siberia within five years at least': 19, 'Till\nthen they rested their hopes on Sonia': 8, "Pulcheria Alexandrovna was delighted to give her blessing to Dounia's\nmarriage with Razumihin; but after the marriage she became even more\nmelancholy and anxious": 24, 'To give her pleasure Razumihin told her how\nRaskolnikov had looked after the poor student and his decrepit father\nand how a year ago he had been burnt and injured in rescuing two\nlittle children from a fire': 38, "These two pieces of news excited Pulcheria\nAlexandrovna's disordered imagination almost to ecstasy": 13, 'She was\ncontinually talking about them, even entering into conversation with\nstrangers in the street, though Dounia always accompanied her': 20, 'In public\nconveyances and shops, wherever she could capture a listener, she would\nbegin the discourse about her son, his article, how he had helped the\nstudent, how he had been burnt at the fire, and so on': 38, 'Dounia did\nnot know how to restrain her': 8, "Apart from the danger of her morbid\nexcitement, there was the risk of someone's recalling Raskolnikov's name\nand speaking of the recent trial": 23, 'Pulcheria Alexandrovna found out the\naddress of the mother of the two children her son had saved and insisted\non going to see her': 24, 'At last her restlessness reached an extreme point': 8, 'She would sometimes\nbegin to cry suddenly and was often ill and feverishly delirious': 14, 'One\nmorning she declared that by her reckoning Rodya ought soon to be home,\nthat she remembered when he said good-bye to her he said that they must\nexpect him back in nine months': 34, 'She began to prepare for his coming,\nbegan to do up her room for him, to clean the furniture, to wash and\nput up new hangings and so on': 29, 'Dounia was anxious, but said nothing and\nhelped her to arrange the room': 13, 'After a fatiguing day spent in continual\nfancies, in joyful day-dreams and tears, Pulcheria Alexandrovna was\ntaken ill in the night and by morning she was feverish and delirious': 29, 'It was brain fever': 4, 'She died within a fortnight': 5, "In her delirium she\ndropped words which showed that she knew a great deal more about her\nson's terrible fate than they had supposed": 24, "For a long time Raskolnikov did not know of his mother's death, though\na regular correspondence had been maintained from the time he reached\nSiberia": 25, 'It was carried on by means of Sonia, who wrote every month\nto the Razumihins and received an answer with unfailing regularity': 22, "At\nfirst they found Sonia's letters dry and unsatisfactory, but later on\nthey came to the conclusion that the letters could not be better, for\nfrom these letters they received a complete picture of their unfortunate\nbrother's life": 38, "Sonia's letters were full of the most matter-of-fact\ndetail, the simplest and clearest description of all Raskolnikov's\nsurroundings as a convict": 21, 'There was no word of her own hopes, no\nconjecture as to the future, no description of her feelings': 19, 'Instead of\nany attempt to interpret his state of mind and inner life, she gave the\nsimple facts--that is, his own words, an exact account of his health,\nwhat he asked for at their interviews, what commission he gave her\nand so on': 43, 'All these facts she gave with extraordinary minuteness': 8, 'The\npicture of their unhappy brother stood out at last with great clearness\nand precision': 15, 'There could be no mistake, because nothing was given but\nfacts': 11, 'But Dounia and her husband could get little comfort out of the news,\nespecially at first': 16, 'Sonia wrote that he was constantly sullen and not\nready to talk, that he scarcely seemed interested in the news she gave\nhim from their letters, that he sometimes asked after his mother and\nthat when, seeing that he had guessed the truth, she told him at last\nof her death, she was surprised to find that he did not seem greatly\naffected by it, not externally at any rate': 70, 'She told them that, although\nhe seemed so wrapped up in himself and, as it were, shut himself off\nfrom everyone--he took a very direct and simple view of his new life;\nthat he understood his position, expected nothing better for the time,\nhad no ill-founded hopes (as is so common in his position) and scarcely\nseemed surprised at anything in his surroundings, so unlike anything he\nhad known before': 70, 'She wrote that his health was satisfactory; he did his\nwork without shirking or seeking to do more; he was almost indifferent\nabout food, but except on Sundays and holidays the food was so bad that\nat last he had been glad to accept some money from her, Sonia, to have\nhis own tea every day': 56, 'He begged her not to trouble about anything else,\ndeclaring that all this fuss about him only annoyed him': 19, 'Sonia wrote\nfurther that in prison he shared the same room with the rest, that she\nhad not seen the inside of their barracks, but concluded that they were\ncrowded, miserable and unhealthy; that he slept on a plank bed with a\nrug under him and was unwilling to make any other arrangement': 53, 'But that\nhe lived so poorly and roughly, not from any plan or design, but simply\nfrom inattention and indifference': 20, 'Sonia wrote simply that he had at first shown no interest in her visits,\nhad almost been vexed with her indeed for coming, unwilling to talk and\nrude to her': 30, 'But that in the end these visits had become a habit and\nalmost a necessity for him, so that he was positively distressed when\nshe was ill for some days and could not visit him': 35, 'She used to see him\non holidays at the prison gates or in the guard-room, to which he was\nbrought for a few minutes to see her': 27, 'On working days she would go to\nsee him at work either at the workshops or at the brick kilns, or at the\nsheds on the banks of the Irtish': 30, 'About herself, Sonia wrote that she had succeeded in making some\nacquaintances in the town, that she did sewing, and, as there\nwas scarcely a dressmaker in the town, she was looked upon as an\nindispensable person in many houses': 40, 'But she did not mention that the\nauthorities were, through her, interested in Raskolnikov; that his task\nwas lightened and so on': 22, 'At last the news came (Dounia had indeed noticed signs of alarm and\nuneasiness in the preceding letters) that he held aloof from everyone,\nthat his fellow prisoners did not like him, that he kept silent for days\nat a time and was becoming very pale': 46, 'In the last letter Sonia wrote\nthat he had been taken very seriously ill and was in the convict ward of\nthe hospital': 23, 'II\n\nHe was ill a long time': 7, 'But it was not the horrors of prison life, not\nthe hard labour, the bad food, the shaven head, or the patched clothes\nthat crushed him': 26, 'What did he care for all those trials and hardships': 10, 'he was even glad of the hard work': 8, 'Physically exhausted, he could at\nleast reckon on a few hours of quiet sleep': 14, 'And what was the food to\nhim--the thin cabbage soup with beetles floating in it': 15, 'In the past as a\nstudent he had often not had even that': 13, 'His clothes were warm and suited\nto his manner of life': 11, 'He did not even feel the fetters': 7, 'Was he ashamed\nof his shaven head and parti-coloured coat': 10, 'Before whom': 2, 'Before Sonia': 2, 'Sonia was afraid of him, how could he be ashamed before her': 12, 'And yet he\nwas ashamed even before Sonia, whom he tortured because of it with\nhis contemptuous rough manner': 19, 'But it was not his shaven head and his\nfetters he was ashamed of: his pride had been stung to the quick': 22, 'It was\nwounded pride that made him ill': 8, 'Oh, how happy he would have been if he\ncould have blamed himself': 13, 'He could have borne anything then, even\nshame and disgrace': 10, 'But he judged himself severely, and his exasperated\nconscience found no particularly terrible fault in his past, except\na simple _blunder_ which might happen to anyone': 26, 'He was ashamed just\nbecause he, Raskolnikov, had so hopelessly, stupidly come to grief\nthrough some decree of blind fate, and must humble himself and submit to\n"the idiocy" of a sentence, if he were anyhow to be at peace': 40, 'Vague and objectless anxiety in the present, and in the future a\ncontinual sacrifice leading to nothing--that was all that lay before\nhim': 23, 'And what comfort was it to him that at the end of eight years he\nwould only be thirty-two and able to begin a new life': 26, 'What had he to\nlive for': 6, 'What had he to look forward to': 7, 'Why should he strive': 4, 'To live\nin order to exist': 6, 'Why, he had been ready a thousand times before to\ngive up existence for the sake of an idea, for a hope, even for a fancy': 26, 'Mere existence had always been too little for him; he had always wanted\nmore': 14, 'Perhaps it was just because of the strength of his desires that he\nhad thought himself a man to whom more was permissible than to others': 26, 'And if only fate would have sent him repentance--burning repentance that\nwould have torn his heart and robbed him of sleep, that repentance, the\nawful agony of which brings visions of hanging or drowning': 34, 'Oh, he would\nhave been glad of it': 8, 'Tears and agonies would at least have been life': 9, 'But he did not repent of his crime': 8, 'At least he might have found relief in raging at his stupidity, as he\nhad raged at the grotesque blunders that had brought him to prison': 26, 'But now in prison, _in freedom_, he thought over and criticised all his\nactions again and by no means found them so blundering and so grotesque\nas they had seemed at the fatal time': 34, '"In what way," he asked himself, "was my theory stupider than others\nthat have swarmed and clashed from the beginning of the enough": 3, 'Of course, in that case many of the\nbenefactors of mankind who snatched power for themselves instead of\ninheriting it ought to have been punished at their first steps': 29, "But\nthose which he\ncould not step over, again through weakness and meanness': 22, 'He looked at\nhis fellow prisoners and was amazed to see how they all loved life and\nprized it': 19, 'It seemed to him that ('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART ONE', {'Stepan Arkadyevitch was a truthful man in his relations with himself': 11, 'He was incapable of deceiving himself and persuading himself that he\nrepented of his conduct': 15, 'He could not at this date repent of the fact\nthat he, a handsome, susceptible man of thirty-four, was not in love\nwith his wife, the mother of five living and two dead children, and\nonly a year younger than himself': 41, 'All he repented of was that he had\nnot succeeded better in hiding it from his wife': 17, 'But he felt all the\ndifficulty of his position and was sorry for his wife, his children,\nand himself': 19, 'Possibly he might have managed to conceal his sins better\nfrom his wife if he had anticipated that the knowledge of them would\nhave had such an effect on her': 30, 'He had never clearly thought out the\nsubject, but he had vaguely conceived that his wife must long ago have\nsuspected him of being unfaithful to her, and shut her eyes to the\nfact': 34, 'He had even supposed that she, a worn-out woman no longer young\nor good-looking, and in no way remarkable or interesting, merely a good\nmother, ought from a sense of fairness to take an indulgent view': 36, 'It\nhad turned out quite the other way': 8, '"Oh, it\'s awful': 3, 'oh dear, oh dear': 4, 'awful': 1, '" Stepan Arkadyevitch kept\nrepeating to himself, and he could think of nothing to be done': 16, '"And\nhow well things were going up till now': 9, 'how well we got on': 5, 'She was\ncontented and happy in her children; I never interfered with her in\nanything; I let her manage the children and the house just as she\nliked': 28, "It's true it's bad _her_ having been a governess in our house": 12, "That's bad": 2, "There's something common, vulgar, in flirting with one's\ngoverness": 9, 'But what a governess': 4, '" (He vividly recalled the roguish\nblack eyes of Mlle': 10, 'Roland and her smile': 4, ') "But after all, while she\nwas in the house, I kept myself in hand': 15, "And the worst of it all is\nthat she's already": 10, 'it seems as if ill-luck would have it so': 9, 'Oh,\noh': 2, 'But what, what is to be done': 7, '"\n\nThere was no solution, but that universal solution which life gives to\nall questions, even the most complex and insoluble': 21, 'That answer is: one\nmust live in the needs of the day—that is, forget oneself': 15, 'To forget\nhimself in sleep was impossible now, at least till nighttime; he could\nnot go back now to the music sung by the decanter-women; so he must\nforget himself in the dream of daily life': 36, '"Then we shall see," Stepan Arkadyevitch said to himself, and getting\nup he put on a gray dressing-gown lined with blue silk, tied the\ntassels in a knot, and, drawing a deep breath of air into his broad,\nbare chest, he walked to the window with his usual confident step,\nturning out his feet that carried his full frame so easily': 61, 'He pulled\nup the blind and rang the bell loudly': 10, 'It was at once answered by the\nappearance of an old friend, his valet, Matvey, carrying his clothes,\nhis boots, and a telegram': 23, 'Matvey was followed by the barber with all\nthe necessaries for shaving': 12, '"Are there any papers from the office': 7, '" asked Stepan Arkadyevitch,\ntaking the telegram and seating himself at the looking-glass': 13, '"On the table," replied Matvey, glancing with inquiring sympathy at his\nmaster; give it to her, and then do\nwhat she tells you': 15, '"\n\n"You want to try it on," Matvey understood, but he only said, "Yes,\nsir': 15, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch was already washed and combed and ready to be\ndressed, when Matvey, stepping deliberately in his creaky boots, came\nback into the room with the telegram in his hand': 32, 'The barber had gone': 4, '"Darya Alexandrovna told me to inform you that she is going away': 12, 'Let\nhim do—that is you—as he likes," he said, laughing only with his eyes,\nand putting his hands in his pockets, he watched his master with his\nhead on one side': 31, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch was silent a minute': 6, 'Then a\ngood-humored and rather pitiful smile showed itself on his handsome\nface': 13, '"Eh, Matvey': 2, '" he said, shaking his head': 6, '"It\'s all right, sir; ('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART ONE', {'When he was dressed, Stepan Arkadyevitch sprinkled some scent on\nhimself, pulled down his shirt-cuffs, distributed into his pockets his\ncigarettes, pocketbook, matches, and watch with its double chain and\nseals, and shaking out his handkerchief, feeling himself clean,\nfragrant, healthy, and physically at ease, in spite of his unhappiness,\nhe walked with a slight swing on each leg into the dining-room, where\ncoffee was already waiting for him, and beside the coffee, letters and\npapers from the office': 79, 'He read the letters': 4, "One was very unpleasant, from a merchant who was\nbuying a forest on his wife's property": 16, 'To sell this forest was\nabsolutely essential; but at present, until he was reconciled with his\nwife, the subject could not be discussed': 23, 'The most unpleasant thing of\nall was that his pecuniary interests should in this way enter into the\nquestion of his reconciliation with his wife': 25, 'And the idea that he\nmight be led on by his interests, that he might seek a reconciliation\nwith his wife on account of the sale of the forest—that idea hurt him': 32, 'When he had finished his letters, Stepan Arkadyevitch moved the\noffice-papers close to him, rapidly looked through two pieces of\nbusiness, made a few notes with a big pencil, and pushing away the\npapers, turned to his coffee': 38, 'As he sipped his coffee, he opened a\nstill damp morning paper, and began reading it': 16, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch took in and read a liberal paper, not an extreme\none, but one advocating the views held by the majority': 22, 'And in spite of\nthe fact that science, art, and politics had no special interest for\nhim, he firmly held those views on all these subjects which were held\nby the majority and by his paper, and he only changed them when the\nmajority changed them—or, more strictly speaking, he did not change\nthem, but they imperceptibly changed of themselves within him': 62, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch had not chosen his political opinions or his views;\nthese political opinions and views had come to him of themselves, just\nas he did not choose the shapes of his hat and coat, but simply took\nthose that were being worn': 43, 'And for him, living in a certain\nsociety—owing to the need, ordinarily developed at years of discretion,\nfor some degree of mental activity—to have views was just as\nindispensable as to have a hat': 34, 'If there was a reason for his\npreferring liberal to conservative views, which were held also by many\nof his circle, it arose not from his considering liberalism more\nrational, but from its being in closer accordance with his manner of\nlife': 42, 'The liberal party said that in Russia everything is wrong, and\ncertainly Stepan Arkadyevitch had many debts and was decidedly short of\nmoney': 23, 'The liberal party said that marriage is an institution quite out\nof date, and that it needs reconstruction; and family life certainly\nafforded Stepan Arkadyevitch little gratification, and forced him into\nlying and hypocrisy, which was so repulsive to his nature': 41, 'The liberal\nparty said, or rather allowed it to be understood, that religion is\nonly a curb to keep in check the barbarous classes of the people; and\nStepan Arkadyevitch could not get through even a short service without\nhis legs aching from standing up, and could never make out what was the\nobject of all the terrible and high-flown language about another world\nwhen life might be so very amusing in this world': 74, 'And with all this,\nStepan Arkadyevitch, who liked a joke, was fond of puzzling a plain man\nby saying that if he prided himself on his origin, he ought not to stop\nat Rurik and disown the first founder of his family—the monkey': 43, "And so\nLiberalism had become a habit of Stepan Arkadyevitch's, and he liked\nhis newspaper, as he did his cigar after dinner, for the slight fog it\ndiffused in his brain": 31, 'He read the leading article, in which it was\nmaintained that it was quite senseless in our day to raise an outcry\nthat radicalism was threatening to swallow up all conservative\nelements, and that the government ought to take measures to crush the\nrevolutionary hydra; that, on the contrary, "in our opinion the danger\nlies not in that fantastic revolutionary hydra, but in the obstinacy of\ntraditionalism clogging progress," etc': 70, ', etc': 2, 'He read another article,\ntoo, a financial one, which alluded to Bentham and Mill, and dropped\nsome innuendoes reflecting on the ministry': 22, 'With his characteristic\nquickwittedness he caught the drift of each innuendo, divined whence it\ncame, at whom and on what ground it was aimed, and that afforded him,\nas it always did, a certain satisfaction': 35, "But today that satisfaction\nwas embittered by Matrona Philimonovna's advice and the unsatisfactory\nstate of the household": 17, 'He read, too, that Count Beist was rumored to\nhave left for Wiesbaden, and that one need have no more gray hair, and\nof the sale of a light carriage, and of a young person seeking a\nsituation; but these items of information did not give him, as usual, a\nquiet, ironical gratification': 53, 'Having finished the paper, a second cup\nof coffee and a roll and butter, he got up, shaking the crumbs of the\nroll off his waistcoat; and, squaring his broad chest, he smiled\njoyously: not because there was anything particularly agreeable in his\nmind—the joyous smile was evoked by a good digestion': 52, 'But this joyous smile at once recalled everything to him, and he grew\nthoughtful': 14, 'Two childish voices (Stepan Arkadyevitch recognized the voices of\nGrisha, his youngest boy, and Tanya, his eldest girl) were heard\noutside the door': 23, 'They were carrying something, and dropped it': 7, '"I told you not to sit passengers on the roof," said the little girl in\nEnglish; "there, pick them up': 20, '"\n\n"Everything\'s in confusion," thought Stepan Arkadyevitch; "there are\nthe children running about by themselves': 15, '" And going to the door, he\ncalled them': 9, 'They threw down the box, that represented a train, and\ncame in to their father': 15, "The little girl, her father's favorite, ran up boldly, embraced him,\nand hung laughingly on his neck, enjoying as she always did the smell\nof scent that came from his whiskers": 31, 'At last the little girl kissed\nhis face, which was flushed from his stooping posture and beaming with\ntenderness, loosed her hands, and was about to run away again; but ('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART ONE', {'Darya Alexandrovna, in a dressing jacket, and with her now scanty, once\nluxuriant and beautiful hair fastened up with hairpins on the nape of\nher neck, with a sunken, thin face and large, startled eyes, which\nlooked prominent from the thinness of her face, was standing among a\nlitter of all sorts of things scattered all over the room, before an\nopen bureau, from which she was taking something': 69, "Hearing her husband's\nsteps, she stopped, looking towards the door, and trying assiduously to\ngive her features a severe and contemptuous expression": 22, 'She felt she\nwas afraid of him, and afraid of the coming interview': 13, 'She was just\nattempting to do what she had attempted to do ten times already in\nthese last three days—to sort out the children\'s things and her own, so\nas to take them to her mother\'s—and again she could not bring herself\nto do this; but now again, as each time before, she kept saying to\nherself, "that things cannot go on like this, that she must take some\nstep" to punish him, put him to shame, avenge on him some little part\nat least of the suffering he had caused her': 92, 'She still continued to\ntell herself that she should leave him, but she was conscious that this\nwas impossible; it was impossible because she could not get out of the\nhabit of regarding him as her husband and loving him': 40, 'Besides this, she\nrealized that if even here in her own house she could hardly manage to\nlook after her five children properly, they would be still worse off\nwhere she was going with them all': 36, 'As it was, even in the course of\nthese three days, the youngest was unwell from being given unwholesome\nsoup, and the others had almost gone without their dinner the day\nbefore': 32, 'She was conscious that it was impossible to go away; but,\ncheating herself, she went on all the same sorting out her things and\npretending she was going': 28, 'Seeing her husband, she dropped her hands into the drawer of the bureau\nas though looking for something, and only looked round at him when he\nhad come quite up to her': 32, 'But her face, to which she tried to give a\nsevere and resolute expression, betrayed bewilderment and suffering': 18, '"Dolly': 1, '" he said in a subdued and timid voice': 9, 'He bent his head towards\nhis shoulder and tried to look pitiful and humble, but for all that he\nwas radiant with freshness and health': 25, 'In a rapid glance she scanned\nhis figure that beamed with health and freshness': 14, '"Yes, he is happy and\ncontent': 6, '" she thought; "while I': 5, 'And that disgusting good nature,\nwhich everyone likes him for and praises—I hate that good nature of\nhis," she thought': 20, 'Her mouth stiffened, the muscles of the cheek\ncontracted on the right side of her pale, nervous face': 18, '"What do you want': 4, '" she said in a rapid, deep, unnatural voice': 9, '" he repeated, with a quiver in his voice': 9, '"Anna is coming\ntoday': 4, '"\n\n"Well, what is that to me': 7, "I can't see her": 4, '" she cried': 3, '"But you must, really, Dolly': 5, '"\n\n"Go away, go away, go away': 7, '" she shrieked, not looking at him, as\nthough this shriek were called up by physical pain': 17, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch could be calm when he thought of his wife, he could\nhope that she would _come round_, as Matvey expressed it, and could\nquietly go on reading his paper and drinking his coffee; but when he\nsaw her tortured, suffering face, heard the tone of her voice,\nsubmissive to fate and full of despair, there was a catch in his breath\nand a lump in his throat, and his eyes began to shine with tears': 77, '"My God': 2, 'what have I done': 4, 'Dolly': 1, "For God's sake": 3, 'You know': 2, '" He\ncould not go on; there was a sob in his throat': 13, 'She shut the bureau with a slam, and glanced at him': 11, '"Dolly, what can I say': 5, 'One thing: forgive': 3, 'Remember, cannot nine\nyears of my life atone for an instant': 11, '"\n\nShe dropped her eyes and listened, expecting what he would say, as it\nwere beseeching him in some way or other to make her believe\ndifferently': 27, '"—instant of passion': 3, '" he said, and would have gone on, but at that\nword, as at a pang of physical pain, her lips stiffened again, and\nagain the muscles of her right cheek worked': 32, '"Go away, go out of the room': 7, '" she shrieked still more shrilly, "and\ndon\'t talk to me of your passion and your loathsomeness': 17, '"\n\nShe tried to go out, but tottered, and clung to the back of a chair to\nsupport herself': 19, 'His face relaxed, his lips swelled, his eyes were\nswimming with tears': 12, '" he said, sobbing now; "for mercy\'s sake, think of the\nchildren; they are not to blame': 17, 'I am to blame, and punish me, make me\nexpiate my fault': 12, 'Anything I can do, I am ready to do anything': 10, 'I am to\nblame, no words can express how much I am to blame': 14, 'But, Dolly, forgive\nme': 4, '"\n\nShe sat down': 4, 'He listened to her hard, heavy breathing, and he was\nunutterably sorry for her': 14, 'She tried several times to begin to speak,\nbut could not': 11, 'He waited': 2, '"You remember the children, Stiva, to play with them; but I remember\nthem, and know that this means their ruin," she said—obviously one of\nthe phrases she had more than once repeated to herself in the course of\nthe last few days': 42, 'She had called him "Stiva," and he glanced at her with gratitude, and\nmoved to take her hand, but she drew back from him with aversion': 26, '"I think of the children, and for that reason I would do anything in\nthe world to save them, but I don\'t myself know how to save them': 28, 'By\ntaking them away from their father, or by leaving them with a pitiful\nvoice, not knowing what he was saying, as his head sank lower and\nlower': 21, '"You are loathsome to me, repulsive': 6, '" she shrieked, getting more and\nmore heated': 8, '"Your tears mean nothing': 4, 'You have never loved me; you\nhave neither heart nor honorable feeling': 12, 'You are hateful to me,\ndisgusting, a stranger—yes, a complete stranger': 11, '" With pain and wrath\nshe the next room a child began to cry; probably it had\nfallen down': 17, 'Darya Alexandrovna listened, and her face suddenly\nsoftened': 8, 'She seemed to be pulling herself together for a few seconds, as though\nshe did not know where she was, and what she was doing, and getting up\nrapidly, she moved towards the door': 34, '"Well, she loves my child," he thought, noticing the change of her face\nat the child\'s cry, "my child: how can she hate me': 24, '"\n\n"Dolly, one word more," he said, following her': 9, '"If you come near me, I will call in the servants, the children': 13, 'They\nmay all know you are a scoundrel': 8, 'I am going away at once, and you may\nlive here with your mistress': 14, '"\n\nAnd she went out, slamming the door': 8, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch sighed, wiped his face, and with a subdued tread\nwalked out of the room': 16, '"Matvey says she will come round; but how': 8, "I\ndon't see the least chance of it": 8, 'Ah, oh, how horrible it is': 6, 'And how\nvulgarly she shouted," he said to himself, remembering her shriek and\nthe words—"scoundrel" and "mistress': 17, '" "And very likely the maids were\nlistening': 8, 'Horribly vulgar': 2, 'horrible': 1, '" Stepan Arkadyevitch stood a few\nseconds alone, wiped his face, squared his chest, and walked out of the\nroom': 20, 'It was Friday, and in the dining-room the German watchmaker was winding\nup the clock': 15, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch remembered his joke about this\npunctual, bald watchmaker, "that the German was wound up for a whole\nlifetime himself, to wind up watches," and he '" he shouted': 3, '"Arrange everything with Darya in the sitting\nroom for Anna Arkadyevna," he said to Matvey when he came in': 19, '"Yes, sir': 2, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch put on his fur coat and pocketbook': 13, '"That\'ll be enough': 3, '"\n\n"Enough or not enough, we must make it do," said Matvey, slamming the\ncarriage door and stepping back onto the steps': 22, 'Darya Alexandrovna meanwhile having pacified the child, and knowing\nfrom the sound of the carriage that he had gone off, went back again to\nher bedroom': 26, 'It was her solitary refuge from the household cares which\ncrowded upon her directly she went out from it': 19, 'Even now, in the short\ntime she had been in the nursery, the English governess and Matrona\nPhilimonovna had succeeded in putting several questions to her, which\ndid not admit of delay, and which only she could answer: "What were the\nchildren to put on for their walk': 48, 'Should they have any milk': 5, 'Should\nnot a new cook be sent for': 8, '"\n\n"Ah, let me alone, let me alone': 8, '" she said, and going back to her\nbedroom she sat down in the same place as she had sat when talking to\nher husband, clasping tightly her thin hands with the rings that\nslipped down on her bony fingers, and fell to going over in her memory\nall the conversation': 51, '"He has gone': 3, 'But has he broken it off with her': 8, '"\nshe ('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART ONE', {'Stepan Arkadyevitch had learned easily at school, thanks to his\nexcellent abilities, but he had been idle and mischievous, and\ntherefore was one of the lowest in his class': 29, 'But in spite of his\nhabitually dissipated mode of life, his inferior grade in the service,\nand his comparative youth, he occupied the honorable and lucrative\nposition of president of one of the government boards at Moscow': 37, "This\npost he had received through his sister Anna's husband, Alexey\nAlexandrovitch Karenin, who held one of the most important positions in\nthe ministry to whose department the Moscow office belonged": 31, "But if\nKarenin had not got his brother-in-law this berth, then through a\nhundred other personages—brothers, sisters, cousins, uncles, and\naunts—Stiva Oblonsky would have received this post, or some other\nsimilar one, together with the salary of six thousand absolutely\nneedful for him, as his affairs, in spite of his wife's considerable\nproperty, were in an embarrassed condition": 58, 'Half Moscow and Petersburg were friends and relations of Stepan\nArkadyevitch': 11, 'He was born in the midst of those who had been and are\nthe powerful ones of this world': 19, "One-third of the men in the\ngovernment, the older men, had been friends of his father's, and had\nknown him in petticoats; another third were his intimate chums, and the\nremainder were friendly acquaintances": 34, 'Consequently the distributors of\nearthly blessings in the shape of places, rents, shares, and such, were\nall his friends, and could not overlook one of their own set; and\nOblonsky had no need to make any special exertion to get a lucrative\npost': 43, 'He had only not to refuse things, not to show jealousy, not to be\nquarrelsome or take offense, all of which from his characteristic good\nnature he never did': 29, 'It would have struck him as absurd if he had been\ntold that he would not get a position with the salary he required,\nespecially as he expected nothing out of the way; he only wanted what\nthe men of his own age and standing did get, and he was no worse\nqualified for performing duties of the kind than any other man': 63, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch was not merely liked by all who knew him for his\ngood humor, but for his bright disposition, and his unquestionable\nhonesty': 24, 'In him, in his handsome, radiant figure, his sparkling eyes,\nblack hair and eyebrows, and the white and red of his face, there was\nsomething which produced a physical effect of kindliness and good humor\non the people who met him': 41, '"Aha': 1, 'Stiva': 1, 'Oblonsky': 1, 'Here he is': 3, '" was\nalmost always said with a smile of delight on meeting him': 13, 'Even though\nit happened at times that after a conversation with him it seemed that\nnothing particularly delightful had happened, the next day, and the\nnext, everyone was just as delighted at meeting him again': 35, 'After filling for three years the post of president of one of the\ngovernment boards at Moscow, Stepan Arkadyevitch had won the respect,\nas well as the liking, of his fellow-officials, subordinates, and\nsuperiors, and all who had had business with him': 42, 'The principal\nqualities in Stepan Arkadyevitch which had gained him this universal\nrespect in the service consisted, in the first place, of his extreme\nindulgence for others, founded on a consciousness of his own\nshortcomings; secondly, of his perfect liberalism—not the liberalism he\nread of in the papers, but the liberalism that was in his blood, in\nvirtue of which he treated all men perfectly equally and exactly the\nsame, whatever their fortune or calling might be; and thirdly—the most\nimportant point—his complete indifference to the business in which he\nwas engaged, in consequence of which he was never carried away, and\nnever made mistakes': 105, 'On reaching the offices of the board, Stepan Arkadyevitch, escorted by\na deferential porter with a portfolio, went into his little private\nroom, put on his uniform, and went into the boardroom': 32, 'The clerks and\ncopyists all rose, greeting him with good-humored deference': 11, 'Stepan\nArkadyevitch moved quickly, as ever, to his place, shook hands with his\ncolleagues, and sat down': 17, 'He made a joke or two, and talked just as\nmuch as was consistent with due decorum, and began work': 20, 'No one knew\nbetter than Stepan Arkadyevitch how to hit on the exact line between\nfreedom, simplicity, and official stiffness necessary for the agreeable\nconduct of business': 27, "A secretary, with the good-humored deference\ncommon to everyone in Stepan Arkadyevitch's office, came up with\npapers, and began to speak in the familiar and easy tone which had ('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART ONE', {'When Oblonsky asked Levin what had brought him to town, Levin blushed,\nand was furious with himself for blushing, because he could not answer,\n"I have come to make your sister-in-law an offer," though that was\nprecisely what he had come for': 42, 'The families of the Levins and the Shtcherbatskys were old, noble\nMoscow families, and had always been on intimate and friendly terms': 22, "This intimacy had grown still closer during Levin's student days": 10, 'He\nhad both prepared for the university with the young Prince\nShtcherbatsky, the brother of Kitty and Dolly, and had entered at the\nsame time with him': 27, "In those days Levin used often to be in the\nShtcherbatskys' house, and he was in love with the Shtcherbatsky\nhousehold": 21, 'Strange as it may appear, it was with the household, the\nfamily, that Konstantin Levin was in love, especially with the feminine\nhalf of the household': 26, "Levin did not remember his own mother, and his\nonly sister was older than he was, so that it was in the\nShtcherbatskys' house that he saw for the first time that inner life of\nan old, noble, cultivated, and honorable family of which he had been\ndeprived by the death of his father and mother": 56, 'All the members of that\nfamily, especially the feminine half, were pictured by him, as it were,\nwrapped about with a mysterious poetical veil, and he not only\nperceived no defects whatever in them, but under the poetical veil that\nshrouded them he assumed the existence of the loftiest sentiments and\nevery possible perfection': 54, "Why it was the three young ladies had one\nday to speak French, and the next English; why it was that at certain\nhours they played by turns on the piano, the sounds of which were\naudible in their brother's room above, where the students used to work;\nwhy they were visited by those professors of French literature, of\nmusic, of drawing, of dancing; why at certain hours all the three young\nladies, with Mademoiselle Linon, drove in the coach to the Tversky\nboulevard, dressed in their satin cloaks, Dolly in a long one, Natalia\nin a half-long one, and Kitty in one so short that her shapely legs in\ntightly-drawn red stockings were visible to all beholders; why it was\nthey had to walk about the Tversky boulevard escorted by a footman with\na gold cockade in his hat—all this and much more that was done in their\nmysterious world he did not understand, but he was sure that everything\nthat was done there was very good, and he was in love precisely with\nthe mystery of the proceedings": 180, 'In his student days he had all but been in love with the eldest, Dolly,\nbut she was soon married to Oblonsky': 22, 'Then he began being in love with\nthe second': 9, 'He felt, as it were, that he had to be in love with one of\nthe sisters, only he could not quite make out which': 25, 'But Natalia, too,\nhad hardly made her appearance in the world when she married the\ndiplomat Lvov': 17, 'Kitty was still a child when Levin left the university': 10, "Young Shtcherbatsky went into the navy, was drowned in the Baltic, and\nLevin's relations with the Shtcherbatskys, in spite of his friendship\nwith Oblonsky, became less intimate": 27, 'But when early in the winter of\nthis year Levin came to Moscow, after a year in the country, and saw\nthe Shtcherbatskys, he realized which of the three sisters he was\nindeed destined to love': 36, 'One would have thought that nothing could be simpler than for him, a\nman of good family, rather rich than poor, and thirty-two years old, to\nmake the young Princess Shtcherbatskaya an offer of marriage; in all\nlikelihood he would at once have been looked upon as a good match': 50, 'But\nLevin was in love, and so it seemed to him that Kitty was so perfect in\nevery respect that she was a creature far above everything earthly; and\nthat he was a creature so low and so earthly that it could not even be\nconceived that other people and she herself could regard him as worthy\nof her': 59, 'After spending two months in Moscow in a state of enchantment, seeing\nKitty almost every day in society, into which he went so as to meet\nher, he abruptly decided that it could not be, and went back to the\ncountry': 41, "Levin's conviction that it could not be was founded on the idea that in\nthe eyes of her family he was a disadvantageous and worthless match for\nthe charming Kitty, and that Kitty herself could not love him": 38, "In her\nfamily's eyes he had no ordinary, definite career and position in\nsociety, while his contemporaries by this time, when he was thirty-two,\nwere already, one a colonel, and another a professor, another director\nof a bank and railways, or president of a board like Oblonsky": 47, 'But he\n(he knew very well how he must appear to others) was a country\ngentleman, occupied in breeding cattle, shooting game, and building\nbarns; in other words, a fellow of no ability, who had not turned out\nwell, and who was doing just what, according to the ideas of the world,\nis done by people fit for nothing else': 60, 'The mysterious, enchanting Kitty herself could not love such an ugly\nperson as he conceived himself to be, and, above all, such an ordinary,\nin no way striking person': 29, 'Moreover, his attitude to Kitty in the\npast—the attitude of a grown-up person to a child, arising from his\nfriendship with her brother—seemed to him yet another obstacle to love': 30, 'An ugly, good-natured man, as he considered himself, might, he\nsupposed, be liked as a friend; but to be loved with such a love as\nthat with which he loved Kitty, one would need to be a handsome and,\nstill more, a distinguished man': 44, 'He had heard that women often did care for ugly and ordinary men, but\nhe did not believe it, for he judged by himself, and he could not\nhimself have loved any but beautiful, mysterious, and exceptional\nwomen': 38, "But after spending two months alone in the country, he was convinced\nthat this was not one of those passions of which he had had experience\nin his early youth; that this feeling gave him not an instant's rest;\nthat he could not live without deciding the question, would she or\nwould she not be his wife, and that his despair had arisen only from\nhis own imaginings, that he had no sort of proof that he would be\nrejected": 80, 'And he had now come to Moscow with a firm determination to\nmake an offer, and get married if he were accepted': 22, 'Or': 1, 'he could not\nconceive what would become of him if he were rejected': 13, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART ONE', {'On arriving in Moscow by a morning train, Levin had put up at the house\nof his elder half-brother, Koznishev': 20, "After changing his clothes he\nwent down to his brother's study, intending to talk to him at once\nabout the object of his visit, and to ask his advice; but his brother\nwas not alone": 35, 'With him there was a well-known professor of philosophy,\nwho had come from Harkov expressly to clear up a difference that had\narisen between them on a very important philosophical question': 31, 'The\nprofessor was carrying on a hot crusade against materialists': 10, "Sergey\nKoznishev had been following this crusade with interest, and after\nreading the professor's last article, he had written him a letter\nstating his objections": 25, 'He accused the professor of making too great\nconcessions to the materialists': 12, 'And the professor had promptly\nappeared to argue the matter out': 11, 'The point in discussion was the\nquestion then in vogue: Is there a line to be drawn between\npsychological and physiological phenomena in man': 24, 'and if so, where': 4, 'Sergey Ivanovitch met his brother with the smile of chilly friendliness\nhe always had for everyone, and introducing him to the professor, went\non with the conversation': 27, 'A little man in spectacles, with a narrow forehead, tore himself from\nthe discussion for an instant to greet Levin, and then went on talking\nwithout paying any further attention to him': 32, 'Levin sat down to wait\ntill the professor should go, but he soon began to get interested in\nthe subject under discussion': 22, 'Levin had come across the magazine articles about which they were\ndisputing, and had read them, interested in them as a development of\nthe first principles of science, familiar to him as a natural science\nstudent at the university': 39, 'But he had never connected these scientific\ndeductions as to the origin of man as an animal, as to reflex action,\nbiology, and sociology, with those questions as to the meaning of life\nand death to himself, which had of late been more and more often in his\nmind': 49, "As he listened to his brother's argument with the professor, he noticed\nthat they connected these scientific questions with those spiritual\nproblems, that at times they almost touched on the latter; but every\ntime they were close upon what seemed to him the chief point, they\npromptly beat a hasty retreat, and plunged again into a sea of subtle\ndistinctions, reservations, quotations, allusions, and appeals to\nauthorities, and it was with difficulty that he understood what they\nwere talking about": 80, '"I cannot admit it," said Sergey Ivanovitch, with his habitual\nclearness, precision of expression, and elegance of phrase': 18, '"I cannot\nin any case agree with Keiss that my whole conception of the external\nworld has been derived from perceptions': 21, 'The most fundamental idea, the\nidea of existence, has not been received by me through sensation;\nindeed, there is no special sense-organ for the transmission of such an\nidea': 29, '"\n\n"Yes, but they—Wurt, and Knaust, and Pripasov—would answer that your\nconsciousness of existence is derived from the conjunction of all your\nsensations, that that consciousness of existence is the result of your\nsensations': 34, 'Wurt, indeed, says plainly that, assuming there are no\nsensations, it follows that there is no idea of existence': 19, '"\n\n"I maintain the contrary," began Sergey Ivanovitch': 8, 'But here it seemed to Levin that just as they were close upon the real\npoint of the matter, they were again retreating, and he made up his\nmind to put a question to the professor': 36, '"According to that, if my senses are annihilated, if my body is dead, I\ncan have no existence of any sort': 21, '" he queried': 3, "The professor, in annoyance, and, as it were, mental suffering at the\ninterruption, looked round at the strange inquirer, more like a\nbargeman than a philosopher, and turned his eyes upon Sergey\nIvanovitch, as though to ask: What's one to say to him": 43, 'But Sergey\nIvanovitch, who had been talking with far less heat and one-sidedness\nthan the professor, and who had sufficient breadth of mind to answer\nthe professor, and at the same time to comprehend the simple and\nnatural point of view from which the question was put, smiled and said:\n\n"That question we have no right to answer as yet': 60, '"\n\n"We have not the requisite data," chimed in the professor, and he went\nback to his argument': 18, '"No," he said; "I would point out the fact that\nif, as Pripasov directly asserts, perception is based on sensation,\nthen we are bound to distinguish sharply between these two\nconceptions': 31, '"\n\nLevin listened no more, and simply waited for the professor to go': 13, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 8 PART ONE', {'When the professor had gone, Sergey Ivanovitch turned to his brother': 11, '"Delighted that you\'ve come': 4, 'For some time, is it': 5, "How's your farming\ngetting on": 5, '"\n\nLevin knew that his elder brother took little interest in farming, and\nonly put the question in deference to him, and so he only told him\nabout the sale of his wheat and money matters': 36, 'Levin had meant to tell his brother of his determination to get\nmarried, and to ask his advice; he had indeed firmly resolved to do so': 26, "But after seeing his brother, listening to his conversation with the\nprofessor, hearing afterwards the unconsciously patronizing tone in\nwhich his brother questioned him about agricultural matters (their\nmother's property had not been divided, and Levin took charge of both\ntheir shares), Levin felt that he could not for some reason begin to\ntalk to him of his intention of marrying": 61, 'He felt that his brother\nwould not look at it as he would have wished him to': 17, '"Well, how is your district council doing': 7, '" asked Sergey Ivanovitch,\nwho was greatly interested in these local boards and attached great\nimportance to them': 18, '"I really don\'t know': 4, '"\n\n"What': 2, "Why, surely you're a member of the board": 8, '"\n\n"No, I\'m not a member now; I\'ve resigned," answered Levin, "and I no\nlonger attend the meetings': 18, '"\n\n"What a pity': 4, '" commented Sergey Ivanovitch, frowning': 5, 'Levin in self-defense began to describe what took place in the meetings\nin his district': 15, '"That\'s how it always is': 5, '" Sergey Ivanovitch interrupted him': 5, '"We\nRussians are always like that': 6, "Perhaps it's our strong point, really,\nthe faculty of seeing our own shortcomings; but we overdo it, we\ncomfort ourselves with irony which we always have on the tip of our\ntongues": 32, 'All I say is, give such rights as our local self-government to\nany other European people—why, the Germans or the English would have\nworked their way to freedom from them, while we simply turn them into\nridicule': 37, '"\n\n"But how can it be helped': 7, '" said Levin penitently': 4, '"It was my last\neffort': 5, 'And I did try with all my soul': 8, "I can't": 2, "I'm no good at it": 5, '"\n\n"It\'s not that you\'re no good at it," said Sergey Ivanovitch; "it is\nthat you don\'t look at it as you should': 23, '"\n\n"Perhaps not," Levin answered dejectedly': 6, '"Oh': 1, "do you know brother Nikolay's turned up again": 8, '"\n\nThis brother Nikolay was the elder brother of Konstantin Levin, and\nhalf-brother of Sergey Ivanovitch; a man utterly ruined, who had\ndissipated the greater part of his fortune, was living in the strangest\nand lowest company, and had quarreled with his brothers': 43, '"What did you say': 4, '" Levin cried with horror': 5, '"How do you know': 4, '"\n\n"Prokofy saw him in the street': 7, '"\n\n"Here in Moscow': 4, 'Where is he': 3, 'Do you know': 3, '" Levin got up from his\nchair, as though on the point of starting off at once': 17, '"I am sorry I told you," said Sergey Ivanovitch, shaking his head at\nhis younger brother\'s excitement': 17, '"I sent to find out where he is\nliving, and sent him his IOU to Trubin, which I paid': 19, 'This is the\nanswer he sent me': 7, '"\n\nAnd Sergey Ivanovitch took a note from under a paper-weight and handed\nit to his brother': 17, 'Levin read in the queer, familiar handwriting: "I humbly beg you to\nleave me in peace': 16, "That's the only favor I ask of my gracious\nbrothers": 10, '—Nikolay Levin': 2, '"\n\nLevin read it, and without raising his head stood with the note in his\nhands opposite Sergey Ivanovitch': 19, 'There was a struggle in his heart between the desire to forget his\nunhappy brother for the time, and the consciousness that it would be\nbase to do so': 29, '"He obviously wants to offend me," pursued Sergey Ivanovitch; "but he\ncannot offend me, and I should have wished with all my heart to assist\nhim, but I know it\'s impossible to do that': 34, '"\n\n"Yes, yes," repeated Levin': 5, '"I understand and appreciate your attitude\nto him; but I shall go and see him': 15, '"\n\n"If you want to, do; but I shouldn\'t advise it," said Sergey\nIvanovitch': 14, '"As regards myself, I have no fear of your doing so; he\nwill not make you quarrel with me; but for your own sake, I should say\nyou would do better not to go': 34, "You can't do him any good; still, do as\nyou please": 11, '"\n\n"Very likely I can\'t do any good, but I feel—especially at such a\nmoment—but that\'s another thing—I feel I could not be at peace': 25, '"\n\n"Well, that I don\'t understand," said Sergey Ivanovitch': 9, '"One thing I\ndo understand," he added; "it\'s a lesson in humility': 12, 'I have come to\nlook very differently and more charitably on what is called infamous\nsince brother Nikolay has become what he is': 23, 'you know what he\ndid': 5, '"\n\n"Oh, it\'s awful, awful': 5, '" repeated Levin': 3, "After obtaining his brother's address from Sergey Ivanovitch's footman,\nLevin was on the point of setting off at once to see him, but on second\nthought he decided to put off his visit till the evening": 36, 'The first\nthing to do to set his heart at rest was to accomplish what he had come\nto Moscow for': 21, "From his brother's Levin went to Oblonsky's office, and\non getting news of the Shtcherbatskys from him, he drove to the place\nwhere he had been told he might find Kitty": 31, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART ONE', {"At four o'clock, conscious of his throbbing heart, Levin stepped out of\na hired sledge at the Zoological Gardens, and turned along the path to\nthe frozen mounds and the skating ground, knowing that he would\ncertainly find her there, as he had seen the Shtcherbatskys' carriage\nat the entrance": 50, 'It was a bright, frosty day': 6, 'Rows of carriages, sledges, drivers, and\npolicemen were standing in the approach': 12, 'Crowds of well-dressed people,\nwith hats bright in the sun, swarmed about the entrance and along the\nwell-swept little paths between the little houses adorned with carving\nin the Russian style': 31, 'The old curly birches of the gardens, all their\ntwigs laden with snow, looked as though freshly decked in sacred\nvestments': 21, 'He walked along the path towards the skating-ground, and kept saying to\nhimself—"You mustn\'t be excited, you must be calm': 20, "What's the matter\nwith you": 5, 'What do you want': 4, 'Be quiet, stupid," he conjured his heart': 7, 'And the more he tried to compose himself, the more breathless he found\nhimself': 14, 'An acquaintance met him and called him by his name, but Levin\ndid not even recognize him': 17, 'He went towards the mounds, whence came the\nclank of the chains of sledges as they slipped down or were dragged up,\nthe rumble of the sliding sledges, and the sounds of merry voices': 34, 'He\nwalked on a few steps, and the skating-ground lay open before his eyes,\nand at once, amidst all the skaters, he knew her': 24, 'He knew she was there by the rapture and the terror that seized on his\nheart': 16, 'She was standing talking to a lady at the opposite end of the\nground': 14, 'There was apparently nothing striking either in her dress or\nher attitude': 12, 'But for Levin she was as easy to find in that crowd as a\nrose among nettles': 17, 'Everything was made bright by her': 6, 'She was the\nsmile that shed light on all round her': 11, '"Is it possible I can go over\nthere on the ice, go up to her': 15, '" he thought': 3, 'The place where she stood\nseemed to him a holy shrine, unapproachable, and there was one moment\nwhen he was almost retreating, so overwhelmed was he with terror': 28, 'He\nhad to make an effort to master himself, and to remind himself that\npeople of all sorts were moving about her, and that he too might come\nthere to skate': 31, 'He walked down, for a long while avoiding looking at\nher as at the sun, but seeing her, as one does the sun, without\nlooking': 25, 'On that day of the week and at that time of day people of one set, all\nacquainted with one another, used to meet on the ice': 27, 'There were crack\nskaters there, showing off their skill, and learners clinging to chairs\nwith timid, awkward movements, boys, and elderly people skating with\nhygienic motives': 26, 'They seemed to Levin an elect band of blissful beings\nbecause they were here, near her': 16, 'All the skaters, it seemed, with\nperfect self-possession, skated towards her, skated by her, even spoke\nto her, and were happy, quite apart from her, enjoying the capital ice\nand the fine weather': 33, "Nikolay Shtcherbatsky, Kitty's cousin, in a short jacket and tight\ntrousers, was sitting on a garden seat with his skates on": 21, 'Seeing\nLevin, he shouted to him:\n\n"Ah, the first skater in Russia': 12, 'Been here long': 3, 'First-rate ice—do put\nyour skates on': 6, '"\n\n"I haven\'t got my skates," Levin answered, marveling at this boldness\nand ease in her presence, and not for one second losing sight of her,\nthough he did not look at her': 33, 'He felt as though the sun were coming\nnear him': 10, 'She was in a corner, and turning out her slender feet in\ntheir high boots with obvious timidity, she skated towards him': 22, 'A boy\nin Russian dress, desperately waving his arms and bowed down to the\nground, overtook her': 17, 'She skated a little uncertainly; taking her hands\nout of the little muff that hung on a cord, she held them ready for\nemergency, and looking towards Levin, whom she had recognized, she\nsmiled at him, and at her own fears': 41, 'When she had got round the turn,\nshe gave herself a push off with one foot, and skated straight up to\nShtcherbatsky': 22, 'Clutching at his arm, she nodded smiling to Levin': 9, 'She\nwas more splendid than he had imagined her': 9, 'When he thought of her, he could call up a vivid picture of her to\nhimself, especially the charm of that little fair head, so freely set\non the shapely girlish shoulders, and so full of childish brightness\nand good humor': 41, 'The childishness of her expression, together with the\ndelicate beauty of her figure, made up her special charm, and that he\nfully realized': 23, 'But what always struck him in her as something unlooked\nfor, was the expression of her eyes, soft, serene, and truthful, and\nabove all, her smile, which always transported Levin to an enchanted\nworld, where he felt himself softened and tender, as he remembered\nhimself in some days of his early childhood': 52, '"Have you been here long': 5, '" she said, giving him her hand': 7, '"Thank you,"\nshe added, as he picked up the handkerchief that had fallen out of her\nmuff': 17, '"I': 1, "I've not long": 3, 'yesterday': 1, 'I mean today': 3, 'I arrived,"\nanswered Levin, in his emotion not at once understanding her question': 13, '"I was meaning to come and see you," he said; and then, recollecting\nwith what intention he was trying to see her, he was promptly overcome\nwith confusion and blushed': 30, '"I didn\'t know you could skate, and skate so well': 10, '"\n\nShe looked at him earnestly, as though wishing to make out the cause of\nhis confusion': 17, '"Your praise is worth having': 5, 'The tradition is kept up here that you\nare the best of skaters," she said, with her little black-gloved hand\nbrushing a grain of hoarfrost off her muff': 28, '"Yes, I used once to skate face': 20, '"Yes," he thought, "this now is life, this is happiness': 10, '_Together,_\nshe said; _let us skate together': 7, '_ Speak to her now': 5, "But that's just\nwhy I'm afraid to speak—because I'm happy now, happy in hope,\nanyway": 15, 'And then': 2, 'But I must': 3, 'I must': 2, 'Away with\nweakness': 3, '"\n\nLevin rose to his feet, took off his overcoat, and scurrying over the\nrough hand': 29, '"With you I should soon learn; I somehow feel confidence in you," she\nsaid to him': 16, '"And I have confidence in myself when you are leaning on me," he said,\nbut was at once panic-stricken at what he had said, and blushed': 26, 'And\nindeed, no sooner had he uttered these words, when all at once, like\nthe sun going behind a cloud, her face lost all its friendliness, and\nLevin detected the familiar change in her expression that denoted the\nworking of thought; a crease showed on her smooth brow': 48, '"Is there anything troubling you': 5, '—though I\'ve no right to ask such a\nquestion," he added hurriedly': 12, '"Oh, why so': 3, 'No, I have nothing to trouble me," she responded\ncoldly; and she added immediately: "You haven\'t seen Mlle': 18, 'Linon, the joke\nfor ten years now, and was fond of it': 22, '"Now, go and skate, go and skate': 7, "Our Kitty has learned to skate\nnicely, hasn't she": 9, '"\n\nWhen Levin darted up to Kitty her face was no longer stern; her eyes\nlooked at him with the same sincerity and friendliness, but Levin\nfancied that in her friendliness there was a certain note of deliberate\ncomposure': 39, 'And he felt depressed': 4, 'After talking a little of her old\ngoverness and her peculiarities, she questioned him about his life': 17, '"Surely you must be dull in the country in the winter, aren\'t you': 13, '" she\nsaid': 3, '"No, I\'m not dull, I am very busy," he said, feeling that she was\nholding him in check by her composed tone, which he would not have the\nforce to break through, just as it had been at the beginning of the\nwinter': 43, '"Are you going to stay in town long': 8, '" Kitty questioned him': 4, '"I don\'t know," he answered, not thinking of what he was saying': 12, 'The\nthought that it you don\'t know': 6, '"\n\n"I don\'t know': 4, 'It depends upon you," he said, and was immediately\nhorror-stricken at his own words': 14, 'Whether it was that she had heard his words, or that she '" Nikolay Shtcherbatsky\nshouted after him': 6, 'Levin went to the steps, took a run from above as best he could, and\ndashed down, preserving his balance in this unwonted movement with his\nhands': 27, 'On the last step he stumbled, but barely touching the ice with\nhis hand, with a violent effort recovered himself, and skated off,\nlaughing': 24, '"How splendid, how nice he is': 6, '" Kitty was ('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART ONE', {'When Levin went into the restaurant with Oblonsky, he could not help\nnoticing a certain peculiarity of expression, as it were, a restrained\nradiance, about the face and whole figure of Stepan Arkadyevitch': 33, 'Oblonsky took off his overcoat, and with his hat over one ear walked\ninto the dining-room, giving directions to the Tatar waiters, who were\nclustered about him in evening coats, bearing napkins': 32, 'Bowing to right\nand left to the people he met, and here as everywhere joyously greeting\nacquaintances, he went up to the sideboard for a preliminary appetizer\nof fish and vodka, and said to the painted Frenchwoman decked in\nribbons, lace, and ringlets, behind the counter, something so amusing\nthat even that Frenchwoman was moved to genuine laughter': 58, 'Levin for his\npart refrained from taking any vodka simply because he felt such a\nloathing of that Frenchwoman, all made up, it seemed, of false hair,\n_poudre de riz,_ and _vinaigre de toilette_': 34, 'He made haste to move away\nfrom her, as from a dirty place': 13, 'His whole soul was filled with\nmemories of Kitty, and there was a smile of triumph and happiness\nshining in his eyes': 22, '"This way, your excellency, please': 5, 'Your excellency won\'t be disturbed\nhere," said a particularly pertinacious, white-headed old Tatar with\nimmense hips and coat-tails gaping widely behind': 21, '"Walk in, your\nexcellency," he said to Levin; by way of showing his respect to Stepan\nArkadyevitch, being attentive to his guest as well': 24, 'Instantly flinging a fresh cloth over the round table under the bronze\nchandelier, though it already had a table cloth on it, he pushed up\nvelvet chairs, and came to a standstill before Stepan Arkadyevitch with\na napkin and a bill of fare in his hands, awaiting his commands': 49, '"If you prefer it, your excellency, a private room will be free\ndirectly; Prince Golistin with a lady': 18, 'Fresh oysters have come in': 5, '"\n\n"Ah': 2, 'oysters': 1, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch became thoughtful': 5, '"How if we were to change our program, Levin': 9, '" he said, keeping his\nfinger on the bill of fare': 11, 'And his face expressed serious hesitation': 6, '"Are the oysters good': 4, 'Mind now': 2, '"\n\n"They\'re Flensburg, your excellency': 5, "We've no Ostend": 3, '"\n\n"Flensburg will do, but are they fresh': 8, '"\n\n"Only arrived yesterday': 4, '"\n\n"Well, then, how if we were to begin with oysters, and so change the\nwhole program': 17, 'Eh': 1, '"\n\n"It\'s all the same to me': 7, "I should like cabbage soup and porridge\nbetter than anything; but of course there's nothing like that here": 18, '"\n\n"_Porridge à la Russe,_ your honor would like': 9, '" said the Tatar, bending\ndown to Levin, like a nurse speaking to a child': 15, '"No, joking apart, whatever you choose is sure to be good': 11, "I've been\nskating, and I'm hungry": 6, 'And don\'t imagine," he added, detecting a look\nof dissatisfaction on Oblonsky\'s face, "that I shan\'t appreciate your\nchoice': 19, 'I am fond of good things': 6, '"\n\n"I should hope so': 5, 'After all, it\'s one of the pleasures of life," said\nStepan Arkadyevitch': 12, '"Well, then, my friend, you give us two—or better\nsay three—dozen oysters, clear soup with vegetables': 16, '"\n\n"_Printanière,_" prompted the Tatar': 5, 'But Stepan Arkadyevitch apparently\ndid not care to allow him the satisfaction of giving the French names\nof the dishes': 20, '"With vegetables in it, you know': 6, 'Then turbot with thick sauce, then': 6, "roast beef; and mind it's good": 6, 'Yes, and capons, perhaps, and then\nsweets': 7, '"\n\nThe Tatar, recollecting that it was Stepan Arkadyevitch\'s way not to\ncall the dishes by the names in the French bill of fare, did not repeat\nthem after him, but could not resist rehearsing the whole menu to\nhimself according to the bill:—"_Soupe printanière, turbot, sauce\nBeaumarchais, poulard à l\'estragon, macédoine de fruits_': 54, 'etc': 1, '," and\nthen instantly, as though worked by springs, laying down one bound bill\nof fare, he took up another, the list of wines, and submitted it to\nStepan Arkadyevitch': 30, '"What shall we drink': 4, '"\n\n"What you like, only not too much': 8, 'Champagne," said Levin': 3, '"What': 1, 'to start with': 3, "You're right though, I dare say": 6, 'Do you like the\nwhite seal': 6, '"\n\n"_Cachet blanc,_" prompted the Tatar': 6, '"Very well, then, give us that brand with the oysters, and then we\'ll\nsee': 14, '"\n\n"Yes, sir': 3, 'And what '"\n\n"No, it\'s all the same to me," said Levin, unable to suppress a smile': 15, 'And the Tatar ran off with flying coat-tails, and in five minutes\ndarted in with a dish of opened oysters on mother-of-pearl shells, and\na bottle between his fingers': 29, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch crushed the starchy napkin, tucked it into his\nwaistcoat, and settling his arms comfortably, started on the oysters': 20, '"Not bad," he said, stripping the oysters from the pearly shell with a\nsilver fork, and swallowing them one after another': 21, '"Not bad," he\nrepeated, turning his dewy, brilliant was\nnot in good spirits; he was ill at ease': 16, 'With what he had in his soul,\nhe felt sore and uncomfortable in the restaurant, in the midst of\nprivate rooms where men were dining with ladies, in all this fuss and\nbustle; the surroundings of bronzes, looking-glasses, gas, and\nwaiters—all of it was offensive to him': 47, 'He was afraid of sullying what\nhis soul was brimful of': 11, '"I': 1, 'Yes, I am; but besides, all this bothers me," he said': 11, '"You can\'t\nconceive how queer it all seems to a country person like me, as queer\nas that gentleman\'s nails I saw at your place': 25, '"\n\n"Yes, I saw how much interested you were in poor Grinevitch\'s nails,"\nsaid Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing': 17, '"It\'s too much for me," responded Levin': 7, '"Do try, now, and put yourself\nin my place, take the point of view of a country person': 18, 'We in the\ncountry try to bring our hands into such a state as will be most\nconvenient for working with': 21, 'So we cut our nails; sometimes we turn up\nour sleeves': 11, 'And here people purposely let their nails grow as long as\nthey will, and link on small saucers by way of studs, so that they can\ndo nothing with their hands': 31, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch smiled gaily': 5, '"Oh, yes, that\'s just a sign that he has no need to do coarse work': 15, 'His\nwork is with the mind': 6, '"\n\n"Maybe': 2, "But still it's queer to me, just as at this moment it seems\nqueer to me that we country folks try to get our meals over as soon as\nwe can, so as to be ready for our work, while here are we trying to\ndrag out our meal as long as possible, and with that object eating\noysters": 59, '"\n\n"Why, of course," objected Stepan Arkadyevitch': 7, '"But that\'s just the\naim of civilization—to make everything a source ('TOL CHAPTER 11 PART ONE', {'Levin emptied his glass, and they were silent for a while': 11, '"There\'s one other thing I ought to tell you': 9, 'Do you know Vronsky': 4, '"\nStepan Arkadyevitch
