('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART ONE', {'The young Princess Kitty Shtcherbatskaya was eighteen': 7, 'It was the first\nwinter that she had been out in the world': 13, 'Her success in society had\nbeen greater than that of either of her elder sisters, and greater even\nthan her mother had anticipated': 23, 'To say nothing of the young men who\ndanced at the Moscow balls being almost all in love with Kitty, two\nserious suitors had already this first winter made their appearance:\nLevin, and immediately after his departure, Count Vronsky': 39, "Levin's appearance at the beginning of the winter, his frequent visits,\nand evident love for Kitty, had led to the first serious conversations\nbetween Kitty's parents as to her future, and to disputes between them": 35, "The prince was on Levin's side; he said he wished for nothing better\nfor Kitty": 15, 'The princess for her part, going round the question in the\nmanner peculiar to women, maintained that Kitty was too young, that\nLevin had done nothing to prove that he had serious intentions, that\nKitty felt no great attraction to him, and other side issues; but she\ndid not state the principal point, which was that she looked for a\nbetter match for her daughter, and that Levin was not to her liking,\nand she did not understand him': 79, 'When Levin had abruptly departed, the\nprincess was delighted, and said to her husband triumphantly: "You see\nI was right': 20, '" When Vronsky appeared on the scene, she was still more\ndelighted, confirmed in her opinion that Kitty was to make not simply a\ngood, but a brilliant match': 29, "In the mother's eyes there could be no comparison between Vronsky and\nLevin": 13, 'She disliked in Levin his strange and uncompromising opinions\nand his shyness in society, founded, as she supposed, on his pride and\nhis queer sort of life, as she considered it, absorbed in cattle and\npeasants': 36, 'She did not very much like it that he, who was in love with\nher daughter, had kept coming to the house for six weeks, as though he\nwere waiting for something, inspecting, as though he were afraid he\nmight be doing them too great an honor by making an offer, and did not\nrealize that a man, who continually visits at a house where there is a\nyoung unmarried girl, is bound to make his intentions clear': 78, 'And\nsuddenly, without doing so, he disappeared': 7, '"It\'s as well he\'s not\nattractive enough for Kitty to have fallen in love with him," thought\nthe mother': 19, "Vronsky satisfied all the mother's desires": 6, 'Very wealthy, clever, of\naristocratic family, on the highroad to a brilliant career in the army\nand at court, and a fascinating man': 23, 'Nothing better could be wished\nfor': 6, 'Vronsky openly flirted with Kitty at balls, danced with her, and came\ncontinually to the house, consequently there could be no doubt of the\nseriousness of his intentions': 28, 'But, in spite of that, the mother had\nspent the whole of that winter in a state of terrible anxiety and\nagitation': 22, 'Princess Shtcherbatskaya had herself been married thirty years ago, her\naunt arranging the match': 14, 'Her husband, about whom everything was well\nknown beforehand, had come, looked at his future bride, and been looked\nat': 20, 'The matchmaking aunt had ascertained and communicated their mutual\nimpression': 10, 'That impression had been favorable': 5, 'Afterwards, on a day\nfixed beforehand, the expected offer was made to her parents, and\naccepted': 16, 'All had passed very simply and easily': 7, 'So it seemed, at\nleast, to the princess': 8, "But over her own daughters she had felt how far\nfrom simple and easy is the business, apparently so commonplace, of\nmarrying off one's daughters": 25, 'The panics that had been lived through,\nthe thoughts that had been brooded over, the money that had been\nwasted, and the disputes with her husband over marrying the two elder\ngirls, Darya and Natalia': 35, 'Now, since the youngest had come out, she was\ngoing through the same terrors, the same doubts, and still more violent\nquarrels with her husband than she had over the elder girls': 32, 'The old\nprince, like all fathers indeed, was exceedingly punctilious on the\nscore of the honor and reputation of his daughters': 21, 'He was irrationally\njealous over his daughters, especially over Kitty, who was his\nfavorite': 14, 'At every turn he had scenes with the princess for\ncompromising her daughter': 13, "The princess had grown accustomed to this\nalready with her other daughters, but now she felt that there was more\nground for the prince's touchiness": 25, "She saw that of late years much was\nchanged in the manners of society, that a mother's duties had become\nstill more difficult": 23, "She saw that girls of Kitty's age formed some\nsort of clubs, went to some sort of lectures, mixed freely in men's\nsociety; drove about the streets alone, many of them did not curtsey,\nand, what was the most important thing, all the girls were firmly\nconvinced that to choose their husbands was their own affair, and not\ntheir parents'": 60, '"Marriages aren\'t made nowadays as they used to be,"\nwas thought and said by all these young girls, and even by their\nelders': 23, 'But how marriages were made now, the princess could not learn\nfrom anyone': 13, "The French fashion—of the parents arranging their\nchildren's future—was not accepted; it was condemned": 14, 'The English\nfashion of the complete independence of girls was also not accepted,\nand not possible in Russian society': 19, 'The Russian fashion of matchmaking\nby the offices of intermediate persons was for some reason considered\nunseemly; it was ridiculed by everyone, and by the princess herself': 27, 'But how girls were to be married, and how parents were to marry them,\nno one knew': 17, 'Everyone with whom the princess had chanced to discuss the\nmatter said the same thing: "Mercy on us, it\'s high time in our day to\ncast off all that old-fashioned business': 31, "It's the young people have to\nmarry; and not their parents; and so we ought to leave the young people\nto arrange it as they choose": 26, '" It was very easy for anyone to say that\nwho had no daughters, but the princess realized that in the process of\ngetting to know each other, her daughter might fall in love, and fall\nin love with someone who did not care to marry her or who was quite\nunfit to be her husband': 56, 'And, however much it was instilled into the\nprincess that in our times young people ought to arrange their lives\nfor themselves, she was unable to believe it, just as she would have\nbeen unable to believe that, at any time whatever, the most suitable\nplaythings for children five years old ought to be loaded pistols': 56, 'And\nso the princess was more uneasy over Kitty than she had been over her\nelder sisters': 17, 'Now she was afraid that Vronsky might confine himself to simply\nflirting with her daughter': 15, 'She saw that her daughter was in love with\nhim, but tried to comfort herself with the thought that he was an\nhonorable man, and would not do this': 29, "But at the same time she knew how\neasy it is, with the freedom of manners of today, to turn a girl's\nhead, and how lightly men generally regard such a crime": 32, 'The week\nbefore, Kitty had told her mother of a conversation she had with\nVronsky during a mazurka': 18, 'This conversation had partly reassured the\nprincess; but perfectly at ease she could not be': 15, 'Vronsky had told\nKitty that both he and his brother were so used to obeying their mother\nthat they never made up their minds to any important undertaking\nwithout consulting her': 31, '"And just now, I am impatiently awaiting my\nmother\'s arrival from Petersburg, as peculiarly fortunate," he told\nher': 18, 'Kitty had repeated this without attaching any significance to the\nwords': 11, 'But her mother saw them in a different light': 9, "She knew that the\nold lady was expected from day to day, that she would be pleased at her\nson's choice, and she felt it strange that he should not make his offer\nthrough fear of vexing his mother": 39, 'However, she was so anxious for the\nmarriage itself, and still more for relief from her fears, that she\nbelieved it was so': 23, "Bitter as it was for the princess to see the\nunhappiness of her eldest daughter, Dolly, on the point of leaving her\nhusband, her anxiety over the decision of her youngest daughter's fate\nengrossed all her feelings": 37, "Today, with Levin's reappearance, a fresh\nsource of anxiety arose": 10, "She was afraid that her daughter, who had at\none time, as she fancied, a feeling for Levin, might, from extreme\nsense as they\nreturned home': 10, '"He came today, mamma': 4, '"\n\n"There\'s one thing I want to say': 8, '" began the princess, and from her\nserious and alert face, Kitty guessed what it would be': 17, ('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART ONE', {'After dinner, and till the beginning of the evening, Kitty was feeling\na sensation akin to the sensation of a young man before a battle': 25, 'Her\nheart throbbed violently, and her thoughts would not rest on anything': 12, 'She felt that this evening, when they would both meet for the first\ntime, would be a turning point in her life': 22, 'And she was continually\npicturing them to herself, at one moment each separately, and then both\ntogether': 17, 'When she mused on the past, she dwelt with pleasure, with\ntenderness, on the memories of her relations with Levin': 20, "The memories\nof childhood and of Levin's friendship with her dead brother gave a\nspecial poetic charm to her relations with him": 22, 'His love for her, of\nwhich she felt certain, was flattering and delightful to her; and it\nwas pleasant for her to think of Levin': 25, 'In her memories of Vronsky\nthere always entered a certain element of awkwardness, though he was in\nthe highest degree well-bred and at ease, as though there were some\nfalse note—not in Vronsky, he was very simple and nice, but in herself,\nwhile with Levin she felt perfectly simple and clear': 51, 'But, on the other\nhand, directly she thought of the future with Vronsky, there arose\nbefore her a perspective of brilliant happiness; with Levin the future\nseemed misty': 28, 'When she went upstairs to dress, and looked into the looking-glass, she\nnoticed with joy that it was one of her good days, and that she was in\ncomplete possession of all her forces,—she needed this so for what lay\nbefore her: she was conscious of external composure and free grace in\nher movements': 54, 'At half-past seven she had only just gone down into the drawing-room,\nwhen the footman announced, "Konstantin Dmitrievitch Levin': 19, '" The\nprincess was still in her room, and the prince had not come in': 15, '"So it\nis to be," thought Kitty, and all the blood seemed to rush to her\nheart': 17, 'She was horrified at her paleness, as she glanced into the\nlooking-glass': 12, 'At that moment she knew beyond doubt that he had come\nearly on purpose to find her alone and to make her an offer': 24, 'And only\nthen for the first time the whole thing presented itself in a new,\ndifferent aspect; only then she realized that the question did not\naffect her only—with whom she would be happy, and whom she loved—but\nthat she would have that moment to wound a man whom she liked': 51, 'And to\nwound him cruelly': 5, 'What for': 2, 'Because he, dear fellow, loved her, was in\nlove with her': 11, 'But there was no help for it, so it must be, so it would\nhave to be': 17, '"My God': 2, 'shall I myself really have to say it to him': 10, '" she thought': 3, '"Can I tell him I don\'t love him': 8, 'That will be a lie': 5, 'What am I to say\nto him': 7, 'That I love someone else': 5, "No, that's impossible": 3, "I'm going\naway, I'm going away": 6, '"\n\nShe had reached the door, when she heard his step': 11, '"No': 1, "it's not\nhonest": 3, 'What have I to be afraid of': 7, 'I have done nothing wrong': 5, 'What is\nto be, will be': 6, "I'll tell the truth": 4, "And with him one can't be ill at\nease": 9, 'Here he is," she said to herself, seeing his powerful, shy\nfigure, with his shining eyes fixed on her': 19, 'She looked straight into\nhis face, as though imploring him to spare her, and gave her hand': 17, '"It\'s not time yet; ('TOL CHAPTER 14 PART ONE', {'But at that very moment the princess came in': 9, 'There was a look of\nhorror on her face when she saw them alone, and their disturbed faces': 18, 'Levin bowed to her, ('TOL CHAPTER 15 PART ONE', {'At the end of the evening Kitty told her mother of her conversation\nwith Levin, and in spite of all the pity she felt for Levin, she was\nglad at the thought that she on\nthe pillow, smiling with happiness': 29, '"I\'m sorry, I\'m sorry; but what\ncould I do': 9, 'It\'s not my fault," she said to herself; but an inner voice\ntold her something else': 16, "Whether she felt remorse at having won Levin's\nlove, or at having refused him, she did not know": 18, 'But her happiness was\npoisoned by doubts': 7, '"Lord, have pity on us; Lord, have pity on us;\nLord, '"\n\nAnd signing each other with the cross, the husband and wife parted with\na kiss, feeling that they each remained of their own opinion': 25, "The princess had at first been quite certain that ('TOL CHAPTER 16 PART ONE', {'Vronsky had never had a real home life': 8, 'His mother had been in her\nyouth a brilliant society woman, who had had during her married life,\nand still more afterwards, many love affairs notorious in the whole\nfashionable world': 31, 'His father he scarcely remembered, and he had been\neducated in the Corps of Pages': 15, 'Leaving the school very young as a brilliant officer, he had at once\ngot into the circle of wealthy Petersburg army men': 22, 'Although he did go\nmore or less into Petersburg society, his love affairs had always\nhitherto been outside it': 19, 'In Moscow he had for the first time felt, after his luxurious and\ncoarse life at Petersburg, all the charm of intimacy with a sweet and\ninnocent girl of his own rank, who cared for him': 36, 'It never even entered\nhis head that there could be any harm in his relations with Kitty': 17, 'At\nballs he danced principally with her': 7, 'He was a constant visitor at\ntheir house': 8, 'He talked to her as people commonly do talk in society—all\nsorts of nonsense, but nonsense to which he could not help attaching a\nspecial meaning in her case': 29, 'Although he said nothing to her that he\ncould not have said before everybody, he felt that she was becoming\nmore and more dependent upon him, and the more he felt this, the better\nhe liked it, and the tenderer was his feeling for her': 45, 'He did not know\nthat his mode of behavior in relation to Kitty had a definite\ncharacter, that it is courting young girls with no intention of\nmarriage, and that such courting is one of the evil actions common\namong brilliant young men such as he was': 47, 'It seemed to him that he was\nthe first who had discovered this pleasure, and he was enjoying his\ndiscovery': 20, 'If he could have heard what her parents were saying that evening, if he\ncould have put himself at the point of view of the family and have\nheard that Kitty would be unhappy if he did not marry her, he would\nhave been greatly astonished, and would not have believed it': 52, 'He could\nnot believe that what gave such great and delicate pleasure to him, and\nabove all to her, could be wrong': 22, 'Still less could he have believed\nthat he ought to marry': 11, 'Marriage had never presented itself to him as a possibility': 10, 'He not\nonly disliked family life, but a family, and especially a husband was,\nin accordance with the views general in the bachelor world in which he\nlived, conceived as something alien, repellant, and, above all,\nridiculous': 37, "But though Vronsky had not the least suspicion what the parents were\nsaying, he felt on coming away from the Shtcherbatskys' that the secret\nspiritual bond which existed between him and Kitty had grown so much\nstronger that evening that some step must be taken": 45, 'But what step could\nand ought to be taken he could not imagine': 13, '"What is so exquisite," he thought, as he returned from the\nShtcherbatskys\', carrying away with him, as he always did, a delicious\nfeeling of purity and freshness, arising partly from the fact that he\nhad not been smoking for a whole evening, and with it a new feeling of\ntenderness at her love for him—"what is so exquisite is that not a word\nhas been said by me or by her, but we understand each other so well in\nthis unseen language of looks and tones, that this evening more clearly\nthan ever she told me she loves me': 99, 'And how secretly, simply, and most\nof all, how trustfully': 10, 'I feel myself better, purer': 5, 'I feel that I have\na heart, and that there is a great deal of good in me': 18, 'Those sweet,\nloving eyes': 4, 'When she said: ‘Indeed I do': 6, '\'\n\n"Well, what then': 4, 'Oh, nothing': 2, "It's good for me, and good for her": 8, '" And\nhe began wondering where to finish the evening': 10, 'He passed in review of the places he might go to': 11, '"Club': 1, 'a game of\nbezique, champagne with Ignatov': 7, "No, I'm not going": 4, '_Château des\nFleurs_; there I shall find Oblonsky, songs, the cancan': 11, "No, I'm sick\nof it": 5, "That's why I like the Shtcherbatskys', that I'm growing better": 10, "I'll go home": 3, '" He went straight to his room at Dussots\' Hotel, ordered\nsupper, and then undressed, and as soon as his head touched the pillow,\nfell into a sound sleep': 29, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART ONE', {"Next day at eleven o'clock in the morning Vronsky drove to the station\nof the Petersburg railway to meet his mother, and the first person he\ncame across on the great flight of steps was Oblonsky, who was\nexpecting his sister by the same train": 45, '"Ah': 1, 'your excellency': 2, '" cried Oblonsky, "whom are you meeting': 7, '"\n\n"My mother," Vronsky responded, smiling, as everyone did who met\nOblonsky': 12, 'He shook hands with him, and together they ascended the\nsteps': 11, '"She is to be here from Petersburg today': 8, '"\n\n"I was looking out for you till two o\'clock last night': 12, "Where did you\ngo after the Shtcherbatskys'": 7, '"\n\n"Home," answered Vronsky': 4, '"I must own I felt so well content yesterday\nafter the Shtcherbatskys\' that I didn\'t care to go anywhere': 19, '"\n\n"I know a gallant steed by tokens sure,\n\nAnd by his eyes I know a youth in love,"\n\n\n\ndeclaimed Stepan Arkadyevitch, just as he had done before to Levin': 30, 'Vronsky smiled with a look that seemed to say that he did not deny it,\nbut he promptly changed the subject': 21, '"And whom are you meeting': 5, '" he asked': 3, '"I': 1, 'I\'ve come to meet a pretty woman," said Oblonsky': 9, '"You don\'t say so': 4, '"\n\n"_Honi soit qui mal y pense': 7, '_ My sister Anna': 4, '"\n\n"Ah': 2, 'that\'s Madame Karenina," said Vronsky': 5, '"You know fellow," pursued Oblonsky': 7, '"Isn\'t he': 2, '"\n\n"I don\'t know why it is," responded Vronsky, "in all Moscow\npeople—present company of course excepted," he put in jestingly,\n"there\'s something uncompromising': 24, 'They are all on the defensive, lose\ntheir tempers, as though they all want to make one feel something': 19, '"\n\n"Yes, that\'s true, it is so," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, laughing\ngood-humoredly': 12, '"Will the train soon be in': 6, '" Vronsky asked a railway official': 6, '"The train\'s signaled," answered the man': 6, 'The approach of the train was more and more evident by the preparatory\nbustle in the station, the rush of porters, the movement of policemen\nand attendants, and people meeting the train': 32, 'Through the frosty vapor\ncould be seen workmen in short sheepskins and soft felt boots crossing\nthe rails of the curving line': 22, 'The hiss of the boiler could be heard on\nthe distant rails, and the rumble of something heavy': 18, _belle-sœur_ an offer yesterday': 10, '"\n\n"Maybe," said Stepan Arkadyevitch': 5, '"I fancied something of the sort\nyesterday': 7, 'Yes, if he went away early, and was out of humor too, it\nmust few instants later\nthe platform was quivering, and with puffs of steam hanging low in the\nair from the frost, the engine rolled up, with the lever of the middle\nwheel rhythmically moving up and down, and the stooping figure of the\nengine-driver covered with frost': 47, 'Behind the tender, setting the\nplatform more and more slowly swaying, came the luggage van with a dog\nwhining in it': 21, 'At last the passenger carriages rolled in, oscillating\nbefore coming to a standstill': 13, 'A smart guard jumped out, giving a whistle, and after him one by one\nthe impatient passengers began to get down: an officer of the guards,\nholding himself erect, and looking severely about him; a nimble little\nmerchant with a satchel, smiling gaily; a peasant with a sack over his\nshoulder': 51, 'Vronsky, standing beside Oblonsky, watched the carriages and the\npassengers, totally oblivious of his mother': 15, 'What he had just heard\nabout Kitty excited and delighted him': 11, 'Unconsciously he arched his\nchest, and his eyes flashed': 9, 'He felt himself a conqueror': 5, '"Countess Vronskaya is in that compartment," said the smart guard,\ngoing up to Vronsky': 14, "The guard's words roused him, and forced him to think of his mother and\nhis approaching meeting with her": 19, 'He did not in his heart respect his\nmother, and without acknowledging it to himself, he did not love her,\nthough in accordance with the ideas of the set in which he lived, and\nwith his own education, he could not have conceived of any behavior to\nhis mother not in the highest degree respectful and obedient, and the\nmore externally obedient and respectful his behavior, the less in his\nheart he respected and loved her': 76, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART ONE', {'Vronsky followed the guard to the carriage, and at the door of the\ncompartment he stopped short to make room for a lady who was getting\nout': 27, "With the insight of a man of the world, from one glance at this lady's\nappearance Vronsky classified her as belonging to the best society": 25, 'He\nbegged pardon, and was getting into the carriage, but felt he must\nglance at her once more; not that she was very beautiful, not on\naccount of the elegance and modest grace which were apparent in her\nwhole figure, but because in the expression of her charming face, as\nshe passed close by him, there was something peculiarly caressing and\nsoft': 62, 'As he looked round, she too turned her head': 9, 'Her shining gray\neyes, that looked dark from the thick lashes, rested with friendly\nattention on his face, as though she were recognizing him, and then\npromptly turned away to the passing crowd, as though seeking someone': 37, 'In that brief look Vronsky had time to notice the suppressed eagerness\nwhich played over her face, and flitted between the brilliant eyes and\nthe faint smile that curved her red lips': 32, 'It was as though her nature\nwere so brimming over with something that against her will it showed\nitself now in the flash of her eyes, and now in her smile': 31, 'Deliberately\nshe shrouded the light in her eyes, but it shone against her will in\nthe faintly perceptible smile': 19, 'Vronsky stepped into the carriage': 5, 'His mother, a dried-up old lady with\nblack eyes and ringlets, screwed up her eyes, scanning her son, and\nsmiled slightly with her thin lips': 25, 'Getting up from the seat and\nhanding her maid a bag, she gave her little wrinkled hand to her son to\nkiss, and lifting his head from her hand, ('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART ONE', {'When Anna went into the room, Dolly was sitting in the little\ndrawing-room with a white-headed fat little boy, already like his\nfather, giving him a lesson in French reading': 30, 'As the boy read, he kept\ntwisting and trying to tear off a button that was nearly off his\njacket': 20, 'His mother had several times taken his hand from it, but the\nfat little hand went back to the button again': 21, 'His mother pulled the\nbutton off and put it in her pocket': 12, '"Keep your hands still, Grisha," she said, and she took up her work, a\ncoverlet she had long been making': 20, 'She always set to work on it at\ndepressed moments, and now she knitted at it nervously, twitching her\nfingers and counting the stitches': 24, 'Though she had sent word the day\nbefore to her husband that it was nothing to her whether his sister\ncame or not, she had made everything ready for her arrival, and was\nexpecting her sister-in-law with emotion': 38, 'Dolly was crushed by her sorrow, utterly swallowed up by it': 11, 'Still she\ndid not forget that Anna, her sister-in-law, was the wife of one of the\nmost important personages in Petersburg, and was a Petersburg _grande\ndame_': 27, 'And, thanks to this circumstance, she did not carry out her\nthreat to her husband—that is to say, she remembered that her\nsister-in-law was coming': 25, '"And, after all, Anna is in no wise to\nblame," thought Dolly': 12, '"I know nothing of her except the very best, and\nI have seen nothing but kindness and affection from her towards\nmyself': 22, '" It was true that as far as she could recall her impressions at\nPetersburg at the Karenins\', she did not like their household itself;\nthere was something artificial in the whole framework of their family\nlife': 37, '"But why should I not receive her': 7, "If only she doesn't take it\ninto her head to console me": 12, '" thought Dolly': 3, '"All consolation and\ncounsel and Christian forgiveness, all that I have thought over a\nthousand times, and it\'s all no use': 21, '"\n\nAll these days Dolly had been alone with her children': 11, 'She did not want\nto talk of her sorrow, but with that sorrow in her heart she could not\ntalk of outside matters': 23, 'She knew that in one way or another she would\ntell Anna everything, and she was alternately glad at the thought of\nspeaking freely, and angry at the necessity of speaking of her\nhumiliation with her, his sister, and of hearing her ready-made phrases\nof good advice and comfort': 49, 'She had been on the lookout for her,\nglancing at her watch every minute, and, as so often happens, let slip\njust that minute when her visitor arrived, so that she did not hear the\nbell': 36, 'Catching a sound of skirts and light steps at the door, she looked\nround, and her care-worn face unconsciously expressed not gladness, but\nwonder': 24, 'She got up and embraced her sister-in-law': 7, '"What, here already': 3, '" she said as she kissed her': 7, '"Dolly, how glad I am to see you': 8, '"\n\n"I am glad, too," said Dolly, faintly smiling, and trying by the\nexpression of Anna\'s face to find out whether she knew': 23, '"Most likely\nshe knows," she thought, noticing the sympathy in Anna\'s face': 12, '"Well,\ncome along, I\'ll take you to your room," she went on, trying to defer\nas long as possible the moment of confidences': 23, '"Is this Grisha': 3, "Heavens, how he's grown": 4, '" said Anna; and kissing him,\nnever taking her eyes off Dolly, she stood still and flushed a little': 19, '"No, please, let us stay here': 6, '"\n\nShe took off her kerchief and her hat, and catching it in a lock of her\nblack hair, which was a mass of curls, she tossed her head and shook\nher hair down': 34, '"You are radiant with health and happiness': 7, '" said Dolly, almost with\nenvy': 6, '"I': 1, 'Yes," said Anna': 3, '"Merciful heavens, Tanya': 3, 'You\'re the same age\nas my Seryozha," she speak for him to you, nor to\ntry to comfort you; that\'s impossible': 21, "But, darling, I'm simply sorry,\nsorry from my heart for you": 11, '"\n\nUnder the thick lashes of her shining eyes tears 'She said:\n\n"To comfort me\'s impossible': 6, "Everything's lost after what has happened,\neverything's over": 8, '"\n\nAnd directly she had said this, her face suddenly softened': 11, 'Anna lifted\nthe wasted, thin hand of Dolly, kissed it and said:\n\n"But, Dolly, what\'s to be done, what\'s to be done': 22, "How is it best to\nact in this awful position—that's what you must think of": 15, '"\n\n"All\'s over, and there\'s nothing more," said Dolly': 9, '"And the worst of\nall is, you see, that I can\'t cast him off: there are the children, I\nam tied': 21, "And I can't live with and love unfeigned were visible on Anna's face": 9, '"Very well," she said all at once': 7, '"But I will tell you it from the\nbeginning': 9, 'You know how I was married': 6, 'With the education mamma gave us\nI was more than innocent, I was stupid': 14, 'I knew nothing': 3, 'I know they say\nmen tell their wives of their former lives, but Stiva"—she corrected\nherself—"Stepan Arkadyevitch told me nothing': 20, "You'll hardly believe it,\nbut till now I imagined that I was the only woman he had known": 18, 'So I\nlived eight years': 5, 'You must understand that I was so far from\nsuspecting infidelity, I regarded it as impossible, and then—try to\nimagine it—with such ideas, to find out suddenly all the horror, all\nthe loathsomeness': 33, 'You must try and understand me': 6, "To be fully\nconvinced of one's happiness, and all at once": 11, '" continued Dolly,\nholding back her sobs, "to get a letter': 11, 'his letter to his mistress,\nmy governess': 7, "No, it's too awful": 4, '" She hastily pulled out her\nhandkerchief and hid her face in it': 13, '"I can understand being carried\naway by feeling," she went on after a brief silence, "but deliberately,\nslyly deceiving me': 20, 'and with whom': 3, 'To go on being my husband\ntogether with her': 9, "it's awful": 2, "You can't understand": 3, '"\n\n"Oh, yes, I understand': 5, 'I understand': 2, 'Dolly, dearest, I do '"\n\n"Oh, no': 3, '" Anna interposed quickly': 4, '"He\'s to be pitied, he\'s weighed\ndown by remorse': 9, '"\n\n"Is he capable of remorse': 6, '" Dolly interrupted, gazing intently into ('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART ONE', {"The whole of that day Anna spent at home, that's to say at the\nOblonskys', and received no one, though some of her acquaintances had\nalready heard of her arrival, and came to call the same day": 37, 'Anna spent\nthe whole morning with Dolly and the children': 10, 'She merely sent a brief\nnote to her brother to tell him that he must not fail to dine at home': 21, '"Come, God is merciful," she wrote': 6, 'Oblonsky did dine at home: the conversation was general, and his wife,\nspeaking to him, addressed him as "Stiva," as she had not done before': 25, 'In the relations of the husband and wife the same estrangement still\nremained, but there was no talk now of separation, and Stepan\nArkadyevitch saw the possibility of explanation and reconciliation': 31, 'Immediately after dinner Kitty came in': 6, "She knew Anna Arkadyevna, but\nonly very slightly, and she came now to her sister's with some\ntrepidation, at the prospect of meeting this fashionable Petersburg\nlady, whom everyone spoke so highly of": 33, 'But she made a favorable\nimpression on Anna Arkadyevna—she saw that at once': 13, "Anna was\nunmistakably admiring her loveliness and her youth: before Kitty knew\nwhere she was she found herself not merely under Anna's sway, but in\nlove with her, as young girls do fall in love with older and married\nwomen": 40, 'Anna was not like a fashionable lady, nor the mother of a boy of\neight years old': 17, 'In the elasticity of her movements, the freshness and\nthe unflagging eagerness which persisted in her face, and broke out in\nher smile and her glance, she would rather have passed for a girl of\ntwenty, had it not been for a serious and at times mournful look in her\neyes, which struck and attracted Kitty': 56, 'Kitty felt that Anna was\nperfectly simple and was concealing nothing, but that she had another\nhigher world of interests inaccessible to her, complex and poetic': 26, 'After dinner, when Dolly went away to her own room, Anna rose quickly\nand went up to her brother, who was just lighting a cigar': 25, '"Stiva," she said to him, winking gaily, crossing him and glancing\ntowards the door, "go, and God help you': ('TOL CHAPTER 21 PART ONE', {'Dolly came out of her room to the tea of the grown-up people': 13, 'Stepan\nArkadyevitch did not come out': 6, "He must have left his wife's room by the\nother door": 11, can that be': 4, '" said Dolly': 3, '"It\'s early for me to be fetched, and for anyone else it\'s late,"\nobserved Kitty': 15, '"Sure to be someone with papers for me," put in Stepan Arkadyevitch': recognized Vronsky, and a\nstrange feeling of pleasure and at the same time of dread of something\nstirred in her heart': 26, 'He was standing still, not taking off his coat,\npulling something out of why he\nhad come, and why he would not come up': 21, '"He has been at home," she\nthought, "and didn\'t find me, and thought I should be here, but he did\nnot come up because he thought it late, and Anna\'s here': 31, '"\n\nAll of them looked at each other, saying nothing, and began to look at\nAnna\'s album': 17, "There was nothing either exceptional or strange in a man's calling at\nhalf-past nine on a friend to inquire details of a proposed dinner\nparty and not coming in, but it seemed strange to all of them": 37, 'Above\nall, it seemed strange and not right to Anna': 10, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 22 PART ONE', {'The ball was only just beginning as Kitty and her mother walked up the\ngreat staircase, flooded with light, and lined with flowers and footmen\nin powder and red coats': 30, 'From the rooms came a constant, steady hum, as\nfrom a hive, and the rustle of movement; and while on the landing\nbetween trees they gave last touches to their hair and dresses before\nthe mirror, they heard from the ballroom the careful, distinct notes of\nthe fiddles of the orchestra beginning the first waltz': 55, 'A little old\nman in civilian dress, arranging his gray curls before another mirror,\nand diffusing an odor of scent, stumbled against them on the stairs,\nand stood aside, evidently admiring Kitty, whom he did not know': 37, 'A\nbeardless youth, one of those society youths whom the old Prince\nShtcherbatsky called "young bucks," in an exceedingly open waistcoat,\nstraightening his white tie as he went, bowed to them, and after\nrunning by, came back to ask Kitty for a quadrille': 43, 'As the first\nquadrille had already been given to Vronsky, she had to promise this\nyouth the second': 18, 'An officer, buttoning his glove, stood aside in the\ndoorway, and stroking his mustache, admired rosy Kitty': 17, "Although her dress, her coiffure, and all the preparations for the ball\nhad cost Kitty great trouble and consideration, at this moment she\nwalked into the ballroom in her elaborate tulle dress over a pink slip\nas easily and simply as though all the rosettes and lace, all the\nminute details of her attire, had not cost her or her family a moment's\nattention, as though she had been born in that tulle and lace, with her\nhair done up high on her head, and a rose and two leaves on the top of\nit": 95, 'When, just before entering the ballroom, the princess, her mother,\ntried to turn right side out of the ribbon of her sash, Kitty had drawn\nback a little': 28, 'She felt that everything must be right of itself, and\ngraceful, and nothing could need setting straight': 17, "It was one of Kitty's best days": 7, 'Her dress was not uncomfortable\nanywhere; her lace berthe did not droop anywhere; her rosettes were not\ncrushed nor torn off; her pink slippers with high, hollowed-out heels\ndid not pinch, but gladdened her feet; and the thick rolls of fair\nchignon kept up on her head as if they were her own hair': 54, 'All the three\nbuttons buttoned up without tearing on the long glove that covered her\nhand without concealing its lines': 20, 'The black velvet of her locket\nnestled with special softness round her neck': 13, 'That velvet was\ndelicious; at home, looking at her neck in the looking-glass, Kitty had\nfelt that that velvet was speaking': 21, 'About all the rest there might be a\ndoubt, but the velvet was delicious': 14, 'Kitty smiled here too, at the\nball, when she glanced at it in the glass': 15, 'Her bare shoulders and arms\ngave Kitty a sense of chill marble, a feeling she particularly liked': 17, 'Her eyes sparkled, and her rosy lips could not keep from smiling from\nthe consciousness of her own attractiveness': 19, 'She had scarcely entered\nthe ballroom and reached the throng of ladies, all tulle, ribbons,\nlace, and flowers, waiting to be asked to dance—Kitty was never one of\nthat throng—when she was asked for a waltz, and asked by the best\npartner, the first star in the hierarchy of the ballroom, a renowned\ndirector of dances, a married man, handsome and well-built, Yegorushka\nKorsunsky': 64, 'He had only just left the Countess Bonina, with whom he had\ndanced the first half of the waltz, and, scanning his kingdom—that is\nto say, a few couples who had started dancing—he caught sight of Kitty,\nentering, and flew up to her with that peculiar, easy amble which is\nconfined to directors of balls': 55, 'Without even asking her if she cared to\ndance, he put out his arm to encircle her slender waist': 19, 'She looked\nround for someone to give her fan to, and their hostess, smiling to\nher, took it': 18, '"How nice you\'ve come in good time," he said to her, embracing her\nwaist; "such a bad habit to be late': 21, '" Bending her left hand, she laid\nit on his shoulder, and her little feet in their pink slippers began\nswiftly, lightly, and rhythmically moving over the slippery floor in\ntime to the music': 34, '"It\'s a rest to waltz with you," he said to her, as they fell into the\nfirst slow steps of the waltz': 22, '"It\'s exquisite—such lightness,\nprecision': 4, '" He said to her the same thing he said to almost all his\npartners whom he knew well': 19, fairyland': 23, 'And she was not a\ngirl who had gone the stale round of balls till every face in the\nballroom was familiar and tiresome': 24, 'But she was in the middle stage\nbetween these two; she ('TOL CHAPTER 23 PART ONE', {'Vronsky and Kitty waltzed several times round the room': 9, 'After the first\nwaltz Kitty went to her mother, and she had hardly time to say a few\nwords to Countess ('TOL CHAPTER 25 PART ONE', {'"So you see," pursued Nikolay Levin, painfully wrinkling his forehead\nand twitching': 12, 'It was obviously difficult for him to think of what to say and do': 14, '"Here, do you see': 4, '"': 1, 'He pointed to some sort of iron bars, fastened\ntogether with strings, lying in a corner of the room': 19, '"Do you see that': 4, "That's the beginning of a new thing not force\nhimself to listen to what his brother was telling him about the\nassociation': 34, 'He saw that this association was a mere anchor to save him\nfrom self-contempt': 14, 'Nikolay Levin went on talking:\n\n"You know that capital oppresses the laborer': 12, "The laborers with us, the\npeasants, bear all the burden of labor, and are so placed that however\nmuch they work they can't escape from their position of beasts of\nburden": 31, 'All the profits of labor, on which they might improve their\nposition, and gain leisure for themselves, and after that education,\nall the surplus values are taken from them by the capitalists': 32, "And\nsociety's so constituted that the harder they work, the greater the\nprofit of the merchants and landowners, while they stay beasts of\nburden to the end": 27, 'And that state of things must be changed," he\nfinished up, and he looked questioningly at his brother': 18, '"Yes, of course," said Konstantin, looking at the patch of red that had\ncome out on his brother\'s projecting cheekbones': 20, '"And so we\'re founding a locksmiths\' association, where all the\nproduction and profit and the chief instruments of production will ('TOL CHAPTER 26 PART ONE', {'In the morning Konstantin Levin left Moscow, and towards evening he\nreached home': 13, 'On the journey in the train he talked to his neighbors\nabout politics and the new railways, and, just as in Moscow, he was\novercome by a sense of confusion of ideas, dissatisfaction with\nhimself, shame of something or other': 40, 'But when he got out at his own\nstation, when he saw his one-eyed coachman, Ignat, with the collar of\nhis coat turned up; when, in the dim light reflected by the station\nfires, he saw his own sledge, his own horses with their tails tied up,\nin their harness trimmed with rings and tassels; when the coachman\nIgnat, as he put in his luggage, told him the village news, that the\ncontractor had arrived, and that Pava had calved,—he felt that little\nby little the confusion was clearing up, and the shame and\nself-dissatisfaction were passing away': 98, 'He felt this at the mere sight\nof Ignat and the horses; but when he had put on the sheepskin brought\nfor him, had sat down wrapped up in the sledge, and had driven off\npondering on the work that lay before him in the village, and staring\nat the side-horse, that had been his saddle-horse, past his prime now,\nbut a spirited beast from the Don, he began to see what had happened to\nhim in quite a different light': 81, 'He felt himself, and did not want to be\nanyone else': 11, 'All he wanted now was to be better than before': 10, 'In the\nfirst place he resolved that from that day he would give up hoping for\nany extraordinary happiness, such as marriage must have given him, and\nconsequently he would not so disdain what he really had': 37, 'Secondly, he\nwould never again let himself give way to low passion, the memory of\nwhich had so tortured him when he had been making up his mind to make\nan offer': 32, 'Then remembering his brother Nikolay, he resolved to himself\nthat he would never allow himself to forget him, that he would follow\nhim up, and not lose sight of him, so as to be ready to help when\nthings should go ill with him': 44, 'And that would be soon, he felt': 7, "Then,\ntoo, his brother's talk of communism, which he had treated so lightly\nat the time, now made him think": 20, 'He considered a revolution in economic\nconditions nonsense': 8, 'But he always felt the injustice of his own\nabundance in comparison with the poverty of the peasants, and now he\ndetermined that so as to feel quite in the right, though he had worked\nhard and lived by no means luxuriously before, he would now work still\nharder, and would allow himself even less luxury': 56, 'And all this seemed\nto him so easy a conquest over himself that he spent the whole drive in\nthe pleasantest daydreams': 22, "With a resolute feeling of hope in a new,\nbetter life, he reached home before nine o'clock at night": 19, 'The snow of the little quadrangle before the house was lit up by a\nlight in the bedroom windows of his old nurse, Agafea said Agafea Mihalovna': 8, '"I got tired of it, Agafea Mihalovna': 7, 'With friends, one is well; but at\nhome, one is better," he answered, and went into his study': 18, 'The study was slowly lit up as the candle was brought in': 12, "The familiar\ndetails came out: the stag's horns, the bookshelves, the looking-glass,\nthe stove with its ventilator, which had long wanted mending, his\nfather's sofa, a large table, on the table an open book, a broken\nashtray, a manuscript book with his handwriting": 43, 'As he saw all this,\nthere came over him for an instant a doubt of the possibility of\narranging the new life, of which he had been dreaming on the road': 31, 'All\nthese traces of his life seemed to clutch him, and to say to him: "No,\nyou\'re not going to get away from us, and you\'re not going to be\ndifferent, but you\'re going to be the same as you\'ve always been; with\ndoubts, everlasting dissatisfaction with yourself, vain efforts to\namend, and falls, and everlasting expectation, of a happiness which you\nwon\'t get, and which isn\'t possible for you': 70, '"\n\nThis the things said to him, but another voice in his heart was telling\nhim that he must not fall partly invented by Levin': 12, 'The bailiff\nhad always been against the drying machine, and now it was with\nsuppressed triumph that he announced that the buckwheat had been\nscorched': 25, 'Levin was firmly convinced that if the buckwheat had been\nscorched, it was only because the precautions had not been taken, for\nwhich he had hundreds of times given orders': 30, 'He was annoyed, and\nreprimanded the bailiff': 7, 'But there had been an important and joyful\nevent: Pava, his best cow, an expensive beast, bought at a show, had\ncalved': 22, '"Kouzma, give me my sheepskin': 5, ('TOL CHAPTER 27 PART ONE', {'The house was big and old-fashioned, and Levin, though he lived alone,\nhad the whole house heated and used': 19, 'He knew that this was stupid, he\nknew that it was on\nwhich its whole happiness turned': 15, 'And now he had to give up that': 8, 'When he had gone into the little drawing-room, where he always had tea,\nand had settled himself in his armchair with a ('TOL CHAPTER 28 PART ONE', {'After the ball, early next morning, Anna Arkadyevna sent her husband a\ntelegram that she was leaving Moscow the same day': 21, '"No, I must go, I must go"; she explained to her sister-in-law the\nchange in her plans in a tone that suggested that she had to remember\nso many things that there was no enumerating them: "no, it had really\nbetter be today': 43, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch was not dining at home, but he promised to come and\nsee his sister off at seven o\'clock': 21, 'Kitty, too, did not come, sending a note that she had a headache': 13, that day from what she\nhad been when they had taken such a fancy to her, that she was not now\ninterested in them,—but they had abruptly dropped their play with their\naunt, and their love for her, and were quite indifferent that she was\ngoing away': 68, 'Anna was absorbed the whole morning in preparations for her\ndeparture': 11, 'She wrote notes to her Moscow acquaintances, put down her\naccounts, and packed': 13, 'Altogether Dolly fancied she was not in a placid\nstate of mind, but in that worried mood, which Dolly knew well with\nherself, and which does not come without cause, and for the most part\ncovers dissatisfaction with self': 39, 'After dinner, Anna went up to her\nroom to dress, and Dolly followed her': 14, '"How queer you are today': 5, '" Dolly said to her': 5, just because I could never let myself doubt myself\nfor an instant," said Anna': 19, 'But at the very moment she was uttering the words, she felt that they\nwere not true': 17, 'She was not merely will': 5, '"\n\nShe crimsoned and stopped': 5, '"Oh, they feel it directly': 5, '"But I should be in despair if there were anything serious in it on his\nside," Anna interrupted her': 19, '"And I am pleasure came out on her face, when she heard the idea, that\nabsorbed her, put into words': 26, '"And so here I am going away, having made\nan enemy of Kitty, whom I liked so much': 18, 'Ah, how ('TOL CHAPTER 29 PART ONE', {'"Come, it\'s all over, and thank God': 7, '" was the first thought that came\nto Anna Arkadyevna, when she had said good-bye for the last time to her\nbrother, who had stood blocking up the entrance to the carriage till\nthe third bell rang': 37, 'She sat down on her lounge beside Annushka, and\nlooked about her in the twilight of the sleeping-carriage': 18, '"Thank God': 2, 'tomorrow I shall see Seryozha and Alexey Alexandrovitch, and my life\nwill go on in the old way, all nice and as usual': 23, '"\n\nStill in the same anxious frame of mind, as she had been all that day,\nAnna took pleasure in arranging herself for the journey with great\ncare': 28, 'With her little deft hands she opened and shut her little red\nbag, took out a cushion, laid it on her knees, and carefully wrapping\nup her feet, settled herself comfortably': 31, 'An invalid lady had already\nlain down to sleep': 9, 'Two other ladies began talking to Anna, and a stout\nelderly lady tucked up her feet, and made observations about the\nheating of the train': 25, 'Anna answered a few words, but not foreseeing any\nentertainment from the conversation, she asked Annushka to get a lamp,\nhooked it onto the arm of her seat, and took from her bag a paper-knife\nand an English novel': 39, 'At first her reading made no progress': 7, 'The fuss\nand bustle were disturbing; then when the train had started, she could\nnot help listening to the noises; then the snow beating on the left\nwindow and sticking to the pane, and the sight of the muffled guard\npassing by, covered with snow on one side, and the conversations about\nthe terrible snowstorm raging outside, distracted her attention': 60, 'Farther on, it was continually the same again and again: the same\nshaking and rattling, the same snow on the window, the same rapid\ntransitions from steaming heat to cold, and back again to heat, the\nsame passing glimpses of the same figures in the twilight, and the same\nvoices, and Anna began to read and to understand what she read': 61, 'Annushka was already dozing, the red bag on her lap, clutched by her\nbroad hands, in gloves, of which one was torn': 22, "Anna Arkadyevna read and\nunderstood, but it was distasteful to her to read, that is, to follow\nthe reflection of other people's lives": 23, 'She had too great a desire to\nlive herself': 9, 'If she read that the heroine of the novel was nursing a\nsick man, she longed to move with noiseless steps about the room of a\nsick man; if she read of a member of Parliament making a speech, she\nlonged to be delivering the speech; if she read of how Lady Mary had\nridden after the hounds, and had provoked her sister-in-law, and had\nsurprised everyone by her boldness, she too wished to be doing the\nsame': 78, 'But there was no chance of doing anything; and twisting the\nsmooth paper-knife in her little hands, she forced herself to read': 22, 'The hero of the novel was already almost reaching his English\nhappiness, a baronetcy and an estate, and Anna was feeling a desire to\ngo with him to the estate, when she suddenly felt that _he_ ought to\nfeel ashamed, and that she was ashamed of the same thing': 49, 'But what had\nhe to be ashamed of': 8, '"What have I to be ashamed of': 7, '" she asked herself\nin injured surprise': 7, 'She laid down the book and sank against the back\nof the chair, tightly gripping the paper-cutter in both hands': 20, 'There\nwas nothing': 3, 'She went over all her Moscow recollections': 7, 'All were good,\npleasant': 4, 'She remembered the ball, remembered Vronsky and his face of\nslavish adoration, remembered all her conduct with him: there was\nnothing shameful': 22, 'And for all that, at the same point in her memories,\nthe feeling of shame was intensified, as though some inner voice, just\nat the point when she thought of Vronsky, were saying to her, "Warm,\nvery warm, hot': 39, '" "Well, what is it': 5, '" she said to herself resolutely,\nshifting her seat in the lounge': 12, '"What does it mean': 4, 'Am I afraid to\nlook it straight in the face': 10, 'Why, what is it': 4, 'Can it be that between\nme and this officer boy there exist, or can exist, any other relations\nthan such as are common with every acquaintance': 26, '" She laughed\ncontemptuously and took up her book again; but now she was definitely\nunable to follow what she read': 21, 'She passed the paper-knife over the\nwindow pane, then laid its smooth, cool surface to her cheek, and\nalmost laughed aloud at the feeling of delight that all at once without\ncause came over her': 35, 'She felt as though her nerves were strings being\nstrained tighter and tighter on some sort of screwing peg': 19, 'She felt her\neyes opening wider and wider, her fingers and toes twitching nervously,\nsomething within oppressing her breathing, while all shapes and sounds\nseemed in the uncertain half-light to strike her with unaccustomed\nvividness': 35, 'Moments of doubt were continually coming upon her, when she\nwas uncertain whether the train were going forwards or backwards, or\nwere standing still altogether; whether it were Annushka at her side or\na stranger': 35, '"What\'s that on the arm of the chair, a fur cloak or some\nbeast': 14, 'And what am I myself': 5, 'Myself or some other woman': 5, '" She was\nafraid of giving way to this delirium': 10, 'But something drew her towards\nit, and she could yield to it or resist it at will': 17, 'She got up to rouse\nherself, and slipped off her plaid and the cape of her warm dress': 18, 'For\na moment she regained her self-possession, and realized that the thin\npeasant who had come in wearing a long overcoat, with buttons missing\nfrom it, was the stoveheater, that he was looking at the thermometer,\nthat it was the wind and snow bursting in after him at the door; but\nthen everything grew blurred again': 56, 'That peasant with the long waist\nseemed to be gnawing something on the wall, the old lady began\nstretching her legs the whole length of the carriage, and filling it\nwith a black cloud; then there was a fearful shrieking and banging, as\nthough someone were being torn to pieces; then there was a blinding\ndazzle of red fire before her eyes and a wall seemed to rise up and\nhide everything': 72, 'Anna felt as though she were sinking down': 8, 'But it was\nnot terrible, but delightful': 7, 'The voice of a man muffled up and covered\nwith snow shouted something in her ear': 16, 'She got up and pulled herself\ntogether; ('TOL CHAPTER 31 PART ONE', {'Vronsky had not even tried to sleep all that night': 10, 'He sat in his\narmchair, looking straight before him or scanning the people who got in\nand out': 18, 'If he had indeed on previous occasions struck and impressed\npeople who did not know him by his air of unhesitating composure, he\nseemed now more haughty and self-possessed than ever': 31, 'He looked at\npeople as if they were things': 9, 'A nervous young man, a clerk in a law\ncourt, sitting opposite him, hated him for that look': 18, 'The young man\nasked him for a light, and entered into conversation with him, and even\npushed against him, to make him feel that he was not a thing, but a\nperson': 32, 'But Vronsky gazed at him exactly as he did at the lamp, and the\nyoung man made a because he\nbelieved that he had made an impression on Anna—he did not yet believe\nthat,—but because the impression she had made on him gave him happiness\nand pride': 35, 'What would come of it all he did not know, he did not even think': 15, 'He\nfelt that all his forces, hitherto dissipated, wasted, were centered on\none thing, and bent with fearful energy on one blissful goal': 23, 'And journey, and\nher excitement, too, had completely vanished': 19, 'In the habitual\nconditions of her life she felt again resolute and irreproachable': 13, 'She recalled with wonder her state of mind on the previous day': 12, '"What\nwas it': 3, 'Nothing': 1, 'Vronsky said something silly, which it was easy to put\na stop to, and I answered as I ought to have done': 22, 'To speak of it to my\nhusband would be unnecessary and out of the question': 15, 'To speak of it\nwould be to attach importance to what has no importance': 14, '" She\nremembered how she had told her husband of what was almost a\ndeclaration made her at Petersburg by a young man, one of her husband\'s\nsubordinates, and how Alexey Alexandrovitch had answered that every\nwoman living in the world was exposed to such incidents, but that he\nhad the fullest confidence in her tact, and could never lower her and\nhimself by jealousy': 65, '"So then there\'s no reason to speak of it': 9, 'And\nindeed, thank God, ('TOL CHAPTER 33 PART ONE', {"Alexey Alexandrovitch came back from the meeting of the ministers at\nfour o'clock, but as often happened, he had not time to come in to her": 26, 'He went into his study to see the people waiting for him with\npetitions, and to sign some papers brought him by his chief secretary': 25, 'At dinner time (there were always a few people dining with the\nKarenins) there 'Anna\nwent into the drawing-room to receive these guests': 9, "Precisely at five\no'clock, before the bronze Peter the First clock had struck the fifth\nstroke, Alexey Alexandrovitch came in, wearing a white tie and evening\ncoat with two stars, as he had to go out directly after dinner": 39, "Every\nminute of Alexey Alexandrovitch's life was portioned out and occupied": 11, 'And to make time to get through all that lay before him every day, he\nadhered to the strictest punctuality': 20, '"Unhasting and unresting," was\nhis motto': 6, 'He came into the dining hall, greeted everyone, and\nhurriedly sat down, smiling to his wife': 16, '"Yes, my solitude is over': 5, 'You wouldn\'t believe how uncomfortable" (he\nlaid stress on the word _uncomfortable_) "it is to dine alone': 17, '"\n\nAt dinner he talked a little to his wife about Moscow matters, and,\nwith a sarcastic smile, asked her after Stepan Arkadyevitch; but the\nconversation was for the most part general, dealing with Petersburg\nofficial and public news': 39, "After dinner he spent half an hour with his\nguests, and again, with a smile, pressed his wife's hand, withdrew, and\ndrove off to the council": 26, 'Anna did not go out that evening either to\nthe Princess Betsy Tverskaya, who, hearing of her return, had invited\nher, nor to the theater, where she had a box for that evening': 33, 'She did\nnot go out principally because the dress she had reckoned upon was not\nready': 16, 'Altogether, Anna, on turning, after the departure of her guests,\nto the consideration of her attire, was very much annoyed': 20, 'She was\ngenerally a mistress of the art of dressing well without great expense,\nand before leaving Moscow she had given her dressmaker three dresses to\ntransform': 27, 'The dresses had to be altered so that they could not be\nrecognized, and they ought to have been ready three days before': 23, 'It\nappeared that two dresses had not been done at all, while the other one\nhad not been altered as Anna had intended': 23, 'The dressmaker came to\nexplain, declaring that it would be better as she had done it, and Anna\nwas so furious that she felt ashamed when she thought of it afterwards': 31, 'To regain her serenity completely she went into the nursery, and spent\nthe whole evening with her son, put him to bed herself, signed him with\nthe cross, and tucked him up': 32, 'She was glad she had not gone out\nanywhere, and had spent the evening so well': 16, 'She felt so light-hearted\nand serene, she saw so clearly that all that had seemed to her so\nimportant on her railway journey was only one of the common trivial\nincidents of fashionable life, and that she had no reason to feel\nashamed before anyone else or before herself': 49, 'Anna sat down at the\nhearth with an English novel and waited for her husband': 15, 'Exactly at\nhalf-past nine she heard his ring, and he came into the room': 14, '"Here you are at last': 5, '" she observed, holding out her hand to him': 9, 'He kissed her hand and sat down beside her': 9, '"Altogether then, I see your visit was a success," he said to her': 13, '"Oh, yes," she said, and she began telling him about everything ('TOL CHAPTER 34 PART ONE', {'When Vronsky went to Moscow from Petersburg, he had left his large set\nof rooms in Morskaia to his friend and favorite comrade Petritsky': 24, 'Petritsky was a young lieutenant, not particularly well-connected, and\nnot merely not wealthy, but always hopelessly in debt': 18, 'Towards evening\nhe was always drunk, and he had often been locked up after all sorts believe that one husband ought to live with the\none wife whom he has lawfully married; that a girl should be innocent,\na woman modest, and a man manly, self-controlled, and strong; that one\nought and\nboiled away, doing just what was required of it—that is, providing much\ncause for much noise and laughter, and spoiling a costly rug and the\nbaroness's gown": 38, '"Well now, good-bye, or ('TOL CHAPTER 1 PART TWO', {"At the end of the winter, in the Shtcherbatskys' house, a consultation\nwas being held, which was to pronounce on the state of Kitty's health\nand the measures to be taken to restore her failing strength": 36, 'She had\nbeen ill, and as spring came on she grew worse': 12, 'The family doctor gave\nher cod liver oil, then iron, then nitrate of silver, but as the first\nand the second and the third were alike in doing no good, and as his\nadvice when spring came was to go abroad, a celebrated physician was\ncalled in': 47, 'The celebrated physician, a very handsome man, still\nyoungish, asked to examine the patient': 14, 'He maintained, with peculiar\nsatisfaction, it seemed, that maiden modesty is a mere relic of\nbarbarism, and that nothing could be more natural than for a man still\nyoungish to handle a young girl naked': 35, 'He thought it natural because he\ndid it every day, and felt and thought, as it seemed to him, no harm as\nhe did it and consequently he considered modesty in the girl not merely\nas a relic of barbarism, but also as an insult to himself': 47, "There was nothing for it but to submit, since, although all the doctors\nhad studied in the same school, had read the same books, and learned\nthe same science, and though some people said this celebrated doctor\nwas a bad doctor, in the princess's household and circle it was for\nsome reason accepted that this celebrated doctor alone had some special\nknowledge, and that he alone could save Kitty": 69, 'After a careful\nexamination and sounding of the bewildered patient, dazed with shame,\nthe celebrated doctor, having scrupulously washed his hands, was\nstanding in the drawing-room talking to the prince': 30, 'The prince frowned\nand coughed, listening to the doctor': 9, "As a man who had seen something\nof life, and neither a fool nor an invalid, he had no faith in\nmedicine, and in his heart was furious at the whole farce, specially as\nhe was perhaps the only one who fully comprehended the cause of Kitty's\nillness": 48, '"Conceited blockhead': 2, '" he thought, as he listened to the\ncelebrated doctor\'s chatter about his daughter\'s symptoms': 15, 'The doctor\nwas meantime with difficulty restraining the expression of his contempt\nfor this old gentleman, and with difficulty condescending to the level\nof his intelligence': 26, 'He perceived that it was no good talking to the\nold man, and that the principal person in the house was the mother': 23, 'Before her he decided to scatter his pearls': 8, 'At that instant the\nprincess came into the drawing-room with the family doctor': 13, 'The prince\nwithdrew, trying not to show how ridiculous he thought the whole\nperformance': 14, 'The princess was distracted, and did not know what to do': 11, 'She felt she had sinned against Kitty': 7, '"Well, doctor, decide our fate," said the princess': 8, '"Tell me\neverything': 3, '"\n\n"Is there hope': 4, '" she meant to say, but her lips quivered, and she could\nnot utter the question': 16, '"Well, doctor': 2, '"\n\n"Immediately, princess': 3, 'I will talk it over with my colleague, and then\nI will have the honor of laying my opinion before you': 21, '"\n\n"So we had better leave you': 7, '"\n\n"As you please': 4, '"\n\nThe princess went out with a sigh': 8, 'When the doctors were left alone, the family doctor began timidly\nexplaining his opinion, that there was a commencement of tuberculous\ntrouble, but': 23, 'and so on': 3, 'The celebrated doctor listened to him, and\nin the middle of his sentence looked at his big gold watch': 19, '"Yes," said he': 3, '"But': 1, '"\n\nThe family doctor respectfully ceased in the middle of his\nobservations': 12, '"The commencement of the tuberculous process we are not, as you are\naware, able to define; till there are cavities, there is nothing\ndefinite': 24, 'But we may suspect it': 5, 'And there are indications;\nmalnutrition, nervous excitability, and so on': 10, 'The question stands\nthus: in presence of indications of tuberculous process, what is to be\ndone to maintain nutrition': 19, '"\n\n"But, you know, there are always moral, spiritual causes at the back in\nthese cases," the family doctor permitted himself to interpolate with a\nsubtle smile': 27, '"Yes, that\'s an understood thing," responded the celebrated physician,\nagain glancing at his watch': 14, '"Beg pardon, is the Yausky bridge done\nyet, or shall I have to drive around': 15, '" he asked': 3, '"Ah': 1, 'it is': 2, 'Oh, well,\nthen I can do it in twenty minutes': 10, 'So we were saying the problem may\nbe put thus: to maintain nutrition and to give tone to the nerves': 20, 'The\none is in close connection with the other, one must attack both sides\nat once': 16, '"\n\n"And how about a tour abroad': 7, '" asked the family doctor': 5, '"I\'ve no liking for foreign tours': 6, 'And take note: if there is an early\nstage of tuberculous process, of which we cannot be certain, a foreign\ntour will be of no use': 26, 'What is wanted is means of improving nutrition,\nand not for lowering it': 13, '" And the celebrated doctor expounded his plan\nof treatment with Soden waters, a remedy obviously prescribed primarily\non the ground that they could do no harm': 27, 'The family doctor listened attentively and respectfully': 7, '"But in favor of foreign travel I would urge the change of habits, the\nremoval from conditions calling up reminiscences': 20, 'And then the mother\nwishes it," he added': 8, 'Well, in that case, to be sure, let them go': 10, 'Only, those German\nquacks are mischievous': 6, 'They ought to be persuaded': 5, 'Well, let\nthem go then': 5, '"\n\nHe glanced once more at his watch': 8, '"Oh': 1, 'time\'s up already," And he went to the door': 9, 'The celebrated doctor\nannounced to the princess (a feeling of what was due from him dictated\nhis doing so) that he ought to see the patient once more': 28, '"What': 1, 'another examination': 2, '" cried the mother, with horror': 6, '"Oh, no, only a few details, princess': 7, '"\n\n"Come this way': 4, '"\n\nAnd the mother, accompanied by the doctor, went into the drawing-room\nto Kitty': 14, 'Wasted and flushed, with a peculiar glitter in her eyes, left\nthere by the agony of shame she had been put through, Kitty stood in\nthe middle of the room': 30, 'When the doctor came in she flushed crimson,\nand her eyes filled with tears': 14, 'All her illness and treatment struck\nher as a thing so stupid, ludicrous even': 14, 'Doctoring her seemed to her\nas absurd as putting together the pieces of a broken vase': 16, 'Her heart\nwas broken': 4, 'Why would they try to cure her with pills and powders': 11, 'But\nshe could not grieve her mother, especially as her mother considered\nherself to blame': 15, '"May I trouble you to sit down, princess': 8, '" the celebrated doctor said\nto her': 7, 'He sat down with a smile, facing her, felt her pulse, and again began\nasking her tiresome questions': 18, 'She answered him, and all at once got\nup, furious': 10, '"Excuse me, doctor, but there is really no object in this': 11, "This is the\nthird time you've asked me the same thing": 11, '"\n\nThe celebrated doctor did not take offense': 8, '"Nervous irritability," he said to the princess, when Kitty had left\nthe room': 13, '"However, I had finished': 4, '"\n\nAnd the doctor began scientifically explaining to the princess, as an\nexceptionally intelligent woman, the condition of the young princess,\nand concluded by insisting on the drinking of the waters, which were\ncertainly harmless': 35, 'At the question: Should they go abroad': 7, 'the doctor\nplunged into deep meditation, as though resolving a weighty problem': 12, 'Finally his decision was pronounced: they were to go abroad, but to put\nno faith in foreign quacks, and to apply to him in any need': 26, 'It seemed as though some piece of good fortune had come to pass after\nthe doctor had gone': 18, 'The mother was much more cheerful when she went\nback to her daughter, and Kitty pretended to be more cheerful': 20, 'She had\noften, almost always, to be pretending now': 9, '"Really, I\'m quite well, mamma': 5, "But if you want to go abroad, let's\ngo": 9, '" she said, and trying to appear interested in the proposed tour,\nshe began talking of the preparations for the journey': 21, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART TWO', {'Soon after the doctor, Dolly had arrived': 7, "She knew that there was to be\na consultation that day, and though she was only just up after her\nconfinement (she had another baby, a little girl, born at the end of\nthe winter), though she had trouble and anxiety enough of her own, she\nhad left her tiny baby and a sick child, to come and hear Kitty's fate,\nwhich was to be decided that day": 68, '"Well, well': 2, '" she said, coming into the drawing-room, without taking\noff her hat': 12, '"You\'re all in good spirits': 5, 'Good news, then': 3, '"\n\nThey tried to tell her what the doctor had said, but it appeared that\nthough the doctor had talked distinctly enough and at great length, it\nwas utterly impossible to report what he had said': 36, 'The only point of\ninterest was that it was settled they should go abroad': 14, 'Dolly could not help sighing': 5, 'Her dearest friend, her sister, was going\naway': 8, 'And her life was not a cheerful one': 8, 'Her relations with Stepan\nArkadyevitch after their reconciliation had become humiliating': 11, 'The\nunion Anna had cemented turned out to be of no solid character, and\nfamily harmony was breaking down again at the same point': 24, 'There had\nbeen nothing definite, but Stepan Arkadyevitch was hardly ever at home;\nmoney, too, was hardly ever forthcoming, and Dolly was continually\ntortured by suspicions of infidelity, which she tried to dismiss,\ndreading the agonies of jealousy she had been through already': 43, 'The\nfirst onslaught of jealousy, once lived through, could never come back\nagain, and even the discovery of infidelities could never now affect\nher as it had the first time': 30, 'Such a discovery now would only mean\nbreaking up family habits, and she let herself be deceived, despising\nhim and still more herself, for the weakness': 26, 'Besides this, the care of\nher large family was a constant worry to her: first, the nursing of her\nyoung baby did not go well, then the nurse had gone away, now one of\nthe children had fallen ill': 39, '"Well, how are all of you': 6, '" asked her mother': 4, '"Ah, mamma, we have plenty of troubles of our own': 10, "Lili is ill, and I'm\nafraid it's scarlatina": 8, 'I have come here now to hear about Kitty, and\nthen I shall shut myself up entirely, if—God forbid—it should be\nscarlatina': 22, '"\n\nThe old prince too had come in from his study after the doctor\'s\ndeparture, and after presenting his cheek to Dolly, and saying a few\nwords to her, he turned to his wife:\n\n"How have you settled it': 39, "you're going": 2, 'Well, and what do you mean to\ndo with me': 10, '"\n\n"I suppose you had better stay here, Alexander," said his wife': 12, '"That\'s as you lifted her head and\nlooked at him with a forced smile': 12, 'It always seemed to her that he\nunderstood her better than anyone in the family, though he did not say\nmuch about her': 23, "Being the youngest, she was her father's favorite, and\nshe fancied that his love gave him insight": 17, 'When now her glance met his\nblue kindly eyes looking intently at her, it seemed to her that he saw\nright through her, and understood all that was not good that was\npassing within her': 35, 'Reddening, she stretched out towards him expecting\na kiss, but he only patted her hair and your young buck about, hey': 14, '"\n\n"Nothing, father," answered Dolly, understanding that her husband was\nmeant': 11, '"He\'s always out; I scarcely ever see him," she could not resist\nadding ('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART TWO', {"When she went into Kitty's little room, a pretty, pink little room,\nfull of knick-knacks in _vieux saxe,_ as fresh, and pink, and white,\nand gay as Kitty herself had been two months ago, Dolly remembered how\nthey had decorated the room the year before together, with what love\nand gaiety": 51, 'Her heart turned cold when she saw Kitty sitting on a low\nchair near the door, her eyes fixed immovably on a corner of the rug': 26, 'Kitty glanced at her sister, and the cold, rather ill-tempered\nexpression of her face did not change': 17, '"I\'m just going now, and I shall have to keep in and you won\'t be able\nto come to see me," said Dolly, sitting down beside her': 27, '"I want to\ntalk to you': 6, '"\n\n"What about': 3, '" Kitty asked swiftly, lifting her head in dismay': 9, '"What should it be, but your trouble': 7, '"\n\n"I have no trouble': 5, '"\n\n"Nonsense, Kitty': 3, 'Do you suppose I could help knowing': 7, 'I know all about\nit': 5, "And believe me, it's of so little consequence": 8, "We've all been\nthrough it": 5, '"\n\nKitty did not speak, and her face had a stern expression': 12, '"He\'s not worth your grieving over him," pursued Darya Alexandrovna,\ncoming straight to the point': 15, '"No, because he has treated me with contempt," said Kitty, in a\nbreaking voice': 14, '"Don\'t talk of it': 4, "Please, don't talk of it": 5, '"\n\n"But who can have told you so': 8, 'No one has said that': 5, "I'm certain he was\nin love with you, and would still be in love with you, if it\nhadn't": 19, '"\n\n"Oh, the most awful thing of all for me is this sympathizing': 13, '" shrieked\nKitty, suddenly flying into a passion': 8, 'She turned round on her chair,\nflushed crimson, and rapidly moving her fingers, pinched the clasp of\nher belt first with one hand and then with the other': 28, 'Dolly knew this\ntrick her sister had of clenching her hands when she was much excited;\nshe knew, too, that in moments of excitement would I do as you're doing—go back to a man who's\ndeceived you, who has cared for another woman": 35, "I can't understand it": 4, "You may, but I can't": 5, '"\n\nAnd saying these words she glanced at her sister, and seeing that Dolly\nsat silent, her head mournfully bowed, Kitty, instead of running out of\nthe room as she had meant to do, sat down near the door, and hid her\nface in her handkerchief': 46, 'The silence lasted for two minutes: Dolly was thinking of herself': 11, 'That\nhumiliation of which she was always conscious came back to her with a\npeculiar bitterness when her face covered with tears hid itself in Darya Alexandrovna's skirt": 13, 'As though tears were the indispensable oil, without which the machinery\nof mutual confidence could not run smoothly between the
