('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART TWO', {'The highest Petersburg society is essentially one: in it everyone knows\neveryone else, everyone even visits everyone else': 18, 'But this great set\nhas its subdivisions': 7, 'Anna Arkadyevna Karenina had friends and close\nties in three different circles of this highest society': 16, "One circle was\nher husband's government official set, consisting of his colleagues and\nsubordinates, brought together in the most various and capricious\nmanner, and belonging to different social strata": 29, 'Anna found it\ndifficult now to recall the feeling of almost awe-stricken reverence\nwhich she had at first entertained for these persons': 22, 'Now she knew all\nof them as people know one another in a country town; she knew their\nhabits and weaknesses, and where the shoe pinched each one of them': 30, 'She\nknew their relations with one another and with the head authorities,\nknew who was for whom, and how each one maintained his position, and\nwhere they agreed and disagreed': 30, "But the circle of political, masculine\ninterests had never interested her, in spite of countess Lidia\nIvanovna's influence, and she avoided it": 22, 'Another little set with which Anna was in close relations was the one\nby means of which Alexey Alexandrovitch had made his career': 23, 'The center\nof this circle was the Countess Lidia Ivanovna': 10, 'It was a set made up of\nelderly, ugly, benevolent, and godly women, and clever, learned, and\nambitious men': 19, 'One of the clever people belonging to the set had called\nit "the conscience of Petersburg society': 17, '" Alexey Alexandrovitch had\nthe highest esteem for this circle, and Anna with her special gift for\ngetting on with everyone, had in the early days of her life in\nPetersburg made friends in this circle also': 37, 'Now, since her return from\nMoscow, she had come to feel this set insufferable': 14, 'It seemed to her\nthat both she and all of them were insincere, and she felt so bored and\nill at ease in that world that she went to see the Countess Lidia\nIvanovna as little as possible': 38, 'The third circle with which Anna had ties was preeminently the\nfashionable world—the world of balls, of dinners, of sumptuous dresses,\nthe world that hung on to the court with one hand, so as to avoid\nsinking to the level of the demi-monde': 43, 'For the demi-monde the members\nof that fashionable world believed that they despised, though their\ntastes were not merely similar, but in fact identical': 24, "Her connection\nwith this circle was kept up through Princess Betsy Tverskaya, her\ncousin's wife, who had an income of a hundred and twenty thousand\nroubles, and who had taken a great fancy to Anna ever since she first\ncame out, showed her much attention, and drew her into her set, making\nfun of Countess Lidia Ivanovna's coterie": 58, '"When I\'m old and ugly I\'ll be the same," Betsy used to say; "but for a\npretty young woman like you it\'s early days for that house of charity': 29, '"\n\nAnna had at first avoided as far as she could Princess Tverskaya\'s\nworld, because it necessitated an expenditure beyond her means, and\nbesides in her heart she preferred the first circle': 32, 'But since her\nvisit to Moscow she had done quite the contrary': 12, 'She avoided her\nserious-minded friends, and went out into the fashionable world': 12, 'There\nshe met Vronsky, and experienced an agitating joy at those meetings': 12, "She met Vronsky specially often at Betsy's for Betsy was a Vronsky by\nbirth and his cousin": 17, 'Vronsky was everywhere where he had any chance of\nmeeting Anna, and speaking to her, when he could, of his love': 21, 'She gave\nhim no encouragement, but every time she met him there surged up in her\nheart that same feeling of quickened life that had come upon her that\nday in the railway carriage when she saw him for the first time': 42, 'She\nwas conscious herself that her delight sparkled in her eyes and curved\nher lips into a smile, and she could not quench the expression of this\ndelight': 28, 'At first Anna sincerely believed that she was displeased with him for\ndaring to pursue her': 16, 'Soon after her return from Moscow, on arriving at\na _soirée_ where she had expected to meet him, and not finding him\nthere, she realized distinctly from the rush of disappointment that she\nhad been deceiving herself, and that this pursuit was not merely not\ndistasteful to her, but that it made the whole interest of her life': 58, 'The celebrated singer was singing for the second time, and all the\nfashionable world was in the theater': 18, "Vronsky, seeing his cousin from\nhis stall in the front row, did not wait till the _entr'acte_, but went\nto her box": 22, '"Why didn\'t you come to dinner': 6, '" she said to him': 5, '"I marvel at the\nsecond sight of lovers," she added with a smile, so that no one but he\ncould hear; "_she wasn\'t there_': 24, 'But come after the opera': 5, '"\n\nVronsky looked inquiringly at her': 6, 'She nodded': 2, 'He thanked her by a\nsmile, and sat down beside her': 11, '"But how I remember your jeers': 6, '" continued Princess Betsy, who took a\npeculiar pleasure in following up this passion to a successful issue': 18, '"What\'s become of all that': 5, "You're caught, my dear boy": 5, '"\n\n"That\'s my one desire, to be caught," answered Vronsky, with his\nserene, good-humored smile': 15, '"If I complain of anything it\'s only that\nI\'m not caught enough, to tell the truth': 16, 'I begin to lose hope': 5, '"\n\n"Why, whatever hope can you have': 7, '" said Betsy, offended on behalf of\nher friend': 9, '"_Entendons nous': 2, '_" But in her eyes there were gleams of\nlight that betrayed that she understood perfectly and precisely as he\ndid what hope he might have': 26, '"None whatever," said Vronsky, laughing and showing his even rows of\nteeth': 12, '"Excuse me," he added, taking an opera-glass out of her hand,\nand proceeding to scrutinize, over her bare shoulder, the row of boxes\nfacing them': 25, '"I\'m afraid I\'m becoming ridiculous': 5, '"\n\nHe was very well aware that he ran no risk of being ridiculous in the\neyes of Betsy or any other fashionable people': 24, 'He was very well aware\nthat in their eyes the position of an unsuccessful lover of a girl, or\nof any woman free to marry, might be ridiculous': 28, 'But the position of a\nman pursuing a married woman, and, regardless of everything, staking\nhis life on drawing her into adultery, has something fine and grand\nabout it, and can never be ridiculous; and so it was with a proud and\ngay smile under his mustaches that he lowered the opera-glass and\nlooked at his cousin': 57, '"But why was it you didn\'t come to dinner': 9, '" she said, admiring him': 5, '"I must tell you about that': 6, 'I was busily employed, and doing what, do\nyou suppose': 10, "I'll give you a hundred guesses, a thousand": 8, "you'd\nnever guess": 3, "I've been reconciling a husband with a man who'd insulted\nhis wife": 12, 'Yes, really': 2, '"\n\n"Well, did you succeed': 5, '"\n\n"Almost': 2, '"\n\n"You really must tell me about it," she said, getting up': 12, '"Come to me\nin the next _entr\'acte': 7, '_"\n\n"I can\'t; I\'m going to the French theater': 9, '"\n\n"From Nilsson': 3, '" Betsy queried in horror, though she could not herself\nhave distinguished Nilsson\'s voice from any chorus girl\'s': 18, '"Can\'t help it': 3, "I've an appointment there, all to do with my mission of\npeace": 12, '"\n\n"‘Blessed are the peacemakers; theirs is the kingdom of heaven,\'" said\nBetsy, vaguely recollecting she had heard some similar saying from\nsomeone': 23, '"Very well, then, sit down, and tell me what it\'s all about': 12, '"\n\nAnd she sat down again': 6, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART TWO', {'"This is rather indiscreet, but it\'s so good it\'s an awful temptation\nto tell the story," said Vronsky, looking at her with his laughing\neyes': 25, '"I\'m not going to mention any names': 7, '"\n\n"But I shall guess, so much the better': 9, '"\n\n"Well, listen: two festive young men were driving—"\n\n"Officers of your regiment, of course': 15, '"\n\n"I didn\'t say they were officers,—two young men who had been lunching': 13, '"\n\n"In other words, drinking': 5, '"\n\n"Possibly': 2, 'They were driving on their way to dinner with a friend in\nthe most festive state of mind': 18, 'And they beheld a pretty woman in a\nhired sledge; she overtakes them, looks round at them, and, so they\nfancy anyway, nods to them and laughs': 27, 'They, of course, follow her': 5, 'They gallop at full speed': 5, 'To their amazement, the fair one alights at\nthe entrance of the very house to which they were going': 19, 'The fair one\ndarts upstairs to the top story': 9, 'They get a glimpse of red lips under a\nshort veil, and exquisite little feet': 15, '"\n\n"You describe it with such feeling that I fancy you must be one of the\ntwo': 17, '"\n\n"And after what you said, just now': 8, "Well, the young men go in to their\ncomrade's; he was giving a farewell dinner": 15, 'There they certainly did\ndrink a little too much, as one always does at farewell dinners': 16, 'And at\ndinner they inquire who lives at the top in that house': 13, "No one knows;\nonly their host's valet, in answer to their inquiry whether any ‘young\nladies' are living on the top floor, answered that there were a great\nmany of them about there": 33, "After dinner the two young men go into their\nhost's study, and write a letter to the unknown fair one": 20, 'They compose\nan ardent epistle, a declaration in fact, and they carry the letter\nupstairs themselves, so as to elucidate whatever might appear not\nperfectly intelligible in the letter': 29, '"\n\n"Why are you telling me these horrible stories': 9, 'Well': 1, '"\n\n"They ring': 3, "A maid-servant opens the door, they hand her the letter,\nand assure the maid that they're both so in love that they'll die on\nthe spot at the door": 29, 'The maid, stupefied, carries in their messages': 7, 'All at once a gentleman appears with whiskers like sausages, as red as\na lobster, announces that there is no one living in the flat except his\nwife, and sends them both about their business': 35, '"\n\n"How do you know he had whiskers like sausages, as you say': 13, '"\n\n"Ah, you shall hear': 5, "I've just been to make peace between them": 8, '"\n\n"Well, and what then': 5, '"\n\n"That\'s the most interesting part of the story': 9, "It appears that it's a\nhappy couple, a government clerk and his lady": 13, 'The government clerk\nlodges a complaint, and I became a mediator, and such a mediator': 15, "I\nassure you Talleyrand couldn't hold a candle to me": 10, '"\n\n"Why, where was the difficulty': 6, 'We apologize in due form: we are in despair, we\nentreat forgiveness for the unfortunate misunderstanding': 16, "The\ngovernment clerk with the sausages begins to melt, but he, too, desires\nto express his sentiments, and as soon as ever he begins to express\nthem, he begins to get hot and say nasty things, and again I'm obliged\nto trot out all my diplomatic talents": 47, 'I allowed that their conduct was\nbad, but I urged him to take into consideration their heedlessness,\ntheir youth; then, too, the young men had only just been lunching\ntogether': 30, '‘You understand': 2, 'They regret it deeply, and beg you to\noverlook their misbehavior': 11, "' The government clerk was softened once\nmore": 8, "‘I consent, count, and am ready to overlook it; but you perceive\nthat my wife—my wife's a respectable woman—has been exposed to the\npersecution, and insults, and effrontery of young upstarts,\nscoundrels": 32, "' And you must understand, the young upstarts are present\nall the while, and I have to keep the peace between them": 22, 'Again I call\nout all my diplomacy, and again as soon as the thing was about at an\nend, our friend the government clerk gets hot and red, and his sausages\nstand on end with wrath, and once more I launch out into diplomatic\nwiles': 45, '"\n\n"Ah, he must tell you this story': 8, '" said Betsy, laughing, to a lady who\ncame into her box': 12, '"He has been making me laugh so': 7, '"\n\n"Well, _bonne chance_': 4, '" she added, giving Vronsky one finger of the\nhand in which she held her fan, and with a shrug of her shoulders she\ntwitched down the bodice of her gown that had worked up, so as to be\nduly naked as she moved forward towards the footlights into the light\nof the gas, and the sight of all eyes': 60, 'Vronsky drove to the French theater, where he really had to see the\ncolonel of his regiment, who never missed a single performance there': 24, 'He wanted to see him, to report on the result of his mediation, which\nhad occupied and amused him for the last three days': 24, 'Petritsky, whom he\nliked, was implicated in the affair, and the other culprit was a\ncapital fellow and first-rate comrade, who had lately joined the\nregiment, the young Prince Kedrov': 30, 'And what was most important, the\ninterests of the regiment were involved in it too': 15, "Both the young men were in Vronsky's company": 8, 'The colonel of the\nregiment was waited upon by the government clerk, Venden, with a\ncomplaint against his officers, who had insulted his wife': 24, 'His young\nwife, so Venden told the story—he had been married half a year—was at\nchurch with her mother, and suddenly overcome by indisposition, arising\nfrom her interesting condition, she could not remain standing, she\ndrove home in the first sledge, a smart-looking one, she came across': 47, 'On the spot the officers set off in pursuit of her; she was alarmed,\nand feeling still more unwell, ran up the staircase home': 24, 'Venden\nhimself, on returning from his office, heard a ring at their bell and\nvoices, went out, and seeing the intoxicated officers with a letter, he\nhad turned them out': 30, 'He asked for exemplary punishment': 5, '"Yes, it\'s all very well," said the colonel to Vronsky, whom he had\ninvited to come and see him': 19, '"Petritsky\'s becoming impossible': 3, 'Not a\nweek goes by without some scandal': 8, "This government clerk won't let it\ndrop, he'll go on with the thing": 13, '"\n\nVronsky saw all the thanklessness of the business, and that there could\nbe no question of a duel in it, that everything must be done to soften\nthe government clerk, and hush the matter up': 36, 'The colonel had called in\nVronsky just because he knew him to be an honorable and intelligent\nman, and, more than all, a man who cared for the honor of the regiment': 32, "They talked it over, and decided that Petritsky and Kedrov must go with\nVronsky to Venden's to apologize": 18, "The colonel and Vronsky were both\nfully aware that Vronsky's name and rank would be sure to contribute\ngreatly to the softening of the injured husband's feelings": 27, 'And these two influences were not in fact without effect; though the\nresult remained, as Vronsky had described, uncertain': 19, 'On reaching the French theater, Vronsky retired to the foyer with the\ncolonel, and reported to him his success, or non-success': 21, 'The colonel,\nthinking it all over, made up his mind not to pursue the matter\nfurther, but then for his own satisfaction proceeded to cross-examine\nVronsky about his interview; and it was a long while before he could\nrestrain his laughter, as Vronsky described how the government clerk,\nafter subsiding for a while, would suddenly flare up again, as he\nrecalled the details, and how Vronsky, at the last half word of\nconciliation, skillfully manœuvered a retreat, shoving Petritsky out\nbefore him': 82, '"It\'s a disgraceful story, but killing': 6, "Kedrov really can't fight the\ngentleman": 6, 'Was he so awfully hot': 5, '" he commented, laughing': 4, '"But what do\nyou say to Claire today': 8, 'She\'s marvelous," he went on, speaking of a\nnew French actress': 11, '"However often you see her, every day she\'s\ndifferent': 9, "It's only the French who can do that": 8, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART TWO', {'Princess Betsy drove home from the theater, without waiting for the end\nof the last act': 16, 'She had only just time to go into her dressing-room,\nsprinkle her long, pale face with powder, rub it, set her dress to\nrights, and order tea in the big drawing-room, when one after another\ncarriages drove up to her huge house in Bolshaia Morskaia': 45, 'Her guests\nstepped out at the wide entrance, and the stout porter, who used to\nread the newspapers in the mornings behind the glass door, to the\nedification of the passers-by, noiselessly opened the immense door,\nletting the visitors pass by him into the house': 45, 'Almost at the same instant the hostess, with freshly arranged coiffure\nand freshened face, walked in at one door and her guests at the other\ndoor of the drawing-room, a large room with dark walls, downy rugs, and\na brightly lighted table, gleaming with the light of candles, white\ncloth, silver samovar, and transparent china tea-things': 56, 'The hostess sat down at the table and took off her gloves': 12, 'Chairs were\nset with the aid of footmen, moving almost imperceptibly about the\nroom; the party settled itself, black eyebrows': 53, 'In both groups\nconversation wavered, as it always does, for the first few minutes,\nbroken up by meetings, greetings, offers of tea, and as it were,\nfeeling about for something ('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART TWO', {'Steps were heard at the door, and Princess Betsy, knowing it was Madame\nKarenina, glanced at Vronsky': 17, 'He was looking towards the door, and his\nface wore a strange using the English word, and like a skillful hostess she at\nonce brought him into a serious conversation on the subject of\nuniversal conscription': 39, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch was immediately\ninterested in the subject, and began seriously defending the new\nimperial decree against Princess Betsy, who had attacked it': 23, 'Vronsky and Anna still sat at the little table': 9, 'Noticing the disagreeable impression that was being made on everyone,\nPrincess Betsy slipped someone else into her place to listen to Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, and went up to Anna': 28, '"I\'m always amazed at the clearness and precision of your husband\'s\nlanguage," she said': 14, '"The most transcendental ideas seem to be within\nmy grasp when he\'s speaking': 13, '"\n\n"Oh, yes': 3, '" said aims that evening than\nduring the last two months': 38, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 8 PART TWO', {'Alexey Alexandrovitch had seen nothing striking or improper in the fact\nthat his wife was sitting with Vronsky at a table apart, in eager\nconversation with him about something': 29, 'But he noticed that to the rest\nof the party this appeared something striking and improper, and for\nthat reason it seemed to him too to be improper': 28, 'He made up his mind\nthat he must speak of it to his wife': 14, "On reaching home Alexey Alexandrovitch went to his study, as he usually\ndid, seated himself in his low chair, opened a book on the Papacy at\nthe place where he had laid the paper-knife in it, and read till one\no'clock, just as he usually did": 46, 'But from time to time he rubbed his\nhigh forehead and shook his head, as though to drive away something': 20, 'At\nhis usual time he got up and made his toilet for the night': 14, 'Anna\nArkadyevna had not yet come in': 7, 'With a book under his arm he went\nupstairs': 9, 'But this evening, instead of his usual thoughts and\nmeditations upon official details, his thoughts were absorbed by his\nwife and something disagreeable connected with her': 26, 'Contrary to his\nusual habit, he did not get into bed, but fell to walking up and down\nthe rooms with his hands clasped behind his back': 27, 'He could not go to\nbed, feeling that it was absolutely needful for him first to think\nthoroughly over the position that had just arisen': 25, 'When Alexey Alexandrovitch had made up his mind that he must talk to\nhis wife about it, it had seemed a very easy and simple matter': 26, 'But\nnow, when he began to think over the question that had just presented\nitself, it seemed to him very complicated and difficult': 23, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch was not jealous': 5, "Jealousy according to his\nnotions was an insult to one's wife, and one ought to have confidence\nin one's wife": 20, 'Why one ought to have confidence—that is to say,\ncomplete conviction that his young wife would always love him—he did\nnot ask himself': 23, 'But he had no experience of lack of confidence,\nbecause he had confidence in her, and told himself that he ought to\nhave it': 24, 'Now, though his conviction that jealousy was a shameful\nfeeling and that one ought to feel confidence, had not broken down, he\nfelt that he was standing face to face with something illogical and\nirrational, and did not know what was to be done': 44, "Alexey Alexandrovitch\nwas standing face to face with life, with the possibility of his wife's\nloving someone other than himself, and this seemed to him very\nirrational and incomprehensible because it was life itself": 34, 'All his\nlife Alexey Alexandrovitch had lived and worked in official spheres,\nhaving to do with the reflection of life': 20, 'And every time he had\nstumbled against life itself he had shrunk away from it': 15, 'Now he\nexperienced a feeling akin to that of a man who, while calmly crossing\na precipice by a bridge, should suddenly discover that the bridge is\nbroken, and that there is a chasm below': 35, 'That chasm was life itself,\nthe bridge that artificial life in which Alexey Alexandrovitch had\nlived': 16, "For the first time the question presented itself to him of the\npossibility of his wife's loving someone else, and he was horrified at\nit": 25, 'He did not undress, but walked up and down with his regular tread over\nthe resounding parquet of the dining-room, where one lamp was burning,\nover the carpet of the dark drawing-room, in which the light was\nreflected on the big new portrait of himself hanging over the sofa, and\nacross her boudoir, where two candles burned, lighting up the portraits\nof her parents and woman friends, and the pretty knick-knacks of her\nwriting-table, that he knew so well': 79, 'He me': 60, "But what's to be done": 5, "I'm not one of\nthose men who submit to uneasiness and worry without having the force\nof character to face them": 21, '"I must think it over, come to a decision, referred': 59, '"And so," Alexey Alexandrovitch said to himself, "questions as to her\nfeelings, and so on, are questions for her conscience, with which I can\nhave nothing to do': 28, 'My duty is ('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART TWO', {'Anna came in with hanging head, playing with the tassels of her hood': 13, 'Her face was brilliant and glowing; but this glow was not one of\nbrightness; it suggested the ('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART TWO', {'From that time a new life began for Alexey Alexandrovitch and for his\nwife': 14, 'Nothing special happened': 3, "Anna went out into society, as she had\nalways done, was particularly often at Princess Betsy's, and met\nVronsky everywhere": 20, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch saw this, but could do\nnothing': 8, 'All his efforts to draw her into open discussion she\nconfronted with a barrier which he could not penetrate, made up of a\nsort of amused perplexity': 27, 'Outwardly everything was the same, but their\ninner relations were completely changed': 12, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch, a man\nof great power in the world of politics, felt himself helpless in this': 17, 'Like an ox with head bent, submissively he awaited the blow which he\nfelt was lifted over him': 18, 'Every time he began to think about it, he\nfelt that he must try once more, that by kindness, tenderness, and\npersuasion there was still hope of saving her, of bringing her back to\nherself, and every day he made ready to talk to her': 45, 'But every time he\nbegan talking to her, he felt that the spirit of evil and deceit, which\nhad taken possession of her, had possession of him too, and he talked\nto her in a tone quite unlike that in which he had meant to talk': 46, 'Involuntarily he talked to her in his habitual tone of jeering at\nanyone who should say what he was saying': 20, 'And in that tone it was\nimpossible to say what needed to be said to her': 16, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 11 PART TWO', {'That which for Vronsky had been almost a whole year the one absorbing\ndesire of his life, replacing all his old desires; that which for Anna\nhad been an impossible, terrible, and even for that reason more\nentrancing dream of bliss, that desire had been fulfilled': 46, 'He stood\nbefore her, pale, his lower jaw quivering, and besought her to be calm,\nnot knowing how or why': 20, '"Anna': 1, 'Anna': 1, '" he said with a choking voice, "Anna, for pity\'s sake': 11, '"\n\nBut the louder he spoke, the lower she dropped her once proud and gay,\nnow shame-stricken head, and she bowed down and sank from the sofa\nwhere she was sitting, down on the floor, at his feet; she would have\nfallen on the carpet if he had not held her': 51, '"My God': 2, 'Forgive me': 2, '" she said, sobbing, pressing his hands to her\nbosom': 10, 'She felt so sinful, so guilty, that nothing was left her but to\nhumiliate herself and beg forgiveness; and as now there was no one in\nher life but him, to him she addressed her prayer for forgiveness': 38, 'Looking at him, she had a physical sense of her humiliation, and she\ncould say nothing more': 17, 'He felt what a murderer must feel, when he sees\nthe body he has robbed of life': 17, 'That body, robbed by him of life, was\ntheir love, the first stage of their love': 16, 'There was something awful\nand revolting in the memory of what had been bought at this fearful\nprice of shame': 20, 'Shame at their spiritual nakedness crushed her and\ninfected him': 10, "But in spite of all the murderer's horror before the body\nof his victim, he must hack it to pieces, hide the body, must use what\nhe has gained by his murder": 32, 'And with fury, as it were with passion, the murderer falls on the body,\nand drags it and hacks at it; so he covered her face and shoulders with\nkisses': 30, 'She held his hand, and did not stir': 8, '"Yes, these kisses—that is\nwhat has been bought by this shame': 11, 'Yes, and one hand, which will\nalways be mine—the hand of my accomplice': 13, '" She lifted up that hand and\nkissed it': 9, 'He sank on his knees and tried to see her face; but she hid\nit, and said nothing': 18, 'At last, as though making an effort over herself,\nshe got up and pushed him away': 16, 'Her face was still as beautiful, but it\nwas only the more pitiful for that': 15, '"All is over," she said; "I have nothing but you': 10, 'Remember that': 2, '"\n\n"I can never forget what is my whole life': 10, 'For one instant of this\nhappiness': 6, '"\n\n"Happiness': 2, '" she said with horror and loathing and her horror\nunconsciously infected him': 13, '"For pity\'s sake, not a word, not a word\nmore': 10, '"\n\nShe rose quickly and moved away from him': 9, '"Not a word more," she repeated, and with a look of chill despair,\nincomprehensible to him, she parted from him': 20, 'She felt that at that\nmoment she could not put into words the sense of shame, of rapture, and\nof horror at this stepping into a new life, and she did not want to\nspeak of it, to vulgarize this feeling by inappropriate words': 44, 'But\nlater too, and the next day and the third day, she still found no words\nin which she could express the complexity of her feelings; indeed, she\ncould not even find thoughts in which she could clearly think out all\nthat was in her soul': 46, 'She said to herself: "No, just now I can\'t think of it, later on, when\nI am calmer': 18, '" But this calm for thought never came; every time the\nthought rose of what she had done and what would happen to her, and\nwhat she ought to do, a horror came over her and she drove those\nthoughts away': 41, '"Later, later," she said—"when I am calmer': 7, '"\n\nBut in dreams, when she had no control over her thoughts, her position\npresented itself to her in all its hideous nakedness': 23, 'One dream haunted\nher almost every night': 7, 'She dreamed that both were her husbands at\nonce, that both were lavishing caresses on her': 16, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch\nwas weeping, kissing her hands, and saying, "How happy we are now': 14, '" And\nAlexey Vronsky was there too, and he too was her husband': 13, 'And she was\nmarveling that it had once seemed impossible to her, was explaining to\nthem, laughing, that this was ever so much simpler, and that now both\nof them were happy and contented': 34, 'But this dream weighed on her like a\nnightmare, and she awoke from it in terror': 16, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART TWO', {'In the early days after his return from Moscow, whenever Levin\nshuddered and grew red, remembering the disgrace of his rejection, he\nsaid to himself: "This was just how I used to shudder and blush,\nthinking myself utterly lost, when I was plucked in physics and did not\nget my remove; and how I thought myself utterly ruined after I had\nmismanaged that affair of my sister\'s that was entrusted to me': 72, 'And\nyet, now that years have passed, I recall it and wonder that it could\ndistress me so much': 19, 'It will be the same thing too with this trouble': 10, 'Time will go by and I shall not mind about this either': 12, '"\n\nBut three months had passed and he had not left off minding about it;\nand it was as painful for him to think of it as it had been those first\ndays': 33, 'He could not be at peace because after dreaming so long of family\nlife, and feeling himself so ripe for it, he was still not married, and\nwas further than ever from marriage': 33, 'He was painfully conscious\nhimself, as were all about him, that at his years it is not well for\nman to be alone': 23, 'He remembered how before starting for Moscow he had\nonce said to his cowman Nikolay, a simple-hearted peasant, whom he\nliked talking to: "Well, Nikolay': 25, 'I mean to get married," and how\nNikolay had promptly answered, as of a matter on which there could be\nno possible doubt: "And high time too, Konstantin Dmitrievitch': 29, '" But\nmarriage had now become further off than ever': 10, 'The place was taken, and\nwhenever he tried to imagine any of the girls he knew in that place, he\nfelt that it was utterly impossible': 26, 'Moreover, the recollection of the\nrejection and the part he had played in the affair tortured him with\nshame': 19, 'However often he told himself that he was in no wise to blame in\nit, that recollection, like other humiliating reminiscences of a\nsimilar kind, made him twinge and blush': 30, "There had been in his past, as\nin every man's, actions, recognized by him as bad, for which his\nconscience ought to have tormented him; but the memory of these evil\nactions was far from causing him so much suffering as those trivial but\nhumiliating reminiscences": 46, 'These wounds never healed': 4, 'And with these\nmemories was now ranged his rejection and the pitiful position in which\nhe must have appeared to others that evening': 23, 'But time and work did\ntheir part': 7, 'Bitter memories were more and more covered up by the\nincidents—paltry in his eyes, but really important—of his country life': 20, 'Every week he thought less often of Kitty': 8, 'He was impatiently looking\nforward to the news that she was married, or just going to be married,\nhoping that such news would, like having a tooth out, completely cure\nhim': 31, 'Meanwhile spring came on, beautiful and kindly, without the delays and\ntreacheries of spring,—one of those rare springs in which plants,\nbeasts, and man rejoice alike': 26, 'This lovely spring roused Levin still\nmore, and strengthened him in his resolution of renouncing all his past\nand building up his lonely life firmly and independently': 27, 'Though many\nof the plans with which he had returned to the country had not been\ncarried out, still his most important resolution—that of purity—had\nbeen kept by him': 29, 'He was free from that shame, which had usually\nharassed him after a fall; and he could look everyone straight in the\nface': 23, "In February he had received a letter from Marya Nikolaevna\ntelling him that his brother Nikolay's health was getting worse, but\nthat he would not take advice, and in consequence of this letter Levin\nwent to Moscow to his brother's and succeeded in persuading him to see\na doctor and to go to a watering-place abroad": 56, 'He succeeded so well in\npersuading his brother, and in lending him money for the journey\nwithout irritating him, that he was satisfied with himself in that\nmatter': 28, 'In addition to his farming, which called for special attention\nin spring, and in addition to reading, Levin had begun that winter a\nwork on agriculture, the plan of which turned on taking into account\nthe character of the laborer on the land as one of the unalterable data\nof the question, like the climate and the soil, and consequently\ndeducing all the principles of scientific culture, not simply from the\ndata of soil and climate, but from the data of soil, climate, and a\ncertain unalterable character of the laborer': 91, 'Thus, in spite of his\nsolitude, or in consequence of his solitude, his life was exceedingly\nfull': 17, 'Only rarely he suffered from an unsatisfied desire to communicate\nhis stray ideas to someone besides Agafea Mihalovna': 18, "With her indeed he\nnot infrequently fell into discussion upon physics, the theory of\nagriculture, and especially philosophy; philosophy was Agafea\nMihalovna's favorite subject": 24, 'Spring was slow in unfolding': 5, 'For the last few weeks it had been\nsteadily fine frosty weather': 12, 'In the daytime it thawed in the sun, but\nat night there were even seven degrees of frost': 18, 'There was such a\nfrozen surface on the snow that they drove the wagons anywhere off the\nroads': 18, 'Easter came in the snow': 5, 'Then all of a sudden, on Easter Monday,\na warm wind sprang up, storm clouds swooped down, and for three days\nand three nights the warm, driving rain fell in streams': 31, 'On Thursday\nthe wind dropped, and a thick gray fog brooded over the land as though\nhiding the mysteries of the transformations that were being wrought in\nnature': 28, 'Behind the fog there was the flowing of water, the cracking and\nfloating of ice, the swift rush of turbid, foaming torrents; and on the\nfollowing Monday, in the evening, the fog parted, the storm clouds\nsplit up into little curling crests of cloud, the sky cleared, and the\nreal spring had come': 53, 'In the morning the sun rose brilliant and quickly\nwore away the thin layer of ice that covered the water, and all the\nwarm air was quivering with the steam that rose up from the quickened\nearth': 37, 'The old grass looked greener, and the young grass thrust up its\ntiny blades; the buds of the guelder-rose and of the currant and the\nsticky birch-buds were swollen with sap, and an exploring bee was\nhumming about the golden blossoms that studded the willow': 45, 'Larks\ntrilled unseen above the velvety green fields and the ice-covered\nstubble-land; peewits wailed over the low lands and marshes flooded by\nthe pools; cranes and wild geese flew high across the sky uttering\ntheir spring calls': 37, 'The cattle, bald in patches where the new hair had\nnot grown yet, lowed in the pastures; the bowlegged lambs frisked round\ntheir bleating mothers': 25, 'Nimble children ran about the drying paths,\ncovered with the prints of bare feet': 14, 'There was a merry chatter of\npeasant women over their linen at the pond, and the ring of axes in the\nyard, where the peasants were repairing ploughs and harrows': 30, 'The real\nspring had come': 5, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART TWO', {'Levin put on his big boots, and, for the first time, a cloth jacket,\ninstead of his fur cloak, and went out to look after his farm, stepping\nover streams of water that flashed in the sunshine and dazzled his\neyes, and treading one minute on ice and the next into sticky mud': 53, 'Spring is the time of plans and projects': 8, 'And, as he came out into the\nfarmyard, Levin, like a tree in spring that knows not what form will be\ntaken by the young shoots and twigs imprisoned in its swelling buds,\nhardly knew what undertakings he was going to begin upon now in the\nfarm work that was so dear to him': 54, 'But he felt that he was full of the\nmost splendid plans and projects': 14, 'First of all he went to the cattle': 8, 'The cows had been let out into their paddock, and their smooth sides\nwere already shining with their new, sleek, spring coats; they basked\nin the sunshine and lowed to go to the meadow': 34, 'Levin gazed admiringly\nat the cows he knew so intimately to the minutest detail of their\ncondition, and gave orders for them to be driven out into the meadow,\nand the calves to be let into the paddock': 38, 'The herdsman ran gaily to\nget ready for the meadow': 10, 'The cowherd girls, picking up their\npetticoats, ran splashing through the mud with bare legs, still white,\nnot yet brown from the sun, waving brush wood in their hands, chasing\nthe calves that frolicked in the mirth of spring': 39, "After admiring the young ones of that year, who were particularly\nfine—the early calves were the size of a peasant's cow, and Pava's\ndaughter, at three months old, was as big as a yearling—Levin gave\norders for a trough to be brought out and for them to be fed in the\npaddock": 52, 'But it appeared that as the paddock had not been used during\nthe winter, the hurdles made in the autumn for it were broken': 24, 'He sent\nfor the carpenter, who, according to his orders, ought to have been at\nwork at the thrashing machine': 20, 'But it appeared that the carpenter was\nrepairing the harrows, which ought to have been repaired before Lent': 18, 'This was very annoying to Levin': 6, 'It was annoying to come upon that\neverlasting slovenliness in the farm work against which he had been\nstriving with all his might for so many years': 27, "The hurdles, as he\nascertained, being not wanted in winter, had been carried to the\ncart-horses' stable; and there broken, as they were of light\nconstruction, only meant for feeding calves": 31, 'Moreover, it was apparent\nalso that the harrows and all the agricultural implements, which he had\ndirected to be looked over and repaired in the winter, for which very\npurpose he had hired three carpenters, had not been put into repair,\nand the harrows were being repaired when they ought to have been\nharrowing the field': 56, 'Levin sent for his bailiff, but immediately went\noff himself to look for him': 14, 'The bailiff, beaming all over, temper': 16, 'When Vassily came up, Levin told him to lead\nthe horse to the hedge': 14, '"It\'s all right, sir, it\'ll spring up again," responded Vassily': 10, '"Please don\'t argue," said Levin, ('TOL CHAPTER 14 PART TWO', {'As he rode up to the house in the happiest frame of mind, Levin heard\nthe bell ring at the side of the principal entrance of the house': 28, '"Yes, that\'s someone from the railway station," he thought, "just the\ntime to be here from the Moscow train': 19, 'Who could it be': 4, "What if it's\nbrother Nikolay": 5, "He did say: ‘Maybe I'll go to the waters, or maybe\nI'll come down to you": 16, '\'" He felt dismayed and vexed for the first\nminute, that his brother Nikolay\'s presence should come to disturb his\nhappy mood of spring': 24, 'But he felt ashamed of the feeling, and at once\nhe opened, as it were, the arms of his soul, and with a softened\nfeeling of joy and expectation, now he hoped with all his heart that it\nwas his brother': 41, 'He pricked up his horse, and riding out from behind\nthe acacias he saw a hired three-horse sledge from the railway station,\nand a gentleman in a fur coat': 29, 'It was not his brother': 5, '"Oh, if it were\nonly some nice person one could talk to a little': 14, '" he thought': 3, '"Ah," cried Levin joyfully, flinging up both his hands': 9, '"Here\'s a\ndelightful visitor': 4, 'Ah, how glad I am to see you': 8, '" he shouted,\nrecognizing Stepan Arkadyevitch': 6, '"I shall find out for certain whether she\'s married, or when she\'s\ngoing to be married," he thought': 18, 'And on that delicious spring day he\nfelt that the thought of her did not hurt him at all': 19, '"Well, you didn\'t expect me, eh': 6, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting out\nof the sledge, splashed with mud on the bridge of his nose, on his\ncheek, and on his eyebrows, but radiant with health and good spirits': 32, '"I\'ve come to see you in the first place," he said, embracing and\nkissing him, "to have some stand-shooting second, and to sell the\nforest at Ergushovo third': 28, '"\n\n"Delightful': 2, "What a spring we're having": 5, 'How ever did you get along in\na sledge': 9, '"\n\n"In a cart it would have been worse still, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,"\nanswered the driver, who knew him': 18, '"Well, I\'m very, very glad to see you," said Levin, with a genuine\nsmile of childlike delight': 17, "Levin led his friend to the room set apart for visitors, where Stepan\nArkadyevitch's things were carried also—a bag, a gun in a case, a\nsatchel for cigars": 28, 'Leaving him there to wash and change his clothes,\nLevin went off to the counting house to speak about the ploughing and\nclover': 23, 'Agafea Mihalovna, always very anxious for the credit of the\nhouse, met him in the hall with inquiries about dinner': 20, '"Do just as you like, only let it be as soon as possible," he said, and\nwent to the bailiff': 20, 'When he came back, Stepan Arkadyevitch, washed and combed, came out of\nhis room with a beaming smile, and they went upstairs together': 23, '"Well, I am glad I managed to get away to you': 11, 'Now I shall understand\nwhat the mysterious business is that you are always absorbed in here': 16, 'No, really, I envy you': 5, 'What a house, how nice it all is': 8, 'So bright, so\ncheerful': 4, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, forgetting that it was not always\nspring and fine weather like that day': 17, '"And your nurse is simply\ncharming': 6, 'A pretty maid in an apron might be even more agreeable,\nperhaps; but for your severe monastic style it does very well': 22, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch told him many interesting pieces of news;\nespecially interesting to Levin was the news that his brother, Sergey\nIvanovitch, was intending to pay him a visit in the summer': 32, 'Not one word did Stepan Arkadyevitch say in reference to Kitty and the\nShtcherbatskys; he merely gave him greetings from his wife': 22, 'Levin was\ngrateful to him for his delicacy and was very glad of his visitor': 15, 'As\nalways happened with him during his solitude, a mass of ideas and\nfeelings had been accumulating within him, which he could not\ncommunicate to those about him': 28, 'And now he poured out upon Stepan\nArkadyevitch his poetic joy in the spring, and his failures and plans\nfor the land, and his thoughts and criticisms on the books he had been\nreading, and the idea of his own book, the basis of which really was,\nthough he was unaware of it himself, a criticism of all the old books\non agriculture': 63, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch, always charming, understanding\neverything at the slightest reference, was particularly charming on\nthis visit, and Levin noticed in him a special tenderness, as it were,\nand a new tone of respect that flattered him': 36, "The efforts of Agafea Mihalovna and the cook, that the dinner should be\nparticularly good, only ended in the two famished friends attacking the\npreliminary course, eating a great deal of bread and butter, salt goose\nand salted mushrooms, and in Levin's finally ordering the soup to be\nserved without the accompaniment of little pies, with which the cook\nhad particularly meant to impress their visitor": 66, 'But though Stepan\nArkadyevitch was accustomed to very different dinners, he thought\neverything excellent: the herb brandy, and the bread, and the butter,\nand above all the salt goose and the mushrooms, and the nettle soup,\nand the chicken in white sauce, and the white Crimean wine—everything\nwas superb and delicious': 51, '"Splendid, splendid': 2, '" he said, lighting a fat cigar after the roast': 10, '"I\nfeel as if, coming to you, I had landed on a peaceful shore after the\nnoise and jolting of a steamer': 22, 'And so you maintain that the laborer\nhimself is an element to be studied and to regulate the choice of\nmethods in agriculture': 23, "Of course, I'm an ignorant outsider; but I\nshould fancy theory and its application will have its influence on the\nlaborer too": 22, '"\n\n"Yes, but wait a bit': 6, "I'm not talking of political economy, I'm talking\nof the science of agriculture": 13, 'It ought to be like the natural\nsciences, and to observe given phenomena and the laborer in his\neconomic, ethnographical': 20, '"\n\nAt that instant Agafea Mihalovna came in with jam': 10, '"Oh, Agafea Mihalovna," said the window at the sun sinking behind the bare\ntree-tops of the forest': 17, '"Yes, it\'s time," he said': 5, '"Kouzma, get ready the trap," and he ran\ndownstairs': 9, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch, going down, carefully took the canvas cover off\nhis varnished gun case with his own hands, and opening it, began to get\nready his expensive new-fashioned gun': 29, "Kouzma, who already scented a\nbig tip, never left Stepan Arkadyevitch's side, and put on him both his\nstockings and boots, a task which Stepan Arkadyevitch readily left him": 29, '"Kostya, give orders that if the merchant Ryabinin comes': '"\n\n"To be sure I do': 6, 'I have had to do business with him, ‘positively and\nconclusively': 11, '\'"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch laughed': 4, '"Positively and conclusively" were the\nmerchant\'s favorite words': 8, '"Yes, it\'s wonderfully funny the way he talks': 8, "She knows where her\nmaster's going": 6, '" he added, patting Laska, who hung about Levin, whining\nand licking his hands, his boots, and his gun': 19, 'The trap was already at the steps when they went out': 11, '"I told them to bring the trap round; or would you rather walk': 13, '"\n\n"No, we\'d better drive," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, getting into the\ntrap': 12, 'He sat down, tucked the tiger-skin rug round him, and lighted a\ncigar': 13, '"How is it you don\'t smoke': 6, 'A cigar is a sort of thing, not\nexactly a pleasure, but the crown and outward sign of pleasure': 19, 'Come,\nthis is life': 4, 'How splendid it is': 4, 'This is how I should like to live': 8, '"\n\n"Why, who prevents you': 5, '" said Levin, smiling': 4, '"No, you\'re a lucky man': 5, "You've got everything you like": 5, 'You like\nhorses—and you have them; dogs—you have them; shooting—you have it;\nfarming—you have it': 15, '"\n\n"Perhaps because I rejoice in what I have, and don\'t fret for what I\nhaven\'t," said Levin, thinking of Kitty': 21, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch comprehended, looked at him, but said nothing': 9, 'Levin was grateful to Oblonsky for noticing, with his never-failing\ntact, that he dreaded conversation about the Shtcherbatskys, and so\nsaying nothing about them': 24, 'But now Levin was longing to find out what\nwas tormenting him so, yet he had not the courage to begin': 21, '"Come, tell me how things are going with you," said Levin, bethinking\nhimself that it was not nice of him to think only of himself': 25, "Stepan Arkadyevitch's eyes sparkled merrily": 5, '"You don\'t admit, I know, that one can be fond of new rolls when one\nhas had one\'s rations of bread—to your mind it\'s a crime; but I don\'t\ncount life as life without love," he said, taking Levin\'s question his\nown way': 43, '"What am I to do': 5, "I'm made that way": 4, 'And really, one does so\nlittle harm to anyone, and gives oneself so much pleasure': 15, '"\n\n"What': 2, 'is there something new, then': 5, '" queried Levin': 3, '"Yes, my boy, there is': 5, "There, do you see, you know the type of\nOssian's women": 11, 'Women, such as one sees in dreams': 7, 'Well, these\nwomen are sometimes to be met in reality': 10, 'and these women are\nterrible': 5, "Woman, don't you know, is such a subject that however much\nyou study it, it's always perfectly new": 18, '"\n\n"Well, then, it would be better not to study it': 11, '"\n\n"No': 2, 'Some mathematician has said that enjoyment lies in the search for\ntruth, not in the finding it': 17, '"\n\nLevin listened in silence, and in spite of all the efforts he made, he\ncould not in the least enter into the feelings of his friend ('TOL CHAPTER 15 PART TWO', {'The place fixed on for the stand-shooting was not far above a stream in\na little aspen copse': 18, 'On reaching the copse, Levin got out of the trap\nand led Oblonsky to a corner of a mossy, swampy glade, already quite\nfree from snow': 26, 'He went back himself to a double birch tree on the\nother side, and leaning his gun on the fork of a dead lower branch, he\ntook off his full overcoat, fastened his belt again, and worked his\narms to see if they were free': 45, 'Gray old Laska, who had followed them, sat down warily opposite him and\npricked up her ears': 17, 'The sun was setting behind a thick forest, and in\nthe glow of sunset the birch trees, dotted about in the aspen copse,\nstood out clearly with their hanging twigs, and their buds swollen\nalmost to bursting': 37, 'From the thickest parts of the copse, where the snow still remained,\ncame the faint sound of narrow winding threads of water running away': 24, 'Tiny birds twittered, and now and then fluttered from tree to tree': 12, "In the pauses of complete stillness there came the rustle of last\nyear's leaves, stirred by the thawing of the earth and the growth of\nthe grass": 27, '"Imagine': 1, 'One can hear and see the grass growing': 8, '" Levin said to\nhimself, noticing a wet, slate-colored aspen leaf moving beside a blade\nof young grass': 18, 'He stood, listened, and gazed sometimes down at the wet\nmossy ground, sometimes at Laska listening all alert, sometimes at the\nsea of bare tree tops that stretched on the slope below him, sometimes\nat the darkening sky, covered with white streaks of cloud': 44, 'A hawk flew high over a forest far away with slow sweep of its wings;\nanother flew with exactly the same motion in the same direction and\nvanished': 28, 'The birds twittered more and more loudly and busily in the\nthicket': 12, 'An owl hooted not far off, and Laska, starting, stepped\ncautiously a few steps forward, and putting her head on one side, began\nto listen intently': 26, 'Beyond the stream was heard the cuckoo': 7, 'Twice she\nuttered her usual cuckoo call, and then gave a hoarse, hurried call and\nbroke down': 17, 'the cuckoo already': 3, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, coming out\nfrom behind a bush': 10, '"Yes, I hear it," answered Levin, reluctantly breaking the stillness\nwith his voice, which sounded disagreeable to himself': 18, '"Now '"Tchk': 1, 'tchk': 1, '" came the snapping sound of Stepan Arkadyevitch cocking\nhis gun': 11, '"What\'s that cry': 3, '" asked Oblonsky, drawing Levin\'s attention to a\nprolonged cry, as though a colt were whinnying in a high voice, in\nplay': 22, '"Oh, don\'t you know it': 5, "That's the hare": 3, 'But enough talking': 3, "Listen,\nit's flying": 3, '" almost shrieked Levin, cocking his gun': be heard': 36, 'Levin looked about him to right and to left, and there, just facing him\nagainst the dusky blue sky above the confused mass of tender shoots of\nthe aspens, he saw the flying bird': 34, 'It was flying straight towards him;\nthe guttural cry, like the even tearing of some strong stuff, sounded\nclose to his ear; the long beak and neck of the bird could be seen, and\nat the very instant when Levin was taking aim, behind the bush where\nOblonsky stood, there was a flash of red lightning: the bird dropped\nlike an arrow, and darted upwards again': 66, 'Again came the red flash and\nthe sound of a blow, and fluttering its wings as though trying to keep\nup in the air, the bird halted, stopped still an instant, and fell with\na heavy splash on the slushy ground': 41, '"Can I have missed it': 5, '" shouted Stepan Arkadyevitch, who could not see\nfor the smoke': 11, '"Here it is': 3, '" said Levin, pointing to Laska, who with one ear raised,\nwagging the end of her shaggy 'Stepan Arkadyevitch shot two more birds\nand Levin two, of which one was not found': 15, 'It began to get dark': 5, 'Venus,\nbright and silvery, shone with her soft light low down in the west\nbehind ('TOL CHAPTER 16 PART TWO', {"On the way home Levin asked all details of Kitty's illness and the\nShtcherbatskys' plans, and though he would have been ashamed to admit\nit, he was pleased at what he ('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART TWO', {'Stepan Arkadyevitch went upstairs with his pocket bulging with notes,\nwhich the merchant had paid him for three months in advance': 21, 'The\nbusiness of the forest was over, the money in his pocket; their\nshooting had been excellent, and Stepan Arkadyevitch was in the\nhappiest frame of mind, and so he felt specially anxious to dissipate\nthe ill-humor that had come upon Levin': 42, 'He wanted to finish the day at\nsupper as pleasantly as it had been begun': 15, 'Levin certainly was out of humor, and in spite of all his desire to be\naffectionate and cordial to his charming visitor, he could not control\nhis mood': 28, 'The intoxication of the news that Kitty was not married had\ngradually begun to work upon him': 17, 'Kitty was not married, but ill, and ill from love for a man who had\nslighted her': 17, 'This slight, as it were, rebounded upon him': 8, 'Vronsky had\nslighted her, and she had slighted him, Levin': 10, 'Consequently Vronsky had\nthe right to despise Levin, and therefore he was his enemy': 14, 'But all\nthis Levin did not think out': 8, 'He vaguely felt that there was something\nin it insulting to him, and he was not angry now at impoverishment is not due to\nextravagance—that would be nothing; living in good style—that's the\nproper thing for noblemen; it's only the nobles who know how to do it": 30, "Now the peasants about us buy land, and I don't mind that": 12, 'The\ngentleman does nothing, while the peasant works and supplants the idle\nman': 13, "That's as it ought to be": 6, "And I'm very glad for the peasant": 7, "But I\ndo mind seeing the process of impoverishment from a sort of—I don't\nknow what to call it—innocence": 19, 'Here a Polish speculator bought for\nhalf its value a magnificent estate from a young Ryabinin\ndid": 7, "Ryabinin's children will have means of livelihood and education,\nwhile yours maybe will not": 14, '"\n\n"Well, you must excuse me, but there\'s something mean in this counting': he\nwent on, leaning his elbow on the table, and propping on his hand his\nhandsome ruddy face, in which his moist, good-natured, sleepy eyes\nshone like stars': 38, '"It\'s your own fault': 4, 'You He yawned inwardly, without opening his mouth': 8, '"Does he know, or doesn\'t he, that I did make an offer': 12, '" Levin\nwondered, gazing at him': 6, '"Yes, there\'s something humbugging, diplomatic\nin his face," and feeling he was blushing, he looked Stepan\nArkadyevitch straight in the face without speaking': 23, '"If there was anything on her side at the time, it was nothing but a\nsuperficial attraction," pursued Oblonsky': 19, '"His being such a perfect\naristocrat, don\'t you know, and his future position in society, had an\ninfluence not with her, but with her mother': 25, '"\n\nLevin scowled': 3, 'The humiliation of his rejection stung him to the heart,\nas though it were a fresh wound he had only just received': 22, 'But he was\nat home, and the walls of home are a support': 13, '"Stay, stay," he began, interrupting Oblonsky': 6, '"You talk of his being\nan aristocrat': 7, 'But allow me to ask what it consists in, that\naristocracy of Vronsky or of anybody else, beside which I can be looked\ndown upon': 25, "You consider Vronsky an aristocrat, but I don't": 8, "A man whose\nfather crawled up from nothing at all by intrigue, and whose mother—God\nknows whom she wasn't mixed up with": 22, "No, excuse me, but I consider\nmyself aristocratic, and people like me, who can point back in the past\nto three or four honorable generations of their family, of the highest\ndegree of breeding (talent and intellect, of course that's another\nmatter), and have never curried favor with anyone, never depended on\nanyone for anything, like my father and my grandfather": 61, 'And I know many\nsuch': 5, "You think it mean of me to count the trees in my forest, while\nyou make Ryabinin a present of thirty thousand; but you get rents from\nyour lands and I don't know what, while I don't and so I prize what's\ncome to me from my ancestors or been won by hard work": 54, 'We are\naristocrats, and not those who can only exist by favor of the powerful\nof this world, and who can be bought for twopence halfpenny': 26, '"\n\n"Well, but whom are you attacking': 7, 'I agree with you," said Stepan\nArkadyevitch, sincerely and genially; though he was aware that in the\nclass of those who could be bought for twopence halfpenny Levin was\nreckoning him too': 32, "Levin's warmth gave him genuine pleasure": 6, '"Whom are\nyou attacking': 4, "Though a good deal is not true that you say about\nVronsky, but I won't talk about that": 18, 'I tell you straight out, if I\nwere you, I should go back with me to Moscow, and': 18, '"\n\n"No; I don\'t know whether you know it or not, but I don\'t care': 15, 'And I\ntell you—I did make an offer and was rejected, and Katerina\nAlexandrovna is nothing now to me but a painful and humiliating\nreminiscence': 25, '"\n\n"What ever for': 4, 'What nonsense': 2, '"\n\n"But we won\'t talk about it': 7, 'Please forgive me, if I\'ve been nasty,"\nsaid Levin': 9, 'Now that he had opened his heart, he became as he had been\nin the morning': 16, '"You\'re not angry with me, Stiva': 6, 'Please don\'t be\nangry," he said, and smiling, he took his hand': 12, '"Of course not; not a bit, and no reason to be': 11, "I'm glad we've spoken\nopenly": 5, 'And do you know, stand-shooting in the morning is unusually\ngood—why not go': 13, "I couldn't sleep the night anyway, but I might go\nstraight from shooting to the station": 16, '"\n\n"Capital': 2, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART TWO', {"Although all Vronsky's inner life was absorbed in his passion, his\nexternal life unalterably and inevitably followed along the old\naccustomed lines of his social and regimental ties and interests": 30, "The\ninterests of his regiment took an important place in Vronsky's life,\nboth because he was fond of the regiment, and because the regiment was\nfond of him": 28, 'They were not only fond of Vronsky in his regiment, they\nrespected him too, and were proud of him; proud that this man, with his\nimmense wealth, his brilliant education and abilities, and the path\nopen before him to every kind of success, distinction, and ambition,\nhad disregarded all that, and of all the interests of life had the\ninterests of his regiment and his comrades nearest to his heart': 70, "Vronsky was aware of his comrades' view of him, and in addition to his\nliking for the life, he felt bound to keep up that reputation": 26, 'It need not be said that he did not speak of his love to any of his\ncomrades, nor did he betray his secret even in the wildest drinking\nbouts (though indeed he was never so drunk as to lose all control of\nhimself)': 44, 'And he shut up any of his thoughtless comrades who attempted\nto allude to his connection': 16, 'But in spite of that, his love was known\nto all the town; everyone guessed with more or less confidence at his\nrelations with Madame Karenina': 26, 'The majority of the younger men envied\nhim for just what was the most irksome factor in his love—the exalted\nposition of Karenin, and the consequent publicity of their connection\nin society': 32, 'The greater number of the young women, who envied Anna and had long\nbeen weary of hearing her called _virtuous_, rejoiced at the\nfulfillment of their predictions, and were only waiting for a decisive\nturn in public opinion to fall upon her with all the weight of their\nscorn': 49, 'They were already making ready their handfuls of mud to fling at\nher when the right moment arrived': 18, 'The greater number of the\nmiddle-aged people and certain great personages were displeased at the\nprospect of the impending scandal in society': 22, "Vronsky's mother, on hearing of his connection, was at first pleased at\nit, because nothing to her mind gave such a finishing touch to a\nbrilliant young man as a _liaison_ in the highest society; she was\npleased, too, that Madame Karenina, who had so taken her fancy, and had\ntalked so much of her son, was, after all, just like all other pretty\nand well-bred women,—at least according to the Countess Vronskaya's\nideas": 74, 'But she had heard of late that her son had refused a position\noffered him of great importance to his career, simply in order to\nremain in the regiment, where he could be constantly seeing Madame\nKarenina': 37, 'She learned that great personages were displeased with him on\nthis account, and she changed her opinion': 17, 'She was vexed, too, that\nfrom all she could learn of this connection it was not that brilliant,\ngraceful, worldly _liaison_ which she would have welcomed, but a sort\nof Wertherish, desperate passion, so she was told, which might well\nlead him into imprudence': 44, 'She had not seen him since his abrupt\ndeparture from Moscow, and she sent her elder son to bid him come to\nsee her': 24, 'This elder son, too, was displeased with his younger brother': 10, "He did\nnot distinguish what sort of love his might be, big or little,\npassionate or passionless, lasting or passing (he kept a ballet girl\nhimself, though he was the father of a family, so he was lenient in\nthese matters), but he knew that this love affair was viewed with\ndispleasure by those whom it was necessary to please, and therefore he\ndid not approve of his brother's conduct": 70, 'Besides the service and society, Vronsky had another great\ninterest—horses; he was passionately fond of horses': 16, 'That year races and a steeplechase had been arranged for the officers': 12, 'Vronsky had put his name down, bought a thoroughbred English mare, and\nin spite of his love affair, he was looking forward to the races with\nintense, though reserved, excitement': 30, 'These two passions did not interfere with one another': 9, 'On the contrary,\nhe needed occupation and distraction quite apart from his love, so as\nto recruit and rest himself from the violent emotions that agitated\nhim': 27, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART TWO', {'On the day of the races at Krasnoe Selo, Vronsky had come earlier than\nusual to eat beefsteak in the common messroom of the regiment': 25, 'He had\nno need to be strict with himself, as he had very quickly been brought\ndown to the required light weight; but still he had to avoid gaining\nflesh, and so he eschewed farinaceous and sweet dishes': 38, 'He sat with his\ncoat unbuttoned over a white waistcoat, resting both elbows on the\ntable, and while waiting for the steak he had ordered he looked at a\nFrench novel that lay open on his plate': 37, 'He was only looking at the\nbook to avoid conversation with the officers coming in and out; he was\nthinking': 20, "He was thinking of Anna's promise to see him that day after the races": 14, 'But he had not seen her for three days, and as her husband had just\nreturned from abroad, he did not know whether she would be able to meet\nhim today or not, and he did not know how to find out': 42, "He had had his\nlast interview with her at his cousin Betsy's summer villa": 14, "He visited\nthe Karenins' summer villa as rarely as possible": 10, 'Now he wanted to go\nthere, and he pondered the question how to do it': 15, '"Of course I shall say Betsy has sent me to ask whether she\'s coming to\nthe races': 17, 'Of course, I\'ll go," he decided, lifting his head from the\nbook': 12, 'And as he vividly pictured the happiness of seeing her, his face\nlighted up': 14, '"Send to my house, and tell them to have out the carriage and three\nhorses as quick as they can," he said to the servant, who handed him\nthe steak on a hot silver dish, and moving the dish up he began eating': 43, 'From the billiard room next door came the sound of balls knocking, of\ntalk and laughter': 16, 'Two officers appeared at the entrance-door: one, a\nyoung fellow, with a feeble, delicate face, who had lately joined the\nregiment from the Corps of Pages; the other, a plump, elderly officer,\nwith a bracelet on his wrist, and little eyes, lost in fat': 44, 'Vronsky glanced at them, frowned, and looking down at his book as\nthough he had not noticed them, he proceeded to eat and read at the\nsame time': 28, '"What': 1, 'Fortifying yourself for your work': 5, '" said the plump officer,\nsitting down beside him': 9, '"As you see," responded Vronsky, knitting his brows, wiping his mouth,\nand not looking at the officer': 17, '"So you\'re not afraid of getting fat': 7, '" said the latter, turning a chair\nround for the young officer': 12, '" said Vronsky angrily, making a wry face of disgust, and showing\nhis even teeth': 15, '"You\'re not afraid of getting fat': 6, '"\n\n"Waiter, sherry': 3, '" said Vronsky, without replying, and moving the book\nto the other side of him, he went on reading': 19, 'The plump officer took up the list of wines and turned to the young\nofficer': 15, '"You choose what we\'re to drink," he said, handing him the card, and\nlooking at him': 16, '"Rhine wine, please," said the young officer, stealing a timid glance\nat Vronsky, and trying to pull his scarcely visible mustache': 21, 'Seeing\nthat Vronsky did not turn round, the young officer got up': 12, '"Let\'s go into the billiard room," he said': 8, 'The plump officer rose submissively, and they moved towards the door': 11, 'At that moment there walked into the room the tall and well-built\nCaptain Yashvin': 14, 'Nodding with an air of lofty contempt to the two\nofficers, he went up to Vronsky': 16, '"Ah': 1, 'here he is': 3, '" he cried, bringing his big hand down heavily on his\nepaulet': 12, 'Vronsky looked round angrily, but his face lighted up\nimmediately with his characteristic expression of genial and manly\nserenity': 19, '"That\'s it, Alexey," said the captain, in his loud baritone': 10, '"You must\njust eat a mouthful, now, and drink only one tiny glass': 13, '"\n\n"Oh, I\'m not hungry': 5, '"\n\n"There go the inseparables," Yashvin dropped, glancing sarcastically at\nthe two officers who were at that instant leaving the room': 21, 'And he bent\nhis long legs, swathed in tight riding breeches, and sat down in the\nchair, too low for him, so that his knees were cramped up in a sharp\nangle': 32, '"Why didn\'t you turn up at the Red Theater yesterday': 10, "Numerova wasn't\nat all bad": 5, 'Where were you': 3, '"\n\n"I was late at the Tverskoys\'," said Vronsky': 9, '" responded Yashvin': 3, "Yashvin, a gambler and a rake, a man not merely without moral\nprinciples, but of immoral principles, Yashvin was Vronsky's greatest\nfriend in the regiment": 25, 'Vronsky liked him both for his exceptional\nphysical strength, which he showed for the most part by being able to\ndrink like a fish, and do without sleep without being in the slightest\ndegree affected by it; and for his great strength of character, which\nhe showed in his relations with his comrades and superior officers,\ncommanding both fear and respect, and also at cards, when he would play\nfor tens of thousands and however much he might have drunk, always with\nsuch skill and decision that he was reckoned the best player in the\nEnglish Club': 97, 'Vronsky respected and liked Yashvin particularly because\nhe felt Yashvin liked him, not for his name and his money, but for\nhimself': 22, 'And of all men he was the only one with whom Vronsky would\nhave liked to speak of his love': 20, 'He felt that Yashvin, in spite of his\napparent contempt for every sort of feeling, was the only man who\ncould, so he fancied, comprehend the intense passion which now filled\nhis whole life': 34, 'Moreover, he felt certain that Yashvin, as it was, took\nno delight in gossip and scandal, and interpreted his feeling rightly,\nthat is to say, knew and believed that this passion was not a jest, not\na pastime, but something more serious and important': 44, 'Vronsky had never spoken to him of his passion, but he was aware that\nhe knew all about it, and that he put the right interpretation on it,\nand he was glad to see that in his eyes': 38, 'yes," he said, to the announcement that Vronsky had been at the\nTverskoys\'; and his black eyes shining, he plucked at his left\nmustache, and began twisting it into his mouth, a bad habit he had': 36, '"Well, and what did you do yesterday': 7, 'Win anything': 2, '" asked Vronsky': 3, '"Eight thousand': 2, "But three don't count; he won't pay up": 8, '"\n\n"Oh, then you can afford to lose over me," said Vronsky, laughing': 13, '(Yashvin had bet heavily on Vronsky in the races': 9, ')\n\n"No chance of my losing': 6, "Mahotin's the only one that's risky": 6, '"\n\nAnd the conversation passed to forecasts of the coming race, the only\nthing Vronsky could think of just now': 20, '"Come along, I\'ve finished," said Vronsky, and getting up he went to\nthe door': 14, 'Yashvin got up too, stretching his long legs and his long\nback': 12, '"It\'s too early for me to dine, but I must have a drink': 13, "I'll come\nalong directly": 4, 'Hi, wine': 2, '" he shouted, in his rich voice, that always\nrang out so loudly at drill, and set the windows shaking now': 21, '"No, all right," he shouted again immediately after': 8, '"You\'re going\nhome, so I\'ll go with you': 8, '"\n\nAnd he walked out with Vronsky': 7, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART TWO', {'Vronsky was staying in a roomy, clean, Finnish hut, divided into two by\na partition': 15, 'Petritsky lived with him in camp too': 7, 'Petritsky was asleep\nwhen Vronsky and Yashvin came into the hut': 11, '"Get up, don\'t go on sleeping," said Yashvin, going behind the\npartition and giving Petritsky, who was lying with ruffled hair and\nwith his nose in the pillow, a prod on the shoulder': 33, 'Petritsky jumped up suddenly onto his knees and looked round': 10, '"Your brother\'s been here," he said to Vronsky': 8, '"He waked me up, damn\nhim, and said he\'d look in again': 12, '" And pulling up the rug he flung\nhimself back on the pillow': 13, '"Oh, do shut up, Yashvin': 5, '" he said, getting\nfurious with Yashvin, who was pulling the rug off him': 14,
