('TOL CHAPTER 21 PART TWO', {'The temporary stable, a wooden shed, had been put up close to the race\ncourse, and there his mare was to have been taken the previous day': 27, 'He\nhad not yet seen her there': 7, 'During the last few days he had not ridden her out for exercise\nhimself, but had put her in the charge of the trainer, and so now he\npositively did not know in what condition his mare had arrived\nyesterday and was today': 43, 'He had scarcely got out of his carriage when\nhis groom, the so-called "stable boy," recognizing the carriage some\nway off, called the trainer': 24, 'A dry-looking Englishman, in high boots\nand a short jacket, clean-shaven, except for a tuft below his chin,\ncame to meet him, walking with the uncouth gait of jockey, turning his\nelbows out and swaying from side to side': 39, '"Well, how\'s Frou-Frou': 3, '" Vronsky asked in English': 5, '"All right, sir," the Englishman\'s voice responded somewhere in the\ninside of his throat': 14, '"Better not go in," he added, touching his hat': 9, '"I\'ve put a muzzle on her, and the mare\'s fidgety': 10, "Better not go in,\nit'll excite the mare": 8, '"\n\n"No, I\'m going in': 5, 'I want to look at her': 6, '"\n\n"Come along, then," said the Englishman, frowning, and speaking with\nhis mouth shut, and, with swinging elbows, he went on in front with his\ndisjointed gait': 27, 'They went into the little yard in front of the shed': 11, 'A stable boy,\nspruce and smart in his holiday attire, met them with a broom in his\nhand, and followed them': 21, 'In the shed there were five horses in their\nseparate stalls, and Vronsky knew that his chief rival, Gladiator, a\nvery tall chestnut horse, had been brought there, and must be standing\namong them': 34, 'Even more than his mare, Vronsky longed to see Gladiator,\nwhom he had never seen': 15, 'But he knew that by the etiquette of the race\ncourse it was not merely impossible for him to see the horse, but\nimproper even to ask questions about him': 30, 'Just as he was passing along\nthe passage, the boy opened the door into the second horse-box on the\nleft, and Vronsky caught a glimpse of a big chestnut horse with white\nlegs': 33, "He knew that this was Gladiator, but, with the feeling of a man\nturning away from the sight of another man's open letter, he turned\nround and went into Frou-Frou's stall": 31, '"The horse is here belonging to Mak': 7, 'Mak': 1, 'I never can say the\nname," said the Englishman, over his shoulder, pointing his big finger\nand dirty nail towards Gladiator\'s stall': 22, '"Mahotin': 1, 'Yes, he\'s my most serious rival," said Vronsky': 8, '"If you were riding him," said the Englishman, "I\'d bet on you': 12, '"\n\n"Frou-Frou\'s more nervous; he\'s stronger," said Vronsky, smiling at the\ncompliment to his riding': 15, '"In a steeplechase it all depends on riding and on pluck," said the\nEnglishman': 14, 'Of pluck—that is, energy and courage—Vronsky did not merely feel that\nhe had enough; what was of far more importance, he was firmly convinced\nthat no one in the world could have more of this "pluck" than he had': 39, '"Don\'t you think I want more thinning down': 8, '"\n\n"Oh, no," answered the Englishman': 6, '"Please, don\'t speak loud': 4, 'The\nmare\'s fidgety," he added, nodding towards the horse-box, before which\nthey were standing, and from which came the sound of restless stamping\nin the straw': 26, 'He opened the door, and Vronsky went into the horse-box, dimly lighted\nby one little window': 16, 'In the horse-box stood a dark bay mare, with a\nmuzzle on, picking at the fresh straw with her hoofs': 20, 'Looking round him\nin the twilight of the horse-box, Vronsky unconsciously took in once\nmore in a comprehensive glance all the points of his favorite mare': 26, "Frou-Frou was a beast of medium size, not altogether free from\nreproach, from a breeder's point of view": 18, 'She was small-boned all over;\nthough her chest was extremely prominent in front, it was narrow': 16, 'Her\nhind-quarters were a little drooping, and in her fore-legs, and still\nmore in her hind-legs, there was a noticeable curvature': 21, 'The muscles of\nboth hind- and fore-legs were not very thick; but across her shoulders\nthe mare was exceptionally broad, a peculiarity specially striking now\nthat she was lean from training': 31, 'The bones of her legs below the knees\nlooked no thicker than a finger from in front, but were extraordinarily\nthick seen from the side': 25, 'She looked altogether, except across the\nshoulders, as it were, pinched in at the sides and pressed out in\ndepth': 20, 'But she had in the highest degree the quality that makes all\ndefects forgotten: that quality was _blood_, the blood _that tells_, as\nthe English expression has it': 28, 'The muscles stood up sharply under the\nnetwork of sinews, covered with the delicate, mobile skin, soft as\nsatin, and they were hard as bone': 25, 'Her clean-cut head, with prominent,\nbright, spirited eyes, broadened out at the open nostrils, that showed\nthe red blood in the cartilage within': 23, 'About all her figure, and\nespecially her head, there was a certain expression of energy, and, at\nthe same time, of softness': 22, 'She was one of those creatures which seem\nonly not to speak because the mechanism of their mouth does not allow\nthem to': 23, 'To Vronsky, at any rate, it seemed that she understood all he felt at\nthat moment, looking at her': 19, 'Directly Vronsky went towards her, she drew in a deep breath, and,\nturning back her prominent eye till the white looked bloodshot, she\nstarted at the approaching figures from the opposite side, shaking her\nmuzzle, and shifting lightly from one leg to the other': 44, '"There, you see how fidgety she is," said the Englishman': 10, '"There, darling': 2, 'There': 1, '" said Vronsky, going up to the mare and\nspeaking soothingly to her': 13, 'But the nearer he came, the more excited she grew': 10, 'Only when he stood\nby her head, she was suddenly quieter, while the muscles quivered under\nher soft, delicate coat': 20, "Vronsky patted her strong neck, straightened\nover her sharp withers a stray lock of her mane that had fallen on the\nother side, and moved his face near her dilated nostrils, transparent\nas a bat's wing": 36, 'She drew a loud breath and snorted out through her\ntense nostrils, started, pricked up her sharp ear, and put out her\nstrong, black lip towards Vronsky, as though she would nip hold of his\nsleeve': 36, 'But remembering the muzzle, she shook it and again began\nrestlessly stamping one after the other her shapely legs': 19, '"Quiet, darling, quiet': 3, '" he said, patting her again over her\nhind-quarters; and with a glad sense that his mare was in the best\npossible condition, he went out of the horse-box': 29, "The mare's excitement had infected Vronsky": 6, 'He felt that his heart was\nthrobbing, and that he, too, like the mare, longed to move, to bite; it\nwas both dreadful and delicious': 25, '"Well, I rely on you, then," he said to the Englishman; "half-past six\non the ground': 16, '"\n\n"All right," said the Englishman': 6, '"Oh, where are you going, my lord': 7, '"\nhe asked suddenly, using the title "my lord," which he had scarcely\never used before': 16, "Vronsky in amazement raised his head, and stared, as he knew how to\nstare, not into the Englishman's eyes, but at his forehead, astounded\nat the impertinence of his question": 30, 'But realizing that in asking this\nthe Englishman had been looking at him not as an employer, but as a\njockey, he answered:\n\n"I\'ve got to go to Bryansky\'s; I shall be home within an hour': 36, '"\n\n"How often I\'m asked that question today': 8, '" he said to himself, and he\nblushed, a thing which rarely happened to him': 15, 'The Englishman looked\ngravely at him; and, as though he, too, knew where Vronsky was going,\nhe added:\n\n"The great thing\'s to keep quiet before a race," said he; "don\'t get\nout of temper or upset about anything': 38, '"\n\n"All right," answered Vronsky, smiling; and jumping into his carriage,\nhe told the man to drive to Peterhof': 19, 'Before he had driven many paces away, the dark clouds that had been\nthreatening rain all day broke, and there was a heavy downpour of rain': 26, '"What a pity': 3, '" thought Vronsky, putting up the roof of the carriage': 10, '"It was muddy before, now it will be a perfect swamp': 11, '" As he sat in\nsolitude in the closed carriage, he took out his mother\'s letter and\nhis brother\'s note, and read them through': 24, 'Yes, it was the same thing over and over again': 10, 'Everyone, his mother,\nhis brother, everyone thought fit to interfere in the affairs of his\nheart': 16, 'This interference aroused in him a feeling of angry hatred—a\nfeeling he had rarely known before': 16, '"What business is it of theirs': 6, 'Why\ndoes everybody feel called upon to concern himself about me': 11, 'And why do\nthey worry me so': 7, "Just because they see that this is something they\ncan't understand": 11, 'If it were a common, vulgar, worldly intrigue, they\nwould have left me alone': 14, 'They feel that this is something different,\nthat this is not a mere pastime, that this woman is dearer to me than\nlife': 23, "And this is incomprehensible, and that's why it annoys them": 10, 'Whatever our destiny is or may be, we have made it ourselves, and we do\nnot complain of it," he said, in the word _we_ linking himself with\nAnna': 29, '"No, they must needs teach us how to live': 9, 'They haven\'t an idea\nof what happiness is; they don\'t know that without our love, for us\nthere is neither happiness nor unhappiness—no life at all," he thought': 28, 'He was angry with all of them for their interference just because he\nfelt in his soul that they, all these people, were right': 24, 'He felt that\nthe love that bound him to Anna was not a momentary impulse, which\nwould pass, as worldly intrigues do pass, leaving no other traces in\nthe life of either but pleasant or unpleasant memories': 37, 'He felt all the\ntorture of his own and her position, all the difficulty there was for\nthem, conspicuous as they were in the eye of all the world, in\nconcealing their love, in lying and deceiving; and in lying, deceiving,\nfeigning, and continually thinking of others, when the passion that\nunited them was so intense that they were both oblivious of everything\nelse but their love': 67, 'He vividly recalled all the constantly recurring instances of\ninevitable necessity for lying and deceit, which were so against his\nnatural bent': 22, 'He recalled particularly vividly the shame he had more\nthan once detected in her at this necessity for lying and deceit': 21, 'And\nhe experienced the strange feeling that had sometimes come upon him\nsince his secret love for Anna': 18, 'This was a feeling of loathing for\nsomething—whether for Alexey Alexandrovitch, or for himself, or for the\nwhole world, he could not have said': 24, 'But he always drove away this\nstrange feeling': 8, 'Now, too, he shook it off and continued the thread of\nhis thoughts': 13, '"Yes, she was unhappy before, but proud and at peace; and now she\ncannot be at peace and feel secure in her dignity, though she does not\nshow it': 29, 'Yes, we must put an end to it," he decided': 10, 'And for the first time the idea clearly presented itself that it was\nessential to put an end to this false position, and the sooner the\nbetter': 27, '"Throw up everything, she and I, and hide ourselves somewhere\nalone with our love," he said to himself': 18, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 22 PART TWO', {'The rain did not last long, and by the time Vronsky arrived, his\nshaft-horse trotting at full speed and dragging the trace-horses\ngalloping through the mud, with their reins hanging loose, the sun had\npeeped out again, the roofs of the summer villas and the old limetrees\nin the gardens on both sides of the principal streets sparkled with wet\nbrilliance, and from the twigs came a pleasant drip and from the roofs\nrushing streams of water': 77, 'He thought no more of the shower spoiling the\nrace course, but was rejoicing now that—thanks to the rain—he would be\nsure to find her at home and alone, as he knew that Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, who had lately returned from a foreign watering place,\nhad not moved from Petersburg': 49, 'Hoping to find her alone, Vronsky alighted, as he always did, to avoid\nattracting attention, before crossing the bridge, and walked to the\nhouse': 24, 'He did not go up the steps to the street door, but went into the\ncourt': 16, '"Has your master come': 4, '" he asked a gardener': 5, '"No, sir': 2, 'The mistress is at home': 5, 'But will you please go to the front\ndoor; there are servants there," the gardener answered': 16, '"They\'ll open\nthe door': 4, '"\n\n"No, I\'ll go in from the garden': 8, '"\n\nAnd feeling satisfied that she was alone, and wanting to take her by\nsurprise, since he had not promised to be there today, and she would\ncertainly not expect him to come before the races, he walked, holding\nhis sword and stepping cautiously over the sandy path, bordered with\nflowers, to the terrace that looked out upon the garden': 60, 'Vronsky forgot\nnow all that he had thought on the way of the hardships and\ndifficulties of their position': 19, 'He thought of nothing but that he would\nsee her directly, not in imagination, but living, all of her, as she\nwas in reality': 24, 'He was just going in, stepping on his whole foot so as\nnot to creak, up the worn steps of the terrace, when he suddenly\nremembered what he always forgot, and what caused the most torturing\nside of his relations with her, her son with his questioning—hostile,\nas he fancied—eyes': 50, 'This boy was more often than anyone else a check upon their freedom': 13, 'When he was present, both Vronsky and Anna did not merely avoid\nspeaking of anything that they could not have repeated before everyone;\nthey did not even allow themselves to refer by hints to anything the\nboy did not understand': 40, 'They had made no agreement about this, it had\nsettled itself': 11, 'They would have felt it wounding themselves to deceive\nthe child': 11, 'In his presence they talked like acquaintances': 7, "But in spite\nof this caution, Vronsky often saw the child's intent, bewildered\nglance fixed upon him, and a strange shyness, uncertainty, at one time\nfriendliness, at another, coldness and reserve, in the boy's manner to\nhim; as though the child felt that between this man and his mother\nthere existed some important bond, the significance of which he could\nnot understand": 62, 'As a fact, the boy did feel that he could not understand this relation,\nand he tried painfully, and was not able to make clear to himself what\nfeeling he ought to have for this man': 36, "With a child's keen instinct for\nevery manifestation of feeling, he saw distinctly that his father, his\ngoverness, his nurse,—all did not merely dislike Vronsky, but looked on\nhim with horror and aversion, though they never said anything about\nhim, while his mother looked on him as her greatest friend": 50, '"What does it mean': 4, 'Who is he': 3, 'How ought I to love him': 6, 'If I don\'t\nknow, it\'s my fault; either I\'m stupid or a naughty boy," thought the\nchild': 17, 'And this was what caused his dubious, inquiring, sometimes\nhostile, expression, and the shyness and uncertainty which Vronsky\nfound so irksome': 21, "This child's presence always and infallibly called up\nin Vronsky that strange feeling of inexplicable loathing which he had\nexperienced of late": 22, "This child's presence called up both in Vronsky\nand in Anna a feeling akin to the feeling of a sailor who sees by the\ncompass that the direction in which he is swiftly moving is far from\nthe right one, but that to arrest his motion is not in his power, that\nevery instant is carrying him further and further away, and that to\nadmit to himself his deviation from the right direction is the same as\nadmitting his certain ruin": 81, 'This child, with his innocent outlook upon life, was the compass that\nshowed them the point to which they had departed from what they knew,\nbut did not want to know': 31, 'This time Seryozha was not at home, and she was completely alone': 12, 'She\nwas sitting on the terrace waiting for the return of her son, who had\ngone out for his walk and been caught in the rain': 26, 'She had sent a\nmanservant and a maid out to look for him': 13, 'Dressed in a white gown,\ndeeply embroidered, she was sitting in a corner of the terrace behind\nsome flowers, and did not hear him': 24, 'Bending her curly black head, she\npressed her forehead against a cool watering pot that stood on the\nparapet, and both her lovely hands, with the rings he knew so well,\nclasped the pot': 34, 'The beauty of her whole figure, her head, her neck,\nher hands, struck Vronsky every time as something new and unexpected': 21, 'He stood still, gazing at her in ecstasy': 8, 'But, directly he would have\nmade a step to come nearer to her, she was aware of his presence,\npushed away the watering pot, and turned her flushed face towards him': 31, '"What\'s the matter': 3, 'You are ill': 3, '" he said to her in French, going up to\nher': 11, 'He would have run to her, but remembering that there might be\nspectators, he looked round towards the balcony door, and reddened a\nlittle, as he always reddened, feeling that he had to be afraid and be\non his guard': 40, '"No, 12, 'He\nsaw it, and his face expressed that utter subjection, that slavish\ndevotion, which had done so much to win her': 21, '"I see something has happened': 5, 'Do you suppose I can be at been longing for\nhad come now; that it was impossible to go on concealing things from\nher husband, and it was inevitable in one way or another that they\nshould soon put an end to their unnatural position': 50, 'But, besides that,\nher emotion physically affected him in the same way': 12, 'He looked at her\nwith a look of submissive tenderness, kissed her hand, got up, and, in\nsilence, paced up and down the terrace': 24, '"Yes," he said, going up to her resolutely': 8, '"Neither you nor I have\nlooked on our relations as a passing amusement, and now our fate is\nsealed': 19, 'It is absolutely necessary to put an end"—he looked round as he\nspoke—"to the deception in which we are living': 20, '"\n\n"Put an end': 4, 'How put an end, Alexey': 5, '" she said softly': 4, 'She was calmer now, and her face lighted up with a tender smile': 13, '"Leave your husband and make our life one': 8, '"\n\n"It is one as it is," she answered, scarcely audibly': 11, '"Yes, but altogether; altogether': 4, '"\n\n"But how, Alexey, tell me how': 7, '" she said in melancholy mockery at the\nhopelessness of her own position': 13, '"Is there any way out of such a\nposition': 9, 'Am I not the wife of my husband': 8, '"\n\n"There is a way out of every position': 9, 'We must take our line," he said': 7, '"Anything\'s better than the position in which you\'re living': 9, 'Of course,\nI see how you torture yourself over everything—the world and your son\nand your husband': 17, '"\n\n"Oh, not over my husband," she said, with a quiet smile': 12, '"I don\'t know\nhim, I don\'t think of him': 9, "He doesn't exist": 3, '"\n\n"You\'re not speaking sincerely': 5, 'I know you': 3, 'You worry about him too': 5, '"\n\n"Oh, he doesn\'t even know," she said, and suddenly a hot flush came\nover her face; her cheeks, her brow, her neck crimsoned, and tears of\nshame came into her eyes': 32, '"But we won\'t talk of him': 6, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 23 PART TWO', {'Vronsky had several times already, though not so resolutely as now,\ntried to bring her to consider their position, and every time he had\nbeen confronted by the same superficiality and triviality with which\nshe met his appeal now': 39, 'It was as though there were something in this\nwhich she could not or would not face, as though directly she began to\nspeak of this, she, the real Anna, retreated somehow into herself, and\nanother strange and unaccountable woman came out, whom he did not love,\nand whom he feared, and who was in opposition to him': 58, 'But today he was\nresolved to have it out': 9, '"Whether he knows or not," said Vronsky, in his usual quiet and\nresolute tone, "that\'s nothing to do with us': 20, 'We cannot': 2, 'you cannot\nstay like this, especially now': 7, '"\n\n"What\'s to be done, according to you': 8, '" she asked with the same\nfrivolous irony': 8, 'She who had so feared he would take her condition too\nlightly was now vexed with him for deducing from it the necessity of\ntaking some step': 27, '"Tell him everything, and leave him': 6, '"\n\n"Very well, let us suppose I do that," she said': 11, '"Do you know what the\nresult of that would be': 10, 'I can tell you it all beforehand," and a\nwicked light gleamed in her eyes, that had been so soft a minute\nbefore': 23, '"‘Eh, you love another man, and have entered into criminal\nintrigues with him': 13, '\'" (Mimicking her husband, she threw an emphasis on\nthe word "criminal," as Alexey Alexandrovitch did': 16, ') "‘I warned you of\nthe results in the religious, the civil, and the domestic relation': 16, 'You\nhave not listened to me': 6, 'Now I cannot let you disgrace my name,—\'" "and\nmy son," she had meant to say, but about her son she could not\njest,—"‘disgrace my name, and\'—and more in the same style," she added': 34, '"In general terms, he\'ll say in his official manner, and with all\ndistinctness and precision, that he cannot let me go, but will take all\nmeasures in his power to prevent scandal': 32, 'And he will calmly and\npunctually act in accordance with his words': 12, "That's what will happen": 4, 'He\'s not a man, but a machine, and a spiteful machine when he\'s angry,"\nshe added, recalling Alexey Alexandrovitch as she spoke, with all the\npeculiarities of his figure and manner of speaking, and reckoning\nagainst him every defect she could find in him, softening nothing for\nthe great wrong she herself was doing him': 55, '"But, Anna," said Vronsky, in a soft and persuasive voice, trying to\nsoothe her, "we absolutely must, anyway, tell him, and then be guided\nby the line he takes': 29, '"\n\n"What, run away': 4, '"\n\n"And why not run away': 6, "I don't see how we can keep on like this": 10, 'And\nnot for my sake—I see that you suffer': 9, '"\n\n"Yes, run away, and become your mistress," she said angrily': 11, '"Anna," he said, with reproachful tenderness': 6, '"Yes," she went on, "become your mistress, and complete the ruin\nof': 12, '"\n\nAgain she would have said "my son," but she could not utter that word': 15, 'Vronsky could not understand how she, with her strong and truthful\nnature, could endure this state of deceit, and not long to get out of\nit': 26, 'But he did not suspect that the chief cause of it was the\nword—_son_, which she could not bring herself to pronounce': 22, 'When she\nthought of her son, and his future attitude to his mother, who had\nabandoned his father, she felt such terror at what she had done, that\nshe could not face it; but, like a woman, could only try to comfort\nherself with lying assurances that everything would remain as it always\nhad been, and that it was possible to forget the fearful question of\nhow it would be with her son': 73, '"I beg you, I entreat you," she said suddenly, taking his hand, and\nspeaking in quite a different tone, sincere and tender, "never speak to\nme of that': 28, '"\n\n"But, Anna': 3, '"\n\n"Never': 2, 'Leave it to me': 4, "I know all the baseness, all the horror of my\nposition; but it's not so easy to arrange as you think": 21, 'And leave it to\nme, and do what I say': 10, 'Never speak to me of peace": 11, '"\n\n"I': 2, '" she repeated': 3, '"Yes, I am worried sometimes; but that will pass, if\nyou will never talk about this': 16, "When you talk about it—it's only then\nit worries me": 10, '"\n\n"I don\'t understand," he said': 6, '"I know," she interrupted him, "how hard it is for your truthful nature\nto lie, and I grieve for you': 20, 'I often think that you have ruined your\nwhole 3, '" she said, coming closer to him, and looking at him with an\necstatic smile of love': 17, '"I am like a hungry man who has been given\nfood': 11, 'He may be cold, and dressed in rags, and ashamed, but he is not\nunhappy': 15, 'I unhappy': 2, 'No, this is my unhappiness': 5, '"\n\nShe could hear the sound of her son\'s voice coming towards them, and\nglancing swiftly round the terrace, she got up impulsively': 23, 'Her eyes\nglowed with the fire he knew so well; with a rapid movement she raised\nher lovely hands, covered with rings, took his head, looked a long look\ninto his face, and, putting up her face with smiling, parted lips,\nswiftly kissed his mouth and both eyes, and pushed him away': 52, 'She would\nhave gone, but he held her back': 9, '"When': 1, '" he murmured in a whisper, gazing in ecstasy at her': 11, '"Tonight, at one o\'clock," she whispered, and, with a heavy sigh, she\nwalked with her light, swift step to meet her son': 22, 'Seryozha had been caught by to fetch me': 5, '"\n\nVronsky, looking at his watch, went away hurriedly': 9, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 24 PART TWO', {"When Vronsky looked at his watch on the Karenins' balcony, he was so\ngreatly agitated and lost in his thoughts that he saw the figures on\nthe watch's face, but could not take in what time it was": 38, 'He came out\non to the highroad and walked, picking his way carefully through the\nmud, to his carriage': 19, "He was so completely absorbed in his feeling for\nAnna, that he did not even think what o'clock it was, and whether he\nhad time to go to Bryansky's": 29, 'He had left him, as often happens, only\nthe external faculty of memory, that points out each step one has to\ntake, one after the other': 26, "He went up to his coachman, who was dozing\non the box in the shadow, already lengthening, of a thick limetree; he\nadmired the shifting clouds of midges circling over the hot horses,\nand, waking the coachman, he jumped into the carriage, and told him to\ndrive to Bryansky's": 49, 'It was only after driving nearly five miles that\nhe had sufficiently recovered himself to look at his watch, and realize\nthat it was half-past five, and he was late': 30, "There were several races fixed for that day: the Mounted Guards' race,\nthen the officers' mile-and-a-half race, then the three-mile race, and\nthen the race for which he was entered": 30, "He could still be in time for\nhis race, but if he went to Bryansky's he could only just be in time,\nand he would arrive when the whole of the court would be in their\nplaces": 37, 'That would be a pity': 5, 'But he had promised Bryansky to come, and\nso he decided to drive on, telling the coachman not to spare the\nhorses': 22, "He reached Bryansky's, spent five minutes there, and galloped back": 10, 'This rapid drive calmed him': 5, 'All that was painful in his relations with\nAnna, all the feeling of indefiniteness left by their conversation, had\nslipped out of his mind': 24, 'He was thinking now with pleasure and\nexcitement of the race, of his being anyhow, in time, and now and then\nthe thought of the blissful interview awaiting him that night flashed\nacross his imagination like a flaming light': 39, 'The excitement of the approaching race gained upon him as he drove\nfurther and further into the atmosphere of the races, overtaking\ncarriages driving up from the summer villas or out of Petersburg': 33, 'At his quarters no one was left at home; all were at the races, and his\nvalet was looking out for him at the gate': 25, 'While he was changing his\nclothes, his valet told him that the second race had begun already,\nthat a lot of gentlemen had been to ask for him, and a boy had twice\nrun up from the stables': 38, 'Dressing without hurry (he never hurried\nhimself, and never lost his self-possession), Vronsky drove to the\nsheds': 17, 'From the sheds he could see a perfect sea of carriages, and\npeople on foot, soldiers surrounding the race course, and pavilions\nswarming with people': 25, 'The second race was apparently going on, for just\nas he went into the sheds he heard a bell ringing': 20, "Going towards the\nstable, he met the white-legged chestnut, Mahotin's Gladiator, being\nled to the race-course in a blue forage horsecloth, with what looked\nlike huge ears edged with blue": 30, '"Where\'s Cord': 2, '" he asked the stable-boy': 5, '"In the stable, putting on the saddle': 7, '"\n\nIn the open horse-box stood Frou-Frou, saddled ready': 9, 'They were just\ngoing to lead her out': 8, '"I\'m not too late': 4, '"\n\n"All right': 3, 'All right': 2, '" said the Englishman; "don\'t upset yourself': 7, '"\n\nVronsky once more took in in one glance the exquisite lines of his\nfavorite mare; who was quivering all over, and with an effort he tore\nhimself from the sight of her, and went out of the stable': 39, 'He went\ntowards the pavilions at the most favorable moment for escaping\nattention': 13, 'The mile-and-a-half race was just finishing, and all eyes\nwere fixed on the horse-guard in front and the light hussar behind,\nurging their horses on with a last effort close to the winning post': 34, 'From the center and outside of the ring all were crowding to the\nwinning post, and a group of soldiers and officers of the horse-guards\nwere shouting loudly their delight at the expected triumph of their\nofficer and comrade': 39, 'Vronsky moved into the middle of the crowd\nunnoticed, almost at the very moment when the bell rang at the finish\nof the race, and the tall, mudspattered horse-guard who came in first,\nbending over the saddle, let go the reins of his panting gray horse\nthat looked dark with sweat': 51, 'The horse, stiffening out its legs, with an effort stopped its rapid\ncourse, and the officer of the horse-guards looked round him like a man\nwaking up from a heavy sleep, and just managed to smile': 36, 'A crowd of\nfriends and outsiders pressed round him': 9, 'Vronsky intentionally avoided that select crowd of the upper world,\nwhich was moving and talking with discreet freedom before the\npavilions': 21, "He knew that Madame Karenina was there, and Betsy, and his\nbrother's wife, and he purposely did not go near them for fear of\nsomething distracting his attention": 28, 'But he was continually met and\nstopped by acquaintances, who told him about the previous races, and\nkept asking him why he was so late': 25, "At the time when the racers had to go to the pavilion to receive the\nprizes, and all attention was directed to that point, Vronsky's elder\nbrother, Alexander, a colonel with heavy fringed epaulets, came up to\nhim": 38, 'He was not tall, though as broadly built as Alexey, and handsomer\nand rosier than he; he had a red nose, and an open, drunken-looking\nface': 26, '"Did you get my note': 5, '" he said': 3, '"There\'s never any finding you': 5, '"\n\nAlexander Vronsky, in spite of the dissolute life, and in especial the\ndrunken habits, for which he was notorious, was quite one of the court\ncircle': 27, 'Now, as he talked to his brother of a matter bound to be exceedingly\ndisagreeable to him, knowing that the eyes of many people might be\nfixed upon him, he kept a smiling countenance, as though he were\njesting with his brother about something of little moment': 47, '"I got it, and I really can\'t make out what _you_ are worrying yourself\nabout," said Alexey': 17, '"I\'m worrying myself because the remark has just been made to me that\nyou weren\'t here, and that you were seen in Peterhof on Monday': 25, '"\n\n"There are matters which only concern those directly interested in\nthem, and the matter you are so worried about is': 21, '"\n\n"Yes, but if so, you may as well cut the service': 12, '"\n\n"I beg you not to meddle, and that\'s all I have to say': 14, '"\n\nAlexey Vronsky\'s frowning face turned white, and his prominent lower\njaw quivered, which happened rarely with him': 18, 'Being a man of very warm\nheart, he was seldom angry; but when he was angry, and when his chin\nquivered, then, as Alexander Vronsky knew, he was dangerous': 29, 'Alexander\nVronsky smiled gaily': 4, '"I only wanted to give you Mother\'s letter': 8, "Answer it, and don't worry\nabout anything just before the race": 11, '_Bonne chance,_" he added, smiling\nand he moved away from him': 11, 'But after him another friendly greeting\nbrought Vronsky to a standstill': 11, '"So you won\'t recognize your friends': 6, 'How are you, _mon cher': 5, '_" said\nStepan Arkadyevitch, as conspicuously brilliant in the midst of all the\nPetersburg brilliance as he was in Moscow, his face rosy, and his\nwhiskers sleek and glossy': 29, '"I came up yesterday, and I\'m delighted that\nI shall see your triumph': 13, 'When shall we meet': 4, '"\n\n"Come tomorrow to the messroom," said Vronsky, and squeezing him by the\nsleeve of his coat, with apologies, he moved away to the center of the\nrace course, where the horses were being led for the great\nsteeplechase': 39, 'The horses who had run in the last race were being led home, steaming\nand exhausted, by the stable-boys, and one after another the fresh\nhorses for the coming race made their appearance, for the most part\nEnglish racers, wearing horsecloths, and looking with their drawn-up\nbellies like strange, huge birds': 51, 'On the right was led in Frou-Frou,\nlean and beautiful, lifting up her elastic, rather long pasterns, as\nthough moved by springs': 22, 'Not far from her they were taking the rug off\nthe lop-eared Gladiator': 13, "The strong, exquisite, perfectly correct lines\nof the stallion, with his superb hind-quarters and excessively short\npasterns almost over his hoofs, attracted Vronsky's attention in spite\nof himself": 28, 'He would have gone up to his mare, but he was again\ndetained by an acquaintance': 16, '"Oh, there\'s Karenin': 3, '" said the acquaintance with whom he was chatting': 9, '"He\'s looking for his wife, and she\'s in the middle of the pavilion': 13, "Didn't you see her": 4, '"\n\n"No," answered Vronsky, and without even glancing round towards the\npavilion where his friend was pointing out Madame Karenina, he went up\nto his mare': 26, 'Vronsky had not had time to look at the saddle, about which he had to\ngive some direction, when the competitors were summoned to the pavilion\nto receive their numbers and places in the row at starting': 37, 'Seventeen\nofficers, looking serious and severe, many with pale faces, met\ntogether in the pavilion and drew the numbers': 19, 'Vronsky drew the number\nseven': 5, 'The cry was heard: "Mount': 5, '"\n\nFeeling that with the others riding in the race, he was the center upon\nwhich all eyes were fastened, Vronsky walked up to his mare in that\nstate of nervous tension in which he usually became deliberate and\ncomposed in his movements': 43, 'Cord, in honor of the races, had put on his\nbest clothes, a black coat buttoned up, a stiffly starched collar,\nwhich propped up his cheeks, a round black hat, and top boots': 33, 'He was\ncalm and dignified as ever, and was with his own hands holding\nFrou-Frou by both reins, standing straight in front of her': 24, 'Frou-Frou\nwas still trembling as though in a fever': 9, 'Her eye, full of fire,\nglanced sideways at Vronsky': 9, 'Vronsky slipped his finger under the\nsaddle-girth': 7, 'The mare glanced aslant at him, drew up her lip, and\ntwitched her ear': 14, 'The Englishman puckered up his lips, intending to\nindicate a smile that anyone should verify his saddling': 17, '"Get up; you won\'t feel so excited': 7, '"\n\nVronsky looked round for the last time at his rivals': 11, 'He knew that he\nwould not see them during the race': 11, 'Two were already riding forward to\nthe point from which they were to start': 14, "Galtsin, a friend of Vronsky's\nand one of his more formidable rivals, was moving round a bay horse\nthat would not let him mount": 24, 'A little light hussar in tight riding\nbreeches rode off at a gallop, crouched up like a cat on the saddle, in\nimitation of English jockeys': 26, 'Prince Kuzovlev sat with a white face on\nhis thoroughbred mare from the Grabovsky stud, while an English groom\nled her by the bridle': 24, 'Vronsky and all his comrades knew Kuzovlev and\nhis peculiarity of "weak nerves" and terrible vanity': 16, 'They knew that he\nwas afraid of everything, afraid of riding a spirited horse': 14, 'But now,\njust because it was terrible, because people broke their necks, and\nthere was a doctor standing at each obstacle, and an ambulance with a\ncross on it, and a sister of mercy, he had made up his mind to take\npart in the race': 46, 'Their eyes met, and Vronsky gave him a friendly and\nencouraging nod': 12, 'Only one he did not see, his chief rival, Mahotin on\nGladiator': 12, '"Don\'t be in a hurry," said Cord to Vronsky, "and remember one thing:\ndon\'t hold her in at the fences, and don\'t urge her on; let her go as\nshe likes': 31, '"\n\n"All right, all right," said Vronsky, taking the reins': 10, '"If you can, lead the race; but don\'t lose heart till the last minute,\neven if you\'re behind': 18, '"\n\nBefore the mare had time to move, Vronsky stepped with an agile,\nvigorous movement into the steel-toothed stirrup, and lightly and\nfirmly seated himself on the creaking leather of the saddle': 32, 'Getting\nhis right foot in the stirrup, he smoothed the double reins, as he\nalways did, between his fingers, and Cord let go': 23, 'As though she did not know which foot to put first, Frou-Frou started,\ndragging at the reins with her long neck, and as though she were on\nsprings, shaking her rider from side to side': 35, 'Cord quickened his step,\nfollowing him': 6, 'The excited mare, trying to shake off her rider first on\none side and then the other, pulled at the reins, and Vronsky tried in\nvain with voice and hand to soothe her': 33, 'They were just reaching the dammed-up stream on their way to the\nstarting point': 14, 'Several of the riders were in front and several behind,\nwhen suddenly Vronsky heard the sound of a horse galloping in the mud\nbehind him, and he was overtaken by Mahotin on his white-legged,\nlop-eared Gladiator': 36, 'Mahotin smiled, showing his long teeth, but\nVronsky looked angrily at him': 12, 'He did not like him, and regarded him\nnow as his most formidable rival': 14, 'He was angry with him for galloping\npast and exciting his mare': 12, 'Frou-Frou started into a gallop, her left\nfoot forward, made two bounds, and fretting at the tightened reins,\npassed into a jolting trot, bumping her rider up and down': 29, 'Cord, too,\nscowled, and followed Vronsky almost at a trot': 10, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 25 PART TWO', {'There were seventeen officers in all riding in this race': 10, 'The race\ncourse was a large three-mile ring of the form of an ellipse in front\nof the pavilion': 19, 'On this course nine obstacles had been arranged: the\nstream, a big and solid barrier five feet high, just before the\npavilion, a dry ditch, a ditch full of water, a precipitous slope, an\nIrish barricade (one of the most difficult obstacles, consisting of a\nmound fenced with brushwood, beyond which was a ditch out of sight for\nthe horses, so that the horse had to clear both obstacles or might be\nkilled); then two more ditches filled with water, and one dry one; and\nthe end of the race was just facing the pavilion': 95, 'But the race began\nnot in the ring, but two hundred yards away from it, and in that part\nof the course was the first obstacle, a dammed-up stream, seven feet in\nbreadth, which the racers could leap or wade through as they preferred': 44, 'Three times they were ranged ready to start, but each time some horse\nthrust itself out of line, and they had to begin again': 24, 'The umpire who\nwas starting them, Colonel Sestrin, was beginning to lose his temper,\nwhen at last for the fourth time he shouted "Away': 24, '" and the racers\nstarted': 5, 'Every eye, every opera-glass, was turned on the brightly colored group\nof riders at the moment they were in line to start': 22, '"They\'re off': 2, "They're starting": 2, '" was heard on all sides after the hush\nof expectation': 11, 'And little groups and solitary figures among the public began running\nfrom place to place to get a better view': 20, 'In the very first minute the\nclose group of horsemen drew out, and it could be seen that they were\napproaching the stream in twos and threes and one behind another': 31, 'To\nthe spectators it seemed as though they had all started simultaneously,\nbut to the racers there were seconds of difference that had great value\nto them': 27, "Frou-Frou, excited and over-nervous, had lost the first moment, and\nseveral horses had started before her, but before reaching the stream,\nVronsky, who was holding in the mare with all his force as she tugged\nat the bridle, easily overtook three, and there were left in front of\nhim Mahotin's chestnut Gladiator, whose hind-quarters were moving\nlightly and rhythmically up and down exactly in front of Vronsky, and\nin front of all, the dainty mare Diana bearing Kuzovlev more dead than\nalive": 82, 'For the first instant Vronsky was not master either of himself or his\nmare': 14, 'Up to the first obstacle, the stream, he could not guide the\nmotions of his mare': 16, "Gladiator and Diana came up to it together and almost at the same\ninstant; simultaneously they rose above the stream and flew across to\nthe other side; Frou-Frou darted after them, as if flying; but at the\nvery moment when Vronsky felt himself in the air, he suddenly saw\nalmost under his mare's hoofs Kuzovlev, who was floundering with Diana\non the further side of the stream": 67, '(Kuzovlev had let go the reins as he\ntook the leap, and the mare had sent him flying over her head': 21, ") Those\ndetails Vronsky learned later; at the moment all he saw was that just\nunder him, where Frou-Frou must alight, Diana's legs or head might be\nin the way": 30, 'But Frou-Frou drew up her legs and back in the very act of\nleaping, like a falling cat, and, clearing the other mare, alighted\nbeyond her': 26, '"O the darling': 3, '" thought Vronsky': 3, 'After crossing the stream Vronsky had complete control of his mare, and\nbegan holding her in, intending to cross the great barrier behind\nMahotin, and to try to overtake him in the clear ground of about five\nhundred yards that followed it': 42, 'The great barrier stood just in front of the imperial pavilion': 11, 'The\nTsar and the whole court and crowds of people were all gazing at\nthem—at him, and Mahotin a length ahead of him, as they drew near the\n"devil," as the solid barrier was called': 35, 'Vronsky was aware of those\neyes fastened upon him from all sides, but he saw nothing except the\nears and neck of his own mare, the ground racing to meet him, and the\nback and white legs of Gladiator beating time swiftly before him, and\nkeeping always the same distance ahead': 51, 'Gladiator rose, with no sound\nof knocking against anything': 9, "With a wave of his short tail he\ndisappeared from Vronsky's sight": 12, '"Bravo': 1, '" cried a voice': 4, "At the same instant, under Vronsky's eyes, right before him flashed the\npalings of the barrier": 16, 'Without the slightest change in her action his\nmare flew over it; the palings vanished, and he heard only a crash\nbehind him': 23, "The mare, excited by Gladiator's keeping ahead, had risen\ntoo soon before the barrier, and grazed it with her hind hoofs": 21, 'But her\npace never changed, and Vronsky, feeling a spatter of mud in his face,\nrealized that he was once more the same distance from Gladiator': 26, 'Once\nmore he perceived in front of him the same back and short tail, and\nagain the same swiftly moving white legs that got no further away': 27, 'At the very moment when Vronsky thought that now was the time to\novertake Mahotin, Frou-Frou herself, understanding his thoughts,\nwithout any incitement on his part, gained ground considerably, and\nbegan getting alongside of Mahotin on the most favorable side, close to\nthe inner cord': 45, 'Mahotin would not let her pass that side': 8, 'Vronsky had\nhardly formed the thought that he could perhaps pass on the outer side,\nwhen Frou-Frou shifted her pace and began overtaking him on the other\nside': 28, "Frou-Frou's shoulder, beginning by now to be dark with sweat, was\neven with Gladiator's back": 15, 'For a few lengths they moved evenly': 7, 'But\nbefore the obstacle they were approaching, Vronsky began working at the\nreins, anxious to avoid having to take the outer circle, and swiftly\npassed Mahotin just upon the declivity': 30, 'He caught a glimpse of his\nmud-stained face as he flashed by': 12, 'He even fancied that he smiled': 6, 'Vronsky passed Mahotin, but he was immediately aware of him close upon\nhim, and he never ceased hearing the even-thudding hoofs and the rapid\nand still quite fresh breathing of Gladiator': 31, 'The next two obstacles, the water course and the barrier, were easily\ncrossed, but Vronsky began to hear the snorting and thud of Gladiator\ncloser upon him': 27, "He urged on his mare, and to his delight felt that she\neasily quickened her pace, and the thud of Gladiator's hoofs was again\nheard at the same distance away": 30, 'Vronsky was at the head of the race, just as he wanted to be and as\nCord had advised, and now he felt sure of being the winner': 28, 'His\nexcitement, his delight, and his tenderness for Frou-Frou grew keener\nand keener': 13, 'He longed to look round again, but he did not dare do this,\nand tried to be cool and not to urge on his mare so to keep the same\nreserve of force in her as he felt that Gladiator still kept': 42, 'There\nremained only one obstacle, the most difficult; if he could cross it\nahead of the others he would come in first': 22, "He was flying towards the\nIrish barricade, Frou-Frou and he both together saw the barricade in\nthe distance, and both the man and the mare had a moment's hesitation": 29, "He saw the uncertainty in the mare's ears and lifted the whip, but at\nthe same time felt that his fears were groundless; the mare knew what\nwas wanted": 29, 'She quickened her pace and rose smoothly, just as he had\nfancied she would, and as she left the ground gave herself up to the\nforce of her rush, which carried her far beyond the ditch; and with the\nsame rhythm, without effort, with the same leg forward, Frou-Frou fell\nback into her pace again': 55, '"Bravo, Vronsky': 2, '" he heard shouts from a knot of men—he knew they were\nhis friends in the regiment—who were standing at the obstacle': 22, "He could\nnot fail to recognize Yashvin's voice though he did not see him": 14, '"O my sweet': 3, '" he said inwardly to Frou-Frou, as he listened for what\nwas happening behind': 14, '"He\'s cleared it': 3, '" he thought, catching the thud\nof Gladiator\'s hoofs behind him': 11, 'There remained only the last ditch,\nfilled with water and five feet wide': 13, "Vronsky did not even look at it,\nbut anxious to get in a long way first began sawing away at the reins,\nlifting the mare's head and letting it go in time with her paces": 35, 'He\nfelt that the mare was at her very last reserve of strength; not her\nneck and shoulders merely were wet, but the sweat was standing in drops\non her mane, her head, her sharp ears, and her breath came in short,\nsharp gasps': 44, 'But he knew that she had strength left more than enough\nfor the remaining five hundred yards': 17, 'It was only from feeling himself\nnearer the ground and from the peculiar smoothness of his motion that\nVronsky knew how greatly the mare had quickened her pace': 28, 'She flew over\nthe ditch as though not noticing it': 10, "She flew over it like a bird; but\nat the same instant Vronsky, to his horror, felt that he had failed to\nkeep up with the mare's pace, that he had, he did not know how, made a\nfearful, unpardonable mistake, in recovering his seat in the saddle": 48, 'All at once his position had shifted and he knew that something awful\nhad happened': 15, 'He could not yet make out what had happened, when the\nwhite legs of a chestnut horse flashed by close to him, and Mahotin\npassed at a swift gallop': 29, 'Vronsky was touching the ground with one\nfoot, and his mare was sinking on that foot': 16, 'He just had time to free\nhis leg when she fell on one side, gasping painfully, and, making vain\nefforts to rise with her delicate, soaking neck, she fluttered on the\nground at his feet like a shot bird': 39, 'The clumsy movement made by\nVronsky had broken her back': 10, 'But that he only knew much later': 7, 'At that\nmoment he knew only that Mahotin had flown swiftly by, while he stood\nstaggering alone on the muddy, motionless ground, and Frou-Frou lay\ngasping before him, bending her head back and gazing at him with her\nexquisite eyes': 40, "Still unable to realize what had happened, Vronsky\ntugged at his mare's reins": 13, 'Again she struggled all over like a fish,\nand her shoulders setting the saddle heaving, she rose on her front\nlegs but unable to lift her back, she quivered all over and again fell\non her side': 37, 'With a face hideous with passion, his lower jaw trembling,\nand his cheeks white, Vronsky kicked her with his heel in the stomach\nand again fell to tugging at the rein': 31, 'She did not stir, but thrusting\nher nose into the ground, she simply gazed at her master with her\nspeaking eyes': 21, '"A—a—a': 1, '" groaned Vronsky, clutching at his head': 7, '"Ah': 1, 'what have I\ndone': 4, '" he cried': 3, '"The race lost': 3, 'And my fault': 3, 'shameful, unpardonable': 2, 'And the poor darling, ruined mare': 6, 'Ah': 1, 'what have I done': 4, '"\n\nA crowd of men, a doctor and his assistant, the officers of his\nregiment, ran up to him': 19, 'To his misery he felt that he was whole and\nunhurt': 11, 'The mare had broken her back, and it was decided to shoot her': 13, 'Vronsky could not answer questions, could not speak to anyone': 10, 'He\nturned, and without picking up his cap that had fallen off, walked away\nfrom the race course, not knowing where he was going': 24, 'He felt utterly\nwretched': 4, 'For the first time in his life he knew the bitterest sort of\nmisfortune, misfortune beyond remedy, and caused by his own fault': 23, 'Yashvin overtook him with his cap, and led him home, and half an hour\nlater Vronsky had regained his self-possession': 20, 'But the memory of that\nrace remained for long in his heart, the cruelest and bitterest memory\nof his life': 20, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 26 PART TWO', {'The external relations of Alexey Alexandrovitch and his wife had\nremained unchanged': 12, 'The sole difference lay in the fact that he was\nmore busily occupied than ever': 15, "As in former years, at the beginning of\nthe spring he had gone to a foreign watering-place for the sake of his\nhealth, deranged by the winter's work that every year grew heavier": 33, 'And\njust as always he returned in July and at once fell to work as usual\nwith increased energy': 19, 'As usual, too, his wife had moved for the summer\nto a villa out of town, while he remained in Petersburg': 21, "From the date\nof their conversation after the party at Princess Tverskaya's he had\nnever spoken again to Anna of his suspicions and his jealousies, and\nthat habitual tone of his bantering mimicry was the most convenient\ntone possible for his present attitude to his wife": 46, 'He was a little\ncolder to his wife': 8, 'He simply seemed to be slightly displeased with her\nfor that first midnight conversation, which she had repelled': 18, 'In his\nattitude to her there was a shade of vexation, but nothing more': 14, '"You\nwould not be open with me," he seemed to say, mentally addressing her;\n"so much the worse for you': 20, "Now you may beg as you please, but I won't\nbe open with you": 14, 'So much the worse for you': 6, '" he said mentally, like a\nman who, after vainly attempting to extinguish a fire, should fly in a\nrage with his vain efforts and say, "Oh, very well then': 30, 'you shall burn\nfor this': 5, '" This man, so subtle and astute in official life, did not\nrealize all the senselessness of such an attitude to his wife': 23, 'He did\nnot realize it, because it was too terrible to him to realize his\nactual position, and he shut down and locked and sealed up in his heart\nthat secret place where lay hid his feelings towards his family, that\nis, his wife and son': 46, 'He who had been such a careful father, had from\nthe end of that winter become peculiarly frigid to his son, and adopted\nto him just the same bantering tone he used with his wife': 35, '"Aha, young\nman': 3, '" was the greeting with which he met him': 9, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch asserted and believed that he had never in any\nprevious year had so much official business as that year': 21, 'But he was\nnot aware that he sought work for himself that year, that this was one\nof the means for keeping shut that secret place where lay hid his\nfeelings towards his wife and son and his thoughts about them, which\nbecame more terrible the longer they lay there': 50, "If anyone had had the\nright to ask Alexey Alexandrovitch what he thought of his wife's\nbehavior, the mild and peaceable Alexey Alexandrovitch would have made\nno answer, but he would have been greatly angered with any man who\nshould question him on that subject": 45, "For this reason there positively\ncame into Alexey Alexandrovitch's face a look of haughtiness and\nseverity whenever anyone inquired after his wife's health": 23, "Alexey\nAlexandrovitch did not want to think at all about his wife's behavior,\nand he actually succeeded in not thinking about it at all": 24, "Alexey Alexandrovitch's permanent summer villa was in Peterhof, and the\nCountess Lidia Ivanovna used as a rule to spend the summer there, close\nto Anna, and constantly seeing her": 29, "That year Countess Lidia Ivanovna\ndeclined to settle in Peterhof, was not once at Anna Arkadyevna's, and\nin conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch hinted at the unsuitability\nof Anna's close intimacy with Betsy and Vronsky": 34, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch\nsternly cut her short, roundly declaring his wife to be above\nsuspicion, and from that time began to avoid Countess Lidia Ivanovna': 24, "He did not want to see, and did not see, that many people in society\ncast dubious glances on his wife; he did not want to understand, and\ndid not understand, why his wife had so particularly insisted on\nstaying at Tsarskoe, where Betsy was staying, and not far from the camp\nof Vronsky's regiment": 55, 'He did not allow himself to think about it, and\nhe did not think about it; but all the same though he never admitted it\nto himself, and had no proofs, not even suspicious evidence, in the\nbottom of his heart he knew beyond all doubt that he was a deceived\nhusband, and he was profoundly miserable about it': 59, 'How often during those eight years of happy life with his wife Alexey\nAlexandrovitch had looked at other men\'s faithless wives and other\ndeceived husbands and asked himself: "How can people descend to that': 34, "how is it they don't put an end to such a hideous position": 13, '" But now,\nwhen the misfortune had come upon himself, he was so far from thinking\nof putting an end to the position that he would not recognize it at\nall, would not recognize it just because it was too awful, too\nunnatural': 43, 'Since his return from abroad Alexey Alexandrovitch had twice been at\ntheir country villa': 14, 'Once he dined there, another time he spent the\nevening there with a party of friends, but he had not once stayed the\nnight there, as it had been his habit to do in previous years': 36, 'The day of the races had been a very busy day for Alexey\nAlexandrovitch; but when mentally sketching out the day in the morning,\nhe made up his mind to go to their country house to see his wife\nimmediately after dinner, and from there to the races, which all the\nCourt were to witness, and at which he was bound to be present': 64, 'He was\ngoing to see his wife, because he had determined to see her once a week\nto keep up appearances': 21, 'And besides, on that day, as it was the\nfifteenth, he had to give his wife some money for her expenses,\naccording to their usual arrangement': 26, 'With his habitual control over his thoughts, though he thought all this\nabout his wife, he did not let his thoughts stray further in regard to\nher': 27, 'That morning was a very full one for Alexey Alexandrovitch': 10, 'The evening\nbefore, Countess Lidia Ivanovna had sent him a pamphlet by a celebrated\ntraveler in China, who was staying in Petersburg, and with it she\nenclosed a note begging him to see the traveler himself, as he was an\nextremely interesting person from various points of view, and likely to\nbe useful': 53, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch had not had time to read the pamphlet\nthrough in the evening, and finished it in the morning': 20, 'Then people\nbegan arriving with petitions, and there came the reports, interviews,\nappointments, dismissals, apportionment of rewards, pensions, grants,\nnotes, the workaday round, as Alexey Alexandrovitch called it, that\nalways took up so much time': 35, 'Then there was private business of his\nown, a visit from the doctor and the steward who managed his property': 20, 'The steward did not take up much time': 8, 'He simply gave Alexey\nAlexandrovitch the money he needed together with a brief statement of\nthe position of his affairs, which was not altogether satisfactory, as\nit had happened that during that year, owing to increased expenses,\nmore had been paid out than usual, and there was a deficit': 49, 'But the\ndoctor, a celebrated Petersburg doctor, who was an intimate\nacquaintance of Alexey Alexandrovitch, took up a great deal of time': 22, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch had not expected him that day, and was surprised\nat his visit, and still more so when the doctor questioned him very\ncarefully about his health, listened to his breathing, and tapped at\nhis liver': 37, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch did not know that his friend Lidia\nIvanovna, noticing that he was not as well as usual that year, had\nbegged the doctor to go and examine him': 30, '"Do this for my sake," the\nCountess Lidia Ivanovna had said to him': 13, '"I will do it for the sake of Russia, countess," replied the doctor': 13, '"A priceless man': 3, '" said the Countess Lidia Ivanovna': 6, 'The doctor was extremely dissatisfied with Alexey Alexandrovitch': 8, 'He\nfound the liver considerably enlarged, and the digestive powers\nweakened, while the course of mineral waters had been quite without\neffect': 22, "He prescribed more physical exercise as far as possible, and as\nfar as possible less mental strain, and above all no worry—in other\nwords, just what was as much out of Alexey Alexandrovitch's power as\nabstaining from breathing": 38, 'Then he withdrew, leaving in Alexey\nAlexandrovitch an unpleasant sense that something was wrong with him,\nand that there was no chance of curing it': 25, "As he was coming away, the doctor chanced to meet on the staircase an\nacquaintance of his, Sludin, who was secretary of Alexey\nAlexandrovitch's department": 25, 'They had been comrades at the university,\nand though they rarely met, they thought highly of each other and were\nexcellent friends, and so there was no one to whom the doctor would\nhave given his opinion of a patient so freely as to Sludin': 45, '"How glad I am you\'ve been seeing him': 8, '" said Sludin': 3, '"He\'s not well,\nand I fancy': 6, 'Well, what do you think of him': 7, '"\n\n"I\'ll tell you," said the doctor, beckoning over Sludin\'s head to his\ncoachman to bring the carriage round': 19, '"It\'s just this," said the\ndoctor, taking a finger of his kid glove in his white hands and pulling\nit, "if you don\'t strain the strings, and then try to break them,\nyou\'ll find it a difficult job; but strain a string to its very utmost,\nand the mere weight of one finger on the strained string will snap it': 60, 'And with his close assiduity, his conscientious devotion to his work,\nhe\'s strained to the utmost; and there\'s some outside burden weighing\non him, and not a light one," concluded the doctor, raising his\neyebrows significantly': 36, '"Will you be at the races': 6, '" he added, as he\nsank into his seat in the carriage': 12, '"Yes, yes, to be sure; it does waste a lot of time," the doctor\nresponded vaguely to some reply of Sludin\'s he had not caught': 25, 'Directly after the doctor, who had taken up so much time, came the\ncelebrated traveler, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, by means of the\npamphlet he had only just finished reading and his previous\nacquaintance with the subject, impressed the traveler by the depth of\nhis knowledge of the subject and the breadth and enlightenment of his\nview of it': 58, 'At the same time as the traveler there was announced a provincial\nmarshal of nobility on a visit to Petersburg, with whom Alexey\nAlexandrovitch had to have some conversation': 29, 'After his departure, he\nhad to finish the daily routine of business with his secretary, and\nthen he still had to drive round to call on a certain great personage\non a matter of grave and serious import': 38, "Alexey Alexandrovitch only\njust managed to be back by five o'clock, his dinner-hour, and after\ndining with his secretary, he invited him to drive with him to his\ncountry villa and to the races": 34, 'Though he did not acknowledge it to himself, Alexey Alexandrovitch\nalways tried nowadays to secure the presence of a third person in his\ninterviews with his wife': 27, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 27 PART TWO', {"Anna was upstairs, standing before the looking-glass, and, with\nAnnushka's assistance, pinning the last ribbon on her gown when she\nheard carriage wheels crunching the gravel at the entrance": 29, '"It\'s too early for Betsy," she thought, and glancing out of the window\nshe caught sight of the carriage and the black hat of Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, and the ears that she knew so well sticking up each\nside of it': 40, '"How unlucky': 2, 'Can he be going to stay the night': 8, '" she\nwondered, and the thought of all that might come of such a chance\nstruck her as so awful and terrible that, without dwelling on it for a\nmoment, she went down to meet him with a bright and radiant face; and\nconscious of the presence of that spirit of falsehood and deceit in\nherself that she had come to know of late, she abandoned herself to\nthat spirit and began talking, hardly knowing what she was saying': 79, '"Ah, how nice of you': 5, '" she said, giving her ('TOL CHAPTER 28 PART TWO', {'When Alexey Alexandrovitch reached the race-course, Anna was already\nsitting in the pavilion beside Betsy, in that pavilion where all the\nhighest society had gathered': 25, 'She caught sight of her husband in the\ndistance': 9, 'Two men, her husband and her lover, were the two centers of\nher existence, and unaided by her external senses she was aware of\ntheir nearness': 26, 'She was aware of her husband approaching a long way\noff, and she could not help following him in the surging crowd in the\nmidst of which he was moving': 30, 'She watched his progress towards the\npavilion, saw him now responding condescendingly to an ingratiating\nbow, now exchanging friendly, nonchalant greetings with his equals, now\nassiduously trying to catch the eye of some great one of this world,\nand taking off his big round hat that squeezed the tips of his ears': 52, 'All these ways of his she knew, and all were hateful to her': 13, '"Nothing\nbut ambition, nothing but the desire to get on, that\'s all there is in\nhis soul," she thought; "as for these lofty ideals, love of culture,\nreligion, they are only so many tools for getting on': 37, '"\n\nFrom his glances towards the ladies\' pavilion (he was staring straight\nat her, but did not distinguish his wife in the sea of muslin, ribbons,\nfeathers, parasols and flowers) she saw that he was looking for her,\nbut she purposely avoided noticing him': 44, '"Alexey Alexandrovitch': 2, '" Princess Betsy called to him; "I\'m sure you\ndon\'t see your wife: here she is': 16, '"\n\nHe smiled his chilly smile': 6, '"There\'s so much splendor here that one\'s eyes are dazzled," he said,\nand he went into the pavilion': 18, 'He smiled to his wife as a man should\nsmile on meeting his wife after only just parting from her, and greeted\nthe princess and other acquaintances, giving to each what was due—that\nis to say, jesting with the ladies and dealing out friendly greetings\namong the men': 48, 'Below, near the pavilion, was standing an\nadjutant-general of whom Alexey Alexandrovitch had a high opinion,\nnoted for his intelligence and culture': 22, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch entered\ninto conversation with him': 7, 'There was an interval between the races, and so nothing hindered\nconversation': 12, 'The adjutant-general expressed his disapproval of races': 7, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch replied defending them': 5, 'Anna heard his high,\nmeasured tones, not losing one word, and every word struck her as\nfalse, and stabbed her ears with pain': 23, 'When the three-mile steeplechase was beginning, she bent forward and\ngazed with fixed eyes at Vronsky as he went up to his horse and\nmounted, and at the same time she heard that loathsome, never-ceasing\nvoice of her husband': 39, "She was in an agony of terror for Vronsky, but a\nstill greater agony was the never-ceasing, as it seemed to her, stream\nof her husband's shrill voice with its familiar intonations": 32, '"I\'m a wicked woman, a lost woman," she thought; "but I don\'t like\nlying, I can\'t endure falsehood, while as for _him_ (her husband) it\'s\nthe breath of his life—falsehood': 30, 'He knows all about it, he sees it\nall; what does he care if he can talk so calmly': 19, 'If he were to kill me,\nif he were to kill Vronsky, I might respect him': 16, 'No, all he wants is\nfalsehood and propriety," Anna said to herself, not considering exactly\nwhat it was she wanted of her husband, and how she would have liked to\nsee him behave': 33, "She did not understand either that Alexey\nAlexandrovitch's peculiar loquacity that day, so exasperating to her,\nwas merely the expression of his inward distress and uneasiness": 26, "As a\nchild that has been hurt skips about, putting all his muscles into\nmovement to drown the pain, in the same way Alexey Alexandrovitch\nneeded mental exercise to drown the thoughts of his wife that in her\npresence and in Vronsky's, and with the continual iteration of his\nname, would force themselves on his attention": 56, 'And it was as natural\nfor him to talk well and cleverly, as it is natural for a child to skip\nabout': 22, 'He was saying:\n\n"Danger in the races of officers, of cavalry men, is an essential\nelement in the race': 19, 'If England can point to the most brilliant feats\nof cavalry in military history, it is simply owing to the fact that she\nhas historically developed this force both in beasts and in men': 34, 'Sport\nhas, in my opinion, a great value, and as is always the case, we see\nnothing but what is most superficial': 22, '"\n\n"It\'s not superficial," said Princess Tverskaya': 7, '"One of the officers,\nthey say, has broken two ribs': 10, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch smiled his smile, which uncovered his teeth, but\nrevealed nothing more': 14, '"We\'ll admit, princess, that that\'s not superficial," he said, "but\ninternal': 11, 'But that\'s not the point," and he turned again to the general\nwith whom he was talking seriously; "we mustn\'t forget that those who\nare taking part in the race are military men, who have chosen that\ncareer, and one must allow that every calling has its disagreeable\nside': 49, 'It forms an integral part of the duties of an officer': 11, 'Low\nsports, such as prize-fighting or Spanish bull-fights, are a sign of\nbarbarity': 13, 'But specialized trials of skill are a sign of development': 10, '"\n\n"No, I shan\'t come another time; it\'s too upsetting," said Princess\nBetsy': 13, '"Isn\'t it, Anna': 3, '"\n\n"It is upsetting, but one can\'t tear oneself away," said another lady': 13, '"If I\'d been a Roman woman I should never have missed a single circus': 14, '"\n\nAnna said nothing, and keeping her opera-glass up, gazed always at the\nsame spot': 15, 'At that moment a tall general walked through the pavilion': 10, 'Breaking off\nwhat he was saying, Alexey Alexandrovitch got up hurriedly, though with\ndignity, and bowed low to the general': 20, '"You\'re not racing': 3, '" the officer asked, chaffing him': 6, '"My race is a harder one," Alexey Alexandrovitch responded\ndeferentially': 10, 'And though the answer meant nothing, the general looked as though he\nhad heard a witty remark from a witty man, and fully relished _la\npointe de la sauce_': 29, '"There are two aspects," Alexey Alexandrovitch resumed: "those who take\npart and those who look on; and love for such spectacles is an\nunmistakable proof of a low degree of development in the spectator, I\nadmit, but': 37, '"\n\n"Princess, bets': 3, '" sounded Stepan Arkadyevitch\'s voice from below,\naddressing Betsy': 9, '"Who\'s your favorite': 3, '"\n\n"Anna and I are for Kuzovlev," replied Betsy': 9, '"I\'m for Vronsky': 3, 'A pair of gloves': 4, '"\n\n"Done': 2, '"\n\n"But it is a pretty sight, isn\'t it': 9, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch paused while there was talking about him, but he\nbegan again directly': 15, '"I admit that manly sports do not': 7, '" he was continuing': 4, 'But at that moment the racers started, and all conversation ceased': 11, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch too was silent, and everyone stood up and turned\ntowards the stream': 14, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch took no interest in the race,\nand so he did not watch the racers, but fell listlessly to scanning the\nspectators with his weary eyes': 27, 'His eyes rested upon Anna': 5, 'Her face was white and set': 6, 'She was obviously seeing nothing and no one\nbut one man': 11, 'Her hand had convulsively clutched her fan, and she held\nher breath': 12, 'He looked at her and hastily turned away, scrutinizing\nother faces': 11, '"But here\'s this lady too, and others very much moved as well; it\'s\nvery natural," Alexey Alexandrovitch told himself': 19, 'He tried not to look\nat her, but unconsciously his eyes were drawn to her': 15, 'He examined that\nface again, trying not to read what was so plainly written on it, and\nagainst his own will, with horror read on it what he did not want to\nknow': 33, "The first fall—Kuzovlev's, at the stream—agitated everyone, but Alexey\nAlexandrovitch saw distinctly on Anna's pale, triumphant face that the\nman she was watching had not fallen": 26, 'When, after Mahotin and Vronsky\nhad cleared the worst barrier, the next officer had been thrown\nstraight on his head at it and fatally injured, and a shudder of horror\npassed over the whole public, Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that Anna did\nnot even notice it, and had some difficulty in realizing what they were\ntalking of about her': 58, 'But more and more often, and with greater\npersistence, he watched her': 12, "Anna, wholly engrossed as she was with the\nrace, became aware of her husband's cold eyes fixed upon her from one\nside": 22, 'She glanced round for an instant, looked inquiringly at him, and with a\nslight frown turned away again': 18, '"Ah, I don\'t care': 4, '" she seemed to say to him, and she did not once\nglance at him again': 16, 'The race was an unlucky one, and of the seventeen officers who rode in\nit more than half were thrown and hurt': 22, 'Towards the end of the race\neveryone was in a state of agitation, which was intensified by the fact\nthat the Tsar was displeased': 24, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 29 PART TWO', {'Everyone was loudly expressing disapprobation, everyone was repeating a\nphrase someone had uttered—"The lions and gladiators will be the next\nthing," and everyone was
