('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART THREE', {'The croquet party to which the Princess Tverskaya had invited Anna was\nto consist of two ladies and their adorers': 20, 'These two ladies were the\nchief representatives of a select new Petersburg circle, nicknamed, in\nimitation of some imitation, _les sept merveilles du monde_': 24, 'These\nladies belonged to a circle which, though of the highest society, was\nutterly hostile to that in which Anna moved': 21, "Moreover, Stremov, one of\nthe most influential people in Petersburg, and the elderly admirer of\nLiza Merkalova, was Alexey Alexandrovitch's enemy in the political\nworld": 25, "From all these considerations Anna had not meant to go, and the\nhints in Princess Tverskaya's note referred to her refusal": 21, 'But now\nAnna was eager to go, in the hope of seeing Vronsky': 13, "Anna arrived at Princess Tverskaya's earlier than the other guests": 10, "At the same moment as she entered, Vronsky's footman, with\nside-whiskers combed out like a _Kammerjunker_, went in too": 19, 'He stopped\nat the door, and, taking off his cap, let her pass': 13, 'Anna recognized\nhim, and only then recalled that Vronsky had told her the day before\nthat he would not come': 20, 'Most likely he was sending a note to say so': 10, 'As she took off her outer garment in the hall, she heard the footman,\npronouncing his "_r\'s_" even like a _Kammerjunker_, say, "From the\ncount for the princess," and hand the note': 32, 'She longed to question him as to where his master was': 11, 'She longed to\nturn back and send him a letter to come and see her, or to go herself\nto see him': 22, 'But neither the first nor the second nor the third course\nwas possible': 13, "Already she heard bells ringing to announce her arrival\nahead of her, and Princess Tverskaya's footman was standing at the open\ndoor waiting for her to go forward into the inner rooms": 32, '"The princess is in the garden; they will inform her immediately': 11, 'Would\nyou be pleased to walk into the garden': 9, '" announced another footman in\nanother room': 7, 'The position of uncertainty, of indecision, was still the same as at\nhome—worse, in fact, since it was impossible to take any step,\nimpossible to see Vronsky, and she had to remain here among outsiders,\nin company so uncongenial to her present mood': 43, 'But she was wearing a\ndress that she knew suited her': 11, 'She was not alone; all around was that\nluxurious setting of idleness that she was used to, and she felt less\nwretched than at home': 25, 'She was not forced to think what she was to do': 11, 'Everything would be done of itself': 6, 'On meeting Betsy coming towards her\nin a white gown that struck her by its elegance, Anna smiled at her\njust as she always did': 25, 'Princess Tverskaya was walking with Tushkevitch\nand a young lady, a relation, who, to the great joy of her parents in\nthe provinces, was spending the summer with the fashionable princess': 31, 'There was probably something unusual about Anna, for Betsy noticed it\nat once': 13, '"I slept badly," answered Anna, looking intently at the footman who\ncame to meet them, and, as she supposed, brought Vronsky\'s note': 22, '"How glad I am you\'ve come': 6, '" said Betsy': 3, '"I\'m tired, and was just\nlonging to have some tea before they come': 13, 'You might go"—she turned to\nTushkevitch—"with Masha, and try the croquet ground over there where\nthey\'ve been cutting it': 19, "We shall have time to talk a little over tea;\nwe'll have a cozy chat, eh": 16, '" she said in English to Anna, with a smile,\npressing the hand with which she held a parasol': 19, '"Yes, especially as I can\'t stay very long with you': 10, "I'm forced to go\non to old Madame Vrede": 9, 'I\'ve been promising to go for a century," said\nAnna, to whom lying, alien as it was to her nature, had become not\nmerely simple and natural in society, but a positive source of\nsatisfaction': 35, 'Why she said this, which she had not thought of a second\nbefore, she could not have explained': 18, 'She had said it simply from the\nreflection that as Vronsky would not be here, she had better secure her\nown freedom, and try to see him somehow': 28, 'But why she had spoken of old\nMadame Vrede, whom she had to go and see, as she had to see many other\npeople, she could not have explained; and yet, as it afterwards turned\nout, had she contrived the most cunning devices to meet Vronsky, she\ncould have thought of nothing better': 53, '"No': 1, 'I\'m not going to let you go for anything," answered Betsy, looking\nintently into Anna\'s face': 16, '"Really, if I were not fond of you, I should\nfeel offended': 12, 'One would think you were afraid my society would\ncompromise you': 11, 'Tea in the little dining-room, please," she said, half\nclosing her eyes, as she always did when addressing the footman': 20, 'Taking the note from him, she read it': 8, '"Alexey\'s playing us false," she said in French; "he writes that he\ncan\'t come," she added in a tone as simple and natural as though it\ncould never enter her head that Vronsky could mean anything more to\nAnna than a game of croquet': 44, 'Anna knew that Betsy knew everything, but,\nhearing how she spoke of Vronsky before her, she almost felt persuaded\nfor a minute that she knew nothing': 26, '"Ah': 1, '" said Anna indifferently, as though not greatly interested in the\nmatter, and she went on smiling: "How can you or your friends\ncompromise anyone': 25, '"\n\nThis playing with words, this hiding of a secret, had a great\nfascination for Anna, as, indeed, it has for all women': 23, 'And it was not\nthe necessity of concealment, not the aim with which the concealment\nwas contrived, but the process of concealment itself which attracted\nher': 26, '"I can\'t be more Catholic than the Pope," she said': 10, '"Stremov and Liza\nMerkalova, why, they\'re the cream of the cream of society': 13, 'Besides,\nthey\'re received everywhere, and _I_"—she laid special stress on the\nI—"have never been strict and intolerant': 17, "It's simply that I haven't\nthe time": 7, '"\n\n"No; you don\'t care, perhaps, to meet Stremov': 9, "Let him and Alexey\nAlexandrovitch tilt at each other in the committee—that's no affair of\nours": 16, "But in the world, he's the most amiable man I know, and a devoted\ncroquet player": 16, 'You shall see': 3, "And, in spite of his absurd position as\nLiza's lovesick swain at his age, you ought to see how he carries off\nthe absurd position": 25, "He's very nice": 3, "Sappho Shtoltz you don't know": 5, "Oh,\nthat's a new type, quite new": 7, '"\n\nBetsy said all this, and, at the same time, from her good-humored,\nshrewd glance, Anna felt that she partly guessed her plight, and was\nhatching something for her benefit': 30, 'They were in the little boudoir': 6, '"I must write to Alexey though," and Betsy sat down to the table,\nscribbled a few lines, and put the note in an envelope': 24, '"I\'m telling him to come to dinner': 7, "I've one lady extra to dinner with\nme, and no man to take her in": 15, "Look what I've said, will that persuade\nhim": 8, 'Excuse me, I must leave you for a minute': 9, 'Would you seal it up,\nplease, and send it off': 10, '" she said from the door; "I have to give some\ndirections': 12, '"\n\nWithout a moment\'s thought, Anna sat down to the table with Betsy\'s\nletter, and, without reading it, wrote below: "It\'s essential for me to\nsee you': 27, 'Come to the Vrede garden': 5, "I shall be there at six o'clock": 7, '"\nShe sealed it up, and, Betsy coming back, in her presence handed the\nnote to be taken': 18, 'At tea, which was brought them on a little tea-table in the cool little\ndrawing-room, the cozy chat promised by Princess Tverskaya before the\narrival of her visitors really did come off between the two women': 36, 'They\ncriticized the people they were expecting, and the conversation fell\nupon Liza Merkalova': 14, '"She\'s very sweet, and I always liked her," said Anna': 10, '"You ought to like her': 5, 'She raves about you': 4, 'Yesterday she came up to\nme after the races and was in despair at not finding you': 17, "She says\nyou're a real heroine of romance, and that if she were a man she would\ndo all sorts of mad things for your sake": 26, 'Stremov says she does that as\nit is': 8, '"\n\n"But do tell me, please, I never could make it out," said Anna, after\nbeing silent for some time, speaking in a tone that showed she was not\nasking an idle question, but that what she was asking was of more\nimportance to her than it should have been; "do tell me, please, what\nare her relations with Prince Kaluzhsky, Mishka, as he\'s called': 65, "I've\nmet them so little": 5, 'What does it mean': 4, '"\n\nBetsy smiled with her eyes, and looked intently at Anna': 11, '"It\'s a new manner," she said': 6, '"They\'ve all adopted that manner': 5, "They've flung their caps over the windmills": 7, 'But there are ways and\nways of flinging them': 9, '"\n\n"Yes, but what are her relations precisely with Kaluzhsky': 10, '"\n\nBetsy broke into unexpectedly mirthful and irrepressible laughter, a\nthing which rarely happened with her': 16, '"You\'re encroaching on Princess Myakaya\'s special domain now': 8, 'That\'s\nthe question of an _enfant terrible_," and Betsy obviously tried to\nrestrain herself, but could not, and went off into peals of that\ninfectious laughter that people laugh who do not laugh often': 34, '"You\'d\nbetter ask them," she brought out, between tears of laughter': 11, '"No; you laugh," said Anna, laughing too in spite of herself, "but I\nnever could understand it': 17, "I can't understand the husband's rôle in\nit": 8, '"\n\n"The husband': 3, "Liza Merkalova's husband carries her shawl, and is always\nready to be of use": 14, 'But anything more than that in reality, no one\ncares to inquire': 12, "You know in decent society one doesn't talk or think\neven of certain details of the toilet": 17, "That's how it is with this": 6, '"\n\n"Will you be at Madame Rolandak\'s fête': 8, '" asked Anna, to change the\nconversation': 7, '"I don\'t think so," answered Betsy, and, without looking at her friend,\nshe began filling the little transparent cups with fragrant tea': 22, 'Putting a cup before Anna, she took out a cigarette, and, fitting it\ninto a silver holder, she lighted it': 20, '"It\'s like this, you see: I\'m in a fortunate position," she began,\nquite serious now, as she took up her cup': 21, '"I understand you, and I\nunderstand Liza': 7, "Liza now is one of those naïve natures that, like\nchildren, don't know what's good and what's bad": 18, "Anyway, she didn't\ncomprehend it when she was very young": 10, "And now she's aware that the\nlack of comprehension suits her": 11, 'Now, perhaps, she doesn\'t know on\npurpose," said Betsy, with a subtle smile': 13, '"But, anyway, it suits her': 5, "The very same thing, don't you see, may be looked at tragically, and\nturned into a misery, or it may be looked at simply and even\nhumorously": 27, 'Possibly you are inclined to look at things too\ntragically': 10, '"\n\n"How I should like to know other people just as I know myself': 14, '" said\nAnna, seriously and dreamily': 6, '"Am I worse than other people, or better': 8, "I think I'm worse": 4, '"\n\n"_Enfant terrible, enfant terrible': 5, '_" repeated Betsy': 3, '"But here they\nare': 4, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART THREE', {"They heard the sound of steps and a man's voice, then a woman's voice\nand laughter, and immediately thereafter there walked in the expected\nguests: Sappho Shtoltz, and a young man beaming with excess of health,\nthe so-called Vaska": 39, 'It was evident that ample supplies of beefsteak,\ntruffles, and Burgundy never failed to reach him at the fitting hour': 20, 'Vaska bowed to the two ladies, and glanced at them, but only for one\nsecond': 15, 'He walked after Sappho into the drawing-room, and followed her\nabout as though he were chained to her, keeping his sparkling eyes\nfixed on her as though he wanted to eat her': 32, 'Sappho Shtoltz was a\nblonde beauty with black eyes': 9, 'She walked with smart little steps in\nhigh-heeled shoes, and shook hands with the ladies vigorously like a\nman': 19, 'Anna had never met this new star of fashion, and was struck by her\nbeauty, the exaggerated extreme to which her dress was carried, and the\nboldness of her manners': 30, 'On her head there was such a superstructure of\nsoft, golden hair—her own and false mixed—that her head was equal in\nsize to the elegantly rounded bust, of which so much was exposed in\nfront': 35, 'The impulsive abruptness of her movements was such that at every\nstep the lines of her knees and the upper part of her legs were\ndistinctly marked under her dress, and the question involuntarily rose\nto the mind where in the undulating, piled-up mountain of material at\nthe back the real body of the woman, so small and slender, so naked in\nfront, and so hidden behind and below, really came to an end': 74, 'Betsy made haste to introduce her to Anna': 8, '"Only fancy, we all but ran over two soldiers," she began telling them\nat once, using her eyes, smiling and twitching away her tail, which she\nflung back at one stroke all on one side': 35, '"I drove here with Vaska': 5, "Ah, to be sure, you don't know each other": 9, '" And mentioning his surname\nshe '"Oh, all right, I\'ll have it later': 7, '"\n\n"Very well, very well': 5, 'Oh, yes': 2, '" She turned suddenly to Princess Betsy:\n"I am a nice person': 12, 'I positively forgot it': 4, "I've brought you a\nvisitor": 5, 'And here he comes': 4, '" The unexpected young visitor, whom Sappho\nhad invited, and whom she had forgotten, was, however, a personage of\nsuch consequence that, in spite of his observed and appreciated the fact) was\nin perfect harmony with her style of beauty': 22, 'Liza was as soft and\nenervated as Sappho was smart and abrupt': 12, "But to Anna's taste Liza was far more attractive": 9, 'Betsy had said to\nAnna that she had adopted the pose of an innocent child, but when Anna\nsaw her, she felt that this was not the truth': 28, 'She really was both\ninnocent and corrupt, but a sweet and passive woman': 13, "It is true that\nher tone was the same as Sappho's; that like Sappho, she had two men,\none young and one old, tacked onto her, and devouring her with their\neyes": 32, 'But there was something in her higher than what surrounded her': 11, 'There was in her the glow of the real diamond among glass imitations': 13, 'This glow shone out in her exquisite, truly enigmatic eyes': 10, 'The weary,\nand at the same time passionate, glance of those eyes, encircled by\ndark rings, impressed one by its perfect sincerity': 22, 'Everyone looking\ninto those eyes fancied he knew her wholly, and knowing her, could not\nbut love her': 18, 'At the sight of Anna, her whole face lighted up at once\nwith a smile of delight': 17, '"Ah, how glad I am to see 3, '" she said,\nlooking at Anna with eyes that seemed to lay bare all her soul': 16, '"Yes; I had no idea it would be so thrilling," said Anna, blushing': 13, 'The company got up at this moment to go into the garden': 12, '"I\'m not going," said Liza, smiling and settling herself close to Anna': 12, '"You won\'t go either, will you': 6, 'Who wants to play croquet': 5, '"\n\n"Oh, I like it," said Anna': 7, '"There, how do you manage never to be bored by things': 11, "It's delightful\nto look at you": 6, "You're alive, but I'm bored": 5, '"\n\n"How can you be bored': 6, 'Why, you live in the people, always the same': 8, 'Always the same thing': 4, 'We lounged about on sofas all the evening': 8, 'What\nis there to enjoy in that': 7, 'No; do tell me how you manage never to be\nbored': 11, '" she said, addressing Anna again': 6, '"One has but to look at you\nand one sees, here\'s a woman who may be happy or unhappy, but isn\'t\nbored': 22, 'Tell me how you do it': 6, '"\n\n"I do nothing," answered Anna, blushing at these searching questions': 11, '"That\'s the best way," Stremov put in': 7, 'Stremov was a man of fifty,\npartly gray, but still vigorous-looking, very ugly, but with a\ncharacteristic and intelligent face': 20, "Liza Merkalova was his wife's\nniece, and he spent all his leisure hours with her": 15, "On meeting Anna\nKarenina, as he was Alexey Alexandrovitch's enemy in the government, he\ntried, like a shrewd man and a man of the world, to be particularly\ncordial with her, the wife of his enemy": 36, '"‘Nothing,\'" he put in with a subtle smile, "that\'s the very best way': 13, 'I told you long ago," he said, turning to Liza Merkalova, "that if you\ndon\'t want to be bored, you mustn\'t think you\'re going to be bored': 27, "It's just as you mustn't only clever but\ntrue," said Anna, smiling': 21, '"No, do tell me why it is one can\'t go to sleep, and one can\'t help\nbeing bored': 18, '"\n\n"To sleep well one ought to work, and to enjoy oneself one ought to\nwork too': 17, '"\n\n"What am I to work for when my work is no use to anybody': 15, "And I can't\nand won't knowingly make a pretense about it": 11, '"\n\n"You\'re incorrigible," said Stremov, not looking at her, and he spoke\nagain to Anna': 15, 'As he rarely met Anna, he could say nothing but\ncommonplaces to her, but he said those commonplaces as to when she was\nreturning to Petersburg, and how fond Countess Lidia Ivanovna was of\nher, with an expression which suggested that he longed with his whole\nsoul to please her and show his regard for her and even more than that': man's\nflattering words, the naïve, childlike affection shown her by Liza\nMerkalova, and all the social atmosphere she was used to,—it was all so\neasy, and what was in store for her was so home, if she did not come to some decision,\nremembering that gesture—terrible even in memory—when she had clutched\nher hair in both hands—she said good-bye and went away': 38, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART THREE', {"In spite of Vronsky's apparently frivolous life in society, he was a\nman who hated irregularity": 16, 'In early youth in the Corps of Pages, he\nhad experienced the humiliation of a refusal, when he had tried, being\nin difficulties, to borrow money, and since then he had never once put\nhimself in the same position again': 40, 'In order to keep his affairs in some sort of order, he used about five\ntimes a year (more or less frequently, according to circumstances) to\nshut himself up alone and put all his affairs into definite shape': 38, 'This\nhe used to call his day of reckoning or _faire la lessive_': 13, 'On waking up the day after the races, Vronsky put on a white linen\ncoat, and without shaving or taking his bath, he distributed about the\ntable moneys, bills, and letters, and set to work': 35, 'Petritsky, who knew\nhe was ill-tempered on such occasions, on waking up and seeing his\ncomrade at the writing-table, quietly dressed and went out without\ngetting in his way': 29, 'Every man who knows to the minutest details all the complexity of the\nconditions surrounding him, cannot help imagining that the complexity\nof these conditions, and the difficulty of making them clear, is\nsomething exceptional and personal, peculiar to himself, and never\nsupposes that others are surrounded by just as complicated an array of\npersonal affairs as he is': 59, 'So indeed it seemed to Vronsky': 6, 'And not\nwithout inward pride, and not without reason, he thought that any other\nman would long ago have been in difficulties, would have been forced to\nsome dishonorable course, if he had found himself in such a difficult\nposition': 40, 'But Vronsky felt that now especially it was essential for him\nto clear up and define his position if he were to avoid getting into\ndifficulties': 26, 'What Vronsky attacked first as being the easiest was his pecuniary\nposition': 12, 'Writing out on note paper in his minute hand all that he\nowed, he added up the amount and found that his debts amounted to\nseventeen thousand and some odd hundreds, which he left out for the\nsake of clearness': 40, 'Reckoning up his money and his bank book, he found\nthat he had left one thousand eight hundred roubles, and nothing coming\nin before the New Year': 27, 'Reckoning over again his list of debts, Vronsky\ncopied it, dividing it into three classes': 15, "In the first class he put\nthe debts which he would have to pay at once, or for which he must in\nany case have the money ready so that on demand for payment there could\nnot be a moment's delay in paying": 43, "Such debts amounted to about four\nthousand: one thousand five hundred for a horse, and two thousand five\nhundred as surety for a young comrade, Venovsky, who had lost that sum\nto a cardsharper in Vronsky's presence": 37, 'Vronsky had wanted to pay the\nmoney at the time (he had that amount then), but Venovsky and Yashvin\nhad insisted that they would pay and not Vronsky, who had not played': 32, 'That was so far well, but Vronsky knew that in this dirty business,\nthough his only share in it was undertaking by word of mouth to be\nsurety for Venovsky, it was absolutely necessary for him to have the\ntwo thousand five hundred roubles so as to be able to fling it at the\nswindler, and have no more words with him': 62, 'And so for this first and\nmost important division he must have four thousand roubles': 15, 'The second\nclass—eight thousand roubles—consisted of less important debts': 9, 'These\nwere principally accounts owing in connection with his race horses, to\nthe purveyor of oats and hay, the English saddler, and so on': 24, 'He would\nhave to pay some two thousand roubles on these debts too, in order to\nbe quite free from anxiety': 21, 'The last class of debts—to shops, to\nhotels, to his tailor—were such as need not be considered': 17, 'So that he\nneeded at least six thousand roubles for current expenses, and he only\nhad one thousand eight hundred': 20, "For a man with one hundred thousand\nroubles of revenue, which was what everyone fixed as Vronsky's income,\nsuch debts, one would suppose, could hardly be embarrassing; but the\nfact was that he was far from having one hundred thousand": 40, "His father's\nimmense property, which alone yielded a yearly income of two hundred\nthousand, was left undivided between the brothers": 20, "At the time when the\nelder brother, with a mass of debts, married Princess Varya Tchirkova,\nthe daughter of a Decembrist without any fortune whatever, Alexey had\ngiven up to his elder brother almost the whole income from his father's\nestate, reserving for himself only twenty-five thousand a year from it": 51, 'Alexey had said at the time to his brother that that sum would be\nsufficient for him until he married, which he probably never would do': 26, 'And his brother, who was in command of one of the most expensive\nregiments, and was only just married, could not decline the gift': 24, 'His\nmother, who had her own separate property, had allowed Alexey every\nyear twenty thousand in addition to the twenty-five thousand he had\nreserved, and Alexey had spent it all': 30, 'Of late his mother, incensed\nwith him on account of his love affair and his leaving Moscow, had\ngiven up sending him the money': 24, 'And in consequence of this, Vronsky,\nwho had been in the habit of living on the scale of forty-five thousand\na year, having only received twenty thousand that year, found himself\nnow in difficulties': 34, 'To get out of these difficulties, he could not\napply to his mother for money': 15, 'Her last letter, which he had received\nthe day before, had particularly exasperated him by the hints in it\nthat she was quite ready to help him to succeed in the world and in the\narmy, but not to lead a life which was a scandal to all good society': 50, "His mother's attempt to buy him stung him to the quick and made him\nfeel colder than ever to her": 20, 'But he could not draw back from the\ngenerous word when it was once uttered, even though he felt now,\nvaguely foreseeing certain eventualities in his intrigue with Madame\nKarenina, that this generous word had been spoken thoughtlessly, and\nthat even though he were not married he might need all the hundred\nthousand of income': 55, 'But it was impossible to draw back': 7, "He had only to\nrecall his brother's wife, to remember how that sweet, delightful Varya\nsought, at every convenient opportunity, to remind him that she\nremembered his generosity and appreciated it, to grasp the\nimpossibility of taking back his gift": 40, 'It was as impossible as beating\na woman, stealing, or lying': 11, "One thing only could and ought to be done,\nand Vronsky determined upon it without an instant's hesitation: to\nborrow money from a money-lender, ten thousand roubles, a proceeding\nwhich presented no difficulty, to cut down his expenses generally, and\nto sell his race horses": 45, 'Resolving on this, he promptly wrote a note to\nRolandak, who had more than once sent to him with offers to buy horses\nfrom him': 25, 'Then he sent for the Englishman and the money-lender, and\ndivided what money he had according to the accounts he intended to pay': 23, 'Having finished this business, he wrote a cold and cutting answer to\nhis mother': 14, "Then he took out of his notebook three notes of Anna's,\nread them again, burned them, and remembering their conversation on the\nprevious day, he sank into meditation": 28, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART THREE', {"Vronsky's life was particularly happy in that he had a code of\nprinciples, which defined with unfailing certitude what he ought and\nwhat he ought not to do": 28, "This code of principles covered only a very\nsmall circle of contingencies, but then the principles were never\ndoubtful, and Vronsky, as he never went outside that circle, had never\nhad a moment's hesitation about doing what he ought to do": 41, 'These\nprinciples laid down as invariable rules: that one must pay a\ncardsharper, but need not pay a tailor; that one must never tell a lie\nto a man, but one may to a woman; that one must never cheat anyone, but\none may a husband; that one must never pardon an insult, but one may\ngive one and so on': 61, 'These principles were possibly not reasonable and\nnot good, but they were of unfailing certainty, and so long as he\nadhered to them, Vronsky felt that his heart was at peace and he could\nhold his head up': 38, 'Only quite lately in regard to his relations with\nAnna, Vronsky had begun to feel that his code of principles did not\nfully cover all possible contingencies, and to foresee in the future\ndifficulties and perplexities for which he could find no guiding clue': 44, 'His present relation to Anna and to her husband was to his mind clear\nand simple': 16, 'It was clearly and precisely defined in the code of\nprinciples by which he was guided': 16, 'She was an honorable woman who had bestowed her love upon him, and he\nloved her, and therefore she was in his eyes a woman who had a right to\nthe same, or even more, respect than a lawful wife': 40, 'He would have had\nhis hand chopped off before he would have allowed himself by a word, by\na hint, to humiliate her, or even to fall short of the fullest respect\na woman could look for': 37, 'His attitude to society, too, was clear': 7, 'Everyone might know, might\nsuspect it, but no one might dare to speak of it': 15, 'If any did so, he was\nready to force all who might speak to be silent and to respect the\nnon-existent honor of the woman he loved': 27, 'His attitude to the husband was the clearest of all': 10, 'From the moment\nthat Anna loved Vronsky, he had regarded his own right over her as the\none thing unassailable': 20, 'Her husband was simply a superfluous and\ntiresome person': 9, 'No doubt he was in a pitiable position, but how could\nthat be helped': 14, 'The one thing the husband had a right to was to demand\nsatisfaction with a weapon in his hand, and Vronsky was prepared for\nthis at any minute': 28, 'But of late new inner relations had arisen between him and her, which\nfrightened Vronsky by their indefiniteness': 18, 'Only the day before she had\ntold him that she was with child': 13, 'And he felt that this fact and what\nshe expected of him called for something not fully defined in that code\nof principles by which he had hitherto steered his course in life': 33, 'And\nhe had been indeed caught unawares, and at the first moment when she\nspoke to him of her position, his heart had prompted him to beg her to\nleave her husband': 32, 'He had said that, but now thinking things over he\nsaw clearly that it would be better to manage to avoid that; and at the\nsame time, as he told himself so, he was afraid whether it was not\nwrong': 40, '"If I told her to leave her husband, that must mean uniting her life\nwith mine; am I prepared for that': 21, 'How can I take her away now, when I\nhave no money': 12, 'Supposing I could arrange': 4, "But how can I take her\naway while I'm in the service": 12, 'If I say that—I ought to be prepared to\ndo it, that is, I ought to have the money and to retire from the army': 25, '"\n\nAnd he grew thoughtful': 5, 'The question whether to retire from the service\nor not brought him to the other and perhaps the chief though hidden\ninterest of his life, of which none knew but he': 31, 'Ambition was the old dream of his youth and childhood, a dream which he\ndid not confess even to himself, though it was so strong that now this\npassion was even doing battle with his love': 36, 'His first steps in the\nworld and in the service had been successful, but two years before he\nhad made a great mistake': 23, 'Anxious to show his independence and to\nadvance, he had refused a post that had been offered him, hoping that\nthis refusal would heighten his value; but it turned out that he had\nbeen too bold, and he was passed over': 41, 'And having, whether he liked or\nnot, taken up for himself the position of an independent man, he\ncarried it off with great tact and good sense, behaving as though he\nbore no grudge against anyone, did not regard himself as injured in any\nway, and cared for nothing but to be left alone since he was enjoying\nhimself': 59, 'In reality he had ceased to enjoy himself as long ago as the\nyear before, when he went away to Moscow': 21, 'He felt that this independent\nattitude of a man who might have done anything, but cared to do\nnothing, was already beginning to pall, that many people were beginning\nto fancy that he was not really capable of anything but being a\nstraightforward, good-natured fellow': 45, 'His connection with Madame\nKarenina, by creating so much sensation and attracting general\nattention, had given him a fresh distinction which soothed his gnawing\nworm of ambition for a while, but a week before that worm had been\nroused up again with fresh force': 44, 'The friend of his childhood, a man of\nthe same set, of the same coterie, his comrade in the Corps of Pages,\nSerpuhovskoy, who had left school with him and had been his rival in\nclass, in gymnastics, in their scrapes and their dreams of glory, had\ncome back a few days before from Central Asia, where he had gained two\nsteps up in rank, and an order rarely bestowed upon generals so young': 74, 'As soon as he arrived in Petersburg, people began to talk about him as\na newly risen star of the first magnitude': 22, "A schoolfellow of Vronsky's\nand of the same age, he was a general and was expecting a command,\nwhich might have influence on the course of political events; while\nVronsky, independent and brilliant and beloved by a charming woman\nthough he was, was simply a cavalry captain who was readily allowed to\nbe as independent as ever he liked": 59, '"Of course I don\'t envy\nSerpuhovskoy and never could envy him; but his advancement shows me\nthat one has only to watch one\'s opportunity, and the career of a man\nlike me may be very rapidly made': 37, 'Three years ago he was in just the\nsame position as I am': 13, 'If I retire, I burn my ships': 7, 'If I remain in the\narmy, I lose nothing': 9, 'She said herself she did not wish to change her\nposition': 11, 'And with her love I cannot feel envious of Serpuhovskoy': 10, '" And\nslowly twirling his mustaches, he got up from the table and walked\nabout the room': 17, 'His eyes shone particularly brightly, and he felt in\nthat confident, calm, and happy frame of mind which always came after\nhe had thoroughly faced his position': 27, 'Everything was straight and\nclear, just as after former days of reckoning': 12, 'He shaved, took a cold\nbath, dressed and went out': 10, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 21 PART THREE', {'"We\'ve come to fetch you': 5, 'Your _lessive_ lasted a good time today,"\nsaid Petritsky': 9, '"Well, is it over': 4, '"\n\n"It is over," answered Vronsky, smiling with his eyes only, and\ntwirling the tips of his mustaches as circumspectly as though after the\nperfect order into which his affairs had been brought any over-bold or\nrapid movement might disturb it': 41, '"You\'re always just as if you\'d come out of a bath after it," said\nPetritsky': 15, '"I\'ve come from Gritsky\'s" (that was what they called the\ncolonel); "they\'re expecting you': 14, '"\n\nVronsky, without answering, looked at his comrade, thinking of\nsomething else': 12, '"Yes; is that music at his place': 7, '" he said, listening to the familiar\nsounds of polkas and waltzes floating across to him': 16, '"What\'s the fête': 3, '"\n\n"Serpuhovskoy\'s come': 3, '"\n\n"Aha': 2, '" said Vronsky, "why, I didn\'t know': 7, '"\n\nThe smile in his eyes gleamed more brightly than ever': 11, 'Having once made up his mind that he was happy in his love, that he\nsacrificed his ambition to it—having anyway taken up this position,\nVronsky was incapable of feeling either envious of Serpuhovskoy or hurt\nwith him for not coming first to him when he came to the regiment': 50, 'Serpuhovskoy was a good friend, and he was delighted he had come': 12, '"Ah, I\'m very glad': 4, '"\n\nThe colonel, Demin, had taken a large country house': 10, 'The whole party\nwere in the wide lower balcony': 9, "In the courtyard the first objects that\nmet Vronsky's eyes were a band of singers in white linen coats,\nstanding near a barrel of vodka, and the robust, good-humored figure of\nthe colonel surrounded by officers": 36, "He had gone out as far as the first\nstep of the balcony and was loudly shouting across the band that played\nOffenbach's quadrille, waving his arms and giving some orders to a few\nsoldiers standing on one side": 39, 'A group of soldiers, a quartermaster,\nand several subalterns came up to the balcony with Vronsky': 16, 'The colonel\nreturned to the table, went out again onto the steps with a tumbler in\nhis hand, and proposed the toast, "To the health of our former comrade,\nthe gallant general, Prince Serpuhovskoy': 34, 'Hurrah': 1, '"\n\nThe colonel was followed by Serpuhovskoy, who came out onto the steps\nsmiling, with a glass in his hand': 20, '"You always get younger, Bondarenko," he said to the rosy-cheeked,\nsmart-looking quartermaster standing just before him, still youngish\nlooking though doing his second term of service': 26, 'It was three years since Vronsky had seen Serpuhovskoy': 9, 'He looked more\nrobust, had let his whiskers grow, but was still the same graceful\ncreature, whose face and figure were even more striking from their\nsoftness and nobility than their beauty': 32, 'The only change Vronsky\ndetected in him was that subdued, continual radiance of beaming content\nwhich settles on the faces of men who are successful and are sure of\nthe recognition of their success by everyone': 36, 'Vronsky knew that radiant\nair, and immediately observed it in Serpuhovskoy': 11, 'As Serpuhovskoy came down the steps he saw Vronsky': 9, 'A smile of pleasure\nlighted up his face': 8, 'He tossed his head upwards and waved the glass in\nhis hand, greeting Vronsky, and showing him by the gesture that he\ncould not come to him before the quartermaster, who stood craning\nforward his lips ready to be kissed': 40, '"Here he is': 3, '" shouted the colonel': 4, '"Yashvin told me you were in one of\nyour gloomy tempers': 11, '"\n\nSerpuhovskoy kissed the moist, fresh lips of the gallant-looking\nquartermaster, and wiping his mouth with his handkerchief, went up to\nVronsky': 22, '"How glad I am': 4, '" he said, squeezing his hand and drawing him on one\nside': 12, '"You look after him," the colonel shouted to Yashvin, pointing to\nVronsky; and he went down below to the soldiers': 20, the\nadjutant: "Please have this divided from me, each man as much as it\nruns to': 26, '" And he hurriedly took notes for three hundred roubles from\nhis pocketbook, blushing a little': 16, '"Vronsky': 1, 'Have anything to eat or drink': 6, '" asked Yashvin': 3, '"Hi, something\nfor the count to eat': 7, 'Ah, here it is: have a glass': 7, '"\n\nThe fête at the colonel\'s lasted a long it, but it would be dull': 15, 'Of\ncourse I may be mistaken, but I fancy I have a certain capacity for the\nline I\'ve chosen, and that power of any sort in my hands, if it is to\nbe, will be better than in the hands of a good many people I know,"\nsaid Serpuhovskoy, with beaming consciousness of success; "and so the\nnearer I get to it, the better pleased I am': 67, '"\n\n"Perhaps that is true for you, but not for everyone': 11, 'I used to think so\ntoo, but here I live and think life worth living not only for that': 19, '"\n\n"There it\'s out': 4, 'here it comes': 3, '" said Serpuhovskoy, ('TOL CHAPTER 22 PART THREE', {"It was six o'clock already, and so, in order to be there quickly, and\nat the same time not to drive with his own horses, known to everyone,\nVronsky got into Yashvin's hired fly, and told the driver to drive as\nquickly as possible": 44, 'It was a roomy, old-fashioned fly, with seats for\nfour': 10, 'He sat in one corner, stretched his legs out on the front seat,\nand sank into meditation': 17, 'A vague sense of the order into which his affairs had been brought, a\nvague recollection of the friendliness and flattery of Serpuhovskoy,\nwho had considered him a man that was needed, and most of all, the\nanticipation of the interview before him—all blended into a general,\njoyous sense of life': 51, 'This feeling was so strong that he could not help\nsmiling': 11, 'He dropped his legs, crossed one leg over the other knee, and\ntaking it in his hand, felt the springy muscle of the calf, where it\nhad been grazed the day before by his fall, and leaning back he drew\nseveral deep breaths': 43, '"I\'m happy, very happy': 4, '" he said to himself': 5, 'He had often before had\nthis sense of physical joy in his own body, but he had never felt so\nfond of himself, of his own body, as at that moment': 31, 'He enjoyed the\nslight ache in his strong leg, he enjoyed the muscular sensation of\nmovement in his chest as he breathed': 22, 'The bright, cold August day,\nwhich had made Anna feel so hopeless, seemed to him keenly stimulating,\nand refreshed his face and neck that still tingled from the cold water': 30, 'The scent of brilliantine on his whiskers struck him as particularly\npleasant in the fresh air': 16, 'Everything he saw from the carriage window,\neverything in that cold pure air, in the pale light of the sunset, was\nas fresh, and gay, and strong as he was himself: the roofs of the\nhouses shining in the rays of the setting sun, the sharp outlines of\nfences and angles of buildings, the figures of passers-by, the\ncarriages that met him now and then, the motionless green of the trees\nand grass, the fields with evenly drawn furrows of potatoes, and the\nslanting shadows that fell from the houses, and trees, and bushes, and\neven from the rows of potatoes—everything was bright like a pretty\nlandscape just finished and freshly varnished': 112, '"Get on, get on': 4, '" he said to the driver, putting his head out of the\nwindow, and pulling a three-rouble note out of his pocket he handed it\nto the man as he looked round': 32, "The driver's hand fumbled with something\nat the lamp, the whip cracked, and the carriage rolled rapidly along\nthe smooth highroad": 21, '"I want nothing, nothing but this happiness," he thought, staring at\nthe bone button of the bell in the space between the windows, and\npicturing to himself Anna just as he had seen her last time': 36, '"And as I\ngo on, I love her more and more': 11, "Here's the garden of the Vrede Villa": 7, 'Whereabouts there was now no time for\nwonder': 8, 'He called to the driver to stop before reaching the avenue, and\nopening the door, jumped out of the carriage as it was moving, and went\ninto the avenue that led up to the house': 35, 'There was no one in the\navenue; but looking round to the right he caught sight of her': 18, 'Her face\nwas hidden by a veil, but he drank in with glad eyes the conscious of himself from the\nspringy motions of his legs to the movements of his lungs as he\nbreathed, and something set his lips twitching': 30, 'Joining him, she pressed his hand tightly': 7, '"You\'re not angry that I sent for you': 8, 'I absolutely had to see you,"\nshe said; and the serious and set line of her lips, which he saw under\nthe veil, transformed his mood at once': 28, '"I angry': 2, 'But how have you come, where from': 7, '"\n\n"Never mind," she said, laying her hand on his, "come along, I must\ntalk to you': 17, '"\n\nHe saw that something had happened, and that the interview would not be\na joyous one': 17, 'In her presence he had no will of his own: without\nknowing the grounds of her distress, he already felt the same distress\nunconsciously passing over him': 27, '"What is it': 3, 'what': 1, '" he asked her, squeezing her hand with his elbow,\nand trying to read her thoughts in her face': 19, 'She walked on a few steps in silence, gathering up her courage; then\nsuddenly she stopped': 16, '"I did not tell you yesterday," she began, breathing quickly and\npainfully, "that coming home with Alexey Alexandrovitch I told him\neverything': 22, 'told him I could not be his wife, that': 9, 'and told him\neverything': 4, '"\n\nHe heard her, unconsciously bending his whole figure down to her as\nthough hoping in this way to soften the hardness of her position for\nher': 27, 'But directly she had said this he suddenly drew himself up, and a\nproud and hard expression came over his face': 21, '"Yes, yes, that\'s better, a thousand times better': 8, ('TOL CHAPTER 23 PART THREE', {'On Monday there was the usual sitting of the Commission of the 2nd of\nJune': 15, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch walked into the hall where the sitting was\nheld, greeted the members and the president, as usual, and sat down in\nhis place, putting his hand on the papers laid ready before him': 35, 'Among\nthese papers lay the necessary evidence and a rough outline of the\nspeech he intended to make': 18, 'But he did not really need these documents': 8, 'He remembered every point, and did not think it necessary to go over in\nhis memory what he would say': 20, 'He knew that when the time came, and when\nhe saw his enemy facing him, and studiously endeavoring to assume an\nexpression of indifference, his speech would flow of itself better than\nhe could prepare it now': 37, 'He felt that the import of his speech was of\nsuch magnitude that every word of it would have weight': 20, 'Meantime, as he\nlistened to the usual report, he had the most innocent and inoffensive\nair': 16, 'No one, looking at his white hands, with their swollen veins and\nlong fingers, so softly stroking the edges of the white paper that lay\nbefore him, and at the air of weariness with which his head drooped on\none side, would have suspected that in a few minutes a torrent of words\nwould flow from his lips that would arouse a fearful storm, set the\nmembers shouting and attacking one another, and force the president to\ncall for order': 80, 'When the report was over, Alexey Alexandrovitch\nannounced in his subdued, delicate voice that he had several points to\nbring before the meeting in regard to the Commission for the\nReorganization of the Native Tribes': 35, 'All attention was turned upon him': 6, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch cleared his throat, and not looking at his\nopponent, but selecting, as he always did while he was delivering his\nspeeches, the first person sitting opposite him, an inoffensive little\nold man, who never had an opinion of any sort in the Commission, began\nto expound his views': 50, 'When he reached the point about the fundamental\nand radical law, his opponent jumped up and began to protest': 19, 'Stremov,\nwho was also a member of the Commission, and also stung to the quick,\nbegan defending himself, and altogether a stormy sitting followed; but\nAlexey Alexandrovitch triumphed, and his motion was carried, three new\ncommissions were appointed, and the next day in a certain Petersburg\ncircle nothing else was talked of but this sitting': 55, "Alexey\nAlexandrovitch's success had been even greater than he had anticipated": 11, 'Next morning, Tuesday, Alexey Alexandrovitch, on waking up, recollected\nwith pleasure his triumph of the previous day, and he could not help\nsmiling, though he tried to appear indifferent, when the chief\nsecretary of his department, anxious to flatter him, informed him of\nthe rumors that had reached him concerning what had happened in the\nCommission': 56, 'Absorbed in business with the chief secretary, Alexey Alexandrovitch\nhad completely forgotten that it was Tuesday, the day fixed by him for\nthe return of Anna Arkadyevna, and he was surprised and received a\nshock of annoyance when a servant came in to inform him of her arrival': 48, 'Anna had arrived in Petersburg early in the morning; the carriage had\nbeen sent to meet her in accordance with her telegram, and so Alexey\nAlexandrovitch might have known of her arrival': 32, 'But when she arrived,\nhe did not meet her': 9, 'She was told that he had not yet gone out, but was\nbusy with his secretary': 16, 'She sent word to her husband that she had\ncome, went to her own room, and occupied herself in sorting out her\nthings, expecting he would come to her': 29, 'But an hour passed; he did not\ncome': 8, 'She went into the dining-room on the pretext of giving some\ndirections, and spoke loudly on purpose, expecting him to come out\nthere; but he did not come, though she heard him go to the door of his\nstudy as he parted from the chief secretary': 46, 'She knew that he usually\nwent out quickly to his office, and she wanted to see him before that,\nso that their attitude to one another might be defined': 29, 'She walked across the drawing-room and went resolutely to him': 10, 'When she\nwent into his study he was in official uniform, obviously ready to go\nout, sitting at a little table on which he rested his elbows, looking\ndejectedly before him': 31, 'She saw him before he saw her, and she saw that\nhe was thinking of her': 16, 'On seeing her, he would have risen, but changed his mind, then his face\nflushed hotly—a thing Anna had never seen before, and he got up quickly\nand went to meet her, looking not at her eyes, but above them at her\nforehead and hair': 45, 'He went up to her, took her by the hand, and asked\nher to sit down': 16, '"I am very glad you have come," he said, sitting down beside her, and\nobviously wishing to say something, he stuttered': 21, 'Several times he\ntried to begin to speak, but stopped': 10, 'In spite of the fact that,\npreparing herself for meeting him, she had schooled herself to despise\nand reproach him, she did not know what to say to him, and she felt\nsorry for him': 35, 'And so the silence lasted for some time': 8, '"Is Seryozha\nquite well': 4, '" he said, and not waiting for an answer, he added: "I\nshan\'t be dining at home today, and I have got to go out directly': 26, '"\n\n"I had thought of going to Moscow," she said': 10, '"No, you did quite, quite right to come," he said, and was silent\nagain': 14, 'Seeing that he was powerless to begin the conversation, she began\nherself': 12, '"Alexey Alexandrovitch," she said, looking at him and not dropping her\neyes under his persistent gaze at her hair, "I\'m a guilty woman, I\'m a\nbad woman, but I am the same as I was, as I told you then, and I have\ncome to tell you that I can change nothing': 52, '"\n\n"I have asked you no question about that," he said, all at once,\nresolutely and with hatred looking her straight in the face; "that was\nas I had supposed': 30, '" Under the influence of anger he apparently regained\ncomplete possession of all his faculties': 15, '"But as I told you then, and\nhave written to you," he said in a thin, shrill voice, "I repeat now,\nthat I am not bound to know this': 29, 'I ignore it': 3, 'Not all wives are so\nkind as you, to be in such a hurry to communicate such agreeable news\nto their husbands': 22, '" He laid special emphasis on the word "agreeable': 9, '"\n"I shall ignore it so long as the world knows nothing of it, so long as\nmy name is not disgraced': 22, 'And so I simply inform you that our relations\nmust be just as they have always been, and that only in the event of\nyour compromising me I shall be obliged to take steps to secure my\nhonor': 38, '"\n\n"But our relations cannot be the same as always," Anna began in a timid\nvoice, looking at him with dismay': 21, 'When she saw once more those composed gestures, heard that shrill,\nchildish, and sarcastic voice, her aversion for him extinguished her\npity for him, and she felt only afraid, but at all costs she wanted to\nmake clear her position': 40, '"I cannot be your wife while I': 7, '" she began': 3, 'He laughed a cold and malignant laugh': 7, '"The manner of life you have chosen is reflected, I suppose, in your\nideas': 14, 'I have too much respect or contempt, or both': 9, 'I respect your\npast and despise your present': 8, 'that I was far from the\ninterpretation you put on my words': 12, '"\n\nAnna sighed and bowed her head': 7, '"Though indeed I fail to comprehend how, with the independence you\nshow," he went on, getting hot, "—announcing your infidelity to your\nhusband and seeing nothing reprehensible in it, apparently—you can see\nanything reprehensible in performing a wife\'s duties in relation to\nyour husband': 44, '"\n\n"Alexey Alexandrovitch': 3, 'What is it you want of me': 7, '"\n\n"I want you not to meet that man here, and to conduct yourself so that\nneither the world nor the servants can reproach you': 25, 'not to see him': 4, "That's not much, I think": 5, 'And in return you will enjoy all the\nprivileges of a faithful wife without fulfilling her duties': 17, "That's all\nI have to say to you": 8, "Now it's time for me to go": 7, "I'm not dining at\nhome": 5, '" He got up and moved towards the door': 9, 'Anna got up too': 4, 'Bowing in silence, he let her pass before him': 9, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 24 PART THREE', {'The night spent by Levin on the haycock did not pass without result for\nhim': 15, 'The way in which he had been managing his land revolted him and\nhad lost all attraction for him': 19, 'In spite of the magnificent harvest,\nnever had there been, or, at least, never it seemed to him, had there\nbeen so many hindrances and so many quarrels between him and the\npeasants as that year, and the origin of these failures and this\nhostility was now perfectly comprehensible to him': 51, 'The delight he had\nexperienced in the work itself, and the consequent greater intimacy\nwith the peasants, the envy he felt of them, of their life, the desire\nto adopt that life, which had been to him that night not a dream but an\nintention, the execution of which he had thought out in detail—all this\nhad so transformed his view of the farming of the land as he had\nmanaged it, that he could not take his former interest in it, and could\nnot help seeing that unpleasant relation between him and the workpeople\nwhich was the foundation of it all': 102, 'The herd of improved cows such as\nPava, the whole land ploughed over and enriched, the nine level fields\nsurrounded with hedges, the two hundred and forty acres heavily\nmanured, the seed sown in drills, and all the rest of it—it was all\nsplendid if only the work had been done for themselves, or for\nthemselves and comrades—people in sympathy with them': 62, 'But he saw\nclearly now (his work on a book of agriculture, in which the chief\nelement in husbandry was to have been the laborer, greatly assisted him\nin this) that the sort of farming he was carrying on was nothing but a\ncruel and stubborn struggle between him and the laborers, in which\nthere was on one side—his side—a continual intense effort to change\neverything to a pattern he considered better; on the other side, the\nnatural order of things': 81, 'And in this struggle he saw that with immense\nexpenditure of force on his side, and with no effort or even intention\non the other side, all that was attained was that the work did not go\nto the liking of either side, and that splendid tools, splendid cattle\nand land were spoiled with no good to anyone': 58, 'Worst of all, the energy\nexpended on this work was not simply wasted': 13, 'He could not help feeling\nnow, since the meaning of this system had become clear to him, that the\naim of his energy was a most unworthy one': 28, 'In reality, what was the\nstruggle about': 7, "He was struggling for every farthing of his share (and\nhe could not help it, for he had only to relax his efforts, and he\nwould not have had the money to pay his laborers' wages), while they\nwere only struggling to be able to do their work easily and agreeably,\nthat is to say, as they were used to doing it": 62, 'It was for his interests\nthat every laborer should work as hard as possible, and that while\ndoing so he should keep his wits about him, so as to try not to break\nthe winnowing machines, the horse rakes, the thrashing machines, that\nhe should attend to what he was doing': 51, 'What the laborer wanted was to\nwork as pleasantly as possible, with rests, and above all, carelessly\nand heedlessly, without thinking': 21, 'That summer Levin saw this at every\nstep': 8, 'He sent the men to mow some clover for hay, picking out the worst\npatches where the clover was overgrown with grass and weeds and of no\nuse for seed; again and again they mowed the best acres of clover,\njustifying themselves by the pretense that the bailiff had told them\nto, and trying to pacify him with the assurance that it would be\nsplendid hay; but he knew that it was owing to those acres being so\nmuch easier to mow': 82, 'He sent out a hay machine for pitching the hay—it\nwas broken at the first row because it was dull work for a peasant to\nsit on the seat in front with the great wings waving above him': 38, 'And he\nwas told, "Don\'t trouble, your honor, sure, the womenfolks will pitch\nit quick enough': 16, '" The ploughs were practically useless, because it\nnever occurred to the laborer to raise the share when he turned the\nplough, and forcing it round, he strained the horses and tore up the\nground, and Levin was begged not to mind about it': 44, 'The horses were\nallowed to stray into the wheat because not a single laborer would\nconsent to be night-watchman, and in spite of orders to the contrary,\nthe laborers insisted on taking turns for night duty, and Ivan, after\nworking all day long, fell asleep, and was very penitent for his fault,\nsaying, "Do what you will to me, your honor': 61, '"\n\nThey killed three of the best calves by letting them into the clover\naftermath without care as to their drinking, and nothing would make the\nmen believe that they had been blown out by the clover, but they told\nhim, by way of consolation, that one of his neighbors had lost a\nhundred and twelve head of cattle in three days': 62, 'All this happened, not\nbecause anyone felt ill-will to Levin or his farm; on the contrary, he\nknew that they liked him, thought him a simple gentleman (their highest\npraise); but it happened simply because all they wanted was to work\nmerrily and carelessly, and his interests were not only remote and\nincomprehensible to them, but fatally opposed to their most just\nclaims': 63, 'Long before, Levin had felt dissatisfaction with his own\nposition in regard to the land': 15, 'He saw where his boat leaked, but he\ndid not look for the leak, perhaps purposely deceiving himself': 18, '(Nothing would be left him if he lost faith in it': 11, ') But now he could\ndeceive himself no longer': 9, 'The farming of the land, as he was managing\nit, had become not merely unattractive but revolting to him, and he\ncould take no further interest in it': 28, 'To this now was joined the presence, only twenty-five miles off, of\nKitty Shtcherbatskaya, whom he longed to see and could not see': 23, 'Darya\nAlexandrovna Oblonskaya had invited him, when he was over there, to\ncome; to come with the object of renewing his offer to her sister, who\nwould, so she gave him to understand, accept him now': 36, "Levin himself had\nfelt on seeing Kitty Shtcherbatskaya that he had never ceased to love\nher; but he could not go over to the Oblonskys', knowing she was there": 29, 'The fact that he had made her an offer, and she had refused him, had\nplaced an insuperable barrier between her and him': 23, '"I can\'t ask her to\nbe my wife merely because she can\'t be the wife of the man she wanted\nto marry," he said to himself': 26, 'The thought of this made him cold and\nhostile to her': 11, '"I should not be able to speak to her without a feeling\nof reproach; I could not look at her without resentment; and she will\nonly hate me all the more, as she\'s bound to': 35, 'And besides, how can I\nnow, after what Darya Alexandrovna told me, go to see them': 16, 'Can I help\nshowing that I know what she told me': 11, 'And me to go magnanimously to\nforgive her, and have pity on her': 13, 'Me go through a performance before\nher of forgiving, and deigning to bestow my love on her': 17, 'What\ninduced Darya Alexandrovna to tell me that': 8, "By chance I might have seen\nher, then everything would have happened of itself; but, as it is, it's\nout of the question, out of the question": 27, '"\n\nDarya Alexandrovna sent him a letter, asking him for a side-saddle for\nKitty\'s use': 15, '"I\'m told you have a side-saddle," she wrote to him; "I\nhope you will bring it over yourself': 18, '"\n\nThis was more than he could stand': 8, 'How could a woman of any\nintelligence, of any delicacy, put her sister in such a humiliating\nposition': 18, 'He wrote ten notes, and tore them all up, and sent the saddle\nwithout any reply': 16, 'To write that he would go was impossible, because he\ncould not go; to write that he could not come because something\nprevented him, or that he would be away, that was still worse': 34, 'He sent\nthe saddle without an answer, and with a sense of having done something\nshameful; he handed over all the now revolting business of the estate\nto the bailiff, and set off next day to a remote district to see his\nfriend Sviazhsky, who had splendid marshes for grouse in his\nneighborhood, and had lately written to ask him to keep a long-standing\npromise to stay with him': 69, 'The grouse-marsh, in the Surovsky district,\nhad long tempted Levin, but he had continually put off this visit on\naccount of his work on the estate': 26, 'Now he was glad to get away from the\nneighborhood of the Shtcherbatskys, and still more from his farm work,\nespecially on a shooting expedition, which always in trouble served as\nthe best consolation': 34, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 25 PART THREE', {'In the Surovsky district there was no railway nor service of post\nhorses, and Levin drove there with his own horses in his big,\nold-fashioned carriage': 26, "He stopped halfway at a well-to-do peasant's to feed his horses": 11, 'A\nbald, well-preserved old man, with a broad, red beard, gray on his\ncheeks, opened the gate, squeezing against the gatepost to let the\nthree horses pass': 27, 'Directing the coachman to a place under the shed in\nthe big, clean, tidy yard, with charred, old-fashioned ploughs in it,\nthe old man asked Levin to come into the parlor': 31, 'A cleanly dressed\nyoung woman, with clogs on her bare feet, was scrubbing the floor in\nthe new outer room': 20, 'She was frightened of the dog, that ran in after\nLevin, and uttered a shriek, but began laughing at her own fright at\nonce when she was told the dog would not hurt her': 34, 'Pointing Levin with\nher bare arm to the door into the parlor, she bent down again, hiding\nher handsome face, and went on scrubbing': 24, '"Would you like the samovar': 5, '" she asked': 3, '"Yes, please': 2, '"\n\nThe parlor was a big room, with a Dutch stove, and a screen dividing it\ninto two': 18, 'Under the holy pictures stood a table painted in patterns, a\nbench, and two chairs': 15, 'Near the entrance was a dresser full of\ncrockery': 9, 'The shutters were closed, there were few flies, and it was so\nclean that Levin was anxious that Laska, who had been running along the\nroad and bathing in puddles, should not muddy the floor, and ordered\nher to a place in the corner by the door': 47, 'After looking round the\nparlor, Levin went out in the back yard': 12, 'The good-looking young woman\nin clogs, swinging the empty pails on the yoke, ran on before him to\nthe well for water': 22, '"Look sharp, my girl': 4, '" the old man shouted after her, good-humoredly,\nand he went up to Levin': 14, '"Well, sir, are you going to Nikolay\nIvanovitch Sviazhsky': obviously\naccepting the invitation with pleasure': 17, '"But just a glass for company': 6, '"\n\nOver their tea Levin heard all about the old man\'s farming': 12, 'Ten years\nbefore, the old man had rented three hundred acres from the lady who\nowned them, and a year ago he had bought them and rented another three\nhundred from a neighboring landowner': 34, 'A small part of the land—the\nworst part—he let out for rent, while a hundred acres of arable land he\ncultivated himself with his family and two hired laborers': 29, 'The old man\ncomplained that things were doing badly': 9, 'But Levin saw that he simply\ndid so from a feeling of propriety, and that his farm was in a\nflourishing condition': 22, 'If it had been unsuccessful he would not have\nbought land at thirty-five roubles the going": 47, 'From his conversation with the old man, Levin thought he\nwas not averse to new methods either': 17, "He had planted a great many\npotatoes, and his potatoes, as Levin had seen driving seen this splendid fodder wasted, and tried to get it saved; but\nalways it had turned out to be impossible': 25, 'The peasant got this done,\nand he could not say enough in praise of it as food for
