that demanded his special attention": 29, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 26 PART THREE', {'Sviazhsky was the marshal of his district': 7, 'He was five years older than\nLevin, and had long been married': 12, 'His sister-in-law, a young girl Levin\nliked very much, lived in his house; and Levin knew that Sviazhsky and\nhis wife would have greatly liked to marry the girl to him': 31, 'He knew\nthis with certainty, as so-called eligible young men always know it,\nthough he could never have brought himself to speak of it to anyone;\nand he knew too that, although he wanted to get married, and although\nby every token this very attractive girl would make an excellent wife,\nhe could no more have married her, even if he had not been in love with\nKitty Shtcherbatskaya, than he could have flown up to the sky': 78, 'And this\nknowledge poisoned the pleasure he had hoped to find in the visit to\nSviazhsky': 16, "On getting Sviazhsky's letter with the invitation for shooting, Levin\nhad immediately thought of this; but in spite of it he had made up his\nmind that Sviazhsky's having such views for him was simply his own\ngroundless supposition, and so he would go, all the same": 47, 'Besides, at\nthe bottom of his heart he had a desire to try himself, put himself to\nthe test in regard to this girl': 24, "The Sviazhskys' home-life was\nexceedingly pleasant, and Sviazhsky himself, the best type of man\ntaking part in local affairs that Levin knew, was very interesting to\nhim": 27, 'Sviazhsky was one of those people, always a source of wonder to Levin,\nwhose convictions, very logical though never original, go one way by\nthemselves, while their life, exceedingly definite and firm in its\ndirection, goes its way quite apart and almost always in direct\ncontradiction to their convictions': 49, 'Sviazhsky was an extremely advanced\nman': 6, 'He despised the nobility, and believed the mass of the nobility to\nbe secretly in favor of serfdom, and only concealing their views from\ncowardice': 25, 'He regarded Russia as a ruined country, rather after the\nstyle of Turkey, and the government of Russia as so bad that he never\npermitted himself to criticize its doings seriously, and yet he was a\nfunctionary of that government and a model marshal of nobility, and\nwhen he drove about he always wore the cockade of office and the cap\nwith the red band': 65, 'He considered human life only tolerable abroad, and\nwent abroad to stay at every opportunity, and at the same time he\ncarried on a complex and improved system of agriculture in Russia, and\nwith extreme interest followed everything and knew everything that was\nbeing done in Russia': 47, 'He considered the Russian peasant as occupying a\nstage of development intermediate between the ape and the man, and at\nthe same time in the local assemblies no one was readier to shake hands\nwith the peasants and listen to their opinion': 42, 'He believed neither in\nGod nor the devil, but was much concerned about the question of the\nimprovement of the clergy and the maintenance of their revenues, and\ntook special trouble to keep up the church in his village': 39, 'On the woman question he was on the side of the extreme advocates of\ncomplete liberty for women, and especially their right to labor': 24, "But he\nlived with his wife on such terms that their affectionate childless\nhome life was the admiration of everyone, and arranged his wife's life\nso that she did nothing and could do nothing but share her husband's\nefforts that her time should pass as happily and as agreeably as\npossible": 51, 'If it had not been a characteristic of Levin\'s to put the most\nfavorable interpretation on people, Sviazhsky\'s character would have\npresented no doubt or difficulty to him: he would have said to himself,\n"a fool or a knave," and everything would have seemed clear': 45, 'But he\ncould not say "a fool," because Sviazhsky was unmistakably clever, and\nmoreover, a highly cultivated man, who was exceptionally modest over\nhis culture': 25, 'There was not a subject he knew nothing of': 9, 'But he did not\ndisplay his knowledge except when he was compelled to do so': 15, 'Still less\ncould Levin say that he was a knave, as Sviazhsky was unmistakably an\nhonest, good-hearted, sensible man, who worked good-humoredly, keenly,\nand perseveringly at his work; he was held in high honor by everyone\nabout him, and certainly he had never consciously done, and was indeed\nincapable of doing, anything base': 53, 'Levin tried to understand him, and could not understand him, and looked\nat him and his life as at a living enigma': 22, 'Levin and he were very friendly, and so Levin used to venture to sound\nSviazhsky, to try to get at the very foundation of his view of life;\nbut it was always in vain': 34, "Every time Levin tried to penetrate beyond\nthe outer chambers of Sviazhsky's mind, which were hospitably open to\nall, he noticed that Sviazhsky was slightly disconcerted; faint signs\nof alarm were visible in his eyes, as though he were afraid Levin would\nunderstand him, and he would give him a kindly, good-humored repulse": 53, 'Just now, since his disenchantment with farming, Levin was particularly\nglad to stay with Sviazhsky': 15, 'Apart from the fact that the sight of this\nhappy and affectionate couple, so pleased with themselves and everyone\nelse, and their well-ordered home had always a cheering effect on\nLevin, he felt a longing, now that he was so dissatisfied with his own\nlife, to get at that secret in Sviazhsky that gave him such clearness,\ndefiniteness, and good courage in life': 63, "Moreover, Levin knew that at\nSviazhsky's he should meet the landowners of the neighborhood, and it\nwas particularly interesting for him just now to hear and take part in\nthose rural conversations concerning crops, laborers' wages, and so on,\nwhich, he was aware, are conventionally regarded as something very low,\nbut which seemed to him just now to constitute the one subject of\nimportance": 64, '"It was not, perhaps, of importance in the days of serfdom,\nand it may not be of importance in England': 20, 'In both cases the\nconditions of agriculture are firmly established; but among us now,\nwhen everything has been turned upside down and is only just taking\nshape, the question what form these conditions will take is the one\nquestion of importance in Russia," thought Levin': 45, 'The shooting turned out to be worse than Levin had expected': 11, 'The marsh\nwas dry and there were no grouse at all': 11, 'He walked about the whole day\nand only brought back three birds, but to make up for that—he brought\nback, as he always did from shooting, an excellent appetite, excellent\nspirits, and that keen, intellectual mood which with him always\naccompanied violent physical exertion': 44, 'And while out shooting, when he\nseemed to be thinking of nothing at all, suddenly the old man and his\nfamily kept coming back to his mind, and the impression of them seemed\nto claim not merely his attention, but the solution of some question\nconnected with them': 48, 'In the evening at tea, two landowners who had come about some business\nconnected with a wardship were of the party, and the interesting\nconversation Levin had been looking forward to sprang up': 33, 'Levin was sitting beside his hostess at the tea table, and was obliged\nto keep up a conversation with her and her sister, who was sitting\nopposite him': 28, 'Madame Sviazhskaya was a round-faced, fair-haired, rather\nshort woman, all smiles and dimples': 13, 'Levin tried through her to get a\nsolution of the weighty enigma her husband presented to his mind; but\nhe had not complete freedom of ideas, because he was in an agony of\nembarrassment': 34, 'This agony of embarrassment was due to the fact that the\nsister-in-law was sitting opposite to him, in a dress, specially put\non, as he fancied, for his benefit, cut particularly open, in the shape\nof a trapeze, on her white bosom': 42, "This quadrangular opening, in spite\nof the bosom's being very white, or just because it was very white,\ndeprived Levin of the full use of his faculties": 27, 'He imagined, probably\nmistakenly, that this low-necked bodice had been made on his account,\nand felt that he had no right to look at it, and tried not to look at\nit; but he felt that he was to blame for the very fact of the\nlow-necked bodice having been made': 51, 'It seemed to Levin that he had\ndeceived someone, that he ought to explain something, but that to\nexplain it was impossible, and for that reason he was continually\nblushing, was ill at ease and awkward': 36, 'His awkwardness infected the\npretty sister-in-law too': 7, 'But their hostess appeared not to observe\nthis, and kept purposely drawing her into the conversation': 16, '"You say," she said, pursuing the subject that had been started, "that\nmy husband cannot be interested in what\'s Russian': 20, "It's quite the\ncontrary; he is always in cheerful spirits abroad, but not as he is\nhere": 17, 'Here, he feels in his proper place': 7, 'He has so much to do, and he\nhas the faculty of interesting himself in everything': 16, "Oh, you've not\nbeen to see our school, have you": 10, '"\n\n"I\'ve seen it': 4, "The little house covered with ivy, isn't it": 8, '"\n\n"Yes; that\'s Nastia\'s work," she said, indicating her sister': 10, '"You teach in it yourself': 5, '" asked Levin, trying to look above the open\nneck, but feeling that wherever he looked in that direction he should\nsee it': 23, '"Yes; I used to teach in it myself, and do teach still, but we have a\nfirst-rate schoolmistress now': 19, "And we've started gymnastic exercises": 5, '"\n\n"No, thank you, I won\'t have any more tea," said Levin, and conscious\nof doing a rude thing, but incapable of continuing the conversation, he\ngot up, blushing': 29, '"I hear a very interesting conversation," he added,\nand walked to the other end of the table, where Sviazhsky was sitting\nwith the two gentlemen of the neighborhood': 28, 'Sviazhsky was sitting\nsideways, with one elbow on the table, and a cup in one hand, while\nwith the other hand he gathered up his beard, held it to his nose and\nlet it drop again, as though he were smelling it': 42, 'His brilliant black\neyes were looking straight at the excited country gentleman with gray\nwhiskers, and apparently he derived amusement from his remarks': 23, 'The\ngentleman was complaining of the peasants': 7, "It was evident to Levin that\nSviazhsky knew an answer to this gentleman's complaints, which would at\nonce demolish his whole contention, but that in his position he could\nnot give utterance to this answer, and listened, not without pleasure,\nto the landowner's comic speeches": 45, 'The gentleman with the gray whiskers was obviously an inveterate\nadherent of serfdom and a devoted agriculturist, who had lived all his\nlife in the country': 26, 'Levin saw proofs of this in his dress, in the\nold-fashioned threadbare coat, obviously not his everyday attire, in\nhis shrewd, deep-set eyes, in his idiomatic, fluent Russian, in the\nimperious tone that had become habitual from long use, and in the\nresolute gestures of his large, red, sunburnt hands, with an old\nbetrothal ring on the little finger': 59, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 27 PART THREE', {'"If I\'d only the heart to throw up what\'s been set going': 12, 'such a lot\nof trouble wasted': 6, "I'd turn my back on the whole business, sell up,\ngo off like Nikolay Ivanovitch": 15, 'to hear _La Belle Hélène_," said the\nlandowner, a pleasant smile lighting up his shrewd old face': 17, '"But you see you don\'t throw it up," said Nikolay Ivanovitch Sviazhsky;\n"so there must be something gained': 18, '"\n\n"The only gain is that I live in my own house, neither bought nor\nhired': 16, 'Besides, one keeps hoping the people will learn sense': 9, "Though,\ninstead of that, you'd never believe it—the drunkenness, the\nimmorality": 11, 'They keep chopping and changing their bits of land': 9, 'Not a\nsight of a horse or a cow': 9, "The peasant's dying of hunger, but just go\nand take him on as a laborer, he'll do his best to do you a mischief,\nand then bring you up before the justice of the peace": 35, '"\n\n"But then you make complaints to the justice too," said Sviazhsky': 12, '"I lodge complaints': 3, 'Not for anything in the world': 6, 'Such a talking, and\nsuch a to-do, that one would have cause to regret it': 15, 'At the works, for\ninstance, they pocketed the advance-money and made off': 12, 'What did the\njustice do': 5, 'Why, acquitted them': 3, 'Nothing keeps them in order but their\nown communal court and their village elder': 14, "He'll flog them in the good\nold style": 8, "But for that there'd be nothing for it but to give it all up\nand run away": 17, '"\n\nObviously the landowner was chaffing Sviazhsky, who, far from resenting\nit, was apparently amused by it': 17, '"But you see we manage our land without such extreme measures," said\nhe, smiling: "Levin and I and this gentleman': 20, '"\n\nHe indicated the other landowner': 6, '"Yes, the thing\'s done at Mihail Petrovitch\'s, but ask him how it\'s\ndone': 13, 'Do you call that a rational system': 7, '" said the landowner,\nobviously rather proud of the word "rational': 11, '"\n\n"My system\'s very simple," said Mihail Petrovitch, "thank God': 10, 'All my\nmanagement rests on getting the money ready for the autumn taxes, and\nthe peasants come to me, ‘Father, master, help us': 23, "' Well, the peasants\nare all one's neighbors; one feels for them": 12, "So one advances them a\nthird, but one says: ‘Remember, lads, I have helped you, and you must\nhelp me when I need it—whether it's the sowing of the oats, or the\nhaycutting, or the harvest'; and well, one agrees, so much for each\ntaxpayer—though there are dishonest ones among them too, it's true": 54, '"\n\nLevin, who had long been familiar with these patriarchal methods,\nexchanged glances with Sviazhsky and interrupted Mihail Petrovitch,\nturning again to the gentleman with the gray whiskers': 28, '"Then what do you think': 5, '" he asked; "what system is one to adopt\nnowadays': 10, '"\n\n"Why, manage like Mihail Petrovitch, or let the land for half the crop\nor for rent to the peasants; that one can do—only that\'s just how the\ngeneral prosperity of the country is being ruined': 36, 'Where the land with\nserf-labor and good management gave a yield of nine to one, on the\nhalf-crop system it yields three to one': 24, 'Russia has been ruined by the\nemancipation': 7, '"\n\nSviazhsky looked with smiling eyes at Levin, and even made a faint\ngesture of irony to him; but Levin did not think the landowner\'s words\nabsurd, he understood them better than he did Sviazhsky': 35, 'A great deal\nmore of what the gentleman with the gray whiskers said to show in what\nway Russia was ruined by the emancipation struck him indeed as very\ntrue, new to him, and quite incontestable': 36, 'The landowner unmistakably\nspoke his own individual thought—a thing that very rarely happens—and a\nthought to which he had been brought not by a desire of finding some\nexercise for an idle brain, but a thought which had grown up out of the\nconditions of his life, which he had brooded over in the solitude of\nhis village, and had considered in every aspect': 64, '"The point is, don\'t you see, that progress of every sort is only made\nby the use of authority," he said, evidently wishing to show he was not\nwithout culture': 30, '"Take the reforms of Peter, of Catherine, of\nAlexander': 9, 'Take European history': 3, 'And progress in agriculture more than\nanything else—the potato, for instance, that was introduced among us by\nforce': 18, "The wooden plough too wasn't always used": 7, 'It was introduced\nmaybe in the days before the Empire, but it was probably brought in by\nforce': 18, 'Now, in our own day, we landowners in the serf times used\nvarious improvements in our husbandry: drying machines and thrashing\nmachines, and carting manure and all the modern implements—all that we\nbrought into use by our authority, and the peasants opposed it at\nfirst, and ended by imitating us': 50, 'Now, by the abolition of serfdom we\nhave been deprived of our authority; and so our husbandry, where it had\nbeen raised to a high level, is bound to sink to the most savage\nprimitive condition': 36, "That's how I see it": 5, '"\n\n"But why so': 4, 'If it\'s rational, you\'ll be able to keep up the same\nsystem with hired labor," said Sviazhsky': 17, '"We\'ve no power over them': 5, 'With whom am I going to work the system,\nallow me to ask': 13, '"\n\n"There it is—the labor force—the chief element in agriculture," thought\nLevin': 12, '"With laborers': 2, '"\n\n"The laborers won\'t work well, and won\'t work with good implements': 12, "Our\nlaborer can do nothing but get drunk like a pig, and when he's drunk he\nruins everything you give him": 21, 'He makes the horses ill with too much\nwater, cuts good harness, barters the tires of the wheels for drink,\ndrops bits of iron into the thrashing machine, so as to break it': 33, "He\nloathes the sight of anything that's not after his fashion": 11, "And that's\nhow it is the whole level of husbandry has fallen": 12, 'Lands gone out of\ncultivation, overgrown with weeds, or divided among the peasants, and\nwhere millions of bushels were raised you get a hundred thousand; the\nwealth of the country has decreased': 32, 'If the same thing had been done,\nbut with care that': 11, '"\n\nAnd he proceeded to unfold his own scheme of emancipation by means of\nwhich these drawbacks might have been avoided': 21, 'This did not interest Levin, but when he had finished, Levin went back\nto his first position, and, addressing Sviazhsky, and trying to draw\nhim into expressing his serious opinion:—\n\n"That the standard of culture is falling, and that with our present\nrelations to the peasants there is no possibility of farming on a\nrational system to yield a profit—that\'s perfectly true," said he': 64, '"I don\'t believe it," Sviazhsky replied quite seriously; "all I see is\nthat we don\'t know how to cultivate the land, and that our system of\nagriculture in the serf days was by no means too high, but too low': 40, "We\nhave no machines, no good stock, no efficient supervision; we don't\neven know how to keep accounts": 18, "Ask any landowner; he won't be able to\ntell you what crop's profitable, and what's not": 16, '"\n\n"Italian bookkeeping," said the gentleman of the gray whiskers\nironically': 11, '"You may keep your books as you like, but if they spoil\neverything for you, there won\'t be any profit': 20, '"\n\n"Why do they spoil things': 6, "A poor thrashing machine, or your Russian\npresser, they will break, but my steam press they don't break": 18, "A\nwretched Russian nag they'll ruin, but keep good dray-horses—they won't\nruin them": 13, 'And so it is all round': 6, 'We must raise our farming to a\nhigher level': 9, '"\n\n"Oh, if one only had the means to do it, Nikolay Ivanovitch': 13, "It's all\nvery well for you; but for me, with a son to keep at the university,\nlads to be educated at the high school—how am I going to buy these\ndray-horses": 32, '"\n\n"Well, that\'s what the land banks are for': 9, '"\n\n"To get what\'s left me sold by auction': 9, 'No, thank you': 3, '"\n\n"I don\'t agree that it\'s necessary or possible to raise the level of\nagriculture still higher," said Levin': 19, '"I devote myself to it, and I\nhave means, but I can do nothing': 14, "As to the banks, I don't know to whom\nthey're any good": 12, "For my part, anyway, whatever I've spent money on in\nthe way of husbandry, it has been a loss: stock—a loss, machinery—a\nloss": 23, '"\n\n"That\'s true enough," the gentleman with the gray whiskers chimed in,\npositively laughing with satisfaction': 16, '"And I\'m not the only one," pursued Levin': 8, '"I mix with all the\nneighboring landowners, who are cultivating their land on a rational\nsystem; they all, with rare exceptions, are doing so at a loss': 27, 'Come,\ntell us how does your land do—does it pay': 10, '" said Levin, and at once in\nSviazhsky\'s eyes he detected that fleeting expression of alarm which he\nhad noticed whenever he had tried to penetrate beyond the outer\nchambers of Sviazhsky\'s mind': 33, "Moreover, this question on Levin's part was not quite in good faith": 12, 'Madame Sviazhskaya had just told him at tea that they had that summer\ninvited a German expert in bookkeeping from Moscow, who for a\nconsideration of five hundred roubles had investigated the management\nof their property, and found that it was costing them a loss of three\nthousand odd roubles': 50, 'She did not remember the precise sum, but it\nappeared that the German had worked it out to the fraction of a\nfarthing': 23, "The gray-whiskered landowner smiled at the mention of the profits of\nSviazhsky's farming, obviously aware how much gain his neighbor and\nmarshal was likely to be making": 27, '"Possibly it does not pay," answered Sviazhsky': 7, '"That merely proves\neither that I\'m a bad manager, or that I\'ve sunk my capital for the\nincrease of my rents': 21, '"\n\n"Oh, rent': 3, '" Levin cried with horror': 5, '"Rent there may be in Europe,\nwhere land has been improved by the labor put into it, but with us all\nthe land is deteriorating from the labor put into it—in other words\nthey\'re working it out; so there\'s no question of rent': 43, '"\n\n"How no rent': 4, "It's a law": 3, '"\n\n"Then we\'re outside the law; rent explains nothing for us, but simply\nmuddles us': 15, 'No, tell me how there can be a theory of rent': 11, '"\n\n"Will you have some junket': 6, 'Masha, pass us some junket or raspberries': 7, '"\nHe turned to his wife': 6, '"Extraordinarily late the raspberries are\nlasting this year': 8, '"\n\nAnd in the happiest frame of mind Sviazhsky got up and walked off,\napparently supposing the conversation to have ended at the very point\nwhen to Levin it seemed that it was only just beginning': 36, "Having lost his antagonist, Levin continued the conversation with the\ngray-whiskered landowner, trying to prove to him that all the\ndifficulty arises from the fact that we don't find out the\npeculiarities and habits of our laborer; but the landowner, like all\nmen who think independently and in isolation, was slow in taking in any\nother person's idea, and particularly partial to his own": 64, 'He stuck to\nit that the Russian peasant is a swine and likes swinishness, and that\nto get him out of his swinishness one must have authority, and there is\nnone; one must have the stick, and we have become so liberal that we\nhave all of a sudden replaced the stick that served us for a thousand\nyears by lawyers and model prisons, where the worthless, stinking\npeasant is fed on good soup and has a fixed allowance of cubic feet of\nair': 84, '"What makes you think," said Levin, trying to get back to the question,\n"that it\'s impossible to find some relation to the laborer in which the\nlabor would become productive': 30, '"\n\n"That never could be so with the Russian peasantry; we\'ve no power over\nthem," answered the landowner': 18, '"How can new conditions be found': 6, '" said Sviazhsky': 3, 'Having eaten some\njunket and lighted a cigarette, he came back to the discussion': 14, '"All\npossible relations to the labor force have been defined and studied,"\nhe said': 14, '"The relic of barbarism, the primitive commune with each\nguarantee for all, will disappear of itself; serfdom has been\nabolished—there remains nothing but free labor, and its forms are fixed\nand ready made, and must be adopted': 37, "Permanent hands, day-laborers,\nrammers—you can't get out of those forms": 10, '"\n\n"But Europe is dissatisfied with these forms': 8, '"\n\n"Dissatisfied, and seeking new ones': 6, 'And will find them, in all\nprobability': 7, '"\n\n"That\'s just what I was meaning," answered Levin': 9, '"Why shouldn\'t we\nseek them for ourselves': 7, '"\n\n"Because it would be just like inventing afresh the means for\nconstructing railways': 14, 'They are ready, invented': 4, '"\n\n"But if they don\'t do for us, if they\'re stupid': 11, '" said Levin': 3, 'And again he detected the expression of alarm in the eyes of Sviazhsky': 13, '"Oh, yes; we\'ll bury the world under our caps': 9, "We've found the secret\nEurope was seeking for": 8, "I've heard all that; but, excuse me, do you\nknow all that's been done in Europe on the question of the organization\nof labor": 24, '"\n\n"No, very little': 4, '"\n\n"That question is now absorbing the best minds in Europe': 11, 'The\nSchulze-Delitsch movement': 3, checking Levin in\nhis inconvenient habit of peeping into what was beyond the outer\nchambers of his mind, went to see his guests out': 34, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 28 PART THREE', {"Levin was insufferably bored that evening with the ladies; he was\nstirred as he had never been before by the idea that the\ndissatisfaction he was feeling with his system of managing his land was\nnot an exceptional case, but the general condition of things in Russia;\nthat the organization of some relation of the laborers to the soil in\nwhich they would work, as with the peasant he had met half-way to the\nSviazhskys', was not a dream, but a problem which must be solved": 86, 'And\nit seemed to him that the problem could be solved, and that he ought to\ntry and solve it': 20, "After saying good-night to the ladies, and promising to stay the whole\nof the next day, so as to make an expedition on horseback with them to\nsee an interesting ruin in the crown forest, Levin went, before going\nto bed, into his host's study to get the books on the labor question\nthat Sviazhsky had offered him": 58, "Sviazhsky's study was a huge room,\nsurrounded by bookcases and with two tables in it—one a massive\nwriting-table, standing in the middle of the room, and the other a\nround table, covered with recent numbers of reviews and journals in\ndifferent languages, ranged like the rays of a star round the lamp": 52, 'On\nthe writing-table was a stand of drawers marked with gold lettering,\nand full of papers of various sorts': 19, 'Sviazhsky took out the books, and sat down in a rocking-chair': 11, '"What are you looking at there': 6, '" he said to Levin, who was standing at\nthe round table looking through the reviews': 16, '"Oh, yes, there\'s a very interesting article here," said Sviazhsky of\nthe review Levin was holding in his hand': 19, '"It appears," he went on,\nwith eager interest, "that Friedrich was not, after all, the person\nchiefly responsible for the partition of Poland': 23, 'It is proved': 3, '"\n\nAnd with his characteristic clearness, he summed up those new, very\nimportant, and interesting revelations': 16, 'Although Levin was engrossed at\nthe moment by his ideas about the problem of the land, he wondered, as\nhe heard Sviazhsky: "What is there inside of him': 28, 'And why, why is he\ninterested in the partition of Poland': 11, '" When Sviazhsky had finished,\nLevin could not help asking: "Well, and what then': 14, '" But there was\nnothing to follow': 7, 'It was simply interesting that it had been proved to\nbe so and so': 14, 'But Sviazhsky did not explain, and saw no need to explain\nwhy it was interesting to him': 17, '"Yes, but I was very much interested by your irritable neighbor," said\nLevin, sighing': 14, '"He\'s a clever fellow, and said a lot that was true': 11, '"\n\n"Oh, get along with you': 6, 'An inveterate supporter of serfdom at heart,\nlike all of them': 11, '" said Sviazhsky': 3, '"Whose marshal you are': 4, '"\n\n"Yes, only I marshal them in the other direction," said Sviazhsky,\nlaughing': 13, '"I\'ll tell you what interests me very much," said Levin': 10, '"He\'s right\nthat our system, that\'s to say of rational farming, doesn\'t answer,\nthat the only thing that answers is the money-lender system, like that\nmeek-looking gentleman\'s, or else the very simplest': 32, 'Whose fault is\nit': 4, '"\n\n"Our own, of course': 5, "Besides, it's not true that it doesn't answer": 8, 'It\nanswers with Vassiltchikov': 4, '"\n\n"A factory': 3, '"\n\n"But I really don\'t know what it is you are surprised at': 13, "The people\nare at such a low stage of rational and moral development, that it's\nobvious they're bound to oppose everything that's strange to them": 25, "In\nEurope, a rational system answers because the people are educated; it\nfollows that we must educate the people—that's all": 20, '"\n\n"But how are we to educate the people': 9, '"\n\n"To educate the people three things are needed: schools, and schools,\nand schools': 14, '"\n\n"But you said yourself the people are at such a low stage of material\ndevelopment: what help are schools for that': 22, '"\n\n"Do you know, you remind me of the story of the advice given to the\nsick man—You should try purgative medicine': 22, 'Taken: worse': 2, 'Try leeches': 2, 'Tried them: worse': 3, "Well, then, there's nothing left but to pray to God": 10, 'Tried it: worse': 3, "That's just how it is with us": 7, 'I say political\neconomy; you say—worse': 6, 'I say socialism: worse': 4, 'Education: worse': 2, '"\n\n"But how do schools help matters': 7, '"\n\n"They give the peasant fresh wants': 7, '"\n\n"Well, that\'s a thing I\'ve never understood," Levin replied with heat': 12, '"In what way are schools going to help the people to improve their\nmaterial position': 15, 'You say schools, education, will give them fresh\nwants': 9, "So much the worse, since they won't be capable of satisfying\nthem": 12, 'And in what way a knowledge of addition and subtraction and the\ncatechism is going to improve their material condition, I never could\nmake out': 25, 'The day before yesterday, I met a peasant woman in the\nevening with a little baby, and asked her where she was going': 23, 'She said\nshe was going to the wise woman; her boy had screaming fits, so she was\ntaking him to be doctored': 22, 'I asked, ‘Why, how does the wise woman cure\nscreaming fits': 11, "' ‘She puts the child on the hen-roost and repeats some\ncharm": 12, '\'"\n\n"Well, you\'re saying it yourself': 6, "What's wanted to prevent her taking\nher child to the hen-roost to cure it of screaming fits is just": 19, '"\nSviazhsky said, smiling good-humoredly': 5, '"Oh, no': 2, '" said Levin with annoyance; "that method of doctoring I merely\nmeant as a simile for doctoring the people with schools': 21, 'The people are\npoor and ignorant—that we see as surely as the peasant woman sees the\nbaby is ill because it screams': 22, 'But in what way this trouble of poverty\nand ignorance is to be cured by schools is as incomprehensible as how\nthe hen-roost affects the screaming': 26, 'What has to be cured is what makes\nhim poor': 10, '"\n\n"Well, in that, at least, you\'re in agreement with Spencer, whom you\ndislike so much': 16, 'He says, too, that education may be the consequence of\ngreater prosperity and comfort, of more frequent washing, as he says,\nbut not of being able to read and write': 30, '"\n\n"Well, then, I\'m very glad—or the contrary, very sorry, that I\'m in\nagreement with Spencer; only I\'ve known it a long while': 23, 'Schools can do\nno good; what will do good is an economic organization in which the\npeople will become richer, will have more leisure—and then there will\nbe schools': 29, '"\n\n"Still, all over Europe now schools are obligatory': 9, '"\n\n"And how far do you agree with Spencer yourself about it': 12, '" asked Levin': 3, 'But there was a gleam of alarm in Sviazhsky\'s eyes, and he said\nsmiling:\n\n"No; that screaming story is positively capital': 21, 'Did you really hear it\nyourself': 6, '"\n\nLevin saw that he was not to discover the connection between this man\'s\nlife and his thoughts': 18, 'Obviously he did not care in the least what his\nreasoning led him to; all he wanted was the process of reasoning': 22, 'And\nhe did not like it when the process of reasoning brought him into a\nblind alley': 17, 'That was the only thing he disliked, and avoided by\nchanging the conversation to something agreeable and amusing': 18, 'All the impressions of the day, beginning with the impression made by\nthe old peasant, which served, as it were, as the fundamental basis of\nall the conceptions and ideas of the day, threw Levin into violent\nexcitement': 38, 'This dear good Sviazhsky, keeping a stock of ideas simply\nfor social purposes, and obviously having some other principles hidden\nfrom Levin, while with the crowd, whose name is legion, he guided\npublic opinion by ideas he did not share; that irascible country\ngentleman, perfectly correct in the conclusions that he had been\nworried into by life, but wrong in his exasperation against a whole\nclass, and that the best class in Russia; his own dissatisfaction with\nthe work he had been doing, and the vague hope of finding a remedy for\nall this—all was blended in a sense of inward turmoil, and anticipation\nof some solution near at hand': 110, 'Left alone in the room assigned him, lying on a spring mattress that\nyielded unexpectedly at every movement of his arm or his leg, Levin did\nnot fall asleep for a long while': 33, 'Not one conversation with Sviazhsky,\nthough he had said a great deal that was clever, had interested Levin;\nbut the conclusions of the irascible landowner required consideration': 27, 'Levin could not help recalling every word he had said, and in\nimagination amending his own replies': 17, '"Yes, I ought to have said to him: You say that our husbandry does not\nanswer because the peasant hates improvements, and that they must be\nforced on him by authority': 31, 'If no system of husbandry answered at all\nwithout these improvements, you would be quite right': 16, "But the only\nsystem that does answer is where laborer is working in accordance with\nhis habits, just as on the old peasant's land half-way here": 26, 'Your and\nour general dissatisfaction with the system shows that either we are to\nblame or the laborers': 18, 'We have gone our way—the European way—a long\nwhile, without asking ourselves about the qualities of our labor force': 19, 'Let us try to look upon the labor force not as an abstract force, but\nas the _Russian peasant_ with his instincts, and we shall arrange our\nsystem of culture in accordance with that': 34, 'Imagine, I ought to have\nsaid to him, that you have the same system as the old peasant has, that\nyou have found means of making your laborers take an interest in the\nsuccess of the work, and have found the happy mean in the way of\nimprovements which they will admit, and you will, without exhausting\nthe soil, get twice or three times the yield you got before': 69, 'Divide it\nin halves, give half as the share of labor, the surplus left you will\nbe greater, and the share of labor will be greater too': 27, 'And to do this\none must lower the standard of husbandry and interest the laborers in\nits success': 18, 'How to do this': 4, "—that's a matter of detail; but undoubtedly\nit can be done": 11, '"\n\nThis idea threw Levin into a great excitement': 9, 'He did not sleep half\nthe night, thinking over in detail the putting of his idea into\npractice': 18, 'He had not intended to go away next day, but he now\ndetermined to go home early in the morning': 20, 'Besides, the sister-in-law\nwith her low-necked bodice aroused in him a feeling akin to shame and\nremorse for some utterly base action': 22, 'Most important of all—he must get\nback without delay: he would have to make haste to put his new project\nto the peasants before the sowing of the winter wheat, so that the\nsowing might be undertaken on a new basis': 41, 'He had made up his mind to\nrevolutionize his whole system': 11, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 29 PART THREE', {"The carrying out of Levin's plan presented many difficulties; but he\nstruggled on, doing his utmost, and attained a result which, though not\nwhat he desired, was enough to enable him, without self-deception, to\nbelieve that the attempt was worth the trouble": 42, 'One of the chief\ndifficulties was that the process of cultivating the land was in full\nswing, that it was impossible to stop everything and begin it all again\nfrom the beginning, and the machine had to be mended while in motion': 42, 'When on the evening that he arrived home he informed the bailiff of his\nplans, the latter with visible pleasure agreed with what he said so\nlong as he was pointing out that all that had been done up to that time\nwas stupid and useless': 46, 'The bailiff said that he had said so a long\nwhile ago, but no heed had been paid him': 19, 'But as for the proposal made\nby Levin—to take a part as shareholder with his laborers in each\nagricultural undertaking—at this the bailiff simply expressed a\nprofound despondency, and offered no definite opinion, but began\nimmediately talking of the urgent necessity of carrying the remaining\nsheaves of rye the next day, and of sending the men out for the second\nploughing, so that Levin felt that this was not the time for discussing\nit': 74, 'On beginning to talk to the peasants about it, and making a proposition\nto cede them the land on new terms, he came into collision with the\nsame great difficulty that they were so much absorbed by the current\nwork of the day, that they had not time to consider the advantages and\ndisadvantages of the proposed scheme': 58, "The simple-hearted Ivan, the cowherd, seemed completely to grasp\nLevin's proposal—that he should with his family take a share of the\nprofits of the cattle-yard—and he was in complete sympathy with the\nplan": 33, "But when Levin hinted at the future advantages, Ivan's face\nexpressed alarm and regret that he could not hear all he had to say,\nand he made haste to find himself some task that would admit of no\ndelay: he either snatched up the fork to pitch the hay out of the pens,\nor ran to get water or to clear out the dung": 64, "Another difficulty lay in the invincible disbelief of the peasant that\na landowner's object could be anything else than a desire to squeeze\nall he could out of them": 29, 'They were firmly convinced that his real aim\n(whatever he might say to them) would always be in what he did not say\nto them': 25, 'And they themselves, in giving their opinion, said a great\ndeal but never said what was their real object': 19, 'Moreover (Levin felt\nthat the irascible landowner had been right) the peasants made their\nfirst and unalterable condition of any agreement whatever that they\nshould not be forced to any new methods of tillage of any kind, nor to\nuse new implements': 42, 'They agreed that the modern plough ploughed better,\nthat the scarifier did the work more quickly, but they found thousands\nof reasons that made it out of the question for them to use either of\nthem; and though he had accepted the conviction that he would have to\nlower the standard of cultivation, he felt sorry to give up improved\nmethods, the advantages of which were so obvious': 68, 'But in spite of all\nthese difficulties he got his way, and by autumn the system was\nworking, or at least so it seemed to him': 26, 'At first Levin had thought of giving up the whole farming of the land\njust as it was to the peasants, the laborers, and the bailiff on new\nconditions of partnership; but he was very soon convinced that this was\nimpossible, and determined to divide it up': 47, 'The cattle-yard, the\ngarden, hay fields, and arable land, divided into several parts, had to\nbe made into separate lots': 20, 'The simple-hearted cowherd, Ivan, who,\nLevin fancied, understood the matter better than any of them,\ncollecting together a gang of workers to help him, principally of his\nown family, became a partner in the cattle-yard': 35, 'A distant part of the\nestate, a tract of waste land that had lain fallow for eight years, was\nwith the help of the clever carpenter, Fyodor Ryezunov, taken by six\nfamilies of peasants on new conditions of partnership, and the peasant\nShuraev took the management of all the vegetable gardens on the same\nterms': 55, "The remainder of the land was still worked on the old system,\nbut these three associated partnerships were the first step to a new\norganization of the whole, and they completely took up Levin's time": 35, 'It is true that in the cattle-yard things went no better than before,\nand Ivan strenuously opposed warm housing for the cows and butter made\nof fresh cream, affirming that cows require less food if kept cold, and\nthat butter is more profitable made from sour cream, and he asked for\nwages just as under the old system, and took not the slightest interest\nin the fact that the money he received was not wages but an advance out\nof his future share in the profits': 86, "It is true that Fyodor Ryezunov's company did not plough over the\nground twice before sowing, as had been agreed, justifying themselves\non the plea that the time was too short": 31, 'It is true that the peasants\nof the same company, though they had agreed to work the land on new\nconditions, always spoke of the land, not as held in partnership, but\nas rented for half the crop, and more than once the peasants and\nRyezunov himself said to Levin, "If you would take a rent for the land,\nit would save you trouble, and we should be more free': 70, '" Moreover the\nsame peasants kept putting off, on various excuses, the building of a\ncattleyard and barn on the land as agreed upon, and delayed doing it\ntill the winter': 31, 'It is true that Shuraev would have liked to let out the kitchen gardens\nhe had undertaken in small lots to the peasants': 23, 'He evidently quite\nmisunderstood, and apparently intentionally misunderstood, the\nconditions upon which the land had been given to him': 19, 'Often, too, talking to the peasants and explaining to them all the\nadvantages of the plan, Levin felt that the peasants heard nothing but\nthe sound of his voice, and were firmly resolved, whatever he might\nsay, not to let themselves be taken in': 44, "He felt this especially when he\ntalked to the cleverest of the peasants, Ryezunov, and detected the\ngleam in Ryezunov's eyes which showed so plainly both ironical\namusement at Levin, and the firm conviction that, if anyone were to be\ntaken in, it would not be he, Ryezunov": 48, 'But in spite of all this Levin\nthought the system worked, and that by keeping accounts strictly and\ninsisting on his own way, he would prove to them in the future the\nadvantages of the arrangement, and then the system would go of itself': 44, 'These matters, together with the management of the land still left on\nhis hands, and the indoor work over his book, so engrossed Levin the\nwhole summer that he scarcely ever went out shooting': 34, 'At the end of\nAugust he heard that the Oblonskys had gone away to Moscow, from their\nservant who brought back the side-saddle': 23, "He felt that in not answering\nDarya Alexandrovna's letter he had by his rudeness, of which he could\nnot think without a flush of shame, burned his ships, and that he would\nnever go and see them again": 38, 'He had been just as rude with the\nSviazhskys, leaving them without saying good-bye': 14, 'But he would never go\nto see them again either': 10, 'He did not care about that now': 7, 'The business\nof reorganizing the farming of his land absorbed him as completely as\nthough there would never be anything else in his life': 24, 'He read the\nbooks lent him by Sviazhsky, and copying out what he had not got, he\nread both the economic and socialistic books on the subject, but, as he\nhad anticipated, found nothing bearing on the scheme he had undertaken': 41, 'In the books on political economy—in Mill, for instance, whom he\nstudied first with great ardor, hoping every minute to find an answer\nto the questions that were engrossing him—he found laws deduced from\nthe condition of land culture in Europe; but he did not see why these\nlaws, which did not apply in Russia, must be general': 58, 'He saw just the\nsame thing in the socialistic books: either they were the beautiful but\nimpracticable fantasies which had fascinated him when he was a student,\nor they were attempts at improving, rectifying the economic position in\nwhich Europe was placed, with which the system of land tenure in Russia\nhad nothing in common': 55, 'Political economy told him that the laws by\nwhich the wealth of Europe had been developed, and was developing, were\nuniversal and unvarying': 23, 'Socialism told him that development along\nthese lines leads to ruin': 11, 'And neither of them gave an answer, or even\na hint, in reply to the question what he, Levin, and all the Russian\npeasants and landowners, were to do with their millions of hands and\nmillions of acres, to make them as productive as possible for the\ncommon weal': 49, 'Having once taken the subject up, he read conscientiously everything\nbearing on it, and intended in the autumn to go abroad to study land\nsystems on the spot, in order that he might not on this question be\nconfronted with what so often met him on various subjects': 48, 'Often, just\nas he was beginning to understand the idea in the mind of anyone he was\ntalking to, and was beginning to explain his own, he would suddenly be\ntold: "But Kauffmann, but Jones, but Dubois, but Michelli': 39, "You haven't\nread them: they've thrashed that question out thoroughly": 10, '"\n\nHe saw now distinctly that Kauffmann and Michelli had nothing to tell\nhim': 14, 'He knew what he wanted': 5, "He saw that Russia has splendid land,\nsplendid laborers, and that in certain cases, as at the peasant's on\nthe way to Sviazhsky's, the produce raised by the laborers and the land\nis great—in the majority of cases when capital is applied in the\nEuropean way the produce is small, and that this simply arises from the\nfact that the laborers want to work and work well only in their own\npeculiar way, and that this antagonism is not incidental but\ninvariable, and has its roots in the national spirit": 90, 'He thought that\nthe Russian people whose task it was to colonize and cultivate vast\ntracts of unoccupied land, consciously adhered, till all their land was\noccupied, to the methods suitable to their purpose, and that their\nmethods were by no means so bad as was generally supposed': 48, 'And he\nwanted to prove this theoretically in his book and practically on his\nland': 15, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 30 PART THREE', {'At the end of September the timber had been carted for building the\ncattleyard on the land that had been allotted to the association of\npeasants, and the butter from the cows was sold and the profits\ndivided': 38, 'In practice the system worked capitally, or, at least, so it\nseemed to Levin': 14, "In order to work out the whole subject theoretically\nand to complete his book, which, in Levin's daydreams, was not merely\nto effect a revolution in political economy, but to annihilate that\nscience entirely and to lay the foundation of a new science of the\nrelation of the people to the soil, all that was left to do was to make\na tour abroad, and to study on the spot all that had been done in the\nsame direction, and to collect conclusive evidence that all that had\nbeen done there was not what was wanted": 96, 'Levin was only waiting for the\ndelivery of his wheat to receive the money for it and go abroad': 19, 'But\nthe rains began, preventing the harvesting of the corn and potatoes\nleft in the fields, and putting a stop to all work, even to the\ndelivery of the wheat': 30, 'The mud was impassable along the roads; two mills were carried away,\nand the weather got worse and worse': 19, 'On the 30th of September the sun came out in the morning, and hoping\nfor fine weather, Levin began making final preparations for his\njourney': 25, 'He gave orders for the wheat to be delivered, sent the bailiff\nto the merchant to get the money owing him, and went out himself to\ngive some final directions on the estate before setting off': 36, 'Having finished all his business, soaked through with the streams of\nwater which kept running down the leather behind his neck and his\ngaiters, but in the keenest and most confident temper, Levin returned\nhomewards in the evening': 38, 'The weather had become worse than ever\ntowards evening; the hail lashed the drenched mare so cruelly that she\nwent along sideways, shaking her head and ears; but Levin was all right\nunder his hood, and he looked cheerfully about him at the muddy streams\nrunning under the wheels, at the drops hanging on every bare twig, at\nthe whiteness of the patch of unmelted hailstones on the planks of the\nbridge, at the thick layer of still juicy, fleshy leaves that lay\nheaped up about the stripped elm-tree': 89, 'In spite of the gloominess of\nnature around him, he felt peculiarly eager': 13, 'The talks he had been\nhaving with the peasants in the further village had shown that they\nwere beginning to get used to their new position': 26, "The old servant to\nwhose hut he had gone to get dry evidently approved of Levin's plan,\nand of his own accord proposed to enter the partnership by the purchase\nof cattle": 32, '"I have only to go stubbornly on towards my aim, and I shall attain my\nend," thought Levin; "and it\'s something to work and take trouble for': 27, 'This is not a matter of myself individually; the prosperity and content; instead of hostility,\nharmony and unity of interests': 15, 'In short, a bloodless revolution, but a\nrevolution of the greatest magnitude, beginning in the little circle ('TOL CHAPTER 31 PART THREE', {'Running halfway down the staircase, Levin caught a sound he knew, a\nfamiliar cough in the hall': 17, 'But he heard it indistinctly through the\nsound of his own thoughts nearest his heart, would force him to show\nhimself fully': 48, 'And that he was not disposed to do': 8, 'Angry with himself for so base a feeling, Levin ran into the hall; as\nsoon as he had ('TOL CHAPTER 32 PART THREE', {'Levin had long before made the observation that when one is\nuncomfortable with people from their being excessively amenable and\nmeek, one is apt very soon after to find things intolerable from their\ntouchiness and irritability': 36, 'He felt that this was how it would be with\nhis brother': 12, "And his brother Nikolay's gentleness did in fact not last\nout for long": 13, 'The very next morning he began to be irritable, and\nseemed doing his best to find fault with his brother, attacking him on\nhis tenderest points': 26, 'Levin felt himself to blame, and could not set things right': 11, 'He felt\nthat if they had both not kept up appearances, but had spoken, as it is\ncalled, from the heart—that is to say, had said only just what they\nwere thinking and feeling—they would simply have looked into each\nother\'s faces, and Konstantin could only have said, "You\'re dying,\nyou\'re dying': 52, '" and Nikolay could only have answered, "I know I\'m dying,\nbut I\'m afraid, I\'m afraid, I\'m afraid': 18, '" And they could have said\nnothing more, if they had said only what was in their hearts': 18, 'But life\nlike that was impossible, and so Konstantin tried to do what he had\nbeen trying to do all his life, and never could learn to do, though, as\nfar as he could observe, many people knew so well how to do it, and\nwithout it there was no living at all': 53, 'He tried to say what he was not\nthinking, but he felt continually that it had a ring of falsehood, that\nhis brother detected him in it, and was exasperated at it': 32, 'The third day Nikolay induced his brother to explain his plan to him\nagain, and began not merely attacking it, but intentionally confounding\nit with communism': 26, '"You\'ve simply borrowed an idea that\'s not your own, but you\'ve\ndistorted it, and are trying to apply it where it\'s not applicable': 23, '"\n\n"But I tell you it\'s nothing to do with it': 11, 'They deny the justice of\nproperty, of capital, of inheritance, while I do not deny this chief\nstimulus': 18, '" (Levin felt disgusted himself at using such expressions, but\never since he had been engrossed by his work, he had unconsciously come\nmore and more frequently to use words not Russian': 32, ') "All I want is to\nregulate labor': 8, '"\n\n"Which means, you\'ve borrowed an idea, stripped it of all that gave it\nits force, and want to make believe that it\'s something new," said\nNikolay, angrily tugging at his necktie': 32, '"But my idea has nothing in common': 7, '"\n\n"That, anyway," said Nikolay Levin, with an ironical smile, his eyes\nflashing malignantly, "has the charm of—what\'s one to call\nit': 22, '—geometrical symmetry, of clearness, of definiteness': 6, 'It may be a\nUtopia': 5, 'But if once one allows the possibility of making of all the\npast a _tabula rasa_—no property, no family—then labor would organize\nitself': 23, 'But you gain nothing': 4, '"\n\n"Why do you mix things up': 7, "I've never been a communist": 5, '"\n\n"But I have, and I consider it\'s premature, but rational, and it has a\nfuture, just like Christianity in its first ages': 23, '"\n\n"All that I maintain is that the labor force ought to be investigated\nfrom the point of view of natural science; that is to say, it ought to\nbe studied, its qualities ascertained': 34, '"\n\n"But that\'s utter waste of time': 7, 'That force finds a certain form of\nactivity of itself, according to the stage of its development': 17, 'There\nhave been slaves first everywhere, then metayers; and we have the\nhalf-crop system, rent, and day laborers': 18, 'What are you trying to find': 6, '"\n\nLevin suddenly lost his temper at these words, because at the bottom of\nhis heart he was afraid that it was true—true that he was trying to\nhold the balance even between communism and the familiar forms, and\nthat this was hardly possible': 44, '"I am trying to find means of working productively for myself and for\nthe laborers': 15, 'I want to organize': 4, '" he answered hotly': 4, '"You don\'t want to organize anything; it\'s simply just as you\'ve been\nall your life, that you want to be original to pose as not exploiting\nthe peasants simply, but with some idea in view': 35, '"\n\n"Oh, all right, that\'s what you think—and let me alone': 11, '" answered\nLevin, feeling the muscles of his left cheek twitching uncontrollably': 12, '"You\'ve never had, and never have, convictions; all you want is to\nplease your vanity': 15, '"\n\n"Oh, very well; then let me alone': 8, '"\n\n"And I will let you alone': 7, "and it's high time I did, and go to the\ndevil with you": 13, "and I'm very sorry I ever came": 7, '"\n\nIn spite of all Levin\'s efforts to soothe his brother afterwards,\nNikolay would listen to nothing he said, declaring that it was better\nto part, and Konstantin saw that it simply was that life was unbearable\nto him': 39, 'Nikolay was just getting ready to go, when Konstantin went in to him\nagain and begged him, rather unnaturally, to forgive him if he had hurt\nhis feelings in any way': 31, '"Ah, generosity': 2, '" said Nikolay, and he smiled': 6, '"If you want to be\nright, I can give you that satisfaction': 12, "You're in the right; but I'm\ngoing all the same": 10, '"\n\nIt was only just at parting that Nikolay kissed him, and said, looking\nwith sudden strangeness and seriousness at his brother:\n\n"Anyway, don\'t remember evil against me, Kostya': 29, '" and his voice\nquivered': 5, 'These were the only words that had been spoken sincerely\nbetween them': 12, 'Levin knew that those words meant, "You see, and you\nknow, that I\'m in a bad way, and maybe we shall not see each other\nagain': 26, '" Levin knew this, and the tears gushed from his eyes': 11, 'He kissed\nhis brother once more, but he could not speak, and knew not what to\nsay': 17, "Three days after his brother's departure, Levin too set off for his\nforeign tour": 14, "Happening to meet Shtcherbatsky, Kitty's cousin, in the\nrailway train, Levin greatly astonished him by his depression": 17, '"What\'s the matter with you': 5, '" Shtcherbatsky asked him': 4, '"Oh, nothing; there\'s not much happiness in life': 8, '"\n\n"Not much': 3, 'You come with me to Paris instead of to Mulhausen': 10, 'You shall\nsee how to be happy': 7, '"\n\n"No, I\'ve done with it all': 7, "It's time I was dead": 5, '"\n\n"Well, that\'s a good one': 6, '" said Shtcherbatsky, laughing; "why, I\'m only\njust getting ready to begin': 12, '"\n\n"Yes, I thought the same not long ago, but now I know I shall soon be\ndead': 18, '"\n\nLevin said what he had genuinely been thinking of late': 11, 'He saw nothing\nbut death or the advance towards death in everything': 12, 'But his cherished\nscheme only engrossed him the more': 9, 'Life had to be got through somehow\ntill death did come': 11, 'Darkness had fallen upon everything for him; but\njust because of this darkness he felt that the one guiding clue in the\ndarkness was his work, and he clutched it and clung to it with all his\nstrength': 38, 'PART FOUR': 2})
('TOL CHAPTER 1 PART FOUR', {'The Karenins, husband and wife, continued living in the same house, met\nevery day, but were complete strangers to one another': 21, 'Alexey\nAlexandrovitch made it a rule to see his wife every day, so that the\nservants might have no grounds for suppositions, but avoided dining at\nhome': 27, "Vronsky was never at Alexey Alexandrovitch's house, but Anna saw\nhim away from home, and her husband was aware of it": 21, 'The position was one of misery for all three; and not one of them would\nhave been equal to enduring this position for a single day, if it had\nnot been for the expectation that it would change, that it was merely a\ntemporary painful ordeal which would pass over': 50, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch\nhoped that this passion would pass, as everything does pass, that\neveryone would forget about it, and his name would remain unsullied': 24, 'Anna, on whom the position depended, and for whom it was more miserable\nthan for anyone, endured it because she not merely hoped, but firmly\nbelieved, that it would all very soon be settled and come right': 37, 'She\nhad not the least idea what would settle the position, but she firmly\nbelieved that something would very soon turn up now': 23, 'Vronsky, against\nhis own will or wishes, followed her lead, hoped too that something,\napart from his own action, would be sure to solve all difficulties': 26, 'In the middle of the winter Vronsky spent a very tiresome week': 12, 'A\nforeign prince, who had come on a visit to Petersburg, was put under\nhis charge, and he had to show him the sights worth seeing': 26, 'Vronsky was\nof distinguished appearance; he possessed, moreover, the art of\nbehaving with respectful dignity, and was used to having to do with\nsuch grand personages—that was how he came to be put in charge of the\nprince': 38, 'But he felt his duties very irksome': 7, 'The prince was anxious to\nmiss nothing of which he would be asked at home, had he seen that in\nRussia': 21, 'And on his own account he was anxious to enjoy to the utmost\nall Russian forms of amusement': 18, 'Vronsky was obliged to be his guide in\nsatisfying both these inclinations': 12, 'The mornings they spent driving to\nlook at places of interest; the evenings they passed enjoying the\nnational entertainments': 19, 'The prince rejoiced in health exceptional even\namong princes': 9, 'By gymnastics and careful attention to his health he had\nbrought himself to such a point that in spite of his excess in pleasure\nhe looked as fresh as a big glossy green Dutch cucumber': 35, 'The prince had\ntraveled a great deal, and considered one of the chief advantages of\nmodern facilities of communication was the accessibility of the\npleasures of all nations': 28, 'He had been in Spain, and there had indulged in serenades and had made\nfriends with a Spanish girl who played the mandolin': 23, 'In Switzerland he\nhad killed chamois': 6, 'In England he had galloped in a red coat over\nhedges and killed two hundred pheasants for a bet': 19, 'In Turkey he had got\ninto a harem; in India he had hunted on an elephant, and now in Russia\nhe wished to taste all the specially Russian forms of pleasure': 31, 'Vronsky, who was, as it were, chief master of the ceremonies to him,\nwas at great pains to arrange all the Russian amusements suggested by\nvarious persons to the prince': 30, 'They had race horses, and Russian\npancakes and bear hunts and three-horse sledges, and gypsies and\ndrinking feasts, with the Russian accompaniment of broken crockery': 25, 'And\nthe prince with surprising ease fell in with the Russian spirit,\nsmashed trays full of crockery, sat with a gypsy girl on his knee, and\nseemed to be asking—what more, and does the whole Russian spirit\nconsist in just this': 41, 'In reality, of all the Russian entertainments the prince liked best\nFrench actresses and ballet dancers and white-seal champagne': 19, 'Vronsky\nwas used to princes, but, either because he had himself changed of\nlate, or that he was in too close proximity to the prince, that week\nseemed fearfully wearisome to him': 32, 'The whole of that week he\nexperienced a sensation such as a man might have set in charge of a\ndangerous madman, afraid of the madman, and at the same time, from\nbeing with him, fearing for his own reason': 40, 'Vronsky was continually\nconscious of the necessity of never for a second relaxing the tone of\nstern official respectfulness, that he might not himself be insulted': 26, "The prince's manner of treating the very people who, to Vronsky's\nsurprise, were ready to descend to any depths to provide him with\nRussian amusements, was contemptuous": 27, 'His criticisms of Russian women,\nwhom he wished to study, more than once made Vronsky crimson with\nindignation': 18, 'The chief reason why the prince was so particularly\ndisagreeable to Vronsky was that he could not help seeing himself in\nhim': 22, 'And what he saw in this mirror did not gratify his self-esteem': 12, 'He\nwas a very stupid and very self-satisfied and very healthy and very\nwell-washed man, and nothing else': 18, 'He was a gentleman—that was true,\nand Vronsky could not deny it': 12, 'He was equable and not cringing with his\nsuperiors, was free and ingratiating in his behavior with his equals,\nand was contemptuously indulgent with his inferiors': 26, 'Vronsky was\nhimself the same, and regarded it as a great merit to be so': 15, 'But for\nthis prince he was an inferior, and his contemptuous and indulgent\nattitude to him revolted him': 18, '"Brainless beef': 2, 'can I be like that': 5, '" he thought': 3, 'Be that as it might, when, on the seventh day, he parted from the\nprince, who was starting for Moscow, and received his thanks, he was\nhappy to be rid of his uncomfortable position and the unpleasant\nreflection of himself': 40, 'He said good-bye to him at the station on their\nreturn from a bear hunt, at which they had had a display of Russian\nprowess kept up all night': 29, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART FOUR', {'When he got home, Vronsky found there a note from Anna': 11, 'She wrote, "I\nam ill and unhappy': 7, 'I cannot come out, but I cannot go on longer\nwithout seeing you': 13, 'Come in this evening': 4, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch goes to\nthe council at seven and will be there till ten': 14, '" Thinking for an\ninstant of the strangeness of her bidding him come straight to her, in\nspite of her husband\'s insisting on her not receiving him, he decided\nto go': 31, 'Vronsky had that winter got his promotion, was now a colonel, had left\nthe regimental quarters, and was living alone': 20, 'After having some lunch,\nhe lay down on the sofa immediately, and in five minutes memories of\nthe hideous scenes he had witnessed during the last few days were\nconfused together and joined on to a mental image of Anna and of the\npeasant who had played an important part in the bear hunt, and Vronsky\nfell asleep': 58, 'He waked up in the dark, trembling with horror, and made\nhaste to light a candle': 16, '"What was it': 3, 'What': 1, 'What was the dreadful\nthing I dreamed': 7, 'Yes, yes; I think a little dirty man with a disheveled\nbeard was stooping down doing something, and all of a sudden he began\nsaying some strange words in French': 30, 'Yes, there was nothing else in the\ndream," he said to himself': 12, '"But why was it so awful': 6, '" He vividly\nrecalled the peasant again and those incomprehensible French words the\npeasant had uttered, and a chill of horror ran down his spine': 25, '"What nonsense': 2, '" thought Vronsky, and glanced at his watch': 8, 'It was half-past eight already': 5, 'He rang up his servant, dressed in\nhaste, and went out onto the steps, completely forgetting the dream and\nonly worried at being late': 24, "As he drove up to the Karenins' entrance he\nlooked at his watch and saw it was ten minutes to nine": 21, 'A high, narrow\ncarriage with a pair of grays was standing at the entrance': 14, "He\nrecognized Anna's carriage": 4, '"She is coming to me," thought Vronsky,\n"and better she should': 11, "I don't like going into that house": 7, 'But no\nmatter; I can\'t hide myself," he thought, and with that manner peculiar\nto him from childhood, as of a man who has nothing to be ashamed of,\nVronsky got out of his sledge and went to the door': 40, 'The door opened,\nand the hall-porter with a rug on his arm called the carriage': 15, 'Vronsky,\nthough he did not usually notice details, noticed at this moment the\namazed expression with which the porter glanced at him': 22, 'In the very\ndoorway Vronsky almost ran up against Alexey Alexandrovitch': 11, 'The gas\njet threw its full light on the bloodless, sunken face under the black\nhat and on the white cravat, brilliant against the beaver of the coat': 28, "Karenin's fixed, dull eyes were fastened upon Vronsky's face": 9, 'Vronsky\nbowed, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, chewing his lips, lifted his hand to\nhis hat and went on': 17, 'Vronsky saw him without looking round get into the\ncarriage, pick up the rug and the opera-glass at the window and\ndisappear': 22, 'Vronsky went into the hall': 5, 'His brows were scowling, and his\neyes gleamed with a proud and angry light in them': 16, '"What a position': 3, '" he thought': 3, '"If he would fight, would stand up for\nhis honor, I could act, could express my feelings; but this weakness or\nbaseness': 22, 'He puts me in the position of playing false, which I never\nmeant and never mean to do': 18, '"\n\nVronsky\'s ideas had changed since the day of his conversation with Anna\nin the Vrede garden': 17, 'Unconsciously yielding to the weakness of Anna—who\nhad surrendered herself up to him utterly, and simply looked to him to\ndecide her fate, ready to submit to anything—he had long ceased to\nthink that their tie might end as he had thought then': 43, 'His ambitious\nplans had retreated into the background again, and feeling that he had\ngot out of that circle of activity in which everything was definite, he\nhad given himself entirely to his passion, and that passion was binding\nhim more and more closely to her': 46, 'He was still in the hall when he caught the sound of her retreating\nfootsteps': 15, 'He knew she had been expecting him, had listened for him,\nand was now going back to the drawing-room': 19, '"No," she cried, on seeing him, and at the first sound of her voice the\ntears came into her eyes': 20, '"No; if things are to go on like this, the\nend will come much, much too soon': 17, '"\n\n"What is it, dear one': 6, '"\n\n"What': 2, "I've been waiting in agony for an hour, two hours": 10, "No, I\nwon't": 3, "I can't quarrel with you": 5, "Of course you couldn't come": 5, '" She laid her two hands on his shoulders, and looked a long\nwhile at him with a profound, passionate, and at the same time\nsearching look': 27, 'She was studying his face to make up for the time she\nhad not seen him': 16, 'She was, every time she saw him, making the picture\nof him in her imagination (incomparably superior, impossible in\nreality) fit with him as he really was': 27, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART FOUR', {'"You met him': 3, '" she asked, when they had sat down at the table in the\nlamplight': 14, '"You\'re punished, you see, for being late': 7, '"\n\n"Yes; but how was it': of\nhis dream': 12, '"Yes, a dream," she said': 5, '"It\'s a long while since I dreamed it': 8, 'I\ndreamed that I ran into my bedroom, that I had to get something there,\nto find out something; you know how it is in dreams," she said, her\neyes wide with horror; "and in the bedroom, in the corner, stood\nsomething': 42, '"\n\n"Oh, what nonsense': 4, 'How can you believe': 4, '"\n\nBut she would not let him interrupt her': 9, 'What she was saying was too\nimportant to her': 9, '"And the something turned round, and I saw it was a peasant with a\ndisheveled beard, little, and dreadful looking': 20, 'I wanted to run away,\nbut he bent down over a sack, and was fumbling there with his\nhands': 19, '"\n\nShe showed how he had moved his hands': 9, 'There was terror in her face': 6, 'And Vronsky, remembering his dream, felt the same terror filling his\nsoul': 12, '"He was fumbling and kept talking quickly, quickly in French, you know:\n_Il faut le battre, le fer, le broyer, le pétrir_': 22, 'And in my horror\nI tried to wake up, and woke up': 12, 'but woke up in the dream': 6, 'And I\nbegan asking myself what it meant': 8, "And Korney said to me: ‘In\nchildbirth you'll die, ma'am, you'll die": 12, "' And I woke up": 5, '"\n\n"What nonsense, what nonsense': 5, '" said Vronsky; but he felt himself that\nthere was no conviction in his voice': 15, '"But don\'t let\'s talk of it': 6, "Ring the bell, I'll have tea": 6, "And stay a\nlittle now; it's not long I shall": 10, '"\n\nBut all at once she stopped': 7, 'The expression of her face instantaneously\nchanged': 7, 'Horror and excitement were suddenly replaced by a look of\nsoft, solemn, blissful attention': 14, 'He could not comprehend the meaning\nof the change': 9, 'She was listening to the stirring of the new life within\nher': 12, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART FOUR', {'Alexey Alexandrovitch, after meeting Vronsky on his own steps, drove,\nas he had intended, to the Italian opera': 18, 'He sat through two acts\nthere, and saw everyone he had wanted to see': 14, 'On returning home, he\ncarefully scrutinized the hat stand, and noticing that there was not a\nmilitary overcoat there, he went, as usual, to his own room': 27, "But,\ncontrary to his usual habit, he did not go to bed, he walked up and\ndown his study till three o'clock in the morning": 25, 'The feeling of\nfurious anger with his wife, who would not observe the proprieties and\nkeep to the one stipulation he had laid on her, not to receive her\nlover in her own home, gave him no peace': 38, 'She had not complied with his\nrequest, and he was bound to punish her and carry out his threat—obtain\na divorce and take away his son': 26, 'He knew all the difficulties connected\nwith this course, but he had said he would do it, and now he must carry\nout his threat': 25, 'Countess Lidia Ivanovna had hinted that this was the\nbest way out of his position, and of late the obtaining of divorces had\nbeen brought to such perfection that Alexey Alexandrovitch saw a\npossibility of overcoming the formal difficulties': 39, 'Misfortunes never\ncome singly, and the affairs of the reorganization of the native\ntribes, and of the irrigation of the lands of the Zaraisky province,\nhad brought such official worries upon Alexey Alexandrovitch that he\nhad been of late in a continual condition of extreme irritability': 46, 'He did not sleep the whole night, and his fury, growing in a sort of\nvast, arithmetical progression, reached its highest limits in the\nmorning': 25, 'He dressed in haste, and as though carrying his cup full of\nwrath, and fearing to spill any over, fearing to lose with his wrath\nthe energy necessary for the interview with his wife, he went into her\nroom directly he heard she was up': 45, 'Anna, who had thought she knew her husband so well, was amazed at his\nappearance when he went in to her': 21, 'His brow was lowering, and his eyes\nstared darkly before him, avoiding her eyes; his mouth was tightly and\ncontemptuously shut': 21, 'In his walk, in his gestures, in the sound of his\nvoice there was a determination and firmness such as his wife had never\nseen in him': 27, 'He went into her room, and without greeting her, walked\nstraight up to her writing-table, and taking her keys, opened a drawer': 22, '"What do you want': 4, '" she cried': 3, '"Your lover\'s letters," he said': 5, put her most\nimportant papers': 41, 'She tried to pull the portfolio away, but he pushed\nher back': 12, '"Sit down': 2, 'I have to speak to you," he said, putting the portfolio\nunder his arm, and squeezing it so tightly with his elbow that his\nshoulder stood up': 27, 'Amazed and intimidated, she gazed at him in silence': 9, '"I told you that I would not allow you to receive your lover in cruelty for a husband to give his wife liberty, giving her\nthe honorable protection of his name, simply on the condition of\nobserving the proprieties: is that cruelty': 32, '"\n\n"It\'s worse than "If you care to use that word, what is base is to forsake husband\nand child for a lover, while you eat your husband's bread": 25, '"\n\nShe bowed her head': 5, 'She did not say what she had said the evening\nbefore to her lover, that _he_ was her husband, and her husband was\nsuperfluous; she did not even think that': 30, 'She felt all the justice of\nhis words, and only said softly:\n\n"You ('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART FOUR', {'The waiting-room of the celebrated Petersburg lawyer was full when\nAlexey Alexandrovitch entered it': 14, "Three ladies—an old lady, a young\nlady, and a merchant's wife—and three gentlemen—one a German banker\nwith a ring on his finger, the second a merchant with a beard, and the\nthird a wrathful-looking government clerk in official uniform, with a\ncross on his neck—had obviously been waiting a long while already": 52, 'Two\nclerks were writing at tables with scratching pens': 9, 'The appurtenances\nof the writing-tables, about which Alexey Alexandrovitch was himself\nvery fastidious, were exceptionally good': 16, 'He could not help observing\nthis': 6, 'One of the clerks, without getting up, turned wrathfully to\nAlexey Alexandrovitch, half closing his eyes': 16, '"What are you wanting': 4, '"\n\nHe replied that he had to see the lawyer on some business': 13, '"He is engaged," the clerk responded severely, and he pointed with his\npen at the persons waiting, and went on writing': 21, '"Can\'t he spare time to see me': 7, '" said Alexey Alexandrovitch': 4, '"He has no time free; he is always busy': 9, 'Kindly wait your turn': 4, '"\n\n"Then I must trouble you to give him my card," Alexey Alexandrovitch\nsaid with dignity, seeing the impossibility of preserving his\nincognito': 23, 'The clerk took the card and, obviously not approving of what he read on\nit, went to the door': 19, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch was in principle in favor of the publicity of\nlegal proceedings, though for some higher official considerations he\ndisliked the application of the principle in Russia, and disapproved of\nit, as far as he could disapprove of anything instituted by authority\nof the Emperor': 46, 'His whole life had been spent in administrative work,\nand consequently, when he did not approve of anything, his disapproval\nwas softened by the recognition of the inevitability of mistakes and\nthe possibility of reform in every department': 38, 'In the new public law\ncourts he disliked the restrictions laid on the lawyers conducting\ncases': 16, "But till then he had had nothing to do with the law courts, and\nso had disapproved of their publicity simply in theory; now his\ndisapprobation was strengthened by the unpleasant impression made on\nhim in the lawyer's waiting room": 40, '"Coming immediately," said the clerk; and two minutes later there did\nactually appear in the doorway the large figure of an old solicitor who\nhad been consulting with the lawyer himself': 31, 'The lawyer was a little, squat, bald man, with a dark, reddish beard,\nlight-colored long eyebrows, and an overhanging brow': 20, 'He was attired as\nthough for a wedding, from his cravat to his double watch-chain and\nvarnished boots': 18, 'His face was clever and manly, but his dress was\ndandified and in bad taste': 15, '"Pray walk in," said the lawyer, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch; and,\ngloomily ushering Karenin in before him, he closed the door': 20, '"Won\'t you sit down': 4, '" He indicated an armchair at a writing-table\ncovered with papers': 11, 'He sat down himself, and, rubbing his little hands\nwith short fingers covered with white hairs, he bent his head on one\nside': 23, 'But as soon as he was settled in this position a moth flew over\nthe table': 16, 'The lawyer, with a swiftness that could never have been\nexpected of him, opened his hands, caught the moth, and resumed his\nformer attitude': 24, '"Before beginning to speak of my business," said Alexey Alexandrovitch,\nfollowing the lawyer\'s movements with wondering eyes, "I ought to\nobserve that the business about which I have to speak to you is to be\nstrictly private': 37, '"\n\nThe lawyer\'s overhanging reddish mustaches were parted in a scarcely\nperceptible smile': 13, '"I should not be a lawyer if I could not keep the secrets confided to\nme': 16, 'But if you would like proof': 6, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch glanced at his face, and saw that the shrewd,\ngray eyes were laughing, and seemed to know all about it already': 24, '"You know my name': 4, '" Alexey Alexandrovitch resumed': 4, '"I know you and the good"—again he caught a moth—"work you are doing,\nlike every Russian," said the lawyer, bowing': 20, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch sighed, plucking up his courage': 7, 'But having once\nmade up his mind he went on in his shrill voice, without timidity—or\nhesitation, accentuating here and there a word': 23, '"I have the misfortune," Alexey Alexandrovitch began, "to have been\ndeceived in my married life, and I desire to break off all relations\nwith my wife by legal means—that is, to be divorced, but to do this so\nthat my son may not remain with his mother': 47, '"\n\nThe lawyer\'s gray eyes tried not to laugh, but they were dancing with\nirrepressible glee, and Alexey Alexandrovitch saw that it was not\nsimply the delight of a man who has just got a profitable job: there\nwas triumph and joy, there was a gleam like the malignant gleam he saw\nin his wife\'s eyes': 56, '"You desire my assistance in securing a divorce': 8, '"\n\n"Yes, precisely so; but I ought to warn you that I may be wasting your\ntime and attention': 19, 'I have come simply to consult you as a preliminary\nstep': 11, 'I want a divorce, but the form in which it is possible is of\ngreat consequence to me': 18, 'It is very possible that if that form does not\ncorrespond with my requirements I may give up a legal divorce': 21, '"\n\n"Oh, that\'s always the case," said the
