24, "He\nlooked at a moth that flew before his nose, and moved his hands, but\ndid not catch it from regard for Alexey Alexandrovitch's position": 25, '"Though in their general features our laws on this subject are known to\nme," pursued Alexey Alexandrovitch, "I should be glad to have an idea\nof the forms in which such things are done in practice': 36, '"\n\n"You would be glad," the lawyer, without lifting his eyes, responded,\nadopting, with a certain satisfaction, the tone of his client\'s\nremarks, "for me to lay before you all the methods by which you could\nsecure what you desire': 40, '"\n\nAnd on receiving an assuring nod from Alexey Alexandrovitch, he went\non, stealing a glance now and then at Alexey Alexandrovitch\'s face,\nwhich was growing red in patches': 29, '"Divorce by our laws," he said, with a slight shade of disapprobation\nof our laws, "is possible, as you are aware, in the following cases': 25, 'Wait a little': 3, '" he called to a clerk who put his head in at the door,\nbut he got up all the same, said a few words to him, and sat down\nagain': 31, '"': 1, 'In the following cases: physical defect in the married\nparties, desertion without communication for five years," he said,\ncrooking a short finger covered with hair, "adultery" (this word he\npronounced with obvious satisfaction), "subdivided as follows" (he\ncontinued to crook his fat fingers, though the three cases and their\nsubdivisions could obviously not be classified together): "physical\ndefect of the husband or of the wife, adultery of the husband or of the\nwife': 73, '" As by now all his fingers were used up, he uncrooked all his\nfingers and went on: "This is the theoretical view; but I imagine you\nhave done me the honor to apply to me in order to learn its application\nin practice': 44, "And therefore, guided by precedents, I must inform you\nthat in practice cases of divorce may all be reduced to the\nfollowing—there's no physical defect, I may assume, nor desertion": 30, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch bowed his head in assent': 8, '"—May be reduced to the following: adultery of one of the married\nparties, and the detection in the fact of the guilty party by mutual\nagreement, and failing such agreement, accidental detection': 32, 'It must be\nadmitted that the latter case is rarely met with in practice," said the\nlawyer, and stealing a glance at Alexey Alexandrovitch he paused, as a\nman selling pistols, after enlarging on the advantages of each weapon,\nmight await his customer\'s choice': 44, 'But Alexey Alexandrovitch said\nnothing, and therefore the lawyer went on: "The most usual and simple,\nthe sensible course, I consider, is adultery by mutual consent': 26, 'I\nshould not permit myself to express it so, speaking with a man of no\neducation," he said, "but I imagine that to you this is\ncomprehensible': 27, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch was, however, so perturbed that he did not\nimmediately comprehend all the good sense of adultery by mutual\nconsent, and his eyes expressed this uncertainty; but the lawyer\npromptly came to his assistance': 36, '"People cannot go on living together—here you have a fact': 10, 'And if both\nare agreed about it, the details and formalities become a matter of no\nimportance': 17, 'And at the same time this is the simplest and most certain\nmethod': 13, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch fully understood now': 6, 'But he had religious\nscruples, which hindered the execution of such a plan': 13, '"That is out of the question in the present case," he said': 12, '"Only one\nalternative is possible: undesigned detection, supported by letters\nwhich I have': 13, '"\n\nAt the mention of letters the lawyer pursed up his lips, and gave\nutterance to a thin little compassionate and contemptuous sound': 23, '"Kindly consider," he began, "cases of that kind are, as you are aware,\nunder ecclesiastical jurisdiction; the reverend fathers are fond of\ngoing into the minutest details in cases of that kind," he said with a\nsmile, which betrayed his sympathy with the reverend fathers\' taste': 46, '"Letters may, of course, be a partial confirmation; but detection in\nthe fact there must be of the most direct kind, that is, by\neyewitnesses': 25, 'In fact, if you do me the honor to intrust your\nconfidence to me, you will do well to leave me the choice of the\nmeasures to be employed': 29, 'If one wants the result, one must admit the\nmeans': 10, '"\n\n"If it is so': 5, '" Alexey Alexandrovitch began, suddenly turning white;\nbut at that moment the lawyer rose and again went to the door to speak\nto the intruding clerk': 26, '"Tell her we don\'t haggle over fees': 7, '" he said, and returned to Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 8, 'On his way back he caught unobserved another moth': 9, '"Nice state my rep\ncurtains will be in by the summer': 11, '" he thought, frowning': 4, '"And so you were saying': 5, '" he said': 3, '"I will communicate my decision to you by letter," obtained': 21, 'I would ask you\nto let me know what are your terms': 12, '"\n\n"It may be obtained if you give me complete liberty of action," said\nthe lawyer, not answering his question': 20, '"When can I reckon on receiving\ninformation from you': 9, '" he asked, moving towards the door, his eyes and\nhis varnished boots shining': 14, '"In a week\'s time': 4, 'Your answer as to whether you will undertake to\nconduct the case, and on what terms, you will be so good as to\ncommunicate to me': 26, '"\n\n"Very good': 3, '"\n\nThe lawyer bowed respectfully, let his client out of the door, and,\nleft alone, gave himself up to his sense of amusement': 23, "He felt so\nmirthful that, contrary to his rules, he made a reduction in his terms\nto the haggling lady, and gave up catching moths, finally deciding that\nnext winter he must have the furniture covered with velvet, like\nSigonin's": 40, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART FOUR', {'Alexey Alexandrovitch had gained a brilliant victory at the sitting of\nthe Commission of the 17th of August, but in the sequel this victory\ncut the ground from under his feet': 31, 'The new commission for the inquiry\ninto the condition of the native tribes in all its branches had been\nformed and despatched to its destination with an unusual speed and\nenergy inspired by Alexey Alexandrovitch': 35, 'Within three months a report\nwas presented': 7, 'The condition of the native tribes was investigated in\nits political, administrative, economic, ethnographic, material, and\nreligious aspects': 18, 'To all these questions there were answers admirably\nstated, and answers admitting no shade of doubt, since they were not a\nproduct of human thought, always liable to error, but were all the\nproduct of official activity': 37, 'The answers were all based on official\ndata furnished by governors and heads of churches, and founded on the\nreports of district magistrates and ecclesiastical superintendents,\nfounded in their turn on the reports of parochial overseers and parish\npriests; and so all of these answers were unhesitating and certain': 49, 'All\nsuch questions as, for instance, of the cause of failure of crops, of\nthe adherence of certain tribes to their ancient beliefs,\netc': 24, '—questions which, but for the convenient intervention of the\nofficial machine, are not, and cannot be solved for ages—received full,\nunhesitating solution': 22, "And this solution was in favor of Alexey\nAlexandrovitch's contention": 10, "But Stremov, who had felt stung to the\nquick at the last sitting, had, on the reception of the commission's\nreport, resorted to tactics which Alexey Alexandrovitch had not\nanticipated": 30, "Stremov, carrying with him several members, went over to\nAlexey Alexandrovitch's side, and not contenting himself with warmly\ndefending the measure proposed by Karenin, proposed other more extreme\nmeasures in the same direction": 33, "These measures, still further\nexaggerated in opposition to what was Alexey Alexandrovitch's\nfundamental idea, were passed by the commission, and then the aim of\nStremov's tactics became apparent": 28, 'Carried to an extreme, the measures\nseemed at once to be so absurd that the highest authorities, and public\nopinion, and intellectual ladies, and the newspapers, all at the same\ntime fell foul of them, expressing their indignation both with the\nmeasures and their nominal father, Alexey Alexandrovitch': 48, 'Stremov drew\nback, affecting to have blindly followed Karenin, and to be astounded\nand distressed at what had been done': 20, 'This meant the defeat of Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 7, 'But in spite of failing health, in spite of his\ndomestic griefs, he did not give in': 17, 'There was a split in the\ncommission': 7, 'Some members, with Stremov at their head, justified their\nmistake on the ground that they had put faith in the commission of\nrevision, instituted by Alexey Alexandrovitch, and maintained that the\nreport of the commission was rubbish, and simply so much waste paper': 43, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch, with a following of those who saw the danger of\nso revolutionary an attitude to official documents, persisted in\nupholding the statements obtained by the revising commission': 29, 'In\nconsequence of this, in the higher spheres, and even in society, all\nwas chaos, and although everyone was interested, no one could tell\nwhether the native tribes really were becoming impoverished and ruined,\nor whether they were in a flourishing condition': 42, "The position of Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, owing to this, and partly owing to the contempt\nlavished on him for his wife's infidelity, became very precarious": 24, 'And\nin this position he took an important resolution': 9, 'To the astonishment\nof the commission, he announced that he should ask permission to go\nhimself to investigate the question on the spot': 23, 'And having obtained\npermission, Alexey Alexandrovitch prepared to set off to these remote\nprovinces': 14, "Alexey Alexandrovitch's departure made a great sensation, the more so\nas just before he started he officially returned the posting-fares\nallowed him for twelve horses, to drive to his destination": 30, '"I think it very noble," Betsy said about this to the Princess Myakaya': 13, '"Why take money for posting-horses when everyone knows that there are\nrailways everywhere now': 14, '"\n\nBut Princess Myakaya did not agree, and the Princess Tverskaya\'s\nopinion annoyed her indeed': 15, '"It\'s all very well for you to talk," said she, "when you have I don\'t\nknow how many millions; but I am very glad when my husband goes on a\nrevising tour in the summer': 35, "It's very good for him and pleasant\ntraveling about, and it's a settled arrangement for me to keep a\ncarriage and coachman on the money": 25, '"\n\nOn his way to the remote provinces Alexey Alexandrovitch stopped for\nthree days at Moscow': 16, 'The day after his arrival he was driving back from calling on the\ngovernor-general': 14, 'At the crossroads by Gazetoy Place, where there are\nalways crowds of carriages and sledges, Alexey Alexandrovitch suddenly\nheard his name called out in such a loud and cheerful voice that he\ncould not help looking round': 37, 'At the corner of the pavement, in a\nshort, stylish overcoat and a low-crowned fashionable hat, jauntily\naskew, with a smile that showed a gleam of white teeth and red lips,\nstood Stepan Arkadyevitch, radiant, young, and beaming': 38, 'He called him\nvigorously and urgently, and insisted on his stopping': 11, 'He had one arm\non the window of a carriage that was stopping at the corner, and out of\nthe window were thrust the heads of a lady in a velvet hat, and two\nchildren': 35, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch was smiling and beckoning to his\nbrother-in-law': 9, 'The lady smiled a kindly smile too, and she too waved\nher hand to Alexey Alexandrovitch': 16, 'It was Dolly with her children': 6, "Alexey Alexandrovitch did not want to see anyone in Moscow, and least\nof all his wife's brother": 17, 'He raised his hat and would have driven on,\nbut Stepan Arkadyevitch told his coachman to stop, and ran across the\nsnow to him': 24, '"Well, what a shame not to have let us know': 10, 'Been here long': 3, 'I was at\nDussots\' yesterday and saw ‘Karenin\' on the visitors\' list, but it\nnever entered my head that it was you," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,\nsticking his head in at the window of the carriage, "or I should have\nlooked you up': 42, 'I am glad to see you': 6, '" he said, knocking one foot\nagainst the other to shake the snow off': 14, '"What a shame of you not to\nlet us know': 10, '" he repeated': 3, '"I had no time; I am very busy," Alexey Alexandrovitch responded dryly': 12, '"Come to my wife, she does so want to see you': 11, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch unfolded the rug in which his frozen feet were\nwrapped, and getting out of his carriage made his way over the snow to\nDarya Alexandrovna': 28, '"Why, Alexey Alexandrovitch, what are you cutting us like this for': 11, '"\nsaid Dolly, smiling': 4, '"I was very busy': 4, 'Delighted to see you': 4, '" he said in a tone clearly\nindicating that he was annoyed by it': 14, '"How are you': 3, '"\n\n"Tell me, how is my darling Anna': 8, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch mumbled something and would have gone on': 10, 'But\nStepan Arkadyevitch stopped him': 5, '"I tell you what we\'ll do ('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART FOUR', {'The next day was Sunday': 5, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch went to the Grand Theater\nto a rehearsal of the ballet, and gave Masha Tchibisova, a pretty\ndancing-girl whom he had just taken under his protection, the coral\nnecklace he had promised her the evening before, and behind the scenes\nin the dim daylight of the theater, managed to kiss her pretty little\nface, radiant over her present': 60, 'Besides the gift of the necklace he\nwanted to arrange with her about meeting after the ballet': 17, 'After\nexplaining that he could not come at the beginning of the ballet, he\npromised he would come for the last act and take her to supper': 27, "From\nthe theater Stepan Arkadyevitch drove to Ohotny Row, selected himself\nthe fish and asparagus for dinner, and by twelve o'clock was at\nDussots', where he had to see three people, luckily all staying at the\nsame hotel: Levin, who had recently come back from abroad and was\nstaying there; the new head of his department, who had just been\npromoted to that position, and had come on a tour of revision to\nMoscow; and his brother-in-law, Karenin, whom he must see, so as to be\nsure of bringing him to dinner": 92, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch liked dining, but still better he liked to give a\ndinner, small, but very choice, both as regards the food and drink and\nas regards the selection of guests': 31, "He particularly liked the program\nof that day's dinner": 9, 'There would be fresh perch, asparagus, and _la\npièce de resistance_—first-rate, but quite plain, roast beef, and wines\nto suit: so much for the eating and drinking': 27, 'Kitty and Levin would be\nof the party, and that this might not be obtrusively evident, there\nwould be a girl cousin too, and young Shtcherbatsky, and _la pièce de\nresistance_ among the guests—Sergey Koznishev and Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 38, 'Sergey Ivanovitch was a Moscow man, and a philosopher;\nAlexey Alexandrovitch a Petersburger, and a practical politician': 17, 'He\nwas asking, too, the well-known eccentric enthusiast, Pestsov, a\nliberal, a great talker, a musician, an historian, and the most\ndelightfully youthful person of fifty, who would be a sauce or garnish\nfor Koznishev and Karenin': 37, 'He would provoke them and set them off': 8, 'The second installment for the forest had been received from the\nmerchant and was not yet exhausted; Dolly had been very amiable and\ngood-humored of late, and the idea of the dinner pleased Stepan\nArkadyevitch from every point of view': 40, 'He was in the most light-hearted\nmood': 7, 'There were two circumstances a little unpleasant, but these two\ncircumstances were drowned in the sea of good-humored gaiety which\nflooded the soul of Stepan Arkadyevitch': 26, "These two circumstances were:\nfirst, that on meeting Alexey Alexandrovitch the day before in the\nstreet he had noticed that he was cold and reserved with him, and\nputting the expression of Alexey Alexandrovitch's face and the fact\nthat he had not come to see them or let them know of his arrival with\nthe rumors he had heard about Anna and Vronsky, Stepan Arkadyevitch\nguessed that something was wrong between the husband and wife": 75, 'That was one disagreeable thing': 5, "The other slightly disagreeable fact\nwas that the new head of his department, like all new heads, had the\nreputation already of a terrible person, who got up at six o'clock in\nthe morning, worked like a horse, and insisted on his subordinates\nworking in the same way": 48, 'Moreover, this new head had the further\nreputation of being a bear in his manners, and was, according to all\nreports, a man of a class in all respects the opposite of that to which\nhis predecessor had belonged, and to which Stepan Arkadyevitch had\nhitherto belonged himself': 48, 'On the previous day Stepan Arkadyevitch had\nappeared at the office in a uniform, and the new chief had been very\naffable and had talked to him as to an acquaintance': 31, 'Consequently\nStepan Arkadyevitch deemed it his duty to call upon him in his\nnon-official dress': 15, 'The thought that the new chief might not tender him\na warm reception was the other unpleasant thing': 18, 'But Stepan\nArkadyevitch instinctively felt that everything would _come round_ all\nright': 12, '"They\'re all people, all men, like us poor sinners; why be nasty\nand quarrelsome': 14, '" he thought as he went into the hotel': 9, '"Good-day, Vassily," he said, walking into the corridor with his hat\ncocked on one side, and addressing a footman he knew; "why, you\'ve let\nyour whiskers grow': 27, 'Levin, number seven, eh': 4, 'Take me up, please': 4, 'And\nfind out whether Count Anitchkin" (this was the new head) "is\nreceiving': 13, '"\n\n"Yes, sir," Vassily responded, smiling': 6, '"You\'ve not been to see us for\na long while': 10, '"\n\n"I was here yesterday, but at the other entrance': 10, 'Is this number\nseven': 4, '"\n\nLevin was standing with a peasant from Tver in the middle of the room,\nmeasuring a fresh bearskin, when Stepan Arkadyevitch went in': 24, '"What': 1, 'you killed him': 3, '" cried Stepan Arkadyevitch': 4, '"Well done': 2, 'A\nshe-bear': 2, 'How are you, Arhip': 4, '"\n\nHe shook hands with the peasant and sat down on the edge of a chair,\nwithout taking off his coat and hat': 23, '"Come, take off your coat and stay a little," said Levin, taking his\nhat': 14, '"No, I haven\'t time; I\'ve only looked in for a tiny second," answered\nStepan Arkadyevitch': 15, 'He threw open his coat, but afterwards did take it\noff, and sat on for a whole hour, talking to Levin about hunting and\nthe most intimate subjects': 28, '"Come, tell me, please, what you did abroad': 8, 'Where have you been': 4, '" said\nStepan Arkadyevitch, when the peasant had gone': 9, '"Oh, I stayed in Germany, in Prussia, in France, and in England—not in\nthe capitals, but in the manufacturing towns, and saw a great deal that\nwas new to me': 30, "And I'm glad I went": 5, '"\n\n"Yes, I knew your idea of the solution of the labor question': 13, '"\n\n"Not a bit: in Russia there can be no labor question': 12, "In Russia the\nquestion is that of the relation of the working people to the land;\nthough the question exists there too—but there it's a matter of\nrepairing what's been ruined, while with us": 34, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch listened attentively to Levin': 7, '"Yes, yes': 2, '" he said, "it\'s very possible you\'re right': 8, "But I'm glad\nyou're in good spirits, and are hunting bears, and working, and\ninterested": 15, 'Shtcherbatsky told me another story—he met you—that you\nwere in such a depressed state, talking of nothing but death': 19, '"\n\n"Well, what of it': 5, 'I\'ve not given up thinking of death," said Levin': 9, '"It\'s true that it\'s high time I was dead; and that all this is\nnonsense': 15, "It's the truth I'm telling you": 6, 'I do value my idea and my\nwork awfully; but in reality only consider this: all this world of ours\nis nothing but a speck of mildew, which has grown up on a tiny planet': 35, "And for us to suppose we can have something great—ideas, work—it's all\ndust and ashes": 15, '"\n\n"But all that\'s as old as the hills, my boy': 11, '"\n\n"It is old; but do you know, when you grasp this fully, then somehow\neverything becomes of no consequence': 20, 'When you understand that you will\ndie tomorrow, if not today, and nothing will be left, then everything\nis so unimportant': 21, 'And I consider my idea very important, but it turns\nout really to be as unimportant too, even if it were carried out, as\ndoing for that bear': 28, 'So one goes on living, amusing oneself with\nhunting, with work—anything so as not to think of death': 18, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch smiled a subtle affectionate smile as he listened\nto Levin': 13, '"Well, of course': 3, "Here you've come round to my point": 7, 'Do you remember\nyou attacked me for seeking enjoyment in life': 11, "Don't be so severe, O\nmoralist": 6, '"\n\n"No; ('TOL CHAPTER 8 PART FOUR', {'Alexey Alexandrovitch, on coming back from church service, had spent\nthe whole morning indoors': 14, 'He had two pieces of business before him\nthat morning; first, to receive and send on a deputation from the\nnative tribes which was on its way to Petersburg, and now at Moscow;\nsecondly, to write the promised letter to the lawyer': 42, "The deputation,\nthough it had been summoned at Alexey Alexandrovitch's instigation, was\nnot without its discomforting and even dangerous aspect, and he was\nglad he had found it in Moscow": 30, 'The members of this deputation had not\nthe slightest conception of their duty and the part they were to play': 20, "They naïvely believed that it was their business to lay before the\ncommission their needs and the actual condition of things, and to ask\nassistance of the government, and utterly failed to grasp that some of\ntheir statements and requests supported the contention of the enemy's\nside, and so spoiled the whole business": 53, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch was\nbusily engaged with them for a long while, drew up a program for them\nfrom which they were not to depart, and on dismissing them wrote a\nletter to Petersburg for the guidance of the deputation': 39, 'He had his\nchief support in this affair in the Countess Lidia Ivanovna': 13, 'She was a\nspecialist in the matter of deputations, and no one knew better than\nshe how to manage them, and put them in the way they should go': 29, 'Having\ncompleted this task, Alexey Alexandrovitch wrote the letter to the\nlawyer': 12, 'Without the slightest hesitation he gave him permission to act\nas he might judge best': 15, "In the letter he enclosed three of Vronsky's\nnotes to Anna, which were in the portfolio he had taken away": 20, "Since Alexey ('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART FOUR', {'It was past five, and several guests had already arrived, before the\nhost himself got home': 16, 'He went in together with Sergey Ivanovitch\nKoznishev and Pestsov, who had reached the street door at the same\nmoment': 20, 'These were the two leading representatives of the Moscow\nintellectuals, as Oblonsky had called them': 15, 'Both were men respected for\ntheir character and their intelligence': 10, 'They respected each other, but\nwere in complete and hopeless disagreement upon almost every subject,\nnot because they belonged to opposite parties, but precisely because\nthey were of the same party (their enemies refused to see any\ndistinction between their views); but, in that party, each had his own\nspecial shade of opinion': 53, "And since no difference is less easily\novercome than the difference of opinion about semi-abstract questions,\nthey never agreed in any opinion, and had long, indeed, been accustomed\nto jeer without anger, each at the other's incorrigible aberrations": 38, 'They were just going in at the door, talking of the weather, when\nStepan Arkadyevitch overtook them': 17, 'In the drawing-room there were\nalready sitting Prince Alexander Dmitrievitch Shtcherbatsky, young\nShtcherbatsky, Turovtsin, Kitty, and Karenin': 17, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch saw immediately that things were not going well in\nthe drawing-room without him': 15, "Darya Alexandrovna, in her best gray silk\ngown, obviously worried about the children, who were to have their\ndinner by themselves in the nursery, and by her husband's absence, was\nnot equal to the task of making the party mix without him": 42, "All were\nsitting like so many priests' wives on a visit (so the old prince\nexpressed it), obviously wondering why they were there, and pumping up\nremarks simply to avoid being silent": 32, 'Turovtsin—good, simple man—felt\nunmistakably a fish out of water, and the smile with which his thick\nlips greeted Stepan Arkadyevitch said, as plainly as words: "Well, old\nboy, you have popped me down in a learned set': 37, 'A drinking party now, or\nthe _Château des Fleurs_, would be more in my line': 15, '" The old prince sat\nin silence, his bright little eyes watching Karenin from one side, and\nStepan Arkadyevitch saw that he had already formed a phrase to sum up\nthat politician of whom guests were invited to partake as though he\nwere a sturgeon': 45, 'Kitty was looking at the door, calling up all her\nenergies to keep her from blushing at the entrance of Konstantin Levin': 22, 'Young Shtcherbatsky, who had not been introduced to Karenin, was trying\nto look as though he were not in the least conscious of it': 24, 'Karenin\nhimself had followed the Petersburg fashion for a dinner with ladies\nand was wearing evening dress and a white tie': 21, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch saw\nby his face that he had come simply to keep his promise, and was\nperforming a disagreeable duty in being present at this gathering': 27, 'He\nwas indeed the person chiefly responsible for the chill benumbing all\nthe guests before Stepan Arkadyevitch came in': 19, 'On entering the drawing-room Stepan Arkadyevitch apologized, explaining\nthat he had been detained by that prince, who was always the scapegoat\nfor all his absences and unpunctualities, and in one moment he had made\nall the guests acquainted with each other, and, bringing together\nAlexey Alexandrovitch and Sergey Koznishev, started them on a\ndiscussion of the Russification of Poland, into which they immediately\nplunged with Pestsov': 66, 'Slapping Turovtsin on the shoulder, he whispered\nsomething comic in his ear, and set him down by his wife and the old\nprince': 23, 'Then he told Kitty she was looking very pretty that evening,\nand presented Shtcherbatsky to Karenin': 16, 'In a moment he had so kneaded\ntogether the social dough that the drawing-room became very lively, and\nthere was a merry buzz of voices': 25, 'Konstantin Levin was the only person\nwho had not arrived': 10, "But this was so much the better, as going into the\ndining-room, Stepan Arkadyevitch found to his horror that the port and\nsherry had been procured from Depré, and not from Levy, and, directing\nthat the coachman should be sent off as speedily as possible to Levy's,\nhe was going back to the drawing-room": 54, 'In the dining-room he was met by Konstantin Levin': 9, '"I\'m not late': 3, '"\n\n"You can never help being late': 7, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, taking his\narm': 7, '"Have you a lot of people': 6, "Who's here": 2, '" asked Levin, unable to help\nblushing, as he knocked the snow off his cap with his glove': 18, '"All our own set': 4, "Kitty's here": 2, "Come along, I'll introduce you to\nKarenin": 7, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch, for all his liberal views, was well aware that to\nmeet Karenin was sure to be felt a flattering distinction, and so\ntreated his best friends to this honor': 32, 'But at that instant Konstantin\nLevin was not in a condition to feel all the gratification of making\nsuch an acquaintance': 21, 'He had not seen Kitty since that memorable\nevening when he met Vronsky, not counting, that is, the moment when he\nhad had a glimpse of her on the highroad': 30, 'He had known at the bottom of\nhis heart that he would see her here today': 16, 'But to keep his thoughts\nfree, he had tried to persuade himself that he did not know it': 18, 'Now\nwhen he heard that she was here, he was suddenly conscious of such\ndelight, and at the same time of such dread, that his breath failed him\nand he could not utter what he wanted to say': 38, '"What is she like, what is she like': 8, 'Like what she used to be, or like\nwhat she was in the carriage': 14, 'What if Darya Alexandrovna told the\ntruth': 7, "Why shouldn't it be the truth": 6, '" he thought': 3, '"Oh, please, introduce me to Karenin," he brought out with an effort,\nand with a desperately determined step he walked into the drawing-room\nand beheld her': 26, 'She was not the same as she used to be, nor was she as she had been in\nthe carriage; she was quite different': 24, 'She was scared, shy, shame-faced, and still more charming from it': 11, 'She\nsaw him the very instant he walked into the room': 11, 'She had been\nexpecting him': 5, 'She was delighted, and so confused at her own delight\nthat there was a moment, the moment when he went up to her sister and\nglanced again at her, when she, and he, and Dolly, who saw it all,\nthought she would break down and would begin to cry': 49, 'She crimsoned,\nturned white, crimsoned again, and grew faint, waiting with quivering\nlips for him to come to her': 19, 'He went up to her, bowed, and held out his\nhand without speaking': 13, 'Except for the slight quiver of her lips and the\nmoisture in her eyes that made them brighter, her smile was almost calm\nas she said:\n\n"How long it is since we\'ve seen each other': 35, '" and with desperate\ndetermination she pressed his hand with her cold hand': 13, '"You\'ve not seen me, but I\'ve seen you," said Levin, with a radiant\nsmile of happiness': 16, '"I saw you when you were driving from the railway\nstation to Ergushovo': 13, '"\n\n"When': 2, '" she asked, wondering': 4, '"You were driving to Ergushovo," said Levin, feeling as if he would sob\nwith the rapture that was flooding his heart': 21, '"And how dared I\nassociate a thought of anything not innocent with this touching\ncreature': 15, 'And, yes, I do believe it\'s true what Darya Alexandrovna told\nme," he thought': 14, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch took him by the arm and led him away to Karenin': 13, '"Let me introduce you': 4, '" He mentioned their names': 5, '"Very glad to meet you again," said Alexey Alexandrovitch coldly,\nshaking hands with Levin': 14, '"You are acquainted': 3, '" Stepan Arkadyevitch asked in surprise': 6, '"We spent three hours together in the train," said Levin smiling, "but\ngot out, just as in a masquerade, quite mystified—at least I was': 24, '"\n\n"Nonsense': 2, 'Come along, please," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, pointing in\nthe direction of the dining-room': 13, 'The men went into the dining-room and went up to a table, laid with six\nsorts of spirits and as many kinds of cheese, some with little silver\nspades and some without, caviar, herrings, preserves of various kinds,\nand plates with slices of French bread': 45, 'The men stood round the strong-smelling spirits and salt delicacies,\nand the discussion of the Russification of Poland between Koznishev,\nKarenin, and Pestsov died down in anticipation of dinner': 29, 'Sergey Ivanovitch was unequaled in his skill in winding up the most\nheated and serious argument by some unexpected pinch of Attic salt that\nchanged the disposition of his opponent': 30, 'He did this now': 4, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch had been maintaining that the Russification of\nPoland could only be accomplished as a result of larger measures which\nought to be introduced by the Russian government': 29, 'Pestsov insisted that one country can only absorb another when it is\nthe more densely populated': 16, 'Koznishev admitted both points, but with limitations': 7, 'As they were\ngoing out of the drawing-room to conclude the argument, Koznishev said,\nsmiling:\n\n"So, then, for the Russification of our foreign populations there is\nbut one method—to bring up as many children as one can': 37, 'My brother and\nI are terribly in fault, I see': 10, 'You married men, especially you, Stepan\nArkadyevitch, are the real patriots: what number have you reached': 16, '" he\nsaid, smiling genially at their host and holding out a tiny wine-glass\nto him': 16, 'Everyone laughed, and Stepan Arkadyevitch with particular good humor': 9, '"Oh, yes, that\'s the best method': 6, '" he said, munching cheese and filling\nthe wine-glass with a special sort of spirit': 15, 'The conversation dropped\nat the jest': 6, '"This cheese is not bad': 5, 'Shall I give you some': 5, '" said the master of the\nhouse': 7, '"Why, have you been going in for gymnastics again': 9, '" he asked\nLevin, pinching his muscle with his left hand': 11, "Levin smiled, bent his\narm, and under Stepan Arkadyevitch's fingers the muscles swelled up\nlike a sound cheese, hard as a knob of iron, through the fine cloth of\nthe coat": 31, '"What biceps': 2, 'A perfect Samson': 3, '"\n\n"I imagine great strength is needed for hunting bears," observed Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, who had the mistiest notions about the chase': 21, 'He cut\noff and spread with cheese a wafer of bread fine as a spider-web': 15, 'Levin smiled': 2, '"Not at all': 3, 'Quite the contrary; a child can kill a bear," he said,\nwith a slight bow moving aside for the ladies, who were approaching the\ntable': 25, '"You have killed a bear, I\'ve been told': 8, '" said Kitty, trying\nassiduously to catch with her fork a perverse mushroom that would slip\naway, and setting the lace quivering over her white arm': 26, '"Are there\nbears on your place': 6, '" she added, turning her charming little head to\nhim and smiling': 12, 'There was apparently nothing extraordinary in what she said, but what\nunutterable meaning there was for him in every sound, in every turn of\nher lips, her eyes, her hand as she said it': 34, 'There was entreaty for\nforgiveness, and trust in him, and tenderness—soft, timid\ntenderness—and promise and hope and love for him, which he could not\nbut believe in and which choked him with happiness': 33, '"No, we\'ve been hunting in the Tver province': 8, 'It was coming back from\nthere that I met your _beau-frère_ in the train, or your _beau-frère\'s_\nbrother-in-law," he said with a smile': 23, '"It was an amusing meeting': 5, '"\n\nAnd he began telling with droll good-humor how, after not sleeping all\nnight, he had, wearing an old fur-lined, full-skirted coat, got into\nAlexey Alexandrovitch\'s compartment': 27, '"The conductor, forgetting the proverb, would have chucked me out on\naccount of my attire; but thereupon I began expressing my feelings in\nelevated language, and': 26, 'you, too," he said, addressing Karenin and\nforgetting his name, "at first would have ejected me on the ground of\nthe old coat, but afterwards you took my part, for which I am extremely\ngrateful': 35, '"\n\n"The rights of passengers generally to choose their seats are too\nill-defined," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, rubbing the tips of his\nfingers on his handkerchief': 25, '"I saw you were in uncertainty about me," said Levin, smiling\ngood-naturedly, "but I made haste to plunge into intellectual\nconversation to smooth over the defects of my attire': 29, '" Sergey\nIvanovitch, while he kept up a conversation with their hostess, had one\near for his brother, and he glanced askance at him': 24, '"What is the matter\nwith him today': 7, 'Why such a conquering hero': 5, 'He did not\nknow that Levin was feeling as though he had grown wings': 14, 'Levin knew\nshe was listening to his words and that she was glad to listen to him': 17, 'And this was the only thing that interested him': 9, 'Not in that room only,\nbut in the whole world, there existed for him only himself, with\nenormously increased importance and dignity in his own eyes, and she': 28, 'He felt himself on a pinnacle that made him giddy, and far away down\nbelow were all those nice excellent Karenins, Oblonskys, and all the\nworld': 26, 'Quite without attracting notice, without glancing at them, as though\nthere were no other places left, Stepan Arkadyevitch put Levin and\nKitty side by side': 25, '"Oh, you may as well sit there," he said to Levin': 11, 'The dinner was as choice as the china, in which Stepan Arkadyevitch was\na connoisseur': 15, 'The _soupe Marie-Louise_ was a splendid success; the\ntiny pies eaten with it melted in the mouth and were irreproachable': 20, 'The two footmen and Matvey, in white cravats, did their duty with the\ndishes and wines unobtrusively, quietly, and swiftly': 20, 'On the material\nside the dinner was a success; it was no less so on the immaterial': 17, 'The\nconversation, at times general and at times between individuals, never\npaused, and towards the end the company was so lively that the men rose\nfrom the table, without stopping speaking, and even Alexey\nAlexandrovitch thawed': 36, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART FOUR', {"Pestsov liked thrashing an argument out to the end, and was not\nsatisfied with Sergey Ivanovitch's words, especially as he felt the\ninjustice of his view": 26, '"I did not mean," he said over the soup, addressing Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, "mere density of population alone, but in conjunction\nwith fundamental ideas, and not by means of principles': 29, '"\n\n"It seems to me," Alexey Alexandrovitch said languidly, and with no\nhaste, "that that\'s the same thing': 18, 'In my opinion, influence over\nanother people is only possible to the people which has the higher\ndevelopment, which': 19, '"\n\n"But that\'s just the question," Pestsov broke in in his bass': 12, 'He was\nalways in a hurry to speak, and seemed always to put his whole soul\ninto what he was saying': 21, '"In what are we to make higher development\nconsist': 9, 'The English, the French, the Germans, which is at the highest\nstage of development': 14, 'Which of them will nationalize the other': 7, 'We see\nthe Rhine provinces have been turned French, but the Germans are not at\na lower stage': 18, '" he shouted': 3, '"There is another law at work there': 7, '"\n\n"I fancy that the greater influence is always on the side of true\ncivilization," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, slightly lifting his\neyebrows': 22, '"But what are we to lay down as the outward signs of true\ncivilization': 14, '" said Pestsov': 3, '"I imagine such signs are generally very well known," said Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 12, '"But are they fully known': 5, '" Sergey Ivanovitch put in with a subtle\nsmile': 9, '"It is the accepted view now that real culture must be purely\nclassical; but we see most intense disputes on each side of the\nquestion, and there is no denying that the opposite camp has strong\npoints in its favor': 40, '"\n\n"You are for classics, Sergey Ivanovitch': 7, 'Will you take red wine': 5, '" said\nStepan Arkadyevitch': 4, '"I am not expressing my own opinion of either form of culture," Sergey\nIvanovitch said, holding out his glass with a smile of condescension,\nas to a child': 28, '"I only say that both sides have strong arguments to\nsupport them," he went on, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch': 18, '"My\nsympathies are classical from education, but in this discussion I am\npersonally unable to arrive at a conclusion': 19, 'I see no distinct grounds\nfor classical studies being given a preeminence over scientific\nstudies': 15, '"\n\n"The natural sciences have just as great an educational value," put in\nPestsov': 14, '"Take astronomy, take botany, or zoology with its system of\ngeneral principles': 12, '"\n\n"I cannot quite agree with that," responded Alexey Alexandrovitch': 10, '"It\nseems to me that one must admit that the very process of studying the\nforms of language has a peculiarly favorable influence on intellectual\ndevelopment': 26, 'Moreover, it cannot be denied that the influence of the\nclassical authors is in the highest degree moral, while, unfortunately,\nwith the study of the natural sciences are associated the false and\nnoxious doctrines which are the curse of our day': 41, '"\n\nSergey Ivanovitch would have said something, but Pestsov interrupted\nhim in his rich bass': 15, 'He began warmly contesting the justice of this\nview': 9, 'Sergey Ivanovitch waited serenely to speak, obviously with a\nconvincing reply ready': 12, '"But," said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling subtly, and addressing Karenin,\n"One must allow that to weigh all the advantages and disadvantages of\nclassical and scientific studies is a difficult task, and the question\nwhich form of education was to be preferred would not have been so\nquickly and conclusively decided if there had not been in favor of\nclassical education, as you expressed it just now, its moral—_disons le\nmot_—anti-nihilist influence': 70, '"\n\n"Undoubtedly': 2, '"\n\n"If it had not been for the distinctive property of anti-nihilistic\ninfluence on the side of classical studies, we should have considered\nthe subject more, have weighed the arguments on both sides," said\nSergey Ivanovitch with a subtle smile, "we should have given elbow-room\nto both tendencies': 48, 'But now we know that these little pills of\nclassical learning possess the medicinal property of anti-nihilism, and\nwe boldly prescribe them to our patients': 25, 'But what if they had no\nsuch medicinal property': 9, '" he wound up humorously': 5, "At Sergey Ivanovitch's little pills, everyone laughed; Turovtsin in\nespecial roared loudly and jovially, glad at last to have found\nsomething to laugh at, all he ever looked for in listening to\nconversation": 33, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch had not made a mistake in inviting Pestsov': 10, 'With\nPestsov intellectual conversation never flagged for an instant': 9, 'Directly Sergey Ivanovitch had concluded the conversation with his\njest, Pestsov promptly started a new one': 16, '"I can\'t agree even," said he, "that the government had that aim': 12, 'The\ngovernment obviously is guided by abstract considerations, and remains\nindifferent to the influence its measures may exercise': 18, 'The education\nof women, for instance, would naturally be regarded as likely to be\nharmful, but the government opens schools and universities for women': 24, '"\n\nAnd the conversation at once passed to the new subject of the education\nof women': 16, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch expressed the idea that the education of women is\napt to be confounded with the emancipation of women, and that it is\nonly so that it can be considered dangerous': 32, '"I consider, on the contrary, that the two questions are inseparably\nconnected together," said Pestsov; "it is a vicious circle': 20, 'Woman is\ndeprived of rights from lack of education, and the lack of education\nresults from the absence of rights': 20, 'We must not forget that the\nsubjection of women is so complete, and dates from such ages back that\nwe are often unwilling to recognize the gulf that separates them from\nus," said he': 34, '"You said rights," said Sergey Ivanovitch, waiting till Pestsov had\nfinished, "meaning the right of sitting on juries, of voting, of\npresiding at official meetings, the right of entering the civil\nservice, of sitting in parliament': 36, '"\n\n"But if women, as a rare exception, can occupy such positions, it seems\nto me you are wrong in using the expression ‘rights': 24, "' It would be more\ncorrect to say duties": 9, 'Every man will agree that in doing the duty of a\njuryman, a witness, a telegraph clerk, we feel we are performing\nduties': 23, 'And therefore it would be correct to say that women are seeking\nduties, and quite legitimately': 16, 'And one can but sympathize with this\ndesire to assist in the general labor of man': 16, '"\n\n"Quite so," Alexey Alexandrovitch assented': 6, '"The question, I imagine,\nis simply whether they are fitted for such duties': 13, '"\n\n"They will most likely be perfectly fitted," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,\n"when education has become general among them': 18, 'We see this': 3, '"\n\n"How about the proverb': 5, '" said the prince, who had a long while been\nintent on the conversation, his little comical eyes twinkling': 19, '"I can\nsay it before my daughter: her hair is long, because her wit is': 15, '"\n\n"Just what they thought of the negroes before their emancipation': 11, '" said\nPestsov angrily': 4, '"What seems strange to me is that women should seek fresh duties," said\nSergey Ivanovitch, "while we see, unhappily, that men usually try to\navoid them': 26, '"\n\n"Duties are bound up with rights—power, money, honor; those are what\nwomen are seeking," said Pestsov': 17, '"Just as though and Sergey Ivanovitch\nregretted that he had not made this comparison': 19, 'Even Alexey\nAlexandrovitch smiled': 4, '"Yes, but a man can\'t nurse a baby," said Pestsov, "while a woman': 13, '"\n\n"No, there was an Englishman who did suckle his baby on board ship,"\nsaid the old prince, feeling this freedom in conversation permissible\nbefore his own daughters': 28, '"There are as many such Englishmen as there would be women officials,"\nsaid Sergey Ivanovitch': 15, '"Yes, but what is a girl to do who has no family': 12, '" put in Stepan\nArkadyevitch, thinking of Masha Tchibisova, whom he had had in his mind\nall along, in sympathizing with Pestsov and supporting him': 25, '"If the story of such a girl were thoroughly sifted, you would find she\nhad abandoned a family—her own or a sister\'s, where she might have\nfound a woman\'s duties," Darya Alexandrovna broke in unexpectedly in a\ntone of exasperation, probably suspecting what sort of girl Stepan\nArkadyevitch was of\nTurovtsin, who in his mirth dropped his asparagus with the thick end in\nthe sauce': 39, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 11 PART FOUR', {'Everyone took part in the conversation except Kitty and Levin': 10, "At\nfirst, when they were talking of the influence that one people has on\nanother, there rose to Levin's mind what he had to say on the subject": 28, 'But these ideas, once of such importance in his eyes, seemed to come\ninto his brain as in a dream, and had now not the slightest interest\nfor him': 29, 'It even struck him as strange that they should be so eager to\ntalk of what was of no use to anyone': 22, 'Kitty, too, should, one would\nhave supposed, have been interested in what they were saying of the\nrights and education of women': 22, 'How often she had mused on the subject,\nthinking of her friend abroad, Varenka, of her painful state of\ndependence, how often she had wondered about herself what would become\nof her if she did not marry, and how often she had argued with her\nsister about it': 48, 'But it did not interest her at all': 8, 'She and Levin had\na conversation of their own, yet not a conversation, but some sort of\nmysterious communication, which brought them every moment nearer, and\nstirred in both a sense of glad terror before the unknown into which\nthey were entering': 42, "At first Levin, in answer to Kitty's question how he could have seen\nher last year in the carriage, told her how he had been coming home\nfrom the mowing along the highroad and had met her": 37, '"It was very, very early in the morning': 8, 'You were probably only just\nawake': 6, 'Your mother was asleep in the corner': 7, 'It was an exquisite\nmorning': 5, then': 12, 'Something important': 2, '"\n\n"Wasn\'t I dreadfully untidy': 5, '" she wondered, but seeing the smile of\necstasy these reminiscences called up, she felt that the impression she\nhad made ('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART FOUR', {'Connected with the conversation that had sprung up on the rights of\nwomen there were certain questions as to the inequality of rights in\nmarriage improper to discuss before the ladies': 31, 'Pestsov had several\ntimes during dinner touched upon these questions, but Sergey Ivanovitch\nand Stepan Arkadyevitch carefully drew him off them': 21, 'When they rose from the table and the ladies had gone out, Pestsov did\nnot follow them, but addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch, began to expound\nthe chief ground of inequality': 29, 'The inequality in marriage, in his\nopinion, lay in the fact that the infidelity of the wife and the\ninfidelity of the husband are punished unequally, both by the law and\nby public opinion': 34, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch went hurriedly up to Alexey\nAlexandrovitch and offered him a cigar': 13, '"No, I don\'t smoke," Alexey Alexandrovitch answered calmly, and as\nthough purposely wishing to show that he was not afraid of the subject,\nhe turned to Pestsov with a chilly smile': 31, '"I imagine that such a view has a foundation in the very nature of\nthings," he said, and would have gone on to the drawing-room': 25, 'But at\nthis point Turovtsin broke suddenly and unexpectedly into the\nconversation, addressing Alexey Alexandrovitch': 15, '"You heard, perhaps, about Pryatchnikov': 5, '" said Turovtsin, warmed up by\nthe champagne he had drunk, and long waiting for an opportunity to\nbreak the silence that had weighed on him': 26, '"Vasya Pryatchnikov," he\nsaid, with a good-natured smile on his damp, red lips, addressing\nhimself principally to the most important guest, Alexey Alexandrovitch,\n"they told me today he fought a duel with Kvitsky at Tver, and has\nkilled him': 39, '"\n\nJust as it always seems that one bruises oneself on a sore place, so\nStepan Arkadyevitch felt now that the conversation would by ill luck\nfall every moment on Alexey Alexandrovitch\'s sore spot': 34, 'He would again\nhave got his brother-in-law away, but Alexey Alexandrovitch himself\ninquired, with curiosity:\n\n"What did Pryatchnikov fight about': 20, '"\n\n"His wife': 3, 'Acted like a man, he did': 6, 'Called him out and shot him': 6, '"\n\n"Ah': 2, '" said Alexey Alexandrovitch indifferently, and lifting his\neyebrows, he went into the drawing-room': 14, '"How glad I am you have come," Dolly said with a frightened smile,\nmeeting him in the outer drawing-room': 19, '"I must talk to you': 5, "Let's sit\nhere": 3, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch, with the same expression of indifference, given\nhim by his lifted eyebrows, sat down beside Darya Alexandrovna, and\nsmiled affectedly': 23, '"It\'s fortunate," said he, "especially as I was meaning to ask you to\nexcuse me, and to be taking leave': 20, 'I have to start tomorrow': 5, '"\n\nDarya Alexandrovna was firmly convinced of Anna\'s innocence, and she\nfelt herself growing pale and her lips quivering with anger at this\nfrigid, unfeeling man, who was so calmly intending to ruin her innocent\nfriend': 36, '"Alexey Alexandrovitch," she said, with desperate resolution looking\nhim in the face, "I asked you about Anna, you made me no answer': 22, 'How is\nshe': 3, '"\n\n"She is, I believe, quite well, Darya Alexandrovna," replied Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, not looking at her': 16, '"Alexey Alexandrovitch, forgive me, I have no right': 8, 'but I love Anna\nas a sister, and esteem her; I beg, I beseech you to tell me what is\nwrong between you': 23, 'what fault do you find with her': 7, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch frowned, and almost closing his eyes, dropped his\nhead': 12, '"I presume that your husband has told you the grounds on which I\nconsider it necessary to change my attitude to Anna Arkadyevna': 23, '" he\nsaid, not looking her in the face, but eyeing with displeasure\nShtcherbatsky, who was walking across the drawing-room': 20, '"I don\'t believe it, I don\'t believe it, I can\'t believe it': 12, '" Dolly\nsaid, clasping her bony hands before her with a vigorous gesture': 13, "She\nrose quickly, and laid her hand on Alexey Alexandrovitch's sleeve": 11, '"We\nshall be disturbed here': 5, 'Come this way, please': 4, '"\n\nDolly\'s agitation had an effect on Alexey Alexandrovitch': 9, 'He got up and\nsubmissively followed her to the schoolroom': 10, 'They sat down to a table\ncovered with an oilcloth cut in slits by penknives': 15, '"I don\'t, I don\'t believe it': 6, '" Dolly said, trying to catch his glance\nthat avoided her': 11, '"One cannot disbelieve facts, Darya Alexandrovna," said he, with an\nemphasis on the word "facts': 15, '"\n\n"But what has she done': 6, '" said Darya Alexandrovna': 4, '"What precisely has\nshe done': 5, '"\n\n"She has forsaken her duty, and deceived her husband': 10, 'That\'s what she\nhas done," said he': 7, '"No, no, it can\'t be': 5, 'No, for God\'s sake, you are mistaken," said\nDolly, putting her hands to her temples and closing her eyes': 19, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled coldly, with his lips alone, meaning to\nsignify to her and to himself the firmness of his conviction; but this\nwarm defense, though it could not shake him, reopened his wound': 34, 'He\nbegan to speak with greater heat': 7, '"It is extremely difficult to be mistaken when a wife herself informs\nher husband of the fact—informs him that eight years of her life, and a\nson, all that\'s a mistake, and that she wants to begin life again," he\nsaid angrily, with a snort': 45, '"Anna and sin—I cannot connect them, I cannot believe it': 10, '"\n\n"Darya Alexandrovna," he said, now looking straight into Dolly\'s\nkindly, troubled face, and feeling that his tongue was being loosened\nin spite of himself, "I would give a great deal for doubt to be still\npossible': 37, 'When I doubted, I was miserable, but it was better than now': 12, 'When I doubted, I had hope; but now there is no hope, and still I doubt\nof everything': 18, 'I am in such doubt of everything that I even hate my\nson, and sometimes do not believe he is my son': 22, 'I am very unhappy': 4, '"\n\nHe had no need to say that': 8, 'Darya Alexandrovna had seen that as soon as\nhe glanced into her face; and she felt sorry for him, and her faith in\nthe innocence of her friend began to totter': 31, '"Oh, this is awful, awful': 5, 'But can it be true that you are resolved on\na divorce': 12, '"\n\n"I am resolved on extreme measures': 7, 'There is nothing else for me to\ndo': 8, '"\n\n"Nothing else to do, nothing else to do': 9, '" she replied, with tears in\nher eyes': 8, '"Oh no, don\'t say nothing else to do': 8, '" she said': 3, '"What is horrible in a trouble of this kind is that one cannot, as in\nany other—in loss, in death—bear one\'s trouble in peace, but that one\nmust act," said he, as though guessing her thought': 36, '"One must get out\nof the humiliating position in which one is placed; one can\'t live _à\ntrois_': 18, '"\n\n"I understand, I quite understand that," said Dolly, and her head sank': 13, 'She was silent for a little, thinking of herself, of her own grief in\nher family, and all at once, with an impulsive movement, she raised her\nhead and clasped her hands with an imploring gesture': 36, '"But wait a\nlittle': 4, 'You are a Christian': 4, 'Think of her': 3, 'What will become of her, if\nyou cast her off': 10, '"\n\n"I have thought, Darya Alexandrovna, I have thought a great deal," said\nAlexey Alexandrovitch': 15, 'His face turned red in patches, and his dim eyes\nlooked straight before him': 14, 'Darya Alexandrovna at that moment pitied\nhim with all her heart': 11, '"That was what I did indeed when she herself\nmade known to me my humiliation; I left everything as of old': 21, 'I gave\nher a chance to reform, I tried to save her': 12, 'And with what result': 4, 'She\nwould not regard the slightest request—that she should observe\ndecorum," he said, getting heated': 15, '"One may save anyone who does not\nwant to be ('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART FOUR', {'When they rose from table, Levin would have liked to follow Kitty into\nthe drawing-room; but he was afraid she might dislike this, as too\nobviously paying her attention': 29, 'He remained in the little ring of men,\ntaking part in the general conversation, and without looking at Kitty,\nhe was aware of her movements, her looks, and the place where she was\nin the drawing-room': 36, 'He did at once, and without the smallest effort, keep the promise he\nhad made her—always to think well of all men, and to like everyone\nalways': 27, 'The conversation fell on the village commune, in which Pestsov\nsaw a sort of special principle, called by him the "choral" principle': 22, 'Levin did not agree with Pestsov, nor with his brother, who had a\nspecial attitude of his own, both admitting and not admitting the\nsignificance of the Russian commune': 29, 'But he talked to them, simply\ntrying to reconcile and soften their differences': 13, 'He was not in the\nleast interested in what he said himself, and even less so in what they\nsaid; that\'s true," said Levin; "it generally happens that one argues\nwarmly simply because one can\'t make out what one\'s opponent wants to\nprove': 25, '"\n\nLevin had often noticed in discussions between the most intelligent\npeople that after enormous efforts, and an enormous expenditure of\nlogical subtleties and words, the disputants finally arrived at being\naware that what they had so long been struggling to prove to one\nanother had long ago, from the beginning of the argument, been known to\nboth, but that they liked different things, and would not define what\nthey liked for fear of its being attacked': 77, 'He had often had the\nexperience of suddenly in a discussion grasping what it was his\nopponent liked and at once liking it too, and immediately he found\nhimself agreeing, and then all arguments fell away as useless': 38, 'Sometimes, too, he had experienced the opposite, expressing at last\nwhat he liked himself, which he was devising arguments to defend, and,\nchancing to express it well and genuinely, he had found his opponent at\nonce agreeing and ceasing to dispute his position': 43, 'He tried to say\nthis': 5, 'She knitted her brow, trying to understand': 7, 'But directly he began to\nillustrate his meaning, she understood at once': 12, '"I know: one must find out what he is arguing for, what is precious to\nhim, then one can': 19, '"\n\nShe had completely guessed and expressed his badly expressed idea': 11, 'Levin smiled joyfully; ('TOL CHAPTER 15 PART FOUR', {'The streets were still empty': 5, 'Levin went to the house of the\nShtcherbatskys': 8, "The visitors' doors were closed and everything was\nasleep": 9, 'He walked back, ('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART FOUR', {"After the conversation with Alexey Alexandrovitch, Vronsky went out\nonto the steps of the Karenins' house and stood still, with difficulty\nremembering where he was, and where he ought to walk or drive": 33, 'He felt\ndisgraced, humiliated, guilty, and deprived of all possibility of\nwashing away his humiliation': 15, 'He felt thrust out of the beaten track\nalong which he had so proudly and lightly walked till then': 19, 'All the\nhabits and rules of his life that had seemed so firm, had turned out\nsuddenly false and inapplicable': 20, 'The betrayed husband, who had figured\ntill that time as a pitiful creature, an incidental and somewhat\nludicrous obstacle to his happiness, had suddenly been summoned by her\nherself, elevated to an awe-inspiring pinnacle, and on the pinnacle\nthat husband had shown himself, not malignant, not false, not\nludicrous, but kind and straightforward and large': 55, 'Vronsky could not\nbut feel this, and the parts were suddenly reversed': 12, 'Vronsky felt his\nelevation and his own abasement, his truth and his own falsehood': 14, 'He\nfelt that the husband was magnanimous even in his sorrow, while he had\nbeen base and petty in his deceit': 21, 'But this sense of his own\nhumiliation before the man he had unjustly despised made up only a\nsmall part of his misery': 23, 'He felt unutterably wretched now, for his\npassion for Anna, which had seemed to him of late to be growing cooler,\nnow that he knew he had lost her forever, was stronger than ever it had\nbeen': 37, 'He had seen all of her in her illness, had come to know her very\nsoul, and it seemed to him that he had never loved her till then': 29, 'And\nnow when he had learned to know her, to love her as she should be\nloved, he had been humiliated before her, and had lost her forever,\nleaving with her nothing of himself but a shameful memory': 38, 'Most\nterrible of all had been his ludicrous, shameful position when Alexey\nAlexandrovitch had pulled his hands away from his humiliated face': 22, "He\nstood on the steps of the Karenins' house like one distraught, and did\nnot know what to do": 19, '"A sledge, sir': 3, '" asked the porter': 4, '"Yes, a sledge': 3, '"\n\nOn getting home, after three sleepless nights, Vronsky, without\nundressing, lay down flat on the sofa, clasping his hands and laying\nhis head on them': 26, 'His head was heavy': 4, 'Images, memories, and ideas of\nthe strangest description followed one another with extraordinary\nrapidity and vividness': 16, "First it was the medicine he had poured out for\nthe patient and spilt over the spoon, then the midwife's white hands,\nthen the queer posture of Alexey Alexandrovitch on the floor beside the\nbed": 35, '"To sleep': 2, 'To forget': 2, '" he said to himself with the serene confidence of\na healthy man that if he is tired and sleepy, he will go to sleep at\nonce': 27, 'And the same instant his head did begin to feel drowsy and he\nbegan to drop off into forgetfulness': 19, 'The waves of the sea of\nunconsciousness had begun to meet over his head, when all at once—it\nwas as though a violent shock of electricity had passed over him': 30, 'He\nstarted so that he leaped up on the springs of the sofa, and leaning on\nhis arms got in a panic onto his knees': 25, 'His eyes were wide open as\nthough he had never been asleep': 12, 'The heaviness in his head and the\nweariness in his limbs that he had felt a minute before had suddenly\ngone': 21, '"You may trample me in the mud," he heard Alexey '"Perhaps': 1, 'What makes men go out of their minds; what makes men shoot themselves': 13, '"\nhe answered himself, and opening his eyes, he saw with wonder an\nembroidered cushion beside him, worked humiliation," he added slowly': 6, 'He went to the door and closed it, then with fixed eyes and clenched\nteeth he went up to the table, took a revolver, looked round him,\nturned it to a loaded barrel, and sank into thought': 37, 'For two minutes,\nhis head bent forward with an expression of an intense effort of\nthought, he stood with the revolver in his hand, motionless, thinking': 26, to him, was simply\nthe result of exactly the same circle of memories and images through\nwhich he had passed ten times already during the last hour—memories of\nhappiness lost forever': 39, 'There was the same conception of the\nsenselessness of everything to come in life, the same consciousness of\nhumiliation': 19, 'Even the sequence of these images and emotions was the\nsame': 11, '"Of 'He tried to clutch at the\nedge of the table, dropped the revolver, staggered, and sat down on the\nground, looking about him in astonishment': 25, 'He did not recognize his\nroom, looking up from his\nsenses': 16, 'He made an effort at thought, and was aware that he was on the\nfloor; and seeing blood on the tiger-skin rug and on his arm, he knew\nhe had shot himself': 32, '"Idiotic': 1, ('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART FOUR', {'The mistake made by Alexey Alexandrovitch in that, when preparing for\nseeing his wife, he had overlooked the possibility that her repentance\nmight be sincere, and he might forgive her, and she might not die—this\nmistake was two months after his return from Moscow brought home to him\nin all its significance': 52, 'But the mistake made by him had arisen not\nsimply from his having overlooked that contingency, but also from the\nfact that until that day of his interview with his dying wife, he had\nnot known his own heart': 39, "At his sick wife's bedside he had for the\nfirst time in his life given way to that feeling of sympathetic\nsuffering always roused in him by the sufferings of others, and\nhitherto looked on by him with shame as a harmful weakness": 43, 'And pity\nfor her, and remorse for having desired her death, and most of all, the\njoy of forgiveness, made him at once conscious, not simply of the\nrelief of his own sufferings, but of a spiritual peace he had never\nexperienced before': 43, 'He suddenly felt that the very thing that was the\nsource of his sufferings had become the source of his spiritual joy;\nthat what had seemed insoluble while he was judging, blaming, and\nhating, had become clear and simple when he forgave and loved': 44, 'He forgave his wife and pitied her for her sufferings and her remorse': 13, 'He forgave Vronsky, and pitied him, especially after reports reached\nhim of his despairing action': 15, 'He felt more for his son than before': 8, 'And\nhe blamed himself now for having taken too little interest in him': 13, 'But\nfor the little newborn baby he felt a quite peculiar sentiment, not of\npity, only, but of tenderness': 19, "At first, from a feeling of compassion\nalone, he had been interested in the delicate little creature, who was\nnot his child, and who was cast on one side during her mother's\nillness, and would certainly have died if he had not troubled about\nher, and he did not himself observe how fond he became of her": 57, 'He would\ngo into the nursery several times a day, and sit there for a long\nwhile, so that the nurses, who were at first afraid of him, got quite\nused to his presence': 34, 'Sometimes for half an hour at a stretch he would\nsit silently gazing at the saffron-red, downy, wrinkled face of the\nsleeping baby, watching the movements of the frowning brows, and the\nfat little hands, with clenched fingers, that rubbed the little eyes\nand nose': 45, 'At such moments particularly, Alexey Alexandrovitch had a\nsense of perfect peace and inward harmony, and saw nothing\nextraordinary in his position, nothing that ought to be changed': 28, 'But as time went on, he saw more and more distinctly that however\nnatural the position now seemed to him, he would not long be allowed to\nremain in it': 30, 'He felt that besides the blessed spiritual force\ncontrolling his soul, there was another, a brutal force, as powerful,\nor more powerful, which controlled his life, and that this force would\nnot allow him that humble peace he longed for': 40, 'He felt that everyone\nwas looking at him with inquiring wonder, that he was not understood,\nand that something was expected of him': 23, 'Above all, he felt the\ninstability and unnaturalness of his relations with his wife': 14, 'When the softening effect of the near approach of death had passed\naway, Alexey Alexandrovitch began to notice that Anna was afraid of\nhim, ill at ease with him, and could not look him straight in the face': 38, 'She seemed to be wanting, and not daring, to tell him something; and as\nthough foreseeing their present relations could not continue, she\nseemed to be expecting something from him': 30, ('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART FOUR', {'Alexey Alexandrovitch took leave of Betsy in the drawing-room, and went\nto his wife': 14, 'She was lying down, but hearing his steps she sat up\nhastily in her former attitude, and looked in a scared way at him': 24, 'He\nsaw she had been crying': 6, '"I am very grateful for your confidence in me': 9, '" He repeated gently in\nRussian the phrase he had said in Betsy\'s presence in French, and sat\ndown beside her': 21, 'When he spoke to her in Russian, using the Russian\n"thou" of intimacy and affection, it was insufferably irritating to\nAnna': 21, '"And I am very grateful for your decision': 8, 'I, too, imagine that\nsince he is going away, there is no sort of necessity for Count Vronsky\nto come here': 21, 'However, if': 2, '"\n\n"But I\'ve said so already, so why repeat it': 10, '" Anna suddenly interrupted\nhim with an irritation she could not succeed in repressing': 14, '"No sort of\nnecessity," she thought, "for a man to come and say good-bye to the\nwoman he loves, for whom he was ready to ruin himself, and has ruined\nhimself, and who cannot live without him': 37, 'No sort of necessity': 4, '" she\ncompressed her lips, and dropped her burning eyes to his hands with\ntheir swollen veins': 17, 'They were rubbing each other': 5, '"Let us never speak of it," she added more calmly': 10, '"I have left this question to you to decide, and I am very glad to\nsee': 16, '" Alexey Alexandrovitch was beginning': 5, '"That my wish coincides with your own," she finished quickly,\nexasperated at his talking so slowly while she knew beforehand all he\nwould say': 24, '"Yes," he assented;
