but if they\nall thought this out of the question, he was even ready to allow these\nrelations to be renewed, so long as the children were not disgraced,\nand he was not deprived of them nor forced to change his position': 59, 'Bad\nas this might be, it was anyway better than a rupture, which would put\nher in a hopeless and shameful position, and deprive him of everything\nhe cared for': 30, 'But he felt helpless; he knew beforehand that everyone\nwas against him, and that he would not be allowed to do what seemed to\nhim now so natural and right, but would be forced to do what was wrong,\nthough it seemed the proper thing to them': 47, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 21 PART FOUR', {"Before Betsy had time to walk out of the drawing-room, she was met in\nthe doorway by Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had just come from Yeliseev's,\nwhere a consignment of fresh oysters had been received": 34, '"Ah': 1, 'princess': 1, 'what a delightful meeting': 4, '" he began': 3, '"I\'ve been to see\nyou': 5, '"\n\n"A meeting for one minute, for I\'m going," said Betsy, smiling and\nputting on her glove': 17, '"Don\'t put on your glove yet, princess; let me kiss your hand': 12, "There's\nnothing I'm so thankful to the revival of the old fashions for as the\nkissing the hand": 18, '" He kissed Betsy\'s hand': 5, '"When shall we see each\nother': 6, '"\n\n"You don\'t deserve it," answered Betsy, smiling': 8, '"Oh, yes, I deserve a great deal, for I\'ve become a most serious\nperson': 14, 'I don\'t only manage my own affairs, but other people\'s too," he\nsaid, with a significant expression': 17, '"Oh, I\'m so glad': 4, '" answered Betsy, at once understanding that he was\nspeaking of Anna': 12, 'And going back into the drawing-room, they stood in a\ncorner': 11, '"He\'s killing her," said Betsy in a whisper full of meaning': 11, '"It\'s impossible, impossible': 3, '"\n\n"I\'m so glad you think so," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, shaking his head\nwith a serious and sympathetically distressed expression, "that\'s what\nI\'ve come to Petersburg for': 27, '"\n\n"The whole town\'s talking of it," she said': 9, '"It\'s an impossible\nposition': 4, 'She pines and pines away': 5, "He doesn't understand that she's\none of those women who can't trifle with their feelings": 15, 'One of two\nthings: either let him take her away, act with energy, or give her a\ndivorce': 18, 'This is stifling her': 4, '"\n\n"Yes, yes': 3, 'just so': 2, '" Oblonsky said, sighing': 4, '"That\'s what I\'ve\ncome for': 5, 'At least not solely for that': 6, "I've been made a\n_Kammerherr_; of course, one has to say thank you": 13, 'But the chief thing\nwas having to settle this': 9, '"\n\n"Well, God help you': 5, '" said Betsy': 3, 'After accompanying Betsy to the outside hall, once more kissing her\nhand above the glove, at the point where the pulse beats, and murmuring\nto her such unseemly nonsense that she did not know whether to laugh or\nbe angry, Stepan Arkadyevitch went to his sister': 46, 'He found her in\ntears': 5, 'Although he happened to be bubbling over with good spirits, Stepan\nArkadyevitch immediately and quite naturally fell into the sympathetic,\npoetically emotional tone which harmonized with her mood': 28, 'He asked her\nhow she was, and how she had spent the morning': 13, '"Very, very miserably': 3, 'Today and this morning and all past days and\ndays to come," she said': 14, '"I think you\'re giving way to pessimism': 7, 'You must rouse yourself, you\nmust look life in the face': 11, "I know it's hard, but": 5, '"\n\n"I have heard it said that women love men even for their vices," Anna\nbegan suddenly, "but I hate him for his virtues': 24, "I can't live with him": 5, 'Do you understand': 3, 'the sight of him has a physical effect on me, it\nmakes me beside myself': 15, "I can't, I can't live with him": 7, 'What am I to\ndo': 5, "I have been unhappy, and used to think one couldn't be more\nunhappy, but the awful state of things I am going through now, I could\nnever have conceived": 29, "Would you believe it, that knowing he's a good\nman, a splendid man, that I'm not worth his little finger, still I hate\nhim": 24, 'I hate him for his generosity': 6, "And there's nothing left for me\nbut": 7, '"\n\nShe would have said death, but Stepan Arkadyevitch would not let her\nfinish': 14, '"You are ill and overwrought," he said; "believe me, you\'re\nexaggerating dreadfully': 12, "There's nothing so terrible in it": 6, '"\n\nAnd Stepan Arkadyevitch smiled': 5, "No one else in Stepan Arkadyevitch's\nplace, having to do with such despair, would have ventured to smile\n(the smile would have seemed brutal); but in his smile there was so\nmuch of sweetness and almost feminine tenderness that his smile did not\nwound, but softened and soothed": 48, 'His gentle, soothing words and smiles\nwere as soothing and softening as almond oil': 14, 'And Anna soon felt this': 5, '"No, Stiva," she said, "I\'m lost, lost': 7, 'worse than lost': 3, "I can't say\nyet that all is over; on the contrary, I feel that it's not over": 17, "I'm\nan overstrained string that must snap": 7, "But it's not ended yet": 5, 'and\nit will have a fearful end': 7, '"\n\n"No matter, we must let the string be loosened, little by little': 13, "There's no position from which there is no way of escape": 11, '"\n\n"I have thought, and thought': 6, 'Only one': 2, '"\n\nAgain he knew from her terrified eyes that this one way of escape in\nher thought was death, and he would not let her say it': 27, '"Not at all," he said': 5, '"Listen to me': 3, "You can't see your own position\nas I can": 9, 'Let me tell you candidly my opinion': 7, '" Again he smiled\ndiscreetly his almond-oil smile': 8, '"I\'ll begin from the beginning': 5, 'You\nmarried a man twenty years older than yourself': 9, 'You married him without\nlove and not knowing what love was': 11, "It was a mistake, let's admit": 6, '"\n\n"A fearful mistake': 4, '" said Anna': 3, '"But I repeat, it\'s an accomplished fact': 7, 'Then you had, let us say, the\nmisfortune to love a man not your husband': 15, 'That was a misfortune; but\nthat, too, is an accomplished fact': 11, 'And your husband knew it and\nforgave it': 8, '" He stopped at each sentence, waiting for her to object,\nbut she made no answer': 16, '"That\'s so': 2, 'Now the question is: can you go on\nliving with your husband': 12, 'Do you wish it': 4, 'Does he wish it': 4, '"\n\n"I know nothing, nothing': 5, '"\n\n"But you said yourself that you can\'t endure him': 10, '"\n\n"No, I didn\'t say so': 6, 'I deny it': 3, "I can't tell, I don't know anything\nabout it": 9, '"\n\n"Yes, but let': 4, '"\n\n"You can\'t understand': 4, "I feel I'm lying head downwards in a sort of\npit, but I ought not to save myself": 18, "And I can't": 3, '"\n\n"Never mind, we\'ll slip something under and pull you out': 11, "I understand\nyou: I understand that you can't take it on yourself to express your\nwishes, your feelings": 18, '"\n\n"There\'s nothing, nothing I wish': 6, 'except for it to be all over': 7, '"\n\n"But he sees this and knows it': 8, 'And do you suppose it weighs on him any\nless than on you': 13, "You're wretched, he's wretched, and what good can\ncome of it": 11, 'while divorce would solve the difficulty completely': 7, '" With\nsome effort Stepan Arkadyevitch brought out his central idea, and\nlooked significantly at her': 16, 'She said nothing, and shook her cropped head in dissent': 10, 'But from the\nlook in her face, that suddenly brightened into its old beauty, he saw\nthat if she did not desire this, it was simply because it seemed to her\nunattainable happiness': 33, '"I\'m awfully sorry for you': 5, 'And how happy I should be if I could\narrange things': 11, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling more boldly': 7, '"Don\'t\nspeak, don\'t say a word': 6, 'God grant only that I may speak as I feel': 10, "I'm\ngoing to him": 4, '"\n\nAnna looked at him with dreamy, shining eyes, and said nothing': 12, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 22 PART FOUR', {"Stepan Arkadyevitch, with the same somewhat solemn expression with\nwhich he used to take his presidential chair at his board, walked into\nAlexey Alexandrovitch's room": 25, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch was walking about\nhis room with his hands behind his back, thinking of just what Stepan\nArkadyevitch had been discussing with his wife': 25, '"I\'m not interrupting you': 4, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, on the sight of\nhis brother-in-law becoming suddenly aware of a sense of embarrassment\nunusual with him': 21, 'To conceal this embarrassment he took out a cigarette\ncase he had just bought that opened in a new way, and sniffing the\nleather, took a cigarette out of it': 30, '"No': 1, 'Do you want anything': 4, '" Alexey Alexandrovitch asked without\neagerness': 6, '"Yes, I wished': 3, 'I wanted': 2, 'yes, I wanted to talk to you," said\nStepan Arkadyevitch, with surprise aware of an unaccustomed timidity': 17, 'This feeling was so unexpected and so strange that he did not believe\nit was the voice of conscience telling him that what he was meaning to\ndo was wrong': 30, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch made an effort and struggled with the timidity that\nhad come over him': 15, '"I hope you believe in my love for my sister and my sincere affection\nand respect for you," he said, reddening': 21, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch stood still and said nothing, but his face struck\nStepan Arkadyevitch by its expression of an unresisting sacrifice': 20, '"I intended': 2, 'I wanted to have a little talk with you about my sister\nand your mutual position," he said, still struggling with an\nunaccustomed constraint': 24, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch smiled mournfully, looked at his brother-in-law,\nand without answering went up to the table, took from it an unfinished\nletter, and handed it to his brother-in-law': 28, '"I think unceasingly of the same thing': 7, 'And here is what I had begun\nwriting, thinking I could say it better by letter, and that my presence\nirritates her," he said, as he gave him the letter': 30, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch took the letter, looked with incredulous surprise\nat the lusterless eyes fixed so immovably on him, and began to read': 22, '"I see that my presence is irksome to you': 9, 'Painful as it is to me to\nbelieve it, I see that it is so, and cannot be otherwise': 19, "I don't blame\nyou, and God is my witness that on seeing you at the time of your\nillness I resolved with my whole heart to forget all that had passed\nbetween us and to begin a new life": 39, 'I do not regret, and shall never\nregret, what I have done; but I have desired one thing—your good, the\ngood of your soul—and now I see I have not attained that': 32, 'Tell me\nyourself what will give you true happiness and peace to your soul': 14, "I\nput myself entirely in your hands, and trust to your feeling of what's\nright": 15, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch handed back the letter, and with the same surprise\ncontinued looking at his brother-in-law, not knowing what to say': 22, "This\nsilence was so awkward for both of them that Stepan Arkadyevitch's lips\nbegan twitching nervously, while he still gazed without speaking at\nKarenin's face": 25, '"That\'s what I wanted to say to her," said Alexey Alexandrovitch,\nturning away': 13, '"Yes, yes': 2, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch, not able to answer for the\ntears that were choking him': 15, '"Yes, yes, I understand you," he brought out at last': 10, '"I want to know what she would like," said Alexey Alexandrovitch': 11, '"I am afraid she does not understand her own position': 10, 'She is not a\njudge," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, recovering himself': 10, '"She is crushed,\nsimply crushed by your generosity': 8, 'If she were to read this letter, she\nwould be incapable of saying anything, she would only hang her head\nlower than ever': 23, '"\n\n"Yes, but what\'s to be done in that case': 10, 'how explain, how find out her\nwishes': 7, '"\n\n"If you will allow me to give my opinion, I think that it lies with you\nto point out directly the steps you consider necessary to end the\nposition': 30, '"\n\n"So you consider it must be ended': 8, '" Alexey Alexandrovitch interrupted\nhim': 5, '"But how': 2, '" he added, with a gesture of his hands before his eyes\nnot usual with him': 16, '"I see no possible way out of it': 8, '"\n\n"There is some way of getting out of every position," said Stepan\nArkadyevitch, standing up and becoming more cheerful': 20, '"There was a time\nwhen you thought of breaking off': 10, 'If you are convinced now that you\ncannot make each other happy': 12, '"\n\n"Happiness may be variously understood': 6, 'But suppose that I agree to\neverything, that I want nothing: what way is there of getting out of\nour position': 21, '"\n\n"If you care to know my opinion," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with the\nsame smile of softening, almond-oil tenderness with which he had been\ntalking to Anna': 27, 'His kindly smile was so winning that Alexey\nAlexandrovitch, feeling his own weakness and unconsciously swayed by\nit, was ready to believe what Stepan Arkadyevitch was saying': 27, '"She will never speak out about it': 7, 'But one thing is possible, one\nthing she might desire," he went on, "that is the cessation of your\nrelations and all memories associated with them': 26, "To my thinking, in\nyour position tone of aversion': 10, '"Yes, I imagine that divorce—yes, divorce," Stepan Arkadyevitch\nrepeated, reddening': 10, '"That is from every point of view the most\nrational course for married people who find themselves in the position\nyou are in': 23, 'What can be done if married people find that life is\nimpossible for them together': 15, 'That may always happen': 4, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch sighed heavily and closed his eyes': 9, '"There\'s only one point to be considered: is either of the parties\ndesirous of forming new ties': 17, 'If not, it is very simple," said Stepan\nArkadyevitch, feeling more and more free from constraint': 16, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch, scowling with emotion, muttered something to\nhimself, and made no answer': 13, 'All that seemed so simple to Stepan\nArkadyevitch, Alexey Alexandrovitch had thought over thousands of\ntimes': 16, 'And, so far from being simple, it all seemed to him utterly\nimpossible': 13, 'Divorce, the details of which he knew by this time, seemed\nto him now out of the question, because the sense of his own dignity\nand respect for religion forbade his taking upon himself a fictitious\ncharge of adultery, and still more suffering his wife, pardoned and\nbeloved by him, to be caught in the fact and put to public shame': 61, 'Divorce appeared to him impossible also on other still more weighty\ngrounds': 12, 'What would become of his son in case of a divorce': 11, 'To leave him with\nhis mother was out of the question': 11, 'The divorced mother would have her\nown illegitimate family, in which his position as a stepson and his\neducation would not be good': 23, 'Keep him with him': 4, 'He knew that would be\nan act of vengeance on his part, and that he did not want': 18, 'But apart\nfrom this, what more than all made divorce seem impossible to Alexey\nAlexandrovitch was, that by consenting to a divorce he would be\ncompletely ruining Anna': 28, 'The saying of Darya Alexandrovna at Moscow,\nthat in deciding on a divorce he was thinking of himself, and not\nconsidering that by this he would be ruining her irrevocably, had sunk\ninto his heart': 35, 'And connecting this saying with his forgiveness of her,\nwith his devotion to the children, he understood it now in his own way': 23, 'To consent to a divorce, to give her her freedom, meant in his thoughts\nto take from himself the last tie that bound him to life—the children\nwhom he loved; and to take from her the last prop that stayed her on\nthe path of right, to thrust her down to her ruin': 53, "If she were\ndivorced, he knew she would join her life to Vronsky's, and their tie\nwould be an illegitimate and criminal one, since a wife, by the\ninterpretation of the ecclesiastical law, could not marry while her\nhusband was living": 41, '"She will join him, and in a year or two he will\nthrow her over, or she will form a new tie," thought Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 25, '"And I, by agreeing to an unlawful divorce, shall be to\nblame for her ruin': 15, '" He had thought it all over hundreds of times, and\nwas convinced that a divorce was not at all simple, as Stepan\nArkadyevitch had said, but was utterly impossible': 30, 'He did not believe a\nsingle word Stepan Arkadyevitch said to him; to every word he had a\nthousand objections to make, but he listened to him, feeling that his\nwords were the expression of that mighty brutal force which controlled\nhis life and to which he would have to submit': 51, '"The only question is on what terms you agree to give her a divorce': 14, 'She does not want anything, does not dare ask you for anything, she\nleaves it all to your generosity': 19, '"\n\n"My God, my God': 5, 'what for': 2, '" thought Alexey Alexandrovitch, remembering\nthe details of divorce proceedings in which the husband took the blame\non himself, and with just the same gesture with which Vronsky had done\nthe same, he hid his face for shame in his hands': 41, '"You are distressed, I understand that': 6, 'But if you think it over': 6, '"\n\n"Whosoever shall smite thee on thy right cheek, turn to him the other\nalso; and if any man take away thy coat, let him have thy cloak also,"\nthought Alexey Alexandrovitch': 32, '" he cried in a shrill voice': 7, '"I will take the disgrace on\nmyself, I will give up even my son, but': 15, "but wouldn't it be better\nto let it alone": 9, 'Still you may do as you like': 7, '"\n\nAnd turning away so that his brother-in-law could not see him, he sat\ndown on a chair at the window': 21, 'There was bitterness, there was shame in\nhis heart, but with bitterness and shame he felt joy and emotion at the\nheight of his own meekness': 26, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch was touched': 4, 'He was silent for a space': 6, '"Alexey Alexandrovitch, believe me, she appreciates your generosity,"\nhe said': 10, '"But it seems it was the will of God," he added, and as he\nsaid it felt how foolish a remark it was, and with difficulty repressed\na smile at his own foolishness': 33, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch would have made some reply, but tears stopped\nhim': 11, '"This is an unhappy fatality, and one must accept it as such': 12, 'I accept\nthe calamity as an accomplished fact, and am doing my best to help both\nher and you," said Stepan Arkadyevitch': 22, "When he went out of his brother-in-law's room he was touched, but that\ndid not prevent him from being glad he had successfully brought the\nmatter to a conclusion, for he felt certain Alexey Alexandrovitch would\nnot go back on his words": 42, 'To this satisfaction was added the fact that\nan idea had just struck him for a riddle turning on his successful\nachievement, that when the affair was over he would ask his wife and\nmost intimate friends': 37, 'He put this riddle into two or three different\nways': 10, '"But I\'ll work it out better than that," he said to himself with\na smile': 15, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 23 PART FOUR', {"Vronsky's wound had been a dangerous one, though it did not touch the\nheart, and for several days he had lain between life and death": 25, "The\nfirst time he was able to speak, Varya, his brother's wife, was alone\nin the room": 17, '"Varya," he said, looking sternly at her, "I shot myself by accident': 12, 'And please never speak of it, and tell everyone so': 10, "Or else it's too\nridiculous": 5, '"\n\nWithout answering his words, Varya bent over him, and with a delighted\nsmile gazed into his face': 18, 'His eyes were clear, not feverish; but their\nexpression was stern': 11, '"Thank God': 2, '" she said': 3, '"You\'re not in pain': 4, '"\n\n"A little here': 4, '" He pointed to his breast': 6, '"Then let me change your bandages': 6, '"\n\nIn silence, stiffening his broad jaws, he looked at her while she\nbandaged him up': 16, 'When she had finished he said:\n\n"I\'m not delirious': 9, 'Please manage that there may be no talk of my\nhaving shot myself on purpose': 15, '"\n\n"No one does say so': 6, 'Only I hope you won\'t shoot yourself by accident\nany more," she said, with a questioning smile': 17, '"Of course I won\'t, but it would have been better': 10, '"\n\nAnd he smiled gloomily': 5, 'In spite of these words and this smile, which so frightened Varya, when\nthe inflammation was over and he began to recover, he felt that he was\ncompletely free from one part of his misery': 35, 'By his action he had, as\nit were, washed away the shame and humiliation he had felt before': 18, 'He\ncould now think calmly of Alexey Alexandrovitch': 8, 'He recognized all his\nmagnanimity, but he did not now feel himself humiliated by it': 15, 'Besides,\nhe got back again into the beaten track of his life': 12, 'He saw the\npossibility of looking men in the face again without shame, and he\ncould live in accordance with his own habits': 23, 'One thing he could not\npluck out of his heart, though he never ceased struggling with it, was\nthe regret, amounting to despair, that he had lost her forever': 29, 'That\nnow, having expiated his sin against the husband, he was bound to\nrenounce her, and never in future to stand between her with her\nrepentance and her husband, he had firmly decided in his heart; but he\ncould not tear out of his heart his regret at the loss of her love, he\ncould not erase from his memory those moments of happiness that he had\nso little prized at the time, and that haunted him in all their charm': 81, 'Serpuhovskoy had planned his appointment at Tashkend, and Vronsky\nagreed to the proposition without the slightest hesitation': 17, 'But the\nnearer the time of departure came, the bitterer was the sacrifice he\nwas making to what he thought his duty': 22, 'His wound had healed, and he was driving about making preparations for\nhis departure for Tashkend': 16, '"To see her once and then to bury myself, to die," he thought, and as\nhe was paying farewell visits, he uttered this thought to Betsy': 26, 'Charged with this commission, Betsy had gone to Anna, and brought him\nback a negative reply': 16, '"So much the better," thought Vronsky, when he received the news': 11, '"It\nwas a weakness, which would have shattered what strength I have left': 13, '"\n\nNext day Betsy herself came to him in the morning, and announced that\nshe had heard through Oblonsky as a positive fact that Alexey\nAlexandrovitch had agreed to a divorce, and that therefore Vronsky\ncould see Anna': 38, "Without even troubling himself to see Betsy out of his flat, forgetting\nall his resolutions, without asking when he could see her, where her\nhusband was, Vronsky drove straight to the Karenins'": 32, 'He ran up the\nstairs seeing no one and nothing, and with a rapid step, almost\nbreaking into a run, he went into her room': 25, 'And without considering,\nwithout noticing whether there was anyone in the room or not, he flung\nhis arms round her, and began to cover her face, her hands, her neck\nwith kisses': 32, 'Anna had been preparing herself for this meeting, had thought what she\nwould say to him, but she did not succeed in saying anything of it; his\npassion mastered her': 30, 'She tried to calm him, to calm herself, but it\nwas too late': 13, 'His feeling infected her': 4, 'Her lips trembled so that for a\nlong while she could say nothing': 13, '"Yes, you have conquered me, and I am yours," she said at last,\npressing his hands to her bosom': 19, '"So it had to be," he said': 7, '"So long as we live, it must be so': 9, 'I know\nit now': 4, '"\n\n"That\'s true," she said, getting whiter and whiter, and embracing his\nhead': 13, '"Still there is something terrible in it after all that has\nhappened': 12, '"\n\n"It will all pass, it will all pass; we shall be so happy': 14, 'Our love, if\nit could be stronger, will be strengthened by there being something\nterrible in it," he said, lifting his head and parting his strong teeth\nin a smile': 30, 'And she could not but respond with a smile—not to his words, but to the\nlove in his eyes': 19, 'She took his hand and stroked her chilled cheeks and\ncropped head with it': 14, '"I don\'t know you with this short hair': 8, "You've grown so pretty": 4, 'A boy': 2, 'But how pale you are': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, I\'m very weak," she said, smiling': 8, 'And her lips began trembling\nagain': 6, '"We\'ll go to Italy; you will get strong," he said': 10, '"Can it be possible we could be like husband and wife, alone, your\nfamily with you': 16, '" she said, looking close into his eyes': 8, '"It only seems strange to me that it can ever have been otherwise': 13, '"\n\n"Stiva says that _he_ has agreed to everything, but I can\'t accept\n_his_ generosity," she said, looking dreamily past Vronsky\'s face': 22, '"I\ndon\'t want a divorce; it\'s all the same to me now': 12, "Only I don't know\nwhat he will decide about Seryozha": 10, '"\n\nHe could not conceive how at this moment of their meeting she could\nremember and think of her son, of divorce': 22, 'What did it all matter': 5, '"Don\'t speak of that, don\'t think of it," he said, turning her hand in\nhis, and trying to draw her attention to him; but still she did not\nlook at him': 31, '"Oh, why didn\'t I die': 5, 'it would have been better," she said, and silent\ntears flowed down both her cheeks; but she tried to smile, so as not to\nwound him': 26, 'To decline the flattering and dangerous appointment at Tashkend would\nhave been, Vronsky had till then considered, disgraceful and\nimpossible': 20, "But now, without an instant's consideration, he declined\nit, and observing dissatisfaction in the most exalted quarters at this\nstep, he immediately retired from the army": 26, 'A month later Alexey Alexandrovitch was left alone with his son in his\nhouse at Petersburg, while Anna and Vronsky had gone abroad, not having\nobtained a divorce, but having absolutely declined all idea of one': 36, 'PART FIVE': 2})
('TOL CHAPTER 1 PART FIVE', {'Princess Shtcherbatskaya considered that it was out of the question for\nthe wedding to take place before Lent, just five weeks off, since not\nhalf the trousseau could possibly be ready by that time': 34, "But she could\nnot but agree with Levin that to fix it for after Lent would be putting\nit off too late, as an old aunt of Prince Shtcherbatsky's was seriously\nill and might die, and then the mourning would delay the wedding still\nlonger": 45, 'And therefore, deciding to divide the trousseau into two\nparts—a larger and smaller trousseau—the princess consented to have the\nwedding before Lent': 22, 'She determined that she would get the smaller part\nof the trousseau all ready now, and the larger part should be made\nlater, and she was much vexed with Levin because he was incapable of\ngiving her a serious answer to the question whether he agreed to this\narrangement or not': 51, 'The arrangement was the more suitable as,\nimmediately after the wedding, the young people were to go to the\ncountry, where the more important part of the trousseau would not be\nwanted': 32, 'Levin still continued in the same delirious condition in which it\nseemed to him that he and his happiness constituted the chief and sole\naim of all existence, and that he need not now think or care about\nanything, that everything was being done and would be done for him by\nothers': 52, 'He had not even plans and aims for the future, he left its\narrangement to others, knowing that everything would be delightful': 22, 'His\nbrother Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch, and the princess guided\nhim in doing what he had to do': 18, 'All he did was to agree entirely with\neverything suggested to him': 12, 'His brother raised money for him, the\nprincess advised him to leave Moscow after the wedding': 16, 'Stepan\nArkadyevitch advised him to go abroad': 7, 'He agreed to everything': 4, '"Do\nwhat you choose, if it amuses you': 8, 'I\'m happy, and my happiness can be\nno greater and no less for anything you do," he thought': 18, "When he told\nKitty of Stepan Arkadyevitch's advice that they should go abroad, he\nwas much surprised that she did not agree to this, and had some\ndefinite requirements of her own in regard to their future": 37, 'She knew\nLevin had work he loved in the country': 10, 'She did not, as he saw,\nunderstand this work, she did not even care to understand it': 17, 'But that\ndid not prevent her from regarding it as a matter of great importance': 15, 'And then she knew their home would be in the country, and she wanted to\ngo, not abroad where she was not going to live, but to the place where\ntheir home would be': 34, 'This definitely expressed purpose astonished\nLevin': 6, 'But since he did not care either way, he immediately asked\nStepan Arkadyevitch, as though it were his duty, to go down to the\ncountry and to arrange everything there to the best of his ability with\nthe taste of which he had so much': 45, '"But I say," Stepan Arkadyevitch said to him one day after he had come\nback from the country, where he had got everything ready for the young\npeople\'s arrival, "have you a certificate of having been at\nconfession': 38, '"\n\n"No': 2, 'But what of it': 4, '"\n\n"You can\'t be married without it': 7, '"\n\n"_Aïe, aïe, aïe': 4, '_" cried Levin': 3, '"Why, I believe it\'s nine years since\nI\'ve taken the sacrament': 11, 'I never thought of it': 5, '"\n\n"You\'re a pretty fellow': 5, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch laughing, "and you\ncall me a Nihilist': 11, "But this won't do, you know": 6, 'You must take the\nsacrament': 5, '"\n\n"When': 2, 'There are four days left now': 6, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch arranged this also, and Levin had to go to\nconfession': 13, 'To Levin, as to any unbeliever who respects the beliefs of\nothers, it was exceedingly disagreeable to be present at and take part\nin church ceremonies': 26, 'At this moment, in his present softened state of\nfeeling, sensitive to everything, this inevitable act of hypocrisy was\nnot merely painful to Levin, it seemed to him utterly impossible': 30, 'Now,\nin the heyday of his highest glory, his fullest flower, he would have\nto be a liar or a scoffer': 21, 'He felt incapable of being either': 6, 'But\nthough he repeatedly plied Stepan Arkadyevitch with questions as to the\npossibility of obtaining a certificate without actually communicating,\nStepan Arkadyevitch maintained that it was out of the question': 30, '"Besides, what is it to you—two days': 7, "And he's an awfully nice clever\nold fellow": 8, "He'll pull the tooth out for you so gently, you won't\nnotice it": 13, '"\n\nStanding at the first litany, Levin attempted to revive in himself his\nyouthful recollections of the intense religious emotion he had passed\nthrough between the ages of sixteen and seventeen': 31, 'But he was at once convinced that it was utterly impossible to him': 13, 'He\nattempted to look at it all as an empty custom, having no sort of\nmeaning, like the custom of paying calls': 22, 'But he felt that he could not\ndo that either': 10, 'Levin found himself, like the majority of his\ncontemporaries, in the vaguest position in regard to religion': 17, 'Believe\nhe could not, and at the same time he had no firm conviction that it\nwas all wrong': 19, 'And consequently, not being able to believe in the\nsignificance of what he was doing nor to regard it with indifference as\nan empty formality, during the whole period of preparing for the\nsacrament he was conscious of a feeling of discomfort and shame at\ndoing what he did not himself understand, and what, as an inner voice\ntold him, was therefore false and wrong': 65, 'During the service he would first listen to the prayers, trying to\nattach some meaning to them not discordant with his own views; then\nfeeling that he could not understand and must condemn them, he tried\nnot to listen to them, but to attend to the thoughts, observations, and\nmemories which floated through his brain with extreme vividness during\nthis idle time of standing in church': 66, "He had stood through the litany, the evening service and the midnight\nservice, and the next day he got up earlier than usual, and without\nhaving tea went at eight o'clock in the morning to the church for the\nmorning service and the confession": 44, 'There was no one in the church but a beggar soldier, two old women, and\nthe church officials': 18, 'A young deacon, whose long back showed in two\ndistinct halves through his thin undercassock, met him, and at once\ngoing to a little table at the wall read the exhortation': 31, 'During the\nreading, especially at the frequent and rapid repetition of the same\nwords, "Lord, have mercy on us': 19, '" which resounded with an echo, Levin\nfelt that thought was shut and sealed up, and that it must not be\ntouched or stirred now or confusion would be the result; and so\nstanding behind the deacon he went on thinking of his own affairs,\nneither listening nor examining what was said': 52, '"It\'s wonderful what\nexpression there is in her hand," he thought, remembering how they had\nbeen sitting the day before at a corner table': 24, 'They had nothing to talk\nabout, as was almost always the case at this time, and laying her hand\non the table she kept opening and shutting it, and laughed herself as\nshe watched her action': 36, 'He remembered how he had kissed it and then had\nexamined the lines on the pink palm': 17, '"Have mercy on us again': 5, '" thought\nLevin, crossing himself, bowing, and looking at the supple spring of\nthe deacon\'s back bowing before him': 19, '"She took my hand then and\nexamined the lines': 9, "‘You've got a splendid hand,' she said": 7, '" And he\nlooked at his own hand and the short hand of the deacon': 15, '"Yes, now it\nwill soon be over," he thought': 9, '"No, it seems to be beginning again,"\nhe thought, listening to the prayers': 13, '"No, it\'s just ending: there he\nis bowing down to the ground': 12, "That's always at the end": 5, '"\n\nThe deacon\'s hand in a plush cuff accepted a three-rouble note\nunobtrusively, and the deacon said he would put it down in the\nregister, and his new boots creaking jauntily over the flagstones of\nthe empty church, he went to the altar': 43, 'A moment later he peeped out\nthence and beckoned to Levin': 11, "Thought, till then locked up, began to\nstir in Levin's head, but he made haste to drive it away": 19, '"It will come\nright somehow," he thought, and went towards the altar-rails': 12, 'He went\nup the steps, and turning to the right saw the priest': 13, 'The priest, a\nlittle old man with a scanty grizzled beard and weary, good-natured\neyes, was standing at the altar-rails, turning over the pages of a\nmissal': 27, 'With a slight bow to Levin he began immediately reading prayers\nin the official voice': 15, 'When he had finished them he bowed down to the\nground and turned, facing Levin': 15, '"Christ is present here unseen, receiving your confession," he said,\npointing to the crucifix': 14, '"Do you believe in all the doctrines of the\nHoly Apostolic Church': 12, '" the priest went on, turning his eyes away from\nLevin\'s face and folding his hands under his stole': 19, '"I have doubted, I doubt everything," said Levin in a voice that jarred\non himself, and he ceased speaking': 19, 'The priest waited a few seconds to see if he would not say more, and\nclosing his eyes he said quickly, with a broad, Vladimirsky accent:\n\n"Doubt is natural to the weakness of mankind, but we must pray that God\nin His mercy will strengthen us': 46, 'What are your special sins': 5, '" he added,\nwithout the slightest interval, as though anxious not to waste time': 14, '"My chief sin is doubt': 5, 'I have doubts of everything, and for the most\npart I am in doubt': 14, '"\n\n"Doubt is natural to the weakness of mankind," the priest repeated the\nsame words': 15, '"What do you doubt about principally': 6, '"\n\n"I doubt of everything': 5, 'I sometimes even have doubts of the existence\nof God," Levin could not help saying, and he was horrified at the\nimpropriety of what he was saying': 27, "But Levin's words did not, it\nseemed, make much impression on the priest": 13, '"What sort of doubt can there be of the existence of God': 12, '" he said\nhurriedly, with a just perceptible smile': 9, 'Levin did not speak': 4, '"What doubt can you have of the Creator when you behold His creation': 13, '"\nthe priest went on in the rapid customary jargon': 10, '"Who has decked the\nheavenly firmament with its lights': 9, 'Who has clothed the earth in its\nbeauty': 8, 'How explain it without the Creator': 6, '" he said, looking\ninquiringly at Levin': 7, 'Levin felt that it would be improper to enter upon a metaphysical\ndiscussion with the priest, and so he said in reply merely what was a\ndirect answer to the question': 31, '"I don\'t know," he said': 5, '"You don\'t know': 3, 'Then how can you doubt that God created all': 9, '" the\npriest said, with good-humored perplexity': 7, '"I don\'t understand it at all," said Levin, blushing, and feeling that\nhis words were stupid, and that they could not be anything but stupid\nin such a position': 29, '"Pray to God and beseech Him': 6, 'Even the holy fathers had doubts, and\nprayed to God to strengthen their faith': 14, 'The devil has great power, and\nwe must resist him': 10, 'Pray to God, beseech Him': 5, 'Pray to God," he repeated\nhurriedly': 6, 'The priest paused for some time, as though meditating': 9, '"You\'re about, I hear, to marry the daughter of my parishioner and son\nin the spirit, Prince Shtcherbatsky': 18, '" he resumed, with a smile': 6, '"An\nexcellent young lady': 4, '"\n\n"Yes," answered Levin, blushing for the priest': 8, '"What does he want to\nask me about this at confession for': 12, '" he thought': 3, 'And, as though answering his thought, the priest said to him:\n\n"You are about to enter into holy matrimony, and God may bless you with\noffspring': 26, 'Well, what sort of bringing-up can you give your babes if\nyou do not overcome the temptation of the devil, enticing you to\ninfidelity': 24, '" he said, with gentle reproachfulness': 6, '"If you love your\nchild as a good father, you will not desire only wealth, luxury, honor\nfor your infant; you will be anxious for his salvation, his spiritual\nenlightenment with the light of truth': 35, 'Eh': 1, 'What answer will you make\nhim when the innocent babe asks you: ‘Papa': 13, 'who made all that enchants\nme in this world—the earth, the waters, the sun, the flowers, the\ngrass': 18, "' Can you say to him: ‘I don't know'": 9, 'You cannot but know, since\nthe Lord God in His infinite mercy has revealed it to us': 17, 'Or your child\nwill ask you: ‘What awaits me in the life beyond the tomb': 15, "' What will\nyou say to him when you know nothing": 11, 'How will you answer him': 5, 'Will you\nleave him to the allurements of the world and the devil': 13, 'That\'s not\nright," he said, and he stopped, putting his head on one side and\nlooking at Levin with his kindly, gentle eyes': 23, 'Levin made no answer this time, not because he did not want to enter\nupon a discussion with the priest, but because, so far, no one had ever\nasked him such questions, and when his babes did ask him those\nquestions, it would be time enough to think about answering them': 51, '"You are entering upon a time of life," pursued the priest, "when you\nmust choose your path and keep to it': 21, 'Pray to God that He may in His\nmercy aid you and have mercy on you': 16, '" he concluded': 3, '"Our Lord and God,\nJesus Christ, in the abundance and riches of His loving-kindness,\nforgives this child': 17, '" and, finishing the prayer of absolution, the\npriest blessed him and dismissed him': 14, 'On getting home that day, Levin had a delightful sense of relief at the\nawkward position being over and having been got through without his\nhaving to tell a lie': 30, 'Apart from this, there remained a vague memory\nthat what the kind, nice old fellow had said had not been at all so\nstupid as he had fancied at first, and that there was something in it\nthat must be cleared up': 42, '"Of course, not now," thought Levin, "but some day later on': 11, '" Levin\nfelt more than ever now that there was something not clear and not\nclean in his soul, and that, in regard to religion, he was in the same\nposition which he perceived so clearly and disliked in others, and for\nwhich he blamed his friend Sviazhsky': 48, "Levin spent that evening with his betrothed at Dolly's, and was in very\nhigh spirits": 15, 'To explain to Stepan Arkadyevitch the state of excitement\nin which he found himself, he said that he was happy like a dog being\ntrained to jump through a hoop, who, having at last caught the idea,\nand done what was required of him, whines and wags its tail, and jumps\nup to the table and the windows in its delight': 61, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART FIVE', {'On the day of the wedding, according to the Russian custom (the\nprincess and Darya Alexandrovna insisted on strictly keeping all the\ncustoms), Levin did not see his betrothed, and dined at his hotel with\nthree bachelor friends, casually brought together at his rooms': 44, "These\nwere Sergey Ivanovitch, Katavasov, a university friend, now professor\nof natural science, whom Levin had met in the street and insisted on\ntaking home with him, and Tchirikov, his best man, a Moscow\nconciliation-board judge, Levin's companion in his bear-hunts": 41, "The\ndinner was a very merry one: Sergey Ivanovitch was in his happiest\nmood, and was much amused by Katavasov's originality": 21, 'Katavasov,\nfeeling his originality was appreciated and understood, made the most\nof it': 13, 'Tchirikov always gave a lively and good-humored support to\nconversation of any sort': 13, '"See, now," said Katavasov, drawling his words from a habit acquired in\nthe lecture-room, "what a capable fellow was our friend Konstantin\nDmitrievitch': 23, "I'm not speaking of present company, for he's absent": 9, 'At\nthe time he left the university he was fond of science, took an\ninterest in humanity; now one-half of his abilities is devoted to\ndeceiving himself, and the other to justifying the deceit': 34, '"\n\n"A more determined enemy of matrimony than you I never saw," said\nSergey Ivanovitch': 15, '"Oh, no, I\'m not an enemy of matrimony': 8, "I'm in favor of division of\nlabor": 7, 'People who can do nothing else ought to rear people while the\nrest work for their happiness and enlightenment': 19, "That's how I look at\nit": 6, "To muddle up two trades is the error of the amateur; I'm not one of\ntheir number": 17, '"\n\n"How happy I shall be when I hear that you\'re in love': 13, '" said Levin': 3, '"Please invite me to the wedding': 6, '"\n\n"I\'m in love now': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, with a cuttlefish': 5, 'You know," Levin turned to his brother,\n"Mihail Semyonovitch is writing a work on the digestive organs of\nthe': 19, '"\n\n"Now, make a muddle of it': 7, "It doesn't matter what about": 5, 'And the fact\nis, I certainly do you may be, you must\nregret your freedom': 10, '"\n\n"And confess there is a feeling that you want to jump out of the\nwindow, like Gogol\'s bridegroom': 19, '"\n\n"Of course there is, but it isn\'t confessed," said Katavasov, and he\nbroke into loud laughter': 17, '"Oh, well, the window\'s open': 5, "Let's start off this instant to Tver": 7, "There's a big she-bear; one can go right up to the my\nheart that feeling of regret for my freedom': 21, '"\n\n"Yes, there\'s such a chaos in your heart just now that you can\'t find\nanything there," said Katavasov': 19, '"Wait a bit, when you set it to rights\na little, you\'ll find it': 14, '"\n\n"No; if so, I should have felt a little, apart from my feeling" (he\ncould not say love before them) "and happiness, a certain regret at\nlosing my a hundredth part of his dreams may be\nrealized—and that would be happiness such as never has been seen on\nearth': 30, '"\n\nSoon after dinner the guests went away to be in time to be dressed spoken': 31, 'He smiled at the question': 5, '"Freedom': 1, 'What is freedom for': 4, "Happiness is only in loving and wishing her\nwishes, thinking her thoughts, that is to say, not freedom at\nall—that's happiness": 21, '"\n\n"But do I know her ideas, her wishes, her feelings': 11, '" some voice\nsuddenly whispered to him': 7, 'The smile died away from his face, and he\ngrew ('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART FIVE', {'A crowd of people, principally women, was thronging round the church\nlighted up for the wedding': 16, 'Those who had not succeeded in getting into\nthe main entrance were crowding about the windows, pushing, wrangling,\nand peeping through the gratings': 23, 'More than twenty carriages had already been drawn up in ranks along the\nstreet by the police': 17, 'A police officer, regardless of the frost, stood\nat the entrance, gorgeous in his uniform': 15, 'More carriages were\ncontinually driving up, and ladies wearing flowers and carrying their\ntrains, and men taking off their helmets or black hats kept walking\ninto the church': 28, 'Inside the church both lusters were already lighted,\nand all the candles before the holy pictures': 16, 'The gilt on the red\nground of the holy picture-stand, and the gilt relief on the pictures,\nand the silver of the lusters and candlesticks, and the stones of the\nfloor, and the rugs, and the banners above in the choir, and the steps\nof the altar, and the old blackened books, and the cassocks and\nsurplices—all were flooded with light': 61, 'On the right side of the warm\nchurch, in the crowd of frock coats and white ties, uniforms and\nbroadcloth, velvet, satin, hair and flowers, bare shoulders and arms\nand long gloves, there was discreet but lively conversation that echoed\nstrangely in the high cupola': 45, 'Every time there was heard the creak of\nthe opened door the conversation in the crowd died away, and everybody\nlooked round expecting to see the bride and bridegroom come in': 31, 'But the\ndoor had opened more than ten times, and each time it was either a\nbelated guest or guests, who joined the circle of the invited on the\nright, or a spectator, who had eluded or softened the police officer,\nand went to join the crowd of outsiders on the left': 52, 'Both the guests\nand the outside public had by now passed through all the phases of\nanticipation': 17, 'At first they imagined that the bride and bridegroom would arrive\nimmediately, and attached no importance at all to their being late': 22, 'Then they began to look more and more often towards the door, and to\ntalk of whether anything could have happened': 21, 'Then the long delay began\nto be positively discomforting, and relations and guests tried to look\nas if they were not thinking of the bridegroom but were engrossed in\nconversation': 30, 'The head deacon, as though to remind them of the value of his time,\ncoughed impatiently, making the window-panes quiver in their frames': 23, 'In\nthe choir the bored choristers could be heard trying their voices and\nblowing their noses': 16, 'The priest was continually sending first the\nbeadle and then the deacon to find out whether the bridegroom had not\ncome, more and more often he went himself, in a lilac vestment and an\nembroidered sash, to the side door, expecting to see the bridegroom': 45, 'At\nlast one of the ladies, glancing at her watch, said, "It really is\nstrange, though': 16, '" and all the guests became uneasy and began loudly\nexpressing their wonder and dissatisfaction': 15, "One of the bridegroom's\nbest men went to find out what had happened": 13, "Kitty meanwhile had long\nago been quite ready, and in her white dress and long veil and wreath\nof orange blossoms she was standing in the drawing-room of the\nShtcherbatskys' house with her sister, Madame Lvova, who was her\nbridal-mother": 40, 'She was looking out of the window, and had been for over\nhalf an hour anxiously expecting to hear from the best man that her\nbridegroom was at the church': 30, 'Levin meanwhile, in his trousers, but without his coat and waistcoat,\nwas walking to and fro in his room at the hotel, continually putting\nhis head out of the door and looking up and down the corridor': 37, 'But in\nthe corridor there was no sign of the person he was looking for and he\ncame back in despair, and frantically waving his hands addressed Stepan\nArkadyevitch, who was smoking serenely': 33, '"Was ever a man in such a fearful fool\'s position': 10, '" he said': 3, '"Yes, it is stupid," Stepan Arkadyevitch assented, smiling soothingly': 9, '"But don\'t worry, it\'ll be brought directly': 7, '"\n\n"No, what is to be done': 7, '" said Levin, with smothered fury': 6, '"And these\nfools of open waistcoats': 6, 'Out of the question': 4, '" he said, looking at the\ncrumpled front of his shirt': 11, '"And what if the things have been taken on\nto the railway station': 13, '" he roared in desperation': 5, '"Then you must put on mine': 6, '"\n\n"I ought to have done so long ago, if at all': 12, '"\n\n"It\'s not nice to look ridiculous': 7, 'Wait a bit': 3, 'it will _come\nround_': 4, '"\n\nThe point was a shirt on," Kouzma answered, with a placid smile': 11, "Kouzma had not thought of leaving out a clean shirt, and on receiving\ninstructions to pack up everything and send it round to the\nShtcherbatskys' house, from which the young people were to set out the\nsame evening, he had done so, packing everything but the dress suit": 48, 'The shirt worn since the morning was crumpled and out of the question\nwith the fashionable open waistcoat': 18, "It was a long way to send to the\nShtcherbatskys'": 10, 'They sent out to buy a shirt': 7, 'The servant came back;\neverything was shut up—it was Sunday': 10, "They sent to Stepan\nArkadyevitch's and brought a shirt—it was impossibly wide and short": 14, "They sent finally to the Shtcherbatskys' to unpack the things": 10, 'The\nbridegroom was expected at the church while he was pacing up and down\nhis room like a wild beast in a cage, peeping out into the corridor,\nand with horror and despair recalling what absurd things he had said to\nKitty and what she might be thinking now': 49, 'At last the guilty Kouzma flew panting into the room with the shirt': 13, '"Only just in time': 4, 'They were just lifting it into the van," said\nKouzma': 10, 'Three minutes later Levin ran full speed into the corridor, not looking\nat his watch for fear of aggravating his sufferings': 21, '"You won\'t help matters like ('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART FIVE', {'"They\'ve come': 2, '" "Here he is': 4, '" "Which one': 3, '" "Rather young, eh': 4, '" "Why, my\ndear soul, she looks more dead than alive': 11, '" were the comments in wedding day as usual; but Levin did not think\nso': 28, 'He looked at her hair done up high, with the long white veil and\nwhite flowers and the high, stand-up, scalloped collar, that in such a\nmaidenly fashion hid her long neck at the sides and only showed it in\nfront, her strikingly slender figure, and it seemed to him that she\nlooked better than ever—not because these flowers, this veil, this gown\nfrom Paris added anything to her beauty; but because, in spite of the\nelaborate sumptuousness of her attire, the expression of her sweet\nface, of her eyes, of her lips was still her little hand in the long\nglove shook as it held the candle': 25, 'All the fuss of the shirt, of being late, all the talk of friends and\nrelations, their annoyance, his ludicrous position—all suddenly 23, 'But this was a\nmistake; she almost completely missed the meaning of the words of the\nservice; she had not heard them, in fact': 24, 'She could not listen to them\nand take them in, so strong was the one feeling that filled her breast\nand grew stronger and stronger': 25, 'That feeling was joy at the completion\nof the process that for the last month and a half had been going on in\nher soul, and had during those six weeks been a joy and a torture to\nher': 39, 'On the day when in the drawing-room of the house in Arbaty Street\nshe had gone up to him in her brown dress, and given herself to him\nwithout a word—on that day, at that hour, there took place in her heart\na complete severance from all her old life, and a quite different, new,\nutterly strange life had begun for her, while the old life was actually\ngoing on as before': 72, 'Those six weeks had for her been a time of the\nutmost bliss and the utmost misery': 17, 'All her life, all her desires and\nhopes were concentrated on this one man, still uncomprehended by her,\nto whom she was bound by a feeling of alternate attraction and\nrepulsion, even less comprehended than the man himself, and all the\nwhile she was going on living in the outward conditions of her old\nlife': 55, 'Living the old life, she was horrified at herself, at her utter\ninsurmountable callousness to all her own past, to things, to habits,\nto the people she had loved, who loved her—to her mother, who was\nwounded by her indifference, to her kind, tender father, till then\ndearer than all the world': 52, 'At one moment she was horrified at this\nindifference, at another she rejoiced at what had brought her to this\nindifference': 21, 'She could not frame a thought, not a wish apart from life\nwith this man; but this new life was not yet, and she could not even\npicture it clearly to herself': 32, 'There was only anticipation, the dread\nand joy of the new and the unknown': 14, 'And now behold—anticipation and\nuncertainty and remorse at the abandonment of the old life—all was\nending, and the new was beginning': 21, 'This new life could not but have\nterrors for her inexperience; but, terrible or not, the change had been\nwrought six weeks before in her soul, and this was merely the final\nsanction of what had long been completed in her heart': 42, "Turning again to the lectern, the priest with ('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART FIVE', {'In the church there was all Moscow, all the friends and relations; and\nduring the ceremony of plighting troth, in the brilliantly lighted\nchurch, there was an incessant ('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART FIVE', {'When the ceremony of plighting troth was over, the beadle spread before\nthe lectern in the middle of the church a piece of pink silken stuff,\nthe choir sang a complicated and elaborate psalm, in which the bass and\ntenor sang responses to one another, and the priest turning round\npointed the bridal pair to the pink silk rug': 59, 'Though both had often\nheard a great deal about the saying that the one who steps first on the\nrug will be the head of the house, neither Levin nor Kitty were capable\nof recollecting it, as they took the few steps towards it': 44, 'They did not\nhear the loud remarks and disputes that followed, some maintaining he\nhad stepped on first, and others that both had stepped on together': 26, 'After the customary questions, whether they desired to enter upon\nmatrimony, and whether they were pledged to anyone else, and their\nanswers, which sounded strange to themselves, a new ceremony began': 31, 'Kitty listened to the words of the prayer, trying to make out their\nmeaning, but she could not': 18, 'The feeling of triumph and radiant\nhappiness flooded her soul more and more as the ceremony went on, and\ndeprived her of all power of attention': 26, 'They prayed: "Endow them with continence and fruitfulness, and\nvouchsafe that their hearts may rejoice looking upon their sons and\ndaughters': 21, '" They alluded to God\'s creation of a wife from Adam\'s rib\n"and for this cause a man shall leave father and mother, and cleave\nunto his wife, and they two shall be one flesh," and that "this is a\ngreat mystery"; they prayed that God would make them fruitful and bless\nthem, like Isaac and Rebecca, Joseph, Moses and Zipporah, and that they\nmight look upon their children\'s children': 70, '"That\'s all splendid,"\nthought Kitty, catching the words, "all that\'s just as it should be,"\nand a smile of happiness, unconsciously reflected in everyone who\nlooked at her, beamed on her radiant face': 33, '"Put it on quite," voices were heard urging when the priest had put on\nthe wedding crowns and Shtcherbatsky, his hand shaking in its\nthree-button glove, held the crown high above her head': 33, '"Put it on': 3, '" she whispered, smiling': 4, 'Levin looked round at her, and was struck by the joyful radiance on her\nface, and unconsciously her feeling infected him': 21, 'He too, like her felt\nglad and happy': 8, "They enjoyed hearing the epistle read, and the roll of the head\ndeacon's voice at the last verse, awaited with such impatience by the\noutside public": 26, 'They enjoyed drinking out of the shallow cup of warm\nred wine and water, and they were still more pleased when the priest,\nflinging back his stole and taking both their hands in his, led them\nround the lectern to the accompaniment of bass voices chanting "Glory\nto God': 49, '"\n\nShtcherbatsky and Tchirikov, supporting the crowns and stumbling over\nthe bride\'s train, smiling too and seeming delighted at something, were\nat one moment left behind, at the next treading on the bridal pair as\nthe priest came to a halt': 41, 'The spark of joy kindled in Kitty seemed to\nhave infected everyone in the church': 15, 'It seemed to Levin that the\npriest and the deacon too wanted to smile just as he did': 18, 'Taking the crowns off their heads the priest read the last prayer and\ncongratulated the young people': 17, 'Levin looked at Kitty, and he had never\nbefore seen her look as she did': 15, 'She was charming with the new radiance\nof happiness in her face': 12, 'Levin longed to say something to her, but he\ndid not know whether it was all over': 17, 'The priest got him out of his\ndifficulty': 8, 'He smiled his kindly smile and said gently, "Kiss your\nwife, and you kiss your husband," and took the candles out of their\nhands': 24, 'Levin kissed her smiling lips with timid care, gave her his arm, and\nwith a new strange sense of closeness, walked out of the church': 25, 'He did\nnot believe, he could not believe, that it was true': 12, 'It was only when\ntheir wondering and timid eyes met that he believed in it, because he\nfelt that they were one': 22, 'After supper, the same night, the young people left for the country': 12, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART FIVE', {'Vronsky and Anna had been traveling for three months together in\nEurope': 12, 'They had visited Venice, Rome, and Naples, and had just arrived\nat a small Italian town where they meant to stay some time': 23, 'A handsome\nhead waiter, with thick pomaded hair parted from the neck upwards, an\nevening coat, a broad white cambric shirt front, and a bunch of\ntrinkets hanging above his rounded stomach, stood with his hands in the\nfull curve of his pockets, looking contemptuously from under his\neyelids while he gave some frigid reply to a gentleman who had stopped\nhim': 62, 'Catching the sound of footsteps coming from the other side of the\nentry towards the staircase, the head waiter turned round, and seeing\nthe Russian count, who had taken their best rooms, he took his hands\nout of his pockets deferentially, and with a bow informed him that a\ncourier had been, and that the business about the palazzo had been\narranged': 62, 'The steward was prepared to sign the agreement': 8, '"Ah': 1, 'I\'m glad to hear it," said Vronsky': 7, '"Is madame at home or not': 6, '"\n\n"Madame has been out for a walk but has returned now," answered the\nwaiter': 15, 'Vronsky took off his soft, wide-brimmed hat and passed his handkerchief\nover his heated brow and hair, which had grown half over his ears, and\nwas brushed back covering the bald patch on his head': 35, 'And glancing\ncasually at the gentleman, who still stood there gazing intently at\nhim, he would have gone on': 19, '"This gentleman is a Russian, and was inquiring after you," said the\nhead waiter': 14, 'With mingled feelings of annoyance at never being able to get away from\nacquaintances anywhere, and longing to find some sort of diversion from\nthe monotony of his life, Vronsky looked once more at the gentleman,\nwho had retreated and stood still again, and at the same moment a light\ncame into the eyes of both': 56, '"Golenishtchev': 1, '"\n\n"Vronsky': 2, '"\n\nIt really was Golenishtchev, a comrade of Vronsky\'s in the Corps of\nPages': 14, 'In the corps Golenishtchev had belonged to the liberal party; he\nleft the corps without entering the army, and had never taken office\nunder the government': 26, 'Vronsky and he had gone completely different ways\non leaving the corps, and had only met once since': 18, "At that meeting Vronsky perceived that Golenishtchev had taken up a\nsort of lofty, intellectually liberal line, and was consequently\ndisposed to look down upon Vronsky's interests and calling in life": 31, 'Hence Vronsky had met him with the chilling and haughty manner he so\nwell knew how to assume, the meaning of which was: "You may like or\ndislike my way of life, that\'s a matter of the most perfect\nindifference to me; you will have to treat me with respect if you want\nto know me': 56, '" Golenishtchev had been contemptuously indifferent to the\ntone taken by Vronsky': 12, 'This second meeting might have been expected,\none would have supposed, to estrange them still more': 16, 'But now they\nbeamed and exclaimed with delight on recognizing one another': 12, 'Vronsky\nwould never have expected to be so pleased to see Golenishtchev, but\nprobably he was not himself aware how bored he was': 23, 'He forgot the\ndisagreeable impression of their last meeting, and with a face of frank\ndelight held out his hand to his old comrade': 24, "The same expression of\ndelight replaced the look of uneasiness on Golenishtchev's face": 13, '"How glad I am to meet you': 7, '" said Vronsky, showing his strong white\nteeth in a friendly smile': 12, '"I heard the name Vronsky, but I didn\'t know which one': 11, "I'm very, very\nglad": 4, '"\n\n"Let\'s go in': 4, "Come, tell me what you're doing": 6, '"\n\n"I\'ve been living here for two years': 8, "I'm working": 2, '"\n\n"Ah': 2, '" said Vronsky, with sympathy; "let\'s go in': 8, '" And with the habit\ncommon with Russians, instead of saying in Russian what he wanted to\nkeep from the servants, he began to speak in French': 27, '"Do you know Madame Karenina': 5, 'We are traveling together': 4, 'I am going to\nsee her now," he said in French, carefully scrutinizing Golenishtchev\'s\nface': 15, 'I did not know" (though he did know), Golenishtchev answered\ncarelessly': 11, '"Have you been here long': 5, '" he added': 3, '"Four days," Vronsky answered, once more scrutinizing his friend\'s face\nintently': 11, '"Yes, he\'s a decent fellow, and will look at the thing properly,"\nVronsky said to himself, catching the significance of Golenishtchev\'s\nface and the change of subject': 27, '"I can introduce him to Anna, he looks\nat it properly': 11, '"\n\nDuring those three months that Vronsky had spent abroad with Anna, he\nhad always on meeting new people asked himself how the new person would\nlook at his relations with Anna, and for the most part, in men, he had\nmet with the "proper" way of looking at it': 50, 'But if he had been asked,\nand those who looked at it "properly" had been asked, exactly how they\ndid look at it, both he and they would have been greatly puzzled to\nanswer': 34, 'In reality, those who in Vronsky\'s opinion had the "proper" view had no\nsort of view at all, but behaved in general as well-bred persons do\nbehave in regard to all the complex and insoluble problems with which\nlife is encompassed on all sides; they behaved with propriety, avoiding\nallusions and unpleasant questions': 53, 'They assumed an air of fully\ncomprehending the import and force of the situation, of accepting and\neven approving of it, but of considering it superfluous and uncalled\nfor to put all this into words': 35, 'Vronsky at once divined that Golenishtchev was of this class, and\ntherefore was doubly pleased to see him': 18, "And in fact, Golenishtchev's\nmanner to Madame Karenina, when he was taken to call on her, was all\nthat Vronsky could have desired": 23, 'Obviously without the slightest effort\nhe steered clear of all subjects which might lead to embarrassment': 16, 'He had never met Anna before, and was struck by her beauty, and still\nmore by the frankness with which she accepted her position': 24, 'She blushed\nwhen Vronsky brought in Golenishtchev, and he was extremely charmed by\nthis childish blush overspreading her candid and handsome face': 22, 'But\nwhat he liked particularly was the way in which at once, as though on\npurpose that there might be no misunderstanding with an outsider, she\ncalled Vronsky simply Alexey, and said they were moving into a house\nthey had just taken, what was here called a palazzo': 48, 'Golenishtchev\nliked this direct and simple attitude to her own position': 11, "Looking at\nAnna's manner of simple-hearted, spirited gaiety, and knowing Alexey\nAlexandrovitch and Vronsky, Golenishtchev fancied that he understood\nher perfectly": 21, 'He fancied that he understood what she was utterly\nunable to understand: how it was that, having made her husband\nwretched, having abandoned him and her son and lost her good name, she\nyet felt full of spirits, gaiety, and happiness': 41, '"It\'s in the guide-book," said Golenishtchev, referring to the palazzo\nVronsky had taken': 13, '"There\'s a first-rate Tintoretto there': 5, 'One of his\nlatest period': 5, '"\n\n"I tell you what: it\'s a lovely day, let\'s go and have another look at\nit," said Vronsky, addressing Anna': 21, '"I shall be very glad to; I\'ll go and put on my hat': 13, "Would you say it's\nhot": 5, '" she said, stopping short in the doorway and looking inquiringly\nat Vronsky': 13, 'And again a vivid flush overspread her face': 8, 'Vronsky saw from her eyes that she did not know on what terms he cared\nto be with Golenishtchev, and so was afraid of with her; and smiling to him, she walked with her rapid\nstep out at the door': 32, 'The friends glanced at one another, and a look of hesitation came into\nboth faces, as though Golenishtchev, unmistakably admiring her, would\nhave liked to say something about her, and could not find the right\nthing to say, while Vronsky desired and dreaded his doing so': 46, '"Well then," Vronsky began to start a conversation of some sort; "so\nyou\'re settled here': 15, "You're still at the same work, then": 7, '" he went on,\nrecalling that he had been told Golenishtchev was writing something': 14, '"Yes, I\'m writing the second part of the _Two Elements_," said\nGolenishtchev, coloring with pleasure at the question—"that is, to be\nexact, I am not writing it yet; I am preparing, collecting materials': 33, 'It will be of far wider scope, and will touch on almost all questions': 14, 'We in Russia refuse to see that we are the heirs of Byzantium," and he\nlaunched into a long and heated explanation of his views': 25, 'Vronsky at the first moment felt embarrassed at not even knowing of the\nfirst part of the _Two Elements_, of which the author spoke as\nsomething well known': 28, 'But as Golenishtchev began to lay down his\nopinions and Vronsky was able to follow them even without knowing the\n_Two Elements_, he listened to him with some interest, for\nGolenishtchev spoke well': 33, 'But Vronsky was startled and annoyed by the\nnervous irascibility with which Golenishtchev talked of the subject\nthat engrossed him': 20, 'As he went on talking, his eyes glittered more and\nmore angrily; he was more and more hurried in his replies to imaginary\nopponents, and his face grew more and more excited and worried': 34, 'Remembering Golenishtchev, a thin, lively, good-natured and well-bred\nboy, always at the head of the class, Vronsky could not make out the\nreason of his irritability, and he did not like it': 32, 'What he\nparticularly disliked was that Golenishtchev, a man belonging to a good\nset, should put himself on a level with some scribbling fellows, with\nwhom he was irritated and angry': 31, 'Was it worth it': 4, 'Vronsky disliked it,\nyet he felt that Golenishtchev was unhappy, and was sorry for him': 15, "Unhappiness, almost mental derangement, was visible on his mobile,\nrather handsome face, while without even noticing Anna's coming in, he\nwent on hurriedly and hotly expressing his views": 28, 'When Anna came in in her hat and cape, and her lovely hand rapidly\nswinging her parasol, and stood beside him, it was with a feeling of\nrelief that Vronsky broke away from the plaintive eyes of Golenishtchev\nwhich fastened persistently upon him, and with a fresh rush of love\nlooked at his charming companion, full of life and happiness': 60, 'Golenishtchev recovered himself with an effort, and at first was\ndejected and gloomy, but Anna, disposed to feel friendly with everyone\nas she was at that time, soon revived his spirits by her direct and\nlively manner': 37, 'After trying various subjects of conversation, she got\nhim upon painting, of which he talked very well, and she listened to\nhim attentively': 23, 'They walked to the house they had taken, and looked\nover it': 12, '"I am very glad of one thing," said Anna to Golenishtchev when they\nwere on their way back, "Alexey will have a capital _atelier_': 24, 'You must\ncertainly take that room," she said to Vronsky in Russian, using the\naffectionately familiar form as though she saw that Golenishtchev would\nbecome intimate with them in their isolation, and that there was no\nneed of reserve before him': 41, '"Do you paint': 3, '" said Golenishtchev, turning round quickly to Vronsky': 8, '"Yes, I used to study long ago, and now I have begun to do a little,"\nsaid Vronsky, reddening': 19, '"He has great talent," said Anna with a delighted smile': 10, '"I\'m no judge,\nof course': 5, 'But good judges have said the same': 7, '"': ('TOL CHAPTER 8 PART FIVE', {'Anna, in that first period of her emancipation and rapid return to\nhealth, felt herself unpardonably happy and full of the joy of life': 24, "The thought of her husband's unhappiness did not poison her happiness": 11, 'On one side that memory was too awful to be thought of': 12, "On the other\nside her husband's unhappiness had given her too much happiness to be\nregretted": 16, "The memory of all that had happened after her illness: her\nreconciliation with her husband, its breakdown, the news of Vronsky's\nwound, his visit, the preparations for divorce, the departure from her\nhusband's house, the parting from her son—all that seemed to her like a\ndelirious dream, from which she had waked up alone with Vronsky abroad": 57, 'The thought of the harm caused to her husband aroused in her a feeling\nlike repulsion, and akin to what a drowning man might feel who has\nshaken off another man clinging to him': 34, 'That man did drown': 4, 'It was an\nevil action, of course, but it was the sole means of escape, and better\nnot to brood over these fearful facts': 24, 'One consolatory reflection upon her conduct had occurred to her at the\nfirst moment of the final rupture, and when now she recalled all the\npast, she remembered that one reflection': 31, '"I have inevitably made that\nman wretched," she thought; "but I don\'t want to profit by his misery': 18, 'I too am suffering, and shall suffer; I am losing what I prized above\neverything—I am losing my good name and my son': 23, "I have done wrong, and\nso I don't want happiness, I don't want a divorce, and shall suffer\nfrom my shame and the separation from my child": 27, '" But, however sincerely\nAnna had meant to suffer, she was not suffering': 13, 'Shame there was not': 4, 'With the tact of which both had such a large share, they had succeeded\nin avoiding Russian ladies abroad, and so had never placed themselves\nin a false position, and everywhere they had met people who pretended\nthat they perfectly understood their position, far better indeed than\nthey did themselves': 50, 'Separation from the son she loved—even that did\nnot cause her anguish in these early days': 16, "The baby girl—_his_\nchild—was so sweet, and had so won Anna's heart, since she was all that\nwas left her, that Anna rarely thought of her son": 27, 'The desire for life, waxing stronger with recovered health, was so\nintense, and the conditions of life were so new and pleasant, that Anna\nfelt unpardonably happy': 27, 'The more she got to know Vronsky, the more she\nloved him': 12, 'She loved him for himself, and for his love for her': 11, 'Her\ncomplete ownership of him was a continual joy to her': 11, 'His presence was\nalways sweet to her': 7, 'All the traits of his character, which she learned\nto know better and better, were unutterably dear to her': 19, 'His\nappearance, changed by his civilian dress, was as fascinating to her as\nthough she were some young girl in love': 21, 'In everything he said,\nthought, and did, she saw something particularly noble and elevated': 14, 'Her adoration of him alarmed her indeed; she sought and could not find\nin him anything not fine': 18, 'She dared not show him her sense of her own\ninsignificance beside him': 13, 'It seemed to her that, knowing this, he\nmight sooner cease to love her; and she dreaded nothing now so much as\nlosing his love, though she had no grounds for fearing it': 33, 'But she\ncould not help being grateful to him for his attitude to her, and\nshowing that she appreciated it': 20, 'He, who had in her opinion such a\nmarked aptitude for a political career, in which he would have been\ncertain to play a leading part—he had sacrificed his ambition for her\nsake, and never betrayed the slightest regret': 39, 'He was more lovingly\nrespectful to her than ever, and the constant care that she should not\nfeel the awkwardness of her position never deserted him for a single\ninstant': 30, 'He, so manly a man, never opposed her, had indeed, with her,\nno will of his own, and was anxious, it seemed, for nothing but to\nanticipate her wishes': 29, 'And she could not but appreciate this, even\nthough the very intensity of his solicitude for her, the atmosphere of\ncare with which he surrounded her, sometimes weighed upon her': 30, 'Vronsky, meanwhile, in spite of the complete realization of what he had\nso long desired, was not perfectly happy': 19, 'He soon felt that the\nrealization of his desires gave him no more than a grain of sand out of\nthe mountain of happiness he had expected': 27, 'It showed him the mistake\nmen make in picturing to themselves happiness as the realization of\ntheir desires': 18, 'For a time after joining his life to hers, and putting\non civilian dress, he had felt all the delight of freedom in general of\nwhich he had known nothing before, and of freedom in his love,—and he\nwas content, but not for long': 44, 'He was soon aware that there was\nspringing up in his heart a desire for desires—_ennui_': 16, 'Without\nconscious intention he began to clutch at every passing caprice, taking\nit for a desire and an object': 19, 'Sixteen hours of the day must be\noccupied in some way, since they were living abroad in complete\nfreedom, outside the conditions of social life which filled up time in\nPetersburg': 31, 'As for the amusements of bachelor existence, which had\nprovided Vronsky with entertainment on previous tours abroad, they\ncould not be thought of, since the sole attempt of the sort had led to\na sudden attack of depression in Anna, quite out of proportion with the\ncause—a late supper with bachelor friends': 52, 'Relations with the society\nof the place—foreign and Russian—were equally out of the question owing\nto the irregularity of their position': 21, 'The inspection of objects of\ninterest, apart from the fact that everything had been seen already,\nhad not for Vronsky, a Russian and a sensible man, the immense\nsignificance Englishmen are able to attach to that pursuit': 37, 'And just as the hungry stomach eagerly accepts every object it can get,\nhoping to find nourishment in it, Vronsky quite unconsciously clutched\nfirst at politics, then at new books, and then at pictures': 34, 'As he had from a child a taste for painting, and as, not knowing what\nto spend his money on, he had begun collecting engravings, he came to a\nstop at painting, began to take interest in it, and concentrated upon\nit the unoccupied mass of desires which demanded satisfaction': 50, 'He had a ready appreciation of art, and probably, with a taste for\nimitating art, he supposed himself to have the real thing essential for\nan artist, and after hesitating for some time which style of painting\nto select—religious, historical, realistic, or genre painting—he set to\nwork to paint': 49, 'He appreciated all kinds, and could have felt inspired\nby anyone of them; but he had no conception of the possibility of\nknowing nothing at all of any school of painting, and of being inspired\ndirectly by what is within the soul, without caring whether what is\npainted will belong to any recognized school': 54, 'Since he knew nothing of\nthis, and drew his inspiration, not directly from life, but indirectly\nfrom life embodied in art, his inspiration came very quickly and\neasily, and as quickly and easily came his success in painting\nsomething very similar to the sort of painting he was trying to\nimitate': 51, "More than any other style he liked the French—graceful and\neffective—and in that style he began to paint Anna's portrait in\nItalian costume, and the portrait seemed to him, and to everyone who\nsaw it, extremely successful": 37, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART FIVE', {'The old neglected palazzo, with its lofty carved ceilings and frescoes\non the walls, with its floors of mosaic, with its heavy yellow stuff\ncurtains on the windows, with its vases on pedestals, and its open\nfireplaces, its carved doors and gloomy reception rooms, hung with\npictures—this palazzo did much, by its very appearance after they had\nmoved into it, to confirm in Vronsky the agreeable illusion that he was\nnot so much a Russian country gentleman, a retired army officer, as an\nenlightened amateur and patron of the arts, himself a modest artist who\nhad renounced the world, his connections, and his ambition for the sake\nof the woman he loved': 112, 'The pose chosen by Vronsky with their removal into the palazzo was\ncompletely successful, and having, through Golenishtchev, made\nacquaintance with a few interesting people, for a time he was\nsatisfied': 31, 'He painted studies from nature under the guidance of an\nItalian professor of painting, and studied mediæval Italian life': 19, 'Mediæval Italian life so fascinated Vronsky that he even wore a hat and\nflung a cloak over his shoulder in the mediæval style, which, indeed,\nwas extremely becoming to him': 30, '"Here we live, and know nothing of what\'s going on," Vronsky said to\nGolenishtchev as he came to see him one morning': 22, '"Have you seen\nMihailov\'s picture': 5, '" he said, handing him a Russian gazette he had\nreceived that morning, and pointing to an article on a Russian artist,\nliving in the very same town, and just finishing a picture which had\nlong been talked about, and had been bought beforehand': 44, 'The article\nreproached the government and the academy for letting so remarkable an\nartist be left without encouragement and support': 20, '"I\'ve seen it," answered Golenishtchev': 5, '"Of course, he\'s not without\ntalent, but it\'s all in a wrong direction': 13, "It's all the\nIvanov-Strauss-Renan attitude to Christ and to religious
