such a gross mistake': 12, 'Christ\nalways has His definite embodiment in the art of the great masters': 13, 'And\ntherefore, if they want to depict, not God, but a revolutionist or a\nsage, let them take from history a Socrates, a Franklin, a Charlotte\nCorday, but not Christ': 30, 'They take the very figure which cannot be taken\nfor their art, and then': 14, '"\n\n"And is it true that this another portrait': 7, 'Better have one of Annie" (so she called her baby girl)': 11, '"Here she is,"\nshe added, looking out of the window at the handsome Italian nurse, who\nwas carrying the child out into the garden, and immediately glancing\nunnoticed at Vronsky': 30, "The handsome nurse, from whom Vronsky was\npainting a head for his picture, was the one hidden grief in Anna's\nlife": 21, 'He painted with her as his model, admired her beauty and\nmediævalism, and Anna dared not confess to herself that she was afraid\nof becoming jealous of this nurse, and was for that reason particularly\ngracious and condescending both to her and her little son': 45, 'Vronsky,\ntoo, glanced out of the window and into Anna\'s eyes, and, turning at\nonce to Golenishtchev, he said:\n\n"Do you know this Mihailov': 24, '"\n\n"I have met him': 5, "But he's a queer fish, and quite without breeding": 9, "You\nknow, one of those uncouth new people one's so often coming across\nnowadays, one of those free-thinkers you know, who are reared\n_d'emblée_ in theories of atheism, scepticism, and materialism": 31, 'In\nformer days," said Golenishtchev, not observing, or not willing to\nobserve, that both Anna and Vronsky wanted to speak, "in former days\nthe free-thinker was a man who had been brought up in ideas of\nreligion, law, and morality, and only through conflict and struggle\ncame to free-thought; but now there has sprung up a new type of born\nfree-thinkers who grow up without even having heard of principles of\nmorality or of religion, of the existence of authorities, who grow up\ndirectly in ideas of negation in everything, that is to say, savages': 95, "Well, he's of that class": 5, "He's the son, it appears, of some Moscow\nbutler, and has never had any sort of bringing-up": 17, "When he got into the\nacademy and made his reputation he tried, as he's no fool, to educate\nhimself": 19, 'And he turned to what seemed to him the very source of\nculture—the magazines': 14, 'In old times, you see, a man who wanted to\neducate himself—a Frenchman, for instance—would have set to work to\nstudy all the classics and theologians and tragedians and historians\nand philosophers, and, you know, all the intellectual work that came in\nhis way': 44, "But in our day he goes straight for the literature of\nnegation, very quickly assimilates all the extracts of the science of\nnegation, and he's ready": 26, "And that's not all—twenty years ago he would\nhave found in that literature traces of conflict with authorities, with\nthe creeds of the ages; he would have perceived from this conflict that\nthere was something else; but now he comes at once upon a literature in\nwhich the old creeds do not even furnish matter for discussion, but it\nis stated baldly that there is nothing else—evolution, natural\nselection, struggle for existence—and that's all": 74, "In my article\nI've": 4, '"\n\n"I tell you what," said Anna, who had for a self-possession and readily agreed': 8, 'But as\nthe artist lived in a remote suburb, it was decided to take the\ncarriage': 16, 'An hour later Anna, with Golenishtchev by her side and Vronsky on studio, but that at that\nmoment he was in his lodging only a couple of steps off, they sent her\nto him with their cards, asking permission to see his picture": 48, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART FIVE', {'The artist Mihailov was, as always, at work when the cards of Count\nVronsky and Golenishtchev were brought to him': 20, 'In the morning he had\nbeen working in his studio at his big picture': 14, 'On getting home he flew\ninto a rage with his wife for not having managed to put off the\nlandlady, who had been asking for money': 26, '"I\'ve said it to you twenty times, don\'t enter into details': 11, 'You\'re\nfool enough at all times, and when you start explaining things in\nItalian you\'re a fool three times as foolish," he said after a long\ndispute': 27, '"Don\'t let it run so long; it\'s not my fault': 10, 'If I had the money': 5, '"\n\n"Leave me in peace, for God\'s sake': 8, '" Mihailov shrieked, with tears in\nhis voice, and, stopping his ears, he went off into his working room,\nthe other side of a partition wall, and closed the door after him': 32, '"Idiotic woman': 2, '" he said to himself, sat down to the table, and,\nopening a portfolio, he set to work at once with peculiar fervor at a\nsketch he had begun': 29, 'Never did he work with such fervor and success as when things went ill\nwith him, and especially when he quarreled with his wife': 24, '"Oh': 1, 'damn\nthem all': 3, '" he thought as he went on working': 8, 'He was making a sketch for\nthe figure of a man in a violent rage': 15, 'A sketch had been made before,\nbut he was dissatisfied with it': 12, '"No, that one was better': 5, 'where is\nit': 3, '" He went back to his wife, and scowling, and not looking at her,\nasked his eldest little girl, where was that piece of paper he had\ngiven them': 29, 'The paper with the discarded sketch on it was found, but it\nwas dirty, and spotted with candle-grease': 18, 'Still, he took the sketch,\nlaid it on his table, and, moving a little away, screwing up his eyes,\nhe fell to gazing at it': 25, 'All at once he smiled and gesticulated\ngleefully': 8, '"That\'s it': 2, "that's it": 2, '" he said, and, at once picking up the pencil, he\nbegan rapidly drawing': 14, 'The spot of tallow had given the man a new pose': 11, 'He had sketched this new pose, when all at once he recalled the face of\na shopkeeper of whom he had bought cigars, a vigorous face with a\nprominent chin, and he sketched this very face, this chin on to the\nfigure of the man': 45, 'He laughed aloud with delight': 5, 'The figure from a\nlifeless imagined thing had become living, and such that it could never\nbe changed': 18, 'That figure lived, and was clearly and unmistakably\ndefined': 9, 'The sketch might be corrected in accordance with the\nrequirements of the figure, the legs, indeed, could and must be put\ndifferently, and the position of the left hand must be quite altered;\nthe hair too might be thrown back': 40, 'But in making these corrections he\nwas not altering the figure but simply getting rid of what concealed\nthe figure': 20, 'He was, as it were, stripping off the wrappings which\nhindered it from being distinctly seen': 16, 'Each new feature only brought\nout the whole figure in all its force and vigor, as it had suddenly\ncome to him from the spot of tallow': 27, 'He was carefully finishing the\nfigure when the cards were brought him': 12, '"Coming, coming': 2, '"\n\nHe went in to his wife': 7, '"Come, Sasha, don\'t be cross': 5, '" he said, smiling timidly and\naffectionately at her': 9, '"You were to blame': 4, 'I was to blame': 4, "I'll make it\nall right": 5, '" And having made peace with his wife he put on an\nolive-green overcoat with a velvet collar and a hat, and went towards\nhis studio': 26, 'The successful figure he had already forgotten': 7, 'Now he was\ndelighted and excited at the visit of these people of consequence,\nRussians, who had come in their carriage': 21, 'Of his picture, the one that stood now on his easel, he had at the\nbottom of his heart one conviction—that no one had ever painted a\npicture like it': 30, 'He did not believe that his picture was better than\nall the pictures of Raphael, but he knew that what he tried to convey\nin that picture, no one ever had conveyed': 32, 'This he knew positively, and\nhad known a long while, ever since he had begun to paint it': 18, "But other\npeople's criticisms, whatever they might be, had yet immense\nconsequence in his eyes, and they agitated him to the depths of his\nsoul": 25, 'Any remark, the most insignificant, that showed that the critic\nsaw even the tiniest part of what he saw in the picture, agitated him\nto the depths of his soul': 30, 'He always attributed to his critics a more\nprofound comprehension than he had himself, and always expected from\nthem something he did not himself see in the picture': 28, 'And often in\ntheir criticisms he fancied that he had found this': 12, "He walked rapidly to the door of his studio, and in spite of his\nexcitement he was struck by the soft light on Anna's figure as she\nstood in the shade of the entrance listening to Golenishtchev, who was\neagerly telling her something, while she evidently wanted to look round\nat the artist": 53, 'He was himself unconscious how, as he approached them,\nhe seized on this impression and absorbed it, as he had the chin of the\nshopkeeper who had sold him the cigars, and put it away somewhere to be\nbrought out when he wanted it': 44, "The visitors, not agreeably impressed\nbeforehand by Golenishtchev's account of the artist, were still less so\nby his personal appearance": 20, 'Thick-set and of middle height, with nimble\nmovements, with his brown hat, olive-green coat and narrow\ntrousers—though wide trousers had been a long while in fashion,—most of\nall, with the ordinariness of his broad face, and the combined\nexpression of timidity and anxiety to keep up his dignity, Mihailov\nmade an unpleasant impression': 53, '"Please step in," he said, trying to look indifferent, and going into\nthe passage he took a key out of his pocket and opened the door': 26, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 11 PART FIVE', {"On entering the studio, Mihailov once more scanned his visitors and\nnoted down in his imagination Vronsky's expression too, and especially\nhis jaws": 23, 'Although his artistic sense was unceasingly at work\ncollecting materials, although he felt a continually increasing\nexcitement as the moment of criticizing his work drew nearer, he\nrapidly and subtly formed, from imperceptible signs, a mental image of\nthese three persons': 41, 'That fellow (Golenishtchev) was a Russian living here': 8, 'Mihailov did not\nremember his surname nor where he had met him, nor what he had said to\nhim': 19, 'He only remembered his face as he remembered all the faces he had\never seen; but he remembered, too, that it was one of the faces laid by\nin his memory in the immense class of the falsely consequential and\npoor in expression': 43, 'The abundant hair and very open forehead gave an\nappearance of consequence to the face, which had only one expression—a\npetty, childish, peevish expression, concentrated just above the bridge\nof the narrow nose': 33, 'Vronsky and Madame Karenina must be, Mihailov\nsupposed, distinguished and wealthy Russians, knowing nothing about\nart, like all those wealthy Russians, but posing as amateurs and\nconnoisseurs': 27, '"Most likely they\'ve already looked at all the antiques,\nand now they\'re making the round of the studios of the new people, the\nGerman humbug, and the cracked Pre-Raphaelite English fellow, and have\nonly come to me to make the point of view complete," he thought': 46, 'He was\nwell acquainted with the way dilettanti have (the cleverer they were\nthe worse he found them) of looking at the works of contemporary\nartists with the sole object of being in a position to say that art is\na thing of the past, and that the more one sees of the new men the more\none sees how inimitable the works of the great old masters have\nremained': 70, 'He expected all this; he saw it all in their faces, he saw it\nin the careless indifference with which they talked among themselves,\nstared at the lay figures and busts, and walked about in leisurely\nfashion, waiting for him to uncover his picture': 44, 'But in spite of this,\nwhile he was turning over his studies, pulling up the blinds and taking\noff the sheet, he was in intense excitement, especially as, in spite of\nhis conviction that all distinguished and wealthy Russians were certain\nto be beasts and fools, he liked Vronsky, and still more Anna': 53, '"Here, if you please," he said, moving on one side with his nimble gait\nand pointing to his picture, "it\'s the exhortation to Pilate': 24, 'Matthew,\nchapter xxvii," he said, feeling his lips were beginning to tremble\nwith emotion': 14, 'He moved away and stood behind them': 7, 'For the few seconds during which the visitors were gazing at the\npicture in silence Mihailov too gazed at it with the indifferent eye of\nan outsider': 27, 'For those few seconds he was sure in anticipation that a\nhigher, juster criticism would be uttered by them, by those very\nvisitors whom he had been so despising a moment before': 32, 'He forgot all\nhe had thought about his picture before during the three years he had\nbeen painting it; he forgot all its qualities which had been absolutely\ncertain to him—he saw the picture with their indifferent, new, outside\neyes, and saw nothing good in it': 46, "He saw in the foreground Pilate's\nirritated face and the serene face of Christ, and in the background the\nfigures of Pilate's retinue and the face of John watching what was\nhappening": 32, 'Every face that, with such agony, such blunders and\ncorrections had grown up within him with its special character, every\nface that had given him such torments and such raptures, and all these\nfaces so many times transposed for the sake of the harmony of the\nwhole, all the shades of color and tones that he had attained with such\nlabor—all of this together seemed to him now, looking at it with their\neyes, the merest vulgarity, something that had been done a thousand\ntimes over': 86, 'The face dearest to him, the face of Christ, the center of\nthe picture, which had given him such ecstasy as it unfolded itself to\nhim, was utterly lost to him when he glanced at the picture with their\neyes': 40, 'He saw a well-painted (no, not even that—he distinctly saw now a\nmass of defects) repetition of those endless Christs of Titian,\nRaphael, Rubens, and the same soldiers and Pilate': 30, 'It was all common,\npoor, and stale, and positively badly painted—weak and unequal': 13, 'They\nwould be justified in repeating hypocritically civil speeches in the\npresence of the painter, and pitying him and laughing at him when they\nwere alone again': 27, 'The silence (though it lasted no more than a minute) became too\nintolerable to him': 15, 'To break it, and to show he was not agitated, he\nmade an effort and addressed Golenishtchev': 17, '"I think I\'ve had the pleasure of meeting you," he said, looking\nuneasily first at Anna, then at Vronsky, in fear of losing any shade of\ntheir expression': 28, '"To be sure': 3, "We met at Rossi's, do you remember, at that _soirée_ when\nthat Italian lady recited—the new Rachel": 17, '" Golenishtchev answered\neasily, removing his eyes without the slightest regret from the picture\nand turning to the artist': 19, 'Noticing, however, that Mihailov was expecting a criticism of the\npicture, he said:\n\n"Your picture has got on a great deal since I saw it last time; and\nwhat strikes me particularly now, as it did then, is the figure of\nPilate': 42, "One so knows the man: a good-natured, capital fellow, but an\nofficial through and through, who does not know what it is he's doing": 24, 'But I fancy': 3, '"\n\nAll Mihailov\'s mobile face beamed at once; his eyes sparkled': 11, 'He tried\nto say something, but he could not speak for excitement, and pretended\nto be coughing': 17, "Low as was his opinion of Golenishtchev's capacity for\nunderstanding art, trifling as was the true remark upon the fidelity of\nthe expression of Pilate as an official, and offensive as might have\nseemed the utterance of so unimportant an observation while nothing was\nsaid of more serious points, Mihailov was in an ecstasy of delight at\nthis observation": 59, "He had himself thought about Pilate's figure just\nwhat Golenishtchev said": 11, "The fact that this reflection was but one of\nmillions of reflections, which as Mihailov knew for certain would be\ntrue, did not diminish for him the significance of Golenishtchev's\nremark": 31, 'His heart warmed to Golenishtchev for this remark, and from a\nstate of depression he suddenly passed to ecstasy': 19, 'At once the whole of\nhis picture lived before him in all the indescribable complexity of\neverything living': 18, 'Mihailov again tried to say that that was how he\nunderstood Pilate, but his lips quivered intractably, and he could not\npronounce the words': 24, "Vronsky and Anna too said something in that\nsubdued voice in which, partly to avoid hurting the artist's feelings\nand partly to avoid saying out loud something silly—so easily said when\ntalking of art—people usually speak at exhibitions of pictures": 40, 'Mihailov fancied that the picture had made an impression on them too': 12, 'He went up to them': 5, '"How marvelous Christ\'s expression is': 5, '" said Anna': 3, 'Of all she saw she\nliked that expression most of all, and she felt that it was the center\nof the picture, and so praise of it would be pleasant to the artist': 33, '"One can see that He is pitying Pilate': 8, '"\n\nThis again was one of the million true reflections that could be found\nin his picture and in the figure of Christ': 23, 'She said that He was\npitying Pilate': 7, "In Christ's expression there ought to be indeed an\nexpression of pity, since there is an expression of love, of heavenly\npeace, of readiness for death, and a sense of the vanity of words": 34, 'Of\ncourse there is the expression of an official in Pilate and of pity in\nChrist, seeing that one is the incarnation of the fleshly and the other\nof the spiritual life': 32, "All this and much more flashed into Mihailov's\nthoughts": 9, '"Yes, and how that figure is done—what atmosphere': 8, 'One can walk round\nit," said figures in\nthe background stand out': 8, 'There you have technique," he said,\naddressing Golenishtchev, alluding to a conversation between them about\nVronsky\'s despair of attaining this technique': 21, '"Yes, yes, marvelous': 3, '" Golenishtchev and Anna assented': 5, "In spite of the\nexcited condition in which he was, the sentence about technique had\nsent a pang to Mihailov's heart, and looking angrily at Vronsky he\nsuddenly scowled": 29, 'He had often heard this word technique, and was\nutterly unable to understand what was understood by it': 18, 'He knew that by\nthis term was understood a mechanical facility for painting or drawing,\nentirely apart from its subject': 20, 'He had noticed often that even in\nactual praise technique was opposed to essential quality, as though one\ncould paint well something that was bad': 25, 'He knew that a great deal of\nattention and care was necessary in taking off the coverings, to avoid\ninjuring the creation itself, and to take off all the coverings; but\nthere was no art of painting—no technique of any sort—about it': 42, 'If to a\nlittle child or to his cook were revealed what he saw, it or she would\nhave been able to peel the wrappings off what was seen': 29, 'And the most\nexperienced and adroit painter could not by mere mechanical facility\npaint anything if the lines of the subject were not revealed to him\nfirst': 27, 'Besides, he saw that if it came to talking about technique, it\nwas impossible to praise him for it': 19, 'In all he had painted and\nrepainted he saw faults that hurt his eyes, coming from want of care in\ntaking off the wrappings—faults he could not correct now without\nspoiling the whole': 33, 'And in almost all the figures and faces he saw,\ntoo, remnants of the wrappings not perfectly removed that spoiled the\npicture': 22, '"One thing might be said, if you will allow me to make the remark': 14, '"\nobserved Golenishtchev': 3, '"Oh, I shall be delighted, I beg you," said Mihailov with a forced\nsmile': 14, '"That is, that you make Him the man-god, and not the God-man': 12, 'But I\nknow that was what you meant to do': 10, '"\n\n"I cannot paint a Christ that is not in my heart," said Mihailov\ngloomily': 15, '"Yes; but in that case, if you will allow me to say what I think': 15, 'Your picture is so fine that my observation cannot detract from it,\nand, besides, it is only my personal opinion': 20, 'With you it is different': 5, 'Your very motive is different': 5, 'But let us take Ivanov': 5, 'I imagine that\nif Christ is brought down to the level of an historical character, it\nwould have been better for Ivanov to select some other historical\nsubject, fresh, untouched': 30, '"\n\n"But if this is the greatest subject presented to art': 11, '"\n\n"If one looked one would find others': 8, 'But the point is that art cannot\nsuffer doubt and discussion': 11, 'And before the picture of Ivanov the\nquestion arises for the believer and the unbeliever alike, ‘Is it God,\nor is it not God': 24, "' and the unity of the impression is destroyed": 9, '"\n\n"Why so': 3, 'I think that for educated people," said Mihailov, "the\nquestion cannot exist': 12, '"\n\nGolenishtchev did not agree with this, and confounded Mihailov by his\nsupport of his first idea of the unity of the impression being\nessential to art': 27, 'Mihailov was greatly perturbed, but he could say nothing in defense of\nhis own idea': 15, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART FIVE', {"Anna and Vronsky had long been exchanging glances, regretting their\nfriend's flow of cleverness": 14, 'At last Vronsky, without waiting for the\nartist, walked away to at his picture with all his own\nfull artist vision, and was soon in that mood of conviction of the\nperfectibility, and so of the significance, of his picture—a conviction\nessential to the most intense fervor, excluding all other interests—in\nwhich alone he could work': 49, "Christ's foreshortened leg was not right, though": 7, 'He took his palette\nand began to work': 8, 'As he corrected to touch that figure, but he felt too much excited\nfor it': 20, 'He was equally unable to work when he was cold and when he was\ntoo much affected and saw everything too much': 22, 'There was only one stage\nin the transition from coldness to inspiration, at which work was\npossible': 17, 'Today he was too much agitated': 6, 'He would have covered the\npicture, but he stopped, holding the cloth in his hand, and, smiling\nblissfully, gazed a long while at the figure of John': 27, 'At last, as it\nwere regretfully tearing himself away, he dropped the cloth, and,\nexhausted but happy, went home': 19, 'Vronsky, Anna, and Golenishtchev, on their way home, were particularly\nlively and cheerful': 13, 'They talked of Mihailov and his pictures': 7, 'The word\n_talent_, by which they meant an inborn, almost physical, aptitude\napart from brain and heart, and in which they tried to find an\nexpression for all the artist had gained from life, recurred\nparticularly often in their talk, as though it were necessary for them\nto sum up what they had no conception of, though they wanted to talk of\nit': 63, 'They said that there was no denying his talent, but that his talent\ncould not develop for want of education—the common defect of our\nRussian artists': 26, 'But the picture of the boys had imprinted itself on\ntheir memories, and they were continually coming back to it': 20, ('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART FIVE', {'Mihailov sold Vronsky his picture, and agreed to paint a portrait of\nAnna': 13, 'On the day fixed he came and began the work': 10, 'From the fifth sitting the portrait impressed everyone, especially\nVronsky, not only by its resemblance, but by its characteristic beauty': 20, 'It was strange how Mihailov could have discovered just her\ncharacteristic beauty': 12, '"One needs to know and love her as I have loved\nher to discover the very sweetest expression of her soul," Vronsky\nthought, though it was only from this portrait that he had himself\nlearned this sweetest expression of her soul': 41, 'But the expression was so\ntrue that he, and others too, fancied they had long known it': 17, '"I have been struggling on for ever so long without doing anything," he\nsaid of his own portrait of her, "and he just looked and painted it': 27, "That's where technique comes in": 5, '"\n\n"That will come," was the consoling reassurance given him by\nGolenishtchev, in whose view Vronsky had both talent, and what was most\nimportant, culture, giving him a wider outlook on art': 32, "Golenishtchev's\nfaith in Vronsky's talent was propped up by his own need of Vronsky's\nsympathy and approval for his own articles and ideas, and he felt that\nthe praise and support must be mutual": 34, "In another man's house, and especially in Vronsky's palazzo, Mihailov\nwas quite a different man from what he was in his studio": 22, 'He behaved\nwith hostile courtesy, as though he were afraid of coming closer to\npeople he did not respect': 19, 'He called Vronsky "your excellency," and\nnotwithstanding Anna\'s and Vronsky\'s invitations, he would never stay\nto dinner, nor come except for the sittings': 23, 'Anna was even more\nfriendly to him than to other people, and was very grateful for her\nportrait': 18, "Vronsky was more than cordial with him, and was obviously\ninterested to know the artist's opinion of his picture": 19, 'Golenishtchev\nnever let slip an opportunity of instilling sound ideas about art into\nMihailov': 14, 'But Mihailov remained equally chilly to all of them': 9, 'Anna was\naware from his eyes that he liked looking at her, but he avoided\nconversation with her': 18, "Vronsky's talk about his painting he met with\nstubborn silence, and he was as stubbornly silent when he was shown\nVronsky's picture": 22, "He was unmistakably bored by Golenishtchev's\nconversation, and he did not attempt to oppose him": 15, 'Altogether Mihailov, with his reserved and disagreeable, as it were,\nhostile attitude, was quite disliked by them as they got to know him\nbetter; and they were glad when the sittings were over, and they were\nleft with a magnificent portrait in their possession, and he gave up\ncoming': 49, 'Golenishtchev was the first to give expression to an idea that\nhad occurred to all of them, which was that Mihailov was simply jealous\nof Vronsky': 26, '"Not envious, let us say, since he has _talent_; but it annoys him that\na wealthy man of the highest society, and a count, too (you know they\nall detest a title), can, without any particular trouble, do as well,\nif not better, than he who has devoted all his life to it': 53, "And more\nthan all, it's a question of culture, which he is without": 13, '"\n\nVronsky defended Mihailov, but at the bottom of his heart he believed\nit, because in his view a man of a different, lower world would be sure\nto be envious': 31, "Anna's portrait—the same subject painted from nature both by him and by\nMihailov—ought to have shown Vronsky the difference between him and\nMihailov; but he did not see it": 29, "Only after Mihailov's portrait was\npainted he left off painting his portrait of Anna, deciding that it was\nnow not needed": 21, 'His picture of mediæval life he went on with': 9, "And he\nhimself, and Golenishtchev, and still more Anna, thought it very good,\nbecause it was far more like the celebrated pictures they knew than\nMihailov's picture": 27, "Mihailov meanwhile, although Anna's portrait greatly fascinated him,\nwas even more glad than they were when the sittings were over, and he\nhad no longer to listen to Golenishtchev's disquisitions upon art, and\ncould forget about Vronsky's painting": 38, 'He knew that Vronsky could not\nbe prevented from amusing himself with painting; he knew that he and\nall dilettanti had a perfect right to paint what they liked, but it was\ndistasteful to him': 35, 'A man could not be prevented from making himself a\nbig wax doll, and kissing it': 16, 'But if the man were to come with the doll\nand sit before a man in love, and begin caressing his doll as the lover\ncaressed the woman he loved, it would be distasteful to the lover': 37, "Just\nsuch a distasteful sensation was what Mihailov felt at the sight of\nVronsky's painting: he felt it both ludicrous and irritating, both\npitiable and offensive": 26, "Vronsky's interest in painting and the Middle Ages did not last long": 12, 'He had enough taste for painting to be unable to finish his picture': 13, 'The picture came to a standstill': 6, 'He was vaguely aware that its\ndefects, inconspicuous at first, would be glaring if he were to go on\nwith it': 21, 'The same experience befell him as Golenishtchev, who felt that\nhe had nothing to say, and continually deceived himself with the theory\nthat his idea was not yet mature, that he was working it out and\ncollecting materials': 38, 'This exasperated and tortured Golenishtchev, but\nVronsky was incapable of deceiving and torturing himself, and even more\nincapable of exasperation': 20, 'With his characteristic decision, without\nexplanation or apology, he simply ceased working at painting': 14, 'But without this occupation, the life of Vronsky and of Anna, who\nwondered at his loss of interest in it, struck them as intolerably\ntedious in an Italian town': 29, 'The palazzo suddenly seemed so obtrusively\nold and dirty, the spots on the curtains, the cracks in the floors, the\nbroken plaster on the cornices became so disagreeably obvious, and the\neverlasting sameness of Golenishtchev, and the Italian professor and\nthe German traveler became so wearisome, that they had to make some\nchange': 53, 'They resolved to go to Russia, to the country': 9, 'In Petersburg\nVronsky intended to arrange a partition of the land with his brother,\nwhile Anna meant to see her son': 21, "The summer they intended to spend on\nVronsky's great family estate": 11, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 14 PART FIVE', {'Levin had been married three months': 6, 'He was happy, but not at all in\nthe way he had expected to be': 15, 'At every step he found his former dreams\ndisappointed, and new, unexpected surprises of happiness': 15, 'He was happy;\nbut on entering upon family life he saw at every step that it was\nutterly different from what he had imagined': 24, 'At every step he\nexperienced what a man would experience who, after admiring the smooth,\nhappy course of a little boat on a lake, should get himself into that\nlittle boat': 31, 'He saw that it was not all sitting still, floating\nsmoothly; that one had to think too, not for an instant to forget where\none was floating; and that there was water under one, and that one must\nrow; and that his unaccustomed hands would be sore; and that it was\nonly to look at it that was easy; but that doing it, though very\ndelightful, was very difficult': 69, "As a bachelor, when he had watched other people's married life, seen\nthe petty cares, the squabbles, the jealousy, he had only smiled\ncontemptuously in his heart": 27, 'In his future married life there could be,\nhe was convinced, nothing of that sort; even the external forms,\nindeed, he fancied, must be utterly unlike the life of others in\neverything': 32, 'And all of a sudden, instead of his life with his wife\nbeing made on an individual pattern, it was, on the contrary, entirely\nmade up of the pettiest details, which he had so despised before, but\nwhich now, by no will of his own, had gained an extraordinary\nimportance that it was useless to contend against': 57, 'And Levin saw that\nthe organization of all these details was by no means so easy as he had\nfancied before': 21, 'Although Levin believed himself to have the most exact\nconceptions of domestic life, unconsciously, like all men, he pictured\ndomestic life as the happiest enjoyment of love, with nothing to hinder\nand no petty cares to distract': 37, 'He ought, as he conceived the position,\nto do his work, and to find repose from it in the happiness of love': 22, 'She ought to be beloved, and nothing more': 8, 'But, like all men, he forgot\nthat she too would want work': 12, 'And he was surprised that she, his\npoetic, exquisite Kitty, could, not merely in the first weeks, but even\nin the first days of their married life, think, remember, and busy\nherself about tablecloths, and furniture, about mattresses for\nvisitors, about a tray, about the cook, and the dinner, and so on': 52, 'While they were still engaged, he had been struck by the definiteness\nwith which she had declined the tour abroad and decided to go into the\ncountry, as though she knew of something she wanted, and could still\nthink of something outside her love': 44, 'This had jarred upon him then, and\nnow her trivial cares and anxieties jarred upon him several times': 18, 'But\nhe saw that this was essential for her': 9, 'And, loving her as he did,\nthough he did not understand the reason of them, and jeered at these\ndomestic pursuits, he could not help admiring them': 27, 'He jeered at the\nway in which she arranged the furniture they had brought from Moscow;\nrearranged their room; hung up curtains; prepared rooms for visitors; a\nroom for Dolly; saw after an abode for her new maid; ordered dinner of\nthe old cook; came into collision with Agafea Mihalovna, taking from\nher the charge of the stores': 58, "He saw how the old cook smiled, admiring\nher, and listening to her inexperienced, impossible orders, how\nmournfully and tenderly Agafea Mihalovna shook her head over the young\nmistress's new arrangements": 31, 'He saw that Kitty was extraordinarily\nsweet when, laughing and crying, she came to tell him that her maid,\nMasha, was used to looking upon her as her young lady, and so no one\nobeyed her': 36, 'It seemed to him sweet, but strange, and he thought it\nwould have been better without this': 17, 'He did not know how great a sense of change she was experiencing; she,\nwho at home had sometimes wanted some favorite dish, or sweets, without\nthe possibility of getting either, now could order what she liked, buy\npounds of sweets, spend as much money as she liked, and order any\npuddings she pleased': 54, "She was dreaming with delight now of Dolly's coming to them with her\nchildren, especially because she would order for the children their\nfavorite puddings and Dolly would appreciate all her new housekeeping": 33, 'She did not know herself why and wherefore, but the arranging of her\nhouse had an irresistible attraction for her': 20, 'Instinctively feeling the\napproach of spring, and knowing that there would be days of rough\nweather too, she built her nest as best she could, and was in haste at\nthe same time to build it and to learn how to do it': 43, "This care for domestic details in Kitty, so opposed to Levin's ideal of\nexalted happiness, was at first one of the disappointments; and this\nsweet care of her household, the aim of which he did not understand,\nbut could not help loving, was one of the new happy surprises": 49, 'Another disappointment and happy surprise came in their quarrels': 9, 'Levin\ncould never have conceived that between him and his wife any relations\ncould arise other than tender, respectful and loving, and all at once\nin the very early days they quarreled, so that she said he did not care\nfor her, that he cared for no one but himself, burst into tears, and\nwrung her arms': 57, "This first quarrel arose from Levin's having gone out to a new\nfarmhouse and having been away half an hour too long, because he had\ntried to get home by a short cut and had lost his way": 38, 'He drove home\nthinking of nothing but her, of her love, of his own happiness, and the\nnearer he drew to home, the warmer was his tenderness for her': 29, "He ran\ninto the room with the same feeling, with an even stronger feeling than\nhe had had when he reached the Shtcherbatskys' house to make his offer": 28, 'And suddenly he was met by a lowering expression he had never seen in\nher': 15, 'He would have kissed her; she pushed him away': 9, '"What is it': 3, '"\n\n"You\'ve been enjoying yourself," she began, trying to be calm and\nspiteful': 13, 'But as soon as she opened her mouth, a stream of reproach, of\nsenseless jealousy, of all that had been torturing her during that half\nhour which she had spent sitting motionless at the window, burst from\nher': 38, 'It was only then, for the first time, that he clearly understood\nwhat he had not understood when he led her out of the church after the\nwedding': 28, 'He felt now that he was not simply close to her, but that he\ndid not know where he ended and she began': 23, 'He felt this from the\nagonizing sensation of division that he experienced at that instant': 15, 'He\nwas offended for the first instant, but the very same second he felt\nthat he could not be offended by her, that she was himself': 26, 'He felt for\nthe first moment as a man feels when, having suddenly received a\nviolent blow from behind, he turns round, angry and eager to avenge\nhimself, to look for his antagonist, and finds that it is he himself\nwho has accidentally struck himself, that there is no one to be angry\nwith, and that he must put up with and try to soothe the pain': 67, 'Never afterwards did he feel it with such intensity, but this first\ntime he could not for a long while get over it': 23, 'His natural feeling\nurged him to defend himself, to prove to her she was wrong; but to\nprove her wrong would mean irritating her still more and making the\nrupture greater that was the cause of all his suffering': 39, 'One habitual\nfeeling impelled him to get rid of the blame and to pass it on to her': 18, 'Another feeling, even stronger, impelled him as quickly as possible to\nsmooth over the rupture without letting it grow greater': 20, 'To remain\nunder such undeserved reproach was wretched, but to make her suffer by\njustifying himself was worse still': 19, 'Like a man half-awake in an agony\nof pain, he wanted to tear out, to fling away the aching place, and\ncoming to his senses, he felt that the aching place was himself': 33, 'He\ncould do nothing but try to help the aching place to bear it, and this\nhe tried to do': 20, 'They made peace': 3, 'She, recognizing that she was wrong, though she did\nnot say so, became tenderer to him, and they experienced new, redoubled\nhappiness in their love': 25, 'But that did not prevent such quarrels from\nhappening again, and exceedingly often too, on the most unexpected and\ntrivial grounds': 21, 'These quarrels frequently arose from the fact that\nthey did not yet know what was of importance to each other and that all\nthis early period they were both often in a bad temper': 34, 'When one was in\na good temper, and the other in a bad temper, the peace was not broken;\nbut when both happened to be in an ill-humor, quarrels sprang up from\nsuch incomprehensibly trifling causes, that they could never remember\nafterwards what they had quarreled about': 47, 'It is true that when they\nwere both in a good temper their enjoyment of life was redoubled': 18, 'But\nstill this first period of their married life was a difficult time for\nthem': 15, 'During all this early time they had a peculiarly vivid sense of\ntension, as it were, a tugging in opposite directions of the chain by\nwhich they were bound': 29, 'Altogether their honeymoon—that is to say, the\nmonth after their wedding—from which from tradition Levin expected so\nmuch, was not merely not a time of sweetness, but remained in the\nmemories of both as the bitterest and most humiliating period in their\nlives': 43, 'They both alike tried in later life to blot out from their\nmemories all the monstrous, shameful incidents of that morbid period,\nwhen both were rarely in a normal frame of mind, both were rarely quite\nthemselves': 37, 'It was only in the third month of their married life, after their\nreturn from Moscow, where they had been staying for a month, that their\nlife began to go more smoothly': 32, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 15 PART FIVE', {'They had just come back from Moscow, and were glad to be alone': 13, 'He was\nsitting at the writing-table in his study, writing': 10, "She, wearing the\ndark lilac dress she had worn during the first days of their married\nlife, and put on again today, a dress particularly remembered and loved\nby him, was sitting on the sofa, the same old-fashioned leather sofa\nwhich had always stood in the study in Levin's father's and\ngrandfather's days": 53, 'She was sewing at _broderie anglaise_': 6, 'He thought\nand wrote, never losing the happy consciousness of her presence': 12, 'His\nwork, both on the land and on the book, in which the principles of the\nnew land system were to be laid down, had not been abandoned; but just\nas formerly these pursuits and ideas had seemed to him petty and\ntrivial in comparison with the darkness that overspread all life, now\nthey seemed as unimportant and petty in comparison with the life that\nlay before him suffused with the brilliant light of happiness': 75, 'He went\non with his work, but he felt now that the center of gravity of his\nattention had passed to something else, and that consequently he looked\nat his work quite differently and more clearly': 36, 'Formerly this work had\nbeen for him an escape from life': 11, 'Formerly he had felt that without\nthis work his life would be too gloomy': 14, 'Now these pursuits were\nnecessary for him that life might not be too uniformly bright': 15, 'Taking\nup his manuscript, reading through what he had written, he found with\npleasure that the work was worth his working at': 22, 'Many of his old ideas\nseemed to him superfluous and extreme, but many blanks became distinct\nto him when he reviewed the whole thing in his memory': 27, 'He was writing\nnow a new chapter on the causes of the present disastrous condition of\nagriculture in Russia': 19, 'He maintained that the poverty of Russia arises\nnot merely from the anomalous distribution of landed property and\nmisdirected reforms, but that what had contributed of late years to\nthis result was the civilization from without abnormally grafted upon\nRussia, especially facilities of communication, as railways, leading to\ncentralization in towns, the development of luxury, and the consequent\ndevelopment of manufactures, credit and its accompaniment of\nspeculation—all to the detriment of agriculture': 72, 'It seemed to him that\nin a normal development of wealth in a state all these phenomena would\narise only when a considerable amount of labor had been put into\nagriculture, when it had come under regular, or at least definite,\nconditions; that the wealth of a country ought to increase\nproportionally, and especially in such a way that other sources of\nwealth should not outstrip agriculture; that in harmony with a certain\nstage of agriculture there should be means of communication\ncorresponding to it, and that in our unsettled condition of the land,\nrailways, called into being by political and not by economic needs,\nwere premature, and instead of promoting agriculture, as was expected\nof them, they were competing with agriculture and promoting the\ndevelopment of manufactures and credit, and so arresting its progress;\nand that just as the one-sided and premature development of one organ\nin an animal would hinder its general development, so in the general\ndevelopment of wealth in Russia, credit, facilities of communication,\nmanufacturing activity, indubitably necessary in Europe, where they had\narisen in their proper time, had with us only done harm, by throwing\ninto the background the chief question calling for settlement—the\nquestion of the organization of agriculture': 205, 'While he was writing his ideas she was thinking how unnaturally cordial\nher husband had been to young Prince Tcharsky, who had, with great want\nof tact, flirted with her the day before they left Moscow': 36, '"He\'s\njealous," she thought': 4, '"Goodness': 1, 'how sweet and silly he is': 6, "He's\njealous of me": 4, 'If he knew that I think no more of them than of Piotr\nthe cook," she thought, looking at his head and red neck with a feeling\nof possession strange to herself': 32, '"Though it\'s a pity to take him from\nhis work (but he has plenty of time': 16, "), I must look at his face; will he\nfeel I'm looking at him": 14, "I wish he'd turn round": 5, "I'll _will_ him\nto": 4, '" and she opened her eyes wide, as though to intensify the influence\nof her gaze': 16, '"Yes, they draw away all the sap and give a false appearance of\nprosperity," he muttered, stopping to write, and, feeling that she was\nlooking at him and smiling, he looked round': 32, '"Well': 1, '" he queried, smiling, and getting up': 7, '"He looked round," she thought': 5, '"It\'s nothing; I wanted you to look round," she said, watching him, and\ntrying to guess whether he was vexed at being interrupted or not': 25, '"How happy we are alone together': 6, '—I am, that is," he said, going up to\nher with a radiant smile of happiness': 16, '"I\'m just as happy': 4, "I'll never go anywhere, especially not to Moscow": 8, '"\n\n"And what were you thinking about': 7, '"\n\n"I': 2, 'I was thinking': 3, 'No, no, go along, go on writing; don\'t break\noff," she said, pursing up her lips, "and I must cut out these little\nholes now, do you see': 28, '"\n\nShe took up her scissors and began cutting them out': 11, '"No; tell me, what was it': 6, '" he said, sitting down beside her and\nwatching the tiny scissors moving round': 14, '"Oh': 1, 'what was I thinking about': 5, 'I was thinking about Moscow, about the\nback of your head': 11, '"\n\n"Why should I, of all people, have such happiness': 10, 'It\'s unnatural, too\ngood," he said, kissing her hand': 9, '"I feel quite the opposite; ('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART FIVE', {'The hotel of the provincial town where Nikolay Levin was lying ill was\none of those provincial hotels which are constructed on the newest\nmodel of modern improvements, with the best intentions of cleanliness,\ncomfort, and even elegance, but owing to the public that patronizes\nthem, are with astounding rapidity transformed into filthy taverns with\na pretension of modern improvement that only makes them worse than the\nold-fashioned, honestly filthy hotels': 71, 'This hotel had already reached\nthat stage, and the soldier in a filthy uniform smoking in the entry,\nsupposed to stand for a hall-porter, and the cast-iron, slippery, dark,\nand disagreeable staircase, and the free and easy waiter in a filthy\nfrock coat, and the common dining-room with a dusty bouquet of wax\nflowers adorning the table, and filth, dust, and disorder everywhere,\nand at the same time the sort of modern up-to-date self-complacent\nrailway uneasiness of this hotel, aroused a most painful feeling in\nLevin after their fresh young life, especially because the impression\nof falsity made by the hotel was so out of keeping with what awaited\nthem': 110, 'As is invariably the case, after they had been asked at what price they\nwanted rooms, it appeared that there was not one decent room for them;\none decent room had been taken by the inspector of railroads, another\nby a lawyer from Moscow, a third by Princess Astafieva from the\ncountry': 52, 'There remained only one filthy room, next to which they\npromised that another should be empty by the evening': 19, 'Feeling angry\nwith his wife because what he had expected had come to pass, which was\nthat at the moment of arrival, when his heart throbbed with emotion and\nanxiety to know how his brother was getting on, he should have to be\nseeing after her, instead of rushing straight to his brother, Levin\nconducted her to the room assigned them': 61, '"Go, do go': 3, '" she said, looking at him with timid and guilty eyes': 11, 'He went out of the door without a word, and at once stumbled over Marya\nNikolaevna, who had heard of his arrival and had not dared to go in to\nsee him': 32, 'She was just the same as when he saw her in Moscow; the same\nwoolen gown, and bare arms and neck, and the same good-naturedly\nstupid, pockmarked face, only a little plumper': 32, '"Well, how is he': 4, 'how is he': 3, '"\n\n"Very bad': 3, "He can't get up": 4, 'He has kept expecting you': 5, 'He': 1, 'Are you': 2, 'with your wife': 3, '"\n\nLevin did not for the first moment understand what it was confused her,\nbut she immediately enlightened him': 19, '"I\'ll go away': 3, 'I\'ll go down to the kitchen," she brought out': 9, '"Nikolay\nDmitrievitch will be delighted': 5, 'He heard about it, and knows your lady,\nand remembers her abroad': 12, '"\n\nLevin realized that she meant his wife, and did not know what answer to\nmake': 16, '"Come along, come along to him': 6, '" he said': 3, 'But her; but it lasted only a single instant': 33, '"Well': 1, '" she turned to her husband and then to her': 10, '"But one can\'t go on talking in the passage like this': 11, '" Levin said,\nlooking herself, but noticing her husband\'s face of dismay, "or go\non; go, and then come for me," she said, and went back into the room': 38, "Levin went to his brother's room": 6, "He had not in the least expected what\nhe saw and felt in his brother's room": 16, "He had expected to find him in\nthe same state of self-deception which he had heard was so frequent\nwith the consumptive, and which had struck him so much during his\nbrother's visit in the autumn": 36, 'He had expected to find the physical\nsigns of the approach of death more marked—greater weakness, greater\nemaciation, but still almost the same condition of things': 26, 'He had\nexpected himself to feel the same distress at the loss of the brother\nhe loved and the same horror in face of death as he had felt then, only\nin a greater degree': 35, 'And he had prepared himself for this; but he found\nsomething utterly different': 13, 'In a little dirty room with the painted panels of its walls filthy with\nspittle, and conversation audible through the thin partition from the\nnext room, in a stifling atmosphere saturated with impurities, on a\nbedstead moved away from the wall, there lay covered with a quilt, a\nbody': 49, 'One arm of this body was above the quilt, and the wrist, huge as\na rake-handle, was attached, inconceivably it seemed, to the thin, long\nbone of the arm smooth from the beginning to the middle': 36, 'The head lay\nsideways on the pillow': 7, 'Levin could see the scanty locks wet with sweat\non the temples and tense, transparent-looking forehead': 16, '"It cannot be that that fearful body was my brother Nikolay': 11, '" thought\nLevin': 3, 'But he went closer, saw the face, and doubt became impossible': 11, 'In spite of the terrible change in the face, Levin had only to glance\nat those eager eyes raised at his approach, only to catch the faint\nmovement of the mouth under the sticky mustache, to realize the\nterrible truth that this death-like body was his living brother': 48, 'The glittering eyes looked sternly and reproachfully at his brother as\nhe drew near': 14, 'And immediately this glance established a living\nrelationship between living men': 11, 'Levin immediately felt the reproach in\nthe eyes fixed on him, and felt remorse at his own happiness': 18, 'When Konstantin took him by the hand, Nikolay smiled': 9, 'The smile was\nfaint, scarcely perceptible, and in spite of the smile the stern\nexpression of the eyes was unchanged': 20, '"You did not expect to find me like this," he articulated with effort': 13, '"Yes': 1, 'no," said Levin, silent, and he did not know what to say,\nespecially as his brother made no reply, and simply stared without\ndropping his eyes, and evidently penetrated to the inner meaning of\neach word': 43, 'Levin told his brother that his wife had come with him': 11, 'Nikolay expressed pleasure, but said he was afraid of frightening her\nby his condition': 14, 'A silence followed': 3, 'Suddenly Nikolay stirred, and\nbegan to say something': 8, 'Levin expected something of peculiar gravity\nand importance from the expression of his face, but Nikolay began\nspeaking of his health': 21, 'He found fault ('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART FIVE', {'Levin could not look calmly at his brother; he could not himself be\nnatural and calm in his presence': 19, "When he went in to the sick man, his\neyes and his attention were unconsciously dimmed, and he did not see\nand did not distinguish the details of his brother's position": 31, 'He smelt\nthe awful odor, saw the dirt, disorder, and miserable condition, and\nheard the groans, and felt that nothing could be done to help': 25, "It never\nentered his head to analyze the details of the sick man's situation, to\nconsider how that body was lying under the quilt, how those emaciated\nlegs and thighs and spine were lying huddled up, and whether they could\nnot be made more comfortable, whether anything could not be done to\nmake things, if not better, at least less bad": 61, 'It made his blood run\ncold when he began to think of all these details': 15, "He was absolutely\nconvinced that nothing could be done to prolong his brother's life or\nto relieve his suffering": 19, 'But a sense of his regarding all aid as out\nof the question was felt by the sick man, and exasperated him': 22, 'And this\nmade it still more painful for Levin': 9, 'To be in the sick-room was agony\nto him, not to be there still worse': 15, 'And he was continually, on various\npretexts, going out of the room, and coming in again, because he was\nunable to remain alone': 23, 'But Kitty thought, and felt, and acted quite differently': 9, 'On seeing the\nsick man, she pitied him': 8, 'And pity in her womanly heart did not arouse\nat all that feeling of horror and loathing that it aroused in her\nhusband, but a desire to act, to find out all the details of his state,\nand to remedy them': 41, 'And since she had not the slightest doubt that it\nwas her duty ('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART FIVE', {'"Thou hast hid these things from the wise and prudent, and hast\nrevealed them unto babes': 16, '" So Levin thought about his wife as he talked\nto her that evening': 14, 'Levin thought of the text, not because he considered himself "wise and\nprudent': 13, '" He did not so consider himself, but he could not help knowing\nthat he had more intellect than his wife and Agafea Mihalovna, and he\ncould not help knowing that when he thought of death, he thought with\nall the force of his intellect': 45, 'He knew too that the brains of many\ngreat men, whose thoughts he had read, had brooded over death and yet\nknew not a hundredth part of what his wife and Agafea Mihalovna knew\nabout it': 36, 'Different as those two women were, Agafea Mihalovna and\nKatya, as his brother Nikolay had called her, and as Levin particularly\nliked to call her now, they were quite alike in this': 32, 'Both knew,\nwithout a shade of doubt, what sort of thing life was and what was\ndeath, and though neither of them could have answered, and would even\nnot have understood the questions that presented themselves to Levin,\nboth had no doubt of the significance of this event, and were precisely\nalike in their way of looking at it, which they shared with millions of\npeople': 66, 'The proof that they knew for a certainty the nature of death\nlay in the fact that they knew without a second of hesitation how to\ndeal with the dying, and were not frightened of them': 36, 'Levin and other\nmen like him, though they could have said a great deal about death,\nobviously did not know this since they were afraid of death, and were\nabsolutely at a loss what to do when people were dying': 40, 'If Levin had\nbeen alone now with his brother Nikolay, he would have looked at him\nwith terror, and with still greater terror waited, and would not have\nknown what else to do': 33, 'More than that, he did not know what to say, how to look, how to move': 16, 'To talk of outside things seemed to him shocking, impossible, to talk\nof death and depressing subjects—also impossible': 18, 'To be silent, also\nimpossible': 5, '"If I look at him he will think evidently did not think of herself, and had no time to\nthink about herself: she was thinking about him because she knew\nsomething, and all went well': 29, 'She told him about herself even and about\nher wedding, and smiled and sympathized with him and petted him, and\ntalked of cases of recovery and all went well; so then she must know': 34, "The proof that her behavior and Agafea Mihalovna's was not instinctive,\nanimal, irrational, was that apart from the physical treatment, the\nrelief of suffering, both Agafea Mihalovna and Kitty required for the\ndying man something else more important than the physical treatment,\nand something which had nothing in common with physical conditions": 52, 'Agafea Mihalovna, speaking of the man just dead, had said: "Well, thank\nGod, he on\nthe contrary, was more active than usual': 9, 'She was even livelier than\nusual': 6, 'She ordered supper to be brought, herself unpacked their things,\nand herself helped to make the beds, and did not even forget to\nsprinkle them with Persian powder': 28, 'She showed that alertness, that\nswiftness of reflection which comes out in men before a battle, in\nconflict, in the dangerous and decisive moments of life—those moments\nwhen a man shows once and for all his value, and that all his past has\nnot been wasted but has been a preparation for these moments': 54, "Everything went ('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART FIVE', {'The next day the sick man received the sacrament and extreme unction': 12, 'During the ceremony Nikolay Levin prayed fervently': 7, 'His great eyes,\nfastened on the holy image that was set out on a card-table covered\nwith a colored napkin, expressed such passionate prayer and hope that\nit was awful to Levin to see it': 35, 'Levin knew that this passionate prayer\nand hope would only make him feel more bitterly parting from the life\nhe so loved': 22, 'Levin knew his brother and the workings of his intellect:\nhe knew that his unbelief came not from life being easier for him\nwithout faith, but had grown up because step by step the contemporary\nscientific interpretation of natural phenomena crushed out the\npossibility of faith; and so he knew that his present return was not a\nlegitimate one, brought about by way of the same working of his\nintellect, but simply a temporary, interested return to faith in a\ndesperate hope of recovery': 84, 'Levin knew too that Kitty had strengthened\nhis hope by accounts of the marvelous recoveries she had heard of': 19, 'Levin knew all this; and it was agonizingly painful to him to behold\nthe supplicating, hopeful eyes and the emaciated wrist, lifted with\ndifficulty, making the sign of the cross on the tense brow, and the\nprominent shoulders and hollow, gasping chest, which one could not feel\nconsistent with the life the sick man was praying for': 57, 'During the\nsacrament Levin did what he, an unbeliever, had done a thousand times': 14, 'He said, addressing God, "If Thou dost exist, make this man to recover"\n(of course this same thing has been repeated many times), "and Thou\nwilt save him and me': 30, '"\n\nAfter extreme unction the sick man became suddenly much better': 11, "He did\nnot cough once in the course of an hour, smiled, kissed Kitty's hand,\nthanking her with tears, and said he was comfortable, free from pain,\nand that he felt strong and had an appetite": 36, 'He even raised himself\nwhen his soup was brought, and asked for a cutlet as well': 16, 'Hopelessly\nill as he was, obvious as it was at the first glance that he could not\nrecover, Levin and Kitty were for that hour both in the same state of\nexcitement, happy, though fearful of being mistaken': 38, '"Is he better': 3, '"\n\n"Yes, much': 3, '"\n\n"It\'s wonderful': 3, '"\n\n"There\'s nothing wonderful in it': 6, '"\n\n"Anyway, he\'s better," they said in a whisper, smiling to one another': 13, 'This self-deception was not of long duration': 7, 'The sick man fell into a\nquiet sleep, but he was waked up half an hour later by his cough': 20, 'And\nall at once every hope vanished in those about him and in himself': 14, 'The\nreality of his suffering crushed all hopes in Levin and Kitty and in\nthe sick man himself, leaving no doubt, no memory even of past hopes': 27, 'Without referring to what he had believed in half an hour before, as\nthough ashamed even to recall it, he asked for iodine to inhale in a\nbottle covered with perforated paper': 32, "Levin gave him the bottle, and\nthe same look of passionate hope with which he had taken the sacrament\nwas now fastened on to the doctor\'s words': 13, '"No; so I can say it': 6, 'It was for her\nsake I went through that farce': 10, "She's so sweet; but you and I can't\ndeceive ourselves": 10, 'This is what I believe in," he said, and, squeezing\nthe bottle in his bony hand, he began breathing over it': 21, "At eight o'clock in the evening Levin and his wife were drinking tea in\ntheir room when Marya Nikolaevna ran in to them breathlessly": 24, 'She was\npale, and her lips were quivering': 8, '"He is dying': 3, '" she whispered': 3, '"I\'m\nafraid will die this minute': 6, '"\n\nBoth of them ran to him': 7, 'He was said Levin, so as to say something': 8, '"Because I\'m setting off," he repeated, as though he had a liking for\nthe phrase': 15, '"It\'s the end': 3, '"\n\nMarya Nikolaevna went up to him': 7, '"You had better lie down; you\'d be easier," she said': 10, '"I shall lie down soon enough," he pronounced slowly, "when I\'m dead,"\nhe said sarcastically, wrathfully': 16, '"Well, you can lay me down if you\nlike': 9, '"\n\nLevin laid his brother on his back, sat down beside him, and gazed at\nhis face, holding his breath': 20, 'The dying man lay with closed eyes, but\nthe muscles twitched from time to time on his forehead, as with one\nthinking deeply and intensely': 25, 'Levin involuntarily thought with him of\nwhat it was that was happening to him now, but in spite of all his\nmental efforts motionless': 17, 'But he was still alive, and from time to time he\nsighed': 12, 'Levin by now was exhausted from mental strain': 8, 'He felt that,\nwith no mental effort, could he understand what it was that was\n_right_': 16, "He could not even think of the problem of death itself, but\nwith no will of his own thoughts kept coming to him of what he had to\ndo next; closing the dead man's eyes, dressing him, ordering the\ncoffin": 40, 'And, strange to say, he felt utterly cold, and was not\nconscious of sorrow nor of loss, less still of pity for his brother': 24, 'If\nhe had any feeling for his brother at that moment, it was envy for the\nknowledge the dying man had now that he could not have': 27, 'A long time more he sat over him so, continually expecting the end': 13, 'But\nthe end did not come': 6, 'The door opened and Kitty appeared': 6, 'Levin got up\nto stop her': 6, 'But at the moment he was getting up, he caught the sound\nof the dying man stirring': 17, '"Don\'t go away," said Nikolay and held out his hand': 10, 'Levin gave him\nhis, and angrily waved to his wife to go away': 13, "With the dying man's hand in his hand, he sat for half an hour, an\nhour, another hour": 18, 'He did not think of death at all now': 9, 'He wondered\nwhat Kitty was doing; who lived in the next room; whether the doctor\nlived in a house of his own': 22, 'He longed for food and for sleep': 7, 'He\ncautiously drew away his hand and felt the feet': 10, 'The feet were cold,\nbut the sick man was still breathing': 11, 'Levin tried again to move away on\ntiptoe, but the sick man stirred again and said: "Don\'t go': 18, '"\n\nThe dawn came; the sick man\'s condition was unchanged': 10, 'Levin stealthily\nwithdrew his hand, and without looking at the dying man, went off to\nhis own room and went to sleep': 22, "When he woke up, instead of news of his\nbrother's death which he expected, he learned that the sick man had\nreturned to his earlier condition": 26, 'He had begun sitting up again,\ncoughing, had begun eating again, talking again, and again had ceased\nto talk of death, again had begun to express hope of his recovery, and\nhad become more irritable and more gloomy than ever': 40, 'No one, neither\nhis brother nor Kitty, could soothe him': 10, 'He was angry with everyone,\nand said nasty things to everyone, reproached everyone for his\nsufferings, and insisted that they should get him a celebrated doctor\nfrom Moscow': 28, 'To all inquiries made him as to how he felt, he made the\nsame answer with an expression of vindictive reproachfulness, "I\'m\nsuffering horribly, intolerably': 25, '"\n\nThe sick man was suffering more and more, especially from bedsores,\nwhich it was impossible now to remedy, and grew more and more angry\nwith everyone about him, blaming them for everything, and especially\nfor not having brought him a doctor from Moscow': 44, 'Kitty tried in every\npossible way to relieve him, to soothe him; but it was all in vain, and\nLevin saw that she herself was exhausted both physically and morally,\nthough she would not admit it': 36, 'The sense of death, which had been\nevoked in all by his taking leave of life on the night when he had sent\nfor his brother, was broken up': 29, 'Everyone knew that he must inevitably\ndie soon, that he was half dead already': 14, 'Everyone wished for nothing\nbut that he should die as soon as possible, and everyone, concealing\nthis, gave him medicines, tried to find remedies and doctors, and\ndeceived him and themselves and each other': 34, 'All this was falsehood,\ndisgusting, irreverent deceit': 7, 'And owing to the bent of his character,\nand because he loved the dying man more than anyone else did, Levin was\nmost painfully conscious of this deceit': 28, 'Levin, who had long been possessed by the idea of reconciling his\nbrothers, at least in face of death, had written to his brother, Sergey\nIvanovitch, and having received an answer from him, he read this letter\nto the sick man': 41, "Sergey Ivanovitch wrote that he could not come\nhimself, and in touching terms he begged his brother's forgiveness": 18, 'The sick man said nothing': 5, '"What am I to write to him': 7, '" said Levin': 3, '"I hope you are not angry with\nhim': 8, '"\n\n"No, not the least': 5, '" Nikolay answered, vexed at the question': 7, '"Tell him\nto send me a doctor': 7, '"\n\nThree more days of agony followed; the sick man was still in the same\ncondition': 16, 'The sense of longing for his death was felt by everyone now\nat the mere sight of him, by the waiters and the hotel-keeper and all\nthe people staying in the hotel, and the doctor and Marya Nikolaevna\nand Levin and Kitty': 42, 'The sick man alone did not express this feeling,\nbut on the contrary was furious at their not getting him doctors, and\nwent on taking medicine and talking of life': 30, 'Only at rare moments, when\nthe opium gave him an instant\'s relief from the never-ceasing pain, he\nwould sometimes, half asleep, utter what was ever more intense in his\nheart than in all the others: "Oh, if it were only the end': 42, '" or: "When\nwill it be over': 7, '"\n\nHis sufferings, steadily growing more intense, did their work and\nprepared him for death': 15, 'There was no position in which he was not in\npain, there was not a minute in which he was unconscious of it, not a\nlimb, not a part of his body that did not ache and cause him agony': 40, 'Even the memories, the impressions, the thoughts of this body awakened\nin him now the same aversion as the body itself': 21, 'The sight of other\npeople, their remarks, his own reminiscences, everything was for him a\nsource of agony': 18, 'Those about him felt this, and instinctively did not\nallow themselves to move freely, to talk, to express their wishes\nbefore him': 22, 'All his life was merged in the one feeling of suffering and\ndesire to be rid of it': 18, 'There was evidently coming over him that revulsion that would make him\nlook upon death as the goal of his desires, as happiness': 23, 'Hitherto each\nindividual desire, aroused by suffering or privation, such as hunger,\nfatigue, thirst, had been satisfied by some bodily function giving\npleasure': 23, 'But now no physical craving or suffering received relief, and\nthe effort to relieve them only caused fresh suffering': 19, 'And so all\ndesires were merged in one—the desire to be rid of all his sufferings\nand their source, the body': 21, 'But he had no words to express this desire\nof deliverance, and so he did not speak of it, and from habit asked for\nthe satisfaction of desires which could not now be satisfied': 34, '"Turn me\nover on the other side," he would say, and immediately after he would\nask to be turned back again as before': 23, '"Give me some broth': 4, 'Take away\nthe broth': 4, 'Talk of something: why are you silent': 7, '" And directly they\nbegan to talk he would close his eyes, and would show weariness,\nindifference, and loathing': 19, 'On the tenth day from their arrival at the town, Kitty was unwell': 13, 'She\nsuffered from headache and sickness, and she could not get up all the\nmorning': 15, 'The doctor opined that the indisposition arose from fatigue and\nexcitement, and prescribed rest': 14, 'After dinner, however, Kitty got up and went as usual with her work to\nthe sick man': 17, 'He looked at her sternly when she came in, and smiled\ncontemptuously when she said she had been unwell': 19, 'That day he was\ncontinually blowing his nose, and into\nthe corridor': 12, '"He has begun picking at himself," said Marya Nikolaevna': 9, '"How do you mean': 4, '"\n\n"Like this," she said, tugging at the folds of her woolen skirt': 13, 'Levin\nnoticed, indeed, that all that day the patient pulled at himself, as it\nwere, trying to snatch something away': 20, "Marya Nikolaevna's prediction came true": 5, 'Towards night the sick man was\nnot able to lift his hands, and could only gaze before him with the\nsame intensely concentrated expression in his eyes': 27, 'Even when his\nbrother or Kitty bent over him, so that he could see closed': 20, 'Levin, Kitty, and Marya Nikolaevna stood at\nthe bedside': 9, 'The priest had not quite finished reading the prayer when\nthe dying man stretched, sighed, and opened his eyes': 19, 'The that was turning cold': 39, '"He is gone," said the priest, and would have moved away; but suddenly\nthere was a faint stir in the mustaches of the dead man that seemed\nglued together, and quite distinctly in the hush they heard from the\nbottom of the chest the sharply defined sounds:\n\n"Not quite': 49, 'soon': 1, '"\n\nAnd a minute later the face brightened, a smile came out under the\nmustaches, and the women who had gathered round began carefully laying\nout the corpse': 28, 'The sight of his brother, and the nearness of death, revived in Levin\nthat sense of horror in face ('TOL CHAPTER 21 PART FIVE', {'From the moment when Alexey Alexandrovitch understood from his\ninterviews with Betsy and with Stepan Arkadyevitch that all that was\nexpected of him was to leave his wife in peace, without burdening her\nwith his presence, and that his wife herself desired this, he felt so\ndistraught that he could come to no decision of himself; he did not\nknow himself what he wanted now, and putting himself in the hands of\nthose who were so pleased to interest themselves in his affairs, he met\neverything with unqualified assent': 89, 'It was only when Anna had left his\nhouse, and the English governess sent to ask him whether she should\ndine with him or separately, that for the first time he clearly\ncomprehended his position, and was appalled by it': 40, 'Most difficult of\nall in this position was the fact that he could not in any way connect\nand reconcile his past with what was now': 26, 'It was not the past when he\nhad lived happily with his wife that troubled him': 16, "The transition from\nthat past to a knowledge of his wife's unfaithfulness he had lived\nthrough miserably already; that state was painful, but he could\nunderstand it": 27, 'If his wife had then, on declaring to him her\nunfaithfulness, left him, he would have been wounded, unhappy, but he\nwould not have been in the hopeless position—incomprehensible to\nhimself—in which he felt himself now': 36, "He could not now reconcile his\nimmediate past, his tenderness, his love for his sick wife, and for the\nother man's child with what was now the case, that is with the fact\nthat, as it were, in return for all this he now found himself alone,\nput to shame, a laughing-stock, needed by no one, and despised by\neveryone": 60, "For the first two days after his wife's departure Alexey Alexandrovitch\nreceived applicants for assistance and his chief secretary, drove to\nthe committee, and went down to dinner in the dining-room as usual": 33, 'Without giving himself a reason for what he was doing, he strained\nevery nerve of his being for those two days, simply to preserve an\nappearance of composure, and even of indifference': 32, "Answering inquiries\nabout the disposition of Anna Arkadyevna's rooms and belongings, he had\nexercised immense self-control to appear like a man in whose eyes what\nhad occurred was not unforeseen nor out of the ordinary course of\nevents, and he attained his aim: no one could have detected in him\nsigns of despair": 53, "But on the second day after her departure, when\nKorney gave him a bill from a fashionable draper's shop, which Anna had\nforgotten to pay, and announced that the clerk from the shop was\nwaiting, Alexey Alexandrovitch told him to show the clerk up": 44, '"Excuse me, your excellency, for venturing to trouble you': 9, 'But if you\ndirect us to apply to her excellency, would you graciously oblige us\nwith her address': 18, '"\n\nAlexey Alexandrovitch pondered, as it seemed to the clerk, and all at\nonce, turning round, he sat down at the table': 22, 'Letting his head sink\ninto his hands, he sat for a long while in that position, several times\nattempted to speak and stopped short': 24, "Korney, perceiving his master's\nemotion, asked the clerk to call another time": 12, 'Left alone, Alexey\nAlexandrovitch recognized that he had not the strength to keep up the\nline of firmness and composure any longer': 22, 'He gave orders for the\ncarriage that was awaiting him to be taken back, and for no one to be\nadmitted, and he did not go down to dinner': 29, 'He felt that he could not endure the weight of universal contempt and\nexasperation, which he had distinctly seen in the face of the clerk and\nof Korney, and of everyone, without exception, whom he had met during\nthose two days': 41, 'He felt that he could not turn aside from himself the\nhatred of men, because that hatred did not come from his being bad (in\nthat case he could have tried to be better), but from his being\nshamefully and repulsively unhappy': 42, 'He knew that for this, for the very\nfact that his heart was torn with grief, they would be merciless to\nhim': 22, 'He felt that men would crush him as dogs strangle a torn dog\nyelping with pain': 16, 'He knew that his sole means of security against\npeople was to hide his wounds from them, and instinctively he tried to\ndo this for two days, but now he felt incapable of keeping up the\nunequal struggle': 38, 'His despair was even intensified by the consciousness that he was\nutterly alone in his sorrow': 16, 'In all Petersburg there was not a human\nbeing to whom he could express what he was feeling, who would feel for\nhim, not as a high official, not as a member of society, but simply as\na suffering man; indeed he had not such a one in the whole world': 51, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch grew up an orphan': 6, 'There were two brothers': 4, 'They\ndid not remember their father, and their mother died when Alexey\nAlexandrovitch was ten years old': 17, 'The property was a small one': 6, 'Their\nuncle, Karenin, a government official of high standing, at one time a\nfavorite of the late Tsar, had brought them up': 22, "On completing his high school and university courses with medals,\nAlexey Alexandrovitch had, with his uncle's aid, immediately started in\na prominent position in the service, and from that time forward he had\ndevoted himself exclusively to political ambition": 39, 'In the high school\nand the university, and afterwards in the service, Alexey\nAlexandrovitch had never formed a close friendship with anyone': 22, "His\nbrother had been the person nearest to his heart, but he had a post in\nthe Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and was always abroad, where he had\ndied shortly after Alexey Alexandrovitch's marriage": 34, "While he was governor of a province, Anna's aunt, a wealthy provincial\nlady, had thrown him—middle-aged as he was, though young for a\ngovernor—with her niece, and had succeeded in putting him in such a\nposition that he had either to declare himself or to leave the town": 48, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch was not long in hesitation': 7, 'There were at the\ntime as many reasons for the enthusiastic fervor': 8, 'He was a believer, who was interested in\nreligion primarily in its political aspect, and the new doctrine which\nventured upon several new interpretations, just because it paved the\nway to discussion and analysis, was in principle disagreeable to him': 40, 'He had hitherto taken up a cold and even antagonistic attitude to this\nnew doctrine, and with Countess Lidia cheeks, she told him that his\nfather was a saint and his mother was dead": 32, 'Countess Lidia Ivanovna kept her promise': 6, "She did actually take upon\nherself the care of the organization and
