quietly and discreetly reported to his master while he was dressing\nall it was necessary for him to know": 56, "But Lidia Ivanovna's help was\nnone the less real; she gave Alexey Alexandrovitch moral support in the\nconsciousness of her love and respect for him, and still more, as it\nwas soothing to her to believe, in that she almost turned him to\nChristianity—that is, from an indifferent and apathetic believer she\nturned him into an ardent and steadfast adherent of the new\ninterpretation of Christian doctrine, which had been gaining ground of\nlate in Petersburg": 76, 'It was easy for Alexey Alexandrovitch to believe in\nthis teaching': 11, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch, like Lidia Ivanovna indeed, and\nothers who shared their views, was completely devoid of vividness of\nimagination, that spiritual faculty in virtue of which the conceptions\nevoked by the imagination become so vivid that they must needs be in\nharmony with other conceptions, and with actual fact': 49, 'He saw nothing\nimpossible and inconceivable in the idea that death, though existing\nfor unbelievers, did not exist for him, and that, as he was possessed\nof the most perfect faith, of the measure of which he was himself the\njudge, therefore there was no sin in his soul, and he was experiencing\ncomplete salvation here on earth': 58, 'It is true that the erroneousness and shallowness of this conception of\nhis faith was dimly perceptible to Alexey Alexandrovitch, and he knew\nthat when, without the slightest idea that his forgiveness was the\naction of a higher power, he had surrendered directly to the feeling of\nforgiveness, he had felt more happiness than now when he was thinking\nevery instant that Christ was in his heart, and that in signing\nofficial papers he was doing His will': 78, 'But for Alexey Alexandrovitch it\nwas a necessity to think in that way; it was such a necessity for him\nin his humiliation to have some elevated standpoint, however imaginary,\nfrom which, looked down upon by all, he could look down on others, that\nhe clung, as to his one salvation, to his delusion of salvation': 56, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 23 PART FIVE', {'The Countess Lidia Ivanovna had, as a very young and sentimental girl,\nbeen married to a wealthy man of high rank, an extremely good-natured,\njovial, and extremely dissipated rake': 29, "Two months after marriage her\nhusband abandoned her, and her impassioned protestations of affection\nhe met with a sarcasm and even hostility that people knowing the\ncount's good heart, and seeing no defects in the sentimental Lidia,\nwere at a loss to explain": 43, 'Though they were divorced and lived apart,\nyet whenever the husband met the wife, he invariably behaved to her\nwith the same malignant irony, the cause of which was incomprehensible': 30, 'Countess Lidia Ivanovna had long given up being in love with her\nhusband, but from that time she had never given up being in love with\nsomeone': 27, 'She was in love with several people at once, both men and\nwomen; she had been in love with almost everyone who had been\nparticularly distinguished in any way': 29, 'She was in love with all the new\nprinces and princesses who married into the imperial family; she had\nbeen in love with a high dignitary of the Church, a vicar, and a parish\npriest; she had been in love with a journalist, three Slavophiles, with\nKomissarov, with a minister, a doctor, an English missionary and\nKarenin': 57, 'All these passions constantly waning or growing more ardent,\ndid not prevent her from keeping up the most extended and complicated\nrelations with the court and fashionable society': 28, "But from the time\nthat after Karenin's trouble she took him under her special protection,\nfrom the time that she set to work in Karenin's household looking after\nhis welfare, she felt that all her other attachments were not the real\nthing, and that she was now genuinely in love, and with no one but\nKarenin": 56, 'The feeling she now experienced for him seemed to her stronger\nthan any of her former feelings': 17, 'Analyzing her feeling, and comparing\nit with former passions, she distinctly perceived that she would not\nhave been in love with Komissarov if he had not saved the life of the\nTsar, that she would not have been in love with Ristitch-Kudzhitsky if\nthere had been no Slavonic question, but that she loved Karenin for\nhimself, for his lofty, uncomprehended soul, for the sweet—to her—high\nnotes of his voice, for his drawling intonation, his weary eyes, his\ncharacter, and his soft white hands with their swollen veins': 87, 'She was\nnot simply overjoyed at meeting him, but she sought in his face signs\nof the impression she was making on him': 23, 'She tried to please him, not\nby her words only, but in her whole person': 15, 'For his sake it was that\nshe now lavished more care on her dress than before': 16, 'She caught herself\nin reveries on what might have been, if she had not been married and he\nhad been free': 21, 'She blushed with emotion when he came into the room, she\ncould not repress a smile of rapture when he said anything amiable to\nher': 25, 'For several days now Countess Lidia Ivanovna had been in a state of\nintense excitement': 15, 'She had learned that Anna and Vronsky were in\nPetersburg': 10, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch must be saved from seeing her, he\nmust be saved even from the torturing knowledge that that awful woman\nwas in the same town with him, and that he might meet her any minute': 36, 'Lidia Ivanovna made inquiries through her friends as to what those\n_infamous people_, as she called Anna and Vronsky, intended doing, and\nshe endeavored so to guide every movement of her friend during those\ndays that he could not come across them': 42, 'The young adjutant, an\nacquaintance of Vronsky, through whom she obtained her information, and\nwho hoped through Countess Lidia Ivanovna to obtain a concession, told\nher that they had finished their business and were going away next day': 38, 'Lidia Ivanovna had already begun to calm down, when the next morning a\nnote was brought her, the handwriting of which she recognized with\nhorror': 25, 'It was the handwriting of Anna Karenina': 7, 'The envelope was of\npaper as thick as bark; on the oblong yellow paper there was a huge\nmonogram, and the letter smelt of agreeable scent': 26, '"Who brought it': 3, '"\n\n"A commissionaire from the hotel': 6, '"\n\nIt was some time before Countess Lidia Ivanovna could sit down to read\nthe letter': 16, 'Her excitement brought on an attack of asthma, to which she\nwas subject': 13, 'When she had recovered her composure, she read the\nfollowing letter in French:\n\n\n\n\n\n"Madame la Comtesse,\n\n"The Christian feelings with which your heart is filled give me the, I\nfeel, unpardonable boldness to write to you': 36, 'I am miserable at being\nseparated from my son': 9, 'I entreat permission to see him once before my\ndeparture': 10, 'Forgive me for recalling myself to your memory': 8, 'I apply to\nyou and not to Alexey Alexandrovitch, simply because I do not wish to\ncause that generous man to suffer in remembering me': 25, 'Knowing your\nfriendship for him, I know you will understand me': 11, 'Could you send\nSeryozha to me, or should I come to the course of that year that his career was at\nan end': 44, 'He still filled a position of consequence, he sat on many\ncommissions and committees, but he was a man whose day was over, and\nfrom whom nothing was expected': 29, 'Whatever he said, whatever he proposed,\nwas heard as though it were something long familiar, and the very thing\nthat was not needed': 23, 'But Alexey Alexandrovitch was not aware of this,\nand, on the contrary, being cut off from direct participation in\ngovernmental activity, he saw more clearly than ever the errors and\ndefects in the action of others, and thought it his duty to point out\nmeans for their correction': 48, 'Shortly after his separation from his wife,\nhe began writing his first note on the new judicial procedure, the\nfirst of the endless series of notes he was destined to write in the\nfuture': 34, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch did not merely fail to observe his hopeless\nposition in the official world, he was not merely free from anxiety on\nthis head, he was positively more satisfied than ever with his own\nactivity': 36, '"He that is unmarried careth for the things that belong to the Lord,\nhow he may please the Lord: but he that is married careth for the\nthings that are of the world, how he may please his wife," says the\nApostle Paul, and Alexey Alexandrovitch, who was now guided in every\naction by Scripture, often recalled this text': 59, 'It seemed to him that\never since he had been left without a wife, he had in these very\nprojects of reform been serving the Lord more zealously than before': 30, 'The unmistakable something, and the more adorned the better': 16, 'Now, on\nthe contrary, she was perforce decked out in a way so inconsistent with\nher age and her figure, that her one anxiety was to contrive that ('TOL CHAPTER 27 PART FIVE', {"After the lesson with the grammar teacher came his father's lesson": 11, 'While waiting for his father, Seryozha sat at the table playing with a\npenknife, and fell to dreaming': 18, "Among Seryozha's favorite occupations\nwas searching for his mother during his walks": 12, 'He did not believe in\ndeath generally, and in her death in particular, in spite of what Lidia\nIvanovna had told him and his father had confirmed, and it was just\nbecause of that, and after he had been told she was dead, that he had\nbegun looking for her when out for a walk': 55, 'Every woman of full,\ngraceful figure with dark hair was his mother': 12, 'At the sight of such a\nwoman such a feeling of tenderness was stirred within him that his\nbreath failed him, and tears came into his eyes': 27, 'And he was on the\ntiptoe of expectation that she would come up to him, would lift her\nveil': 19, 'All her face would be visible, she would smile, she would hug\nhim, he would sniff her fragrance, feel the softness of her arms, and\ncry with happiness, just as he had one evening lain on her lap while\nshe tickled him, and he laughed and bit her white, ring-covered\nfingers': 51, 'Later, when he accidentally learned from his old nurse that\nhis mother was not dead, and his father and Lidia Ivanovna had\nexplained to him that she was dead to him because she was wicked (which\nhe could not possibly believe, because he loved her), he went on\nseeking her and expecting her in the same way': 57, 'That day in the public\ngardens there had been a lady in a lilac veil, whom he had watched with\na throbbing heart, believing it to be she as she came towards them\nalong the path': 36, 'The lady had not come up to them, but had disappeared\nsomewhere': 12, 'That day, more intensely than ever, Seryozha felt a rush of\nlove for her, and now, waiting for his father, he forgot everything,\nand cut all round the edge of the table with his penknife, staring\nstraight before him with sparkling eyes and dreaming of her': 46, '"Here is your papa': 4, '" said Vassily Lukitch, rousing him': 6, 'Seryozha jumped up and went up to his father, and kissing his hand,\nlooked at him intently, trying to discover signs of his joy at\nreceiving the Alexander Nevsky': 29, '"Did you have a nice walk': 6, '" said Alexey Alexandrovitch, sitting down in\nhis easy chair, pulling the volume of the Old Testament to him and\nopening it': 22, 'Although Alexey Alexandrovitch had more than once told\nSeryozha that every Christian ought to know Scripture history\nthoroughly, he often referred to the Bible himself during the lesson,\nand Seryozha observed this': 32, '"Yes, it was very nice indeed, papa," said Seryozha, sitting sideways\non his chair and rocking it, which was forbidden': 20, '"I saw Nadinka"\n(Nadinka was a niece of Lidia Ivanovna\'s who was being brought up in\nher house)': 18, '"She told me you\'d been given a new star': 9, 'Are you glad,\npapa': 4, '"\n\n"First of all, don\'t rock your chair, please," said Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 12, '"And secondly, it\'s not the reward that\'s precious, but\nthe work itself': 12, 'And I could have wished you understood that': 8, 'If you\nnow are going to work, to study in order to win a reward, then the work\nwill seem hard to you; but when you work" (Alexey Alexandrovitch, as he\nspoke, thought of how he had been sustained by a sense of duty through\nthe wearisome labor of the morning, consisting of signing one hundred\nand eighty papers), "loving your work, you will find your reward in\nit': 69, '"\n\nSeryozha\'s eyes, that had been shining with gaiety and tenderness, grew\ndull and dropped before his father\'s gaze': 19, 'This was the same\nlong-familiar tone his father always took with him, and Seryozha had\nlearned by now to fall in with it': 23, 'His father always talked to him—so\nSeryozha felt—as though he were addressing some boy of his own\nimagination, one of those boys that exist in books, utterly unlike\nhimself': 29, 'And Seryozha always tried with his father to act being the\nstory-book boy': 13, '"You understand that, I hope': 5, '" said his father': 4, '"Yes, papa," answered Seryozha, acting the part of the imaginary boy': 11, 'The lesson consisted of learning by heart several verses out of the\nGospel and the repetition of the beginning of the Old Testament': 23, "The\nverses from the Gospel Seryozha knew fairly well, but at the moment\nwhen he was saying them he became so absorbed in watching the sharply\nprotruding, bony knobbiness of his father's forehead, that he lost the\nthread, and he transposed the end of one verse and the beginning of\nanother": 51, 'So it was evident to Alexey Alexandrovitch that he did not\nunderstand what he was saying, and that irritated him': 20, 'He frowned, and began explaining what Seryozha had heard many times\nbefore and never could remember, because he understood it too well,\njust as that "suddenly" is an adverb of manner of action': 33, 'Seryozha\nlooked with scared eyes at his father, and could think of nothing but\nwhether his father would make him repeat what he had said, as he\nsometimes did': 29, 'And this thought so alarmed Seryozha that he now\nunderstood nothing': 11, 'But his father did not make him repeat it, and\npassed on to the lesson out of the Old Testament': 20, 'Seryozha recounted\nthe events themselves well enough, but when he had to answer questions\nas to what certain events prefigured, he knew nothing, though he had\nalready been punished over this lesson': 32, 'The passage at which he was\nutterly unable to say anything, and began fidgeting and cutting the\ntable and swinging his chair, was where he had to repeat the patriarchs\nbefore the Flood': 33, 'He did not know one of them, except Enoch, who had\nbeen taken up alive to heaven': 17, "Last time he had remembered their names,\nbut now he had forgotten them utterly, chiefly because Enoch was the\npersonage he liked best in the whole of the Old Testament, and Enoch's\ntranslation to heaven was connected in his mind with a whole long train\nof thought, in which he became absorbed now while he gazed with\nfascinated eyes at his father's watch-chain and a half-unbuttoned\nbutton on his waistcoat": 70, 'In death, of which they talked to him so often, Seryozha disbelieved\nentirely': 13, 'He did not believe that those he loved could die, above all\nthat he himself would die': 17, 'That was to him something utterly\ninconceivable and impossible': 9, 'But he had been told that all men die; he\nhad asked people, indeed, whom he trusted, and they too, had confirmed\nit; his old nurse, too, said the same, though reluctantly': 32, 'But Enoch\nhad not died, and so it followed that everyone did not die': 14, '"And why\ncannot anyone else so serve God and be taken alive to heaven': 14, '" thought\nSeryozha': 3, 'Bad people, that is those Seryozha did not like, they might\ndie, but the good might all be like Enoch': 20, '"Well, what are the names of the patriarchs': 8, '"\n\n"Enoch, Enos—"\n\n"But you have said that already': 9, 'This is bad, Seryozha, very bad': 6, 'If\nyou don\'t try to learn what is more necessary than anything for a\nChristian," said his father, getting up, "whatever can interest you': 24, 'I\nam displeased with you, and Piotr Ignatitch" (this was the most\nimportant of his teachers) "is displeased with you': 20, 'I shall have to\npunish you': 6, '"\n\nHis father and his teacher were both displeased with Seryozha, and he\ncertainly did learn his lessons very badly': 20, 'But still it could not be\nsaid he was a stupid boy': 12, 'On the contrary, he was far cleverer than the\nboys his teacher held up as examples to Seryozha': 18, "In his father's\nopinion, he did not want to learn what he was taught": 14, 'In reality he\ncould not learn that': 7, 'He could not, because the claims of his own soul\nwere more binding on him than those claims his father and his teacher\nmade upon him': 26, 'Those claims were in opposition, and he was in direct\nconflict with his education': 14, 'He was nine years old; he was a child; but\nhe knew his own soul, it was precious to him, he guarded it as the\neyelid guards the eye, and without the key of love he let no one into\nhis soul': 42, 'His teachers complained that he would not learn, while his\nsoul was brimming over with thirst for knowledge': 18, 'And he learned from\nKapitonitch, from his nurse, from Nadinka, from Vassily Lukitch, but\nnot from his teachers': 18, 'The spring his father and his teachers reckoned\nupon to turn their mill-wheels had long dried up at the source, but its\nwaters did their work in another channel': 29, "His father punished Seryozha by not letting him go to see Nadinka,\nLidia Ivanovna's niece; but this punishment turned out happily for\nSeryozha": 23, 'Vassily Lukitch was in a good humor, and showed him how to\nmake windmills': 14, 'The whole evening passed over this work and in dreaming\nhow to make a windmill on which he could turn himself—clutching at the\nsails or tying himself on and whirling round': 31, 'Of his mother Seryozha\ndid not think all the evening, but when he had gone to bed, he suddenly\nremembered her, and prayed in his own words that his mother tomorrow\nfor his birthday might leave off hiding herself and come to him': 43, '"Vassily Lukitch, do you know what I prayed for tonight extra besides\nthe regular things': 15, '"\n\n"That you might learn your lessons better': 8, '"\n\n"No': 2, '"\n\n"Toys': 2, "You'll never guess": 3, "A splendid thing; but it's a secret": 7, "When it\ncomes to pass I'll tell you": 8, "Can't you guess": 3, '"\n\n"No, I can\'t guess': 5, 'You tell me," said Vassily Lukitch with a smile,\nwhich was rare with him': 14, '"Come, lie down, I\'m putting out the candle': 8, '"\n\n"Without the candle I can see better what I see and what I prayed for': 16, 'There': 1, 'I was almost telling the secret': 6, '" said Seryozha, laughing gaily': 5, 'When the candle was taken away, Seryozha heard and felt his mother': 12, 'She\nstood over him, and with loving eyes caressed him': 10, 'But then came\nwindmills, a knife, everything began to be mixed up, and he fell\nasleep': 16, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 28 PART FIVE', {'On arriving in Petersburg, Vronsky and Anna stayed at one of the best\nhotels; Vronsky apart in a lower story, Anna above with her child, its\nnurse, and her maid, in a large suite of four rooms': 37, "On the day of his arrival Vronsky went to his brother's": 11, 'There he found\nhis mother, who had come from Moscow on business': 12, 'His mother and\nsister-in-law greeted him as usual: they asked him about his stay\nabroad, and talked of their common acquaintances, but did not let drop\na single word in allusion to his connection with Anna': 36, 'His brother came\nthe next morning to see Vronsky, and of his own accord asked him about\nher, and Alexey Vronsky told him directly that he looked upon his\nconnection with Madame Karenina as marriage; that he hoped to arrange a\ndivorce, and then to marry her, and until then he considered her as\nmuch a wife as any other wife, and he begged him to tell their mother\nand his wife so': 73, '"If the world disapproves, I don\'t care," said Vronsky; "but if my\nrelations want to be on terms of relationship with me, they will have\nto be on the same terms with my wife': 34, '"\n\nThe elder brother, who had always a respect for his younger brother\'s\njudgment, could not well tell whether he was right or not till the\nworld had decided the question; for his part he had nothing against it,\nand with Alexey he went up to see Anna': 48, "Before his brother, as before everyone, Vronsky addressed Anna with a\ncertain formality, treating her as he might a very intimate friend, but\nit was understood that his brother knew their real relations, and they\ntalked about Anna's going to Vronsky's estate": 42, 'In spite of all his social experience Vronsky was, in consequence of\nthe new position in which he was placed, laboring under a strange\nmisapprehension': 25, 'One would have thought he must have understood that\nsociety was closed for him and Anna; but now some vague ideas had\nsprung up in his brain that this was only the case in old-fashioned\ndays, and that now with the rapidity of modern progress (he had\nunconsciously become by now a partisan of every sort of progress) the\nviews of society had changed, and that the question whether they would\nbe received in society was not a foregone conclusion': 80, '"Of course," he\nthought, "she would not be received at court, but intimate friends can\nand must look at it in the proper light': 24, '" One may sit for several hours\nat a stretch with one\'s legs crossed in the same position, if one knows\nthat there\'s nothing to prevent one\'s changing one\'s position; but if a\nman knows that he must remain sitting so with crossed legs, then cramps\ncome on, the legs begin to twitch and to strain towards the spot to\nwhich one would like to draw them': 67, 'This was what Vronsky was\nexperiencing in regard to the world': 11, 'Though at the bottom of his heart\nhe knew that the world was shut on them, he put it to the test whether\nthe world had not changed by now and would not receive them': 35, 'But he\nvery quickly perceived that though the world was open for him\npersonally, it was closed for Anna': 19, 'Just as in the game of cat and\nmouse, the hands raised for him were dropped to bar the way for Anna': 22, 'One of the first ladies of Petersburg society whom Vronsky saw was his\ncousin Betsy': 15, '"At last': 2, '" she greeted him joyfully': 5, '"And Anna': 2, 'How glad I am': 4, 'Where\nare you stopping': 4, 'I can fancy after your delightful travels you must\nfind our poor Petersburg horrid': 14, 'I can fancy your honeymoon in Rome': 7, 'How about the divorce': 4, 'Is that all over': 4, '"\n\nVronsky noticed that Betsy\'s enthusiasm waned when she learned that no\ndivorce had as yet taken place': 18, '"People will throw stones at me, I know," she said, "but I shall come\nand see Anna; yes, I shall certainly come': 22, "You won't be here long, I\nsuppose": 7, '"\n\nAnd she did certainly come to see Anna the same day, but her tone was\nnot at all the same as in former days': 25, 'She unmistakably prided herself\non her courage, and wished Anna to appreciate the fidelity of her\nfriendship': 17, 'She only stayed ten minutes, talking of society gossip, and\non leaving she said:\n\n"You\'ve never told me when the divorce is to be': 24, "Supposing I'm ready to\nfling my cap over the mill, other starchy people will give you the cold\nshoulder until you're married": 22, "And that's so simple nowadays": 5, '_Ça se\nfait_': 3, "So you're going on Friday": 5, "Sorry we shan't see each other\nagain": 7, '"\n\nFrom Betsy\'s tone Vronsky might have grasped what he had to expect from\nthe world; but he made another effort in his own family': 25, 'His mother he\ndid not reckon upon': 7, "He knew that his mother, who had been so\nenthusiastic over Anna at their first acquaintance, would have no mercy\non her now for having ruined her son's career": 29, "But he had more hope of\nVarya, his brother's wife": 10, 'He fancied she would not throw stones, and\nwould go simply and directly to see Anna, and would receive her in her\nown house': 24, 'The day after his arrival Vronsky went to her, and finding her alone,\nexpressed his wishes directly': 17, '"You know, Alexey," she said after hearing him, "how fond I am of you,\nand how ready I am to do anything for you; but I have not spoken,\nbecause I knew I could be of no use to you and to Anna Arkadyevna," she\nsaid, articulating the name "Anna Arkadyevna" with particular care': 54, '"Don\'t suppose, please, that I judge her': 7, 'Never; perhaps in her place I\nshould have done the same': 11, 'I don\'t and can\'t enter into that," she\nsaid, glancing timidly at his gloomy face': 15, '"But one must call things by\ntheir names': 8, 'You want me to go and see her, to ask her here, and to\nrehabilitate her in society; but do understand that _I cannot_ do so': 26, "I\nhave daughters growing up, and I must live in the world for my\nhusband's sake": 16, "Well, I'm ready to come and see Anna Arkadyevna: she\nwill understand that I can't ask her here, or I should have to do so in\nsuch a way that she would not meet people who look at things\ndifferently; that would offend her": 44, "I can't raise her": 4, '"\n\n"Oh, I don\'t regard her as fallen more than hundreds of women you do\nreceive': 16, '" Vronsky interrupted her still more gloomily, and he got up in\nsilence, understanding that his sister-in-law\'s decision was not to be\nshaken': 23, '"Alexey': 1, "don't be angry with me": 5, 'Please understand that I\'m not to\nblame," began Varya, looking at him with a timid smile': 16, '"I\'m not angry with you," he said still as gloomily; "but I\'m sorry in\ntwo ways': 16, "I'm sorry, too, that this means breaking up our friendship—if\nnot breaking up, at least weakening it": 17, 'You will understand that for\nme, too, it cannot be otherwise': 11, '"\n\nAnd with that he left her': 7, 'Vronsky knew that further efforts were useless, and that he had to\nspend these few days in Petersburg as though in a strange town,\navoiding every sort of relation with his own old circle in order not to\nbe exposed to the annoyances and humiliations which were so intolerable\nto him': 51, 'One of the most unpleasant features of his position in\nPetersburg was that Alexey Alexandrovitch and his name seemed to meet\nhim everywhere': 23, 'He could not begin to talk of anything without the\nconversation turning on Alexey Alexandrovitch; he could not go anywhere\nwithout risk of meeting him': 25, 'So at least it seemed to Vronsky, just as\nit seems to a man with a sore finger that he is continually, as though\non purpose, grazing his sore finger on everything': 32, 'Their stay in Petersburg was the more painful to Vronsky that he\nperceived all the time a sort of new mood that he could not understand\nin Anna': 28, 'At one time she would seem in love with him, and then she\nwould become cold, irritable, and impenetrable': 19, 'She was worrying over\nsomething, and keeping something back from him, and did not seem to\nnotice the humiliations which poisoned his existence, and for her, with\nher delicate intuition, must have been still more unbearable': 36, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 29 PART FIVE', {"One of Anna's objects in coming back to Russia had been to see her son": 15, 'From the day she left Italy the thought of it had never ceased to\nagitate her': 16, 'And as she got nearer to Petersburg, the delight and\nimportance of this meeting grew ever greater in her imagination': 20, 'She\ndid not even put to herself the question how to arrange it': 13, 'It seemed\nto her natural and simple to see her son when she should be in the same\ntown with him': 21, 'But on her arrival in Petersburg she was suddenly made\ndistinctly aware of her present position in society, and she grasped\nthe fact that to arrange this meeting was no easy matter': 32, 'She had now been two days in Petersburg': 8, 'The thought of her son never\nleft her for a single instant, but she had not yet seen him': 19, 'To go\nstraight to the house, where she might meet Alexey Alexandrovitch, that\nshe felt she had no right to do': 21, 'She might be refused admittance and\ninsulted': 7, 'To write and so enter into relations with her husband—that it\nmade her miserable to think of doing; she could only be at peace when\nshe did not think of her husband': 32, 'To get a glimpse of her son out\nwalking, finding out where and when he went out, was not enough for\nher; she had so looked forward to this meeting, she had so much she\nmust say to him, she so longed to embrace him, to kiss him': 48, "Seryozha's\nold nurse might be a help to her and show her what to do": 15, "But the nurse\nwas not now living in Alexey Alexandrovitch's house": 11, 'In this\nuncertainty, and in efforts to find the nurse, two days had slipped by': 15, "Hearing of the close intimacy between Alexey Alexandrovitch and\nCountess Lidia Ivanovna, Anna decided on the third letter were shown to her husband, he\nwould keep up his character of magnanimity, and would not refuse her\nrequest': 25, 'The commissionaire who took the letter had brought her back the most\ncruel and unexpected answer, that there was no answer': 21, 'She had never\nfelt so humiliated as at the moment when, sending for the\ncommissionaire, she heard from him the exact account of how he had\nwaited, and how afterwards he had been told there was no answer': 38, 'Anna\nfelt humiliated, insulted, but she saw that from her point of view\nCountess Lidia Ivanovna was right': 18, 'Her suffering was the more poignant\nthat she had to bear it in solitude': 14, 'She could not and would not share\nit with Vronsky': 10, 'She knew that to him, although he was the primary\ncause of her distress, the question of her seeing her son would seem a\nmatter of very little consequence': 29, 'She knew that he would never be\ncapable of understanding all the depth of her suffering, that for his\ncool tone at any allusion to it she would begin to hate him': 32, 'And she\ndreaded that more than anything in the world, and so she hid from him\neverything that related to her son': 22, 'Spending the whole day at home she\nconsidered ways of seeing her son, and had reached a decision to write\nto her husband': 23, 'She was just composing this letter when she was handed\nthe letter from Lidia Ivanovna': 15, "The countess's silence had subdued and\ndepressed her, but the letter, all that she read between the lines in\nit, so exasperated her, this malice was so revolting beside her\npassionate, legitimate tenderness for her son, that she turned against\nother people and left off blaming herself": 47, '"This coldness—this pretense of feeling': 5, '" she said to herself': 5, '"They\nmust needs insult me and torture the child, and I am to submit to it': 16, 'Not on any consideration': 4, 'She is worse than I am': 6, "I don't lie, anyway": 4, '"\nAnd she decided on the spot that next day, Seryozha\'s birthday, she\nwould go straight to her husband\'s house, bribe or deceive the\nservants, but at any cost see her son and overturn the hideous\ndeception with which they were encompassing the unhappy child': 45, 'She went to a toy shop, bought toys and thought over a plan of action': 15, "She would go early in the morning at eight o'clock, when Alexey\nAlexandrovitch 'Often as she had dreamed of\nit, she could never think of anything': 13, "The next day, at eight o'clock in the morning, Anna got out of a hired\nsledge and rang at the front entrance of her former ('TOL CHAPTER 30 PART FIVE', {'Meanwhile Vassily Lukitch had not at first understood who this lady\nwas, and had learned from their conversation that it was no other\nperson than the mother who had left her husband, and whom he had not\nseen, as he had entered the house after her departure': 47, 'He was in doubt\nwhether to go in or not, or whether to communicate with Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 17, 'Reflecting finally that his duty was to get Seryozha up\nat the hour fixed, and that it was therefore not his business to\nconsider who was there, the mother or anyone else, but simply to do his\nduty, he finished dressing, went to the door and opened it': 48, 'But the embraces of the mother and child, the sound of their voices,\nand what they were saying, made him change his mind': 23, 'He shook his head, and with a sigh he closed the door': 12, '"I\'ll wait\nanother ten minutes," he said to himself, clearing his throat and\nwiping away tears': 16, 'Among the servants of the household there was intense excitement all\nthis time': 13, "All had heard that their mistress had come, and that\nKapitonitch had let her in, and that she was even now in the nursery,\nand that their master always went in person to the nursery at nine\no'clock, and everyone fully comprehended that it was impossible for the\nhusband and wife to meet, and that they must prevent it": 59, "Korney, the\nvalet, going down to the hall-porter's room, asked who had let her in,\nand how it was he had done so, and ascertaining that Kapitonitch had\nadmitted her and shown her up, he gave the old man a talking-to": 41, 'The\nhall-porter was doggedly silent, but when Korney told him he ought to\nbe sent away, Kapitonitch darted up to him, and waving his hands in\nKorney\'s face, began:\n\n"Oh yes, to be sure you\'d not have let her in': 40, "After ten years'\nservice, and never a word but of kindness, and there you'd up and say,\n‘Be off, go along, get away with you": 25, "' Oh yes, you're a shrewd one at\npolitics, I dare say": 12, "You don't need to be taught how to swindle the\nmaster, and to filch fur coats": 16, '"\n\n"Soldier': 2, '" said Korney contemptuously, and he turned to the downhill, and had turned\nover three times': 30, 'She was listening to the sound of his voice, watching\nhis face and the play of expression on it, touching his hand, but she\ndid not follow what he was saying': 31, 'She must go, she must leave\nhim,—this was the only thing she was thinking and feeling': 16, 'She heard\nthe steps of Vassily Lukitch coming up to the door and coughing; she\nheard, too, the steps of the nurse as she came near; but she sat like\none turned to stone, incapable of beginning to speak or to get up': 43, '"Mistress, darling': 2, '" began the nurse, going up to Anna something': 15, 'He would have liked to\nput a question that would have set at rest this doubt, but he did not\ndare; he saw that she was miserable, and he felt for her': 32, 'Silently he\npressed close to her and whispered, "Don\'t go yet': 11, "He won't come just\nyet": 5, '"\n\nThe mother held him away from her to see what he was thinking, what to\nsay to him, and in his frightened face she 12, 'At that moment the door opened': 6, 'Vassily Lukitch came in': 4, 'At the other door there was the sound of steps, and the nurse in a\nscared whisper said, "He\'s coming," and gave Anna her hat': 25, 'Seryozha sank onto the bed and sobbed, hiding his face in his hands': 13, 'Anna removed his hands, once more kissed his wet face, and with rapid\nsteps went to the door': 18, 'Alexey Alexandrovitch walked in, meeting her': 6, 'Seeing her, he stopped short and bowed his head': 9, 'Although she had just said he was better and kinder than she, in the\nrapid glance she flung at him, taking in his whole figure in all its\ndetails, feelings of repulsion and hatred for him and jealousy over her\nson took possession of her': 45, 'With a swift gesture she put down her veil,\nand, quickening her pace, almost ran out of the room': 19, 'She had not time to undo, and so carried back with her, the parcel of\ntoys she had chosen the day before in a toy shop with such love ('TOL CHAPTER 31 PART FIVE', {'As intensely as Anna had longed to see her son, and long as she had\nbeen thinking of it and preparing herself for it, she had not in the\nleast expected that seeing him would affect her so deeply': 39, 'On getting\nback to her lonely rooms in the hotel she could not for a long while\nunderstand why she was there': 22, '"Yes, it\'s all over, and I am again\nalone," she said to herself, and without taking off her hat she sat\ndown in a low chair by the hearth': 29, 'Fixing her eyes on a bronze clock\nstanding on a table between the windows, she tried to think': 18, 'The French maid brought from abroad came in to suggest she should\ndress': 13, 'She gazed at her wonderingly and said, "Presently': 8, '" A footman\noffered her coffee': 6, '"Later on," she said': 4, 'The Italian nurse, after having taken the baby out in her best, came in\nwith her, and brought her to Anna': 21, 'The plump, well-fed little baby, on\nseeing her mother, as she always did, held out her fat little hands,\nand with a smile on her toothless mouth, began, like a fish with a\nfloat, bobbing her fingers up and down the starched folds of her\nembroidered skirt, making them rustle': 50, 'It was impossible not to smile,\nnot to kiss the baby, impossible not to hold out a finger for her to\nclutch, crowing and prancing all over; impossible not to offer her a\nlip which she sucked into her little mouth by way of a kiss': 46, 'And all\nthis Anna did, and took her in her arms and made her dance, and kissed\nher fresh little cheek and bare little elbows; but at the sight of this\nchild it was plainer than ever to her that the feeling she had for her\ncould not be called love in comparison with what she felt for Seryozha': 59, 'Everything in this baby was charming, but for some reason all this did\nnot go deep to her heart': 19, 'On her first child, though the child of an\nunloved father, had been concentrated all the love that had never found\nsatisfaction': 22, 'Her baby girl had been born in the most painful\ncircumstances and had not had a hundredth part of the care and thought\nwhich had been concentrated on her first child': 31, 'Besides, in the little\ngirl everything was still in the future, while Seryozha was by now\nalmost a personality, and a personality dearly loved': 24, 'In him there was\na conflict of thought and feeling; he would tell him all, and\nthe expressions of love with which he would console her': 40, 'The messenger\nreturned with the answer that he had a visitor with him, but that he\nwould come immediately, and that he asked whether she would let him\nbring with him Prince Yashvin, who had just arrived in Petersburg': 39, '"He\'s not coming alone, and since dinner yesterday he has not seen me,"\nshe thought; "he\'s not coming so that I could tell him everything, but\ncoming with Yashvin': 29, '" And all at once a strange idea came to her: what\nif he had ceased to love her': 19, 'And going over the events ('TOL CHAPTER 32 PART FIVE', {'When Vronsky returned home, Anna was not yet home': 9, 'Soon after he had\nleft, some lady, so they told him, had come to see her, and she had\ngone out with her': 23, ('TOL CHAPTER 33 PART FIVE', {'Vronsky for the first time experienced a feeling of anger against Anna,\nalmost a hatred for her willfully refusing to understand her own\nposition': 24, 'This feeling was aggravated by his being unable to tell her\nplainly the cause of his anger': 17, 'If he had told her directly what he was\nthinking, he would have said:\n\n"In that dress, with a princess only too well known to everyone, to\nshow yourself at the theater is equivalent not merely to acknowledging\nyour position as a fallen woman, but is flinging down a challenge to\nsociety, that is to say, cutting yourself off from it forever': 62, '"\n\nHe could not say that to her': 8, '"But how can she fail to see it, and what\nis going on in her': 15, '" he said to himself': 5, 'He felt at the same time that\nhis respect for her was diminished while his sense of her beauty was\nintensified': 21, 'He went back scowling to his rooms, and sitting down beside Yashvin,\nwho, with his long legs stretched out on a chair, was drinking brandy\nand seltzer water, he ordered a glass of the same for himself': 37, '"You were talking of Lankovsky\'s Powerful': 6, 'That\'s a fine horse, and I\nwould advise you to buy him," said Yashvin, glancing at his comrade\'s\ngloomy face': 20, '"His hind-quarters aren\'t quite first-rate, but the legs\nand head—one couldn\'t wish for anything better': 15, '"\n\n"I think I will take him," answered Vronsky': 9, 'Their conversation about horses interested him, but he did not for an\ninstant forget Anna, and could not help listening to the sound of steps\nin the corridor and looking at the clock on the chimney piece': 37, '"Anna Arkadyevna gave orders to announce that she has gone to the\ntheater': 13, '"\n\nYashvin, tipping another glass of brandy into the bubbling water, drank\nit and got up, buttoning his coat': 19, '"Well, let\'s go," he said, faintly smiling under his mustache, and\nshowing by this smile that he knew the cause of Vronsky\'s gloominess,\nand did not attach any significance to it': 31, '"I\'m not going," Vronsky answered gloomily': 6, '"Well, I must, I promised to': 6, 'Good-bye, then': 2, 'If you do, come to the\nstalls; you can take Kruzin\'s stall," added Yashvin as he went out': 18, '"No, I\'m busy': 3, '"\n\n"A wife is a care, but it\'s worse when she\'s not a wife," thought\nYashvin, as he walked out of the hotel': 23, 'Vronsky, left alone, got up from his chair and began pacing up and down\nthe room': 16, '"And what\'s today': 3, 'The fourth night': 3, 'Yegor and his wife are there,\nand my mother, most likely': 11, "Of course all Petersburg's there": 5, "Now she's\ngone in, taken off her cloak and come into the light": 13, 'Tushkevitch,\nYashvin, Princess Varvara," he pictured them to himself': 9, '"What about\nme': 3, "Either that I'm frightened or have given up to Tushkevitch the\nright to protect her": 15, 'From every point of view—stupid, stupid': 6, 'And\nwhy is she putting me in such a position': 10, '" he said with a gesture of\ndespair': 8, 'With that gesture he knocked against the table, on which there was\nstanding the seltzer water and the decanter of brandy, and almost upset\nit': 25, 'He tried to catch it, let it slip, and angrily kicked the table\nover and rang': 16, '"If you care to be in my service," he said to the valet who came in,\n"you had better remember your duties': 22, "This shouldn't be here": 4, 'You ought\nto have cleared away': 6, '"\n\nThe valet, conscious of his own innocence, would have defended himself,\nbut glancing at his master, he saw from his face that the only thing to\ndo was to be silent, and hurriedly threading his way in and out,\ndropped down on the carpet and began gathering up the whole and broken\nglasses and bottles': 56, '"That\'s not your duty; send the waiter to clear away, and get my dress\ncoat out': 16, '"\n\nVronsky went into the theater at half-past eight': 9, 'The performance was\nin full swing': 6, 'The little old box-keeper, recognizing Vronsky as he\nhelped him off with his fur coat, called him "Your Excellency," and\nsuggested he should not take a number but should simply call Fyodor': 32, 'In\nthe brightly lighted corridor there was no one but the box-opener and\ntwo attendants with fur cloaks on their arms listening at the doors': 25, 'Through the closed doors came the sounds of the discreet _staccato_\naccompaniment of the orchestra, and a single female voice rendering\ndistinctly a musical phrase': 25, "The door opened to let the box-opener slip\nthrough, and the phrase drawing to the end reached Vronsky's hearing\nclearly": 20, 'But the doors were closed again at once, and Vronsky did not\nhear the end of the phrase and the cadence of the accompaniment, though\nhe knew from the thunder of applause that it was over': 36, 'When he entered\nthe hall, brilliantly lighted with chandeliers and gas jets, the noise\nwas still going on': 18, 'On the stage the singer, bowing and smiling, with\nbare shoulders flashing with diamonds, was, with the help of the tenor\nwho had given her his arm, gathering up the bouquets that were flying\nawkwardly over the footlights': 38, 'Then she went up to a gentleman with\nglossy pomaded hair parted down the center, who was stretching across\nthe footlights holding out something to her, and all the public in the\nstalls as well as in the boxes was in excitement, craning forward,\nshouting and clapping': 47, 'The conductor in his high chair assisted in\npassing the offering, and straightened his white tie': 16, 'Vronsky walked\ninto the middle of the stalls, and, standing still, began looking about\nhim': 15, 'That day less than ever was his attention turned upon the\nfamiliar, habitual surroundings, the stage, the noise, all the\nfamiliar, uninteresting, particolored herd of spectators in the packed\ntheater': 30, 'There were, as always, the same ladies of some sort with officers of\nsome sort in the back of the boxes; the same gaily dressed women—God\nknows who—and uniforms and black coats; the same dirty crowd in the\nupper gallery; and among the crowd, in the boxes and in the front rows,\nwere some forty of the _real_ people': 59, 'And to those oases Vronsky at\nonce directed his attention, and with them he entered at once into\nrelation': 19, "The act was over when he went in, and so he did not go straight to his\nbrother's box, but going up to the first row of stalls stopped at the\nfootlights with Serpuhovskoy, who, standing with one knee raised and\nhis heel on the footlights, caught sight of him in the distance and\nbeckoned to him, smiling": 58, 'Vronsky had not yet seen Anna': 6, 'He purposely avoided looking in her\ndirection': 7, "But he knew by the direction of people's eyes where she was": 12, 'He looked round discreetly, but he was not seeking her; expecting the\nworst, his eyes sought for Alexey Alexandrovitch': 19, 'To his relief Alexey\nAlexandrovitch was not in the theater that evening': 12, '"How little of the military man there is left in you': 11, '" Serpuhovskoy was\nsaying to him': 6, '"A diplomat, an artist, something of that sort, one\nwould say': 11, '"\n\n"Yes, it was like going back home when I put on a black coat," answered\nVronsky, smiling and slowly taking out his opera-glass': 24, '"Well, I\'ll own I envy you there': 7, 'When I come back from abroad and put\non this," he touched his epaulets, "I regret my freedom': 18, '"\n\nSerpuhovskoy had long given up all hope of Vronsky\'s career, but he\nliked him as before, and was now particularly cordial to him': 24, '"What a pity you were not in time for the first act': 12, '"\n\nVronsky, listening with one ear, moved his opera-glass from the stalls\nand scanned the boxes': 16, "Near a lady in a turban and a bald old man, who\nseemed to wave angrily in the moving opera-glass, Vronsky suddenly\ncaught sight of Anna's head, proud, strikingly beautiful, and smiling\nin the frame of lace": 37, 'She was in the fifth box, twenty paces from him': 10, 'She was sitting in front, and slightly turning, was saying something to\nYashvin': 13, 'The setting of her head on her handsome, broad shoulders, and\nthe restrained excitement and brilliance of her eyes and her whole face\nreminded him of her just as he had seen her at the ball in Moscow': 38, 'But\nhe felt utterly different towards her beauty now': 9, 'In his feeling for\nher now there was no element of mystery, and so her beauty, though it\nattracted him even more intensely than before, gave him now a sense of\ninjury': 32, 'She was not looking in his direction, but Vronsky felt that she\nhad seen him already': 16, 'When Vronsky turned the opera-glass again in that direction, he noticed\nthat Princess Varvara was particularly red, and kept laughing\nunnaturally and looking round at the next box': 28, 'Anna, folding her fan\nand tapping it on the red velvet, was gazing away and did not see, and\nobviously did not wish to see, what was taking place in the next box': 33, "Yashvin's face wore the expression which was common when he was losing\nat cards": 14, 'Scowling, he sucked the left end of his mustache further and\nfurther into his mouth, and cast sidelong glances at the next box': 23, 'In that box on the left were the Kartasovs': 9, 'Vronsky knew them, and knew\nthat Anna was acquainted with them': 11, 'Madame Kartasova, a thin little\nwoman, was standing up in her box, and, her back turned upon Anna, she\nwas putting on a mantle that her husband was holding for her': 31, 'Her face\nwas pale and angry, and she was talking excitedly': 11, 'Kartasov, a fat,\nbald man, was continually looking round at Anna, while he attempted to\nsoothe his wife': 18, "When the wife had gone out, the husband lingered a\nlong while, and tried to catch Anna's eye, obviously anxious to bow to\nher": 24, 'But Anna, with unmistakable intention, avoided noticing him, and\ntalked to Yashvin, whose cropped head was bent down to her': 20, 'Kartasov\nwent out without making his salutation, and the box was left empty': 13, 'Vronsky could not understand exactly what had passed between the\nKartasovs and Anna, but he saw that something humiliating for Anna had\nhappened': 23, 'He knew this both from what he had seen, and most of all from\nthe face of Anna, who, he could see, was taxing every nerve to carry\nthrough the part she had taken up': 35, 'And in maintaining this attitude of\nexternal composure she was completely successful': 12, 'Anyone who did not\nknow her and her circle, who had not heard all the utterances of the\nwomen expressive of commiseration, indignation, and amazement, that she\nshould show herself in society, and show herself so conspicuously with\nher lace and her beauty, would have admired the serenity and loveliness\nof this woman without a suspicion that she was undergoing the\nsensations of a man in the stocks': 68, "Knowing that something had happened, but not knowing precisely what,\nVronsky felt a thrill of agonizing anxiety, and hoping to find out\nsomething, he went towards his brother's box": 29, "Purposely choosing the\nway round furthest from Anna's box, he jostled as he came out against\nthe colonel of his old regiment talking to two acquaintances": 26, 'Vronsky\nheard the name of Madame Karenina, and noticed how the colonel hastened\nto address Vronsky loudly by name, with a meaning glance at his\ncompanions': 26, '"Ah, Vronsky': 2, 'When are you coming to the regiment': 7, "We can't let you off\nwithout a supper": 8, 'You\'re one of glancing ironically, he thought, at him': 22, '"I am a poor judge of music," he said, looking sternly at her': 13, '"Like Prince Yashvin," she said smiling, "who considers that Patti\nsings too loud': 13, '"\n\n"Thank you," she said, her little hand in its long glove taking the\nplaybill Vronsky picked up, and suddenly at that instant her lovely\nface quivered': 27, 'She got up and went into the interior of the box': 11, 'Noticing in the next act that her box was empty, Vronsky, rousing\nindignant "hushes" in the silent audience, went out in the middle of a\nsolo and drove home': 29, 'Anna was already at home': 5, 'When Vronsky went up to her, she was in the\nsame dress as she had worn at the theater': 19, 'She was sitting in the first\narmchair against the wall, looking straight before her': 14, 'She looked at\nhim, and at once resumed her former position': 11, '"Anna," he said': 3, '"You, you are to blame for everything': 7, '" she cried, with tears of\ndespair and hatred in her voice, getting up': 14, '"I begged, I implored you not to go, I knew it would be unpleasant': 14, '"\n\n"Unpleasant': 2, '" she cried—"hideous': 3, 'As long as I live I shall never\nforget it': 10, gradually\nbecame calmer': 27, 'The next day, completely reconciled, they left for the\ncountry': 10, 'PART SIX': 2})
('TOL CHAPTER 1 PART SIX', {"Darya Alexandrovna spent the summer with her children at Pokrovskoe, at\nher sister Kitty Levin's": 15, 'The house on her own estate was quite in\nruins, and Levin and his wife had persuaded her to spend the summer\nwith them': 24, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch greatly approved of the arrangement': 7, 'He\nsaid he was very sorry his official duties prevented him from spending\nthe summer in the country with his family, which would have been the\ngreatest happiness for him; and remaining in Moscow, he came down to\nthe country from time to time for a day or two': 49, 'Besides the Oblonskys,\nwith all their children and their governess, the old princess too came\nto stay that summer with the Levins, as she considered it her duty to\nwatch over her inexperienced daughter in her _interesting condition_': 38, "Moreover, Varenka, Kitty's friend abroad, kept her promise to come to\nKitty when she was married, and stayed with her friend": 21, "All of these\nwere friends or relations of Levin's wife": 10, 'And though he liked them\nall, he rather regretted his own Levin world and ways, which was\nsmothered by this influx of the "Shtcherbatsky element," as he called\nit to himself': 31, 'Of his own relations there stayed with him only Sergey\nIvanovitch, but he too was a man of the Koznishev and not the Levin\nstamp, so that the Levin spirit was utterly obliterated': 33, "In the Levins' house, so long deserted, there were now so many people\nthat almost all the rooms were occupied, and almost every day it\nhappened that the old princess, sitting down to table, counted them all\nover, and put the thirteenth grandson or granddaughter at a separate\ntable": 49, 'And Kitty, with her careful housekeeping, had no little trouble\nto get all the chickens, turkeys, and geese, of which so many were\nneeded to satisfy the summer appetites of the visitors and children': 34, 'The whole family were sitting at dinner': 7, "Dolly's children, with their\ngoverness and Varenka, were making plans for going to look for\nmushrooms": 16, 'Sergey Ivanovitch, who was looked up to by all the party for\nhis intellect and learning, with a respect that almost amounted to awe,\nsurprised everyone by joining in the conversation about mushrooms': 33, '"Take me with you': 4, 'I am very fond of picking mushrooms," he said,\nlooking at Varenka; "I think it\'s a very nice occupation': 19, '"\n\n"Oh, we shall be delighted," answered Varenka, coloring a little': 11, 'Kitty\nexchanged meaningful glances with Dolly': 6, "The proposal of the learned\nand intellectual Sergey Ivanovitch to go looking for mushrooms with\nVarenka confirmed certain theories of Kitty's with which her mind had\nbeen very busy of late": 31, 'She made haste to address some remark to her\nmother, so that her look should not be noticed': 18, 'After dinner Sergey\nIvanovitch sat with his cup of coffee at the drawing-room window, and\nwhile he took part in a conversation he had begun with his brother, he\nwatched the door through which the children would start on the\nmushroom-picking expedition': 42, 'Levin was sitting in the window near his\nbrother': 9, 'Kitty stood beside her husband, evidently awaiting the end of a\nconversation that had no interest for her, in order to tell him\nsomething': 24, '"You have changed in many respects since your marriage, and for the\nbetter," said Sergey Ivanovitch, smiling to Kitty, and obviously little\ninterested in the conversation, "but you have remained true to your\npassion for defending the most paradoxical theories': 40, '"\n\n"Katya, it\'s not good for you to stand," her husband said to her,\nputting a chair for her and looking significantly at her': 24, '"Oh, and there\'s no time either," added Sergey Ivanovitch, seeing the\nchildren running out': 14, "At the head of them all Tanya galloped sideways, in her tightly-drawn\nstockings, and waving a basket and Sergey Ivanovitch's hat, she ran\nstraight up to him": 27, "Boldly running up to Sergey Ivanovitch with shining eyes, so like her\nfather's fine eyes, she handed him his hat and made as though she would\nput it on for him, softening her freedom by a shy and friendly smile": 40, '"Varenka\'s waiting," she said, carefully putting his hat on, seeing\nfrom Sergey Ivanovitch\'s smile that she might do so': 19, 'Varenka was standing at the door, dressed in a yellow print gown, with\na white kerchief on her head': 19, '"I\'m coming, I\'m coming, Varvara Andreevna," said Sergey Ivanovitch,\nfinishing his cup of coffee, and putting into their separate pockets\nhis handkerchief and cigar-case': 24, '"And how sweet my Varenka is': 6, 'eh': 1, '" said Kitty to her husband, as soon\nas Sergey Ivanovitch rose': 12, 'She spoke so that Sergey Ivanovitch could\nhear, and it was clear that she meant him to do so': 19, '"And how\ngood-looking she is—such a refined beauty': 8, 'Varenka': 1, '" Kitty shouted': 3, '"Shall you be in the mill copse': 7, "We'll come out to you": 5, '"\n\n"You certainly forget your condition, Kitty," said the old princess,\nhurriedly coming out at the door': 17, '"You mustn\'t shout like that': 5, '"\n\nVarenka, hearing Kitty\'s voice and her mother\'s reprimand, went with\nlight, rapid steps up to Kitty': 17, 'The rapidity of her movement, her\nflushed and eager face, everything betrayed that something out of the\ncommon was going on in her': 23, 'Kitty knew what this was, and had been\nwatching her intently': 11, 'She called Varenka at that moment merely in\norder mentally to give her a blessing for the important event which, as\nKitty fancied, was bound to come to pass that day after dinner in the\nwood': 36, '"Varenka, I should be very happy if a certain something were to\nhappen," ('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART SIX', {'On the terrace were assembled all the ladies of the party': 11, 'They always\nliked sitting there after dinner, and that day they had work to do\nthere too': 17, 'Besides the sewing and knitting of baby clothes, with which\nall of them were busy, that afternoon jam was being made on the terrace\nby a method new to Agafea Mihalovna, without the addition of water': 36, 'Kitty had introduced this new method, which had been in use in her\nhome': 14, 'Agafea Mihalovna, to whom the task of jam-making had always been\nintrusted, considering that what had been done in the Levin household\ncould not be amiss, had nevertheless put water with the strawberries,\nmaintaining that the jam could not be made without it': 43, 'She had been\ncaught in the act, and was now making jam before everyone, and it was\nto be proved to her conclusively that jam could be very well made\nwithout water': 32, 'Agafea Mihalovna, her face heated and angry, her hair untidy, and her\nthin arms bare to the elbows, was turning the preserving-pan over the\ncharcoal stove, looking darkly at the raspberries and devoutly hoping\nthey would stick and not cook properly': 41, "The princess, conscious that\nAgafea Mihalovna's wrath must be chiefly directed against her, as the\nperson responsible for the raspberry jam-making, tried to appear to be\nabsorbed in other things and not interested in the jam, talked of other\nmatters, but cast stealthy glances in the direction of the stove": 50, '"I always buy my maids\' dresses myself, of some cheap material," the\nprincess said, continuing the previous conversation': 18, '"Isn\'t it time to\nskim it, my dear': 8, '" she added, addressing Agafea Mihalovna': 6, '"There\'s not\nthe slightest need for you to do it, and it\'s hot for you," she said,\nstopping Kitty': 19, '"I\'ll do it," said Dolly, and getting up, she carefully passed the\nspoon over the frothing sugar, and from time to time shook off the\nclinging jam from the spoon by knocking it on a plate that was covered\nwith yellow-red scum and blood-colored syrup': 45, '"How they\'ll enjoy this\nat tea-time': 6, '" she thought of her children, remembering how she herself\nas a child had wondered how it was the grown-up people did not eat what\nwas best of all—the scum of the jam': 33, '"Stiva says it\'s much better to give money': 8, '" Dolly took up meanwhile\nthe weighty subject under discussion, what presents should be made to\nservants': 17, '"But': 1, '"\n\n"Money\'s out of the question': 6, '" the princess and Kitty exclaimed with\none voice': 9, '"They appreciate a present': 4, '"\n\n"Well, last year, for instance, I bought our Matrona Semyenovna, not a\npoplin, but something of that sort," said the princess': 22, '"I remember she was wearing it on your nameday': 9, '"\n\n"A charming pattern—so simple and refined,—I should have liked it\nmyself, if she hadn\'t had it': 17, "Something like Varenka's": 3, 'So pretty and\ninexpensive': 4, '"\n\n"Well, now I think it\'s done," said Dolly, dropping the syrup from the\nspoon': 15, '"When it sets as it drops, it\'s ready': 8, 'Cook it a little longer, suddenly, looking\nat a sparrow that had settled on the step and was pecking at the center\nof a raspberry': 23, '"Yes, but you keep a little further from the stove," said her mother': 13, '"_À propos de Varenka_," said Kitty, speaking in French, as they had\nbeen doing all the while, so that Agafea Mihalovna should not\nunderstand them, "you know, mamma, I somehow expect things to be\nsettled today': 36, 'You know what I mean': 5, 'How splendid it would be': 5, '"\n\n"But what a famous matchmaker she is': 8, '" said Dolly': 3, '"How carefully and\ncleverly she throws them together': 8, '"\n\n"No; tell me, mamma, what do you think': 9, '"\n\n"Why, what is one to think': 7, 'He" (_he_ meant Sergey Ivanovitch) "might\nat any time have been a match for anyone in Russia; now, of course,\nhe\'s not quite a young man, still I know ever so many girls would be\nglad to marry him even now': 41, "She's a very nice girl, but he\nmight": 8, '"\n\n"Oh, no, mamma, do understand why, said\nher mother, who could not forget that Kitty had married not Vronsky,\nbut Levin': 19, '"What do you want to talk of it for': 9, '" Kitty said with annoyance': 5, '"I\nnever think about it, and I don\'t want to think of it': 13, 'And I don\'t\nwant to think of it," she said, catching the sound of her husband\'s\nwell-known step on the steps of the terrace': 24, '"What\'s that you don\'t want to think about': 8, '" inquired Levin, coming\nonto the terrace': 7, 'But no one answered him, and he did not repeat the question': 12, '"I\'m sorry I\'ve broken in on your feminine parliament," he said,\nlooking round on everyone discontentedly, and perceiving that they had\nbeen talking of something which they would not talk about before him': 33, 'For a second he felt that he was sharing the you': 4, '" he asked her, looking at her with the expression\nwith which everyone looked at her now': 17, '"Oh, very well," said Kitty, smiling, "and how have things gone with\nyou': 13, '"\n\n"The maman," said Kitty': 6, '"I don\'t like to see such imprudence': 7, '"\n\n"Well, I\'ll walk then, I\'m so well': 8, '" Kitty got up and went to her\nhusband and took his hand': 13, '"You may be well, the\nnew way': 8, '"\n\n"I suppose it\'s all right': 6, "For our notions it's boiled too long": 7, '"\n\n"It\'ll be all the better, Agafea Mihalovna, it won\'t mildew, even\nthough our ice has begun to thaw already, so that we\'ve no cool cellar\nto store it," said Kitty, at once divining her husband\'s motive, and\naddressing the old housekeeper with the same feeling; "but your\npickle\'s so good, that mamma says she never tasted any like it," she\nadded, smiling, and putting her kerchief straight': 68, 'Agafea Mihalovna looked angrily at Kitty': 6, '"You needn\'t try to console me, mistress': 7, 'I need only to look at you\nwith him, and I feel happy," she said, and something in the rough\nfamiliarity of that _with him_ touched Kitty': 27, '"Come along with us to look for mushrooms, you will show us the best\nplaces': 15, '" Agafea Mihalovna smiled and shook her head, as though to say:\n"I should like to be angry with you too, but I can\'t': 24, '"\n\n"Do it, please, by my receipt," said the princess; "put some paper over\nthe jam, and moisten it with a little rum, and without even ice, it\nwill never go mildewy': 32, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART SIX', {'Kitty was particularly glad of a chance of being alone with her\nhusband, for she had noticed the shade of mortification that had passed\nover his face—always so quick to reflect every feeling—at the moment\nwhen he had come onto the terrace and asked what they were talking of,\nand had got no answer': 54, 'When they had set off on foot ahead of the others, and had come out of\nsight of the house onto the beaten dusty road, marked with rusty wheels\nand sprinkled with grains of corn, she clung faster to his arm and\npressed it closer to her': 47, 'He had quite forgotten the momentary\nunpleasant impression, and alone with her he felt, now that the thought\nof her approaching motherhood was never for a moment absent from his\nmind, a new and delicious bliss, quite pure from all alloy of sense, in\nthe being near to the woman he loved': 52, 'There was no need of speech, yet\nhe longed to hear the sound of her voice, which like her eyes had\nchanged since she had been with child': 28, 'In her voice, as in her eyes,\nthere was that softness and gravity which is found in people\ncontinually concentrated on some cherished pursuit': 24, '"So you\'re not tired': 4, 'Lean more on me," said he': 6, '"No, I\'m so glad of a chance of being alone with you, and I must own,\nthough I\'m happy with them, I do regret our winter evenings alone': 28, '"\n\n"That was good, but this is even better': 9, 'Both are better," he said,\nsqueezing her hand': 8, '"Do you know what we were talking about when you came in': 12, '"\n\n"About jam': 3, '"\n\n"Oh, yes, about jam too; but afterwards, about how men make offers': 13, '"\n\n"Ah': 2, '" said Levin, listening more to the sound of her voice than to the\nwords she was saying, and all the while paying attention to the road,\nwhich passed now through the forest, and avoiding places where she\nmight make a false step': 43, '"And about Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka': 6, "You've noticed": 2, 'I\'m very\nanxious for it," she went on': 8, '"What do you think about it': 6, '" And she\npeeped into his face': 7, '"I don\'t know what to think," Levin answered, smiling': 9, '"Sergey seems\nvery strange to me in that way': 9, 'I told you, you know': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, that he was in love with that girl who died': 12, '"\n\n"That was when I was a child; I know about it from hearsay and\ntradition': 16, 'I remember him then': 4, 'He was wonderfully sweet': 4, "But I've\nwatched him since with women; he is friendly, some of them he likes,\nbut one feels that to him they're simply people, not women": 26, '"\n\n"Yes, but now with Varenka': 6, "I fancy there's something": 4, '"\n\n"Perhaps there is': 4, 'But one has to know him': 6, "He's a peculiar,\nwonderful person": 5, 'He lives a spiritual life only': 6, "He's is after all fact': 24, '"\n\nLevin had grown used by now to uttering his thought boldly, without\ntaking the trouble of clothing it in exact language': 22, 'He knew that his\nwife, in such moments of loving tenderness as now, would understand\nwhat he meant to say from a hint, and she did understand him': 28, '"Yes, but there\'s not so much of that actual fact about her as about\nme': 15, 'I can see that he would never have cared for me': 11, 'She is altogether\nspiritual': 4, '"\n\n"Oh, no, he is so fond of you, and I am always so glad when my people\nlike you': 20, '"\n\n"Yes, he\'s very nice to me; but': 8, '"\n\n"It\'s not as it was with poor Nikolay': 9, 'you really cared for each\nother," Levin finished': 8, '"Why not speak of him': 5, '" he added': 3, '"I sometimes\nblame myself for not; it ends in one\'s forgetting': 11, 'Ah, how terrible and\ndear he was': 7, 'Yes, what were we talking about': 6, '" Levin said, after a\npause': 6, '"You think he can\'t fall in love," said Kitty, translating into her own\nlanguage': 14, '"It\'s not so much that he can\'t fall in love," Levin said, smiling,\n"but he has not the weakness necessary': 20, "I've always envied him, and\neven now, when I'm so happy, I still envy him": 15, '"\n\n"You envy him for not being able to fall in love': 12, '"\n\n"I envy him for being better than I," said Levin': 11, '"He does not live for\nhimself': 6, 'His whole life is subordinated to his duty': 8, "And that's why he\ncan be calm and contented": 9, '"\n\n"And you': 3, '" Kitty asked, with an ironical and loving smile': 9, 'She could never have explained the chain of thought that made her\nsmile; but the last link in it was that her husband, in exalting his\nbrother and abasing himself, was not quite sincere': 34, 'Kitty knew that\nthis insincerity came from his love for his brother, from his sense of\nshame at being too happy, and above all from his unflagging craving to\nbe better—she loved it in him, and so she smiled': 39, '"And you': 2, 'What are you dissatisfied with': 5, '" she asked, with the same\nsmile': 7, 'Her disbelief in his self-dissatisfaction delighted him, and\nunconsciously he tried to draw her into giving utterance to the grounds\nof her disbelief': 23, '"I am happy, but dissatisfied with myself': 7, '" he said': 3, '"Why, how can you be dissatisfied with yourself if you are happy': 12, '"\n\n"Well, how shall I say': 6, 'In my heart I really care for nothing\nwhatever but that you should not stumble—see': 15, "Oh, but really you\nmustn't skip about like that": 9, '" he cried, breaking off to scold her for\ntoo agile a movement in stepping over a branch that lay in the path': 23, '"But when I think about myself, and compare myself with others,\nespecially with my brother, I Levin': 6, '"But I\'m so happy that I don\'t understand\nanything': 9, "So you think he'll make her an offer today": 9, '" he added after a\nbrief silence': 7, '"I think so, and I don\'t think so': 8,
