('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART SIX', {'Varenka, with her white kerchief on her black hair, surrounded by the\nchildren, gaily and good-humoredly looking after them, and at the same\ntime visibly excited at the possibility of receiving a declaration from\nthe man she cared for, was very attractive': 42, 'Sergey Ivanovitch walked\nbeside her, and never left off admiring her': 11, 'Looking at her, he\nrecalled all the delightful things he had heard from her lips, all the\ngood he knew about her, and became more and more conscious that the\nfeeling he had for her was something special that he had felt long,\nlong ago, and only once, in his early youth': 52, 'The feeling of happiness\nin being near her continually grew, and at last reached such a point\nthat, as he put a huge, slender-stalked agaric fungus in her basket, he\nlooked straight into her face, and noticing the flush of glad and\nalarmed excitement that overspread her face, he was confused himself,\nand smiled to her in silence a smile that said too much': 64, '"If so," he said to himself, "I ought to think it over and make up my\nmind, and not give way like a boy to the impulse of a moment': 30, '"\n\n"I\'m going to pick by myself apart from all the rest, or else my\nefforts will make no show," he said, and he left the edge of the forest\nwhere they were walking on low silky grass between old birch trees\nstanding far apart, and went more into the heart of the wood, where\nbetween the white birch trunks there were gray trunks of aspen and dark\nbushes of hazel': 71, 'Walking some forty paces away, Sergey Ivanovitch,\nknowing he was out of sight, stood still behind a bushy spindle-tree in\nfull flower with its rosy red catkins': 27, 'It was perfectly still all round\nhim': 7, "Only overhead in the birches under which he stood, the flies, like\na swarm of bees, buzzed unceasingly, and from time to time the\nchildren's voices were floated across to him": 31, "All at once he heard, not\nfar from the edge of the wood, the sound of Varenka's contralto voice,\ncalling Grisha, and a smile of delight passed over Sergey Ivanovitch's\nface": 31, 'Conscious of this smile, he shook his head disapprovingly at his\nown condition, and taking out a cigar, he began lighting it': 22, 'For a long\nwhile he could not get a match to light against the trunk of a birch\ntree': 19, 'The soft scales of the white bark rubbed off the phosphorus, and\nthe light went out': 16, 'At last one of the matches burned, and the fragrant\ncigar smoke, hovering uncertainly in flat, wide coils, stretched away\nforwards and upwards over a bush under the overhanging branches of a\nbirch tree': 34, 'Watching the streak of smoke, Sergey Ivanovitch walked\ngently on, deliberating on his position': 14, '"Why not': 2, '" he thought': 3, '"If it were only a passing fancy or a passion,\nif it were only this attraction—this mutual attraction (I can call it a\n_mutual_ attraction), but if I felt that it was in contradiction with\nthe whole bent of my life—if I felt that in giving way to this\nattraction I should be false to my vocation and my duty': 60, "but it's\nnot so": 4, 'The only thing I can say against it is that, when I lost Marie,\nI said to myself that I would remain faithful to her memory': 26, "That's the\nonly thing I can say against my feeling": 10, 'That\'s a great thing,"\nSergey Ivanovitch said to himself, feeling at the same time that this\nconsideration had not the slightest importance for him personally, but\nwould only perhaps detract from his romantic character in the eyes of\nothers': 39, '"But apart from that, however much I searched, I should never\nfind anything to say against my feeling': 18, 'If I were choosing by\nconsiderations of suitability alone, I could not have found anything\nbetter': 16, '"\n\nHowever many women and girls he thought of whom he knew, he could not\nthink of a girl who united to such a degree all, positively all, the\nqualities he would wish to see in his wife': 38, 'She had all the charm and\nfreshness of youth, but she was not a child; and if she loved him, she\nloved him consciously as a woman ought to love; that was one thing': 34, "Another point: she was not only far from being worldly, but had an\nunmistakable distaste for worldly society, and at the same time she\nknew the world, and had all the ways of a woman of the best society,\nwhich were absolutely essential to Sergey Ivanovitch's conception of\nthe woman who was to share his life": 56, 'Thirdly: she was religious, and\nnot like a child, unconsciously religious and good, as Kitty, for\nexample, was, but her life was founded on religious principles': 26, "Even in\ntrifling matters, Sergey Ivanovitch found in her all that he wanted in\nhis wife: she was poor and alone in the world, so she would not bring\nwith her a mass of relations and their influence into her husband's\nhouse, as he saw now in Kitty's case": 49, 'She would owe everything to her\nhusband, which was what he had always desired too for his future family\nlife': 20, 'And this girl, who united all these qualities, loved him': 10, 'He was\na modest man, but he could not help seeing it': 12, 'And he loved her': 4, 'There\nwas one consideration against it—his age': 7, "But he came of a long-lived\nfamily, he had not a single gray hair, no one would have taken him for\nforty, and he remembered Varenka's saying that it was only in Russia\nthat men of fifty thought themselves old, and that in France a man of\nfifty considers himself _dans la force de l'âge_, while a man of forty\nis _un jeune homme_": 64, 'But what did the mere reckoning of years matter\nwhen he felt as young in heart as he had been twenty years ago': 23, 'Was it\nnot youth to feel as he felt now, when coming from the other side to\nthe edge of the wood he saw in the glowing light of the slanting\nsunbeams the gracious figure of Varenka in her yellow gown with her\nbasket, walking lightly by the trunk of an old birch tree, and when\nthis impression of the sight of Varenka blended so harmoniously with\nthe beauty of the view, of the yellow oatfield lying bathed in the\nslanting sunshine, and beyond it the distant ancient forest flecked\nwith yellow and melting into the blue of the distance': 100, 'His heart\nthrobbed joyously': 4, 'A softened feeling came over him': 6, 'He felt that he\nhad made up his mind': 9, 'Varenka, who had just crouched down to pick a\nmushroom, rose with a supple movement and looked round': 18, 'Flinging away\nthe cigar, Sergey Ivanovitch advanced with resolute steps towards her': 12, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART SIX', {'"Varvara Andreevna, when I was very young, I set before myself the\nideal of the woman I loved and should be happy to call my wife': 26, 'I have\nlived through a long life, and now for the first time I have met what I\nsought—in you': 20, 'I love you, and offer you my hand': 8, '"\n\nSergey Ivanovitch was saying this to himself while he was ten paces\nfrom Varvara': 15, 'Kneeling down, with her hands over the mushrooms to guard\nthem from Grisha, she was calling little Masha': 18, '"Come here, little ones': 4, 'There are so many': 4, '" she was saying in her\nsweet, deep voice': 9, 'Seeing Sergey Ivanovitch approaching, she did not get up and did not\nchange her position, but everything told him that she felt his presence\nand was glad of it': 29, '"Well, did you find some': 5, '" she asked from under the white kerchief,\nturning her handsome, gently smiling face to him': 16, '"Not one," said Sergey Ivanovitch': 5, '"Did you': 2, '"\n\nShe did not answer, busy with the children who thronged about her': 13, '"That one too, near the twig," she pointed out to little Masha a little\nfungus, split in half across its rosy cap by the dry grass from under\nwhich it thrust itself': 32, 'Varenka got up while Masha picked the fungus,\nbreaking it into two white halves': 14, '"This brings back my childhood," she\nadded, moving apart from the children beside Sergey Ivanovitch': 15, 'They walked on for some steps in silence': 8, 'Varenka saw that he wanted to\nspeak; she guessed of what, and felt faint with joy and panic': 18, 'They had\nwalked so far away that no one could hear them now, but still he did\nnot begin to speak': 21, 'It would have been better for Varenka to be silent': 10, 'After a silence it would have been easier for them to say what they\nwanted to say than after talking about mushrooms': 22, 'But against her own\nwill, as it were accidentally, Varenka said:\n\n"So you found nothing': 15, 'In the middle of the wood there are always\nfewer, though': 11, '" Sergey Ivanovitch sighed and made no answer': 8, 'He was\nannoyed that she had spoken about the mushrooms': 10, 'He wanted to bring her\nback to the first words she had uttered about her childhood; but after\na pause of some length, as though against his own will, he made an\nobservation in response to her last words': 39, '"I have heard that the white edible funguses are found principally at\nthe edge of the wood, though I can\'t tell them apart': 23, '"\n\nSome minutes more passed, they moved still further away from the\nchildren, and were quite alone': 17, "Varenka's heart throbbed so that she\nheard it beating, and felt that she was turning red and pale and red\nagain": 21, 'To be the wife of a man like Koznishev, after her position with Madame\nStahl, was to her imagination the height of happiness': 23, 'Besides, she was\nalmost certain that she was in love with him': 12, 'And this moment it would\nhave to be decided': 9, 'She felt frightened': 3, 'She dreaded both his speaking\nand his not speaking': 9, 'Now or never it must be said—that Sergey Ivanovitch felt too': 11, 'Everything in the expression, the flushed cheeks and the downcast eyes\nof Varenka betrayed a painful suspense': 17, 'Sergey Ivanovitch saw it and\nfelt sorry for her': 9, 'He felt even that to say nothing now would be a\nslight to her': 14, 'Rapidly in his own mind he ran over all the arguments in\nsupport of his decision': 16, 'He even said over to himself the words in\nwhich he meant to put his offer, but instead of those words, some\nutterly unexpected reflection that occurred to him made him ask:\n\n"What is the difference between the ‘birch\' mushroom and the ‘white\'\nmushroom': 44, '"\n\nVarenka\'s lips quivered with emotion as she answered:\n\n"In the top part there is scarcely any difference, it\'s in the stalk': 22, '"\n\nAnd as soon as these words were uttered, both he and she felt that it\nwas over, that what was to have been said would not be said; and their\nemotion, which had up to then been continually growing more intense,\nbegan to subside': 45, '"The birch mushroom\'s stalk suggests a dark man\'s chin after two days\nwithout shaving," said Sergey Ivanovitch, speaking quite calmly now': 21, '"Yes, that\'s true," answered Varenka smiling, and unconsciously the\ndirection of their walk changed': 14, 'They began to turn towards the\nchildren': 7, 'Varenka felt both sore and ashamed; at the same time she had\na sense of relief': 16, 'When he had got home again and went over the whole subject, Sergey\nIvanovitch thought his previous decision had been a mistaken one': 23, 'He\ncould not be false to the memory of Marie': 10, '"Gently, children, gently': 3, '" Levin shouted quite angrily to the\nchildren, standing before his wife to protect her when the crowd of\nchildren flew with shrieks of delight to meet them': 28, 'Behind the children Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka walked out of the\nwood': 12, 'Kitty had no need to ask Varenka; she saw from the calm and\nsomewhat crestfallen faces of both that her plans had not come off': 25, '"Well': 1, '" her husband questioned her as they were going home again': 11, '"It doesn\'t bite," said Kitty, her smile and manner of speaking\nrecalling her father, a likeness Levin often noticed with pleasure': 21, '"How doesn\'t bite': 3, '"\n\n"I\'ll show you," she said, taking her husband\'s hand, lifting it to her\nmouth, and just faintly brushing it with closed lips': 23, '"Like a kiss on a\npriest\'s hand': 7, '"\n\n"Which didn\'t it bite with': 6, '" he said, laughing': 4, '"Both': 1, 'But it should have been like this': 7, '"\n\n"There are some peasants coming': 6, '"\n\n"Oh, they didn\'t see': 5, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART SIX', {"During the time of the children's tea the grown-up people sat in the\nbalcony and talked as though nothing had happened, though they all,\nespecially Sergey Ivanovitch and Varenka, were very well aware that\nthere had happened an event which, though negative, was of very great\nimportance": 47, 'They both had the same feeling, rather like that of a\nschoolboy after an examination, which has left him in the same class or\nshut him out of the school forever': 31, 'Everyone present, feeling too that\nsomething had happened, talked eagerly about extraneous subjects': 13, 'Levin\nand Kitty were particularly happy and conscious of their love that\nevening': 13, 'And their happiness in their love seemed to imply a\ndisagreeable slur on those who would have liked to feel the same and\ncould not—and they felt a prick of conscience': 31, '"Mark my words, Alexander will not come," said the old princess': 11, 'That evening they were expecting Stepan Arkadyevitch to come down by\ntrain, and the old prince had written that possibly he might come too': 24, '"And I know why," the princess went on; "he says that young people\nought to be left alone for a while at first': 23, '"\n\n"But papa has left us alone': 7, 'We\'ve never seen him," said Kitty': 6, '"Besides, we\'re not young people': 5, "—we're old, married people by now": 6, '"\n\n"Only if he doesn\'t come, I shall say good-bye to you children," said\nthe princess, sighing mournfully': 18, '"What nonsense, mamma': 3, '" both the daughters fell upon her at once': 9, '"How do you suppose he is feeling': 7, 'Why, now': 2, '"\n\nAnd suddenly there was an unexpected quiver in the princess\'s voice': 12, 'Her daughters were silent, and looked at one another': 9, '"Maman always\nfinds something to be miserable about," they said in that glance': 13, "They\ndid not know that happy as the princess was in her daughter's house,\nand useful as she felt herself to be there, she had been extremely\nmiserable, both on her own account and her husband's, ever since they\nhad married their last and favorite daughter, and the old home had been\nleft empty": 54, '"What is it, Agafea Mihalovna': 5, '" Kitty asked suddenly of Agafea\nMihalovna, who was standing with a mysterious air, and a face full of\nmeaning': 20, '"About supper': 2, '"\n\n"Well, that\'s right," said Dolly; "you go and arrange about it, and\nI\'ll go and hear Grisha repeat his lesson, or else he will have nothing\ndone all day': 30, '"\n\n"That\'s my lesson': 4, 'No, Dolly, I\'m going," said Levin, jumping up': 8, 'Grisha, who was by now at a high school, had to go over the lessons of\nthe term in the summer holidays': 22, "Darya Alexandrovna, who had been\nstudying Latin with her son in Moscow before, had made it a rule on\ncoming to the Levins' to go over with him, at least once a day, the\nmost difficult lessons of Latin and arithmetic": 41, "Levin had offered to\ntake her place, but the mother, having once overheard Levin's lesson,\nand noticing that it was not given exactly as the teacher in Moscow had\ngiven it, said resolutely, though with much embarrassment and anxiety\nnot to mortify Levin, that they must keep strictly to the book as the\nteacher had done, and that she had better undertake it again herself": 65, 'Levin was amazed both at Stepan Arkadyevitch, who, by neglecting his\nduty, threw upon the mother the supervision of studies of which she had\nno comprehension, and at the teachers for teaching the children so\nbadly': 36, 'But he promised his sister-in-law to give the lessons exactly as\nshe wished': 13, 'And he went on teaching Grisha, not in his own way, but by\nthe book, and so took little interest in it, and often forgot the hour\nof the lesson': 30, 'So it had been today': 5, '"No, I\'m going, Dolly, you sit still," he said': 9, '"We\'ll do it all\nproperly, like the book': 8, 'Only when Stiva comes, and we go out shooting,\nthen we shall have to miss it': 16, '"\n\nAnd Levin went to Grisha': 6, 'Varenka was saying the same thing to Kitty': 8, 'Even in the happy,\nwell-ordered household of the Levins Varenka had succeeded in making\nherself useful': 16, '"I\'ll see to the supper, you sit still," she said, and got up to go to\nAgafea Mihalovna': 18, '"Yes, yes, most likely they\'ve not been able to get chickens': 11, 'If so,\nours': 3, '"\n\n"Agafea Mihalovna and I will see about it," and Varenka vanished with\nher': 14, '"What a nice girl': 4, '" said the princess': 4, '"Not nice, maman; she\'s an exquisite girl; there\'s no one else like\nher': 13, '"\n\n"So you are expecting Stepan Arkadyevitch today': 8, '" said Sergey\nIvanovitch, evidently not disposed to pursue the conversation about\nVarenka': 13, '"It would be difficult to find two sons-in-law more unlike\nthan yours," he said with a subtle smile': 18, '"One all movement, only\nliving in society, like a fish in water; the other our Kostya, lively,\nalert, quick in everything, but as soon as he is in society, he either\nsinks into apathy, or struggles helplessly like a fish on land': 42, '"\n\n"Yes, he\'s very heedless," said the princess, addressing Sergey\nIvanovitch': 11, '"I\'ve been meaning, indeed, to ask you to tell him that\nit\'s out of the question for her" (she indicated Kitty) "to stay here;\nthat she positively must come to Moscow': 31, 'He talks of getting a doctor\ndown': 7, '"\n\n"Maman, he\'ll do everything; he has agreed to everything," Kitty said,\nangry with her mother for appealing to Sergey Ivanovitch to judge in\nsuch a matter': 27, 'In the middle of their conversation they heard the snorting of horses\nand the sound of wheels on the gravel': 20, 'Dolly had not time to get up to\ngo and meet her husband, when from the window of the room below, where\nGrisha was having his lesson, Levin leaped out and helped Grisha out\nafter him': 36, '"It\'s Stiva': 2, '" Levin shouted from under the balcony': 7, '"We\'ve finished,\nDolly, don\'t be afraid': 6, '" he added, and started running like a boy to\nmeet the carriage': 13, '"_Is ea id, ejus, ejus, ejus': 6, '_" shouted Grisha, skipping along the\navenue': 7, '"And someone else too': 4, 'Papa, of course': 3, '" cried Levin, stopping at the\nentrance of the avenue': 10, '"Kitty, don\'t come down the steep staircase, go\nround': 9, '"\n\nBut Levin had been mistaken in taking the person sitting in the\ncarriage for the old prince': 18, 'As he got nearer to the carriage he saw\nbeside Stepan Arkadyevitch not the prince but a handsome, stout young\nman in a Scotch cap, with long ends of ribbon behind': 31, 'This was Vassenka\nVeslovsky, a distant cousin of the Shtcherbatskys, a brilliant young\ngentleman in Petersburg and Moscow society': 19, '"A capital fellow, and a\nkeen sportsman," as Stepan Arkadyevitch said, introducing him': 13, 'Not a whit abashed by the disappointment caused by his having come in\nplace of the old prince, Veslovsky greeted Levin gaily, claiming\nacquaintance with him in the past, and snatching up Grisha into the\ncarriage, lifted him over the pointer that Stepan Arkadyevitch had\nbrought with him': 48, 'Levin did not get into the carriage, but walked behind': 10, 'He was rather\nvexed at the non-arrival of the old prince, whom he liked more and more\nthe more he saw of him, and also at the arrival of this Vassenka\nVeslovsky, a quite uncongenial and superfluous person': 38, "He seemed to him\nstill more uncongenial and superfluous when, on approaching the steps\nwhere the whole party, children and grown-up, were gathered together in\nmuch excitement, Levin saw Vassenka Veslovsky, with a particularly warm\nand gallant air, kissing Kitty's hand": 41, '"Your wife and I are cousins and very old friends," said Vassenka\nVeslovsky, once more shaking Levin\'s hand with great warmth': 21, '"Well, are there plenty of birds': 6, '" Stepan Arkadyevitch said to Levin,\nhardly leaving time for everyone to utter their greetings': 15, '"We\'ve come\nwith the most savage intentions': 7, "Why, maman, they've not been in Moscow\nsince": 8, "Look, Tanya, here's something for you": 6, "Get it, please, it's in\nthe carriage, behind": 8, '" he talked in all directions': 6, '"How pretty you\'ve\ngrown, Dolly," he said to his wife, once more kissing her hand, holding\nit in one of his, and patting it with the other': 27, 'Levin, who a minute before had been in the happiest frame of mind, now\nlooked darkly at everyone, and everything displeased him': 22, '"Who was it he kissed yesterday with those lips': 9, '" he thought, looking\nat Stepan Arkadyevitch\'s tender demonstrations to his wife': 12, 'He looked\nat Dolly, and he did not like her either': 11, '"She doesn\'t believe in his love': 6, 'So what is she so pleased about': 7, 'Revolting': 1, '" thought Levin': 3, 'He looked at the princess, who had been so dear to him a minute before,\nand he did not like the manner in which she welcomed this Vassenka,\nwith his ribbons, just as though she were in her own house': 40, 'Even Sergey Ivanovitch, who had come out too onto the steps, seemed to\nhim unpleasant with the show of cordiality with which he met Stepan\nArkadyevitch, though Levin knew that his brother neither liked nor\nrespected Oblonsky': 37, 'And Varenka, even she seemed hateful, with her air _sainte nitouche_\nmaking the acquaintance of this gentleman, while all the while she was\nthinking of nothing but getting married': 29, 'And more hateful than anyone was Kitty for falling in with the tone of\ngaiety with which this gentleman regarded his visit in the country, as\nthough it were a holiday for himself and everyone else': 36, 'And, above all,\nunpleasant was that particular smile with which she responded to his\nsmile': 15, 'Noisily talking, they all went into the house; but as soon as they were\nall seated, Levin turned and went out': 21, 'Kitty saw something was wrong with her husband': 8, 'She tried to seize a\nmoment to speak to him alone, but he made haste to get away from her,\nsaying he was wanted at the counting-house': 27, 'It was long since his own\nwork on the estate had seemed to him so important as at that moment': 20, '"It\'s all holiday for them," he thought; "but these are no holiday\nmatters, they won\'t wait, and there\'s no living without them': 22, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART SIX', {'Levin came back to the house only when they sent to summon him to\nsupper': 15, 'On the stairs were standing Kitty and Agafea Mihalovna,\nconsulting about wines for supper': 14, '"But why are you making all this fuss': 8, 'Have what we usually do': 5, '"\n\n"No, Stiva doesn\'t drink': 5, "Kostya, stop, what's the matter": 5, '" Kitty\nbegan, hurrying after him, ('TOL CHAPTER 8 PART SIX', {'Next day, before the ladies were up, the wagonette and a trap for the\nshooting party were at the door, and Laska, aware since early morning\nthat they were going shooting, after much whining and darting to and\nfro, had sat herself down in the wagonette beside the coachman, and,\ndisapproving of the delay, was excitedly watching the door from which\nthe sportsmen still did not come out': 68, 'The first to come out was\nVassenka Veslovsky, in new high boots that reached half-way up his\nthick thighs, in a green blouse, with a new Russian leather\ncartridge-belt, and in his Scotch cap with ribbons, with a brand-new\nEnglish gun without a sling': 44, 'Laska flew up to him, welcomed him, and\njumping up, asked him in her own way whether the others were coming\nsoon, but getting no answer from him, she returned to her post of\nobservation and sank into repose again, her head on one side, and one\near pricked up to listen': 52, "At last the door opened with a creak, and\nStepan Arkadyevitch's spot-and-tan pointer Krak flew out, running round\nand round and turning over in the air": 26, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch himself\nfollowed with a gun in his hand and a cigar in his mouth': 16, '"Good dog, good dog, Krak': 5, '" he cried encouragingly to the dog, who put\nhis paws up on his chest, catching at his game bag': 20, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch\nwas dressed in rough leggings and spats, in torn trousers and a short\ncoat': 16, 'On his head there was a wreck of a hat of indefinite form, but\nhis gun of a new patent was a perfect gem, and his game bag and\ncartridge belt, though worn, were of the very best quality': 39, 'Vassenka Veslovsky had had no notion before that it was truly _chic_\nfor a sportsman to be in tatters, but to have his shooting outfit of\nthe best quality': 29, 'He saw it now as he looked at Stepan Arkadyevitch,\nradiant in his rags, graceful, well-fed, and joyous, a typical Russian\nnobleman': 22, 'And he made up his mind that next time he went shooting he\nwould certainly adopt the same get-up': 19, '"Well, and what about our host': 6, '" he asked': 3, '"A young wife," said Stepan Arkadyevitch, smiling': 7, '"Yes, and such a charming one': 6, '"\n\n"He came down dressed': 5, "No doubt he's run up to her again": 8, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch guessed right': 5, "Levin had run up again to his wife\nto ask her once more if she forgave him for his idiocy yesterday, and,\nmoreover, to beg her for Christ's sake to be more careful": 33, 'The great\nthing was for her to keep away from the children—they might any minute\npush against her': 18, 'Then he had once more to hear her declare that she\nwas not angry with him for going away for two days, and to beg her to\nbe sure to send him a note next morning by a servant on horseback, to\nwrite him, if it were but two words only, to let him know that all was\nwell with her': 61, 'Kitty was distressed, as she always was, at parting for a couple of\ndays from her husband, but when she saw his eager figure, looking big\nand strong in his shooting-boots and his white blouse, and a sort of\nsportsman elation and excitement incomprehensible to her, she forgot\nher own chagrin for the sake of his pleasure, and said good-bye to him\ncheerfully': 63, '"Pardon, gentlemen': 2, '" he said, running out onto the steps': 8, '"Have you put\nthe lunch in': 6, 'Why is the chestnut on the right': 7, "Well, it doesn't\nmatter": 4, 'Laska, down; go and lie down': 6, '"\n\n"Put it with the herd of oxen," he said to the to meet the carpenter, who came towards the steps with a rule in\nhis hand': 30, '"You didn\'t come to the counting house yesterday, and now you\'re\ndetaining me': 13, 'Well, what is it': 4, '"\n\n"Would your honor let me make another turning': 9, "It's only three steps to\nadd": 6, 'And we make it just fit at the same time': 10, 'It will be much more\nconvenient': 6, '"\n\n"You should sloping when it was\nput in place': 42, 'Now the carpenter wanted, keeping the same staircase, to\nadd three steps': 12, '"It will be much better': 5, '"\n\n"But where\'s your staircase coming out well that day himself': 43, 'Not to disgrace himself\nbefore a new spectator—not to be outdone by Oblonsky—that too was a\nthought that crossed his brain': 21, 'Oblonsky was feeling the same, and he day before': 21, 'Vassenka was really a nice fellow, simple,\ngood-hearted, and very good-humored': 11, 'If Levin had met him before he was\nmarried, he would have made friends with him': 16, 'Levin rather disliked his\nholiday attitude to life and a sort of free and easy assumption of\nelegance': 18, 'It was as though he assumed a high degree of importance in\nhimself that could not be disputed, because he had long nails and a\nstylish cap, and everything else to correspond; but this could be\nforgiven for the sake of his good nature and good breeding': 47, 'Levin liked\nhim for his good education, for speaking French and English with such\nan excellent accent, and for being a man of his world': 25, 'Vassenka was extremely delighted with the left horse, a horse of the\nDon Steppes': 14, 'He kept praising him enthusiastically': 5, '"How fine it must\nbe galloping over the steppes on a steppe horse': 13, 'Eh': 1, "isn't it": 2, '" he\nsaid': 3, 'He had imagined riding on a steppe horse as something wild and\nromantic, and it turned out nothing of the sort': 21, 'But his simplicity,\nparticularly in conjunction with his good looks, his amiable smile, and\nthe grace of his movements, was very attractive': 22, 'Either because his\nnature was sympathetic to Levin, or because Levin was trying to atone\nfor his sins of the previous evening by seeing nothing but what was\ngood in him, anyway he liked his society': 36, 'After they had driven over two miles from home, Veslovsky all at once\nfelt for a cigar and his pocketbook, and did not know whether he had\nlost them or left them on the table': 35, 'In the pocketbook there were\nthirty-seven pounds, and so the matter could not be left in\nuncertainty': 17, '"Do you know what, Levin, I\'ll gallop home on that left trace-horse': 12, 'That will be splendid': 4, '" he said, preparing to get out': 7, '"No, why should you': 4, '" answered Levin, calculating that Vassenka could\nhardly weigh less than seventeen stone': 13, '"I\'ll send the coachman': 4, '"\n\nThe coachman rode back on the trace-horse, and Levin himself drove the\nremaining pair': 15, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART SIX', {'"Well, now what\'s our plan of campaign': 7, 'Tell us all about it," said\nStepan Arkadyevitch': 8, '"Our plan is this': 4, "Now we're driving to Gvozdyov": 5, "In Gvozdyov there's a\ngrouse marsh on this side, and beyond Gvozdyov come some magnificent\nsnipe marshes where there are grouse too": 22, "It's hot now, and we'll get\nthere—it's fifteen miles or so—towards evening and have some evening\nshooting; we'll spend the night there and go on tomorrow to the bigger\nmoors": 30, '"\n\n"And is there nothing on the way': 8, '"\n\n"Yes; but we\'ll reserve ourselves; besides it\'s hot': 9, 'There are two nice\nlittle places, but I doubt there being anything to shoot': 14, '"\n\nLevin would himself have liked to go into these little places, but they\nwere near home; he could shoot them over any time, and they were only\nlittle places—there would hardly be room for three to shoot': 38, 'And so,\nwith some insincerity, he said that he doubted there being anything to\nshoot': 15, 'When they reached a little marsh Levin would have driven by, but\nStepan Arkadyevitch, with the experienced eye of a sportsman, at once\ndetected reeds visible from the road': 29, '"Shan\'t we try that': 4, '" he said, pointing to the little marsh': 8, '"Levin, do, please': 3, 'how delightful': 2, '" Vassenka Veslovsky began begging,\nand Levin could but consent': 10, 'Before they had time to stop, the dogs had flown one before the other\ninto the marsh': 17, '"Krak': 1, 'Laska': 1, '"\n\nThe dogs came back': 5, '"There won\'t be room for three': 6, 'I\'ll stay here," said Levin, hoping\nthey would find nothing but peewits, who had been startled by the dogs,\nand turning over in their flight, were plaintively wailing over the\nmarsh': 31, '"No': 1, "Come along, Levin, let's go together": 6, '" Veslovsky called': 3, '"Really, there\'s not room': 4, 'Laska, back, Laska': 3, "You won't want another\ndog, will you": 7, '"\n\nLevin remained with the wagonette, and looked enviously at the\nsportsmen': 12, 'They walked right across the marsh': 6, 'Except little birds and\npeewits, of which Vassenka killed one, there was nothing in the marsh': 16, '"Come, you see now that it was not that I grudged the marsh," said\nLevin, "only it\'s wasting time': 19, '"\n\n"Oh, no, it was jolly all the same': 9, 'Did you see us': 4, '" said Vassenka\nVeslovsky, clambering awkwardly into the wagonette with his gun and his\npeewit in his hands': 18, '"How splendidly I shot this bird': 6, "Didn't I": 2, 'Well,\nshall we soon be getting to beginning to beat\nmore violently; and all of a sudden, as though some sort of shutter had\nbeen drawn back from his straining ears, all sounds, confused but loud,\nbegan to beat on his hearing, ('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART SIX', {'Vassenka drove the horses so smartly that they reached the marsh too\nearly, while it was still hot': 18, 'As they drew near this more important marsh, the chief aim of their\nexpedition, Levin could not help considering how he could get rid of\nVassenka and be free in his movements': 32, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch evidently\nhad the same desire, and on his face Levin saw see, and there are hawks,"\nsaid Stepan Arkadyevitch, pointing to two great birds hovering over the\nreeds': 22, '"Where there are hawks, there is sure to be game': 10, '"\n\n"Now, gentlemen," said movements, and the snipe fell in a heap into the mud': 25, 'Oblonsky aimed deliberately at another, still flying low in the reeds,\nand together with the report of the shot, that snipe too fell, and it\ncould be seen fluttering out where the sedge had been cut, its unhurt\nwing showing white beneath': 42, 'Levin was not so lucky: he aimed at his first bird too low, and missed;\nhe aimed at it again, just as it was rising, but at that instant\nanother snipe flew up at his very feet, distracting him so that he\nmissed again': 44, 'While they were loading their guns, another snipe rose, and themselves in numbers': 6, "They kept flying up\nfrom just under the dogs, from under the sportsmen's legs, and Levin\nmight have retrieved his ill luck": 22, 'But the more he shot, the more he\nfelt his\nears were ringing with the incessant whir of the snipe; he could not\ntouch the stock of his gun, it was so hot; his heart beat with short,\nrapid throbs; his hands shook with excitement, and his ('TOL CHAPTER 11 PART SIX', {"When Levin and Stepan Arkadyevitch reached the peasant's hut where\nLevin always used to stay, Veslovsky was already there": 19, "He was sitting\nin the middle of the his infectious, good-humored laugh': 7, '"I\'ve only just come': 4, '_Ils ont été charmants_': 4, 'Just fancy, they gave me\ndrink, fed me': 8, 'Such bread, it was exquisite': 5, '_Délicieux': 1, '_ And the\nvodka, I never tasted any better': 9, 'And they would not take a penny for\nanything': 9, 'And they kept saying: ‘Excuse our homely ways': 8, '\'"\n\n"What should they take anything for': 7, 'They were entertaining you, to be\nsure': 7, 'Do you suppose they keep vodka for sale': 8, '" said the soldier,\nsucceeding at last in pulling the soaked boot off the blackened\nstocking': 16, 'In spite of the dirtiness of the hut, which was all muddied by their\nboots and the filthy dogs licking themselves clean, and the smell of\nmarsh mud and powder that filled the room, and the absence of knives\nand forks, the party drank their tea and ate their supper with a relish\nonly known to sportsmen': 57, 'Washed and clean, they went into a hay-barn\nswept ready for them, where the coachman had been making up beds for\nthe gentlemen': 23, 'Though it was dusk, not one of them wanted to go to sleep': 13, 'After wavering among reminiscences and anecdotes of guns, of dogs, and\nof former shooting parties, the conversation rested on a topic that\ninterested all of them': 26, "After Vassenka had several times over expressed\nhis appreciation of this delightful sleeping place among the fragrant\nhay, this delightful broken cart (he supposed it to be broken because\nthe shafts had been taken out), of the good nature of the peasants that\nhad treated him to vodka, of the dogs who lay at the feet of their\nrespective masters, Oblonsky began telling them of a delightful\nshooting party at Malthus's, where he had stayed the previous summer": 78, 'Malthus was a well-known capitalist, who had made his money by\nspeculation in railway shares': 15, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch described what\ngrouse moors this Malthus had bought in the Tver province, and how they\nwere preserved, and of the carriages and dogcarts in which the shooting\nparty had been driven, and the luncheon pavilion that had been rigged\nup at the marsh': 45, '"I don\'t understand you," said Levin, sitting up in the hay; "how is it\nsuch people don\'t disgust you': 19, "I can understand a lunch with Lafitte is\nall very pleasant, but don't you dislike just that very sumptuousness": 19, 'All these people, just like our spirit monopolists in old days, get\ntheir money in a way that gains them the contempt of everyone': 24, "They\ndon't care for their contempt, and then they use their dishonest gains\nto buy off the contempt they have deserved": 21, '"\n\n"Perfectly true': 3, '" chimed in Vassenka Veslovsky': 5, '"Perfectly': 1, 'Oblonsky,\nof course, goes out of _bonhomie_, but other people say: ‘Well,\nOblonsky stays with them': 16, "'": 1, '"\n\n"Not a bit of it': 6, '" Levin could hear that Oblonsky was smiling as he\nspoke': 11, '"I simply don\'t consider him more dishonest than any other\nwealthy merchant or nobleman': 14, "They've all made their money alike—by\ntheir work and their intelligence": 11, '"\n\n"Oh, by what work': 5, 'Do you call it work to get hold of concessions and\nspeculate with them': 14, '"\n\n"Of course it\'s work': 5, 'Work in this sense, that if it were not for him\nand others like him, there would have been no railways': 21, '"\n\n"But that\'s not work, like the work of a peasant or a learned\nprofession': 15, '"\n\n"Granted, but it\'s work in the sense that his activity produces a\nresult—the railways': 15, 'But of course you think the railways useless': 8, '"\n\n"No, that\'s another question; I am prepared to admit that they\'re\nuseful': 13, 'But all profit that is out of proportion to the labor expended\nis dishonest': 14, '"\n\n"But who is to define what is proportionate': 9, '"\n\n"Making profit by dishonest means, by trickery," said Levin, conscious\nthat he could not draw a distinct line between honesty and dishonesty': 23, '"Such as banking, for instance," he went on': 8, '"It\'s an evil—the amassing\nof huge fortunes without labor, just the same thing as with the spirit\nmonopolies, it\'s only the form that\'s changed': 24, '_Le roi est mort, vive\nle roi_': 7, 'No sooner were the spirit monopolies abolished than the\nrailways came up, and banking companies; that, too, is profit without\nwork': 21, '"\n\n"Yes, that may all be very true and clever': 10, 'Lie down, Krak': 3, '" Stepan\nArkadyevitch called to his dog, who was scratching and turning over all\nthe hay': 16, 'He was obviously convinced of the correctness of his position,\nand so talked serenely and without haste': 17, '"But you have not drawn the\nline between honest and dishonest work': 12, "That I receive a bigger salary\nthan my chief clerk, though he knows more about the work than I\ndo—that's dishonest, I suppose": 23, '"\n\n"I can\'t say': 4, '"\n\n"Well, but I can tell you: your receiving some five thousand, let\'s\nsay, for your work on the land, while our host, the peasant here,\nhowever hard he works, can never get more than fifty roubles, is just\nas dishonest as my earning more than my chief clerk, and Malthus\ngetting more than a station-master': 56, "No, quite the contrary; I see that\nsociety takes up a sort of antagonistic attitude to these people, which\nis utterly baseless, and I fancy there's envy at the bottom of it": 32, '"\n\n"No, that\'s unfair," said Veslovsky; "how could envy come in': 11, 'There is\nsomething not nice about that sort of business': 10, '"\n\n"You say," Levin went on, "that it\'s unjust for me to receive five\nthousand, while the peasant has fifty; that\'s true': 22, 'It is unfair, and I\nfeel it, but': 8, '"\n\n"It really is': 4, 'Why is it we spend our time riding, drinking, shooting,\ndoing nothing, while they are forever at work': 18, '" said Vassenka\nVeslovsky, obviously for the first time in his life reflecting on the\nquestion, and consequently considering it with perfect sincerity': 23, '"Yes, you feel it, but you don\'t give him your property," said Stepan\nArkadyevitch, intentionally, as it seemed, provoking Levin': 20, 'There had arisen of late something like a secret antagonism between the\ntwo brothers-in-law; as though, since they had married sisters, a kind\nof rivalry had sprung up between them as to which was ordering his life\nbest, and now this hostility showed itself in the conversation, as it\nbegan to take a personal note': 55, '"I don\'t give it away, because no one demands that from me, and if I\nwanted to, I could not give it away," answered Levin, "and have no one\nto give it to': 33, '"\n\n"Give it to this peasant, he would not refuse it': 11, '"\n\n"Yes, but how am I to give it up': 10, 'Am I to go to him and make a deed of\nconveyance': 12, '"\n\n"I don\'t know; but if you are convinced that you have no right': 14, '"\n\n"I\'m not at all convinced': 6, 'On the contrary, I feel I have no right to\ngive it up, that I have duties both to the land and to my family': 25, '"\n\n"No, excuse me, but if you consider this inequality is unjust, why is\nit you don\'t act accordingly': 19, '"\n\n"Well, I do act negatively on that idea, so far as not trying to\nincrease the difference of position existing between him and me': 25, '"\n\n"No, excuse me, that\'s a paradox': 7, after\nhim': 18, '"Yes, capital," answered Levin, still thinking of the subject of their\nconversation just before': 14, 'It seemed to him that he had clearly\nexpressed his thoughts and feelings to the best of his capacity, and\nyet both of them, straightforward men and not fools, had said with one\nvoice that he was comforting himself with sophistries': 41, 'This\ndisconcerted him': 3, '"It\'s just this, my dear boy': 6, "One must do one of two things: either\nadmit that the existing order of society is just, and then stick up for\none's rights in it; or acknowledge that you are enjoying unjust\nprivileges, as I do, and then enjoy them and be satisfied": 44, '"\n\n"No, if it were unjust, you could not enjoy these advantages and be\nsatisfied—at least I could not': 19, "The great thing heard the horses\nmunching hay, then he heard the peasant and his elder boy getting ready\nfor the night, and going off for the night watch with the beasts, then\nhe heard the soldier arranging his bed on the other side of the barn,\nwith his nephew, the younger son of their peasant host': 55, 'He heard the\nboy in his shrill little voice telling his uncle what he thought about\nthe dogs, who seemed to him huge and terrible creatures, and asking\nwhat the dogs were going to hunt next day, and the soldier in a husky,\nsleepy voice, telling him the sportsmen were going in the morning to\nthe marsh, and would shoot with their guns; and then, to check the\nboy\'s questions, he said, "Go to sleep, Vaska; go to sleep, or you\'ll\ncatch it," and soon after he began snoring himself, and everything was\nstill': 94, 'He could only hear the snort of the horses, and the guttural cry\nof a snipe': 16, '"Is it really only negative': 5, '" he repeated to himself': 5, '"Well, what of\nit': ('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART SIX', {'Waking up at earliest dawn, Levin tried to wake his companions': 11, 'Vassenka, lying on his stomach, with one leg in a stocking thrust out,\nwas sleeping so soundly that he could elicit no response': 23, 'Oblonsky,\nhalf asleep, declined to get up so early': 9, 'Even Laska, who was asleep,\ncurled up in the hay, got up unwillingly, and lazily stretched out and\nstraightened her hind legs one after the other': 26, 'Getting on his boots\nand stockings, taking his gun, and carefully opening the creaking door\nof the barn, Levin went out into the road': 24, 'The coachmen were sleeping\nin their carriages, the horses were dozing': 11, 'Only one was lazily eating\noats, dipping its nose into the manger': 12, 'It was still gray out-of-doors': 5, '"Why are you up so early, my dear': 8, '" the old woman, their hostess, said,\ncoming out of the hut and addressing him affectionately as an old\nfriend': 20, '"Going shooting, granny': 3, 'Do I go this way to the marsh': 8, '"\n\n"Straight out at the back; by our threshing floor, my dear, and hemp\npatches; there\'s a little footpath': 19, '" Stepping carefully with her\nsunburnt, bare feet, the old woman conducted Levin, and moved back the\nfence for him by the threshing floor': 24, '"Straight on and you\'ll come to the marsh': 8, 'Our lads drove the cattle\nthere yesterday evening': 8, '"\n\nLaska ran eagerly forward along the little path': 9, 'Levin followed her\nwith a light, rapid step, continually looking at the sky': 13, 'He hoped the\nsun would not be up before he reached the marsh': 13, 'But the sun did not\ndelay': 6, 'The moon, which had been bright when he went out, by now shone\nonly like a crescent of quicksilver': 19, 'The pink flush of dawn, which one\ncould not help seeing before, now had to be sought to be discerned at\nall': 22, 'What were before undefined, vague blurs in the distant countryside\ncould now be distinctly seen': 15, 'They were sheaves of rye': 5, "The dew, not\nvisible till the sun was up, wetted Levin's legs and his blouse above\nhis belt in the high growing, fragrant hemp patch, from which the\npollen had already fallen out": 33, 'In the transparent stillness of morning\nthe smallest sounds were audible': 11, "A bee flew by Levin's ear with the\nwhizzing sound of a bullet": 13, 'He looked carefully, and saw a second and a\nthird': 10, 'They were all flying from the beehives behind the hedge, and\nthey disappeared over the hemp patch in the direction of the marsh': 23, 'The\npath led straight to the marsh': 7, 'The marsh could be recognized by the\nmist which rose from it, thicker in one place and thinner in another,\nso that the reeds and willow bushes swayed like islands in this mist': 33, 'At the edge of the marsh and the road, peasant boys and men, who had\nbeen herding for the night, were lying, and in the dawn all were asleep\nunder their coats': 32, 'Not far from them were three hobbled horses': 8, 'One of\nthem clanked a chain': 6, 'Laska walked beside her master, pressing a little\nforward and looking round': 12, 'Passing the sleeping peasants and reaching\nthe first reeds, Levin examined his pistols and let his dog off': 18, 'One of\nthe horses, a sleek, dark-brown three-year-old, seeing the dog, started\naway, switched its tail and snorted': 18, 'The other horses too were\nfrightened, and splashing through the water with their hobbled legs,\nand drawing their hoofs out of the thick mud with a squelching sound,\nthey bounded out of the marsh': 34, 'Laska stopped, looking ironically at the\nhorses and inquiringly at Levin': 11, 'Levin patted Laska, and whistled as a\nsign that she might begin': 12, 'Laska ran joyfully and anxiously through the slush that swayed under\nher': 12, 'Running into the marsh among the familiar scents of roots, marsh\nplants, and slime, and the extraneous smell of horse dung, Laska\ndetected at once a smell that pervaded the whole marsh, the scent of\nthat strong-smelling bird that always excited her more than any other': 46, 'Here and there among the moss and marsh plants this scent was very\nstrong, but it was impossible to determine in which direction it grew\nstronger or fainter': 28, 'To find the direction, she had to go farther away\nfrom the wind': 13, 'Not feeling the motion of her legs, Laska bounded with a\nstiff gallop, so that at each bound she could stop short, to the right,\naway from the wind that blew from the east before sunrise, and turned\nfacing the wind': 41, 'Sniffing in the air with dilated nostrils, she felt at\nonce that not their tracks only but they themselves were here before\nher, and not one, but many': 28, 'Laska slackened her speed': 4, 'They were here,\nbut where precisely she could not yet determine': 11, "To find the very spot,\nshe began to make a circle, when suddenly her master's voice drew her\noff": 19, '"Laska': 1, 'here': 1, '" he asked, pointing her to a different direction': 9, 'She stopped, asking him if she had better not go on doing as she had\nbegun': 16, 'But he repeated his command in an angry voice, pointing to a\nspot covered with water, where there could not be anything': 22, 'She obeyed\nhim, pretending she was looking, so as to please him, went round it,\nand went back to her former position, and was at once aware of the\nscent again': 31, 'Now when he was not hindering her, she knew what to do,\nand without looking at what was under her feet, and to her vexation\nstumbling over a high stump into the water, but righting herself with\nher strong, supple legs, she began making the circle which was to make\nall clear to her': 54, 'The scent of them reached her, stronger and stronger,\nand more and more defined, and all at once it became perfectly clear to\nher that one of them was here, behind this tuft of reeds, five paces in\nfront of her; she stopped, and her whole body was still and rigid': 51, 'On\nher short legs she could see nothing in front of her, but by the scent\nshe knew it was sitting not more than five paces off': 27, 'She stood still,\nfeeling more and more conscious of it, and enjoying it in anticipation': 15, 'Her tail was stretched straight and tense, and only wagging at the\nextreme end': 14, 'Her mouth was slightly open, her ears raised': 8, 'One ear had\nbeen turned wrong side out as she ran up, and she breathed heavily but\nwarily, and still more warily looked round, but more with her eyes than\nher head, to her master': 35, 'He was coming along with the face she knew so\nwell, though the eyes were always terrible to her': 19, 'He stumbled over the\nstump as he came, and moved, as she thought, extraordinarily slowly': 15, 'She thought he came slowly, but he was running': 9, "Noticing Laska's special luck, especially with the first bird, he ran up to\nher": 50, 'Coming quite close up to her, he could from his height look beyond\nher, and he saw with his eyes what she was seeing with her nose': 27, "In a\nspace between two little thickets, at a couple of yards' distance, he\ncould see a grouse": 18, 'Turning its head, it was listening': 6, 'Then lightly\npreening and folding its wings, it bushes': 34, 'She scented nothing now; she could\nonly see and hear, without understanding anything': 13, 'Ten paces from her former place a grouse rose with a guttural cry and\nthe peculiar round ('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART SIX', {"The sportsman's saying, that if the first beast or the first bird is\nnot missed, the day will be lucky, turned out correct": 23, "At ten o'clock Levin, weary, hungry, and happy after a tramp of twenty\nmiles, returned to his night's lodging with nineteen head of fine game\nand one duck, which he tied to his belt, as it would not go into the\ngame bag": 43, 'His so incredible; on the other, as an event so\nmysterious, that this assumption of a definite knowledge of what would\nbe, and consequent preparation for it, as for something ordinary that\ndid happen his\nagitated face, that they looked like people fleeing from some disaster,\nthey went on with rapid steps, feeling that they must speak out and\nclear up misunderstandings, must be alone together, before her again in\nthe same position with his clenched fists on his chest, as he had stood\nbefore her that night': 26, '"Yes," she said in a shaking voice; "but, Kostya, surely you see I\'m\nnot to blame': 16, "All the morning I've been trying to take a tone": 10, 'but\nsuch people': 3, 'Why did he come': 4, 'How happy we were': 4, '" she said,\nbreathless with the sobs that shook her': 10, ('TOL CHAPTER 15 PART SIX', {"After escorting his wife upstairs, Levin went to Dolly's part of the\nhouse": 13, 'Darya Alexandrovna, for her part, was in great distress too that\nday': 12, 'She was ('TOL CHAPTER 16 PART SIX', {'Darya Alexandrovna carried out her intention and went to see Anna': 11, 'She\nwas sorry to annoy her sister and to do anything Levin disliked': 13, 'She\nquite understood how right the Levins were in not wishing to have\nanything to do with Vronsky': 18, 'But she felt she must go and see Anna, and\nshow her that her feelings could not be changed, in spite of the change\nin her position': 27, 'That she might be independent of the Levins in this\nexpedition, Darya Alexandrovna sent to the village to hire horses for\nthe drive; but Levin learning of it went to her to protest': 33, '"What makes you suppose that I dislike your going': 9, 'But, even if I did\ndislike it, I should still more dislike your not taking my horses," he\nsaid': 19, '"You never told me that you were going for certain': 10, "Hiring horses\nin the village is disagreeable to me, and, what's of more importance,\nthey'll undertake the job and never get you there": 23, 'I have horses': 3, "And\nif you don't want to wound me, you'll take mine": 11, '"\n\nDarya Alexandrovna had to consent, and on the day fixed Levin had ready\nfor his sister-in-law a set of four horses and relays, getting them\ntogether from the farm and saddle-horses—not at all a smart-looking\nset, but capable of taking Darya Alexandrovna the whole distance in a\nsingle day': 50, 'At that moment, when horses were wanted for the princess,\nwho was going, and for the midwife, it was a difficult matter for Levin\nto make up the number, but the duties of hospitality would not let him\nallow Darya Alexandrovna to hire horses when staying in his house': 49, "Moreover, he was well aware that the twenty roubles that would be asked\nfor the journey were a serious matter for her; Darya Alexandrovna's\npecuniary affairs, which were in a very unsatisfactory state, were\ntaken to heart by the Levins as if they were their own": 46, "Darya Alexandrovna, by Levin's advice, started before daybreak": 8, 'The\nroad was good, the carriage comfortable, the horses trotted along\nmerrily, and on the box, besides the coachman, sat the counting-house\nclerk, whom Levin was sending instead of a groom for greater security': 34, 'Darya Alexandrovna dozed and waked up only on reaching the inn where\nthe horses were to be changed': 18, "After drinking tea at the same well-to-do peasant's with whom Levin had\nstayed on the way to Sviazhsky's, and chatting with the women about\ntheir children, and with the old man about Count Vronsky, whom the\nlatter praised very highly, Darya Alexandrovna, at ten o'clock, went on\nagain": 48, 'At home, looking after her children, she had no time to think': 12, 'So now, after this journey of four hours, all the thoughts she had\nsuppressed before rushed swarming into her brain, and she thought over\nall her life as she never had before, and from the most different\npoints of view': 40, 'Her thoughts seemed strange even to herself': 7, 'At first\nshe thought about the children, about whom she was uneasy, although the\nprincess and Kitty (she reckoned more upon her) had promised to look\nafter them': 28, '"If only Masha does not begin her naughty tricks, if Grisha\nisn\'t kicked by a horse, and Lily\'s stomach isn\'t upset again': 22, '" she\nthought': 3, 'But these questions of the present were succeeded by questions\nof the immediate future': 14, 'She began thinking how she had to get a new\nflat in Moscow for the coming winter, to renew the drawing-room\nfurniture, and to make her elder girl a cloak': 30, 'Then questions of the\nmore remote future occurred to her: how she was to place her children\nin the world': 20, '"The girls are all right," she thought; "but the boys': 10, '"\n\n"It\'s very well that I\'m teaching Grisha, but of course that\'s only\nbecause I am free myself now, I\'m not with child': 23, "Stiva, of course,\nthere's no counting on": 7, "And with the help of good-natured friends I can\nbring them up; but if there's another baby coming": 18, '" And the thought\nstruck her how untruly it was said that the curse laid on woman was\nthat in sorrow she should bring forth children': 26, '"The birth itself, that\'s nothing; but the months of carrying the\nchild—that\'s what\'s so intolerable," she thought, picturing to herself\nher last pregnancy, and the death of the last baby': 30, 'And she recalled\nthe conversation she had just had with the young woman at the inn': 16, 'On\nbeing asked whether she had any children, the handsome young woman had\nanswered cheerfully:\n\n"I had a girl baby, but God set me free; I buried her last Lent': 30, '"\n\n"Well, did you grieve very much for her': 9, '" asked Darya Alexandrovna': 4, '"Why grieve': 2, 'The old man has grandchildren enough as it is': 9, 'It was only\na trouble': 5, 'No working, nor nothing': 4, 'Only a tie': 3, '"\n\nThis answer had struck Darya Alexandrovna as revolting in spite of the\ngood-natured and pleasing face of the young woman; but now she could\nnot help recalling these words': 30, 'In those cynical words there was indeed\na grain of truth': 11, '"Yes, altogether," thought Darya Alexandrovna, looking back over her\nwhole existence during those fifteen years of her married life,\n"pregnancy, sickness, mental incapacity, indifference to everything,\nand most of all—hideousness': 30, "Kitty, young and pretty as she is, even\nKitty has lost her looks; and I when I'm with child become hideous, I\nknow it": 24, 'The birth, the agony, the hideous agonies, that last moment': 10, 'then the nursing, the sleepless nights, the fearful pains': 9, '"\n\nDarya Alexandrovna shuddered at the mere recollection of the pain from\nsore breasts which she had suffered with almost every child': 22, '"Then the\nchildren\'s illnesses, that everlasting apprehension; then bringing them\nup; evil propensities" (she thought of little Masha\'s crime among the\nraspberries), "education, Latin—it\'s all so incomprehensible and\ndifficult': 29, 'And on the top of it all, the death of these children': 12, '" And\nthere rose again before her imagination the cruel memory, that always\ntore her mother\'s heart, of the death of her last little baby, who had\ndied of croup; his funeral, the callous indifference of all at the\nlittle pink coffin, and her own torn heart, and her lonely anguish at\nthe sight of the pale little brow with its projecting temples, and the\nopen, wondering little mouth seen in the coffin at the moment when it\nwas being covered with the little pink lid with a cross braided on it': 92, '"And all this, what\'s it for': 6, 'What is to come of it all': 7, "That I'm\nwasting my life, never having a moment's peace, either with child, or\nnursing a child, forever irritable, peevish, wretched myself and\nworrying others, repulsive to my husband, while the children are\ngrowing up unhappy, badly educated, and penniless": 40, "Even now, if it\nweren't for spending the summer at the Levins', I don't know how we\nshould be managing to live": 22, "Of course Kostya and Kitty have so much\ntact that we don't feel it; but it can't go on": 19, "They'll have children,\nthey won't be able to keep us; it's a drag on them as it is": 18, 'How is\npapa, who has hardly anything left for himself, to help us': 13, "So that I\ncan't even bring the children up by myself, and may find it hard with\nthe help of other people, at the cost of humiliation": 27, "Why, even if we\nsuppose the greatest good luck, that the children don't die, and I\nbring them up somehow": 20, "At the very best they'll simply be decent\npeople": 9, "That's all I can hope for": 6, 'And to gain simply that—what\nagonies, what toil': 8, "One's whole life ruined": 4, '" Again she recalled\nwhat the young peasant woman had said, and again she was revolted at\nthe thought; but she could not help admitting that there was a grain of\nbrutal truth in the words': 36, '"Is it far now, Mihail': 5, '" Darya Alexandrovna asked the counting-house\nclerk, to turn her mind from thoughts that were frightening her': 17, '"From this village, they say, it\'s five miles': 8, '" The carriage drove\nalong the village street and onto a bridge': 12, 'On the bridge was a crowd\nof peasant women with coils of ties for the sheaves on their shoulders,\ngaily and noisily chattering': 23, 'They stood still on the bridge, staring\ninquisitively at the carriage': 11, 'All the faces turned to Darya\nAlexandrovna looked to her healthy and happy, making her envious of\ntheir enjoyment of life': 21, '"They\'re all living, they\'re all enjoying\nlife," Darya Alexandrovna still mused when she had passed the peasant\nwomen and was driving uphill again at a trot, seated comfortably on the\nsoft springs of the old carriage, "while I, let out, as it were from\nprison, from the world of worries that fret me to death, am only\nlooking about me now for an instant': 64, 'They all live; those peasant women\nand my sister Natalia and Varenka and Anna, whom I am going to see—all,\nbut not I': 23, '"And they attack Anna': 4, 'What for': 2, 'am I any better': 4, 'I have, anyway, a\nhusband I love—not as I should like to love him, still I do love him,\nwhile Anna never loved hers': 24, 'How is she to blame': 5, 'She wants to live': 4, 'God has put that in our hearts': 7, 'Very likely I should have done the\nsame': 8, "Even to this day I don't feel sure I did right in listening to\nher at that terrible time when she came to me in Moscow": 26, 'I ought then\nto have cast off my husband and have begun my life fresh': 15, 'I might have\nloved and have been loved in reality': 10, 'And is it any better as it is': 8, "I\ndon't respect him": 4, 'He\'s necessary to me," she thought about her\nhusband, "and I put up with him': 15, 'Is that any better': 4, 'At that time I\ncould still have been admired, I had beauty left me still," Darya\nAlexandrovna pursued her thoughts, and she would have liked to look at\nherself in the looking-glass': 32, 'She had a traveling looking-glass in her\nhandbag, and she wanted to take it out; but looking at the backs of the\ncoachman and the swaying counting-house clerk, she felt that she would\nbe ashamed if either of them were to look round, and she did not take\nout the glass': 51, "But without looking in the glass, she thought that even now it was not\ntoo late; and she thought of Sergey Ivanovitch, who was always\nparticularly attentive to her, of Stiva's good-hearted friend,\nTurovtsin, who had helped her nurse her children through the\nscarlatina, and was in love with her": 50, 'And there was someone else, a\nquite young man, who—her husband had told her it as a joke—thought her\nmore beautiful than either of her sisters': 26, "And the most passionate and\nimpossible romances rose before Darya Alexandrovna's imagination": 12, '"Anna\ndid quite right, and certainly I shall never reproach her for it': 13, 'She\nis happy, she makes another person happy, and she\'s not broken down as\nI am, but most likely just as she always was, bright, clever, open to\nevery impression," thought Darya Alexandrovna,—and a sly smile curved\nher lips, for, as she pondered on Anna\'s love affair, Darya\nAlexandrovna constructed on parallel lines an almost identical love\naffair for herself, with an imaginary composite figure, the ideal man\nwho was in love with her': 74, 'She, like Anna, confessed the whole affair to\nher husband': 10, 'And the amazement and perplexity of Stepan Arkadyevitch at\nthis avowal made her smile': 14, 'In such daydreams she reached the turning of the highroad that led to\nVozdvizhenskoe': 14, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART SIX', {'The coachman pulled up his four horses and looked round to the right,\nto a field of rye, where some peasants were sitting on a cart': 26, 'The\ncounting-house clerk was just going to jump down, but on second\nthoughts he shouted peremptorily to the peasants instead, and beckoned\nto them to come up': 27, 'The wind, that seemed to blow as they drove,\ndropped when the carriage stood still; gadflies settled on the steaming\nhorses that angrily shook them off': 26, 'The metallic clank of a whetstone\nagainst a scythe, that came to them from the cart, ceased': 17, 'One of the\npeasants got up and came towards the carriage': 11, '"Well, you are slow': 4, '" the counting-house clerk shouted angrily to the\npeasant who was stepping slowly with his bare feet over the ruts of the\nrough dry road': 25, '"Come along, do': 3, '"\n\nA curly-headed old man with a bit of bast tied round his hair, and his\nbent back dark with perspiration, came towards the carriage, walking\nher horse, a sturdy English cob with cropped mane and short tail, her\nbeautiful head with her black hair straying loose under her high hat,\nher full shoulders, her slender waist in her black riding habit, and\nall the ease and grace of her deportment, impressed Dolly': 50, 'For the first minute it seemed to her unsuitable for Anna to be on\nhorseback': 15, "The conception of riding on horseback for a lady was, in\nDarya Alexandrovna's mind, associated with ideas of youthful flirtation\nand frivolity, which, in her opinion, was unbecoming in Anna's\nposition": 31, 'But when she had scrutinized her, seeing her closer, she was\nat once reconciled to her riding': 17, 'In spite of her elegance, everything\nwas so simple, quiet, and dignified in the attitude, the dress and the\nmovements of Anna, that nothing could have been more natural': 29, 'Beside Anna, on a hot-looking gray cavalry horse, was Vassenka\nVeslovsky in his Scotch cap with floating ribbons, his stout corner of the old carriage, she\nrecognized Dolly": 27, 'She uttered a cry, started in the saddle, and set her\nhorse into a gallop': 15, 'On reaching the carriage she jumped off without\nassistance, and holding up her riding habit, she ran up to greet Dolly': 21, '"I thought it was you and dared not think it': 10, 'How delightful': 2, "You can't\nfancy how glad I am": 7, '" she said, at one moment pressing her face against\nDolly and kissing her, and at the next holding her off and examining\nher with a smile': 27, '"Here\'s a delightful surprise, Alexey': 5, '" she said, looking round at\nVronsky, who had dismounted, and was walking towards them': 15, 'Vronsky, taking off his tall gray hat, went up to Dolly': 11, '"You wouldn\'t believe how glad we are to see you," he said, giving\npeculiar significance to the words, and showing his strong white teeth\nin a smile': 27, 'Vassenka Veslovsky, without getting off his horse, took off his cap and\ngreeted the visitor by gleefully waving the ribbons over his head': 23, '"That\'s Princess Varvara," Anna said in reply to a glance of inquiry\nfrom Dolly as the _char-à-banc_ drove up': 19, '"Ah': 1, '" said Darya Alexandrovna, and unconsciously her face betrayed her\ndissatisfaction': 11, "Princess Varvara was her husband's aunt, and she had long known her,\nand did not respect her": 17, 'She knew that Princess Varvara had passed her\nwhole life toadying on her rich relations, but that she should now be\nsponging on Vronsky, a man who was nothing to her, mortified Dolly on\naccount of her kinship with her husband': 41, "Anna noticed Dolly's\nexpression, and was disconcerted by it": 9, 'She blushed, dropped her riding\nhabit, and stumbled over it': 10, 'Darya Alexandrovna went up to the _char-à-banc_ and coldly greeted\nPrincess Varvara': 12, 'Sviazhsky too she knew': 4, 'He inquired how his queer\nfriend with the young wife was, and running his eyes over the\nill-matched horses and the carriage with its patched mud-guards,\nproposed to the ladies that they should get into the _char-à-banc_': 37, '"And I\'ll get into this vehicle," he said': 8, '"The horse is quiet, and the\nprincess drives capitally': 9, '"\n\n"No, stay as you were," said Anna, coming up, "and we\'ll go in the\ncarriage," and taking Dolly\'s arm, she drew her away': 24, "Darya Alexandrovna's eyes were fairly dazzled by the elegant carriage\nof a pattern she had never seen before, the splendid horses, and the\nelegant and gorgeous people surrounding her": 29, 'But what struck her most\nof all was the change that had taken place in Anna, whom she knew so\nwell and loved': 23, 'Any other woman, a less close observer, not knowing\nAnna before, or not having thought as Darya Alexandrovna had been\nthinking on the road, would not have noticed anything special in Anna': 32, "But now Dolly was struck by that temporary beauty, which is only found\nin women during the moments of love, and which she saw now in Anna's\nface": 28, 'Everything in her face, the clearly marked dimples in her cheeks\nand chin, the line of her lips, the smile which, as it were, fluttered\nabout her face, the brilliance of her eyes, the grace and rapidity of\nher movements, the fulness of the notes of her voice, even the manner\nin which, with a sort of angry friendliness, she answered Veslovsky\nwhen he asked permission to get on her cob, so as to teach it to gallop\nwith the right leg foremost—it was all peculiarly fascinating, and it\nseemed as if she were herself aware of it, and rejoicing in it': 102, 'When both the women were seated in the carriage, a sudden embarrassment\ncame over both of them': 17, 'Anna was disconcerted by the intent look of\ninquiry Dolly fixed upon her': 13, 'Dolly was embarrassed because after\nSviazhsky\'s phrase about "this vehicle," she could not help feeling\nashamed of the dirty old carriage in which Anna was sitting with her': 28, 'The coachman Philip and the counting-house clerk were experiencing the\nsame sensation': 12, 'The counting-house clerk, to conceal his confusion,\nbusied himself settling the ladies, but Philip the coachman became\nsullen, and was bracing himself not to be overawed in future by this\nexternal superiority': 32, "He smiled ironically, looking at the raven horse,\nand was already deciding in his own mind that this smart trotter in the\n_char-à-banc_ was only good for _promenage_, and wouldn't do thirty\nmiles straight off in the heat": 38, 'The peasants had all got up from the cart and were inquisitively and\nmirthfully staring at the meeting of the friends, making their comments\non it': 26, '"They\'re pleased, too; haven\'t seen each other for a long while," said\nthe curly-headed old man with the bast round his hair': 22, '"I say, Uncle Gerasim, if we could take that raven horse now, to cart\nthe corn, that \'ud be quick work': 21, '"\n\n"Look-ee': 2, 'Is that a woman in breeches': 6, '" said one of them, pointing to\nVassenka Veslovsky sitting in a side saddle': 14, '"Nay, a man': 3, "See how smartly he's going it": 6, '"\n\n"Eh, lads': 3, "seems we're not going to sleep, then": 7, '"\n\n"What chance of sleep today': 6, '" said the old man, with a sidelong look at\nthe sun': 12, '"Midday\'s past, look-ee': 3, 'Get your hooks, and come along': 6, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART SIX', {"Anna looked at Dolly's thin, care-worn face, with its wrinkles filled\nwith dust from the road, and she was on the point of saying what she\nwas thinking, that is, that Dolly had got thinner": 35, "But, conscious that\nshe herself had grown handsomer, and that Dolly's eyes were telling her\nso, she sighed and began to speak about herself": 24, '"You are looking at me," she said, "and wondering how I can be happy in\nmy position': 17, 'Well': 1, "it's shameful to confess, but I": 6, "I'm inexcusably\nhappy": 3, "Something magical has happened to me, like a dream, when you're\nfrightened, panic-stricken, and all of a sudden you wake up and all the\nhorrors are no more": 28, 'I have waked up': 4, "I have lived through the misery,\nthe dread, and now for a long while past, especially since we've been\nhere, I've been so happy": 24, '" she said, with a timid smile of inquiry\nlooking at Dolly': 12, '"How glad I am': 4, '" said Dolly smiling, involuntarily speaking more coldly\nthan she wanted to': 12, '"I\'m very glad for you': 5, "Why haven't you written to\nme": 6, '"\n\n"Why': 2, "Because I hadn't the courage": 5, 'You forget my do you think of it': 13, '" she\nasked': 3, '"I consider': 2, '" Darya Alexandrovna was beginning, but at that instant\nVassenka Veslovsky, having brought the cob to gallop with the right anything," she said, "but I always loved you, and if one\nloves anyone, one loves the whole person, just as they are and not as\none would like them to be': 34, '"\n\nAnna, taking her eyes off her friend\'s face and dropping her eyelids\n(this was a new habit Dolly had not seen in her before), pondered,\ntrying to penetrate the full significance of the words': 35, 'And obviously\ninterpreting this place, and, what I never\nexpected, he has become intensely interested in looking after it': 21, 'But\nhis is such a rich nature': 7, 'Whatever he takes up, he does splendidly': 7, 'So\nfar from being bored by it, he works with passionate interest': 12, 'He—with\nhis temperament as I know it—he has become careful and businesslike, a\nfirst-rate manager, he positively reckons every penny in his management\nof the land': 26, 'But only in that': 4, "When it's a question of tens of\nthousands, he doesn't think of money": 13, '" She spoke with that gleefully\nsly smile with which women often that's his hobby just now": 14, 'And do you know how it all came\nabout': 9, 'The peasants asked him for some meadowland, I think it was, at a\ncheaper rate, and he refused, and I accused him of being miserly': 25, 'Of\ncourse it was not really because of that, but everything together, he\nbegan this hospital to prove, do you see, that he was not miserly about\nmoney': 28, "_C'est une petitesse_, ('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART SIX', {"Left alone, Darya Alexandrovna, with a good housewife's eye, scanned\nher room": 12, 'All she had seen in entering the house and walking through\nit, and all she saw now in her room, gave her an impression of wealth\nand sumptuousness and of that modern European luxury of which she had\nonly read in English novels, but had never seen in Russia and in the\ncountry': 53, 'Everything was new from the new French hangings on the walls\nto the carpet which covered the whole floor': 19, 'The bed had a spring\nmattress, and a special sort of bolster and silk pillowcases on the\nlittle pillows': 19, 'The marble washstand, the dressing table, the little\nsofa, the tables, the bronze clock on the chimney piece, the window\ncurtains, and the _portières_ were all new and expensive': 29, "The smart maid, who came in to offer her services, with her hair done\nup high, and a gown more fashionable than Dolly's, was as new and\nexpensive as the whole room": 32, 'Darya Alexandrovna liked her neatness, her\ndeferential and obliging manners, but she felt ill at ease with her': 18, 'She felt ashamed of her seeing the patched dressing jacket that had\nunluckily been packed by mistake for her': 19, 'She was ashamed of the very\npatches and darned places of which she had been so proud at home': 19, 'At\nhome it had been so clear that for six dressing jackets there would be\nneeded twenty-four yards of nainsook at sixteen pence the yard, which\nwas a matter of thirty shillings besides the cutting-out and making,\nand these thirty shillings had been saved': 44, 'But before the maid she\nfelt, if not exactly ashamed, at least uncomfortable': 13, 'Darya Alexandrovna had a great sense of relief when Annushka, whom she\nhad known for years, walked in': 18, 'The smart maid was sent for to go to\nher mistress, and Annushka remained with Darya Alexandrovna': 17, "Annushka was obviously much pleased at that lady's arrival, and began\nto chatter away without a pause": 17, "Dolly observed that she was longing to\nexpress her opinion in regard to her mistress's position, especially as\nto the love and devotion of the count to Anna Arkadyevna, but washing small things,\nbut most of the linen's done by machinery": 17, 'The count goes into\neverything himself': 6, 'Ah, what a husband': 4, '"\n\nDolly was glad when Anna came in, and by her which\nsuch simplicity was obtained': 14, '"An old friend," said Anna of Annushka': 7, 'Anna was not embarrassed now': 5, 'She was perfectly composed and at ease': 7, 'Dolly saw that she had now ('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART SIX', {'"Here\'s Dolly for you, princess, you were so anxious to see her," said\nAnna, coming out with Darya Alexandrovna onto the stone terrace where\nPrincess Varvara was sitting in the shade at an embroidery frame,\nworking at a cover for Count Alexey Kirillovitch\'s easy chair': 45, '"She\nsays she doesn\'t want anything before dinner, but please order some\nlunch for her, and I\'ll go and look for Alexey and bring them all in': 27, '"\n\nPrincess Varvara gave Dolly a cordial and rather patronizing reception,\nand began at once explaining to her that she was living with Anna\nbecause she had always cared more for her than her sister Katerina\nPavlovna, the aunt that had brought Anna up, and that now, when\neveryone had abandoned Anna, she thought it her duty to help her in\nthis most difficult period of transition': 67, '"Her husband will give her a divorce, and then I shall go back to my\nsolitude; but now I can be of use, and I am doing my duty, however\ndifficult it may be for me—not like some other people': 40, 'And how sweet it\nis of you, how right of you to have come': 14, "They live like the best of\nmarried couples; it's for God to judge them, not for us": 17, "And didn't\nBiryuzovsky and Madame Avenieva": 6, 'and Sam Nikandrov, and Vassiliev\nand Madame Mamonova, and Liza Neptunova': 11, 'Did no one say anything\nabout them':
