puis on se sépare': 12, '_\nEveryone does as he pleases till dinner time': 9, "Dinner at seven o'clock": 4, 'Stiva did very rightly to send you': 7, 'He needs their support': 4, 'You know\nthat through his mother and brother he can do anything': 12, 'And then they\ndo so much good': 7, "He didn't tell you about his hospital": 7, '_Ce sera\nadmirable_—everything from Paris': 5, '"\n\nTheir conversation was interrupted by Anna, who had found the men of\nthe party in the billiard room, and returned with them to the terrace': 26, 'There was still a long time before the dinner-hour, it was exquisite\nweather, and so several different methods of spending the next two\nhours were proposed': 26, 'There were very many methods of passing the time\nat Vozdvizhenskoe, and these were all unlike those in use at\nPokrovskoe': 21, '"_Une partie de lawn-tennis,_" Veslovsky proposed, with his handsome\nsmile': 10, '"We\'ll be partners again, Anna Arkadyevna': 6, '"\n\n"No, it\'s too hot; better stroll about the garden and have a row in the\nboat, show Darya Alexandrovna the river banks': 23, '" Vronsky proposed': 3, '"I agree to anything," said Sviazhsky': 6, '"I imagine that what Dolly would like best would be a stroll—wouldn\'t\nyou': 13, 'And then the boat, perhaps," said Anna': 7, 'So it was decided': 4, 'Veslovsky and Tushkevitch went off to the bathing\nplace, promising to get the boat ready and to wait there for them': 21, 'They walked along the path in two couples, Anna with Sviazhsky, and\nDolly with Vronsky': 15, 'Dolly was a little embarrassed and anxious in the\nnew surroundings in which she found herself': 16, "Abstractly, theoretically,\nshe did not merely justify, she positively approved of Anna's conduct": 13, 'As is indeed not unfrequent with women of unimpeachable virtue, weary\nof the monotony of respectable existence, at a distance she not only\nexcused illicit love, she positively envied it': 30, 'Besides, she loved Anna\nwith all her heart': 8, 'But seeing Anna in actual life among these\nstrangers, with this fashionable tone that was so new to Darya\nAlexandrovna, she felt ill at ease': 25, 'What she disliked particularly was\nseeing Princess Varvara ready to overlook everything for the sake of\nthe comforts she enjoyed': 20, "As a general principle, abstractly, Dolly approved of Anna's action;\nbut to see the man for whose sake her action had been taken was\ndisagreeable to her": 27, 'Moreover, she had never liked Vronsky': 6, 'She thought\nhim very proud, and saw nothing in him of which he could be proud\nexcept his wealth': 19, 'But against her own will, here in his own house, he\noverawed her more than ever, and she could not be at ease with him': 25, 'She\nfelt with him the same feeling she had had with the maid about her\ndressing jacket': 17, 'Just as with the maid she had felt not exactly\nashamed, but embarrassed at her darns, so she felt with him not exactly\nashamed, but embarrassed at herself': 28, 'Dolly was ill at ease, and tried to find a subject of conversation': 13, 'Even though she supposed that, through his pride, praise of his house\nand garden would be sure to be disagreeable to him, she did all the\nsame tell him how much she liked his house': 35, '"Yes, it\'s a very fine building, and in the good old-fashioned style,"\nhe said': 14, '"I like so much the court in front of the steps': 11, 'Was that always so': 4, '"\n\n"Oh, no': 3, '" he said, and his face beamed with pleasure': 9, '"If you could\nonly have seen that court last spring': 10, '"\n\nAnd he began, at first which\nwas not yet painted, shone with dazzling brightness in the sunshine': 15, 'Beside the finished building another had been begun, surrounded by\nscaffolding': 11, 'Workmen in aprons, standing on walls were stuccoed to look like\nmarble, the huge plate-glass windows were already in, only the parquet\nfloor was not yet finished, and the carpenters, who were planing a\nblock of it, left their work, taking off the bands that fastened their\nhair, to greet the gentry': 48, '"This is the reception room," said Vronsky': 7, '"Here there will be a desk,\ntables, and benches, and nothing more': springs': 11, 'Then he\nshowed them the wards one after another, the storeroom, the linen room,\nthen the heating stove of a new pattern, then the trolleys, which would\nmake no noise as they carried everything needed along the corridors,\nand many other things': 42, 'Sviazhsky, as a connoisseur in the latest\nmechanical improvements, appreciated everything fully': 12, 'Dolly simply\nwondered at ('TOL CHAPTER 22 PART SIX', {'When Anna found Dolly at home before her, she looked intently in her\neyes, as though questioning her about the talk she had had with\nVronsky, but she made no inquiry in words': 33, '"I believe it\'s dinner time," she said': 7, '"We\'ve not seen each other at\nall yet': 8, 'I am reckoning on the evening': 6, 'Now I want to go and dress': 7, 'I\nexpect you do too; we all got splashed at the buildings': 12, '"\n\nDolly went to her room and she felt amused': 10, 'To change her dress was\nimpossible, for she had already put on her best dress': 15, 'But in order to\nsignify in some way her preparation for dinner, she asked the maid to\nbrush her dress, changed her cuffs and tie, and put some lace on her\nhead': 32, '"This is all I can do," she said with a smile to Anna, who came in to\nher in a third dress, again of extreme simplicity': 26, '"Yes, we are too formal here," she said, as it were apologizing for her\nmagnificence': 15, '"Alexey is delighted at your visit, as he rarely is at\nanything': 12, 'He has completely lost his heart to you," she added': 10, '"You\'re\nnot tired': 3, '"\n\nThere was no time for talking about anything before dinner': 11, 'Going into\nthe drawing-room they found Princess Varvara already there, and the\ngentlemen of the party in black frock-coats': 19, 'The architect wore a\nswallow-tail coat': 6, 'Vronsky presented the doctor and the steward to his\nguest': 10, 'The architect he had already introduced to her at the hospital': 11, 'A stout butler, resplendent with a smoothly shaven round chin and a\nstarched white cravat, announced that dinner was ready, and the ladies\ngot up': 25, 'Vronsky asked Sviazhsky to take in Anna Arkadyevna, and himself\noffered his arm to Dolly': 15, 'Veslovsky was before Tushkevitch in offering\nhis arm to Princess Varvara, so that Tushkevitch with the steward and\nthe doctor walked in alone': 23, 'The dinner, the dining-room, the service, the waiting at table, the\nwine, and the food, were not simply in keeping with the general tone of\nmodern luxury throughout all the house, but seemed even more sumptuous\nand modern': 38, 'Darya Alexandrovna watched this luxury which was novel to\nher, and as a good housekeeper used to managing a household—although\nshe never dreamed of adapting anything she saw to her own household, as\nit was all in a style of luxury far above her own manner of living—she\ncould not help scrutinizing every detail, and wondering how and by whom\nit was all done': 64, 'Vassenka Veslovsky, her husband, and even Sviazhsky,\nand many other people she knew, would never have considered this\nquestion, and would have readily believed what every well-bred host\ntries to make his guests feel, that is, that all that is well-ordered\nin his house has cost him, the host, no trouble whatever, but comes of\nitself': 56, "Darya Alexandrovna was well aware that even porridge for the\nchildren's breakfast does not come of itself, and that therefore, where\nso complicated and magnificent a style of luxury was maintained,\nsomeone must give earnest attention to its organization": 39, 'And from the\nglance with which Alexey Kirillovitch scanned the table, from the way\nhe nodded to the butler, and offered Darya Alexandrovna her choice\nbetween cold soup and hot soup, she saw that it was all organized and\nmaintained by the care of the master of the house himself': 50, 'It was\nevident that it all rested no more upon Anna than upon Veslovsky': 14, 'She,\nSviazhsky, the princess, and Veslovsky, were equally guests, with light\nhearts enjoying what had been arranged for them': 19, 'Anna was the hostess only in conducting the conversation': 9, 'The\nconversation was a difficult one for the lady of the house at a small\ntable with persons present, like the steward and the architect,\nbelonging to a completely different world, struggling not to be\noverawed by an elegance to which they were unaccustomed, and unable to\nsustain a large share in the general conversation': 55, 'But this difficult\nconversation Anna directed with her usual tact and naturalness, and\nindeed she did so with actual enjoyment, as Darya Alexandrovna\nobserved': 24, 'The conversation began about the row Tushkevitch and\nVeslovsky had taken alone together in the boat, and Tushkevitch began\ndescribing the last boat races in Petersburg at the Yacht Club': 30, 'But\nAnna, seizing the first pause, at once turned to the architect to draw\nhim out of his silence': 19, '"Nikolay Ivanitch was struck," she first-rate working with his excellency," said the architect with\na smile (he was respectful and composed, though with a sense of his own\ndignity)': 26, '"It\'s a very different matter to have to do business," said Sviazhsky, with a smile': 12, '"Yes, there they build in a rational fashion': 8, '"\n\nThe conversation passed to the misuse of political power in the United\nStates, but Anna quickly brought it round to another topic, so as to\ndraw the steward into talk': 31, '"Have you ever seen a reaping machine': 7, '" she said, addressing Darya\nAlexandrovna': 6, '"We had just ridden over to 'Like this': 2, '"\n\nAnna took a knife and fork in her beautiful white hands covered with\nrings, and began showing how the machine worked': 22, 'It was clear that she\nsaw nothing would be understood from her explanation; but aware that\nher talk was pleasant and her hands beautiful she went on explaining': 28, '"More like little penknives," Veslovsky said playfully, never taking\nhis always wrote in, but\nrecollecting that he was at a dinner, and observing Vronsky\'s chilly\nglance, he checked himself': 36, '_"Zu compliziert, macht zu viel Klopot,"_\nhe concluded': 8, '_"Wünscht flight," the doctor answered with gloomy\njocoseness': 15, '"Then you\'ve taken a good constitutional': 6, '"\n\n"Splendid': 2, '"\n\n"Well, and how was the old woman': 8, "I hope it's not typhus": 5, '"\n\n"Typhus it is not, but it\'s taking a bad turn': 11, '"\n\n"What a pity': 4, '" said Anna, and having thus paid the dues of civility to\nher domestic circle, she turned to her own friends': 21, she knew\nthere was something charming in her disquisitions upon the machine that\nhad been noticed by Sviazhsky': 27, 'This new trait of girlish coquettishness\nmade an unpleasant impression on Dolly': 12, '"But Anna Arkadyevna\'s knowledge of architecture is marvelous," said\nTushkevitch': 10, '"To be sure, I heard Anna Arkadyevna talking yesterday about plinths\nand damp-courses," said Veslovsky': 15, '"Have I got it right': 5, '"\n\n"There\'s nothing marvelous about it, when one sees and hears so much of\nit," said Anna': 17, '"But, I dare say, you don\'t even know what houses are\nmade of': 13, '"\n\nDarya Alexandrovna saw that Anna disliked the tone of raillery that\nexisted between her and Veslovsky, but fell in with it against her\nwill': 25, 'Vronsky acted in this matter quite differently from Levin': 9, "He obviously\nattached no significance to Veslovsky's chattering; on the contrary, he\nencouraged his jests": 15, '"Come now, tell us, Veslovsky, how are the stones held together': 11, '"\n\n"By cement, of course': 5, '"\n\n"Bravo': 2, 'And what is cement': 4, '"\n\n"Oh, some sort of paste': 6, 'no, putty," said Veslovsky, raising a\ngeneral laugh': 8, 'The company at dinner, with the exception of the doctor, the architect,\nand the steward, who remained plunged in gloomy silence, kept up a\nconversation that never paused, glancing off one subject, fastening on\nanother, and at times stinging one or the other to the quick': 46, 'Once\nDarya Alexandrovna felt wounded to the quick, and got so hot that she\npositively flushed and wondered afterwards whether she had said\nanything extreme or unpleasant': 27, 'Sviazhsky began talking of Levin,\ndescribing his strange view that machinery is simply pernicious in its\neffects on Russian agriculture': 20, '"I have not the pleasure of knowing this M': 9, 'Levin," Vronsky said,\nsmiling, "but most likely he has never seen the machines he condemns;\nor if he has seen and tried any, it must have been after a queer\nfashion, some Russian imitation, not a machine from abroad': 39, 'What sort\nof views can anyone have on such a subject': 11, '"\n\n"Turkish views, in general," Veslovsky said, turning to Anna with a\nsmile': 13, '"I can\'t defend his opinions," Darya Alexandrovna said, firing up; "but\nI can say that he\'s a highly cultivated man, and if he were here he\nwould know very well how to answer you, though I am not capable of\ndoing so': 42, '"\n\n"I like him extremely, and we are great friends," Sviazhsky said,\nsmiling good-naturedly': 14, '"_Mais pardon, il est un petit peu toqué;_ he\nmaintains, for instance, that district councils and arbitration boards\nare all of no use, and he is unwilling to take part in anything': 32, '"\n\n"It\'s our Russian apathy," said Vronsky, pouring water from an iced\ndecanter into a delicate glass on a high stem; "we\'ve no sense of the\nduties our privileges impose upon us, and so we refuse to recognize\nthese duties': 40, '"\n\n"I know no man more strict in the performance of his duties," said\nDarya Alexandrovna, irritated by Vronsky\'s tone of superiority': 22, '"For my part," pursued Vronsky, who was evidently for some reason or\nother keenly affected by this conversation, "such as I am, I am, on the\ncontrary, extremely grateful for the honor they have done me, thanks to\nNikolay Ivanitch" (he indicated Sviazhsky), "in electing me a justice\nof the peace': 51, "I consider that for me the duty of being present at the\nsession, of judging some peasants' quarrel about a horse, is as\nimportant as anything I can do": 29, 'And I shall regard it as an honor if\nthey elect me for the district council': 16, "It's only in that way I can pay\nfor the advantages I enjoy as a landowner": 16, "Unluckily they don't\nunderstand the weight that the big landowners ought to have in the\nstate": 16, '"\n\nIt was strange to Darya Alexandrovna to hear how serenely confident he\nwas of being right at his own table': 21, 'She thought how Levin, who\nbelieved the opposite, was just as positive in his opinions at his own\ntable': 19, 'But she loved Levin, and so she was on his side': 11, '"So we can reckon upon you, count, for the coming elections': 11, '" said\nSviazhsky': 3, '"But you must come a little beforehand, so as to be on the\nspot by the eighth': 17, 'If you would do me the honor to stop with duties in these latter days': 15, "Just as in\nold days there were so many government functionaries that one had to\ncall in a functionary for every single thing, so now everyone's doing\nsome sort of public duty": 32, "Alexey has been here now six months, and he's\na member, I do believe, of five or six different public bodies": 21, '_Du\ntrain que cela va,_ the whole time will be wasted on it': Alexandrovna had seen at formal dinners\nand balls which of late years had become quite unfamiliar to her; it\nall had the same impersonal and constrained character, and so on an\nordinary day and in a little circle of friends it made a disagreeable\nimpression on her': 67, 'After dinner they sat on the terrace, then they proceeded to play lawn\ntennis': 14, 'The players, divided into two parties, stood on opposite sides\nof a tightly drawn net with gilt poles on the carefully leveled and\nrolled croquet-ground': 25, 'Darya Alexandrovna made an attempt to play, but\nit was a long time before she could understand the game, and by the\ntime she did understand it, she was so tired that she sat down with\nPrincess Varvara and simply looked on at the players': 45, 'Her partner,\nTushkevitch, gave up playing too, but the others kept the game up for a\nlong time': 18, 'Sviazhsky and Vronsky both played very well and seriously': 9, "They kept a sharp lookout on the balls served to them, and without\nhaste or getting in each other's way, they ran adroitly up to them,\nwaited for the rebound, and neatly and accurately returned them over\nthe net": 39, 'Veslovsky played worse than the others': 6, 'He was too eager, but\nhe kept the players lively with his high spirits': 14, 'His laughter and\noutcries never paused': 6, "Like the other men of the party, with the\nladies' permission, 44, 'When Darya Alexandrovna lay in bed that night, as soon as she closed\nher eyes, she saw Vassenka Veslovsky flying about the croquet ground': 24, 'During the game Darya Alexandrovna was not enjoying herself': 9, "She did\nnot like the light tone of raillery that was kept up all the time\nbetween Vassenka Veslovsky and Anna, and the unnaturalness altogether\nof grown-up people, all alone without children, playing at a child's\ngame": 37, 'But to avoid breaking up the party and to get through the time\nsomehow, after a rest she joined the game again, and pretended to be\nenjoying it': 28, 'All that day it seemed to her as though she were acting in\na theater with actors cleverer than she, and that her bad acting was\nspoiling the whole performance': 30, 'She had come with the intention of\nstaying two days, if all went well': 14, 'But in the evening, during the\ngame, she made up her mind that she would go home next day': 19, 'The\nmaternal cares and worries, which she had so hated on the way, now,\nafter a day spent without them, struck her in quite another light, and\ntempted her back to them': 32, 'When, after evening tea and a row by night in the boat, ('TOL CHAPTER 25 PART SIX', {'Vronsky and Anna spent the whole summer and part of the winter in the\ncountry, living in just the same condition, and still taking no steps\nto obtain a divorce': 30, 'It was an understood thing between them that they\nshould not go away anywhere; but both felt, the longer they lived\nalone, especially in the autumn, without guests in the house, that they\ncould not stand this existence, and that they would have to alter it': 46, 'Their life was apparently such that nothing better could be desired': 11, 'They had the fullest abundance of everything; they had a child, and\nboth had occupation': 15, 'Anna devoted just as much care to her appearance\nwhen they had no visitors, and she did a great deal of reading, both of\nnovels and of what serious literature was in fashion': 33, 'She ordered all\nthe books that were praised in the foreign papers and reviews she\nreceived, and read them with that concentrated attention which is only\ngiven to what is read in seclusion': 33, 'Moreover, every subject that was of\ninterest to Vronsky, she studied in books and special journals, so that\nhe often went straight to her with questions relating to agriculture or\narchitecture, sometimes even with questions relating to horse-breeding\nor sport': 40, 'He was amazed at her knowledge, her memory, and at first was\ndisposed to doubt it, to ask for confirmation of her facts; and she\nwould find what he asked for in some book, and show it to him': 39, 'The building of the hospital, too, interested her': 8, 'She did not merely\nassist, but planned and suggested a great deal herself': 13, 'But her chief\nthought was still of herself—how far she was dear to Vronsky, how far\nshe could make up to him for all he had given up': 28, 'Vronsky appreciated\nthis desire not only to please, but to serve him, which had become the\nsole aim of her existence, but at the same time he wearied of the\nloving snares in which she tried to hold him fast': 40, 'As time went on, and\nhe saw himself more and more often held fast in these snares, he had an\never growing desire, not so much to escape from them, as to try whether\nthey hindered his freedom': 38, 'Had it not been for this growing desire to\nbe free, not to have scenes every time he wanted to go to the town to a\nmeeting or a race, Vronsky would have been perfectly satisfied with his\nlife': 39, 'The rôle he had taken up, the rôle of a wealthy landowner, one of\nthat class which ought to be the very heart of the Russian aristocracy,\nwas entirely to his taste; and now, after spending six months in that\ncharacter, he derived even greater satisfaction from it': 48, 'And his\nmanagement of his estate, which occupied and absorbed him more and\nmore, was most successful': 17, 'In spite of the immense sums cost him by the\nhospital, by machinery, by cows ordered from Switzerland, and many\nother things, he was convinced that he was not wasting, but increasing\nhis substance': 34, 'In all matters affecting income, the sales of timber,\nwheat, and wool, the letting of lands, Vronsky was hard as a rock, and\nknew well how to keep up prices': 30, 'In all operations on a large scale on\nthis and his other estates, he kept to the simplest methods involving\nno risk, and in trifling details he was careful and exacting to an\nextreme degree': 35, 'In spite of all the cunning and ingenuity of the German\nsteward, who would try to tempt him into purchases by making his\noriginal estimate always far larger than really required, and then\nrepresenting to Vronsky that he might get the thing cheaper, and so\nmake a profit, Vronsky did not give in': 53, 'He listened to his steward,\ncross-examined him, and only agreed to his suggestions when the\nimplement to be ordered or constructed was the very newest, not yet\nknown in Russia, and likely to excite wonder': 35, 'Apart from such\nexceptions, he resolved upon an increased outlay only where there was a\nsurplus, and in making such an outlay he went into the minutest\ndetails, and insisted on getting the very best for his money; so that\nby the method on which he managed his affairs, it was clear that he was\nnot wasting, but increasing his substance': 61, "In October there were the provincial elections in the Kashinsky\nprovince, where were the estates of Vronsky, Sviazhsky, Koznishev,\nOblonsky, and a small part of Levin's land": 27, 'These elections were attracting public attention from several\ncircumstances connected with them, and also from the people taking part\nin them': 21, 'There had been a great deal of talk about them, and great\npreparations were being made for them': 18, 'Persons who never attended the\nelections were coming from Moscow, from Petersburg, and from abroad to\nattend these': 18, 'Vronsky had long before promised Sviazhsky to go to them': 10, 'Before the elections Sviazhsky, who often visited Vozdvizhenskoe, drove\nover to fetch Vronsky': 13, 'On the day before there had been almost a\nquarrel between Vronsky and Anna over this proposed expedition': 18, 'It was\nthe very dullest autumn weather, which is so dreary in the country, and\nso, preparing himself for a struggle, Vronsky, with a hard and cold\nexpression, informed Anna of his departure as he had never spoken to\nher before': 41, 'But, to his surprise, Anna accepted the information with\ngreat composure, and merely asked when he would be back': 19, 'He looked\nintently at her, at a loss to explain this composure': 12, 'She smiled at his\nlook': 5, 'He knew that way she had of withdrawing into herself, and knew\nthat it only happened when she had determined upon something without\nletting him know her plans': 28, 'He was afraid of this; but he was so\nanxious to avoid a scene that he kept up appearances, and half\nsincerely believed in what he longed to believe in—her reasonableness': 31, '"I hope you won\'t be dull': 6, '"\n\n"I hope not," said Anna': 6, '"I got a box of books yesterday from\nGautier\'s': 9, "No, I shan't be dull": 5, '"\n\n"She\'s trying to take that tone, and so much the better," he thought,\n"or else it would be the same thing over and over again': 26, '"\n\nAnd he set off for the elections without appealing to her for a candid\nexplanation': 16, 'It was the first time since the beginning of their\nintimacy that he had parted from her without a full explanation': 21, 'From\none point of view this troubled him, but on the other side he felt that\nit was better so': 20, '"At first there will be, as this time, something\nundefined kept back, and then she will get used to it': 20, 'In any case I\ncan give up anything for her, but not my masculine independence," he\nthought': 17, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 26 PART SIX', {"In September Levin moved to Moscow for Kitty's confinement": 9, 'He had\nspent a whole month in Moscow with nothing to do, when Sergey\nIvanovitch, who had property in the Kashinsky province, and took great\ninterest in the question of the approaching elections, made ready to\nset off to the elections': 41, 'He invited his brother, who had a vote in the\nSeleznevsky district, to come with him': 16, 'Levin had, moreover, to\ntransact in Kashin some extremely important business relating to the\nwardship of land and to the receiving of certain redemption money for\nhis sister, who was abroad': 31, "Levin still hesitated, but Kitty, who saw that he was bored in Moscow,\nand urged him to go, on her own authority ordered him the proper\nnobleman's uniform, costing seven pounds": 31, 'And that seven pounds paid\nfor the uniform was the chief cause that finally decided Levin to go': 18, 'He went to Kashin': 4, "Levin had been six days in Kashin, visiting the assembly each day, and\nbusily engaged about his sister's business, which still dragged on": 23, 'The\ndistrict marshals of nobility were all occupied with the elections, and\nit was impossible to get the simplest thing done that depended upon the\ncourt of wardship': 28, 'The other matter, the payment of the sums due, was\nmet too by difficulties': 14, 'After long negotiations over the legal\ndetails, the money was at last ready to be paid; but the notary, a most\nobliging person, could not hand over the order, because it must have\nthe signature of the president, and the president, though he had not\ngiven over his duties to a deputy, was at the elections': 56, "All these\nworrying negotiations, this endless going from place to place, and\ntalking with pleasant and excellent people, who quite saw the\nunpleasantness of the petitioner's position, but were powerless to\nassist him—all these efforts that yielded no result, led to a feeling\nof misery in Levin akin to the mortifying helplessness one experiences\nin dreams when one tries to use physical force": 63, 'He felt this frequently\nas he talked to his most good-natured solicitor': 12, 'This solicitor did, it\nseemed, everything possible, and strained every nerve to get him out of\nhis difficulties': 18, '"I tell you what you might try," he said more than\nonce; "go to so-and-so and so-and-so," and the solicitor drew up a\nregular plan for getting round the fatal point that hindered\neverything': 34, 'But he would add immediately, "It\'ll mean some delay,\nanyway, but you might try it': 15, '" And Levin did try, and did go': 8, 'Everyone\nwas kind and civil, but the point evaded seemed to crop up again in the\nend, and again to bar the way': 23, 'What was particularly trying, was that\nLevin could not make out with whom he was struggling, to whose interest\nit was that his business should not be done': 28, 'That no one seemed to\nknow; the solicitor certainly did not know': 12, 'If Levin could have\nunderstood why, just as he saw why one can only approach the booking\noffice of a railway station in single file, it would not have been so\nvexatious and tiresome to him': 36, 'But with the hindrances that confronted\nhim in his business, no one could explain why they existed': 17, 'But Levin had changed a good deal since his marriage; he was patient,\nand if he could not see why it was all arranged like this, he told\nhimself that he could not judge without knowing all about it, and that\nmost likely it must be so, and he tried not to fret': 53, 'In attending the elections, too, and taking part in them, he tried now\nnot to judge, not to fall foul of them, but to comprehend as fully as\nhe could the question which was so earnestly and ardently absorbing\nhonest and excellent men whom he respected': 46, 'Since his marriage there\nhad been revealed to Levin so many new and serious aspects of life that\nhad previously, through his frivolous attitude to them, seemed of no\nimportance, that in the question of the elections too he assumed and\ntried to find some serious significance': 47, 'Sergey Ivanovitch explained to him the meaning and object of the\nproposed revolution at the elections': 16, 'The marshal of the province in\nwhose hands the law had placed the control of so many important public\nfunctions—the guardianship of wards (the very department which was\ngiving Levin so much trouble just now), the disposal of large sums\nsubscribed by the nobility of the province, the high schools, female,\nmale, and military, and popular instruction on the new model, and\nfinally, the district council—the marshal of the province, Snetkov, was\na nobleman of the old school,—dissipating an immense fortune, a\ngood-hearted man, honest after his own fashion, but utterly without any\ncomprehension of the needs of modern days': 100, 'He always took, in every\nquestion, the side of the nobility; he was positively antagonistic to\nthe spread of popular education, and he succeeded in giving a purely\nparty character to the district council which ought by rights to be of\nsuch an immense importance': 45, 'What was needed was to put in his place a\nfresh, capable, perfectly modern man, of contemporary ideas, and to\nframe their policy so as from the rights conferred upon the nobles, not\nas the nobility, but as an element of the district council, to extract\nall the powers of self-government that could possibly be derived from\nthem': 58, 'In the wealthy Kashinsky province, which always took the lead of\nother provinces in everything, there was now such a preponderance of\nforces that this policy, once carried through properly there, might\nserve as a model for other provinces for all Russia': 42, 'And hence the\nwhole question was of the greatest importance': 10, 'It was proposed to elect\nas marshal in place of Snetkov either Sviazhsky, or, better still,\nNevyedovsky, a former university professor, a man of remarkable\nintelligence and a great friend of Sergey Ivanovitch': 33, 'The meeting was opened by the governor, who made a speech to the\nnobles, urging them to elect the public functionaries, not from regard\nfor persons, but for the service and welfare of their fatherland, and\nhoping that the honorable nobility of the Kashinsky province would, as\nat all former elections, hold their duty as sacred, and vindicate the\nexalted confidence of the monarch': 64, 'When he had finished with his speech, the governor walked out of the\nhall, and the noblemen noisily and eagerly—some even\nenthusiastically—followed him and thronged round him while he put on\nhis fur coat and conversed amicably with the marshal of the province': 43, 'Levin, anxious to see into everything and not to miss anything, stood\nthere too in the crowd, and heard the governor say: "Please tell Marya\nIvanovna my wife is very sorry she couldn\'t come to the Home': 37, '" And\nthereupon the nobles in high good-humor sorted out their fur coats and\nall drove off to the cathedral': 20, 'In the cathedral Levin, lifting his hand like the rest and repeating\nthe words of the archdeacon, swore with most terrible oaths to do all\nthe governor had hoped they would do': 32, 'Church services always affected\nLevin, and as he uttered the words "I kiss the cross," and glanced\nround at the crowd of young and old men repeating the same, he felt\ntouched': 32, 'On the second and third days there was business relating to the\nfinances of the nobility and the female high school, of no importance\nwhatever, as Sergey Ivanovitch explained, and Levin, busy seeing after\nhis own affairs, did not attend the meetings': 42, "On the fourth day the\nauditing of the marshal's accounts took place at the high table of the\nmarshal of the province": 22, 'And then there occurred the first skirmish\nbetween the new party and the old': 14, 'The committee who had been deputed\nto verify the accounts reported to the meeting that all was in order': 19, 'The marshal of the province got up, thanked the nobility for their\nconfidence, and shed tears': 16, 'The nobles gave him a loud welcome, and\nshook hands with him': 12, "But at that instant a nobleman of Sergey\nIvanovitch's party said that he had heard that the committee had not\nverified the accounts, considering such a verification an insult to the\nmarshal of the province": 35, 'One of the members of the committee\nincautiously admitted this': 10, 'Then a small gentleman, very young-looking\nbut very malignant, began to say that it would probably be agreeable to\nthe marshal of the province to give an account of his expenditures of\nthe public moneys, and that the misplaced delicacy of the members of\nthe committee was depriving him of this moral satisfaction': 53, 'Then the\nmembers of the committee tried to withdraw their admission, and Sergey\nIvanovitch began to prove that they must logically admit either that\nthey had verified the accounts or that they had not, and he developed\nthis dilemma in detail': 41, 'Sergey Ivanovitch was answered by the spokesman\nof the opposite party': 11, 'Then Sviazhsky spoke, and then the malignant\ngentleman again': 9, 'The discussion lasted a long time and ended in\nnothing': 10, 'Levin was surprised that they should dispute upon this subject\nso long, especially as, when he asked Sergey Ivanovitch whether he\nsupposed that money had been misappropriated, Sergey Ivanovitch\nanswered:\n\n"Oh, no': 32, "He's an honest man": 4, 'But those old-fashioned methods of\npaternal family arrangements in the management of provincial affairs\nmust be broken down': 18, '"\n\nOn the fifth day came the elections of the district marshals': 12, 'It was\nrather a stormy day in several districts': 9, 'In the Seleznevsky district\nSviazhsky was elected unanimously without a ballot, and he gave a\ndinner that evening': 18, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 27 PART SIX', {'The sixth day was fixed for the election of the marshal of the\nprovince': 14, 'The rooms, large and small, were full of noblemen in all sorts of\nuniforms': 14, 'Many had come only for that day': 7, 'Men who had not seen each\nother for years, some from the Crimea, some from Petersburg, some from\nabroad, met in the rooms of the Hall of Nobility': 28, "There was much\ndiscussion around the governor's table under the portrait of the Tsar": 14, 'The nobles, both in the larger and the smaller rooms, grouped\nthemselves in camps, and from their hostile and suspicious glances,\nfrom the silence that fell upon them when outsiders approached a group,\nand from the way that some, whispering together, retreated to the\nfarther corridor, it was evident that each side had secrets from the\nother': 57, 'In appearance the noblemen were sharply divided into two\nclasses: the old and the new': 15, 'The old were for the most part either in\nold uniforms of the nobility, buttoned up closely, with spurs and hats,\nor in their own special naval, cavalry, infantry, or official uniforms': 32, 'The uniforms of the older men were embroidered in the old-fashioned way\nwith epaulets on their shoulders; they were unmistakably tight and\nshort in the waist, as though their wearers had grown out of them': 35, 'The\nyounger men wore the uniform of the nobility with long waists and broad\nshoulders, unbuttoned over white waistcoats, or uniforms with black\ncollars and with the embroidered badges of justices of the peace': 34, 'To\nthe younger men belonged the court uniforms that here and there\nbrightened up the crowd': 16, 'But the division into young and old did not correspond with the\ndivision of parties': 15, 'Some of the young men, as Levin observed, belonged\nto the old party; and some of the very oldest noblemen, on the\ncontrary, were whispering with Sviazhsky, and were evidently ardent\npartisans of the new party': 36, 'Levin stood in the smaller room, where they were smoking and taking\nlight refreshments, close to his own friends, and listening to what\nthey were saying, he conscientiously exerted all his intelligence\ntrying to understand what was said': 38, 'Sergey Ivanovitch was the center\nround which the others grouped themselves': 11, 'He was listening at that\nmoment to Sviazhsky and Hliustov, the marshal of another district, who\nbelonged to their party': 20, 'Hliustov would not agree to go with his\ndistrict to ask Snetkov to stand, while Sviazhsky was persuading him to\ndo so, and Sergey Ivanovitch was approving of the plan': 30, 'Levin could not\nmake out why the opposition was to ask the marshal to stand whom they\nwanted to supersede': 20, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had just been drinking and taking some lunch,\ncame up to them in his uniform of a gentleman of the bedchamber, wiping\nhis lips with a perfumed handkerchief of bordered batiste': 34, '"We are placing our forces," he said, pulling out his whiskers, "Sergey\nIvanovitch': 13, '"\n\nAnd listening to the conversation, he supported Sviazhsky\'s contention': 10, '"One district\'s enough, and Sviazhsky\'s obviously of the opposition,"\nhe said, words evidently intelligible to all except Levin': 18, '"Why, Kostya, you here too': 5, "I suppose you're converted, eh": 5, '" he added,\nturning to Levin and drawing his arm through his': 12, 'Levin would have been\nglad indeed to be converted, but could not make out what the point was,\nand retreating a few steps from the speakers, he explained to Stepan\nArkadyevitch his inability to understand why the marshal of the\nprovince should be asked to stand': 46, '_"O sancta simplicitas': 3, '"_ said Stepan Arkadyevitch, and briefly and\nclearly he explained it to Levin': 13, 'If, as at previous elections, all the\ndistricts asked the marshal of the province to stand, then he would be\nelected without a ballot': 24, 'That must not be': 4, 'Now eight districts had\nagreed to call upon him: if two refused to do so, Snetkov might decline\nto stand at all; and then the old party might choose another of their\nparty, which would throw them completely out in their reckoning': 42, "But if\nonly one district, Sviazhsky's, did not call upon him to stand, Snetkov\nwould let himself be balloted for": 20, 'They were even, some of them, going\nto vote for him, and purposely to let him get a good many votes, so\nthat the enemy might be thrown off the scent, and when a candidate of\nthe other side was put up, they too might give him some votes': 49, 'Levin\nunderstood to some extent, but not fully, and would have put a few more\nquestions, when suddenly everyone began talking and making a noise and\nthey moved towards the big room': 32, '"What is it': 3, 'eh': 1, 'whom': 1, '" "No guarantee': 3, 'whose': 1, 'what': 1, '" "They won\'t pass\nhim': 5, '" "They won\'t let Flerov in': 6, '" "Eh, because of the\ncharge against him': 8, '" "Why, at this rate, they won\'t admit anyone': 9, "It's\na swindle": 3, '" "The law': 3, '" Levin heard exclamations on all sides, and he\nmoved into the big room together with the others, all hurrying\nsomewhere and afraid of missing something': 26, 'Squeezed by the crowding\nnoblemen, he drew near the high table where the marshal of the\nprovince, Sviazhsky, and the other leaders were hotly disputing about\nsomething': 27, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 28 PART SIX', {'Levin was standing rather far off': 6, 'A nobleman breathing heavily and\nhoarsely at his side, and another whose thick boots were creaking,\nprevented him from hearing distinctly': 21, 'He could only hear the soft\nvoice of the marshal faintly, then the shrill voice of the malignant\ngentleman, and then the voice of Sviazhsky': 25, 'They were disputing, as far\nas he could make out, as to the interpretation to be put on the act and\nthe exact meaning of the words: "liable to be called up for trial': 34, '"\n\nThe crowd parted to make way for Sergey Ivanovitch approaching the\ntable': 13, 'Sergey Ivanovitch, waiting till the malignant gentleman had\nfinished speaking, said that he thought the best solution would be to\nrefer to the act itself, and asked the secretary to find the act': 33, 'The\nact said that in case of difference of opinion, there must be a ballot': 15, 'Sergey Ivanovitch read the act and began to explain its meaning, but at\nthat point a tall, stout, round-shouldered landowner, with dyed\nwhiskers, in a tight uniform that cut the back of his neck, interrupted\nhim': 36, 'He went up to the table, and striking it with his finger ring, he\nshouted loudly: "A ballot': 18, 'Put it to the vote': 5, 'No need for more\ntalking': 5, '" Then several voices began to talk all at once, and the tall\nnobleman with the ring, getting more and more exasperated, shouted more\nand more loudly': 27, 'But it was impossible to make out what he said': 10, 'He was shouting for the very course Sergey Ivanovitch had proposed; but\nit was evident that he hated him and all his party, and this feeling of\nhatred spread through the whole party and roused in opposition to it\nthe same vindictiveness, though in a more seemly form, on the other\nside': 52, 'Shouts were raised, and for a moment all was confusion, so that\nthe marshal of the province had to call for order': 22, '"A ballot': 2, 'A ballot': 2, 'Every nobleman sees it': 4, 'We shed our blood for our\ncountry': 7, 'The confidence of the monarch': 5, "No checking the accounts\nof the marshal; he's not a cashier": 11, "But that's not the point": 5, 'Votes, please': 2, 'Beastly': 1, '" shouted furious and violent voices on all\nsides': 9, 'Looks and faces were even more violent and furious than their\nwords': 12, 'They expressed the most implacable hatred': 6, 'Levin did not in the\nleast understand what was the matter, and he marveled at the passion\nwith which it was disputed whether or not the decision about Flerov\nshould be put to the vote': 35, "He forgot, as Sergey Ivanovitch explained to\nhim afterwards, this syllogism: that it was necessary for the public\ngood to get rid of the marshal of the province; that to get rid of the\nmarshal it was necessary to have a majority of votes; that to get a\nmajority of votes it was necessary to secure Flerov's right to vote;\nthat to secure the recognition of Flerov's right to vote they must\ndecide on the interpretation to be put on the act": 82, '"And one vote may decide the whole question, and one must be serious\nand consecutive, if one wants to be of use in public life," concluded\nSergey Ivanovitch': 28, 'But Levin forgot all that, and it was painful to him\nto see all these excellent persons, for whom he had a respect, in such\nan unpleasant and vicious state of excitement': 32, 'To escape from this\npainful feeling he went away into the other room where there was nobody\nexcept the waiters at the refreshment bar': 24, 'Seeing the waiters busy over\nwashing up the crockery and setting in order their plates and\nwine-glasses, seeing their calm and cheerful faces, Levin felt an\nunexpected sense of relief as though he had come out of a stuffy room\ninto the fresh air': 44, 'He began walking up and down, looking with pleasure\nat the waiters': 12, 'He particularly liked the way one gray-whiskered\nwaiter, who showed his scorn for the other younger ones and was jeered\nat by them, was teaching them how to fold up napkins properly': 32, 'Levin\nwas just about to enter into conversation with the old waiter, when the\nsecretary of the court of wardship, a little old man whose specialty it\nwas to know all the noblemen of the province by name and patronymic,\ndrew him away': 43, '"Please come, Konstantin Dmitrievitch," he said, "your brother\'s\nlooking for you': 11, 'They are voting on the legal point': 7, '"\n\nLevin walked into the room, received a white ball, and followed his\nbrother, Sergey Ivanovitch, to the table where Sviazhsky was standing\nwith a significant and ironical face, holding his beard in his fist and\nsniffing at it': 39, 'Sergey Ivanovitch put his hand into the box, put the\nball somewhere, and making room for Levin, stopped': 18, 'Levin advanced, but\nutterly forgetting what he was to do, and much embarrassed, he turned\nto Sergey Ivanovitch with the question, "Where am I to put it': 27, '" He\nasked this softly, at a moment when there was talking going on near, so\nthat he had hoped his question would not be overheard': 26, 'But the persons\nspeaking paused, and his improper question was overheard': 11, 'Sergey\nIvanovitch frowned': 3, '"That is a matter for each man\'s own decision," he said severely': 12, 'Several people smiled': 3, 'Levin crimsoned, hurriedly thrust his hand under\nthe cloth, and put the ball to the right as it was in his right hand': 23, 'Having put it in, he recollected that he ought to have thrust his left\nhand too, and so he thrust it in though too late, and, still more\novercome with confusion, he beat a hasty retreat into the background': 39, '"A hundred and twenty-six for admission': 6, 'Ninety-eight against': 2, '" sang\nout the voice of the secretary, who could not pronounce the letter _r_': 15, 'Then there was a laugh; a button and two nuts were found in the box': 15, 'The nobleman was allowed the right to vote, and the new party had\nconquered': 14, 'But the old party did not consider themselves conquered': 9, 'Levin heard\nthat they were asking Snetkov to stand, and he saw that a crowd of\nnoblemen was surrounding the marshal, who was saying something': 25, 'Levin\nwent nearer': 3, 'In reply Snetkov spoke of the trust the noblemen of the\nprovince had placed in him, the affection they had shown him, which he\ndid not deserve, as his only merit had been his attachment to the\nnobility, to whom he had devoted twelve years of service': 47, 'Several times\nhe repeated the words: "I have served to the best of my powers with\ntruth and good faith, I value your goodness and thank you," and\nsuddenly he stopped short from the tears that choked him, and went out\nof the room': 44, 'Whether these tears came from a sense of the injustice\nbeing done him, from his love for the nobility, or from the strain of\nthe position he was placed in, feeling himself surrounded by enemies,\nhis emotion infected the assembly, the majority were touched, and Levin\nfelt a tenderness for Snetkov': 51, 'In the doorway the marshal of the province jostled against Levin': 11, '"Beg pardon, excuse me, please," he said as to a stranger, but\nrecognizing Levin, he smiled timidly': 17, 'It seemed to Levin that he would\nhave liked to say something, but could not speak for emotion': 18, 'His face\nand his whole figure in his uniform with the crosses, and white\ntrousers striped with braid, as he moved hurriedly along, reminded\nLevin of some hunted beast who sees that he is in evil case': 37, "This\nexpression in the marshal's face was particularly touching to Levin,\nbecause, only the day before, he had been at his house about his\ntrustee business and had seen him in all his grandeur, a kind-hearted,\nfatherly man": 38, "The big house with the old family furniture; the rather\ndirty, far from stylish, but respectful footmen, unmistakably old house\nserfs who had stuck to their master; the stout, good-natured wife in a\ncap with lace and a Turkish shawl, petting her pretty grandchild, her\ndaughter's daughter; the young son, a sixth form high school boy,\ncoming home from school, and greeting his father, kissing his big hand;\nthe genuine, cordial words and gestures of the old man—all this had the\nday before roused an instinctive feeling of respect and sympathy in\nLevin": 93, 'This old man was a touching and pathetic figure to Levin now,\nand he longed to say something pleasant to him': 21, '"So you\'re sure to be our marshal again," he said': 10, '"It\'s not likely," said the marshal, looking round with a scared\nexpression': 12, '"I\'m worn out, I\'m old': 5, 'If there are men younger and more\ndeserving than I, let them serve': 13, '"\n\nAnd the marshal disappeared through a side door': 9, 'The most solemn moment was at hand': 7, 'They were to proceed immediately to\nthe election': 8, 'The leaders of both parties were reckoning white and\nblack on their fingers': 13, "The discussion upon Flerov had given the new party not only Flerov's\nvote, but had also gained time for them, so that they could send to\nfetch three noblemen who had been rendered unable to take part in the\nelections by the wiles of the other party": 47, 'Two noble gentlemen, who had\na weakness for strong drink, had been made drunk by the partisans of\nSnetkov, and a third had been robbed of his uniform': 28, 'On learning this, the new party had made haste, during the dispute\nabout Flerov, to send some of their men in a sledge to clothe the\nstripped gentleman, and to bring along one of the intoxicated to the\nmeeting': 39, '"I\'ve brought one, drenched him with water," said the landowner, who\nhad gone on this errand, to Sviazhsky': 18, '"He\'s all right': 3, "he'll do": 2, '"\n\n"Not too drunk, he won\'t fall down': 8, '" said Sviazhsky, shaking his head': 6, '"No, he\'s first-rate': 3, "If only they don't give him any more here": 9, "I've told the waiter not to give him anything on any account": 12, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 29 PART SIX', {'The narrow room, in which they were smoking and taking refreshments,\nwas full of noblemen': 15, 'The excitement grew more intense, and every face\nbetrayed some uneasiness': 11, 'The excitement was specially keen for the\nleaders of each party, who knew every detail, and had reckoned up every\nvote': 21, 'They were the generals organizing the approaching battle': 8, 'The\nrest, like the rank and file before an engagement, though they were\ngetting ready for the fight, sought for other distractions in the\ninterval': 25, 'Some were lunching, standing at the bar, or sitting at the\ntable; others were walking up and down the long room, smoking\ncigarettes, and talking with friends whom they had not seen for a long\nwhile': 36, "Levin did not care to eat, and he was not smoking; he did not want to\njoin his own friends, that is Sergey Ivanovitch, Stepan Arkadyevitch,\nSviazhsky and the rest, because Vronsky in his equerry's uniform was\nstanding down, scanning the\ngroups, and listening to what was being said around him': 20, 'He felt\ndepressed, especially because everyone else was, as he saw, eager,\nanxious, and interested, and he alone, with an old, toothless little\nman with mumbling lips wearing a naval uniform, sitting beside him, had\nno interest in it and nothing to do': 43, '"He\'s such a blackguard': 4, 'I have told him so, forward": 19, 'These\ngentlemen, now, what do they come for': 8, '" he said, pointing to the\nmalignant gentleman, who was talking at the high table': 15, '"That\'s the new generation of nobility': 6, '"\n\n"New it may be, but nobility it isn\'t': 9, "They're proprietors of a sort,\nbut we're the landowners": 9, "As noblemen, they're cutting their own\nthroats": 7, '"\n\n"But you say it\'s an institution that\'s served its time': 11, '"\n\n"That it may be, but still it ought to be treated a little more\nrespectfully': 16, 'Snetkov, now': 2, "We may be of use, or we may not, but\nwe're the growth of a thousand years": 17, "If we're laying out a garden,\nplanning one before the house, you know, and there you've a tree that's\nstood for centuries in the very spot": 26, "Old and gnarled it may be, and\nyet you don't cut down the old fellow to make room for the flowerbeds,\nbut lay out your beds so as to take advantage of the tree": 34, 'You won\'t\ngrow him again in a year," he said cautiously, and he immediately\nchanged the conversation': 17, '"Well, and how is your land doing': 7, '"\n\n"Oh, not very well': 5, 'I make five per cent': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, but you don\'t reckon your own work': 9, "Aren't you worth something\ntoo": 5, "I'll tell you my own case": 6, 'Before I took to seeing after the land,\nI had a salary of three hundred pounds from the service': 19, 'Now I do more\nwork than I did in the service, and like you I get five per cent': 19, 'on\nthe land, and thank God for that': 8, "But one's work is thrown in for\nnothing": 8, '"\n\n"Then why do you do it, if it\'s a clear loss': 12, '"\n\n"Oh, well, one does it': 6, 'What would you have': 4, "It's habit, and one knows\nit's how it should be": 10, 'And what\'s more," the landowner went on, leaning\nhis said the landowner': 4, '"Yes," Levin answered, with proud satisfaction': 6, '"Yes, it\'s rather\nstrange," he went on': 7, '"So we live without making anything, as though we\nwere ancient vestals set send a lawyer, who costs me fifteen': 17, '"\n\nAnd he related how a peasant had stolen some flour from the miller, and\nwhen the miller told him of it, had lodged a complaint for slander': 28, 'All\nthis was utterly uncalled for and stupid, and Levin felt it himself as\nhe said it': 17, '"Oh, this is such an original fellow': 7, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch with\nhis most soothing, was\nsilence in the room': 6, 'The secretary announced in a loud voice that the\ncaptain of the guards, Mihail Stepanovitch Snetkov, would now be\nballoted for as marshal of the province': 26, 'The be mistaken in saying\n"the right side': 27, '" Surely Snetkov was the enemy': 6, 'As he went up, he held\nthe ball in his right hand, but thinking he was wrong, just at the box\nhe changed to the left hand, and undoubtedly put the ball to the left': 35, 'An adept in the business, standing at the box and seeing by the mere\naction of the elbow where each put his ball, scowled with annoyance': 26, 'It\nwas no good for him to use his insight': 10, 'Everything was still, and the counting of the balls was heard': 11, 'Then a\nsingle voice rose and proclaimed the numbers for and against': 12, 'The\nmarshal had been voted for by a considerable majority': 10, 'All was noise\nand eager movement towards the doors': 9, 'Snetkov came in, and the nobles\nthronged round him, congratulating him': little room where the\nrefreshments were, and again had a great sense of comfort when he saw\nthe waiters': 40, 'The little old waiter pressed him to have something, and\nLevin agreed': 12, 'After 14, '"\n\nFinding a free place, Levin leaned over the balustrade and began\nlooking and listening': 15, 'All the noblemen were sitting railed off behind barriers according to\ntheir districts': 13, 'In the middle of the room stood a man in a uniform,\nwho shouted in a loud, high voice:\n\n"As a candidate for the marshalship of the nobility of the province we\ncall upon staff-captain Yevgeney so\nstoutly denied all idea of standing': 19, 'Levin went up to the door of the\nroom; it was locked': 12, 'The secretary knocked, the door opened, and Levin\nwas met by two red-faced gentlemen, who darted out': 17, '"I can\'t stand any more of it," said one red-faced gentleman': 11, 'After them the face of the marshal of the province was poked out': 13, 'His\nface was dreadful-looking from exhaustion and dismay': 8, '"I told you not to let anyone out': 8, '" he cried to the doorkeeper': 6, '"I let someone in, your excellency': 6, '"\n\n"Mercy on us': 4, '" and with a heavy sigh the marshal of the province walked\nwith downcast head to the high table in the middle of the room, his\nlegs staggering in his white trousers': 32, 'Nevyedovsky had scored a higher majority, as they had planned, and he\nwas the new marshal of the province': 19, 'Many people were amused, many were\npleased and happy, many were in ecstasies, many were disgusted and\nunhappy': 18, 'The former marshal of the province was in a state of despair,\nwhich he could not conceal': 17, 'When Nevyedovsky went out of the room, the\ncrowd thronged round him and followed him enthusiastically, just as\nthey had ('TOL CHAPTER 31 PART SIX', {'The newly elected marshal and many of the successful party dined that\nday with Vronsky': 15, 'Vronsky had come to the elections partly because he was bored in the\ncountry and wanted to show Anna his right to independence, and also to\nrepay Sviazhsky by his support at the election for all the trouble he\nhad taken for Vronsky at the district council election, but chiefly in\norder strictly to perform all those duties of a nobleman and landowner\nwhich he had taken upon himself': 69, 'But he had not in the least expected\nthat the election would so interest him, so keenly excite him, and that\nhe would be so good at this kind of thing': 31, 'He was quite a new man in\nthe circle of the nobility of the province, but his success was\nunmistakable, and he was not wrong in supposing that he had already\nobtained a certain influence': 35, "This influence was due to his wealth and\nreputation, the capital house in the town lent him by his old friend\nShirkov, who had a post in the department of finances and was director\nof a flourishing bank in Kashin; the excellent cook Vronsky had brought\nfrom the country, and his friendship with the governor, who was a\nschoolfellow of Vronsky's—a schoolfellow he had patronized and\nprotected indeed": 68, 'But what contributed more than all to his success was\nhis direct, equable manner with everyone, which very quickly made the\nmajority of the noblemen reverse the current opinion of his supposed\nhaughtiness': 33, 'He was himself conscious that, except that whimsical\ngentleman married to Kitty Shtcherbatskaya, who had _à propos de\nbottes_ poured out a stream of irrelevant absurdities with such\nspiteful fury, every nobleman with whom he had made acquaintance had\nbecome his adherent': 42, 'He saw clearly, and other people recognized it,\ntoo, that he had done a great deal to secure the success of\nNevyedovsky': 22, "And now at his own table, celebrating Nevyedovsky's\nelection, he was experiencing an agreeable sense of triumph over the\nsuccess of his candidate": 23, 'The election itself had so fascinated him\nthat, if he could succeed in getting married during the next three\nyears, he began to think of standing himself—much as after winning a\nrace ridden by a jockey, he had longed to ride a race himself': 44, 'Today he was celebrating the success of his jockey': 9, 'Vronsky sat at the\nhead of the table, on his right hand sat the young governor, a general\nof high rank': 21, "To all the rest he was the chief man in the province, who\nhad solemnly opened the elections with his speech, and aroused a\nfeeling of respect and even of awe in many people, as Vronsky saw; to\nVronsky he was little Katka Maslov—that had been his nickname in the\nPages' Corps—whom he felt to be shy and tried to _mettre à son aise_": 64, 'On the left hand sat Nevyedovsky with his youthful, stubborn, and\nmalignant face': 13, 'With him Vronsky was simple and deferential': 7, 'Sviazhsky took his failure very light-heartedly': 6, 'It was indeed no\nfailure in his eyes, as he said himself, turning, glass in hand, to\nNevyedovsky; they could not have found a better representative of the\nnew movement, which the nobility ought to follow': 36, "And so every honest\nperson, as he said, was on the side of today's success and was\nrejoicing over it": 20, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch was glad, too, that he was having a good time, and\nthat everyone was pleased': 17, 'The episode of the elections served as a\ngood occasion for a capital dinner': 14, 'Sviazhsky comically imitated the\ntearful discourse of the marshal, and observed, addressing Nevyedovsky,\nthat his excellency would have to select another more complicated\nmethod of auditing the accounts than tears': 30, "Another nobleman jocosely\ndescribed how footmen in stockings had been ordered for the marshal's\nball, and how now they would have to be sent back unless the new\nmarshal would give a ball with footmen in stockings": 37, 'Continually during dinner they said of Nevyedovsky: "our marshal," and\n"your excellency': 12, '"\n\nThis was said with the same pleasure with which a bride is called\n"Madame" and her husband\'s name': 19, 'Nevyedovsky affected to be not merely\nindifferent but scornful of this appellation, but it was obvious that\nhe was highly delighted, and had to keep a curb on himself not to\nbetray the triumph which was unsuitable to their new liberal tone': 42, 'After dinner several telegrams were sent to people interested in the\nresult of the election': 15, 'And Stepan Arkadyevitch, who was in high good\nhumor, sent Darya Alexandrovna a telegram: "Nevyedovsky elected by\ntwenty votes': 19, 'Congratulations': 1, 'Tell people': 2, '" He dictated it aloud,\nsaying: "We must let them share our rejoicing': 13, '" Darya Alexandrovna,\ngetting the message, simply sighed over the rouble wasted on it, and\nunderstood that it was an after-dinner affair': 22, 'She knew Stiva had a\nweakness after dining for _faire jouer le télégraphe': 13, '_\n\n\n\nEverything, together with the excellent dinner and the wine, not from\nRussian merchants, but imported direct from abroad, was extremely\ndignified, simple, and enjoyable': 25, 'The party—some twenty—had been\nselected by Sviazhsky from among the more active new liberals, all of\nthe same way of thinking, who were at the same time clever and well\nbred': 31, 'They drank, also half in jest, to the health of the new marshal\nof the province, of the governor, of the bank director, and of "our\namiable host': 28, '"\n\nVronsky was satisfied': 4, 'He had never expected to find so pleasant a tone\nin the provinces': 13, 'Towards the end of dinner it was still more lively': 10, 'The governor asked\nVronsky to come to a concert for the benefit of the Servians which his\nwife, who was anxious to make his acquaintance, had been getting up': 29, '"There\'ll be a ball, and you\'ll see the belle of the province': 12, 'Worth\nseeing, really': 3, '"\n\n"Not in my line," Vronsky answered': 7, 'He liked that English phrase': 5, 'But\nhe smiled, and promised to come': 7, "Before they rose from the table, when all of them were smoking,\nVronsky's valet went up to him with a letter on a tray": 24, '"From Vozdvizhenskoe by Friday': 17, 'Today was Saturday, and he knew that the\nletter contained reproaches for not being back at the time fixed': 19, 'The\nletter he had sent the previous evening had probably not reached her\nyet': 14, 'The letter was what he had expected, but the form of it was unexpected,\nand particularly disagreeable to him': 19, '"Annie is very ill, the doctor\nsays it may be inflammation': 11, 'I am losing my head all alone': 7, 'Princess\nVarvara is no help, but a hindrance': 8, 'I expected you the day before\nyesterday, and yesterday, and now I am sending to find out where you\nare and what you are doing': 25, 'I wanted to come myself, but thought better\nof it, knowing you would dislike it': 15, 'Send some answer, that I may know\nwhat to do': 10, '"\n\nThe child ill, yet she had thought of coming herself': 11, 'Their daughter\nill, and this hostile tone': 7, 'The innocent festivities over the election, and this gloomy, burdensome\nlove to which he had to return struck Vronsky by their contrast': 22, 'But he\nhad to go, and by the first train that night he set off home': 16, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 32 PART SIX', {"Before Vronsky's departure for the elections, Anna had reflected that\nthe scenes constantly repeated between them each time he left home,\nmight only make him cold to her instead of attaching him to her, and\nresolved to do all she could to control herself so as to bear the\nparting with composure": 52, 'But the cold, severe glance with which he had\nlooked at her when he came to tell her he was going had wounded her,\nand before he had started her peace of mind was destroyed': 35, 'In solitude afterwards, thinking over that glance which had expressed\nhis right to freedom, she came, as she always did, to the same\npoint—the sense of her own humiliation': 29, '"He has the right to go away\nwhen and where he chooses': 12, 'Not simply to go away, but to leave me': 9, 'He\nhas every right, and I have none': 8, 'But knowing that, he ought not to do\nit': 9, 'What has he done, though': 5, 'He looked at me with a cold, severe\nexpression': 9, 'Of course that is something indefinable, impalpable, but it\nhas never been so before, and that glance means a great deal," she\nthought': 23, '"That glance shows the beginning of indifference': 7, '"\n\nAnd though she felt sure that a coldness was beginning, there was\nnothing she could do, she could not in any way alter her relations to\nhim': 28, 'Just as before, only by love and by charm could she keep him': 13, 'And\nso, just as before, only by occupation in the day, by morphine at\nnight, could she stifle the fearful thought of what would be if he\nceased to love her': 31, 'It is true there was still one means; not to keep\nhim—for that she wanted nothing more than his love—but to be nearer to\nhim, to be in such a position that he would not leave her': 37, 'That means\nwas divorce and marriage': 6, 'And she began to long for that, and made up\nher mind to agree to it the first time he or Stiva approached her on\nthe subject': 27, 'Absorbed in such thoughts, she passed five days without him, the five\ndays that he was to be at the elections': 21, 'Walks, conversation with Princess Varvara, visits to the hospital, and,\nmost of all, reading—reading of one book after another—filled up her\ntime': 22, 'But on the sixth day, when the coachman came back without him,\nshe felt that now she was utterly incapable of stifling the thought of\nhim and of what he was doing there, just at that time her little girl\nwas taken ill': 43, 'Anna began to look after her, but even that did not\ndistract her mind, especially as the illness was not serious': 21, 'However\nhard she tried, she could not love this little child, and to feign love\nwas beyond her powers': 19, 'Towards the evening of that day, still alone,\nAnna was in such a panic about him that she decided to start for the\ntown, but on second thoughts wrote him the contradictory letter that\nVronsky received, and without reading it through, sent it off by a\nspecial messenger': 48, 'The next morning she received his letter and\nregretted her own': 11, 'She dreaded a repetition of the severe look he had\nflung at her at parting, especially when he knew that the baby was not\ndangerously ill': 26, 'But still she was glad she had written to him': 10, 'At this\nmoment Anna was positively admitting to herself that she was a burden\nto him, that he would relinquish his freedom regretfully to return to\nher, and in spite of that she was glad he was coming': 38, 'Let him weary of\nher, but he would be here with her, so that she would see him, would\nknow of every action he took': 25, 'She was sitting in the drawing-room near a lamp, with a new volume of\nTaine, and as she read, listening to the sound of the wind outside, and\nevery minute expecting the carriage to arrive': 35, 'Several times she had\nfancied she heard the sound of wheels, but she had been mistaken': 16, "At\nlast she heard not the sound of wheels, but the coachman's shout and\nthe dull rumble in the covered entry": 21, 'Even Princess Varvara, playing\npatience, confirmed this, and Anna, flushing hotly, got up; but instead\nof going down, as she had done twice before, she stood still': 27, 'She\nsuddenly felt ashamed of her duplicity, but even more she dreaded how\nhe might meet her': 17, 'All feeling of wounded pride had passed now; she was\nonly afraid of the expression of his displeasure': 18, 'She remembered that\nher child had been perfectly well again for the last two days': 15, 'She felt\npositively vexed with her for getting better from the very moment her\nletter was sent off': 18, 'Then he said timidly from below, looking up to Anna as\nshe ran down to him': 16, 'He was sitting on a chair, and a footman was pulling off his warm\nover-boot': 15, '"Oh, she is better': 4, '"\n\n"And you': 3, '" he said, shaking himself': 5, 'She took his hand in both of hers, and drew it to her waist, never\ntaking her eyes off him': 20, '"Well, I\'m glad," he said, coldly scanning her, her hair, her dress,\nwhich he knew she had put on for him': 21, 'All was charming, but how many\ntimes it had charmed him': 11, 'And the stern, stony expression that she so\ndreaded settled upon his face': 13, ('TOL CHAPTER 1 PART SEVEN', {'The Levins had been three months in Moscow': 8, 'The date had long passed on\nwhich, according to the most trustworthy calculations of people learned\nin such matters, Kitty should have been confined': 24, 'But she was still\nabout, and there was nothing to show that her time was any nearer than\ntwo months ago': 21, 'The doctor, the monthly nurse, and Dolly and her\nmother, and most of all Levin, who could not think of the approaching\nevent without terror, began to be impatient and uneasy': 31, 'Kitty was the\nonly person who felt perfectly calm and happy': 11, 'She was distinctly conscious now of the birth of a new feeling of love\nfor the future child, for her to some extent actually existing already,\nand she brooded blissfully over this feeling': 33, 'He was not by now\naltogether a part of herself, but sometimes lived his own life\nindependently of her': 19, 'Often this separate being gave her pain, but at\nthe same time she wanted to laugh with a strange new joy': 21, 'All the people she loved were with her, and all were so good to her, so\nattentively caring for her, so entirely pleasant was everything\npresented to her, that if she had not known and felt that it must all\nsoon be over, she could not have wished for a better and pleasanter\nlife': 54, 'The only thing that spoiled the charm of this manner of life was\nthat her husband was not here as she loved him to be, and as he was in\nthe country': 32, 'She liked his serene, friendly, and hospitable manner in the country': 11, 'In the town he seemed continually uneasy and on his guard, as though he\nwere afraid someone would be rude to him, and still more to her': 27, 'At\nhome in the country, knowing himself distinctly to be in his right\nplace, he was never in haste to be off elsewhere': 23, 'He was never\nunoccupied': 4, 'Here in town he was in a continual hurry, as though afraid\nof missing something, and yet he had nothing to do': 22, 'And she felt sorry\nfor him': 6, 'To others, she knew, he did not appear an object of pity': 12, 'On\nthe contrary, when Kitty looked at him in society, as one sometimes\nlooks at those one loves, trying to see him as if he were a stranger,\nso as to catch the impression he must make on others, she saw with a\npanic even of jealous fear that he was far indeed from being a pitiable\nfigure, that he was very attractive with his fine breeding, his rather\nold-fashioned, reserved courtesy with women, his powerful figure, and\nstriking, as she thought, and expressive face': 85, 'But she saw him not from\nwithout, but from within; she saw that here he was not himself; that\nwas the only way she could define his condition to herself': 30, 'Sometimes\nshe inwardly reproached him for his inability to live in the town;\nsometimes she recognized that it was really hard for him to order his\nlife here so that he could be satisfied with it': 36, 'What had he to do, indeed': 6, 'He did not care for cards; he did not go to\na club': 13, "Spending the time with jovial gentlemen of Oblonsky's type—she\nknew now what that meant": 14, 'it meant drinking and going somewhere\nafter drinking': 8, 'She could not think without horror of where men went on\nsuch occasions': 13, 'Was he to go into society': 6, 'But she knew he could only\nfind satisfaction in that if he took pleasure in the society of young\nwomen, and that she could not wish for': 27, 'Should he stay at home with\nher, her mother and her sisters': 12, 'But much as she liked and enjoyed\ntheir conversations forever on the same subjects—"Aline-Nadine," as the\nold prince called the sisters\' talks—she knew it must bore him': 27, 'What\nwas there left for him to do': 8, 'To go on writing at his book he had\nindeed attempted, and at first he used to go to the library and make\nextracts and look up references for his book': 31, 'But, as he told her, the\nmore he did nothing, the less time he had to do anything': 18, 'And besides,\nhe complained that he had talked too much about his book here, and that\nconsequently all his ideas about it were muddled and had lost their\ninterest for him': 31, 'One advantage in this town life was that quarrels hardly ever happened\nbetween them here in town': 17, 'Whether it was that their conditions were\ndifferent, or that they had both become more careful and sensible in\nthat respect, they had no quarrels in Moscow from jealousy, which they\nhad so dreaded when they moved from the country': 40, "One event, an event of great importance to both from that point of\nview, did indeed happen—that was Kitty's meeting with Vronsky": 22, "The old Princess Marya Borissovna, Kitty's godmother, who had always\nbeen very fond of her, had insisted on seeing her": 20, 'Kitty, though she\ndid not go into society at all on account of her condition, went with\nher father to see the venerable old lady, and there met Vronsky': 29, 'The only thing Kitty could reproach herself for at this meeting was\nthat at the instant when she recognized in his civilian dress the\nfeatures once so familiar to her, her breath failed her, the blood\nrushed to her heart, and a vivid blush—she felt it—overspread her face': 48, 'But this lasted only a few seconds': 7, 'Before her father, who purposely\nbegan talking in a loud voice to Vronsky, had finished, she was\nperfectly ready to look at Vronsky, to speak to him, if necessary,\nexactly as she spoke to Princess Marya Borissovna, and more than that,\nto do so in such a way that everything to the faintest intonation and\nsmile would have been approved by her husband, whose unseen presence\nshe seemed to feel about her at that instant': 75, 'She said a few words to him, even smiled serenely at his joke about the\nelections, which he called "our parliament': 21, '" (She had to smile to show\nshe saw the joke': 11, ') But she turned away immediately to Princess Marya\nBorissovna, and did not once glance at him till he got up to go; then\nshe looked at him, but evidently only because it would be uncivil not\nto look at a man when he is saying good-bye': 47, 'She was grateful to her father for saying nothing to her about their\nmeeting Vronsky, but she saw by his special warmth to her after the\nvisit during their usual walk that he was pleased with her': 37, 'She was\npleased with herself': 5, 'She had not expected she would have had the\npower, while keeping somewhere in the bottom of her heart all the\nmemories of her old feeling for Vronsky, not only to seem but to be\nperfectly indifferent and composed with him': 41, "Levin flushed a great deal more than she when she told him she had met\nVronsky at Princess Marya Borissovna's": 20, 'It was very hard for her to\ntell him this, but still harder to go on speaking of the details of the\nmeeting, as he did not question her, but simply gazed at her with a\nfrown': 37, '"I am very sorry you weren\'t there," she said': 9, '"Not that you weren\'t in\nthe room': 7, "I couldn't have been so natural in your presence": 9, 'I am\nblushing now much more, much, much more," she said, blushing till the\ntears came into her eyes': 19, '"But that you couldn\'t see through a crack': 8, '"\n\nThe truthful eyes told Levin that she was satisfied with herself, and\nin spite of her blushing he was quickly reassured and began questioning\nher, which was all she wanted': 31, 'When he had heard everything, even to\nthe detail that for the first second she could not help flushing, but\nthat afterwards she was just as direct and as much at her ease as with\nany chance acquaintance, Levin was quite happy again and said he was\nglad of it, and would not now behave as stupidly as he had done at the\nelection, but would try the first time he met Vronsky to be as friendly\nas possible': 79, '"It\'s so wretched to feel that there\'s a man almost an enemy whom it\'s\npainful to meet," said Levin': 19, '"I\'m very, very glad': 4, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART SEVEN', {'"Go, please, go then and call on the Bols," Kitty said to her husband,\nwhen he came in to see her at eleven o\'clock before going out': 27, '"I know\nyou are dining at
