had been\nwith him before his marriage, and now looked after their household in\ntown': 28, '"Beauty" (that was the left shaft-horse brought up from the country)\n"has been badly shod and is quite lame," he said': 21, '"What does your honor\nwish to be done': 8, '"\n\nDuring the first part of their stay in Moscow, Levin had used his own\nhorses brought up from the country': 21, 'He had tried to arrange this part\nof their expenses in the best and cheapest way possible; but it\nappeared that their own horses came dearer than hired horses, and they\nstill hired too': 34, '"Send for the veterinary, there may be a bruise': 9, '"\n\n"And for Katerina Alexandrovna': 5, '" asked Kouzma': 3, 'Levin was not by now struck as he had been at first by the fact that to\nget from one end of Moscow to the other he had to have two powerful\nhorses put into a heavy carriage, to take the carriage three miles\nthrough the snowy slush and to keep it standing there four hours,\npaying five roubles every time': 61, 'Now it seemed quite natural': 5, '"Hire a pair for our carriage from the jobmaster," said he': 11, '"Yes, sir': 2, '"\n\nAnd so, simply and easily, thanks to the facilities of town life, Levin\nsettled a question which, in the country, would have called for so much\npersonal trouble and exertion, and going out onto the steps, he called\na sledge, sat down, and drove to Nikitsky': 47, 'On the way he thought no\nmore of money, but mused on the introduction that awaited him to the\nPetersburg savant, a writer on sociology, and what he would say to him\nabout his book': 35, 'Only during the first days of his stay in Moscow Levin had been struck\nby the expenditure, strange to one living in the country, unproductive\nbut inevitable, that was expected of him on every side': 35, 'But by now he\nhad grown used to it': 9, "That had happened to him in this matter which is\nsaid to happen to drunkards—the first glass sticks in the throat, the\nsecond flies down like a hawk, but after the third they're like tiny\nlittle birds": 37, 'When Levin had changed his first hundred-rouble note to\npay for liveries for his footmen and hall-porter he could not help\nreflecting that these liveries were of no use to anyone—but they were\nindubitably necessary, to judge by the amazement of the princess and\nKitty when he suggested that they might do without liveries,—that these\nliveries would cost the wages of two laborers for the summer, that is,\nwould pay for about three hundred working days from Easter to Ash\nWednesday, and each a day of hard work from early morning to late\nevening—and that hundred-rouble note did stick in his throat': 102, 'But the\nnext note, changed to pay for providing a dinner for their relations,\nthat cost twenty-eight roubles, though it did excite in Levin the\nreflection that twenty-eight roubles meant nine measures of oats, which\nmen would with groans and sweat have reaped and bound and thrashed and\nwinnowed and sifted and sown,—this next one he parted with more easily': 60, 'And now the notes he changed no longer aroused such reflections, and\nthey flew off like little birds': 18, 'Whether the labor devoted to obtaining\nthe money corresponded to the pleasure given by what was bought with\nit, was a consideration he had long ago dismissed': 27, 'His business\ncalculation that there was a certain price below which he could not\nsell certain grain was forgotten too': 20, 'The rye, for the price of which\nhe had so long held out, had been sold for fifty kopecks a measure\ncheaper than it had been fetching a month ago': 30, 'Even the consideration\nthat with such an expenditure he could not go on living for a year\nwithout debt, that even had no force': 24, 'Only one thing was essential: to\nhave money in the bank, without inquiring where it came from, so as to\nknow that one had the wherewithal to buy meat for tomorrow': 31, 'And this\ncondition had hitherto been fulfilled; he had always had the money in\nthe bank': 16, 'But now the money in the bank had gone, and he could not\nquite tell where to get the next installment': 21, 'And this it was which, at\nthe moment when Kitty had mentioned money, had disturbed him; but he\nhad no time to think about it': 25, 'He drove off, thinking of Katavasov and\nthe meeting with Metrov that was before him': 15, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART SEVEN', {'Levin had on this visit to town seen a great deal of his old friend at\nthe university, Professor Katavasov, whom he had not seen since his\nmarriage': 28, 'He liked in Katavasov the clearness and simplicity of his\nconception of life': 13, "Levin thought that the clearness of Katavasov's\nconception of life was due to the poverty of his nature; Katavasov\nthought that the disconnectedness of Levin's ideas was due to his lack\nof intellectual discipline; but Levin enjoyed Katavasov's clearness,\nand Katavasov enjoyed the abundance of Levin's untrained ideas, and\nthey liked to meet and to discuss": 56, 'Levin had read Katavasov some parts of his book, and he had liked them': 14, "On the previous day Katavasov had met Levin at a public lecture and\ntold him that the celebrated Metrov, whose article Levin had so much\nliked, was in Moscow, that he had been much interested by what\nKatavasov had told him about Levin's work, and that he was coming to\nsee him tomorrow at eleven, and would be very glad to make Levin's\nacquaintance": 64, '"You\'re positively a reformed character, I\'m glad to see," said\nKatavasov, meeting Levin in the little drawing-room': 17, '"I heard the bell\nand thought: Impossible that it can be he at the exact time': 16, 'Well,\nwhat do you say to the Montenegrins now': 9, "They're a race of warriors": 5, '"\n\n"Why, what\'s happened': 4, '" asked Levin': 3, 'Katavasov in a few words told him the last piece of news from the war,\nand going into his study, introduced Levin to a short, thick-set man of\npleasant appearance': 30, 'This was Metrov': 3, 'The conversation touched for a\nbrief space on politics and on how recent events were looked at in the\nhigher spheres in Petersburg': 23, 'Metrov repeated a saying that had reached\nhim through a most trustworthy source, reported as having been uttered\non this subject by the Tsar and one of the ministers': 29, 'Katavasov had\nheard also on excellent authority that the Tsar had said something\nquite different': 15, 'Levin tried to imagine circumstances in which both\nsayings might have been uttered, and the conversation on that topic\ndropped': 20, '"Yes, here he\'s written almost a book on the natural conditions of the\nlaborer in relation to the land," said Katavasov; "I\'m not a\nspecialist, but I, as a natural science man, was pleased at his not\ntaking mankind as something outside biological laws; but, on the\ncontrary, seeing his dependence on his surroundings, and in that\ndependence seeking the laws of his development': 64, '"\n\n"That\'s very interesting," said Metrov': 6, '"What I began precisely was to write a book on agriculture; but\nstudying the chief instrument of agriculture, the laborer," said Levin,\nreddening, "I could not help coming to quite unexpected results': 32, '"\n\nAnd Levin began carefully, as it were, feeling his ground, to expound\nhis views': 15, 'He knew Metrov had written an article against the generally\naccepted theory of political economy, but to what extent he could\nreckon on his sympathy with his own new views he did not know and could\nnot guess from the clever and serene face of the learned man': 48, '"But in what do you see the special characteristics of the Russian\nlaborer': 13, '" said Metrov; "in his biological characteristics, so to speak,\nor in the condition in which he is placed': 19, '"\n\nLevin saw that there was an idea underlying this question with which he\ndid not agree': 17, 'But he went on explaining his own idea that the Russian\nlaborer has a quite special view of the land, different from that of\nother people; and to support this proposition he made haste to add that\nin his opinion this attitude of the Russian peasant was due to the\nconsciousness of his vocation to people vast unoccupied expanses in the\nEast': 62, '"One may easily be led into error in basing any conclusion on the\ngeneral vocation of a people," said Metrov, interrupting Levin': 22, '"The\ncondition of the laborer will always depend on his relation to the land\nand to capital': 17, '"\n\nAnd without letting Levin finish explaining his idea, Metrov began\nexpounding to him the special point of his own theory': 21, 'In what the point of his theory lay, Levin did not understand, because\nhe did not take the trouble to understand': 21, 'He saw that Metrov, like\nother people, in spite of his own article, in which he had attacked the\ncurrent theory of political economy, looked at the position of the\nRussian peasant simply from the point of view of capital, wages, and\nrent': 43, 'He would indeed have been obliged to admit that in the\neastern—much the larger—part of Russia rent was as yet nil, that for\nnine-tenths of the eighty millions of the Russian peasants wages took\nthe form simply of food provided for themselves, and that capital does\nnot so far exist except in the form of the most primitive tools': 59, 'Yet it\nwas only from that point of view that he considered every laborer,\nthough in many points he differed from the economists and had his own\ntheory of the wage-fund, which he expounded to Levin': 36, 'Levin listened reluctantly, and at first made objections': 8, "He would have\nliked to interrupt Metrov, to explain his own thought, which in his\nopinion would have rendered further exposition of Metrov's theories\nsuperfluous": 25, 'But later on, feeling convinced that they looked at the\nmatter so differently, that they could never understand one another, he\ndid not even oppose his statements, but simply listened': 30, 'Although what\nMetrov was saying was by now utterly devoid of interest for him, he yet\nexperienced a certain satisfaction in listening to him': 24, "It flattered\nhis vanity that such a learned man should explain his ideas to him so\neagerly, with such intensity and confidence in Levin's understanding of\nthe subject, sometimes with a mere hint referring him to a whole aspect\nof the subject": 42, 'He put this down to his own credit, unaware that\nMetrov, who had already discussed his theory over and over again with\nall his intimate friends, talked of it with special eagerness to every\nnew person, and in general was eager to talk to anyone of any subject\nthat interested him, even if still obscure to himself': 57, '"We are late though," said Katavasov, looking at his watch directly\nMetrov had finished his discourse': 16, '"Yes, there\'s a meeting of the Society of Amateurs today in\ncommemoration of the jubilee of Svintitch," said Katavasov in answer to\nLevin\'s inquiry': 24, '"Pyotr Ivanovitch and I were going': 6, "I've promised to\ndeliver an address on his labors in zoology": 11, "Come along with us, it's\nvery interesting": 7, '"\n\n"Yes, and indeed it\'s time to start," said Metrov': 10, '"Come with us, and\nfrom there, if you care to, come to my place': 14, 'I should very much like\nto hear your work': 9, '"\n\n"Oh, no': 3, "It's no good yet, it's unfinished": 6, 'But I shall be very glad to\ngo to the meeting': 11, '"\n\n"I say, friends, have you heard': 7, 'He has handed in the separate report,"\nKatavasov called from the other room, where he was putting on his frock\ncoat': 21, 'And a conversation sprang up upon the university question, which was a\nvery important event that winter in Moscow': 19, 'Three old professors in the\ncouncil had not accepted the opinion of the younger professors': 15, 'The\nyoung ones had registered a separate resolution': 8, 'This, in the judgment\nof some people, was monstrous, in the judgment of others it was the\nsimplest and most just thing to do, and the professors were split up\ninto two parties': 33, 'One party, to which Katavasov belonged, saw in the opposite party a\nscoundrelly betrayal and treachery, while the opposite party saw in\nthem childishness and lack of respect for the authorities': 31, 'Levin,\nthough he did not belong to the university, had several times already\nduring his stay in Moscow heard and talked about this matter, and had\nhis own opinion on the subject': 32, 'He took part in the conversation that\nwas continued in the street, as they all three walked to the buildings\nof the old university': 24, 'The meeting had already begun': 5, 'Round the cloth-covered table, at which\nKatavasov and Metrov seated themselves, there were some half-dozen\npersons, and one of these was bending close over a manuscript, reading\nsomething aloud': 29, 'Levin sat down in one of the empty chairs that were\nstanding round the table, and in a whisper asked a student sitting near\nwhat was being read': 28, 'The student, eyeing Levin with displeasure, said:\n\n"Biography': 8, '"\n\nThough Levin was not interested in the biography, he could not help\nlistening, and learned some new and interesting facts about the life of\nthe distinguished man of science': 30, 'When the reader had finished, the chairman thanked him and read some\nverses of the poet Ment sent him on the jubilee, and said a few words\nby way of thanks to the poet': 34, 'Then Katavasov in his loud, ringing voice\nread his address on the scientific labors of the man whose jubilee was\nbeing kept': 22, 'When Katavasov had finished, Levin looked at his watch, saw it was past\none, and thought that there would not be time before the concert to\nread Metrov his book, and indeed, he did not now care to do so': 40, 'During\nthe reading he had thought over their conversation': 9, "He saw distinctly\nnow that though Metrov's ideas might perhaps have value, his own ideas\nhad a value too, and their ideas could only be made clear and lead to\nsomething if each worked separately in his chosen path, and that\nnothing would be gained by putting their ideas together": 50, "And having\nmade up his mind to refuse Metrov's invitation, Levin went up to him at\nthe end of the meeting": 21, 'Metrov introduced Levin to the chairman, with\nwhom he was talking of the political news': 15, 'Metrov told the chairman\nwhat he had already told Levin, and Levin made the same remarks on his\nnews that he had already made that morning, but for the sake of variety\nhe expressed also a new opinion which had only just struck him': 44, 'After\nthat the conversation turned again on the university question': 10, "As Levin\nhad already heard it all, he made haste to tell Metrov that he was\nsorry he could not take advantage of his invitation, took leave, and\ndrove to Lvov's": 31, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART SEVEN', {"Lvov, the husband of Natalia, Kitty's sister, had spent all his life in\nforeign capitals, where he had been educated, and had been in the\ndiplomatic service": 27, 'During the previous year he had left the diplomatic service, not owing\nto any "unpleasantness" (he never had any "unpleasantness" with\nanyone), and was transferred to the department of the court of the\npalace in Moscow, in order to give his two boys the best education\npossible': 47, 'In spite of the striking contrast in their habits and views and the\nfact that Lvov was older than Levin, they had seen a great deal of one\nanother that winter, and had taken a great liking to each other': 40, 'Lvov was at home, and Levin went in to him unannounced': 11, 'Lvov, in a house coat with a belt and in chamois leather shoes, was\nsitting in an armchair, and with a pince-nez with blue glasses he was\nreading a book that stood on a reading desk, while in his beautiful\nhand he held a half-burned cigarette daintily away from him': 50, 'His handsome, delicate, and still youthful-looking face, to which his\ncurly, glistening silvery hair gave a still more aristocratic air,\nlighted up with a smile when he saw Levin': 29, '"Capital': 1, 'I was meaning to send to you': 7, "How's Kitty": 2, "Sit here, it's\nmore comfortable": 5, '" He got up and pushed up a rocking chair': 10, '"Have you\nread the last circular in the _Journal de St': 11, 'Pétersbourg': 1, '_ I think\nit\'s excellent," he said, with a slight French accent': 12, "Levin told him what he had heard from Katavasov was '"That\'s what I envy you, that you are able to mix in these interesting\nscientific circles," he said': 18, 'And as he talked, he passed as usual into\nFrench, which was easier to him': 15, '"It\'s true I haven\'t the time for it': 8, "My official work and the children leave me no time; and then I'm not\nashamed to own that my education has been too defective": 24, '"\n\n"That I don\'t believe," said Levin with a smile, feeling, as he always\ndid, touched at Lvov\'s low opinion of himself, which was not in the\nleast put on from a desire to seem or to be modest, but was absolutely\nsincere': 43, '"Oh, yes, indeed': 3, 'I feel now how badly educated I am': 8, 'To educate my\nchildren I positively have to look up a great deal, and in fact simply\nto study myself': 20, "For it's not enough than yours, and I wouldn\'t wish for children better than\nyours': 25, '"\n\nLvov visibly tried to restrain the expression of his delight, but he\nwas positively radiant with smiles': 18, '"If only they\'re better than I': 6, "That's all I desire": 4, 'You don\'t know yet\nall the work," he said, "with boys who\'ve been left like mine to run\nwild abroad': 20, '"\n\n"You\'ll catch all that up': 6, "They're such clever children": 4, 'The great\nthing is the education of character': 8, "That's what I learn when I look at\nyour children": 10, '"\n\n"You talk of the education of character': 8, "You can't imagine how\ndifficult that is": 7, 'You have hardly succeeded in combating one tendency\nwhen others crop up, and the struggle begins again': 17, 'If one had not a\nsupport in religion—you remember we talked about that—no father could\nbring children up relying on his own strength alone without that help': 27, '"\n\nThis subject, which always interested Levin, was cut short by the\nentrance of the beauty Natalia Alexandrovna, dressed to go out': 22, '"I didn\'t know you were here," she said, unmistakably feeling no\nregret, but a positive pleasure, in interrupting this her and take her to Kitty's;\nor that, if he had not finished his work, he should send the carriage\nback and Levin would go with her": 61, '"He\'s spoiling me," Lvov said to his wife; "he assures me that our\nchildren are splendid, when I know how much that\'s bad there is in\nthem': 27, '"\n\n"Arseny goes to extremes, I always say," said his wife': 11, '"If you look\nfor perfection, you will never be satisfied': 10, "And it's true, as papa\nsays,—that when we were brought up there was one extreme—we were kept\nin the basement, while our parents lived in the best rooms; now it's\njust the other way—the parents are in the wash house, while the\nchildren are in the best rooms": 48, 'Parents now are not expected to live at\nall, but to exist altogether for their children': 16, '"\n\n"Well, what if they like it better': 8, '" Lvov said, with his beautiful\nsmile, touching her hand': 10, '"Anyone who didn\'t know you would think you\nwere a stepmother, not a true mother': 15, the two handsome\nboys who came in, and after bowing to Levin, went up to their father,\nobviously wishing to ask him about something': 33, "Levin would have liked to talk to them, to hear what they conversation was kept up\nwithout a break upon Herzegovina, Princess Korzinskaya, the town\ncouncil, and the sudden death of Madame Apraksina": 67, 'Levin even forgot the commission intrusted to him': sheepskin cape, waiting till they had finished\nspeaking': 25, '"Come, let us go': 4, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART SEVEN', {'At the concert in the afternoon two very interesting things were\nperformed': 12, 'One was a fantasia, _King Lear;_ the other was a quartette\ndedicated to the memory of Bach': 17, 'Both were new and in the new style,\nand Levin was eager to form an opinion of them': 18, 'After escorting his\nsister-in-law to her stall, he stood against a column and tried to\nlisten as attentively and conscientiously as possible': 22, 'He tried not to\nlet his attention be distracted, and not to spoil his impression by\nlooking at the conductor in a white tie, waving his arms, which always\ndisturbed his enjoyment of music so much, or the ladies in bonnets,\nwith strings carefully tied over their ears, and all these people\neither thinking of nothing at all or thinking of all sorts of things\nexcept the music': 68, 'He tried to avoid meeting musical connoisseurs or\ntalkative acquaintances, and stood looking at the floor straight before\nhim, listening': 20, 'But the more he listened to the fantasia of _King Lear_ the further he\nfelt from forming any definite opinion of it': 22, 'There was, as it were, a\ncontinual beginning, a preparation of the musical expression of some\nfeeling, but it fell to pieces again directly, breaking into new\nmusical motives, or simply nothing but the whims of the composer,\nexceedingly complex but disconnected sounds': 43, 'And these fragmentary\nmusical expressions, though sometimes beautiful, were disagreeable,\nbecause they were utterly unexpected and not led up to by anything': 22, 'Gaiety and grief and despair and tenderness and triumph followed one\nanother without any connection, like the emotions of a madman': 21, "And\nthose emotions, like a madman's, sprang up quite unexpectedly": 10, 'During the whole of the performance Levin felt like a deaf man watching\npeople dancing, and was in a state of complete bewilderment when the\nfantasia was over, and felt a great weariness from the fruitless strain\non his attention': 40, 'Loud applause resounded on all sides': 6, 'Everyone got\nup, moved about, and began talking': 8, 'Anxious to throw some light on his\nown perplexity from the impressions of others, Levin began to walk\nabout, looking for connoisseurs, and was glad to see a well-known\nmusical amateur in conversation with Pestsov, whom he knew': 38, '"Marvelous': 1, '" Pestsov was saying in his mellow bass': 8, '"How are you,\nKonstantin Dmitrievitch': 5, "Particularly sculpturesque and plastic, so to\nsay, and richly colored is that passage where you feel Cordelia's\napproach, where woman, _das ewig Weibliche,_ enters into conflict with\nfate": 28, "Isn't it": 2, '"\n\n"You mean': 3, 'what has Cordelia to do with it': 7, '" Levin asked timidly,\nforgetting that the fantasia was supposed to represent King Lear': 14, '"Cordelia comes in': 3, 'see here': 2, '" said Pestsov, tapping his finger on\nthe satiny surface of the program he held in his hand and passing it to\nLevin': 23, 'Only then Levin recollected the title of the fantasia, and made haste\nto read in the Russian translation the lines from Shakespeare that were\nprinted on the back of the program': 31, '"You can\'t follow it without that," said Pestsov, addressing Levin, as\nthe person he had been speaking to had gone away, and he had no one to\ntalk to': 29, "In the _entr'acte_ Levin and Pestsov fell into an argument upon the\nmerits and defects of music of the Wagner school": 21, 'Levin maintained that\nthe mistake of Wagner and all his followers lay in their trying to take\nmusic into the sphere of another art, just as poetry goes wrong when it\ntries to paint a face as the art of painting ought to do, and as an\ninstance of this mistake he cited the sculptor who carved in marble\ncertain poetic phantasms flitting round the figure of the poet on the\npedestal': 72, '"These phantoms were so far from being phantoms that they\nwere positively clinging on the ladder," said Levin': 18, 'The comparison\npleased him, but he could not remember whether he had not used the same\nphrase before, and to Pestsov, too, and as he said it he felt confused': 30, 'Pestsov maintained that art is one, and that it can attain its highest\nmanifestations only by conjunction with all kinds of art': 22, 'The second piece that was performed Levin could not hear': 10, 'Pestsov, who\nwas standing beside him, was talking to him almost all the time,\ncondemning the music for its excessive affected assumption of\nsimplicity, and comparing it with the simplicity of the Pre-Raphaelites\nin painting': 35, 'As he went out Levin met many more acquaintances, with\nwhom he talked of politics, of music, and of common acquaintances': 21, 'Among others he met Count Bol, whom he had utterly forgotten to call\nupon': 14, '"Well, go at once then," Madame Lvova said, when he told her; "perhaps\nthey\'ll not be at home, and then you can come to the meeting to fetch\nme': 29, "You'll find me still there": 5, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART SEVEN', {'"Perhaps they\'re not at home': 5, '" said Levin, as he went into the hall of\nCountess Bola\'s house': 13, '"At home; please walk in," said the porter, resolutely removing his\novercoat': 12, '"How annoying': 2, '" thought Levin with a sigh, taking off one glove and\nstroking his hat': 14, '"What did I come for': 5, 'What have I to say to them': 7, '"\n\nAs he up, greeted them, and sat down\nbeside the sofa with his hat on his knees': 17, '"How is your wife': 4, 'Have you been at the concert': 6, "We couldn't go": 3, 'Mamma\nhad to be at the funeral service': 8, '"\n\n"Yes, I heard': 4, 'What a sudden death': 4, '" said Levin': 3, 'The countess came in, sat down on the sofa, and she too asked after his\nwife and inquired about the concert': 21, "Levin answered, and repeated an inquiry about Madame Apraksina's sudden\ndeath": 11, '"But she was always in weak health': 7, '"\n\n"Were you at the opera yesterday': 7, '"\n\n"Yes, I was': 4, '"\n\n"Lucca was very good': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, very good," he said, and as it was utterly of no consequence to\nhim what they thought of him, he began repeating what they had heard a\nhundred times about the characteristics of the singer\'s talent': 38, 'Countess Bola pretended to be listening': 6, 'Then, when he had said enough\nand paused, the colonel, who had been silent till then, began to talk': promised my _belle-sœur_ to fetch her from it," said Levin': 12, 'A silence followed': 3, 'The mother once more exchanged glances with a\ndaughter': 9, '"Well, now I think the time has come," thought himself with the reflection that everyone does\nit': 24, 'He drove to the public meeting, where he was to find his\nsister-in-law, so as to drive home with her': 20, 'At the public meeting of the committee there were a great many people,\nand almost all the highest society': 19, 'Levin was in time for the report\nwhich, as everyone said, was very interesting': 14, 'When the reading of the\nreport was over, people moved about, and Levin met Sviazhsky, who\ninvited him very pressingly to come that evening to a meeting of the\nSociety of Agriculture, where a celebrated lecture was to be delivered,\nand Stepan Arkadyevitch, who had only just come from the races, and\nmany other acquaintances; and Levin heard and uttered various\ncriticisms on the meeting, on the new fantasia, and on a public trial': 74, 'But, probably from the mental fatigue he was beginning to feel, he made\na blunder in speaking of the trial, and this blunder he recalled\nseveral times with vexation': 29, 'Speaking of the sentence upon a foreigner\nwho had been condemned in Russia, and of how unfair it would be to\npunish him by exile abroad, Levin repeated what he had heard the day\nbefore in conversation from an acquaintance': 40, '"I think sending him abroad is much the same as punishing a carp by\nputting it into the water," said Levin': 21, "Then he recollected that this\nidea, which he had heard from an acquaintance and uttered as his own,\ncame from a fable of Krilov's, and that the acquaintance had picked it\nup from a newspaper article": 36, 'After driving home with his sister-in-law, and finding Kitty in good\nspirits and quite well, Levin drove to the club': 20, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART SEVEN', {'Levin reached the club just at the right time': 9, 'Members and visitors\nwere driving up as he arrived': 9, 'Levin had not been at the club for a\nvery long while—not since he lived in Moscow, when he was leaving the\nuniversity and going into society': 27, 'He remembered the club, the external\ndetails of its arrangement, but he had completely forgotten the\nimpression it had made on him in old days': 25, "But as soon as, driving into\nthe wide semicircular court and getting out of the sledge, he mounted\nthe steps, and the hall-porter, adorned with ('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART SEVEN', {'"Oblonsky\'s carriage': 2, '" the porter shouted in an angry bass': 8, 'The\ncarriage drove up and both got in': 8, 'It was only for the first few\nmoments, while the ('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART SEVEN', {'She had risen to meet him, not concealing her pleasure at seeing him;\nand in the quiet ease with which she held out her little vigorous hand,\nintroduced him to and natural': 64, '"I am delighted, delighted," she repeated, and on her lips these simple\nwords took for Levin\'s ears a special significance': 20, '"I have known you\nand liked you for a long 'Every word\nin his conversation with her had a special significance': 11, 'And talking to\nher was pleasant; still pleasanter it was to listen to her': 14, 'Anna talked not merely naturally and cleverly, but cleverly and\ncarelessly, attaching no value to her own ideas and giving great weight\nto the ideas of the person she was talking to': 32, 'The conversation turned on the new movement in art, on the new\nillustrations of the Bible by a French artist': 20, 'Vorkuev attacked the\nartist for a realism carried to the point of coarseness': 13, 'Levin said that the French had carried conventionality further than\nanyone, and that consequently they see a great merit in the return to\nrealism': 24, 'In the fact of not lying they see poetry': 9, 'Never had anything clever said by Levin given him so much pleasure as\nthis remark': 15, "Anna's face lighted up at once, as at once she appreciated\nthe thought": 13, 'She laughed': 2, '"I laugh," she said, "as one laughs when one sees a very true portrait': 14, 'What you said so perfectly hits off French art now, painting and\nliterature too, indeed—Zola, Daudet': 16, 'But perhaps it is always so, that\nmen form their conceptions from fictitious, conventional types, and\nthen—all the _combinaisons_ made—they are tired of the fictitious\nfigures and begin to invent more natural, true figures': 34, '"\n\n"That\'s perfectly true," said Vorknev': 6, '"So you\'ve been at the club': 6, '" she said to her brother': 6, '"Yes, yes, this is a woman': 6, '" Levin thought, forgetting himself and\nstaring persistently at dropped her eyelids, as though\nrecollecting something': 8, '"Oh, well, but that\'s of no interest to anyone," she said, and she\nturned to the English girl': 18, '"Please order the tea in the ('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART SEVEN', {'After taking leave of her guests, Anna did not sit down, but began\nwalking up and down the room': 19, 'She had unconsciously the whole evening\ndone her utmost to ('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART SEVEN', {'There are no conditions to which a man cannot become used, especially\nif he sees that all around him are living in the same way': 25, 'Levin could\nnot have believed ('TOL CHAPTER 14 PART SEVEN', {'The doctor was not yet up, and the footman said that "he had been up\nlate, and had given orders not to be waked, but would get up soon': 29, '" The\nfootman was cleaning the lamp-chimneys, and seemed very busy about\nthem': 13, 'This concentration of the footman upon his lamps, and his\nindifference to what was passing in Levin, at first astounded him, but\nimmediately on considering the question he realized that no one knew or\nwas bound to know his feelings, and that it was all the more necessary\nto act calmly, sensibly, and resolutely to get through this wall of\nindifference and attain his aim': 65, '"Don\'t be in a hurry or let anything slip," Levin said to himself,\nfeeling a greater and greater flow of physical energy and attention to\nall that lay before him to do': 32, "Having ascertained that the doctor was not getting up, Levin considered\nvarious plans, and decided on the following one: that Kouzma should go\nfor another doctor, while he himself should go to the chemist's for\nopium, and if when he came back the doctor had not yet begun to get up,\nhe would either by tipping the footman, or by force, wake the doctor at\nall hazards": 67, "At the chemist's the lank shopman sealed up a packet of powders for a\ncoachman who stood waiting, and refused him opium with the same\ncallousness with which the doctor's footman had cleaned his lamp\nchimneys": 36, 'Trying not to get flurried or out of temper, Levin mentioned\nthe names of the doctor and midwife, and explaining what the opium was\nneeded for, tried to persuade him': 30, "The assistant inquired in German\nwhether he should give it, and receiving an affirmative reply from\nbehind the partition, he took out a bottle and a funnel, deliberately\npoured the opium from a bigger bottle into a little one, stuck on a\nlabel, sealed it up, in spite of Levin's request that he would not do\nso, and was about to wrap it up too": 65, 'This was more than Levin could\nstand; the other was in her presence, at her pillow,\nwhere his heart seemed breaking and still did not break from\nsympathetic suffering, and he prayed to God without ceasing": 95, 'And every\ntime he was brought back from a moment of oblivion by a scream reaching\nhim from the bedroom, he fell into the same strange terror that had\ncome upon him the first minute': 35, 'Every time he heard a shriek, he jumped\nup, ran to justify himself, remembered on the way that he was not to\nblame, and he longed to defend her, to help her': 32, 'But as he looked at\nher, he saw again that help was impossible, and he was filled with\nterror and prayed: "Lord, have mercy on us, and help us': 29, '" And as time\nwent on, both these conditions became more intense; ('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART SEVEN', {"Stepan Arkadyevitch's affairs were in a very bad way": 9, 'The money for two-thirds of the forest had all been spent already, and\nhe had borrowed from the merchant in advance at ten per cent discount,\nalmost all the remaining third': 31, 'The merchant would not give more,\nespecially as Darya Alexandrovna, for the first time that winter\ninsisting on her right to her own property, had refused to sign the\nreceipt for the payment of the last third of the forest': 40, 'All his salary\nwent on household expenses and in payment of petty debts that could not\nbe put off': 19, 'There was positively no money': 5, "This was unpleasant and awkward, and in Stepan Arkadyevitch's opinion\nthings could not go on like this": 17, 'The explanation of the position was,\nin his view, to be found in the fact that his salary was too small': 21, 'The\npost he filled had been unmistakably very good five years ago, but it\nwas so no longer': 18, 'Petrov, the bank director, had twelve thousand; Sventitsky, a company\ndirector, had seventeen thousand; Mitin, who had founded a bank,\nreceived fifty thousand': 23, '"Clearly I\'ve been napping, and they\'ve overlooked me," Stepan\nArkadyevitch thought about himself': 13, 'And he began keeping his eyes and\nears open, and towards the end of the winter he had discovered a very\ngood berth and had formed a plan of attack upon it, at first from\nMoscow through aunts, uncles, and friends, and then, when the matter\nwas well advanced, in the spring, he went himself to Petersburg': 57, 'It was\none of those snug, lucrative berths of which there are so many more\nnowadays than there used to be, with incomes ranging from one thousand\nto fifty thousand roubles': 31, 'It was the post of secretary of the\ncommittee of the amalgamated agency of the southern railways, and of\ncertain banking companies': 22, 'This position, like all such appointments,\ncalled for such immense energy and such varied qualifications, that it\nwas difficult for them to be found united in any one man': 29, 'And since a\nman combining all the qualifications was not to be found, it was at\nleast better that the post be filled by an honest than by a dishonest\nman': 31, 'And Stepan Arkadyevitch was not merely an honest\nman—unemphatically—in the common acceptation of the words, he was an\nhonest man—emphatically—in that special sense which the word has in\nMoscow, when they talk of an "honest" politician, an "honest" writer,\nan "honest" newspaper, an "honest" institution, an "honest" tendency,\nmeaning not simply that the man or the institution is not dishonest,\nbut that they are capable on occasion of taking a line of their own in\nopposition to the authorities': 79, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch moved in those circles in Moscow in which that\nexpression had come into use, was regarded there as an honest man, and\nso had more right to this appointment than others': 33, 'The appointment yielded an income of from seven to ten thousand a year,\nand Oblonsky could fill it without giving up his government position': 24, 'It was in the hands of two ministers, one lady, and two Jews, and all\nthese people, though the way had been paved already with them, Stepan\nArkadyevitch had to see in Petersburg': 33, 'Besides this business, Stepan\nArkadyevitch had promised his sister Anna to obtain from Karenin a\ndefinite answer on the question of divorce': 22, 'And begging fifty roubles\nfrom Dolly, he set off for Petersburg': 11, "Stepan Arkadyevitch sat in Karenin's study listening to his report on\nthe causes of the unsatisfactory position of Russian finance, and only\nwaiting for the moment when he would finish to speak about his own\nbusiness or about Anna": 39, '"Yes, that\'s very true," he said, when Alexey Alexandrovitch took off\nthe pince-nez, without which he could not read now, and looked\ninquiringly at his former brother-in-law, "that\'s very true in\nparticular cases, but still the principle of our day is freedom': 42, '"\n\n"Yes, but I lay down another principle, embracing the principle of\nfreedom," said Alexey Alexandrovitch, with emphasis on the word\n"embracing," aloud over again the conclusive passage': 17, '"I don\'t advocate protection for the sake of private interests, but for\nthe public weal, and for the lower and upper classes equally," he Stepan\nArkadyevitch's proposed position ran counter to the main tendency of\nhis own projects of reform, which always leaned towards economy": 34, '"I consider, and I have embodied my views in a note on the subject,\nthat in our day these immense salaries are evidence of the unsound\neconomic _assiette_ of our finances': 31, '"\n\n"But what\'s to be done': 6, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch': 4, '"Suppose a bank\ndirector gets ten thousand—well, he\'s worth it; or an engineer gets\ntwenty thousand—after all, it\'s a growing thing, you know': 23, '"\n\n"I assume that a salary is the price paid for a commodity, and it ought\nto conform with the law of supply and demand': 25, 'If the salary is fixed\nwithout any regard for that law, as, for instance, when I see two\nengineers leaving college together, both equally well trained and\nefficient, and one getting forty thousand while the other is satisfied\nwith two; or when I see lawyers and hussars, having no special\nqualifications, appointed directors of banking companies with immense\nsalaries, I conclude that the salary is not fixed in accordance with\nthe law of supply and demand, but simply through personal interest': 81, 'And\nthis is an abuse of great gravity in itself, and one that reacts\ninjuriously on the government service': 19, 'I consider': 2, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch made haste to interrupt his brother-in-law': 9, '"Yes; but you must agree that it\'s a new institution of undoubted\nutility that\'s being started': 16, "After all, you know, it's a growing\nthing": 8, 'What they lay particular stress on is the thing being carried on\nhonestly," said Stepan Arkadyevitch with emphasis': 18, 'But the Moscow significance of the word "honest" was lost on Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 13, '"Honesty is only a negative qualification," he said': 8, '"Well, you\'ll do me a great service, anyway," said Stepan Arkadyevitch,\n"by putting in a word to Pomorsky—just in the way of conversation': 23, '"\n\n"But I fancy it\'s more in Volgarinov\'s hands," said Alexey\nAlexandrovitch': 12, '"Volgarinov has fully assented, as far as he\'s concerned," said Stepan\nArkadyevitch, turning red': 14, believed most positively that the committee in\nwhich he was trying to get an appointment was a new, genuine, and\nhonest public body, but that morning when Volgarinov had—intentionally,\nbeyond a doubt—kept him two hours waiting with other petitioners in his\nwaiting room, he had suddenly felt uneasy': 50, 'Whether he was uncomfortable that he, a descendant of Rurik, Prince\nOblonsky, had been kept for two hours waiting to see a Jew, or that for\nthe first time in his life he was not following the example of his\nancestors in serving the government, but was turning off into a new\ncareer, anyway he was very uncomfortable': 58, "During those two hours in\nVolgarinov's waiting room Stepan Arkadyevitch, stepping jauntily about\nthe room, pulling his whiskers, entering into conversation with the\nother petitioners, and inventing an epigram on his position,\nassiduously concealed from others, and even from himself, the feeling\nhe was experiencing": 45, 'But all the time he was uncomfortable and angry, he could not have said\nwhy—whether because he could not get his epigram just right, or from\nsome other reason': 29, 'When at last Volgarinov had received him ('TOL CHAPTER 20 PART SEVEN', {'Stepan Arkadyevitch, as usual, did not waste his time in Petersburg': 11, "In\nPetersburg, besides business, his sister's divorce, and his coveted\nappointment, he wanted, as he always did, to freshen himself up, as he\nsaid, after the mustiness of Moscow": 29, 'In spite of its _cafés chantants_ and its omnibuses, Moscow was yet a\nstagnant bog': 15, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch always felt it': 5, 'After living for some\ntime in Moscow, especially in close relations with his family, he was\nconscious of a depression of spirits': 22, "After being a long time in Moscow\nwithout a change, he reached a point when he positively began to be\nworrying himself over his wife's ill-humor and reproaches, over his\nchildren's health and education, and the petty details of his official\nwork; even the fact of being in debt worried him": 51, 'But he had only to go\nand stay a little while in Petersburg, in the circle there in which he\nmoved, where people lived—really lived—instead of vegetating as in\nMoscow, and all such ideas vanished and melted away at once, like wax\nbefore the fire': 45, 'His wife': 2, 'Only that day he had been talking to\nPrince Tchetchensky': 10, 'Prince Tchetchensky had a wife and family,\ngrown-up pages in the corps,': 12, 'and he had another illegitimate family\nof children also': 9, 'Though the first family was very nice too, Prince\nTchetchensky felt happier in his second family; and he used to take his\neldest son with him to his second family, and told Stepan Arkadyevitch\nthat he thought it good for his son, enlarging his ideas': 45, 'What would\nhave been said to that in Moscow': 9, 'His children': 2, 'In Petersburg children did not prevent their parents from\nenjoying life': 11, "The children were brought up in schools, and there was\nno trace of the wild idea that prevailed in Moscow, in Lvov's\nhousehold, for instance, that all the luxuries of life were for the\nchildren, while the parents have nothing but work and anxiety": 44, 'Here\npeople understood that a man is in duty bound to live for himself, as\nevery man of culture should live': 21, 'His official duties': 3, 'Official work here was not the stiff, hopeless\ndrudgery that it was in Moscow': 14, 'Here there was some interest in\nofficial life': 8, "A chance meeting, a service rendered, a happy phrase, a\nknack of facetious mimicry, and a man's career might be made in a\ntrice": 24, 'So it had been with Bryantsev, whom Stepan Arkadyevitch had met\nthe previous day, and who was one of the highest functionaries in\ngovernment now': 25, 'There was some interest in official work like that': 9, 'The Petersburg attitude on pecuniary matters had an especially soothing\neffect on Stepan Arkadyevitch': 14, 'Bartnyansky, who must spend at least\nfifty thousand to judge by the style he lived in, had made an\ninteresting comment the day before on that subject': 27, 'As they were talking before dinner, Stepan Arkadyevitch said to\nBartnyansky:\n\n"You\'re friendly, I fancy, with Mordvinsky; you might do me a favor:\nsay a word to him, please, for me': 31, "There's an appointment I should like\nto get—secretary of the agency": 11, '"\n\n"Oh, I shan\'t remember all that, if you tell it to me': 13, 'But what\npossesses you to have to do with railways and Jews': 12, "Take it as you\nwill, it's a low business": 9, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch did not say to Bartnyansky that it was a "growing\nthing"—Bartnyansky would not have understood that': 19, '"I want the money, I\'ve nothing to live on': 9, '"\n\n"You\'re living, aren\'t you': 5, '"\n\n"Yes, but in debt': 5, '"\n\n"Are you, though': 4, 'Heavily': 1, '" said Bartnyansky sympathetically': 4, '"Very heavily: twenty thousand': 4, '"\n\nBartnyansky broke into good-humored laughter': 6, '"Oh, lucky fellow': 3, '" said he': 3, '"My debts mount up to a million and a\nhalf, and I\'ve nothing, and still I can live, as you see': 21, '"\n\nAnd Stepan Arkadyevitch saw the correctness of this view not in words\nonly but in actual fact': 18, "Zhivahov owed three hundred thousand, and\nhadn't a farthing to bless himself with, and he lived, and in style\ntoo": 20, 'Count Krivtsov was considered a hopeless case by everyone, and yet\nhe kept two mistresses': 15, 'Petrovsky had run through five millions, and\nstill lived in just the same style, and was even a manager in the\nfinancial department with a salary of twenty thousand': 29, 'But besides\nthis, Petersburg had physically an agreeable effect on Stepan\nArkadyevitch': 12, 'It made him younger': 4, 'In Moscow he sometimes found a gray\nhair in his head, dropped asleep after dinner, stretched, walked slowly\nupstairs, breathing heavily, was bored by the society of young women,\nand did not dance at balls': 35, 'In Petersburg he always felt ten years\nyounger': 8, 'His experience in Petersburg was exactly what had been described to him\non the previous day by Prince Pyotr Oblonsky, a man of sixty, who had\njust come back from abroad:\n\n"We don\'t know the way to live here," said Pyotr Oblonsky': 42, '"I spent the\nsummer in Baden, and you wouldn\'t believe it, I felt quite a young man': 17, 'At a glimpse of a pretty woman, my thoughts': 9, 'One dines and drinks a\nglass of wine, and feels strong and ready for anything': 15, "I came home to\nRussia—had to see my wife, and, what's more, go to my country place;\nand there, you'd hardly believe it, in a fortnight I'd got into a\ndressing gown and given up dressing for dinner": 38, "Needn't say I had no\nthoughts left for pretty women": 10, 'I became quite an old gentleman': 6, 'There\nwas nothing left for me but to think of my eternal salvation': 13, 'I went\noff to Paris—I was as right as could be at once': 13, '"\n\nStepan Arkadyevitch felt exactly the difference that Pyotr Oblonsky\ndescribed': 11, 'In Moscow he degenerated so much that if he had had to be\nthere for long together, he might in good earnest have come to\nconsidering his salvation; in Petersburg he felt himself a man of the\nworld again': 39, 'Between Princess Betsy Tverskaya and Stepan Arkadyevitch there had long\nexisted rather curious relations': 14, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch always flirted\nwith her in jest, and used to say to her, also in jest, the most\nunseemly things, knowing that nothing delighted her so much': 28, 'The day\nafter his conversation with Karenin, Stepan Arkadyevitch went to see\nher, and felt so youthful that in this jesting flirtation and nonsense\nhe recklessly went so far that he did not know how to extricate\nhimself, as unluckily he was so far from being attracted by her that he\nthought her positively disagreeable': 55, 'What made it hard to change the\nconversation was the she when she saw him': 7, '"Well, and what news\nof your poor sister': 8, 'You needn\'t look at me like that," she added': 9, '"Ever since they\'ve all turned against her, all those who\'re a done what they all do, except me—only they hide it': 11, "But she\nwouldn't be deceitful, and she did a fine thing": 11, 'And she did better\nstill in throwing up that crazy brother-in-law of yours': ('TOL CHAPTER 21 PART SEVEN', {"After a capital dinner and a great deal of cognac drunk at\nBartnyansky's, Stepan Arkadyevitch, only a little later than the\nappointed time, went in to Countess Lidia ('TOL CHAPTER 22 PART SEVEN', {'Stepan Arkadyevitch felt completely nonplussed by the strange talk\nwhich he was hearing for the first time': 17, 'The complexity of Petersburg,\nas a rule, had a stimulating effect on him, rousing him out of his\nMoscow stagnation': 20, 'But he liked these complications, and understood\nthem only in the circles he knew and was at home in': 19, 'In when he saw Stepan Arkadyevitch, and\nclinging to him, walked with him into his room and there began telling\nhim how he had spent the evening, and fell asleep doing so': 51, 'Stepan Arkadyevitch was ('TOL CHAPTER 23 PART SEVEN', {'In order to carry through any undertaking in family life, there must\nnecessarily be either complete division between the husband and wife,\nor loving agreement': 25, 'When the relations of a couple are vacillating and\nneither one thing nor the other, no sort of enterprise can be\nundertaken': 22, 'Many families remain for years in the same place, though both husband\nand wife are sick of it, simply because there is neither complete\ndivision nor agreement between them': 29, 'Both Vronsky and Anna felt life in Moscow insupportable in the heat and\ndust, when the spring sunshine was followed by the glare of summer, and\nall the trees in the boulevards had long since been in full leaf, and\nthe leaves were covered with dust': 46, 'But they did not go back to\nVozdvizhenskoe, as they had arranged to do long before; they went on\nstaying in Moscow, though they both loathed it, because of late there\nhad been no agreement between them': 37, 'The irritability that kept them apart had no external cause, and all\nefforts to come to an understanding intensified it, instead of removing\nit': 24, 'It was an inner irritation, grounded in her mind on the conviction\nthat his love had grown less; in his, on regret that he had put himself\nfor her sake in a difficult position, which she, instead of lightening,\nmade still more difficult': 43, 'Neither of them gave full utterance to their\nsense of grievance, but they considered each other in the wrong, and\ntried on every pretext to prove this to one another': 30, 'In her eyes the whole of him, with all his habits, ideas, desires, with\nall his spiritual and physical temperament, was one thing—love for\nwomen, and that love, she felt, ought to be entirely concentrated on\nher alone': 38, 'That love was less; consequently, as she reasoned, he must\nhave transferred part of his love to other women or to another\nwoman—and she was jealous': 26, 'She was jealous not of any particular woman\nbut of the decrease of his love': 15, 'Not having got an object for her\njealousy, she was on the lookout for it': 15, 'At the slightest hint she\ntransferred her jealousy from one object to another': 13, 'At one time she\nwas jealous of those low women with whom he might so easily renew his\nold bachelor ties; then she was jealous of the society women he might\nmeet; then she was jealous of the imaginary girl whom he might want to\nmarry, for whose sake he would break with her': 54, 'And this last form of\njealousy tortured her most of all, especially as he had unwarily told\nher, in a moment of frankness, that his mother knew him so little that\nshe had had the audacity to try and persuade him to marry the young\nPrincess Sorokina': 47, 'And being jealous of him, Anna was indignant against him and found\ngrounds for indignation in everything': 17, 'For everything that was\ndifficult in her position she blamed him': 11, 'The agonizing condition of\nsuspense she had passed in Moscow, the tardiness and indecision of\nAlexey Alexandrovitch, her solitude—she put it all down to him': 25, 'If he\nhad loved her he would have seen all the bitterness of her position,\nand would have rescued her from it': 22, 'For her being in Moscow and not in\nthe country, he was to blame too': 15, 'He could not live buried in the\ncountry as she would have liked to do': 15, 'He must have society, and he had\nput her in this awful position, the bitterness of which he would not\nsee': 21, 'And again, it was his fault that she was forever separated from\nher son': 14, 'Even the rare moments of tenderness that came from time to time did not\nsoothe her; in his tenderness now she saw a shade of complacency, of\nself-confidence, which had not been of old, and which exasperated her': 38, 'It was dusk': 3, 'Anna was alone, and waiting for him to come back from a\nbachelor dinner': 14, "She walked up and down in his study (the room where\nthe noise from the street was least heard), and thought over every\ndetail of their yesterday's quarrel": 28, 'Going back from the\nwell-remembered, offensive words of the quarrel to what had been the\nground of it, she arrived at last at its origin': 25, 'For a long while she\ncould hardly believe that their dissension had arisen from a\nconversation so inoffensive, of so little moment to either': 24, 'But so it\nactually had been': 6, "It all arose from his laughing at the girls' high\nschools, declaring they were useless, while she defended them": 19, "He had\nspoken slightingly of women's education in general, and had said that\nHannah, Anna's English protégée, had not the slightest need to know\nanything of physics": 27, 'This irritated Anna': 3, 'She saw in this a contemptuous reference to her\noccupations': 10, 'And she bethought her of a phrase to pay him back for the\npain he had given her': 18, '"I don\'t expect you to understand me, my\nfeelings, as anyone who loved me might, but simple delicacy I did\nexpect," she said': 23, 'And he had actually flushed with vexation, and had said something\nunpleasant': 12, 'She could not recall her answer, but at that point, with an\nunmistakable desire to wound her too, he had said:\n\n"I feel no interest in your infatuation over this girl, that\'s true,\nbecause I see it\'s unnatural': 38, '"\n\nThe cruelty with which he shattered the world she had built up for\nherself so laboriously to enable her to endure her hard life, the\ninjustice with which he had accused her of affectation, of\nartificiality, aroused her': 39, '"I am very sorry that nothing but what\'s coarse and material is\ncomprehensible and natural to you," she said and walked out of the\nroom': 25, 'When he had come in to her yesterday evening, they had not referred to\nthe quarrel, but both felt that the quarrel had been smoothed over, but\nwas not at an end': 32, 'Today he had not been at home all day, and she felt so lonely and\nwretched in being on bad terms with him that she wanted to forget it\nall, to forgive him, and be reconciled with him; she wanted to throw\nthe blame on herself and to justify him': 50, '"I am myself to blame': 5, "I'm irritable, I'm insanely jealous": 5, "I will make\nit up with him, and we'll go away to the country; there I shall be more\nat peace": 21, '"\n\n"Unnatural': 2, '" She suddenly recalled the word that had stung her most of\nall, not so much the word itself as the intent to wound her with which\nit was said': 30, '"I know what he meant; he meant—unnatural, not loving my\nown daughter, to love another person\'s child': 17, "What does he know of love\nfor children, of my love for Seryozha, whom I've sacrificed for him": 18, 'But that wish to wound me': 6, 'No, he loves another woman, it must be so': 9, '"\n\nAnd perceiving that, while trying to regain her peace of mind, she had\ngone round the same circle that she had been round so often before, and\nhad come back to her former state of exasperation, she was horrified at\nherself': 42, '"Can it be impossible': 4, 'Can it be beyond me to control myself': 8, '"\nshe said to herself, and began again from the beginning': 11, '"He\'s\ntruthful, he\'s honest, he loves me': 7, 'I love him, and in a few days the\ndivorce will come': 12, 'What more do I want': 5, 'I want peace of mind and trust,\nand I will take the blame on myself': 15, 'Yes, now when he comes in, I will\ntell him I was wrong, though I was not wrong, and we will go away\ntomorrow': 24, '"\n\nAnd to escape thinking any more, and being overcome by irritability,\nshe rang, and ordered the boxes to be brought up for packing their\nthings for the country': 29, "At ten o'clock Vronsky came in": 6, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 24 PART SEVEN', {'"Well, was it nice': 4, '" she asked, coming out to meet him with a penitent\nand meek expression': 14, '"Just as usual," he answered, seeing at a glance that she was ('TOL CHAPTER 26 PART SEVEN', {'Never before had a day been passed in quarrel': 9, 'Today was the first\ntime': 5, 'And this was not a quarrel': 6, 'It was the open acknowledgment of\ncomplete 44, 'So then everything was over': 5, 'And death rose clearly and vividly before her mind as the sole means of\nbringing back love for her in his heart, of punishing him and of\ngaining the victory in that strife which the evil spirit in possession\nof her heart was waging with him': 46, 'Now nothing mattered: going or not going to Vozdvizhenskoe, getting or\nnot getting a divorce from her husband—all that did not matter': 22, 'The one\nthing that mattered was punishing him': 8, 'When she poured herself out her\nusual dose of opium, and thought that she had only to drink off the\nwhole open eyes, by\nthe light of a single burned-down candle, gazing at the carved cornice\nof the ceiling and at the shadow of the screen that covered part of it,\nwhile she vividly pictured to herself without saying anything to her': 13, 'But now she is no more': 6, 'She has\ngone away from us forever': 7, 'She is': 2, '" Suddenly the shadow of the\nscreen wavered, pounced on the whole cornice, the whole ceiling; other\nshadows from the other side swooped to meet it, for an instant the\nshadows flitted back, but then with fresh swiftness they darted\nforward, wavered, commingled, and all was darkness': 47, '"Death': 1, '" she\nthought': 3, 'And such horror came upon her that for a long while she could\nnot realize where she was, and for a long while her trembling hands\ncould not find the matches and light another candle, instead of the one\nthat had burned down and gone out': 46, '"No, anything—only to live': 4, 'Why, I\nlove him': 4, 'Why, he loves me': 4, 'This has been before and will pass," she\nsaid, feeling that tears of joy at the return to life were trickling\ndown her cheeks': 24, 'And to escape from her panic she went hurriedly to his\nroom': 12, 'He was asleep there, and sleeping soundly': 7, 'She went up to him, and\nholding the light above his face, she gazed a long while at him': 19, 'Now\nwhen he was asleep, she loved him so that at the sight of him she could\nnot keep back tears of tenderness': 23, 'But she knew that if he waked up he\nwould look at her with cold eyes, convinced that he was right, and that\nbefore telling him of her love, she would have to prove to him that he\nhad been wrong in his treatment of her': 46, 'Without waking him, she went\nback, and after a second dose of opium she fell towards morning into a\nheavy, incomplete sleep, during which she never quite lost\nconsciousness': 29, 'In the morning she was waked by a horrible nightmare, which had\nrecurred several times in her dreams, even before her connection with\nVronsky': 24, 'A little old man with unkempt beard was doing something bent\ndown over some iron, muttering meaningless French words, and she, as\nshe always did in this nightmare (it was what made the horror of it),\nfelt that this peasant was taking no notice of her, but was doing\nsomething horrible with the iron—over her': 55, 'And she waked up in a cold\nsweat': 8, 'When she got up, ('TOL CHAPTER 30 PART SEVEN', {'"Here it is again': 4, 'Again I understand it all': 5, '" Anna said to herself, as\nsoon as the carriage had started and swaying lightly, rumbled over the\ntiny cobbles behavior to me': 17, 'He let that out yesterday—he wants divorce and\nmarriage so as to burn his ships': 15, 'He loves me, but how': 5, 'The zest is\ngone, as the English say': 8, 'That fellow wants everyone to admire him and\nis very much pleased with himself," she thought, looking at a red-faced\nclerk, riding on a riding-school horse': 26, '"Yes, there\'s not the same\nflavor about me for him now': 11, 'If I go away from him, at the bottom of\nhis heart he will be glad': 16, '"\n\nThis was not mere supposition, she saw it distinctly in the piercing\nlight, which revealed to her now the meaning of life and human\nrelations': 26, '"My love keeps growing more passionate and egoistic, while his is\nwaning and waning, and that\'s why we\'re drifting apart': 20, '" She went on\nmusing': 5, '"And there\'s no help for it': 6, 'He is everything for me, and I\nwant him more and more to give himself up to me entirely': 19, 'And he wants\nmore and more to get away from me': 11, 'We walked hating each other': 11, 'Come, let me try and think what I want,\nto make me happy': 13, 'Well': 1, 'Suppose I am divorced, and Alexey\nAlexandrovitch lets me have Seryozha, and I marry Vronsky': 15, hands, his intonations and the\ncracking of his fingers, and remembering the feeling which had existed\nbetween them, and which was also called love, she shuddered with\nloathing': 60, '"Well, I\'m come unscrewed': 10, 'Oh, a beggar woman with a baby': 7, "She thinks I'm\nsorry for her": 6, "Aren't we all flung into the world only to hate each\nother, and so to torture ourselves and each other": for another love, and did not regret the\nexchange till that love was satisfied': 24, '" And with loathing she thought\nof what she meant by that love': 13, "And the clearness with which she saw\nlife now, her own and all men's, was a pleasure to her": 19, '"It\'s so with\nme and Pyotr, and the coachman, Fyodor, and that merchant, and all the\npeople living along the Volga, where those placards ('TOL CHAPTER 31 PART SEVEN', {'A bell rang, some young men, ugly and impudent, and at the same time\ncareful of the impression they were making, hurried by': 23, 'Pyotr, too,\ncrossed the room in his livery and top-boots, with his dull, animal\nface, and came up to her to take her to the train': 26, 'Some noisy men were\nquiet as she passed them on the platform, and one whispered something\nabout her to another—something vile, no doubt': 23, 'She stepped up on the\nhigh step, and sat down in a carriage by herself on a dirty seat that\nhad been white': 23, 'Her bag lay beside her, shaken up and down by the\nspringiness of the seat': 15, 'With a foolish smile Pyotr raised his hat,\nwith its colored band, at the window, in token of farewell; an impudent\nconductor slammed the door and the latch': 28, 'A grotesque-looking lady\nwearing a bustle (Anna mentally undressed the woman, and was appalled\nat her hideousness), and a little girl laughing affectedly ran down the\nplatform': 27, '"Katerina Andreevna, she\'s got them all, _ma tante': 8, '_" cried the girl': 4, '"Even the child\'s hideous and affected," thought Anna': 8, 'To avoid seeing\nanyone, she got up quickly and seated herself at the opposite window of\nthe empty carriage': 19, 'A misshapen-looking peasant covered with dirt, in a\ncap from which his tangled hair stuck out all round, passed by that\nwindow, stooping down to the carriage wheels': 28, '"There\'s something\nfamiliar about that hideous peasant," thought Anna': 9, 'And remembering her\ndream, she moved away to the opposite door, shaking with terror': 14, 'The\nconductor opened the door and let in a man and his wife': 13, '"Do you wish to get out': 6, '"\n\nAnna made no answer': 5, 'The conductor and her two fellow-passengers did\nnot notice under her veil her panic-stricken face': 15, 'She went back to her\ncorner and sat down': 9, 'The couple seated themselves on the opposite side,\nand intently but surreptitiously scrutinized her clothes': 15, 'Both husband\nand wife seemed repulsive to Anna': 8, 'The husband asked, would she allow\nhim to smoke, obviously not with a view to smoking but to getting into\nconversation with her': 23, 'Receiving her assent, he said to his wife in\nFrench something about caring less to smoke than to talk': 19, 'They made\ninane and affected remarks to one another, entirely for her benefit': 13, 'Anna saw clearly that they were sick of each other, and hated each\nother': 14, 'And no one could have helped hating such miserable\nmonstrosities': 10, 'A second bell sounded, and was followed by moving of luggage, noise,\nshouting and laughter': 15, 'It was so clear to Anna that there was nothing\nfor anyone to be glad of, that this laughter irritated her agonizingly,\nand she would have liked to stop up her ears not to hear it': 36, 'At last\nthe third bell rang, there was a whistle and a hiss of steam, and a\nclank of chains, and the man in her carriage crossed himself': 28, '"It would\nbe interesting to ask him what meaning he attaches to that," thought\nAnna, looking angrily at him': 19, 'She looked past the lady out of the\nwindow at the people who seemed whirling by as they ran beside the\ntrain or stood on the platform': 27, 'The train, jerking at regular intervals\nat the junctions of the rails, rolled by the platform, past a stone\nwall, a signal-box, past other trains; the wheels, moving more smoothly\nand evenly, resounded with a slight clang on the rails': 40, 'The window was\nlighted up by the bright evening sun, and a slight breeze fluttered the\ncurtain': 17, 'Anna forgot her fellow passengers, and to the light swaying of\nthe train she fell to thinking again, as she breathed the fresh air': 24, '"Yes, what did I stop at': 6, "That I couldn't conceive a position in which\nlife would not be a misery, that we are all created to be miserable,\nand that we all know it, and all invent means of deceiving each other": 36, 'And when one sees the truth, what is one to do': 11, '"\n\n"That\'s what reason is given man for, to escape from what worries him,"\nsaid the lady in French, lisping affectedly, and obviously pleased with\nher phrase': 27, "The words seemed an answer to Anna's thoughts": 8, '"To escape from what worries him," repeated Anna': 8, 'And glancing at the\nred-cheeked husband and the thin wife, she saw that the sickly wife\nconsidered herself misunderstood, and the husband deceived her and\nencouraged her in that idea of herself': 32, 'Anna seemed to see all their\nhistory and all the crannies of their souls, as it were turning a light\nupon them': 22, 'But there was nothing interesting in them, and she pursued\nher thought': 12, '"Yes, I\'m very much worried, and that\'s what reason was given me for,\nto escape; so then one must escape: why not put out the light when\nthere\'s nothing more to look at, when it\'s sickening to look at it all': 41, 'But how': 2, 'Why did the conductor run along the footboard, why are they\nshrieking, those young men in that train': 18, 'why are they talking, why are\nthey laughing': 8, "It's all falsehood, all lying, all humbug, all\ncruelty": 9, '"\n\nWhen the train came into the station, Anna got out into the crowd of\npassengers, and moving apart from them as if they were lepers, she\nstood on the platform, trying to think what she had come here for, and\nwhat she meant to do': 46, 'Everything that had seemed to her possible before\nwas now so difficult to consider, especially in this noisy crowd of\nhideous people who would not leave her alone': 28, 'One moment porters ran up\nto her proffering their services, then young men, clacking their heels\non the planks of the platform and talking loudly, stared at her; people\nmeeting her dodged past on the wrong side': 37, 'Remembering that she had\nmeant to go on further if there were no answer, she stopped a porter\nand asked if her coachman were not here with a note from Count Vronsky': 32, broke it open, and her heart ached before she had read it': 13, '"I am very sorry your note did not reach me': 10, 'I will be home at ten,"\nVronsky had written carelessly': 10, '"Yes, that\'s what I expected': 5, '" she said to herself with an evil smile': 9, '"Very good, you can go home then," she said softly, addressing Mihail': 12, "She spoke softly because the rapidity of her heart's beating hindered\nher breathing": 13, '"No, I won\'t let you make me miserable," she thought\nmenacingly, addressing not him, not herself, but the power that made\nher suffer, and she walked along the
