tried to fling herself below the wheels of the first carriage as it\nreached her; but the red bag which she tried to drop out of her hand\ndelayed her, and she was too late; she missed the moment': 41, 'She had to\nwait for the next carriage': 8, 'A feeling such as she had known when about\nto take the first plunge in bathing came upon her, and she crossed\nherself': 23, 'That familiar gesture brought back into her soul a whole\nseries of girlish and childish memories, and suddenly the darkness that\nhad covered everything for her was torn apart, and life rose up before\nher for an instant with all its bright past joys': 44, 'But she did not take\nher eyes from the wheels of the second carriage': 14, 'And exactly at the\nmoment when the space between the wheels came opposite her, she dropped\nthe red bag, and drawing her head back into her shoulders, fell on her\nhands under the carriage, and lightly, as though she would rise again\nat once, dropped on to her knees': 49, 'And at the same instant she was\nterror-stricken at what she was doing': 13, '"Where am I': 3, 'What am I doing': 4, 'What for': 2, '" She tried to get up, to drop backwards; but something huge\nand merciless struck her on the head and rolled her on her back': 25, '"Lord,\nforgive me all': 4, '" she said, feeling it impossible to struggle': 8, 'A peasant\nmuttering something was working at the iron above her': 11, 'And the light by\nwhich she had read the book filled with troubles, falsehoods, sorrow,\nand evil, flared up more brightly than ever before, lighted up for her\nall that had been in darkness, flickered, began to grow dim, and was\nquenched forever': 43, 'PART EIGHT': 2})
('TOL CHAPTER 1 PART EIGHT', {'Almost two months had passed': 5, 'The hot summer was half over, but Sergey\nIvanovitch was only just preparing to leave Moscow': 16, "Sergey Ivanovitch's life had not been uneventful during this time": 10, 'A\nyear ago he had finished his book, the fruit of six years\' labor,\n"Sketch of a Survey of the Principles and Forms of Government in Europe\nand Russia': 29, '" Several sections of this book and its introduction had\nappeared in periodical publications, and other parts had been read by\nSergey Ivanovitch to persons of his circle, so that the leading ideas\nof the work could not be completely novel to the public': 44, 'But still\nSergey Ivanovitch had expected that on its appearance his book would be\nsure to make a serious impression on society, and if it did not cause a\nrevolution in social science it would, at any rate, make a great stir\nin the scientific world': 46, 'After the most conscientious revision the book had last year been\npublished, and had been distributed among the booksellers': 19, "Though he asked no one about it, reluctantly and with feigned\nindifference answered his friends' inquiries as to how the book was\ngoing, and did not even inquire of the booksellers how the book was\nselling, Sergey Ivanovitch was all on the alert, with strained\nattention, watching for the first impression his book would make in the\nworld and in literature": 61, 'But a week passed, a second, a third, and in society no impression\nwhatever could be detected': 17, 'His friends who were specialists and\nsavants, occasionally—unmistakably from politeness—alluded to it': 12, 'The\nrest of his acquaintances, not interested in a book on a learned\nsubject, did not talk of it at all': 21, 'And society generally—just now\nespecially absorbed in other things—was absolutely indifferent': 11, 'In the\npress, too, for a whole month there was not a word about his book': 16, 'Sergey Ivanovitch had calculated to a nicety the time necessary for\nwriting a review, but a month passed, and a second, and still there was\nsilence': 26, "Only in the _Northern Beetle_, in a comic article on the singer\nDrabanti, who had lost his voice, there was a contemptuous allusion to\nKoznishev's book, suggesting that the book had been long ago seen\nthrough by everyone, and was a subject of general ridicule": 45, 'At last in the third month a critical article appeared in a serious\nreview': 14, 'Sergey Ivanovitch knew the author of the article': 8, "He had met\nhim once at Golubtsov's": 7, 'The author of the article was a young man, an invalid, very bold as a\nwriter, but extremely deficient in breeding and shy in personal\nrelations': 26, 'In spite of his absolute contempt for the author, it was with complete\nrespect that Sergey Ivanovitch set about reading the article': 22, 'The\narticle was awful': 4, 'The critic had undoubtedly put an interpretation upon the book which\ncould not possibly be put on it': 18, 'But he had selected quotations so\nadroitly that for people who had not read the book (and obviously\nscarcely anyone had read it) it seemed absolutely clear that the whole\nbook was nothing but a medley of high-flown phrases, not even—as\nsuggested by marks of interrogation—used appropriately, and that the\nauthor of the book was a person absolutely without knowledge of the\nsubject': 63, 'And all this was so wittily done that Sergey Ivanovitch would\nnot have disowned such wit himself': 17, 'But that was just what was so\nawful': 8, "In spite of the scrupulous conscientiousness with which Sergey\nIvanovitch verified the correctness of the critic's arguments, he did\nnot for a minute stop to ponder over the faults and mistakes which were\nridiculed; but unconsciously he began immediately trying to recall\nevery detail of his meeting and conversation with the author of the\narticle": 55, '"Didn\'t I offend him in some way': 7, '" Sergey Ivanovitch wondered': 4, 'And remembering that when they met he had corrected the young man about\nsomething he had said that betrayed ignorance, Sergey Ivanovitch found\nthe clue to explain the article': 29, "This article was followed by a deadly silence about the book both in\nthe press and in conversation, and Sergey Ivanovitch saw that his six\nyears' task, toiled at with such love and labor, had gone, leaving no\ntrace": 39, "Sergey Ivanovitch's position was still more difficult from the fact\nthat, since he had finished his book, he had had no more literary work\nto do, such as had hitherto occupied the greater part of his time": 37, 'Sergey Ivanovitch was clever, cultivated, healthy, and energetic, and\nhe did not know what use to make of his energy': 20, 'Conversations in\ndrawing-rooms, in meetings, assemblies, and committees—everywhere where\ntalk was possible—took up part of his time': 17, 'But being used for years to\ntown life, he did not waste all his energies in talk, as his less\nexperienced younger brother did, when he was in Moscow': 29, 'He had a great\ndeal of leisure and intellectual energy still to dispose of': 14, 'Fortunately for him, at this period so difficult for him from the\nfailure of his book, the various public questions of the dissenting\nsects, of the American alliance, of the Samara famine, of exhibitions,\nand of spiritualism, were definitely replaced in public interest by the\nSlavonic question, which had hitherto rather languidly interested\nsociety, and Sergey Ivanovitch, who had been one of the first to raise\nthis subject, threw himself into it heart and soul': 75, 'In the circle to which Sergey Ivanovitch belonged, nothing was talked\nof or written about just now but the Servian War': 21, 'Everything that the\nidle crowd usually does to kill time was done now for the benefit of\nthe Slavonic States': 20, "Balls, concerts, dinners, matchboxes, ladies'\ndresses, beer, restaurants—everything testified to sympathy with the\nSlavonic peoples": 15, 'From much of what was spoken and written on the subject, Sergey\nIvanovitch differed on various points': 17, 'He saw that the Slavonic\nquestion had become one of those fashionable distractions which succeed\none another in providing society with an object and an occupation': 26, 'He\nsaw, too, that a great many people were taking up the subject from\nmotives of self-interest and self-advertisement': 19, 'He recognized that the\nnewspapers published a great deal that was superfluous and exaggerated,\nwith the sole aim of attracting attention and outbidding one another': 25, 'He saw that in this general movement those who thrust themselves most\nforward and shouted the loudest were men who had failed and were\nsmarting under a sense of injury—generals without armies, ministers not\nin the ministry, journalists not on any paper, party leaders without\nfollowers': 46, 'He saw that there was a great deal in it that was frivolous\nand absurd': 15, 'But he saw and recognized an unmistakable growing\nenthusiasm, uniting all classes, with which it was impossible not to\nsympathize': 20, 'The massacre of men who were fellow Christians, and of the\nsame Slavonic race, excited sympathy for the sufferers and indignation\nagainst the oppressors': 24, 'And the heroism of the Servians and\nMontenegrins struggling for a great cause begot in the whole people a\nlonging to help their brothers not in word but in deed': 30, 'But in this there was another aspect that rejoiced Sergey Ivanovitch': 11, 'That was the manifestation of public opinion': 7, 'The public had definitely\nexpressed its desire': 7, 'The soul of the people had, as Sergey Ivanovitch\nsaid, found expression': 12, 'And the more he worked in this cause, the more\nincontestable it seemed to him that it was a cause destined to assume\nvast dimensions, to create an epoch': 29, 'He threw himself heart and soul into the service of this great cause,\nand forgot to think about his book': 20, 'His whole time now was engrossed by\nit, so that he could scarcely manage to answer all the letters and\nappeals addressed to him': 24, "He worked the whole spring and part of the\nsummer, and it was only in July that he prepared to go away to his\nbrother's in the country": 28, 'He was going both to rest for a fortnight, and in the very heart of the\npeople, in the farthest wilds of the country, to enjoy the sight of\nthat uplifting of the spirit of the people, of which, like all\nresidents in the capital and big towns, he was fully persuaded': 52, 'Katavasov had long been meaning to carry out his promise to stay with\nLevin, and so he was going with him': 21, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 2 PART EIGHT', {'Sergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov had only just reached the station of\nthe Kursk line, which was particularly busy and full of people that\nday, when, looking round for the groom who was following with their\nthings, they saw a party of volunteers driving up in four cabs': 47, 'Ladies\nmet them with bouquets of flowers, and followed by the rushing crowd\nthey went into the station': 18, 'One of the ladies, who had met the volunteers, came out of the hall and\naddressed Sergey Ivanovitch': 18, '"You too come to see them off': 7, '" she asked in French': 5, '"No, I\'m going away myself, princess': 6, "To my brother's for a holiday": 6, 'Do\nyou always see them off': 6, '" said Sergey Ivanovitch with a hardly\nperceptible smile': 9, '"Oh, that would be impossible': 5, '" answered the princess': 4, '"Is it true that\neight hundred have been sent from us already': 12, "Malvinsky wouldn't\nbelieve me": 4, '"\n\n"More than eight hundred': 5, 'If you reckon those who have been sent not\ndirectly from Moscow, over a thousand," answered Sergey Ivanovitch': 18, '"There': 1, "That's just what I said": 5, '" exclaimed the lady': 4, '"And it\'s true\ntoo, I suppose, that more than a million has been subscribed': 14, '"\n\n"Yes, princess': 3, '"\n\n"What do you say to today\'s telegram': 8, 'Beaten the Turks again': 4, '"\n\n"Yes, so I saw," answered Sergey Ivanovitch': 8, 'They were speaking of the\nlast telegram stating that the Turks had been for three days in\nsuccession beaten at all points and put to flight, and that tomorrow a\ndecisive engagement was expected': 34, '"Ah, by the way, a splendid young fellow has asked leave to go, and\nthey\'ve made some difficulty, I don\'t know why': 22, 'I meant to ask you; I\nknow him; please write a note about his case': 15, "He's being sent by\nCountess Lidia Ivanovna": 7, '"\n\nSergey Ivanovitch asked for all the details the princess knew about the\nyoung man, and going into the first-class waiting-room, wrote a note to\nthe person on whom the granting of leave of absence depended, and\nhanded it to the princess': 42, '"You know Count Vronsky, the notorious one': 7, 'is going by this train': 5, '"\nsaid the princess with a smile full of triumph and meaning, when he\nfound her again and gave her the letter': 22, '"I had heard he was going, but I did not know when': 12, 'By this train': 3, '"\n\n"I\'ve seen him': 4, "He's here: there's only his mother seeing him off": 9, "It's\nthe best thing, anyway, that he could do": 9, '"\n\n"Oh, yes, of course': 5, '"\n\nWhile they were talking the crowd streamed by them into the\ndining-room': 13, 'They went forward too, and heard a gentleman with a glass\nin his hand delivering a loud discourse to the volunteers': 21, '"In the\nservice of religion, humanity, and our brothers," the gentleman said,\nhis voice growing louder and louder; "to this great cause mother Moscow\ndedicates you with her blessing': 29, '_Jivio': 1, '_" he concluded, loudly and\ntearfully': 6, 'Everyone shouted _Jivio': 3, '_ and a fresh crowd dashed into the hall,\nalmost carrying the princess off her legs': 16, '"Ah, princess': 2, 'that was something like': 4, '" said Stepan Arkadyevitch,\nsuddenly appearing in the middle of the crowd and beaming upon them\nwith a delighted smile': 20, '"Capitally, warmly said, wasn\'t it': 5, 'Bravo': 1, 'And\nSergey Ivanovitch': 3, 'Why, you ought to have said something—just a few\nwords, you know, to encourage them; you do that so well," he added with\na soft, respectful, and discreet smile, moving Sergey Ivanovitch\nforward a little by the arm': 38, '"No, I\'m just off': 4, '"\n\n"Where to': 3, '"\n\n"To the country, to my brother\'s," answered Sergey Ivanovitch': 10, '"Then you\'ll see ('TOL CHAPTER 3 PART EIGHT', {'Saying good-bye to the princess, Sergey Ivanovitch was joined by\nKatavasov; together they got into a carriage full to overflowing, and\nthe train started': 24, 'At Tsaritsino station the train was met by a chorus of young men\nsinging "Hail to Thee': 17, '" Again the volunteers bowed and poked their\nheads out, but Sergey Ivanovitch paid no attention to them': 18, 'He had had\nso much to do with the volunteers that the type was familiar to him and\ndid not interest him': 22, 'Katavasov, whose scientific work had prevented\nhis having a chance of observing them hitherto, was very much\ninterested in them and questioned Sergey Ivanovitch': 24, 'Sergey Ivanovitch advised him to go into the second-class and talk to\nthem himself': 14, 'At the next station Katavasov acted on this suggestion': 9, 'At the first stop he moved into the second-class and made the\nacquaintance of the volunteers': 16, 'They were sitting in a corner of the\ncarriage, talking loudly and obviously aware that the attention of the\npassengers and Katavasov as he got in was concentrated upon them': 30, 'More\nloudly than all talked the tall, hollow-chested young man': 10, 'He was\nunmistakably tipsy, and was relating some story that had occurred at\nhis school': 15, 'Facing him sat a middle-aged officer in the Austrian\nmilitary jacket of the Guards uniform': 15, 'He was listening with a smile to\nthe hollow-chested youth, and occasionally pulling him up': 15, 'The third,\nin an artillery uniform, was sitting on a box beside them': 13, 'A fourth was\nasleep': 4, 'Entering into conversation with the youth, Katavasov learned that he\nwas a wealthy Moscow merchant who had run through a large fortune\nbefore he was two-and-twenty': 26, 'Katavasov did not like him, because he\nwas unmanly and effeminate and sickly': 13, 'He was obviously convinced,\nespecially now after drinking, that he was performing a heroic action,\nand he bragged of it in the most unpleasant way': 25, 'The second, the retired officer, made an unpleasant impression too upon\nKatavasov': 12, 'He was, it seemed, a man who had tried everything': 10, 'He had\nbeen on a railway, had been a land-steward, and had started factories,\nand he talked, quite without necessity, of all he had done, and used\nlearned expressions quite inappropriately': 31, 'The third, the artilleryman, on the contrary, struck Katavasov very\nfavorably': 11, 'He was a quiet, modest fellow, unmistakably impressed by the\nknowledge of the officer and the heroic self-sacrifice of the merchant\nand saying nothing about himself': 26, 'When Katavasov asked him what had\nimpelled him to go to Servia, he answered modestly:\n\n"Oh, well, everyone\'s going': 19, 'The Servians want help, too': 5, "I'm sorry for\nthem": 4, '"\n\n"Yes, you artillerymen especially are scarce there," said Katavasov': 10, '"Oh, I wasn\'t long in the artillery, maybe they\'ll put me into the\ninfantry or the cavalry': 17, '"\n\n"Into the infantry when they need artillery more than anything': 11, '" said\nKatavasov, fancying from the artilleryman\'s apparent age that he must\nhave reached a fairly high grade': 18, '"I wasn\'t long in the artillery; I\'m a cadet retired," he said, and he\nbegan to explain how he had failed in his examination': 24, 'All of this together made a disagreeable impression on Katavasov, and\nwhen the volunteers got out at a station for a drink, Katavasov would\nhave liked to compare his unfavorable impression in conversation with\nsomeone': 35, "There was an old man in the carriage, wearing a military\novercoat, who had been listening all the while to Katavasov's\nconversation with the volunteers": 25, 'When they were left alone, Katavasov\naddressed him': 8, '"What different positions they come from, all those fellows who are\ngoing off there," Katavasov said vaguely, not wishing to express his\nown opinion, and at the same time anxious to find out the old man\'s\nviews': 37, 'The old man was an officer who had served on two campaigns': 12, 'He knew\nwhat makes a soldier, and judging by the appearance and the talk of\nthose persons, by the swagger with which they had recourse to the\nbottle on the journey, he considered them poor soldiers': 36, 'Moreover, he\nlived in a district town, and he was longing to tell how one soldier\nhad volunteered from his town, a drunkard and a thief whom no one would\nemploy as a laborer': 34, 'But knowing by experience that in the present\ncondition of the public temper it was dangerous to express an opinion\nopposed to the general one, and especially to criticize the volunteers\nunfavorably, he too watched Katavasov without committing himself': 39, '"Well, men are wanted there," he said, laughing with his eyes': 11, 'And they\nfell to talking of the last war news, and each concealed from the other\nhis perplexity as to the engagement expected next day, since the Turks\nhad been beaten, according to the latest news, at all points': 39, 'And so\nthey parted, neither giving expression to his opinion': 10, 'Katavasov went back to his own carriage, and with reluctant hypocrisy\nreported to Sergey Ivanovitch his observations of the volunteers, from\nwhich it would appear that they were capital fellows': 30, 'At a big station at a town the volunteers were again greeted with\nshouts and singing, again men and women with collecting boxes appeared,\nand provincial ladies brought bouquets to the volunteers and followed\nthem into the refreshment room; but all this was on a much smaller and\nfeebler scale than in Moscow': 53, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 4 PART EIGHT', {'While the train was stopping at the provincial town, Sergey Ivanovitch\ndid not go to the refreshment room, but walked up and down the\nplatform': 25, "The first time he ('TOL CHAPTER 5 PART EIGHT', {'In the slanting evening shadows cast by the baggage piled up on the\nplatform, Vronsky in his long overcoat and slouch hat, with his hands\nin his pockets, strode up and down, like a wild beast in a cage,\nturning sharply after twenty paces': 44, 'Sergey Ivanovitch fancied, as he\napproached him, that Vronsky saw him but was pretending not to see': 17, 'This did not affect Sergey Ivanovitch in the slightest': 9, 'He was above\nall personal considerations with Vronsky': 8, 'At that moment Sergey Ivanovitch looked upon Vronsky as a man taking an\nimportant part in a great cause, and Koznishev thought it his duty to\nencourage him and express his approval': 32, 'He went up to him': 5, 'Vronsky stood still, looked intently at him, recognized him, and going\na few steps forward to meet him, shook hands with him very warmly': 24, '"Possibly you didn\'t wish to see me," said Sergey Ivanovitch, "but\ncouldn\'t I be of use to you': 18, '"\n\n"There\'s no one I should less dislike seeing than you," said Vronsky': 13, '"Excuse me; and there\'s nothing in life for me to like': 11, '"\n\n"I quite understand, and I merely meant to offer you my services," said\nSergey Ivanovitch, scanning Vronsky\'s face, full of unmistakable\nsuffering': 23, '"Wouldn\'t it be of use to you to have a letter to\nRistitch—to Milan': 14, '"\n\n"Oh, no': 3, '" Vronsky said, seeming to understand him with difficulty': 9, '"If\nyou don\'t mind, let\'s walk on': 7, "It's so stuffy among the carriages": 6, 'A\nletter': 2, 'No, thank you; to meet death one needs no letters of\nintroduction': 12, 'Nor for the Turks': 4, '" he said, with a smile that was\nmerely of the lips': 12, 'His eyes still kept their look of angry suffering': 9, '"Yes; but you might find it easier to get into relations, which are\nafter all essential, with anyone prepared to see you': 22, "But that's as you\nlike": 5, 'I was very glad to hear of your intention': 9, 'There have been so\nmany attacks made on the volunteers, and a man like you raises them in\npublic estimation': 20, '"\n\n"My use as a man," said Vronsky, "is that life\'s worth nothing to me': 15, "And that I've enough bodily energy to cut my way into their ranks, and\nto trample on them or fall—I know that": 22, "I'm glad there's something to\ngive my life for, for it's not simply useless but loathsome to me": 18, "Anyone's welcome to it": 4, '" And his jaw twitched impatiently from the\nincessant gnawing toothache, that prevented him from even speaking with\na natural expression': 21, '"You will become another man, I predict," said Sergey Ivanovitch,\nfeeling touched': 12, '"To deliver one\'s brother-men from bondage is an aim\nworth death and life': 13, 'God grant you success outwardly—and inwardly\npeace," he added, and he held out his hand': 15, 'Vronsky warmly pressed his\noutstretched hand': 6, '"Yes, as a weapon I may be of some use': 10, 'But as a man, I\'m a wreck," he\njerked out': 10, 'He could hardly speak for the throbbing ache in his strong teeth, that\nwere like rows of ivory in his mouth': 21, 'He was silent, and his eyes\nrested on the wheels of the tender, slowly and smoothly rolling along\nthe rails': 20, 'And all at once a different pain, not an ache, but an inner trouble,\nthat set his whole being in anguish, made him for an instant forget his\ntoothache': 29, 'As he glanced at the tender and the rails, under the\ninfluence of the conversation with a friend he had not met since his\nmisfortune, he suddenly recalled _her_—that is, what was left of her\nwhen he had run like one distraught into the cloak room of the railway\nstation—on the table, shamelessly sprawling out among strangers, the\nbloodstained body so lately full of life; the head unhurt dropping back\nwith its weight of hair, and the curling tresses about the temples, and\nthe exquisite face, with red, half-opened mouth, the strange, fixed\nexpression, piteous on the lips and awful in the still open eyes, that\nseemed to utter that fearful phrase—that he would be sorry for it—that\nshe had said when they were quarreling': 125, 'And he tried to think of her as she was when he met her the first time,\nat a railway station too, mysterious, exquisite, loving, seeking and\ngiving happiness, and not cruelly revengeful as he remembered her on\nthat last moment': 41, 'He tried to recall his best moments with her, but\nthose moments were poisoned forever': 15, 'He could only think of her as\ntriumphant, successful in her menace of a wholly useless remorse never\nto be effaced': 21, 'He lost all consciousness of toothache, and his face\nworked with sobs': 12, 'Passing twice up and down beside the baggage in silence and regaining\nhis self-possession, he addressed Sergey Ivanovitch calmly:\n\n"You have had no telegrams since yesterday\'s': 26, 'Yes, driven back for a\nthird time, but a decisive engagement expected for tomorrow': 14, '"\n\nAnd after talking a little more of King Milan\'s proclamation, and the\nimmense effect it might have, they parted, going to their carriages on\nhearing the second bell': 29, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 6 PART EIGHT', {'Sergey Ivanovitch had not telegraphed to his brother to send to meet\nhim, as he did not know when he should be able to leave Moscow': 26, 'Levin\nwas not at home when ('TOL CHAPTER 7 PART EIGHT', {'Agafea Mihalovna went out on tiptoe; the nurse let down the blind,\nchased a fly out from under the muslin canopy of the crib, and a\nbumblebee struggling on the window-frame, and sat down waving a faded\nbranch of birch over the mother and the baby': 46, '"How hot it is': 4, 'if God would send a drop of rain," she said': 10, '"Yes, yes, sh—sh—sh——" was all Kitty answered, rocking a little, and\ntenderly squeezing the plump little arm, with rolls of fat at the\nwrist, which Mitya still waved feebly as he opened and shut his eyes': 36, 'That hand worried Kitty; she longed to kiss the little hand, but was\nafraid to for fear of waking the baby': 21, 'At last the little hand ceased\nwaving, and the eyes closed': 11, 'Only from time to time, as he went on\nsucking, the baby raised his long, curly eyelashes and peeped at his\nmother with wet eyes, that looked black in the twilight': 31, 'The nurse had\nleft off fanning, and was dozing': 9, "From above came the peals of the old\nprince's voice, and the chuckle of Katavasov": 15, '"They have got into talk without me," thought Kitty, "but still it\'s\nvexing that Kostya\'s out': 16, "He's sure to have gone to the bee-house\nagain": 9, "Though it's a pity he's there so often, still I'm glad": 11, 'It\ndistracts his mind': 4, "He's become altogether happier and better now than\nin the spring": 11, 'He used to be so gloomy and worried that I felt\nfrightened for him': 14, 'And how absurd he is': 5, '" she whispered, smiling': 4, 'She knew what worried her husband': 6, 'It was his unbelief': 4, 'Although, if\nshe had been asked whether she supposed that in the future life, if he\ndid not believe, he would be damned, she would have had to admit that\nhe would be damned, his unbelief did not cause her unhappiness': 41, "And\nshe, confessing that for an unbeliever there can be no salvation, and\nloving her husband's soul more than anything in the world, thought with\na smile of his unbelief, and told herself that he was absurd": 37, '"What does he keep reading philosophy of some sort for all this year': 13, '"\nshe wondered': 3, '"If it\'s all written in those books, he can understand\nthem': 11, "If it's all wrong, why does he read them": 9, 'He says himself that he\nwould like to believe': 9, "Then why is it he doesn't believe": 7, 'Surely from\nhis thinking so much': 6, 'And he thinks so much from being solitary': 8, "He's\nalways alone, alone": 4, "He can't talk about it all to us": 8, "I fancy he'll be\nglad of these visitors, especially Katavasov": 10, 'He likes discussions with\nthem," she thought, and passed instantly to the consideration of where\nit would be more convenient to put Katavasov, to sleep alone or to\nshare Sergey Ivanovitch\'s room': 32, 'And then an idea suddenly struck her,\nwhich made her shudder and even disturb Mitya, who glanced severely at\nher': 20, '"I do believe the laundress hasn\'t sent the washing yet, and all\nthe best sheets are in use': 18, 'If I don\'t see to it, Agafea Mihalovna will\ngive Sergey Ivanovitch the wrong sheets," and at the very idea of this\nthe blood rushed to Kitty\'s face': 28, '"Yes, I will arrange it," she decided, and going back to her former\nthoughts, she remembered that some spiritual question of importance had\nbeen interrupted, and she began to recall what': 31, '"Yes, Kostya, an\nunbeliever," she thought again with a smile': 10, '"Well, an unbeliever then': 4, 'Better let him always be one than like\nMadame Stahl, or what I tried to be in those days abroad': 20, "No, he won't\never sham anything": 6, '"\n\nAnd a recent instance of his goodness rose vividly to her mind': 13, 'A\nfortnight ago a penitent letter had come from Stepan Arkadyevitch to\nDolly': 13, 'He besought her to save his honor, to sell her estate to pay his\ndebts': 15, 'Dolly was in despair, she detested her husband, despised him,\npitied him, resolved on a separation, resolved to refuse, but ended by\nagreeing to sell part of her property': 29, "After that, with an\nirrepressible smile of tenderness, Kitty recalled her husband's\nshamefaced embarrassment, his repeated awkward efforts to approach the\nsubject, and how at last, having thought of the one means of helping\nDolly without wounding her pride, he had suggested to Kitty—what had\nnot occurred to her before—that she should give up her share of the\nproperty": 59, '"He an unbeliever indeed': 4, 'With his heart, his dread of offending\nanyone, even a child': 11, 'Everything for others, nothing for himself': 6, "Sergey Ivanovitch simply considers it as Kostya's duty to be his\nsteward": 12, "And it's the same with his sister": 7, 'Now Dolly and her children\nare under his guardianship; all these peasants who come to him every\nday, as though he were bound to be at their service': 28, '"\n\n"Yes, only be like your father, only like him," she said, handing Mitya\nover to the nurse, and putting her lips to his cheek': 25, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 8 PART EIGHT', {"Ever since, by his beloved brother's deathbed, Levin had first glanced\ninto the questions of life and death in the light of these new\nconvictions, as he called them, which had during the period from his\ntwentieth to his thirty-fourth year imperceptibly replaced his childish\nand youthful beliefs—he had been stricken with horror, not so much of\ndeath, as of life, without any knowledge of whence, and why, and how,\nand what it was": 74, 'The physical organization, its decay, the\nindestructibility of matter, the law of the conservation of energy,\nevolution, were the words which usurped the place of his old belief': 28, 'These words and the ideas associated with them were very well for\nintellectual purposes': 14, 'But for life they yielded nothing, and Levin\nfelt suddenly like a man who has changed his warm fur cloak for a\nmuslin garment, and going for the first time into the frost is\nimmediately convinced, not by reason, but by his whole nature that he\nis as good as naked, and that he must infallibly perish miserably': 58, 'From that moment, though he did not distinctly face it, and still went\non living as before, Levin had never lost this sense of terror at his\nlack of knowledge': 30, 'He vaguely felt, too, that what he called his new convictions were not\nmerely lack of knowledge, but that they were part of a whole order of\nideas, in which no knowledge of what he needed was possible': 38, 'At first, marriage, with the new joys and duties bound up with it, had\ncompletely crowded out these thoughts': 19, "But of late, while he was\nstaying in Moscow after his wife's confinement, with nothing to do, the\nquestion that clamored for solution had more and more often, more and\nmore insistently, haunted Levin's mind": 35, 'The question was summed up for him thus: "If I do not accept the\nanswers Christianity gives to the problems of my life, what answers do\nI accept': 28, '" And in the whole arsenal of his convictions, so far from\nfinding any satisfactory answers, he was utterly unable to find\nanything at all like an answer': 28, 'He was in the position of a man seeking food in toy shops and tool\nshops': 16, 'Instinctively, unconsciously, with every book, with every conversation,\nwith every man he met, he was on the lookout for light on these\nquestions and their solution': 26, 'What puzzled and distracted him above everything was that the majority\nof men of his age and circle had, like him, exchanged their old beliefs\nfor the same new convictions, and yet saw nothing to lament in this,\nand were perfectly satisfied and serene': 44, 'So that, apart from the\nprincipal question, Levin was tortured by other questions too': 14, 'Were\nthese people sincere': 4, 'he asked himself, or were they playing a part': 9, 'or\nwas it that they understood the answers science gave to these problems\nin some different, clearer sense than he did': 21, "And he assiduously\nstudied both these men's opinions and the books which treated of these\nscientific explanations": 17, 'One fact he had found out since these questions had engrossed his mind,\nwas that he had been quite wrong in supposing from the recollections of\nthe circle of his young days at college, that religion had outlived its\nday, and that it was now practically non-existent': 47, 'All the people\nnearest to him who were good in their lives were believers': 14, 'The old\nprince, and Lvov, whom he liked so much, and Sergey Ivanovitch, and all\nthe women believed, and his wife believed as simply as he had believed\nin his earliest childhood, and ninety-nine hundredths of the Russian\npeople, all the working people for whose life he felt the deepest\nrespect, believed': 52, 'Another fact of which he became convinced, after reading many\nscientific books, was that the men who shared his views had no other\nconstruction to put on them, and that they gave no explanation of the\nquestions which he felt he could not live without answering, but simply\nignored their existence and attempted to explain other questions of no\npossible interest to him, such as the evolution of organisms, the\nmaterialistic theory of consciousness, and so forth': 77, "Moreover, during his wife's confinement, something had happened that\nseemed extraordinary to him": 13, 'He, an unbeliever, had fallen into\npraying, and at the moment he prayed, he believed': 15, 'But that moment had\npassed, and he could not make his state of mind at that moment fit into\nthe rest of his life': 24, 'He could not admit that at that moment he knew the truth, and that now\nhe was wrong; for as soon as he began thinking calmly about it, it all\nfell to pieces': 33, 'He could not admit that he was mistaken then, for his\nspiritual condition then was precious to him, and to admit that it was\na proof of weakness would have been to desecrate those moments': 35, 'He was\nmiserably divided against himself, and strained all his spiritual\nforces to the utmost to escape from this condition': 20, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 9 PART EIGHT', {'These doubts fretted and harassed him, growing weaker or stronger from\ntime to time, but never leaving him': 18, 'He read and thought, and the more\nhe read and the more he thought, the further he felt from the aim he\nwas pursuing': 24, 'Of late in Moscow and in the country, since he had become convinced\nthat he would find no solution in the materialists, he had read and\nre-read thoroughly Plato, Spinoza, Kant, Schelling, Hegel, and\nSchopenhauer, the philosophers who gave a non-materialistic explanation\nof life': 44, 'Their ideas seemed to him fruitful when he was reading or was himself\nseeking arguments to refute other theories, especially those of the\nmaterialists; but as soon as he began to read or sought for himself a\nsolution of problems, the same thing always happened': 45, 'As long as he\nfollowed the fixed definition of obscure words such as _spirit, will,\nfreedom, essence,_ purposely letting himself go into the snare of words\nthe philosophers set for him, he seemed to comprehend something': 36, 'But he\nhad only to forget the artificial train of reasoning, and to turn from\nlife itself to what had satisfied him while thinking in accordance with\nthe fixed definitions, and all this artificial edifice fell to pieces\nat once like a house of cards, and it became clear that the edifice had\nbeen built up out of those transposed words, apart from anything in\nlife more important than reason': 70, 'At one time, reading Schopenhauer, he put in place of his _will_ the\nword _love_, and for a couple of days this new philosophy charmed him,\ntill he removed a little away from it': 34, 'But then, when he turned from\nlife itself to glance at it again, it fell away too, and proved to be\nthe same muslin garment with no warmth in it': 30, 'His brother Sergey Ivanovitch advised him to read the theological works\nof Homiakov': 13, "Levin read the second volume of Homiakov's works, and in\nspite of the elegant, epigrammatic, argumentative style which at first\nrepelled him, he was impressed by the doctrine of the church he found\nin them": 35, 'He was struck at first by the idea that the apprehension of\ndivine truths had not been vouchsafed to man, but to a corporation of\nmen bound together by love—to the church': 32, 'What delighted him was the\nthought how much easier it was to believe in a still existing living\nchurch, embracing all the beliefs of men, and having God at its head,\nand therefore holy and infallible, and from it to accept the faith in\nGod, in the creation, the fall, the redemption, than to begin with God,\na mysterious, far-away God, the creation, etc': 64, "But afterwards, on\nreading a Catholic writer's history of the church, and then a Greek\northodox writer's history of the church, and seeing that the two\nchurches, in their very conception infallible, each deny the authority\nof the other, Homiakov's doctrine of the church lost all its charm for\nhim, and this edifice crumbled into dust like the philosophers'\nedifices": 60, 'All that spring he was not himself, and went through fearful moments of\nhorror': 14, '"Without knowing what I am and why I am here, life\'s impossible; and\nthat I can\'t know, and so I can\'t live," Levin said to himself': 26, '"In infinite time, in infinite matter, in infinite space, is formed a\nbubble-organism, and that bubble lasts a while and bursts, and that\nbubble is Me': 26, '"\n\nIt was an agonizing error, but it was the sole logical result of ages\nof human thought in that direction': 21, 'This was the ultimate belief on which all the systems elaborated by\nhuman thought in almost all their ramifications rested': 20, 'It was the\nprevalent conviction, and of all other explanations Levin had\nunconsciously, not knowing when or how, chosen it, as anyway the\nclearest, and made it his own': 29, 'But it was not merely a falsehood, it was the cruel jeer of some wicked\npower, some evil, hateful power, to whom one could not submit': 26, 'He must escape from this power': 6, 'And the means of escape every man had\nin his own hands': 12, 'He had but to cut short this dependence on evil': 10, 'And\nthere was one means—death': 5, 'And Levin, a happy father and husband, in perfect health, was several\ntimes so near suicide that he hid the cord that he might not be tempted\nto hang himself, and was afraid to go out with his gun for fear of\nshooting himself': 44, 'But Levin did not shoot himself, and did not hang himself; he went on\nliving': 15, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 10 PART EIGHT', {'When Levin thought what he was and what he was living for, he could\nfind no answer to the questions and was reduced to despair, but he left\noff questioning himself about it': 33, 'It seemed as though he knew both what\nhe was and for what he was living, for he acted and lived resolutely\nand without hesitation': 25, 'Indeed, in these latter days he was far more\ndecided and unhesitating in life than he had ever been': 19, 'When he went back to the country at the beginning of June, he went back\nalso to his usual pursuits': 20, "The management of the estate, his relations\nwith the peasants and the neighbors, the care of his household, the\nmanagement of his sister's and brother's property, of which he had the\ndirection, his relations with his wife and kindred, the care of his\nchild, and the new bee-keeping hobby he had taken up that spring,\nfilled all his time": 59, 'These things occupied him now, not because he justified them to himself\nby any sort of general principles, as he had done in former days; on\nthe contrary, disappointed by the failure of his former efforts for the\ngeneral welfare, and too much occupied with his own thought and the\nmass of business with which he was burdened from all sides, he had\ncompletely given up thinking of the general good, and he busied himself\nwith all this work simply because it seemed to him that he must do what\nhe was doing—that he could not do otherwise': 98, 'In former days—almost from\nchildhood, and increasingly up to full manhood—when he had tried to do\nanything that would be good for all, for humanity, for Russia, for the\nwhole village, he had noticed that the idea of it had been pleasant,\nbut the work itself had always been incoherent, that then he had never\nhad a full conviction of its absolute necessity, and that the work that\nhad begun by seeming so great, had grown less and less, till it\nvanished into nothing': 84, 'But now, since his marriage, when he had begun\nto confine himself more and more to living for himself, though he\nexperienced no delight at all at the thought of the work he was doing,\nhe felt a complete conviction of its necessity, saw that it succeeded\nfar better than in old days, and that it kept on growing more and more': 62, 'Now, involuntarily it seemed, he cut more and more deeply into the soil\nlike a plough, so that he could not be drawn out without turning aside\nthe furrow': 29, 'To live the same family life as his father and forefathers—that is, in\nthe same condition of culture—and to bring up his children in the same,\nwas incontestably necessary': 29, 'It was as necessary as dining when one was\nhungry': 10, 'And to do this, just as it was necessary to cook dinner, it was\nnecessary to keep the mechanism of agriculture at Pokrovskoe going so\nas to yield an income': 30, 'Just as incontestably as it was necessary to\nrepay a debt was it necessary to keep the property in such a condition\nthat his son, when he received it as a heritage, would say "thank you"\nto his father as Levin had said "thank you" to his grandfather for all\nhe built and planted': 54, 'And to do this it was necessary to look after the\nland himself, not to let it, and to breed cattle, manure the fields,\nand plant timber': 27, "It was impossible not to look after the affairs of Sergey Ivanovitch,\nof his sister, of the peasants who came to him for advice and were\naccustomed to do so—as impossible as to fling down a child one is\ncarrying in one's arms": 43, 'It was necessary to look after the comfort of\nhis sister-in-law and her children, and of his wife and baby, and it\nwas impossible not to spend with them at least a short time each day': 36, "And all this, together with shooting and his new bee-keeping, filled up\nthe whole of Levin's life, which had no meaning at all for him, when he\nbegan to think": 30, 'But besides knowing thoroughly what he had to do, Levin knew in just\nthe same way _how_ he had to do it all, and what was more important\nthan the rest': 31, 'He knew he must hire laborers as cheaply as possible; but to hire men\nunder bond, paying them in advance at less than the current rate of\nwages, was what he must not do, even though it was very profitable': 40, 'Selling straw to the peasants in times of scarcity of provender was\nwhat he might do, even though he felt sorry for them; but the tavern\nand the pothouse must be put down, though they were a source of income': 40, 'Felling timber must be punished as severely as possible, but he could\nnot exact forfeits for cattle being driven onto his fields; and though\nit annoyed the keeper and made the peasants not afraid to graze their\ncattle on his land, he could not keep their cattle as a punishment': 50, 'To Pyotr, who was paying a money-lender ten per cent': 10, 'a month, he must\nlend a sum of money to set him free': 13, 'But he could not let off peasants\nwho did not pay their rent, nor let them fall into arrears': 19, "It was\nimpossible to overlook the bailiff's not having mown the meadows and\nletting the hay spoil; and it was equally impossible to mow those acres\nwhere a young copse had been planted": 33, 'It was impossible to excuse a\nlaborer who had gone home in the busy season because his father was\ndying, however sorry he might feel for him, and he must subtract from\nhis pay those costly months of idleness': 39, 'But it was impossible not to\nallow monthly rations to the old servants who were of no use for\nanything': 20, 'Levin knew that when he got home he must first of all go to his wife,\nwho was unwell, and that the peasants who had been waiting for three\nhours to see him could wait a little longer': 38, 'He knew too that,\nregardless of all the pleasure he felt in taking a swarm, he must\nforego that pleasure, and leave the old man to see to the bees alone,\nwhile he talked to the peasants who had come after him to the\nbee-house': 45, 'Whether he were acting rightly or wrongly he did not know, and far from\ntrying to prove that he was, nowadays he avoided all thought or talk\nabout it': 29, 'Reasoning had brought him to doubt, and prevented him from seeing what\nhe ought to do and what he ought not': 21, 'When he did not think, but simply\nlived, he was continually aware of the presence of an infallible judge\nin his soul, determining which of two possible courses of action was\nthe better and which was the worse, and as soon as he did not act\nrightly, he was at once aware of it': 54, 'So he lived, not knowing and not seeing any chance of knowing what he\nwas and what he was living for, and harassed at this lack of knowledge\nto such a point that he was afraid of suicide, and yet firmly laying\ndown his own individual definite path in life': 50, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 11 PART EIGHT', {"The day on which Sergey Ivanovitch came to Pokrovskoe was one of\nLevin's most painful days": 16, 'It was the very busiest working time, when\nall the peasantry show an extraordinary intensity of self-sacrifice in\nlabor, such as is never shown in any other conditions of life, and\nwould be highly esteemed if the men who showed these qualities\nthemselves thought highly of them, and if it were not repeated every\nyear, and if the results of this intense labor were not so simple': 67, 'To reap and bind the rye and oats and to carry it, to mow the meadows,\nturn over the fallows, thrash the seed and sow the winter corn—all this\nseems so simple and ordinary; but to succeed in getting through it all\neveryone in the village, from the old man to the young child, must toil\nincessantly for three or four weeks, three times as hard as usual,\nliving on rye-beer, onions, and black bread, thrashing and carrying the\nsheaves at night, and not giving more than two or three hours in the\ntwenty-four to sleep': 96, 'And every year this is done all over Russia': 9, 'Having lived the greater part of his life in the country and in the\nclosest relations with the peasants, Levin always felt in this busy\ntime that he was infected by this general quickening of energy in the\npeople': 39, 'In the early morning he rode over to the first sowing of the rye, and\nto the oats, which were being carried to the stacks, and returning home\nat the time his wife and sister-in-law were getting up, he drank coffee\nwith them and walked to the farm, where a new thrashing machine was to\nbe set working to get ready the seed-corn': 63, 'He was standing in the cool granary, still fragrant with the leaves of\nthe hazel branches interlaced on the freshly peeled aspen beams of the\nnew thatch roof': 28, 'He gazed through the open door in which the dry bitter\ndust of the thrashing whirled and played, at the grass of the thrashing\nfloor in the sunlight and the fresh straw that had been brought in from\nthe barn, then at the speckly-headed, white-breasted swallows that flew\nchirping in under the roof and, fluttering their wings, settled in the\ncrevices of the doorway, then at the peasants bustling in the dark,\ndusty barn, and he thought strange thoughts': 79, '"Why is it all being done': 6, '" he thought': 3, '"Why am I standing here, making\nthem work': 8, 'What are they all so busy for, trying to show their zeal\nbefore me': 14, 'What is that old Matrona, my old friend, toiling for': 10, '(I\ndoctored her, when the beam fell on her in the fire)" he thought,\nlooking at a thin old woman who was raking up the grain, moving\npainfully with her bare, sun-blackened feet over the uneven, rough\nfloor': 38, '"Then she recovered, but today or tomorrow or in ten years she\nwon\'t; they\'ll bury her, and nothing will be left either of her or of\nthat smart girl in the red jacket, who with that skillful, soft action\nshakes the ears out of their husks': 46, 'They\'ll bury her and this piebald\nhorse, and very soon too," he thought, gazing at the heavily moving,\npanting horse that kept walking up the wheel that turned under him': 30, '"And they will bury her and Fyodor the thrasher with his curly beard\nfull of chaff and his shirt torn on his white shoulders—they will bury\nhim': 27, "He's untying the sheaves, and giving orders, and shouting to the\nwomen, and quickly setting straight the strap on the moving wheel": 22, "And\nwhat's more, it's not them alone—me they'll bury too, and nothing will\nbe left": 15, 'What for': 2, '"\n\nHe thought this, and at the same time looked at his watch to reckon how\nmuch they thrashed in an hour': 22, 'He wanted to know this so as to judge by\nit the task to set for the day': 18, '"It\'ll soon be one, and they\'re only beginning the third sheaf,"\nthought Levin': 13, 'He went up to the man that was feeding the machine, and\nshouting over the roar of the machine he told him to put it in more\nslowly': 28, '"You put in too much at a time, Fyodor': 9, "Do you see—it gets\nchoked, that's why it isn't getting on": 11, 'Do it evenly': 3, '"\n\nFyodor, black with the dust that clung to his moist face, shouted\nsomething in response, but still went on doing it as Levin did not want\nhim to': 29, 'Levin, going up to the machine, moved Fyodor aside, and began feeding\nthe corn in himself': 16, "Working on till the peasants' dinner hour, which\nwas not long in coming, he went out of the barn with Fyodor and fell\ninto talk with him, stopping beside a neat yellow sheaf of rye laid on\nthe thrashing floor for seed": 42, 'Fyodor came from a village at some distance from the one in which Levin\nhad once allotted land to his cooperative association': 22, 'Now it had been\nlet to a former house porter': 10, 'Levin talked to Fyodor about this land and asked whether Platon, a\nwell-to-do peasant of good character belonging to the same village,\nwould not take the land for the coming year': 31, '"It\'s a high rent; it wouldn\'t pay Platon, Konstantin Dmitrievitch,"\nanswered the peasant, picking the ears off his sweat-drenched shirt': 20, '"But how does Kirillov make it pay': 7, '"\n\n"Mituh': 2, '" (so the peasant called the house porter, in a tone of\ncontempt), "you may be sure he\'ll make it pay, Konstantin Dmitrievitch': 23, "He'll get his share, however he has to squeeze to get it": 12, "He's no mercy\non a Christian": 6, 'But Uncle Fokanitch" (so he called the old peasant\nPlaton), "do you suppose he\'d flay the skin off a man': 20, "Where there's\ndebt, he'll let anyone off": 7, "And he'll not wring the last penny out": 8, "He's a man too": 4, '"\n\n"But why will he let anyone off': 8, '"\n\n"Oh, well, of course, folks are different': 8, 'One man lives for his own\nwants and nothing else, like Mituh, he only thinks of filling his\nbelly, but Fokanitch is a righteous man': 25, 'He lives for his soul': 5, 'He does\nnot forget God': 5, '"\n\n"How thinks of God': 5, 'How does he live for his soul': 7, '" Levin almost\nshouted': 4, '"Why, to be sure, in truth, in God\'s way': 9, 'Folks are different': 3, "Take you\nnow, you wouldn't wrong a man": 8, '"\n\n"Yes, yes, good-bye': 4, '" said Levin, breathless with excitement, and\nturning round he took his stick and walked quickly away towards home': 19, "At the peasant's words that Fokanitch lived for his soul, in truth, in\nGod's way, undefined but significant ideas seemed to burst out as\nthough they had been locked up, and all striving towards one goal, they\nthronged whirling through his head, blinding him with their light": 47, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 12 PART EIGHT', {'Levin strode along the highroad, absorbed not so much in his thoughts\n(he could not yet disentangle them) as in his spiritual condition,\nunlike anything he had experienced before': 29, 'The words uttered by the peasant had acted on his soul like an electric\nshock, suddenly transforming and combining into a single whole the\nwhole swarm of disjointed, impotent, separate thoughts that incessantly\noccupied his mind': 36, 'These thoughts had unconsciously been in his mind\neven when he was talking about the land': 16, 'He was aware of something new in his soul, and joyfully tested this new\nthing, not yet knowing what it was': 21, '"Not living for his own wants, but for God': 9, 'For what God': 3, 'And could one\nsay anything more senseless than what he said': 11, "He said that one must\nnot live for one's own wants, that is, that one must not live for what\nwe understand, what we are attracted by, what we desire, but must live\nfor something incomprehensible, for God, whom no one can understand nor\neven define": 46, 'What of it': 3, "Didn't I understand those senseless words of\nFyodor's": 8, 'And understanding them, did I doubt of their truth': 9, 'Did I\nthink them stupid, obscure, inexact': 7, 'No, I understood him, and exactly\nas he understands the words': 11, 'I understood them more fully and clearly\nthan I understand anything in life, and never in my life have I doubted\nnor can I doubt about it': 27, 'And not only I, but everyone, the whole world\nunderstands nothing fully but this, and about this only they have no\ndoubt and are always agreed': 26, '"And I looked out for miracles, complained that I did not see a miracle\nwhich would convince me': 18, 'A material miracle would have persuaded me': 7, 'And here is a miracle, the sole miracle possible, continually existing,\nsurrounding me on all sides, and I never noticed it': 21, '"Fyodor says that Kirillov lives for his belly': 8, "That's comprehensible\nand rational": 4, "All of us as rational beings can't do anything else but\nlive for our belly": 15, "And all of a sudden the same Fyodor says that one\nmustn't live for one's belly, but must live for truth, for God, and at\na hint I understand him": 30, 'And I and millions of men, men who lived ages\nago and men living now—peasants, the poor in spirit and the learned,\nwho have thought and written about it, in their obscure words saying\nthe same thing—we are all agreed about this one thing: what we must\nlive for and what is good': 53, 'I and all men have only one firm,\nincontestable, clear knowledge, and that knowledge cannot be explained\nby the reason—it is outside it, and has no causes and can have no\neffects': 32, '"If goodness has causes, it is not goodness; if it has effects, a\nreward, it is not goodness either': 19, 'So goodness is outside the chain of\ncause and effect': 10, '"And yet I know it, and we all know it': 10, '"What could be a greater miracle than that': 8, '"Can I have found the solution of it all': 9, 'can my sufferings be over': 5, '"\nthought Levin, striding along the dusty road, not noticing the heat nor\nhis weariness, and experiencing a sense of relief from prolonged\nsuffering': 24, 'This feeling was so delicious that it seemed to him\nincredible': 11, 'He was breathless with emotion and incapable of going\nfarther; he turned off the road into the forest and lay down in the\nshade of an aspen on the uncut grass': 31, 'He took his hat off his hot head\nand lay propped on his elbow in the lush, feathery, woodland grass': 20, '"Yes, I must make it clear to myself and understand," he thought,\nlooking intently at the untrampled grass before him, and following the\nmovements of a green beetle, advancing along a blade of couch-grass and\nlifting up in its progress a leaf of goat-weed': 44, '"What have I\ndiscovered': 4, '" he asked himself, bending aside the leaf of goat-weed out\nof the beetle\'s way and twisting another blade of grass above for the\nbeetle to cross over onto it': 30, '"What is it makes me glad': 6, 'What have I\ndiscovered': 4, '"I have discovered nothing': 4, 'I have only found out what I knew': 8, 'I\nunderstand the force that in the past gave me life, and now too gives\nme life': 17, 'I have been set free from falsity, I have found the Master': 12, '"Of old I used to say that in my body, that in the body of this grass\nand of this beetle (there, she didn\'t care for the grass, she\'s opened\nher wings and flown away), there was going on a transformation of\nmatter in accordance with physical, chemical, and physiological laws': 51, 'And in all of us, as well as in the aspens and the clouds and the misty\npatches, there was a process of evolution': 24, 'Evolution from what': 3, 'into\nwhat': 2, '—Eternal evolution and struggle': 4, 'As though there could be any\nsort of tendency and struggle in the eternal': 14, 'And I was astonished that\nin spite of the utmost effort of thought along that road I could not\ndiscover the meaning of life, the meaning of my impulses and yearnings': 31, 'Now I say that I know the meaning of my life: ‘To live for God, for my\nsoul': 18, "' And this meaning, in spite of its clearness, is mysterious and\nmarvelous": 13, 'Such, indeed, is the meaning of everything existing': 8, 'Yes,\npride," he said to himself, turning over on his stomach and beginning\nto tie a noose of blades of grass, trying not to break them': 26, '"And not merely pride of intellect, but dulness of intellect': 10, 'And most\nof all, the deceitfulness; yes, the deceitfulness of intellect': 11, 'The\ncheating knavishness of intellect, that\'s it," he said to himself': 11, 'And he briefly went through, mentally, the whole course of his ideas\nduring the last two years, the beginning of which was the clear\nconfronting of death at the sight of his dear brother hopelessly ill': 36, 'Then, for the first time, grasping that for every man, and himself too,\nthere was nothing in store but suffering, death, and forgetfulness, he\nhad made up his mind that life was impossible like that, and that he\nmust either interpret life so that it would not present itself to him\nas the evil jest of some devil, or shoot himself': 61, 'But he had not done either, but had gone on living, thinking, and\nfeeling, and had even at that very time married, and had had many joys\nand had been happy, when he was not thinking of the meaning of his\nlife': 42, 'What did this mean': 4, 'It meant that he had been living rightly, but\nthinking wrongly': 11, "He had lived (without being aware of it) on those spiritual truths that\nhe had sucked in with his mother's milk, but he had thought, not merely\nwithout recognition of these truths, but studiously ignoring them": 36, 'Now it was clear to him that he could only live by virtue of the\nbeliefs in which he had been brought up': 23, '"What should I have been, and how should I have spent my life, if I had\nnot had these beliefs, if I had not known that I must live for God and\nnot for my own desires': 37, 'I should have robbed and lied and killed': 8, 'Nothing of what makes the chief happiness of my life would have existed\nfor me': 15, '" And with the utmost stretch of imagination he could not\nconceive the brutal creature he would have been himself, if he had not\nknown what he was living for': 30, '"I looked for an answer to my question': 8, 'And thought could not give an\nanswer to my question—it is incommensurable with my question': 15, 'The\nanswer has been given me by life itself, in my knowledge of what is\nright and what is wrong': 20, 'And that knowledge I did not arrive at in any\nway, it was given to me as to all men, _given_, because I could not\nhave got it from anywhere': 30, '"Where could I have got it': 6, 'By reason could I have arrived at knowing\nthat I must love my neighbor and not oppress him': 18, 'I was told that in my\nchildhood, and I believed it gladly, for they told me what was already\nin my soul': 22, 'But who discovered it': 4, 'Not reason': 2, 'Reason discovered the\nstruggle for existence, and the law that requires us to oppress all who\nhinder the satisfaction of our desires': 22, 'That is the deduction of\nreason': 6, "But loving one's neighbor reason could never discover, because\nit's irrational": 11, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 13 PART EIGHT', {'And Levin remembered a scene he had lately witnessed between Dolly and\nher children': 14, "The children, left to themselves, had begun cooking\nraspberries over the candles and squirting milk into each other's\nmouths with a syringe": 22, "Their mother, catching them at these pranks,\nbegan reminding them in Levin's presence of the trouble their mischief\ngave to the grown-up people, and that this trouble was all for their\nsake, and that if they smashed the cups they would have nothing to\ndrink their tea out of, and that if they wasted the milk, they would\nhave nothing to eat, and die of hunger": 66, 'And Levin had been struck by the passive, weary incredulity with which\nthe children heard what their mother said to them': 21, 'They were simply\nannoyed that their amusing play had been interrupted, and did not\nbelieve a word of what their mother was saying': 23, 'They could not believe\nit indeed, for they could not take in the immensity of all they\nhabitually enjoyed, and so could not conceive that what they were\ndestroying was the very thing they lived by': 36, '"That all comes of itself," they thought, "and there\'s nothing\ninteresting or important about it because it has always been so, and\nalways will be so': 26, "And it's all always the same": 6, "We've no need to think\nabout that, it's all ready": 10, 'But we want to invent something of our own,\nand new': 11, "So we thought of putting raspberries in a cup, and cooking\nthem over a candle, and squirting milk straight into each other's\nmouths": 23, "That's fun, and something new, and not a bit worse than\ndrinking out of cups": 15, '"\n\n"Isn\'t it just the same that we do, that I did, searching by the aid of\nreason for the significance of the forces of nature and the meaning of\nthe life of man': 34, '" he thought': 3, '"And don\'t all the theories of philosophy do the same, trying by the\npath of thought, which is strange and not natural to man, to bring him\nto a knowledge of what he has known long ago, and knows so certainly\nthat he could not live at all without it': 50, "Isn't it distinctly to be\nseen in the development of each philosopher's theory, that he knows\nwhat is the chief significance of life beforehand, just as positively\nas the peasant Fyodor, and not a bit more clearly than he, and is\nsimply trying by a dubious intellectual path to come back to what\neveryone knows": 55, '"Now then, leave the children to themselves to get things alone and\nmake their crockery, get the milk from the cows, and so on': 24, 'Would they\nbe naughty then': 5, "Why, they'd die of hunger": 5, 'Well, then, leave us with\nour passions and thoughts, without any idea of the one God, of the\nCreator, or without any idea of what is right, without any idea of\nmoral evil': 33, '"Just try and build up anything without those ideas': 9, '"We only try to destroy them, because we\'re spiritually provided for': 11, 'Exactly like the children': 4, '"Whence have I that joyful knowledge, shared with the peasant, that\nalone gives peace to my soul': 17, 'Whence did I get it': 5, '"Brought up with an idea of God, a Christian, my whole life filled with\nthe spiritual blessings Christianity has given me, full of them, and\nliving on those blessings, like the children I did not understand them,\nand destroy, that is try to destroy, what I live by': 48, 'And as soon as an\nimportant moment of life comes, like the children when they are cold\nand hungry, I turn to Him, and even less than the children when their\nmother me,\nrevealed to me, and I know it with my heart, by faith in the chief\nthing taught by the church': 36, '"The church': 2, 'the church': 2, '" Levin repeated to himself': 5, 'He turned over on\nthe other side, and leaning on his elbow, fell to gazing into the\ndistance at a herd of cattle crossing over to the river': 28, '"But can I believe in all the church teaches': 9, '" he thought, trying\nhimself, and thinking of everything that could destroy his present\npeace of mind': 17, 'Intentionally he recalled all those doctrines of the\nchurch which had always seemed most strange and had always been a\nstumbling block to him': 24, '"The Creation': 2, 'But how did I explain existence': 6, 'By existence': 2, 'By\nnothing': 2, 'The devil and sin': 4, 'But how do I explain evil': 6, 'The\natonement': 2, '"But I know nothing, nothing, and I can know nothing but what has been\ntold to me and all men': 20, '"\n\nAnd it seemed to him that there was not a single article of faith of\nthe church which could destroy the chief thing—faith in God, in\ngoodness, as the one goal of man\'s destiny': 35, "Under every article of faith of the church could be put the faith in\nthe service of truth instead of one's desires": 22, 'And each doctrine did\nnot simply leave that faith unshaken, each doctrine seemed essential to\ncomplete that great miracle, continually manifest upon earth, that made\nit possible for each man and millions of different sorts of men, wise\nmen and imbeciles, old men and children—all men, peasants, Lvov, Kitty,\nbeggars and kings to understand perfectly the same one thing, and to\nbuild up thereby that life of the soul which alone is worth living, and\nwhich alone is precious to us': 81, 'Lying on his back, he gazed up now into the high, cloudless sky': 13, '"Do I\nnot know that that is infinite space, and that it is not a round arch': 17, 'But, however I screw up my eyes and strain my sight, I cannot see it\nnot round and not bounded, and in spite of my knowing about infinite\nspace, I am incontestably right when I see a solid blue dome, and more\nright than when I strain my eyes to see beyond it': 53, '"\n\nLevin ceased thinking, and only, as it were, listened to mysterious\nvoices that seemed talking joyfully and earnestly within him': 21, '"Can this be faith': 4, '" he thought, afraid to believe in his happiness': 9, '"My God, I thank Thee': 5, '" he said, gulping down his sobs, and with both\nhands brushing away the tears that filled his eyes': 19, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 14 PART EIGHT', {'Levin looked before him and saw a herd of cattle, then he caught sight\nof his trap with Raven in the shafts, and the coachman, who, driving up\nto the herd, said something to the herdsman': 36, 'Then he heard the rattle\nof the wheels and the snort of the sleek horse close by him': 18, 'But he was\nso buried in his thoughts that he did not even wonder why the flecked with lather between his haunches and\non his neck, where the harness rubbed, stared at Ivan the coachman\nsitting beside him, and remembered that he was expecting his brother,\nthought that '"\n\nPulling the stiff rein and holding in the good horse that snorted with\nimpatience and seemed begging to be let go, Levin looked round at Ivan\nsitting beside him, not knowing what to do with "Going along the narrow path to a little uncut meadow covered on one\nside with thick clumps of brilliant heart's-ease among which stood up\nhere and there tall, dark green tufts of hellebore, Levin settled his\nguests in the dense, cool shade of the young aspens on a bench and some\nstumps purposely put there for visitors to the bee-house who might be\nafraid of the bees, and he went off himself to the hut to get bread,\ncucumbers, and fresh honey, to regale them with": 86, 'Trying to make his movements as deliberate as possible, and listening\nto the bees that buzzed more and more frequently past him, he walked\nalong the little path to the hut': 31, 'In the very entry one bee hummed\nangrily, caught in his beard, but he carefully extricated it': 17, 'Going\ninto the shady outer room, he took down from the wall his veil, that\nhung on a peg, and putting it on, and thrusting his hands into his\npockets, he went into the fenced-in bee-garden, where there stood in\nthe midst of a closely mown space in regular rows, fastened with bast\non posts, all the hives he knew so well, the old stocks, each with its\nown history, and along the fences the younger swarms hived that year': 80, 'In front of the openings of the hives, it made his eyes giddy to watch\nthe bees and drones whirling round and round about the same spot, while\namong them the working bees flew in and out with spoils or in search of\nthem, always in the same direction into the wood to the flowering lime\ntrees and back to the hives': 62, 'His ears were filled with the incessant hum in various notes, now the\nbusy hum of the working bee flying quickly off, then the blaring of the\nlazy drone, and the excited buzz of the bees on guard protecting their\nproperty from the enemy and preparing to sting': 48, 'On the farther side of\nthe fence the old bee-keeper was shaving a hoop for a tub, and he did\nnot see Levin': 23, 'Levin stood still in the midst of the beehives and did\nnot call him': 14, 'He was glad of a chance to be alone to recover from the influence of\nordinary actual life, which had already depressed his happy mood': 25, 'He\nthought that he had already had time to lose his temper with Ivan, to\nshow coolness to his brother, and to talk flippantly with Katavasov': 26, '"Can it have been only a momentary mood, and will it pass and leave no\ntrace': 16, '" he thought': 3, 'But the same instant, going back to his mood, he\nfelt with delight that something new and important had happened to him': 22, 'Real life had only for a time overcast the spiritual peace he had\nfound, but it was still untouched within him': 21, 'Just as the bees, whirling round him, now menacing him and distracting\nhis attention, prevented him from enjoying complete physical peace,\nforced him to restrain his movements to avoid them, so had the petty\ncares that had swarmed about him from the moment he got into the trap\nrestricted his spiritual freedom; but that lasted only so long as he\nwas among them': 63, 'Just as his bodily strength was still unaffected, in\nspite of the bees, so too was the spiritual strength that he had just\nbecome aware of': 26, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 15 PART EIGHT', {'"Do you know, Kostya, with whom Sergey Ivanovitch traveled on his way\nhere': 13, '" said Dolly, doling out cucumbers and honey to the children;\n"with Vronsky': 13, "He's going to Servia": 4, '"\n\n"And not alone; he\'s taking a squadron out with him at his own\nexpense," said Katavasov': 17, '"That\'s the right thing for him," said Levin': 8, '"Are volunteers still\ngoing out then': 6, '" he added, glancing at Sergey Ivanovitch': 7, 'Sergey Ivanovitch did not answer': 5, 'He was carefully with a blunt knife\ngetting a live bee covered with sticky honey out of a cup full of white\nhoneycomb': 23, '"I should think so': 4, 'You should have seen what was going on at the\nstation yesterday': 12, '" said Katavasov, biting with a juicy sound into a\ncucumber': 11, '"Well, what is one to make of it': 8, "For mercy's sake, do explain to me,\nSergey Ivanovitch, where are all those volunteers going, whom are they\nfighting with": 20, '" asked the old prince, unmistakably taking up a\nconversation that had sprung up in Levin\'s absence': 17, '"With the Turks," Sergey Ivanovitch answered, smiling serenely, as he\nextricated the bee, dark with honey and helplessly kicking, and put it\nwith the knife on a stout aspen leaf': 30, '"But who has declared war on the Turks': 8, '—Ivan Ivanovitch Ragozov and\nCountess Lidia Ivanovna, assisted by Madame Stahl': 11, '"\n\n"No one has declared war, but people sympathize with their neighbors\'\nsufferings and are eager to help them," said Sergey Ivanovitch': 22, '"But the prince is not speaking of help," said Levin, coming to the\nassistance of his father-in-law, "but of war': 20, 'The prince says that\nprivate persons cannot take part in war without the permission of the\ngovernment': 17, '"\n\n"Kostya, mind, that\'s a bee': 6, "Really, they'll sting us": 4, '" said Dolly,\nwaving away a wasp': 7, '"But that\'s not a bee, it\'s a wasp," said Levin': 10, '"Well now, well, what\'s your own theory': 7, '" Katavasov said to Levin with\na smile, distinctly challenging him to a discussion': 14, '"Why have not\nprivate persons the right to do so': 10, '"\n\n"Oh, my theory\'s this: war is on one side such a beastly, cruel, and\nawful thing, that no one man, not to speak of a Christian, can\nindividually take upon himself the responsibility of beginning wars;\nthat can only be done by a government, which is called upon to do this,\nand is driven inevitably into war': 58, 'On the other hand, both political\nscience and common sense teach us that in matters of state, and\nespecially in the matter of war, private citizens must forego their\npersonal individual will': 32, '"\n\nSergey Ivanovitch and Katavasov had their replies ready, and both began\nspeaking at the same time': 17, '"But the point is, my dear fellow, that there may be cases when the\ngovernment does not carry out the will of the citizens and then the\npublic asserts its will," said Katavasov': 33, 'But evidently Sergey Ivanovitch did not approve of this answer': 10, "His\nbrows contracted at Katavasov's words and he said something else": 11, '"You don\'t put the matter in its true light': 9, 'There is no question here\nof a declaration of war, but simply the expression of a human Christian\nfeeling': 19, 'Our brothers, one with us in religion and in race, are being\nmassacred': 13, 'Even supposing they were not our brothers nor\nfellow-Christians, but simply children, women, old people, feeling is\naroused and Russians go eagerly to help in stopping these atrocities': 28, 'Fancy, if you were going along the street and saw drunken men beating a\nwoman or a child—I imagine you would not stop to inquire whether war\nhad been declared on the men, but would throw yourself on them, and\nprotect the victim': 43, '"\n\n"But I should not kill them," said Levin': 9, '"Yes, you would kill them': 5, '"\n\n"I don\'t know': 4, "If I saw that, I might give way to my impulse of the\nmoment, but I myself, and I don't feel it": 11, '"\n\n"Here am I too," said the old prince': 9, '"I\'ve been staying abroad and\nreading the papers, and I must own, up to the time of the Bulgarian\natrocities, I more': 6, '" he\nsaid addressing Darya Alexandrovna and pointing to Grisha, who had\nfinished his crust': 15, '"I don\'t need to ask," said Sergey Ivanovitch, "we have seen and are\nseeing hundreds and hundreds of people who give up everything to serve\na just cause, come from every part of Russia, and directly and clearly\nexpress their thought and aim': 43, 'They bring their halfpence or go\nthemselves and say directly what for': 12, 'What does it mean': 4, '"\n\n"It means, to my thinking," said Levin, who was beginning to get warm,\n"that among eighty millions of people there can always be found not\nhundreds, as now, but tens of thousands of people who have lost caste,\nne\'er-do-wells, who are always ready to go anywhere—to Pogatchev\'s\nbands, to Khiva, to Servia': 53, '"\n\n"I tell you that it\'s not a case of hundreds or of ne\'er-do-wells, but\nthe best representatives of the people': 21, '" said Sergey Ivanovitch, with\nas much irritation as if he were defending the last penny of his\nfortune': 19, '"And what of the subscriptions': 5, 'In this case it is a whole\npeople directly expressing their will': 12, '"\n\n"That word ‘people\' is so vague," said Levin': 9, '"Parish clerks, teachers,\nand one in a thousand of the peasants, maybe, know what it\'s all about': 17, "The rest of the eighty millions, like Mihalitch, far from expressing\ntheir will, haven't the faintest idea what there is for them to express\ntheir will about": 27, "What right have we to say that this is the people's\nwill": 12, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 16 PART EIGHT', {'Sergey Ivanovitch, being practiced in argument, did not reply, but at\nonce turned the conversation to another aspect of the subject': 21, '"Oh, if you want to learn the spirit of the people by arithmetical\ncomputation, of course it\'s very difficult to arrive at it': 23, 'And voting\nhas not been introduced among us and cannot be introduced, for it does\nnot express the will of the people; but there are other ways of\nreaching that': 30, 'It is felt in the air, it is felt by the heart': 12, "I won't\nspeak of those deep currents which are astir in the still ocean of the\npeople, and which are evident to every unprejudiced man; let us look at\nsociety in the narrow sense": 34, 'All the most diverse sections of the\neducated public, hostile before, are merged in one': 15, 'Every division is\nat an end, all the public organs say the same thing over and over\nagain, all feel the mighty torrent that has overtaken them and is\ncarrying them in one direction': 34, '"\n\n"Yes, all the newspapers do say the same thing," said the prince': 13, '"That\'s true': 2, 'But so it is the same thing that all the frogs croak\nbefore a storm': 15, 'One can hear nothing for them': 6, '"\n\n"Frogs or no frogs, I\'m not the editor of a paper and I don\'t want to\ndefend them; but I am speaking of the unanimity in the intellectual\nworld," said Sergey Ivanovitch, addressing his brother': 36, 'Levin would\nhave answered, but the old prince interrupted him': 10, '"Well, about that unanimity, that\'s another thing, one may say," said\nthe prince': 13, '"There\'s my son-in-law, Stepan Arkadyevitch, you know him': 8, "He's got a place now on the committee of a commission and something or\nother, I don't remember": 18, "Only there's nothing to do in it—why, Dolly,\nit's no secret": 11, '—and a salary of eight thousand': 6, "You try asking him\nwhether his post is of use, he'll prove to you that it's most\nnecessary": 18, "And he's a truthful man too, but there's no refusing to\nbelieve in the utility of eight thousand roubles": 19, '"\n\n"Yes, he asked me to give a message to Darya Alexandrovna about the\npost," said Sergey Ivanovitch reluctantly, feeling the prince\'s remark\nto be ill-timed': 26, '"So it is with the unanimity of the press': 9, "That's been explained to me:\nas soon as there's war their incomes are doubled": 14, 'How can they help\nbelieving in the destinies of the people and the Slavonic races': 15, 'and\nall that': 3, '"\n\n"I don\'t care for many of the papers, but that\'s unjust," said
