'Very good': 2, 'Let everyone who advocates war be\nenrolled in a special regiment of advance-guards, for the front of\nevery storm, of every attack, to lead them all': 26, '\'"\n\n"A nice lot the editors would make': 8, '" said Katavasov, with a loud roar,\nas he pictured the editors he knew in this picked legion': 18, '"But they\'d run," said Dolly, "they\'d only be in the way': 11, '"\n\n"Oh, if they ran away, then we\'d have grape-shot or Cossacks with whips\nbehind them," said the prince': 19, '"But that\'s a joke, and a poor one too, if you\'ll excuse my saying so,\nprince," said Sergey Ivanovitch': 19, '"I don\'t see that it was a joke, that': 9, '" Levin was beginning, but\nSergey Ivanovitch interrupted him': 9, '"Every member of society is called upon to do his own special work,"\nsaid he': 15, '"And men of thought are doing their work when they express\npublic opinion': 13, 'And the single-hearted and full expression of public\nopinion is the service of the press and a phenomenon to rejoice us at\nthe same time': 25, 'Twenty years ago we should have been silent, but now we\nhave heard the voice of the Russian people, which is ready to rise as\none man and ready to sacrifice itself for its oppressed brethren; that\nis a great step and a proof of strength': 46, '"\n\n"But it\'s not only making a sacrifice, but killing Turks," said Levin\ntimidly': 14, '"The people make sacrifices and are ready to make sacrifices\nfor their soul, but not for murder," he added, instinctively connecting\nthe conversation with the ideas that had been absorbing his mind': 32, '"For their soul': 3, "That's a most puzzling expression for a natural\nscience man, do you understand": 13, 'What sort of thing is the soul': 7, '" said\nKatavasov, smiling': 4, '"Oh, you know': 3, '"\n\n"No, by God, I haven\'t the faintest idea': 9, '" said Katavasov with a loud\nroar of laughter': 9, '"‘I bring not peace, but a sword,\' says Christ," Sergey Ivanovitch\nrejoined for his part, quoting as simply as though it were the easiest\nthing to understand the very passage that had always puzzled Levin\nmost': 36, '"That\'s so, no doubt," the old man repeated again': 9, 'He was standing near\nthem and responded to a chance glance turned in his direction': 15, '"Ah, my dear fellow, you\'re defeated, utterly defeated': 8, '" cried\nKatavasov good-humoredly': 4, 'Levin reddened with vexation, not at being defeated, but at having\nfailed to control himself and being drawn into argument': 20, '"No, I can\'t argue with them," he thought; "they wear impenetrable\narmor, while I\'m naked': 15, '"\n\nHe saw that it was impossible to convince his brother and Katavasov,\nand he saw even less possibility of himself agreeing with them': 24, 'What\nthey advocated was the very pride of intellect that had almost been his\nruin': 15, 'He could not admit that some dozens of men, among them his\nbrother, had the right, on the ground of what they were told by some\nhundreds of glib volunteers swarming to the capital, to say that they\nand the newspapers were expressing the will and feeling of the people,\nand a feeling which was expressed in vengeance and murder': 60, 'He could not\nadmit this, because he neither saw the expression of such feelings in\nthe people among whom he was living, nor found them in himself (and he\ncould not but consider himself one of the persons making up the Russian\npeople), and most of all because he, like the people, did not know and\ncould not know what is for the general good, though he knew beyond a\ndoubt that this general good could be attained only by the strict\nobservance of that law of right and wrong which has been revealed to\nevery man, and therefore he could not wish for war or advocate war for\nany general objects whatever': 113, 'He said as Mihalitch did and the people,\nwho had expressed their feeling in the traditional invitations of the\nVaryagi: "Be princes and rule over us': 26, 'Gladly we promise complete\nsubmission': 5, 'All the labor, all humiliations, all sacrifices we take\nupon ourselves; but we will not judge and decide': 18, '" And now, according\nto Sergey Ivanovitch\'s account, the people had foregone this privilege\nthey had bought at such a costly price': 22, 'He wanted to say too that if public opinion were an infallible guide,\nthen why were not revolutions and the commune as lawful as the movement\nin favor of the Slavonic peoples': 32, 'But these were merely thoughts that\ncould settle nothing': 9, 'One thing could be seen beyond doubt—that was\nthat at the actual moment the discussion was irritating Sergey\nIvanovitch, and so it was wrong to continue it': 27, 'And Levin ceased\nspeaking and then called the attention of his guests to the fact that\nthe storm clouds were gathering, and that they had better be going home\nbefore it rained': 32, '': 0})
('TOL CHAPTER 17 PART EIGHT', {'The old prince and Sergey Ivanovitch got into the trap and drove off;\nthe rest of the party hastened homewards on foot': 22, 'But the storm-clouds, turning white and then black, moved down so\nquickly that they had to quicken their pace to get home before the\nrain': 25, 'The foremost clouds, lowering and black as soot-laden smoke,\nrushed with extraordinary swiftness over the sky': 16, 'They were still two\nhundred paces from home and a gust of wind had already blown up, and\nevery second the downpour might be looked for': 26, 'The children ran ahead with frightened and gleeful shrieks': 9, 'Darya\nAlexandrovna, struggling painfully with her skirts that clung round her\nlegs, was not walking, but running, her eyes fixed on the children': 23, 'The\nmen of the party, holding their hats on, strode with long steps beside\nher': 15, 'They were just at the steps when a big drop fell splashing on the\nedge of the iron guttering': 19, 'The children and their elders after them\nran into the shelter of the house, talking merrily': 16, '"Katerina Alexandrovna': 2, '" Levin asked of Agafea Mihalovna, who met them\nwith kerchiefs and rugs in 11, 'In that brief interval of time the storm clouds had moved on, covering\nthe sun so completely that it was dark as an eclipse': 24, 'Stubbornly, as\nthough insisting on its rights, the wind stopped Levin, and tearing the\nleaves and flowers off the lime trees and stripping the white birch\nbranches into strange unseemly nakedness, it twisted everything on one\nside—acacias, flowers, burdocks, long grass, and tall tree-tops': 44, "The\npeasant girls working in the garden ran shrieking into shelter in the\nservants' quarters": 15, 'The streaming rain had already flung its white veil\nover all the distant forest and half the fields close by, and was\nrapidly swooping down upon the copse': 28, 'The wet of the rain spurting up\nin tiny drops could be smelt in the air': 16, 'Holding his head bent down before him, and struggling with the wind\nthat strove to tear the wraps away from him, Levin was moving up to the\ncopse and had just caught sight of something white behind the oak tree,\nwhen there was a sudden flash, the whole earth seemed on fire, and the\nvault of heaven seemed crashing overhead': 60, 'Opening his blinded eyes,\nLevin gazed through the thick veil of rain that separated him now from\nthe copse, and to his horror the first thing he saw was the green crest\nof the familiar oak-tree in the middle of the copse uncannily changing\nits position': 46, '"Can it have been struck': 5, '" Levin hardly had time to think\nwhen, moving more and more rapidly, the oak tree vanished behind the\nother trees, and he heard the crash of the great tree falling upon the\nothers': 34, 'The flash of lightning, the crash of thunder, and the instantaneous\nchill that ran through him were all merged for Levin in one sense of\nterror': 26, '"My God': 2, 'my God': 2, 'not on them': 3, '" he said': 3, 'And though he thought at once how senseless was his prayer that they\nshould not have been killed by the oak which had fallen now, he\nrepeated it, knowing that he could do nothing better than utter this\nsenseless prayer': 40, 'Running up to the place where they usually went, he did not find them\nthere': 15, 'They were at the other end of the copse under an old lime-tree; they\nwere calling him': 17, 'Two figures in dark dresses (they had been light\nsummer dresses when they started out) were standing bending over\nsomething': 20, 'It was Kitty with the nurse': 6, 'The rain was already ceasing,\nand it was beginning to get light when Levin reached them': 16, 'The nurse\nwas not wet on the lower part of her dress, but Kitty was drenched\nthrough, and her soaked clothes clung to her': 24, 'Though the rain was over,\nthey still stood in the same position in which they had been standing\nwhen the storm broke': 22, 'Both stood bending over a ('TOL CHAPTER 18 PART EIGHT', {'During the whole of that day, in the extremely different conversations\nin which he took part, only as it were with the top layer of his mind,\nin spite of the disappointment of not finding the change he expected in\nhimself, Levin had been all the while joyfully conscious of the fulness\nof his heart': 55, 'After the rain it was too wet to go for a walk; besides, the storm\nclouds still hung about the horizon, and gathered here and there, black\nand thundery, on the rim of the sky': 35, 'The whole party spent the rest of\nthe day in the house': 12, 'No more discussions sprang up; on the contrary, after dinner everyone\nwas in the most amiable frame of mind': 19, 'At first Katavasov amused the ladies by his original jokes, which\nalways pleased people on their first acquaintance with him': 20, 'Then Sergey\nIvanovitch induced him to tell them about the very interesting\nobservations he had made on the habits and characteristics of common\nhouseflies, and their life': 27, 'Sergey Ivanovitch, too, was in good\nspirits, and at tea his brother drew him on to explain his views of the\nfuture of the Eastern question, and he spoke so simply and so well,\nthat everyone listened eagerly': 38, 'Kitty was the only one who did not hear it all—she was summoned to give\nMitya his bath': 18, 'A few minutes after Kitty had left the room she sent for Levin to come\nto the nursery': 18, 'Leaving his tea, and regretfully interrupting the interesting\nconversation, and at the same time uneasily wondering why he had been\nsent for, as this only happened on important occasions, Levin went to\nthe nursery': 34, "Although he had been much interested by Sergey Ivanovitch's views of\nthe new epoch in history that would be created by the emancipation of\nforty millions of men of Slavonic race acting with Russia, a conception\nquite new to him, and although he was disturbed by uneasy wonder at\nbeing sent for by Kitty, as soon as he came out of the drawing-room and\nwas alone, his mind reverted at once to the thoughts of the morning": 77, 'And all the theories of the significance of the Slav element in the\nhistory of the world seemed to him so trivial compared with what was\npassing in his own soul, that he instantly forgot it all and dropped\nback into the same frame of mind that he had been in that morning': 53, 'He did not, as he had done at other times, recall the whole train of\nthought—that he did not need': 20, 'He fell back at once into the feeling\nwhich had guided him, which was connected with those thoughts, and he\nfound that feeling in his soul even stronger and more definite than\nbefore': 33, 'He did not, as he had had to do with previous attempts to find\ncomforting arguments, need to revive a whole chain of thought to find\nthe feeling': 28, 'Now, on the contrary, the feeling of joy and peace was\nkeener than ever, and thought could not keep pace with feeling': 22, 'He walked across the terrace and looked at two stars that had come out\nin the darkening sky, and suddenly he remembered': 22, '"Yes, looking at the\nsky, I thought that the dome that I see is not a deception, and then I\nthought something, I shirked facing something," he mused': 28, '"But whatever\nit was, there can be no disproving it': 10, 'I have but to think, and all\nwill come clear': 10, '"\n\nJust as he was going into the nursery he remembered what it was he had\nshirked facing': 18, 'It was that if the chief proof of the Divinity was His\nrevelation of what is right, how is it this revelation is confined to\nthe Christian church alone': 29, 'What relation to this revelation have the\nbeliefs of the Buddhists, Mohammedans, who preached and did good too': 18, 'It seemed to him that he had an answer to this question; but he had not\ntime to formulate it to himself before he went into the nursery': 28, 'Kitty was standing with her sleeves tucked up over the baby in the\nbath': 14, "Hearing her husband's footstep, she turned towards him, summoning\nhim to her with her smile": 15, 'With one hand she was supporting the fat\nbaby that lay floating and sprawling on its back, while with the other\nshe squeezed the sponge over him': 27, '"Come, look, look': 3, '" she said, when her husband came up to her': 10, '"Agafea\nMihalovna\'s right': 3, 'He knows us': 3, '"\n\nMitya had on that day given unmistakable, incontestable signs of\nrecognizing all his friends': 15, 'As soon as Levin approached the bath, the experiment was tried, and it\nwas completely successful': 16, 'The cook, sent for with this object, bent\nover the baby': 11, 'He frowned and shook his head disapprovingly': 7, 'Kitty bent\ndown to him, he gave her a beaming smile, propped his little hands on\nthe sponge and chirruped, making such a queer little contented sound\nwith his lips, that Kitty and the nurse were not alone in their\nadmiration': 41, 'Levin, too, was surprised and delighted': 6, 'The baby was taken out of the bath, drenched with water, wrapped in\ntowels, dried, and after a piercing scream, handed to his mother': 24, '"Well, I am glad you are beginning to love him," said Kitty to her\nhusband, when she had settled herself comfortably in her usual place,\nwith the baby at her breast': 31, '"I am so glad': 4, 'It had begun to distress\nme': 6, 'You said you had no feeling for him': 8, '"\n\n"No; did I say that': 6, 'I only said I was disappointed': 6, '"\n\n"What': 2, 'disappointed in him': 3, '"\n\n"Not disappointed in him, but in my own feeling; I had expected more': 14, 'I\nhad expected a rush of new delightful emotion to come as a surprise': 14, 'And then instead of that—disgust, pity': 6, '"\n\nShe listened attentively, looking at him over the baby, while she put\nback on her slender fingers the rings she had taken off while giving\nMitya his bath': 29, '"And most of all, at there being far more apprehension and pity than\npleasure': 14, 'Today, after that fright during the storm, I understand how I\nlove him': 13, '"\n\nKitty\'s smile was radiant': 5, '"Were you very much frightened': 5, '" she said': 3, '"So was I too, but I feel it\nmore now that it\'s over': 13, "I'm going to look at the oak": 7, 'How nice\nKatavasov is': 4, "And what a happy day we've had altogether": 8, "And you're so\nnice with Sergey Ivanovitch, when you care to be": 12, 'Well, go back to\nthem': 5, "It's always so hot and steamy here after the bath": 10, '"': 1})
('TOL CHAPTER 19 PART EIGHT', {'Going out of the nursery and being again alone, Levin went back at once\nto the thought, in which there was something not clear': 24, 'Instead of going into the drawing-room, where he heard voices, he\nstopped on the terrace, and leaning his elbows on the parapet, he gazed\nup at the sky': 28, 'It was quite dark now, and in the south, where he was looking, there\nwere no clouds': 17, 'The storm had drifted on to the opposite side of the\nsky, and there were flashes of lightning and distant thunder from that\nquarter': 24, 'Levin listened to the monotonous drip from the lime trees in\nthe garden, and looked at the triangle of stars he knew so well, and\nthe Milky Way with its branches that ran through its midst': 36, 'At each\nflash of lightning the Milky Way, and even the bright stars, vanished,\nbut as soon as the lightning died away, they reappeared in their places\nas though some hand had flung them back with careful aim': 38, '"Well, what is it perplexes me': 6, '" Levin said to himself, feeling\nbeforehand that the solution of his difficulties was ready in his soul,\nthough he did not know it yet': 25, '"Yes, the one unmistakable,\nincontestable manifestation of the Divinity is the law of right and\nwrong, which has come into the world by revelation, and which I feel in\nmyself, and in the recognition of which—I don\'t make myself, but\nwhether I will or not—I am made one with other men in one body of\nbelievers, which is called the church': 61, 'Well, but the Jews, the\nMohammedans, the Confucians, the Buddhists—what of them': 12, '" he put to\nhimself the question he had feared to face': 12, '"Can these hundreds of\nmillions of men be deprived of that highest blessing without which life\nhas no meaning': 19, '" He pondered a moment, but immediately corrected\nhimself': 9, '"But what am I questioning': 5, '" he said to himself': 5, '"I am\nquestioning the relation to Divinity of all the different religions of\nall mankind': 15, 'I am questioning the universal manifestation of God to all\nthe world with all those misty blurs': 17, 'What am I about': 4, 'To me\nindividually, to my heart has been revealed a knowledge beyond all\ndoubt, and unattainable by reason, and here I am obstinately trying to\nexpress that knowledge in reason and words': 32, '"Don\'t I know that the stars don\'t move': 8, '" he asked himself, gazing at\nthe bright planet which had shifted its position up to the topmost twig\nof the birch-tree': 22, '"But looking at the movements of the stars, I can\'t\npicture to myself the rotation of the earth, and I\'m right in saying\nthat the stars move': 27, '"And could the astronomers have understood and calculated anything, if\nthey had taken into account all the complicated and varied motions of\nthe earth': 24, 'All the marvelous conclusions they have reached about the\ndistances, weights, movements, and deflections of the heavenly bodies\nare only founded on the apparent motions of the heavenly bodies about a\nstationary earth, on that very motion I see before me now, which has\nbeen so for millions of men during long ages, and was and will be\nalways alike, and can always be trusted': 65, 'And just as the conclusions of\nthe astronomers would have been vain and uncertain if not founded on\nobservations of the seen heavens, in relation to a single meridian and\na single horizon, so would my conclusions be vain and uncertain if not\nfounded on that conception of right, which has been and will be always\nalike for all men, which has been revealed to me as a Christian, and\nwhich can always be trusted in my soul': 78, 'The question of other religions\nand their relations to Divinity I have no right to decide, and no\npossibility of deciding': 21, '"\n\n"Oh, you haven\'t gone in then': 7, '" he heard Kitty\'s voice all at once, as\nshe came by the same way to the drawing-room': 18, '"What is it': 3, "you're not worried about anything": 5, '" she said, looking\nintently at his face in the starlight': 11, 'But she could not have seen his face if a flash of lightning had not\nhidden the stars and revealed it': 21, 'In that flash she saw his face\ndistinctly, and seeing him calm and happy, she smiled at him': 18, '"She understands," he thought; "she knows what I\'m thinking about': 10, 'Shall I tell her or not': 6, "Yes, I'll tell her": 4, '" But at the moment he was\nabout to speak, she began speaking': 13, '"Kostya': 1, 'do something for me," she said; "go into the corner room and\nsee if they\'ve made it all right for Sergey Ivanovitch': 22, "I can't very\nwell": 4, "See if they've put the new wash stand in it": 10, '"\n\n"Very well, I\'ll go directly," said Levin, standing up and kissing her': 13, '"No, I\'d better not speak of it," he thought, when she had gone in\nbefore him': 16, '"It is a secret for me alone, of vital importance for me,\nand not to be put into words': 19, '"This new feeling has not changed me, has not made me happy and\nenlightened all of a sudden, as I had dreamed, just like the feeling\nfor my child': 29, 'There was no surprise in this either': 7, "Faith—or not\nfaith—I don't know what it is—but this feeling has come just as\nimperceptibly through suffering, and has taken firm root in my soul": 25, '"I shall go on in the same way, losing my temper with Ivan the\ncoachman, falling into angry discussions, expressing my opinions\ntactlessly; there will be still the same wall between the holy of\nholies of my soul and other people, even my wife; I shall still go on\nscolding her for my own terror, and being remorseful for it; I shall\nstill be as unable to understand with my reason why I pray, and I shall\nstill go on praying; but my life now, my whole life apart from anything\nthat can happen to me, every minute of it is no more meaningless, as it\nwas before, but it has the positive meaning of goodness, which I have\nthe power to put into it': 125, '"': 1, '': 0})
